original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One

original: Jātaka-aṭṭhakathā
analyzed: jātaka aṭṭhakathā
translated: Jātaka Commentary

original: (Dutiyo bhāgo)
analyzed: dutiyaḥ bhāgaḥ
translated: (Second Part)

original: 2. Dukanipāto
analyzed: du ka nipātaḥ
translated: The Group of Twos

original: 1. Daḷhavaggo
analyzed: daḷha vaggaḥ
translated: The Chapter on Firm

original: [151] 1. Rājovādajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rājovādajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Counsel of the King

original: Daḷhaṃ daḷhassa khipatīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto rājovādaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: daḷham daḷhassa khipati iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ rāja uvādam ārabbha kathesi
translated: He hurls the firm against the firm: the Master told this story while dwelling at Jetavana, about a counsel of the king.

original: So tesakuṇajātake āvi bhavissati. Ekasmiṃ pana divase kosalarājā ekaṃ agatigataṃ🔽dubbinicchayaṃ aḍḍaṃ vinicchinitvā bhuttapātarāso allahatthova alaṅkatarathaṃ abhiruyha
analyzed: saḥ tesakuṇa jātake bhavissati ekasmin pana divase kosala rājā ekam agati gatam  dubbinicchayam aḍḍam vinicchinitvā bhutta pāta rāsaḥ allahatthā uva alaṅkata ratham abhiruyha
translated: This will be told in the Story of the Birds. But one day the King of Kosala, having decided a case that was difficult to decide and that involved a large sum of money,🔽after breakfast, with his hands still wet, mounted his decorated chariot and

original: satthu santikaṃ gantvā phullapadumasassirikesu pādesu nipatitvā satthāraṃ vanditvā
analyzed: satthu santikam gantvā phulla paduma sassirikesu pādesu nipatitvā satthāram vanditvā
translated: went to the Teacher. He fell at the Teacher’s feet, which were adorned with the signs of the wheels with the thousand spokes, and worshipped him.

original: ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Atha naṃ satthā etadavoca – “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, āgacchasi
analyzed: ekamantam nisīdi atha nam satthā etat avoca handa kutas nu tvam mahā rāja āgacchasi
translated: Then he sat down at one side. The Teacher said to him, “Well, great king, where are you coming from

original: divā divassā”ti. “Bhante, ajja ekaṃ agatigataṃ dubbinicchayaṃ aḍḍaṃ vinicchinanto
analyzed: divā divassa ati bhante ajja ekam agati gatam dubbinicchayam aḍḍam vinicchinantaḥ
translated: at this time of day?” “Reverend Sir, to-day I decided a case that was difficult to decide and that involved a large sum of money.

original: okāsaṃ alabhitvā idāni taṃ tīretvā bhuñjitvā allahatthova tumhākaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ āgatomhī”ti.
analyzed: okāsam a labhitvā idāni tam tīretvā bhuñjitvā allahatthā uva tumhākam upaṭṭhānam āgataḥ asmi iti
translated: and not being able to get a chance, I have now crossed over, eaten, and come to wait upon you with my hands still wet.”

original: Satthā “mahārāja, dhammena samena aḍḍavinicchayaṃ nāma kusalaṃ, saggamaggo esa. Anacchariyaṃ
analyzed: satthā mahā rāja dhammena samena aḍḍavinicchayam nāma kusalam sagga maggaḥ esa
translated: The Teacher said, “Great king, it is good to decide a dispute according to justice and righteousness; this is the way to heaven.

original: kho panetaṃ, yaṃ tumhe mādisassa sabbaññubuddhassa santikā ovādaṃ labhamānā dhammena🔽samena aḍḍaṃ vinicchineyyātha. Etadeva acchariyaṃ, yaṃ pubbe rājāno asabbaññūnampi
analyzed: kho pana itam yam tumhe mādisassa sabbaññu buddhassa santikā ovādam labhamānāḥ dhammena  samena aḍḍam vinicchineyyātha etat eva acchariyam yam pubbe rājānaḥ a sabbaññūnam pi
translated: But it is not strange that you, having received instruction from a Buddha who is all-knowing, should decide a dispute according to justice and righteousness.

original: paṇḍitānaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā dhammena samena aḍḍaṃ vinicchinantā cattāri agatigamanāni
analyzed: paṇḍitānam vacanam sutvā dhammena samena aḍḍam vinicchinantā cattāri agati gamanāni
translated: It is strange that in the past kings, having heard the words of wise men who were not all-knowing, decided a dispute according to justice and righteousness,

original: vajjetvā dasa rājadhamme akopetvā dhammena rajjaṃ kāretvā saggapuraṃ pūrayamānā agamiṃsū”ti
analyzed: vajjetvā dasa rājadhamme a kopetvā dhammena rajjam kāretvā saggapuram pūrayamānāḥ agamiṃsu uti
translated: and having avoided the four wrong ways of deciding a dispute, and having kept the ten royal virtues unviolated, ruled their kingdoms righteously, and went to the city of heaven, filling it.”

original: vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: And being asked by the king to relate the story of the past, he related the following:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto tassa aggamahesiyā kucchismiṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto tassa aggamahesiyā kucchismiṃ
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was conceived in the womb of his chief consort.

original: paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā laddhagabbhaparihāro sotthinā mātukucchimhā nikkhami. Nāmaggahaṇadivase
analyzed: paṭisandhim gahetvā laddha gabbha parihāraḥ sotthinā mātu kucchimhā nikkhami nāma ggahaṇa divase
translated: On the day when the name-giving ceremony was held,

original: panassa “brahmadattakumāro”tveva nāmaṃ akaṃsu. So anupubbena vayappatto soḷasavassakāle
analyzed: panassa brahmadatta kumāraḥ tu eva nāmam akaṃsu so anupubbena vaya patto soḷasa vassa kāle
translated: they gave him the name Prince Brahmadatta. He gradually grew up and when he was sixteen years old

original: takkasilaṃ gantvā sabbasippesu nipphattiṃ patvā pitu accayena rajje patiṭṭhāya dhammena🔽samena rajjaṃ kāresi, chandādivasena agantvā vinicchayaṃ anusāsi. Tasmiṃ evaṃ dhammena
analyzed: takkasilam gantvā sabba sippesu nipphattim patvā pitu accayena rajje patiṭṭhāya dhammena  samena rajjam kāresi chanda ādi vasena a gantvā vinicchayam anusāsi tasmin evam dhammena
translated: he went to Takkasilā and mastered all the crafts. After his father’s death he was established in the kingship and ruled righteously,🔽not according to his own desires, but according to the law. While he was ruling righteously

original: rajjaṃ kārente amaccāpi dhammeneva vohāraṃ vinicchiniṃsu. Vohāresu dhammena vinicchayamānesu
analyzed: rajjam kārente amaccā api dhammena iva vohāram vinicchiniṃsu vohāresu dhammena vinicchayamānesu
translated: the ministers also conducted their business righteously. As the business was conducted righteously

original: kūṭaḍḍakārakā nāma nāhesuṃ, tesaṃ abhāvā aḍḍatthāya rājaṅgaṇe uparavo pacchijji.
analyzed: kūṭaḍḍakārakāḥ nāma na ahesum tesam abhāvā aḍḍatthāya rājaṅgaṇe uparavaḥ pacchijji
translated: there were no cheats and swindlers, and because of their absence the royal storehouse was filled for the sake of charity.

original: Amaccā divasampi vinicchayaṭṭhāne nisīditvā kañci vinicchayatthāya āgacchantaṃ adisvā
analyzed: amaccā divasampi vinicchaya ṭṭhāne nisīditvā kañci vinicchaya tthāya āgacchantam a disvā
translated: The ministers sat in the court of justice all day long, but they saw no one coming for the sake of justice.

original: uṭṭhāya pakkamanti, vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ chaḍḍetabbabhāvaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: uṭṭhāya pakkamanti vinicchaya ṭṭhānam chaḍḍetabba bhāvam pāpuṇi
translated: They got up and left, and the court of justice became deserted.

original: Bodhisatto cintesi – “mayi dhammena rajjaṃ kārente vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchantā nāma
analyzed: bodhisatto cintesi mayi dhammena rajjam kārente vinicchaya ṭṭhānam āgacchantā nāma
translated: The Bodhisatta thought to himself, “While I have ruled righteously, no one has come to the judgment-hall.

original: natthi, uparavo pacchijji, vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ chaḍḍetabbabhāvaṃ pattaṃ, idāni mayā
analyzed: natthi uparavaḥ pacchijji vinicchaya ṭṭhānam chaḍḍetabba bhāvam pattam idāni mayā
translated: The tumult has ceased, and the judgment-hall has become deserted. Now it is time for me

original: attano aguṇaṃ pariyesituṃ vaṭṭati ‘ayaṃ nāma me aguṇo’ti sutvā taṃ pahāya guṇesuyeva
analyzed: attanaḥ aguṇam pariyesitum vaṭṭati ayam nāma me sutvā tam pahāya
translated: to seek out my own faults, thinking, ‘This is my fault.’ Having heard of it, I will abandon it and will live only in virtues.

original: vattissāmī”ti. Tato paṭṭhāya “atthi nu kho me koci aguṇavādī”ti pariggaṇhanto antovaḷañjakānaṃ
analyzed: vattissāmi iti tatas paṭṭhāya atthi nu kho me koci aguṇa vādī iti pariggaṇhantaḥ antovaḷañjakānam
translated: ” From that time on, seeking to find out if there was anyone who would speak of his faults, he found no one in the inner palace

original: antare kañci aguṇavādiṃ adisvā attano guṇakathameva sutvā “ete mayhaṃ bhayenāpi aguṇaṃ
analyzed: antare kañci aguṇa vādim a disvā guṇa katham eva sutvā ete bhayena api aguṇam
translated: who would speak of his faults. Hearing only of his virtues, he thought, “These men, out of fear of me, do not speak of my faults,

original: avatvā guṇameva vadeyyu”nti bahivaḷañjanake pariggaṇhanto tatthāpi adisvā antonagare
analyzed: a vatvā guṇam eva vadeyyunti bahi vaḷañjanake pariggaṇhantaḥ tattha api a disvā antonagare
translated: but speak of my virtues only.” Seeking to find out in the outer palace, he found no one there who would speak of his faults.

original: pariggaṇhi. Bahinagare catūsu dvāresu catugāmake pariggaṇhi. Tatthāpi kañci aguṇavādiṃ
analyzed: pariggaṇhi bahi nagare catūsu dvāresu catu gāmake pariggaṇhi tattha api kañci aguṇa vādiṃ
translated: Then he sought to find out in the inner city, and in the four villages at the four gates of the outer city. There also he found no one who would speak of his faults,

original: adisvā attano guṇakathameva sutvā “janapadaṃ pariggaṇhissāmī”ti amacce rajjaṃ paṭicchāpetvā
analyzed: a disvā attanaḥ guṇa katham eva sutvā janapadam pariggaṇhissāmi iti amacce rajjam paṭicchāpetvā
translated: but heard only of his virtues. Thinking, “I will seek to find out in the provinces,” he entrusted the government to his ministers,

original: rathaṃ āruyha sārathimeva gahetvā aññātakavesena nagarā nikkhamitvā janapadaṃ pariggaṇhamāno
analyzed: ratham āruyha sārathim eva gahetvā aññātaka vesena nagarā nikkhamitvā janapadam pariggaṇhamānaḥ
translated: and, taking his charioteer with him, he left the city in disguise and went to inspect the country.

original: yāva paccantabhūmiṃ gantvā kañci aguṇavādiṃ adisvā attano guṇakathameva sutvā paccantasīmato
analyzed: yāva paccanta bhūmim gantvā kañci aguṇa vādim a disvā guṇa katham eva sutvā paccanta sīmataḥ
translated: He went as far as the frontier districts, and, hearing no one speak ill of him, and hearing only praises of his own virtues, he turned back

original: mahāmaggena nagarābhimukhoyeva nivatti.
analyzed: mahā maggena nagara abhimukhaḥ yā iva
translated: and retraced his steps by the high-road to the city.

original: Tasmiṃ pana kāle balliko nāma kosalarājāpi dhammena rajjaṃ kārento aguṇakathaṃ gavesanto
analyzed: tasmin pana kāle ballikaḥ nāma kosala rājā api dhammena rajjam kārentaḥ aguṇa katham gavesanto
translated: Now at that time the king of Kosala, named Ballika, was also ruling righteously, and, seeking for a report of his own faults,

original: hutvā antovaḷañjakādīsu aguṇavādiṃ adisvā attano guṇakathameva sutvā janapadaṃ pariggaṇhanto
analyzed: hutvā antovaḷañjaka ādīsu aguṇa vādim a disvā attanaḥ guṇa katham eva sutvā janapadam pariggaṇhantaḥ
translated: having made proclamation as above, and having made search in the inner palace, in the stables, and so forth, and hearing no one speak ill of him, and hearing only praises of his own virtues, he went to inspect the country.

original: taṃ padesaṃ agamāsi. Te ubhopi ekasmiṃ ninnaṭṭhāne sakaṭamagge abhimukhā ahesuṃ,
analyzed: tam padesam agamāsi te ubho pi ekasmin ninna ṭhāne sakaṭa magge abhimukhāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: He came to that place, and both of them were on the same road, in the same low-lying place.

original: rathassa ukkamanaṭṭhānaṃ natthi. Atha ballikarañño sārathi bārāṇasirañño sārathiṃ
analyzed: rathassa ukkamana ṭṭhānam natthi atha ballika raññaḥ sārathi bārāṇasi raññaḥ sārathim
translated: There was no place for the chariots to pass. Then the charioteer of King Ballika said to the charioteer of the king of Benares,

original: “tava rathaṃ ukkamāpehī”ti āha. Sopi “ambho sārathi, tava rathaṃ ukkamāpehi, imasmiṃ
analyzed: tava ratham ukkama apehi iti āha saḥ api ambho sārathi tava ratham ukkama apehi imasmin
translated: “Make your chariot turn back.” He replied, “Good charioteer, make your chariot turn back. This is

original: rathe bārāṇasirajjasāmiko brahmadattamahārājā nisinno”ti āha. Itaropi naṃ “ambho
analyzed: rathe bārāṇasi rajja sāmikaḥ brahmadatta mahā rājā āha itaraḥ api nam
translated: and the great king Brahmadatta, the lord of the kingdom of Bārāṇasī, is seated in this chariot.” The other said, “Good charioteer,

original: sārathi, imasmiṃ rathe kosalarajjasāmiko ballikamahārājā nisinno, tava rathaṃ ukkamāpetvā🔽amhākaṃ rañño rathassa okāsaṃ dehī”ti āha. Bārāṇasirañño sārathi “ayampi kira rājāyeva,
analyzed: sārathi imasmin rathe kosala rajja sāmikaḥ ballika mahā rājā nisinnaḥ tava ratham ukkamāpetvā  amhākam raññaḥ rathassa okāsam dehi iti āha bārāṇasi rañño sārathi ayam pi kira rājāya iva
translated: the great king Ballika, the lord of the kingdom of Kosala, is seated in this chariot. You must move aside your chariot🔽and make way for our king’s chariot.” The charioteer of the king of Bārāṇasī thought, “This king is also a king.

original: kiṃ nu kho kātabba”nti cintento “attheso upāyo”ti vayaṃ pucchitvā “daharassa rathaṃ
analyzed: kim nu kho kātabbanti cintentaḥ attha iso upāyaḥ ti vayam pucchitvā daharassa rathaṃ
translated: What should I do?” He thought, “There is a way.” He asked the age of the other king and said, “I will move aside the chariot of the younger king

original: ukkamāpetvā mahallakassa okāsaṃ dāpessāmī”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā taṃ sārathiṃ kosalarañño🔽vayaṃ pucchitvā pariggaṇhanto ubhinnampi samānavayabhāvaṃ ñatvā rajjaparimāṇaṃ balaṃ🔽dhanaṃ yasaṃ jātiṃ gottaṃ kulapadesanti sabbaṃ pucchitvā “ubhopi tiyojanasatikassa
analyzed: ukkamāpetvā mahallakassa okāsam dāpessāmi iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā tam sārathim kosala rañño  vayam pucchitvā pariggaṇhantaḥ ubhinnam pi samāna vaya bhāvam ñatvā rajja parimāṇam balam  dhanam yasam jātim gottam kula padesan ti sabbam pucchitvā ubho api ti yojana satikassa
translated: and make way for the older king.” He made this decision and asked the age of the charioteer of the king of Kosala.🔽Examining him, he found that they were the same age. He asked about the size of their kingdoms, their strength,🔽their wealth, their fame, their birth, their clan, and their family. Having asked about all these things, he found that the two kings were equal in all respects.

original: rajjassa sāmino samānabaladhanayasajātigottakulapadesā”ti ñatvā “sīlavantassa okāsaṃ
analyzed: rajjassa sāmino samāna bala dhana yasa jāti gotta kula padesā ati ñatvā sīlavantassa okāsam
translated: The two kings were lords of kingdoms of three hundred leagues, and they were equal in strength, wealth, fame, birth, clan, and family.

original: dassāmī”ti cintetvā “bho sārathi, tumhākaṃ rañño sīlācāro kīdiso”ti pucchi. So “ayañca
analyzed: dassāmi iti cintetvā bho sārathi tumhākam rañño sīla ācāro kīdiso ti pucchi saḥ ayaṃ ca
translated: “I will show him,” and asked, “Sir, what is your king’s character like?”

original: ayañca amhākaṃ rañño sīlācāro”ti attano rañño aguṇameva guṇato pakāsento paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ayam ca amhākam rañño sīla ācāro ti attanaḥ raññaḥ aguṇam eva guṇataḥ pakāsento paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: The charioteer replied, “This is our king’s character,” and he described his king’s faults as though they were virtues. He spoke the first verse:

original: “Daḷhaṃ daḷhassa khipati, balliko mudunā muduṃ;
analyzed: daḷham daḷhassa khipati ballikaḥ mudunā mudum
translated: “The strong strikes the strong, the weak strikes the weak;

original: Sādhumpi sādhunā jeti, asādhumpi asādhunā;
analyzed: sādhum pi sādhunā jeti asādhum pi asādhunā
translated: The good conquers the good, the bad conquers the bad.

original: Etādiso ayaṃ rājā, maggā uyyāhi sārathī”ti.🔽Tattha daḷhaṃ daḷhassa khipatīti yo daḷho hoti balavadaḷhena pahārena vā vacanena🔽vā jinitabbo, tassa daḷhameva pahāraṃ vā vacanaṃ vā khipati. Evaṃ daḷhova hutvā taṃ🔽jinātīti dasseti. Ballikoti tassa rañño nāmaṃ. Mudunā mudunti mudupuggalaṃ sayampi
analyzed: etādisaḥ ayam rājā maggā uyyāhi sārathī iti  tattha daḷham daḷhassa khipati iti yaḥ daḷhaḥ hoti balava daḷhena pahārena vā vacanena  vā jinitabbaḥ tassa daḷham eva pahāram vā vacanam vā khipati evam daḷhaḥ uva hutvā tam  jināti iti dasseti balliko ti tassa raññaḥ nāmam mudunā mudum ti mudu puggalam sayam pi
translated: Such is this king; drive on, charioteer.”

original: mudu hutvā mudunāva upāyena jināti. Sādhumpi sādhunā jetīti ye sādhū sappurisā, te
analyzed: mudu hutvā mudunā avaḥ upāyena jināti sādhumpi sādhunā jeti iti ye sādhū sappurisā te
translated: Herein, the strong strikes the strong means that one who is strong is to be conquered either by a strong blow or by strong words; he strikes him with a strong blow or with strong words. Thus he shows that he conquers him by being strong himself. Balliko is the king’s name. The weak strikes the weak means that he conquers a weak person by being weak himself and by a weak means. The good conquers the good means that he conquers the good, the virtuous, by being good himself and by a good means.

original: sayampi sādhu hutvā sādhunāva upāyena jināti. Asādhumpi asādhunāti ye pana asādhū,
analyzed: sayampi sādhu hutvā upāyena jināti asādhumpi ye pana asādhū
translated: and the good by good means. The bad by bad means: he shows that those who are bad,

original: te sayampi asādhu hutvā asādhunāva upāyena jinātīti dasseti. Etādiso ayaṃ rājāti
analyzed: te sayam pi asādhu hutvā asādhu nau upāyena jināti iti dasseti etādisaḥ ayam rājā ati
translated: they too, being bad, conquer by bad means. Such is our king:

original: ayaṃ amhākaṃ kosalarājā sīlācārena evarūpo. Maggā uyyāhi sārathīti attano rathaṃ
analyzed: ayam amhākam kosala rājā sīla ācārena evarūpaḥ maggā uyyāhi sārathī iti attanaḥ ratham
translated: this is our King of Kosala, such is he in virtue and conduct. Drive out of the way, charioteer:

original: maggā ukkamāpetvā uyyāhi, uppathena yāhi, amhākaṃ rañño maggaṃ dehīti vadati.
analyzed: maggā ukkamāpetvā uyyāhi uppathena yāhi amhākam raññaḥ maggam dehi iti vadati
translated: drive out of the way his chariot, go by the wrong road, give way to our king.

original: Atha naṃ bārāṇasirañño sārathi “ambho, kiṃ pana tayā attano rañño guṇakathā kathitā”ti
analyzed: atha nam bārāṇasi raññaḥ sārathi ambho kim pana tayā attanaḥ raññaḥ guṇa kathā kathitā ati
translated: Then the charioteer of the king of Bārāṇasī said to him: “Well now, have you been talking about the virtues of your own king?”

original: vatvā “āmā”ti vutte “yadi pana ete guṇāti vadasi, aguṇā pana kīdisī”ti vatvā “ete
analyzed: vatvā āmā iti vutte yadi pana ete guṇā ati vadasi aguṇā pana kīdisī iti vatvā ete
translated: “Yes.” “But if you say these are virtues, what are the vices like?”🔽“Let these be virtues for the time being, but what sort of virtues has your king?” “Well then, listen.”

original: tāva aguṇā hontu, tumhākaṃ pana rañño kīdiso guṇo”ti vutte “tena hi suṇāhī”ti dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tāva aguṇāḥ hontu tumhākam pana rañño kīdisaḥ guṇo ti vutte tena hi suṇāhi iti dutiyam gātham āha
translated: He spoke the second verse:

original: “Akkodhena jine kodhaṃ, asādhuṃ sādhunā jine;
analyzed: a kkodhena jine kodham asādhum sādhunā jine
translated: “By non-anger conquer anger, by good conquer the bad;

original: Jine kadariyaṃ dānena, saccenālikavādinaṃ;
analyzed: jine kadariyam dānena
translated: Conquer the miser by generosity, the liar by truth.

original: Etādiso ayaṃ rājā, maggā uyyāhi sārathī”ti.
analyzed: etādisaḥ ayam rājā maggā uyyāhi sārathī iti
translated: Such is the king, so drive the chariot from the road, charioteer.”

original: Tattha etādisoti etehi “akkodhena jine kodha”ntiādivasena vuttehi guṇehi samannāgato.
analyzed: tattha etādisaḥ ti etehi akkodhena jine kodha anti ādi vasena vuttehi guṇehi samannāgato
translated: Herein, such is the king means endowed with the virtues stated thus: “By non-hate one conquers hate” .

original: Ayañhi kuddhaṃ puggalaṃ sayaṃ akkodho hutvā akkodhena jināti, asādhuṃ pana sayaṃ🔽sādhu hutvā sādhunāva upāyena jināti, kadariyaṃ thaddhamacchariṃ sayaṃ dāyako hutvā
analyzed: ayam hi kuddham puggalam sayam akkodhaḥ hutvā akkodhena jināti asādhum pana sayam  sādhu hutvā sādhu nāvaḥ upāyena jināti kadariyam sayam dāyakaḥ hutvā
translated: For this king, being himself free from hate, conquers a person who is angry by being free from hate; but if the other is not conquered by that means, then he conquers him by what is good, being himself good;🔽if the other is not conquered by that means, then he conquers him by generosity, being himself a giver,

original: dānena jināti. Saccenālikavādinanti musāvādiṃ sayaṃ saccavādī hutvā saccena jināti.🔽Maggā uyyāhi sārathīti, samma sārathi, maggato apagaccha. Evaṃvidhasīlācāraguṇayuttassa
analyzed: dānena jināti musāvādim sayam sacca vādī hutvā saccena jināti  maggā uyyāhi sārathi iti samma sārathi maggataḥ apagaccha evaṃvidha sīla ācāra guṇa yuttassa
translated: and if the other is not conquered by that means, then he conquers him by truth, being himself truthful.🔽Drive the chariot from the road, charioteer means, “Good charioteer, get out of the way of the chariot.

original: amhākaṃ rañño maggaṃ dehi, amhākaṃ rājā maggassa anucchavikoti.
analyzed: amhākam raññaḥ maggam dehi amhākam rājā maggassa anucchavikaḥ ti
translated: Give way to our king, who is endowed with such virtues of moral discipline and good habits as these. Our king is worthy of the road.”🔽When this was said, both the king of Bhallika and the charioteer got down from the chariot, unyoked the horses, removed the chariot,

original: Evaṃ vutte ballikarājā ca sārathi ca ubhopi rathā otaritvā asse mocetvā rathaṃ apanetvā
analyzed: evam vutte ballika rājā ca sārathi ca ubhau api rathau otaritvā asse mocetvā ratham apanetvā
translated: and

original: bārāṇasirañño maggaṃ adaṃsu. Bārāṇasirājā ballikarañño “raññā nāma idañcidañca kātuṃ
analyzed: bārāṇasi raññaḥ maggam bārāṇasi rājā ballika raññaḥ raññā nāma idam ca idam ca kātum
translated: and gave him the road. The king of Bārāṇasī gave the king of Ballika advice, saying, “This and that ought to be done by a king.”

original: vaṭṭatī”ti ovādaṃ datvā bārāṇasiṃ gantvā dānādīni puññāni katvā jīvitapariyosāne
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti ovādam da tvā bārāṇasim gantvā dāna ādīni puññāni katvā jīvita pariyosāne
translated: After he had gone to Bārāṇasī, he made gifts and other meritorious acts, and at the end of his life

original: saggapuraṃ pūresi. Ballikarājāpi tassa ovādaṃ gahetvā janapadaṃ pariggahetvā attano
analyzed: saggapuram pūresi ballika rājā api tassa ovādam gahetvā janapadam pariggahetvā attano
translated: he filled the city of heaven. The king of Ballika also, taking his advice, took possession of the country, and not seeing anyone who could be his equal,

original: aguṇavādiṃ adisvāva sakanagaraṃ gantvā dānādīni puññāni katvā jīvitapariyosāne saggapurameva pūresi.
analyzed: aguṇa vādim a disvā ava saka nagaram gantvā dāna ādīni puññāni katvā jīvita pariyosāne saggapuram eva pūresi
translated: he went to his own city, made gifts and other meritorious acts, and at the end of his life he filled the city of heaven.

original: Satthā kosalarājassa ovādatthāya imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi
analyzed: satthā kosala rājassa ovāda tthāya imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi
translated: The Teacher, in order to give advice to the king of Kosala, related this story of the past,

original: – “tadā ballikarañño sārathi moggallāno ahosi, ballikarājā ānando, bārāṇasirañño
analyzed: tadā ballika raññaḥ sārathi moggallānaḥ ahosi ballika rājā ānandaḥ bārāṇasi rañño
translated: and identified the Birth: — “At that time Moggallāna was the charioteer of the king of Ballika, Ānanda was the king of Ballika, Sāriputta was the charioteer of the king of Bārāṇasī,

original: sārathi sāriputto, bārāṇasirājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: sārathi sāriputto bārāṇasi rājā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: and I myself was the king of Bārāṇasī.”

original: Rājovādajātakavaṇṇanā paṭhamā.🔽[152] 2. Siṅgālajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rājovāda jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā 🔽
translated: The Story of the Advice of the King.🔽The Story of the Jackal.

original: Asamekkhitakammantanti idaṃ satthā kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ viharanto vesālivāsikaṃ ekaṃ nhāpitaputtaṃ🔽ārabbha kathesi. Tassa kira pitā rājūnaṃ rājorodhānaṃ rājakumārānaṃ rājakumārikānañca
analyzed: a samekkhita kammantanti idam satthā kūṭāgāra sālāyam viharantaḥ vesāli vāsikam ekam nhāpita puttam  ārabbha kathesi tassa kira pitā rājūnam rājorodhānam rāja kumārānam rāja kumārikānam ca
translated: This story the Master told while dwelling in the Gabled Hall, about a certain barber’s son of Vesālī.

original: massukaraṇakesasaṇṭhapanaaṭṭhapadaṭṭhapanādīni sabbakiccāni karoti saddho pasanno
analyzed: massu karaṇa kesa saṇṭhapana aṭṭhapada ṭṭhapana ādīni sabba kiccāni karoti saddhaḥ pasanno
translated: His father, it seems, was a faithful, believing man, who had taken the Three Refuges and undertaken the Five Precepts, and who performed all the barber’s duties for the king, the royal family, the princes, and the princesses.

original: tisaraṇagato samādinnapañcasīlo, antarantare satthu dhammaṃ suṇanto kālaṃ vītināmeti.
analyzed: ti saraṇa gataḥ samādinna pañca sīlaḥ antara antare satthu dhammam suṇanto kālam vītināmeti
translated: He spent his time listening to the Master’s preaching.

original: So ekasmiṃ divase rājanivesane kammaṃ kātuṃ gacchanto attano puttaṃ gahetvā gato.
analyzed: so ekasmin divase rāja nivesane kammam kātum gacchantaḥ attano puttam gahetvā gataḥ
translated: One day, as he was going to the royal palace to do his work, he took his son with him.

original: So tattha ekaṃ devaccharāpaṭibhāgaṃ alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ licchavikumārikaṃ disvā kilesavasena
analyzed: saḥ tattha ekam deva charā paṭibhāgam alaṅkata paṭiyattam licchavi kumārikam disvā kilesa vasena
translated: The son, seeing a Licchavi maiden, who was the very image of a fairy, all decked out in finery, became enamored of her.

original: paṭibaddhacitto hutvā pitarā saddhiṃ rājanivesanā nikkhamitvā “etaṃ kumārikaṃ labhamāno
analyzed: paṭibaddha cittaḥ hutvā pitarā saddhim rāja nivesanā nikkhamitvā etam kumārikam labhamānaḥ
translated: When he left the palace with his father, he said, “Father, if I cannot have that maiden, I will die.”

original: jīvissāmi, alabhamānassa me ettheva maraṇa”nti āhārupacchedaṃ katvā mañcakaṃ parissajitvā nipajji.
analyzed: jīvissāmi a labhamānassa me ettha iva maraṇam ti āhāra upacchedam katvā mañcakam parissajitvā nipajji
translated: “I shall die right here if I do not obtain her.” So saying, he cut off his food, spread himself out on a couch, and lay down.

original: Atha naṃ pitā upasaṅkamitvā “tāta, avatthumhi chandarāgaṃ mā kari, hīnajacco tvaṃ
analyzed: atha nam pitā upasaṅkamitvā tāta chanda rāgam mā kari tvam
translated: His father came to him and said, “Dear son, do not cherish desire for an impossible object. You are of low birth,

original: nhāpitaputto, licchavikumārikā khattiyadhītā jātisampannā, na sā tuyhaṃ anucchavikā,
analyzed: nhāpita puttaḥ licchavi kumārikā khattiya dhītā jāti sampannā na sā tuyham anucchavikā
translated: the son of a barber. The daughter of the Licchavi prince is of high birth, the daughter of a Khattiya. She is not fit for you.

original: aññaṃ te jātigottehi sadisaṃ kumārikaṃ ānessāmī”ti āha. So pitu kathaṃ na gaṇhi.
analyzed: aññam te jāti gottehi sadisam kumārikam ānessāmi iti āha saḥ pitu katham na gaṇhi
translated: I will bring you another maiden who is your equal in birth and family.” But he would not listen to his father’s words.

original: Atha naṃ mātā bhātā bhaginī cūḷapitā cūḷamātāti sabbepi ñātakā ceva mittasuhajjā
analyzed: atha nam mātā bhātā bhaginī cūḷa pitā cūḷa mātā ati sabbe pi ñātakā ca iva mitta suhajjā
translated: Then his mother, his brother, his sister, his uncle, and his aunt, and all his kinsmen, and all his friends and companions,

original: ca sannipatitvā saññāpentāpi saññāpetuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu. So tattheva sussitvā parisussitvā
analyzed: ca sannipatitvā saññāpentā api saññāpetum na asakkhiṃsu saḥ tattha iva sussitvā parisussitvā
translated: assembled together and tried to persuade him, but they were unable to persuade him. He continued to lie there, first emaciated, then dried up,

original: jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpuṇi. Athassa pitā sarīrakiccapetakiccāni katvā tanusoko “satthāraṃ
analyzed: jīvita kkhayam pāpuṇi athassa pitā sarīra kicca peta kiccāni katvā tanu sokaḥ satthāram
translated: and finally dead. Then his father performed the funeral rites over his body and, deeply grieved, thought to himself, “I will pay my respects to the Teacher

original: vandissāmī”ti bahuṃ gandhamālāvilepanaṃ gahetvā mahāvanaṃ gantvā satthāraṃ pūjetvā
analyzed: vandissāmi iti bahum gandha mālā vilepanam gahetvā mahā vanam gantvā satthāram pūjetvā
translated: and take with me many fragrant flowers, perfumes, and ointments.” So he went to the Great Forest, paid obeisance to the Teacher, and

original: vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinno “kiṃ nu kho, upāsaka, bahūni divasāni na dissasī”ti vutte🔽tamatthaṃ ārocesi. Satthā “na kho, upāsaka, idāneva tava putto avatthusmiṃ chandarāgaṃ
analyzed: vanditvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ kim nu khalu upāsaka bahūni divasāni na dissasi iti vutte  tam attham ārocesi satthā na kho upāsaka idānā iva tava putto avatthusmim chanda rāgam
translated: and after paying homage to him, sat down at one side. The Teacher asked him, “Layman, why have you not been seen for many days?”

original: uppādetvā vināsaṃ pāpuṇi, pubbepi pattoyevā”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: uppādetvā vināsam pāpuṇi pubbe pi patto yā iva ati vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: and told him the reason. The Teacher said to him, “Layman, this is not the first time your son has met with destruction through arousing desire and passion for that which was not his lawful wife; in a previous state of existence also he met with destruction in the same way.” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto himavantapadese sīhayoniyaṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ himavanta padese sīhayoniyam
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in the Himalaya country in the womb of a lioness.

original: nibbatti. Tassa cha kaniṭṭhabhātaro ekā ca bhaginī ahosi, sabbepi kañcanaguhāyaṃ
analyzed: tassa cha kaniṭṭha bhātaraḥ ekā ca bhaginī ahosi sabbe pi
translated: He had six younger brothers and one sister. All of them lived in a golden cave.

original: vasanti. Tassā pana guhāya avidūre rajatapabbate ekā phalikaguhā atthi, tattheko🔽siṅgālo vasati. Aparabhāge sīhānaṃ mātāpitaro kālamakaṃsu. Te bhaginiṃ sīhapotikaṃ
analyzed: vasanti tassā pana guhāya avidūre rajatapabbate ekā phalika guhā atthi tattha ekaḥ  siṅgālaḥ vasati aparabhāge sīhānam mātā pitaraḥ te bhaginim sīhapotikam
translated: Not far from this cave was a silver mountain, and in a rock-cave in this mountain there lived a jackal.

original: kañcanaguhāyaṃ ṭhapetvā gocarāya pakkamitvā maṃsaṃ āharitvā tassā denti. So siṅgālo
analyzed: ṭhapetvā gocarāya pakkamitvā maṃsam āharitvā tassā denti saḥ siṅgālaḥ
translated: After a time the parents of the lions died. The lions left their sister, a lioness, in the golden cave, and going out to hunt, brought meat and gave it to her. The jackal

original: taṃ sīhapotikaṃ disvā paṭibaddhacitto ahosi. Tassā pana mātāpitūnaṃ dharamānakāle
analyzed: tam sīhapotikam disvā paṭibaddha cittaḥ ahosi tassā pana mātā pitūnam dharamāna kāle
translated: and he became enamoured of the lioness. But while her parents were alive

original: okāsaṃ nālattha, so sattannampi tesaṃ gocarāya pakkantakāle phalikaguhāya otaritvā
analyzed: okāsam na alattha saḥ tesam gocarāya pakkanta kāle phalika guhāya otaritvā
translated: he did not get an opportunity. When they had all gone out to pasture,

original: kañcanaguhāya dvāraṃ gantvā sīhapotikāya purato lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ evarūpaṃ rahassakathaṃ
analyzed: kañcana guhāya dvāram gantvā sīha potikāya puratas loka āmisa paṭisaṃyuttam evarūpam rahassa katham
translated: he went down into the cave of the rock, went to the door of the golden cave, and in front of the lioness he spoke this kind of secret talk connected with the pleasures of the flesh:

original: kathesi – “sīhapotike, ahampi catuppado, tvampi catuppadā, tvaṃ me pajāpatī hohi,
analyzed: kathesi sīhapotike aham pi catuppadaḥ tvam pi catuppadā tvam me pajāpatī hohi
translated: “Lioness, I am a quadruped, and you are a quadruped. You be my wife,

original: ahaṃ te pati bhavissāmi, te mayaṃ samaggā sammodamānā vasissāma, tvaṃ ito paṭṭhāya🔽maṃ kilesavasena saṅgaṇhāhī”ti. Sā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā cintesi – “ayaṃ siṅgālo catuppadānaṃ
analyzed: aham te pati bhavissāmi te mayam samaggā sammodamānāḥ vasissāma tvam itas paṭṭhāya  mam kilesa vasena saṅgaṇhāhi iti sā tassa vacanam sutvā cintesi ayam siṅgālo catuppadānam
translated: and I will be your husband. We will live together in harmony and in mutual appreciation. From now on

original: antare hīno paṭikuṭṭho caṇḍālasadiso, mayaṃ uttamarājakulasammatā, esa kho mayā saddhiṃ
analyzed: antare hīnaḥ paṭikuṭṭho caṇḍāla sadisaḥ mayam uttama rāja kula sammatā esa kho mayā saddhim
translated: you must attend to me with passion.” When she heard his words she thought: “This jackal is the lowest of quadrupeds, despised, like a caṇḍāla. We are honoured in the highest royal family. He is speaking to me

original: asabbhiṃ ananucchavikaṃ kathaṃ katheti, ahaṃ evarūpaṃ kathaṃ sutvā jīvitena kiṃ karissāmi,
analyzed: asabbhim an anucchavikam katham kathā iti aham evarūpam katham sutvā jīvitena kim karissāmi
translated: in a way that is unbecoming and improper. Having heard such talk as this, what is the use of my living?

original: nāsāvātaṃ sannirujjhitvā marissāmī”ti. Athassā etadahosi – “mayhaṃ evameva maraṇaṃ🔽ayuttaṃ, bhātikā tāva me āgacchantu, tesaṃ kathetvā marissāmī”ti. Siṅgālopi tassā
analyzed: na asa vātam san nirujjhitvā marissāmi iti atha assā etat ahosi mayham evam eva maraṇam  ayuttam bhātikā tāva me āgacchantu tesam kathetvā marissāmi iti tassā
translated: “I will stop up my nostrils and die.” Then she thought, “It is not proper for me to die in this way.

original: santikā paṭivacanaṃ alabhitvā “idāni esā mayhaṃ kujjhatī”ti domanassappatto phalikaguhāyaṃ pavisitvā nipajji.
analyzed: santikā paṭivacanam a labhitvā idāni esā mayham kujjhati iti domanassa patto phalika guhāyam pavisitvā nipajji
translated: Let my brothers come. I will die after I have talked with them.” The jackal, not receiving any reply from her, thought, “Now she is angry with me,” and in a dejected mood he entered the cave of the rock-crystal mountain and lay down.

original: Atheko sīhapotako mahiṃsavāraṇādīsu aññataraṃ vadhitvā maṃsaṃ khāditvā bhaginiyā
analyzed: atha ekaḥ sīha potakaḥ mahiṃsa vāraṇa ādīsu aññataram vadhitvā maṃsam khāditvā bhaginiyā
translated: Now a certain lion cub killed an elephant, a buffalo, or some other large animal, ate his fill of meat, and brought the remainder to his sister.

original: bhāgaṃ āharitvā “amma, maṃsaṃ khādassū”ti āha. “Bhātika, nāhaṃ maṃsaṃ khādāmi, marissāmī”ti.
analyzed: bhāgam āharitvā amma maṃsam khādassu iti āha bhātika na aham maṃsam khādāmi marissāmi iti
translated: “Sister, eat some meat.” “Brother, I do not eat meat. I am going to die.”

original: “Kiṃ kāraṇā”ti? Sā taṃ pavattiṃ ācikkhi. “Idāni kahaṃ so siṅgālo”ti ca vutte phalikaguhāyaṃ
analyzed: kim kāraṇā ati sā tam pavattim ācikkhi idāni kaham so siṅgālaḥ ti ca vutte
translated: “What is the reason?” She told him the story from the beginning. “Where is the jackal now?” “He is lying down in the cave of the rock-crystal mountain.”

original: nipannaṃ siṅgālaṃ “ākāse nipanno”ti maññamānā “bhātika, kiṃ na passasi, eso rajatapabbate
analyzed: nipannam siṅgālam ākāse nipannaḥ iti maññamānā bhātika kim na passasi esaḥ rajatapabbate
translated: Thinking to herself, “He is lying down in the sky,” she said, “Brother, do you not see him? There he is, lying down on the silver mountain.

original: ākāse nipanno”ti. Sīhapotako tassa phalikaguhāyaṃ nipannabhāvaṃ ajānanto “ākāse nipanno”ti
analyzed: ākāse nipanno ti sīha potako tassa phalika guhāyam nipanna bhāvam a jānantaḥ ākāse nipannoti
translated: “He is lying in the air.” The lion-cub, not knowing that his brother was lying in the cave, thinking that he was lying in the air,

original: saññī hutvā “māressāmi na”nti sīhavegena pakkhanditvā phalikaguhaṃ hadayeneva pahari.
analyzed: saññī hutvā māressāmi nanti sīha vegena pakkhanditvā phalika guham hadayena iva pahari
translated: ran with the speed of a lion, intending to kill him, and struck the rock-cave with his breast.

original: So hadayena phalitena tattheva jīvitakkhayaṃ patvā pabbatapāde pati. Athāparo āgacchi,
analyzed: saḥ hadayena phalitena tattha iva jīvita kkhayam patvā pabbata pāde atha aparaḥ āgacchi
translated: He died on the spot, his heart being crushed. Then another came,

original: sā tassapi tatheva kathesi. Sopi tatheva katvā jīvitakkhayaṃ patvā pabbatapāde pati.
analyzed: sā tassa api tathā iva kathesi saḥ api tathā iva katvā jīvita kkhayam patvā pabbata pāde pati
translated: and she told him the same story. He did the same thing, and died.

original: Evaṃ chasupi bhātikesu matesu sabbapacchā bodhisatto āgacchi. Sā tassapi taṃ kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: evam chasu pi bhātikesu matesu sabbapacchā bodhisattaḥ āgacchi sā tassa api tam kāraṇam
translated: Thus six of the brothers died. The Bodhisatta came last of all. She told him the same story,

original: ārocetvā “idāni so kuhi”nti vutte “eso rajatapabbatamatthake ākāse nipanno”ti āha.
analyzed: ārocetvā idāni so kuhinti vutte esaḥ rajata pabbata matthake ākāse nipannaḥ ti āha
translated: and when he asked her, “Where is he now?” she said, “He is lying in the air on the top of the Silver Mountain.”

original: Bodhisatto cintesi – “siṅgālānaṃ ākāse patiṭṭhā nāma natthi, phalikaguhāyaṃ nipannako
analyzed: bodhisatto cintesi siṅgālānam ākāse patiṭṭhā nāma natthi phalikaguhā ayam nipannakaḥ
translated: The Bodhisatta thought to himself, “Jackals have no footing in the air. He must be lying in the rock-cave.

original: bhavissatī”ti. So pabbatapādaṃ otaritvā cha bhātike mate disvā “ime attano bālatāya
analyzed: bhavissati iti saḥ pabbata pādam otaritvā cha bhātike mate disvā ime attanaḥ bāla tāya
translated: ” He came down from the mountain-top, and seeing that his six brothers were dead, he said to himself, “These foolish men,

original: pariggaṇhanapaññāya abhāvena phalikaguhabhāvaṃ ajānitvā hadayena paharitvā matā bhavissanti,

analyzed: tam bhikkhum jetavana vāsikassa pariveṇam pahiṇiṃsu te ubho pi caṇḍāḥ aññam aññam disvāva

analyzed: piya saṃvāsam saṃsandiṃsu samiṃsu hattha pāda piṭṭhi sambāhana ādīni akaṃsu dhamma sabhāyam  bhikkhū katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso caṇḍā bhikkhū aññesam upari caṇḍā pharusā
translated: they became friendly, and they rubbed their hands and feet and backs together, and did other things of the same kind.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto tassa sabbatthasādhako atthadhammānusāsako
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto tassa sabba ttha sādhakaḥ attha dhamma anusāsako

original: amacco ahosi. So pana rājā thokaṃ dhanalobhapakatiko, tassa mahāsoṇo nāma kūṭaasso
analyzed: amaccaḥ ahosi saḥ pana rājā thokam dhana lobha pakatiko tassa mahāsoṇaḥ nāma kūṭa asso

analyzed: atthi atha uttarāpathakāḥ assa vāṇijāḥ pañca assa satāni ānesuṃ assānam āgata bhāvam
translated: Now merchants from the North brought five hundred horses,🔽and informed the king of their arrival.

analyzed: ca paṭhamam mahā soṇam yathā tesam assānam antaram pavisati tathā vissajjetvā asse
translated: first let Mahāsoṇa go out among them, and then have the horses valued,

original: ḍaṃsāpetvā vaṇite kārāpetvā dubbalakāle mūlaṃ hāpetvā asse agghāpeyyāsī”ti āha. So
analyzed: ḍaṃsāpetvā vaṇite kārāpetvā dubbala kāle mūlam hāpetvā asse agghāpeyyāsi iti āha saḥ
translated: and have them made fit for the saddle, and when they are weak, then have them valued.” He agreed,

original: “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchitvā tathā akāsi.
analyzed: sādhu iti sampaṭicchitvā tathā akāsi
translated: and did as he was told.

original: Assavāṇijā anattamanā hutvā tena katakiriyaṃ bodhisattassa ārocesuṃ. analyzed: assa vāṇijāḥ anattamanāḥ hutvā tena kata kiriyam bodhisattassa ārocesuṃ bodhisatto kim  pana tumhākam nagare kūṭaasso natthi iti pucchi atthi sāmi suhanu nāma kūṭaasso  caṇḍaḥ pharusaḥ ti tena hi puna āgacchantā tam assam āneyyātha ati te sādhu uti paṭissuṇitvā  punar āgacchantā tam kūṭassam gāhāpetvā āgacchiṃsu rājā assa vāṇijāḥ āgatā ati sutvā
translated: The horse-dealers, displeased, told the Bodhisatta what had happened. “But,” said he, “have you no rogue horse in your town?” “We have, master, a rogue horse named Suhanu.” “Well then, when you come again, bring that horse with you.” “Very well,” they replied, and when they came again they brought the rogue horse with them. The king, hearing that the horse-dealers had come,🔽

original: sīhapañjaraṃ ugghāṭetvā asse oloketvā mahāsoṇaṃ vissajjāpesi. Assavāṇijāpi mahāsoṇaṃ🔽āgacchantaṃ disvā suhanuṃ vissajjāpesuṃ. Te aññamaññaṃ patvā sarīrāni lehantā sammodamānā🔽aṭṭhaṃsu. Rājā bodhisattaṃ pucchi – “passasi ime dve kūṭassā aññesaṃ caṇḍā pharusā🔽sāhasikā, aññe asse ḍaṃsitvā gelaññaṃ pāpenti, idāni aññamaññaṃ pana sarīraṃ lehantā
analyzed: sīha pañjaram ugghāṭetvā asse oloketvā mahā soṇam assa vāṇijā api mahā soṇam 🔽āgacchantam disvā su hanum te aññamaññam patvā sarīrāni lehantā sammodamānā 🔽rājā bodhisattam pucchi passasi ime dve kūṭassā aññesam caṇḍā pharusā 🔽sāhasikāḥ aññe asse ḍaṃsitvā gelaññam pāpenti idāni aññamaññam pana sarīram lehantā
translated: The horse-dealers, displeased, told the Bodhisatta what had happened. “But,” said he, “have you not in your city a horse that is a rogue?” “We have, sir,” said they, “a horse named Suhanu, who is a rogue and a cheat.” “Well then,” said the Bodhisatta, “when you come again, bring that horse with you.” “Very well,” said they, and when they came again, they brought the rogue with them. The king, hearing that the horse-dealers had come, had the door of the stable opened, and, looking at the horses, let out the great horse. The horse-dealers, seeing the great horse coming, let out Suhanu. The two horses met, and, rubbing their bodies against each other, stood there in friendly fashion. The king asked the Bodhisatta, “Do you see these two rogue horses? They are fierce and cruel, and frighten the other horses, and make them ill. But now they rub their bodies against each other.

original: sammodamānā aṭṭhaṃsu, kiṃ nāmeta”nti? Bodhisatto “nayime, mahārāja, visamasīlā, samasīlā
analyzed: sammodamānāḥ aṭṭhaṃsu kim nāma etat ti bodhisattaḥ na yime mahā rāja visama sīlā sama sīlā

original: samadhātukā ca ete”ti vatvā imaṃ gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: sama dhātukā ca etā iti vatvā imam gāthā dvayam āha

original: “Nayidaṃ visamasīlena, soṇena suhanū saha;

translated: “This is not because of evil character, that Soṇa and Suhanu are friends;

original: Suhanūpi tādisoyeva, yo soṇassa sagocaro.
analyzed: yaḥ soṇassa sagocaraḥ
translated: Suhanu is just like him, who is Soṇa’s companion.

original: “Pakkhandinā pagabbhena, niccaṃ sandānakhādinā;

original: Sameti pāpaṃ pāpena, sameti asatā asa”nti.🔽Tattha nayidaṃ visamasīlena, soṇena suhanū sahāti yaṃ idaṃ suhanu kūṭasso soṇena
analyzed: sameti pāpam pāpena sameti asatā asanti  tattha visama sīlena soṇena su hanū saha ati yat idam su hanu soṇena

translated: Herein, this is not because of evil character, that Soṇa and Suhanu are friends, means that this friendship of Suhanu and Kūṭa with Soṇa is not because of their own evil character, but rather it is because of their own good character that they are friends.

translated: But in order to show that their conduct and pasture are the same, the words “with the habit of jumping” , etc., are stated. original: asaṃ asādhukammaṃ sameti, gūthādīni viya gūthādīhi ekato saṃsandati sadisaṃ nibbisesameva hotīti.
analyzed: asam asādhu kammam sameti gūtha ādīni viya gūtha ādīhi ekatas saṃsandati sadisam nibbisesam eva hoti iti
translated: Evil meets evil in them: evil conduct meets evil conduct in them, in one or other of these ways.🔽Evil meets evil in them: evil conduct meets evil conduct

original: Evaṃ vatvā ca pana bodhisatto “mahārāja, raññā nāma atiluddhena na bhavitabbaṃ, parassa🔽santakaṃ nāma nāsetuṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti rājānaṃ ovaditvā asse agghāpetvā bhūtameva mūlaṃ
analyzed: evam vatvā ca pana bodhisatto mahā rāja raññā nāma ati luddhena na bhavitabbam parassa  santakam nāma na āsetum na vaṭṭati iti rājānam ovaditvā asse agghāpetvā bhūtam eva mūlam
translated: And after he had so spoken, the Bodhisatta, admonishing the king, saying, “Your majesty, a king should not be too greedy; it is not right to take what belongs to another,” had the horse valued, and paid the real price for it.

original: dāpesi. Assavāṇijā yathāsabhāvameva mūlaṃ labhitvā haṭṭhatuṭṭhā agamaṃsu. Rājāpi
analyzed: dāpesi assa vāṇijāḥ yathā sabhāvam eva mūlam labhitvā haṭṭha tuṭṭhāḥ agamaṃsu rājā api
translated: Having so spoken, the Bodhisatta said, “Your majesty, a king should not be too greedy. It is not right to take what belongs to another.” Thus he admonished the king, and having had the horses appraised, he made the king pay their real value. The horse-dealers, having got their money, went away well pleased. The king also,

original: bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā yathākammaṃ gato.
analyzed: bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā yathākammam gataḥ
translated: having taken the Bodhisatta’s advice to heart, went his way.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā dve assā ime dve duṭṭhabhikkhū ahesuṃ, rājā ānando, paṇḍitāmacco pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Suhanujātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā dve assā ime dve duṭṭhabhikkhū ahesum rājā ānandaḥ paṇḍitāmacco pana aham eva ahosinti  suhanu jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: When the Master had ended his lesson, he made the connexion, and identified the Birth: “At that time the two horses were the two wicked monks, the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the chief of the wise.”🔽So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,🔽The Ninth Birth Story: The Birth of Suhanu

original: [159] 9. Morajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Udetayaṃ cakkhumā ekarājāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuṃ
analyzed: cakkhumā eka rājā iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum
translated: The Birth Story of the Peacock🔽When the Sun, the One-rayed King, arose, the Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a monk who was discontented.

original: ārabbha kathesi. So hi bhikkhu bhikkhūhi satthu santikaṃ nīto “saccaṃ kira, tvaṃ
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi saḥ hi bhikkhu bhikkhūhi satthu santikam nītaḥ saccam kira tvam
translated: This monk was brought by the monks to the Teacher, and the Teacher asked him, “Is the report true that you are discontented?

original: bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhito”ti vutte “saccaṃ, bhante”ti vatvā “kiṃ disvā”ti vutte “ekaṃ alaṅkatapaṭiyattasarīraṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ iti vutte saccam bhante ti vatvā kim disvā iti vutte ekam alaṅkata paṭiyatta sarīram
translated: “I am, Reverend Sir.” “What did you see?” “I saw a woman with her body adorned and decked out.”

original: mātugāmaṃ oloketvā”ti āha. Atha naṃ satthā “bhikkhu mātugāmo nāma kasmā tumhādisānaṃ🔽cittaṃ nāluḷessati, porāṇakapaṇḍitānampi hi mātugāmassa saddaṃ sutvā satta vassasatāni
analyzed: mātugāmaṃ oloketvā iti āha atha nam satthā bhikkhu mātugāmaḥ nāma kasmā  cittam na āluḷessati porāṇaka paṇḍitānam pi hi mātugāmassa saddam sutvā satta vassa satāni
translated: “How could you, monk, be so foolish as to look at a woman?

original: asamudāciṇṇakilesā okāsaṃ labhitvā khaṇeneva samudācariṃsu. Visuddhāpi sattā saṃkilissanti,
analyzed: a samudāciṇṇa kilesāḥ okāsam labhitvā khaṇena iva samudācariṃsu visuddhāḥ api sattā saṃkilissanti
translated: Even the wise of old, when they heard the voice of a woman, had their passions aroused, and their lust, which had been dormant for seven hundred years, was stirred to its depths.

original: uttamayasasamaṅginopi āyasakyaṃ pāpuṇanti, pageva aparisuddhā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: uttama yasa samaṅginaḥ api āyasakyam pāpuṇanti pagā iva a parisuddhā iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: Even the pure are defiled, even the illustrious are brought to shame, much more the impure.” So saying, he related the following story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto morayoniyaṃ paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ morayoniyam paṭisandhim gahetvā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta took birth in the womb of a peahen.

original: aṇḍakālepi kaṇikāramakuḷavaṇṇaaṇḍakoso hutvā aṇḍaṃ bhinditvā nikkhanto suvaṇṇavaṇṇo
analyzed: aṇḍa kāle pi kaṇikāra makuḷa vaṇṇa aṇḍa kosaḥ hutvā aṇḍam bhinditvā nikkhantaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ
translated: Even while he was in the egg, his egg-shell was the color of a red kanikara flower. When he broke the shell and came forth, he was of golden hue.

original: ahosi dassanīyo pāsādiko pakkhānaṃ antare surattarājivirājito, so attano jīvitaṃ
analyzed: ahosi dassanīyaḥ pāsādiko pakkhānam antare su ratta rāji virājito so attanaḥ jīvitam
translated: He was beautiful and lovely to behold, resplendent among the birds like a king of swans. He lived on a golden peak of the Dāḍimāgiri mountain,

original: rakkhanto tisso pabbatarājiyo atikkamma catutthāya pabbatarājiyā ekasmiṃ daṇḍakahiraññapabbatatale
analyzed: rakkhantaḥ tissaḥ pabbata rājiyaḥ atikkamma catutthāya pabbata rājiyā ekasmim daṇḍaka hirañña pabbata tale
translated: having crossed over three mountain ranges in order to save his life. He made his home on the fourth mountain range, on a golden peak of the Dāḍimāgiri mountain.

original: vāsaṃ kappesi. So pabhātāya rattiyā pabbatamatthake nisinno sūriyaṃ uggacchantaṃ
analyzed: vāsam kappesi saḥ pabhātāya rattiyā pabbata matthake nisinnaḥ sūriyam uggacchantam
translated: In the morning, he would sit on the top of the mountain and watch the sun rise.

original: oloketvā attano gocarabhūmiyaṃ rakkhāvaraṇatthāya brahmamantaṃ bandhanto “udetaya”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: oloketvā attanaḥ gocara bhūmiyam rakkhā āvaraṇa atthāya brahmamantam bandhantaḥ udetayanti ādim āha
translated: Then, in order to protect his domain, he would recite the Brahma-mantra, beginning with the words “Udetaya.”

original: “Udetayaṃ cakkhumā ekarājā,
analyzed: eka rājā
translated: “May the one-eyed king rise up,

original: Harissavaṇṇo pathavippabhāso;
analyzed: harissa vaṇṇaḥ pathavi pabhāsaḥ
translated: golden-hued, illuminating the earth.

original: Taṃ taṃ namassāmi harissavaṇṇaṃ pathavippabhāsaṃ,
analyzed: tam tam namassāmi hari ssavaṇṇam pathavi pabhāsam
translated: I pay homage to you, golden-hued, illuminating the earth.

original: Tayājja guttā viharemu divasa”nti.🔽Tattha udetīti pācīnalokadhātuto uggacchati. Cakkhumāti sakalacakkavāḷavāsīnaṃ andhakāraṃ
analyzed: guttāḥ  tattha udeti iti pācīna lokadhātutaḥ uggacchati cakkhumā ti sakala cakkavāḷa vāsīnam andhakāram
translated: Today, protected by you, may we live out the day.”

original: vidhamitvā cakkhupaṭilābhakaraṇena yaṃ tena tesaṃ dinnaṃ cakkhu, tena cakkhunā cakkhumā.
analyzed: vidhamitvā cakkhu paṭilābha karaṇena yam tena tesam dinnam cakkhu tena cakkhunā cakkhumā
translated: Here, “rising” means rising from the eastern world-sphere. “One-eyed” means that he gives eyes to all those who live in the world-sphere by dispelling the darkness and causing the eyes to appear. Therefore, he is “one-eyed” because of the eyes he gives to them.

original: Ekarājāti sakalacakkavāḷe ālokakarānaṃ antare seṭṭhavisiṭṭhaṭṭhena ekarājā. Harissavaṇṇoti
analyzed: eka rājā ati sakala cakkavāḷe āloka karānam antare seṭṭha visiṭṭha ṭṭhena eka rājā harissavaṇṇoti
translated: Sole King, the best and most excellent of all those who shed light over the whole world. Golden-hued,

original: harisamānavaṇṇo, suvaṇṇavaṇṇoti attho. Pathavippabhāsoti pathaviyā pabhāso. Taṃ taṃ
analyzed: hari samāna vaṇṇaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇo ti attho pathavi pabhāsaḥ tam tam
translated: of the same color as the golden-hued, the meaning is, of the color of gold. Light of the earth, the light of the earth. I pay homage to him,

original: namassāmīti tasmā taṃ evarūpaṃ bhavantaṃ namassāmi vandāmi. Tayājja guttā viharemu
analyzed: namaḥ sāmi iti tasmai tam evarūpam bhavantam namaḥ sāmi vandāmi tayā ajja guttāḥ viharemu
translated: therefore I pay homage to you, I worship you, O Lord. May we live today, protected by you,

original: divasanti tayā ajja rakkhitā gopitā hutvā imaṃ divasaṃ catuiriyāpathavihārena sukhaṃ vihareyyāma.
analyzed: tayā ajja rakkhitāḥ gopitāḥ hutvā imam divasam catuiriyāpatha vihārena sukham vihareyyāma
translated: may we live happily today, by the four postures of the body, protected and guarded by you.

original: Evaṃ bodhisatto imāya gāthāya sūriyaṃ namassitvā dutiyagāthāya atīte parinibbute buddhe ceva buddhaguṇe ca namassati.
analyzed: evam bodhisattaḥ imāya gāthāya sūriyam namassitvā dutiya gāthāya atīte parinibbute buddhe ca iva buddha guṇe ca namassati
translated: Thus the Bodhisatta, having paid homage to the sun with this verse, in the second verse pays homage to the Buddhas of the past, who have attained final Nibbana, and to the qualities of the Buddhas.

original: “Ye brāhmaṇā vedagū sabbadhamme, te me namo te ca maṃ pālayantu;
analyzed: ye brāhmaṇāḥ vedagū sabba dhamme te me namaḥ te ca mama pālayantu
translated: “Those Brahmins who are knowers of the Vedas in all things, to them I pay homage, may they protect me.

original: Namatthu buddhānaṃ namatthu bodhiyā, namo vimuttānaṃ namo vimuttiyā;
analyzed: namatthu buddhānam namatthu bodhiyā namaḥ vimuttānam namaḥ vimuttiyai
translated: Homage to the Buddhas, homage to the Enlightened Ones, homage to the Liberated Ones, homage to Liberation.

original: Imaṃ so parittaṃ katvā, moro carati esanā”ti.
analyzed: imam saḥ parittam katvā moraḥ carati
translated: Having made this protection, the peacock wanders in search of food.”

original: Tattha ye brāhmaṇāti ye bāhitapāpā visuddhibrāhmaṇā. Vedagūti vedānaṃ pāraṃ gatātipi🔽vedagū, vedehi pāraṃ gatātipi vedagū. Idha pana sabbe saṅkhatāsaṅkhatadhamme vidite
analyzed: tattha ye brāhmaṇāḥ ati ye visuddhi brāhmaṇāḥ vedagūti vedānam pāram gatā  vedagū vedehi pāram gatā atipi vedagū idha pana sabbe saṅkhata asaṅkhata dhamme vidite
translated: Herein, those who are Brahmins are those who have expelled evil and are purified, Brahmins by birth.🔽They are also called “vedagū” because they have gone to the end of the Vedas,🔽or because they have gone beyond the Vedas. But here they are called “vedagū” because they have gone by making clear to themselves all things, whether formed or unformed,

original: pākaṭe katvā gatāti vedagū. Tenevāha “sabbadhamme”ti. Sabbe khandhāyatanadhātudhamme
analyzed: pākaṭe katvā gatā ati vedagū tena iva āha sabba dhamma iti sabbe khandha āyatana dhātu dhamme
translated: by means of their specific and general characteristics. Hence it is said: “All things” .🔽They have gone by making clear to themselves all things classed as aggregates, bases, elements,

original: salakkhaṇasāmaññalakkhaṇavasena attano ñāṇassa vidite pākaṭe katvā gatā, tiṇṇaṃ mārānaṃ
analyzed: salakkhaṇa sāmañña lakkhaṇa vasena attanaḥ ñāṇassa vidite pākaṭe katvā gatā tiṇṇam mārānam
translated: by means of their specific and general characteristics. They have gone by crushing the heads of the three defilements,

original: matthakaṃ madditvā dasasahassilokadhātuṃ unnādetvā bodhitale sammāsambodhiṃ patvā
analyzed: matthakam madditvā dasa sahassi lokadhātum unnādetvā bodhi tale sammāsambodhim patvā
translated: by making the ten-thousandfold world system resound, by attaining perfect Supreme Enlightenment on the Bodhi throne,

original: saṃsāraṃ vā atikkantāti attho. Te me namoti te mama imaṃ namakkāraṃ paṭicchantu.
analyzed: saṃsāram vai atikkantā ati te me namaḥ iti te mama imam namakkāram paṭicchantu
translated: by going beyond the round of rebirths, is the meaning. Let them accept my homage: let them accept this homage of mine.

original: Te ca maṃ pālayantūti evaṃ mayā namassitā ca te bhagavanto maṃ pālentu rakkhantu
analyzed: te ca mama pālayantu uti evam mayā namassitā ca te bhagavantaḥ mam pālentu rakkhantu
translated: And let them guard me: let these Blessed Ones, thus honoured by me, guard me, protect me,

original: gopentu. Namatthu buddhānaṃ namatthu bodhiyā, namo vimuttānaṃ namo vimuttiyāti ayaṃ
analyzed: gopentu namatthu buddhānam namatthu bodhiyā namaḥ vimuttānam namaḥ vimuttiyā ati ayaṃ
translated: keep me safe. Homage to the Enlightened Ones, homage to the Enlightening, homage to the Liberated, homage to the Liberating:

original: mama namakkāro atītānaṃ parinibbutānaṃ buddhānaṃ atthu, tesaññeva catūsu ca maggesu
analyzed: mama namakkāraḥ atītānam parinibbutānam buddhānam atthu tesaññeva catūsu ca maggesu
translated: The homage is for the sake of the Buddhas of the past who have attained final Nibbāna, and for the sake of their four paths and

original: catūsu phalesu ñāṇasaṅkhātāya bodhiyā atthu, tathā tesaññeva arahattaphalavimuttiyā🔽vimuttānaṃ atthu, yā ca nesaṃ tadaṅgavimutti vikkhambhanavimutti samucchedavimutti
analyzed: catūsu phalesu ñāṇa saṅkhātāya bodhiyā atthu tathā tesaññeva arahatta phala vimuttiyā  vimuttānam atthu yā ca nesam tat aṅga vimutti vikkhambhana vimutti samuccheda vimutti
translated: four fruits. It is for the sake of the enlightenment that consists in the knowledge of those Buddhas, and for the sake of their deliverance, which is the fruit of arahantship.

original: paṭippassaddhivimutti nissaraṇavimuttīti pañcavidhā vimutti, tassā nesaṃ vimuttiyāpi
analyzed: paṭippassaddhi vimutti nissaraṇa vimutti iti pañcavidhā vimutti tassā na īsam vimuttiyā api
translated: It is for the sake of the fivefold deliverance of those who are delivered by the fruit of arahantship: deliverance by the abandoning of the fetters, deliverance by the suppression of the defilements, deliverance by the cutting off of the fetters, deliverance by the tranquilization of the conditions, and deliverance by the relinquishment of the aggregates.🔽The homage is for the sake of that deliverance of theirs.

original: ayaṃ mayhaṃ namakkāro atthūti. “Imaṃ so parittaṃ katvā, moro carati esanā”ti idaṃ
analyzed: ayam mayham namakkāraḥ imam so parittam katvā moraḥ carati idam
translated: Having made this safeguard, the peacock roams about in search of food.

original: pana padadvayaṃ satthā abhisambuddho hutvā āha. Tassattho – bhikkhave, so moro imaṃ
analyzed: pana pada dvayam satthā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā āha tassa atthaḥ bhikkhave saḥ moraḥ imaṃ
translated: This pair of lines was uttered by the Master after his enlightenment. The meaning is this:

original: parittaṃ imaṃ rakkhaṃ katvā attano gocarabhūmiyaṃ pupphaphalādīnaṃ atthāya nānappakārāya esanāya carati.
analyzed: parittam imam rakkham katvā attanaḥ gocara bhūmiyam puppha phala ādīnam atthāya nānappakārāya esanāya carati
translated: Monks, this peacock, having made this safeguard, this protection, roams about in search of various kinds of food, such as flowers, fruits, etc., in his own range.

original: Evaṃ divasaṃ caritvā sāyaṃ pabbatamatthake nisīditvā atthaṅgataṃ sūriyaṃ olokento
analyzed: evam divasam caritvā sāyam pabbata matthake nisīditvā atthaṅgatam sūriyam olokento
translated: Having roamed about thus during the day, he sits in the evening on the top of a rock and looks at the setting sun.

original: buddhaguṇe āvajjetvā nivāsaṭṭhāne rakkhāvaraṇatthāya puna brahmamantaṃ bandhanto🔽“apetaya”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: buddha guṇe āvajjetvā nivāsa ṭṭhāne rakkhā āvaraṇa tthāya puna brahmamantam bandhantaḥ  apetayanti ādim āha
translated: and having brought to mind the Buddha’s special qualities, he bound the Brahma-mantra again for the purpose of protection and guarding in the dwelling place,

original: “Apetayaṃ cakkhumā ekarājā, harissavaṇṇo pathavippabhāso;
analyzed: cakkhumā eka rājā harissavaṇṇo pathavi pabhāsaḥ
translated: saying: “Apetayaṃ cakkhumā ekarājā, harissavaṇṇo pathavippabhāso;

original: Taṃ taṃ namassāmi harissavaṇṇaṃ pathavippabhāsaṃ, tayājja guttā viharemu rattiṃ.
analyzed: tam tam namassāmi hari ssavaṇṇam pathavi pabhāsam tayā ajja guttāḥ viharemu rattim
translated: Taṃ taṃ namassāmi harissavaṇṇaṃ pathavippabhāsaṃ, tayājja guttā viharemu rattiṃ.

original: “Ye brāhmaṇā vedagū sabbadhamme, te me namo te ca maṃ pālayantu;
analyzed: ye brāhmaṇāḥ vedagū sabba dhamme te me namaḥ te ca mama pālayantu
translated: “Ye brāhmaṇā vedagū sabbadhamme, te me namo te ca maṃ pālayantu;

original: Namatthu buddhānaṃ namatthu bodhiyā, namo vimuttānaṃ namo vimuttiyā;
analyzed: namatthu buddhānam namatthu bodhiyā namaḥ vimuttānam namaḥ vimuttiyai
translated: Namatthu buddhānaṃ namatthu bodhiyā, namo vimuttānaṃ namo vimuttiyā;

original: Imaṃ so parittaṃ katvā, moro vāsamakappayī”ti.
analyzed: imam saḥ parittam katvā moraḥ vāsam akappayi iti
translated: Imaṃ so parittaṃ katvā, moro vāsamakappayī”ti.

original: Tattha apetīti apayāti atthaṃ gacchati. Imaṃ so parittaṃ katvā, moro vāsamakappayīti
analyzed: tattha apeti iti apayāti attham gacchati imam saḥ parittam katvā moraḥ vāsam akappayi iti
translated: Herein, apetī means it goes away, it perishes. Imaṃ so parittaṃ katvā, moro vāsamakappayī means

original: idampi abhisambuddho hutvā āha. Tassattho – bhikkhave, so moro imaṃ parittaṃ imaṃ
analyzed: idam pi abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā āha tassa atthaḥ bhikkhave saḥ moraḥ imam parittam imam
translated: after becoming fully enlightened he said this. Its meaning is this:

original: rakkhaṃ katvā attano nivāsaṭṭhāne vāsaṃ kappayittha, tassa rattiṃ vā divā vā imassa
analyzed: rakkham katvā attanaḥ nivāsa ṭṭhāne vāsam kappayittha tassa rattim vā divā vā imassa
translated: Monks, that peacock made this protection, this guarding, and he made a dwelling place in his dwelling place. Whether by night or by day

original: parittassānubhāvena neva bhayaṃ, na lomahaṃso ahosi.
analyzed: parittassa anubhāvena nā iva bhayam na lomahaṃsaḥ ahosi
translated: and neither fear nor trembling came over him.

original: Atheko bārāṇasiyā avidūre nesādagāmavāsī nesādo himavantapadese vicaranto tasmiṃ
analyzed: atha ekaḥ bārāṇasiyāḥ avidūre nesāda gāma vāsī nesādaḥ himavanta padese vicarantaḥ tasmin
translated: Now a certain hunter who lived in the village of Nesāda, not far from Benares, while wandering in the Himālaya country,

original: daṇḍakahiraññapabbatamatthake nisinnaṃ bodhisattaṃ disvā āgantvā puttassa ārocesi.
analyzed: daṇḍaka hirañña pabbata matthake nisinnam bodhisattam disvā āgantvā puttassa ārocesi
translated: saw the Bodhisatta sitting on the top of the Golden Rock in the Daṇḍaka forest, and went and told his son.

original: Athekadivasaṃ khemā nāma bārāṇasirañño devī supinena suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ moraṃ dhammaṃ🔽desentaṃ disvā pabuddhakāle rañño ārocesi – “ahaṃ, deva, suvaṇṇavaṇṇassa morassa
analyzed: atha eka divasam khemā nāma bārāṇasi raññaḥ devī supinena suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam moram dhammaṃ  desentam disvā pabuddha kāle raññaḥ ārocesi aham deva suvaṇṇa vaṇṇassa morassa
translated: One day a queen of Benares, named Khema, in a dream saw a peacock of golden hue preaching the Law,🔽and when she awoke she told the king, saying, “Your majesty, I am desirous of hearing the Law from a golden-hued peacock.” The king asked his ministers,

original: dhammaṃ sotukāmā”ti. Rājā amacce pucchi. Amaccā “brāhmaṇā jānissantī”ti āhaṃsu. Brāhmaṇā
analyzed: dhammam sotu kāmā ati rājā amacce pucchi amaccāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ jānissanti iti āhaṃsu brāhmaṇāḥ
translated: and they said, “The Brāhmans will know.” The Brāhmans,

original: taṃ sutvā “suvaṇṇavaṇṇā morā nāma hontī”ti vatvā “kattha hontī”ti vutte “nesādā jānissantī”ti
analyzed: tam sutvā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇāḥ morāḥ nāma honti iti vatvā kattha honti iti vutte nesādāḥ jānissanti iti
translated: hearing the matter, said, “There are golden-hued peacocks.” “Where are they?” “The hunters will know.”

original: āhaṃsu. Rājā nesāde sannipātetvā pucchi. Atha so nesādaputto “āma, mahārāja, daṇḍakahiraññapabbato
analyzed: āhaṃsu rājā nesāde sannipātetvā pucchi atha saḥ nesāda putto āma mahā rāja daṇḍaka hirañña pabbato
translated: The king assembled the hunters and asked them. Then the hunter’s son said, “Yes, your majesty, on the Golden Rock in the Daṇḍaka forest,

original: nāma atthi, tattha suvaṇṇavaṇṇo moro vasatī”ti āha. “Tena hi taṃ moraṃ amāretvā bandhitvāva
analyzed: nāma atthi tattha suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ moraḥ vasati iti āha tena hi tam moram a māretvā bandhitvā ava
translated: “There is such a place, and a peacock of golden hue lives there.” “Well then, catch that peacock without killing it,

original: ānehī”ti. Nesādo gantvā tassa gocarabhūmiyaṃ pāse oḍḍesi. Morena akkantaṭṭhānepi
analyzed: ānehi iti nesādaḥ gantvā tassa gocara bhūmiyam pāse oḍḍesi morena akkanta ṭṭhāne pi
translated: and bring it here.” The fowler went and set a snare in the peacock’s feeding-ground. But when the peacock stepped on the spot where the snare was,

analyzed: pāsaḥ na sañcarati nesādaḥ gaṇhitum a sakkontaḥ satta vassāni vicaritvā tattha iva kālam akāsi
translated: the snare did not move. The fowler was unable to catch the peacock. He wandered about for seven years and died right there.

original: Khemāpi devī patthitaṃ alabhamānā kālamakāsi.
analyzed: khemā api devī patthitam a labhamānā kālam akāsi
translated: Queen Khemā, not receiving what she had asked for, died.

original: Rājā “moraṃ me nissāya devī kālakatā”ti kujjhitvā “himavantapadese daṇḍakahiraññapabbato🔽nāma atthi, tattha suvaṇṇavaṇṇo moro vasati, ye tassa maṃsaṃ khādanti, te ajarā amarā
analyzed: rājā moram me nissāya devī kālakatā ati kujjhitvā himavanta padese daṇḍaka hirañña pabbato  nāma atthi tattha suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ moraḥ vasati ye tassa maṃsam khādanti te ajarāḥ amarā
translated: The king, thinking, “My queen died because of the peacock,” became angry and said, “In the land of the Himalayas there is a mountain of gold called Daṇḍaka,

original: hontī”ti akkharaṃ suvaṇṇapaṭṭe likhāpetvā suvaṇṇapaṭṭaṃ mañjūsāya nikkhipāpesi. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: honti iti akkharam suvaṇṇa paṭṭe likhāpetvā suvaṇṇa paṭṭam mañjūsāya nikkhipāpesi tasmin
translated: on which a peacock of golden hue lives. Those who eat its flesh become ageless and immortal.” He had this statement written on a golden plate and had the golden plate placed in a casket.

original: kālakate añño rājā rajjaṃ patvā suvaṇṇapaṭṭaṃ vācetvā “ajaro amaro bhavissāmī”ti
analyzed: kālakate aññaḥ rājā rajjam patvā suvaṇṇa paṭṭam vācetvā ajaraḥ amaraḥ bhavissāmi iti
translated: When he died, another king became king. He had the golden plate read and thought, “I will become ageless and immortal.”

original: aññaṃ nesādaṃ pesesi. Sopi gantvā bodhisattaṃ gahetuṃ asakkonto tattheva kālamakāsi.
analyzed: aññam nesādam pesesi saḥ api gantvā bodhisattam gahetum a sakkontaḥ tattha iva kālam akāsi
translated: and sent another fowler. He too went, but was unable to catch the Bodhisatta, and died on the spot.

original: Eteneva niyāmena cha rājaparivaṭṭā gatā. Atha sattamo rājā rajjaṃ patvā ekaṃ nesādaṃ
analyzed: etena iva niyāmena cha rāja parivaṭṭāḥ gatāḥ atha sattamaḥ rājā rajjam patvā ekam nesādam
translated: In this way six kings passed away. Then the seventh king came to the throne, and sent a fowler

original: pahiṇi. So gantvā bodhisattena akkantaṭṭhānepi pāsassa asañcaraṇabhāvaṃ, attano parittaṃ🔽katvā gocarabhūmigamanabhāvañcassa ñatvā paccantaṃ otaritvā ekaṃ moriṃ gahetvā yathā🔽hatthatāḷasaddena naccati, accharāsaddena ca vassati, evaṃ sikkhāpetvā taṃ ādāya
analyzed: pahiṇi saḥ gantvā bodhisattena akkanta ṭṭhāne pi pāsassa a sañcaraṇa bhāvam attano parittam  katvā gocara bhūmi gamana bhāvañca assa ñatvā paccantam otaritvā ekam morim gahetvā yathā  hattha tāḷa saddena naccati accharā saddena ca vassati evam sikkhāpetvā tam ādāya
translated: to catch the Bodhisatta. He went, and seeing that the snare was not disturbed where the Bodhisatta had stood, and knowing that the Bodhisatta had gone to his feeding-ground after reciting his protection charm,🔽he went to the frontier country, and caught a peacock, and trained it to dance at the sound of a hand-clapping, and to rain at the sound of a flute. Then taking it with him,

original: gantvā morena paritte akate pātoyeva pāsayaṭṭhiyo ropetvā pāse oḍḍetvā moriṃ vassāpesi.
analyzed: gantvā morena paritte a kate pātoyā iva pāsa yaṭṭhiyo ropetvā pāse oḍḍetvā morim vassāpesi
translated: he went and planted the snare-stakes in a place where the peacock’s charm was not effective, and set the snare, and made the peacock rain.

original: Moro visabhāgaṃ mātugāmasaddaṃ sutvā kilesāturo hutvā parittaṃ kātuṃ asakkuṇitvā
analyzed: moraḥ visa bhāgam mātu gāma saddam sutvā kilesa āturaḥ hutvā parittam kātum a sakkuṇitvā
translated: The peacock, hearing the sound of a woman, was overcome with passion, and unable to recite his charm,

analyzed: gantvā pāse bajjhi atha nam nesādaḥ gahetvā gantvā bārāṇasi raññaḥ adāsi
translated: went into the snare and was caught. Then the fowler took him, and went and gave him to the king of Bārāṇasī.

original: Rājā tassa rūpasampattiṃ disvā tuṭṭhamānaso āsanaṃ dāpesi. Bodhisatto paññattāsane
analyzed: rājā tassa rūpa sampattim disvā tuṭṭha mānasaḥ āsanam dāpesi bodhisatto paññatta āsane
translated: The king, seeing his beauty, was pleased, and had a seat prepared for him. The Bodhisatta sat down on the seat prepared for him,

analyzed: nisīditvā mahā rāja kasmai mama pucchi ye kira tava maṃsam khādanti
translated: and asked, “Great king, why did you have me seized?” “They say that those who eat your flesh

analyzed: etam mātā alayam tava ati etam gāmantam ukkāra ṭṭhānam āmaka susāna ṭṭhānam ca tava mātu  ālayam geham vasanaṭṭhānam tattha gacchāhi iti evam tam tat jetvā gacchatha naṃ

analyzed: santappitaḥ sappinā pāyasena kicchākatam paṇṇa kuṭim adayhi iti  na taṇhā santhavā api ca mitta santhavā api ca ati duvidhā api
translated: He has burned my leaf-hut, which I built with ghee-rice and rice-milk.”🔽Herein, there is no greater evil than friendship means that there is no other evil greater than the two kinds of friendship, namely, the friendship of craving and the friendship of a scoundrel.

original: santhavā paraṃ uttari aññaṃ pāpataraṃ natthi, lāmakataraṃ nāma natthīti attho. Yo

translated: “There is no evil worse than friendship with a wicked man.”🔽Why is that? “For though he was satisfied with milk and rice-gruel,

translated: he burned my leaf-hut.” The meaning is: “Though I satisfied him with ghee and rice-gruel,

analyzed: ayam aggi mayā kicchena katam paṇṇa sālam jhāpesi iti attho
translated: this fire burns my leaf-hut which I built with difficulty.”

analyzed: saḥ evam vatvā na me tayā mitta dubbhinā atthaḥ iti tam aggim udakena nibbāpetvā sākhāhi
translated: After saying this, he extinguished the fire with water, thinking, “I have no use for you, a betrayer of friends.” He then pulled down the leaf-hut with branches,

analyzed: ca mukham lehantim disvā sappurisehi saddhim santhavā param seyyaḥ nāma natthi iti
translated: Thinking, “There is nothing better than friendship with good people,”

analyzed: sīhassa byagghassa ca dīpino ca sāmā mukham lehati santhavena ati

original: [163] 3. Susīmajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Kāḷā migā setadantā tavīmeti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto chandakadānaṃ ārabbha🔽kathesi. Sāvatthiyañhi kadāci ekameva kulaṃ buddhappamukhassa bhikkhusaṅghassa dānaṃ

original: deti, kadāci aññatitthiyānaṃ deti, kadāci gaṇabandhanena bahū ekato hutvā denti,

translated: The black deer with white tusks, the king of the forest. This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a gift of choice. For at Sāvatthi, on one occasion, a single family gave a feast to the Congregation of Monks presided over by the Buddha, on another occasion to the sectaries, on another occasion many together gave a feast by subscription.

original: kadāci vīthisabhāgena, kadāci sakalanagaravāsino chandakaṃ saṃharitvā dānaṃ denti.

analyzed: imasmin pana kāle sakala nagara vāsino chandakam saṃharitvā sabba parikkhāra dānam sajjetvā

analyzed: sāyanha samaye bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam sannipatitvā katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso  añña titthiya sāvakāḥ buddhānam dātabba dānassa antarāya karaṇa tthāya vā āyamantā api antarāyam

analyzed: gantvā eka rattena iva tayaḥ vede ca hatthi suttam ca uggaṇhitvā puna divase āgantvā catutthe

translated: The teacher asked him, “Where do you come from, my son?” “From Bārāṇasī, teacher.” “For what purpose?”

translated: “To learn from you the Three Vedas and the Science of Elephants.” “Very well, my son, learn.”
