translated: they reported to the king. The king said, “Catch just one vulture, and I’ll get everything back.” He had nets and snares

original: dassessāmā”ti nenti. Bārāṇasiseṭṭhi rājupaṭṭhānaṃ gacchanto te manusse gijjhaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: dassessāma iti nenti bārāṇasi seṭṭhi rāja upaṭṭhānam gacchantaḥ te manusse gijjham gahetvā
translated: spread here and there. The vulture who fed his mother was caught in a snare. They took him, saying, “We’ll show him to the king.” The chief merchant of Bārāṇasī, going to wait on the king, saw those men taking the vulture

original: gacchante disvā “mā imaṃ gijjhaṃ bādhayiṃsū”ti saddhiññeva agamāsi. Gijjhaṃ rañño
analyzed: gacchante disvā mā imam gijjham bādhayiṃsu iti saddhiññā iva agamāsi gijjham rañño
translated: and going. “Don’t bother this vulture,” he said, and went along with them. The vulture

original: dassesuṃ. Atha naṃ rājā pucchi – “tumhe nagaraṃ vilumpitvā vatthādīni gaṇhathā”ti.
analyzed: atha nam rājā pucchi tumhe nagaram vilumpitvā vattha ādīni gaṇhatha ati
translated: The king asked them, “Did you plunder the city and take the goods?”

original: “Āma, mahārājā”ti. “Kassa tāni dinnānī”ti? “Bārāṇasiseṭṭhissā”ti. “Kiṃkāraṇā”ti?
analyzed: āma mahā rāja ati kassa tāni dinnāni iti bārāṇasi seṭṭhissa ati kiṃkāraṇā ati
translated: “Yes, great king.” “To whom did you give them?” “To the chief merchant of Bārāṇasī.” “Why?”

original: “Amhākaṃ tena jīvitaṃ dvinnaṃ, upakārassa nāma paccupakāraṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati, tasmā
analyzed: amhākam tena jīvitam dvinnam upakārassa nāma paccupakāram kātum vaṭṭati tasmā
translated: “He saved our lives. It is right to repay a benefactor. Therefore

original: adamhā”ti. Atha naṃ rājā “gijjhā kira yojanasatamatthake ṭhatvā kuṇapaṃ passanti,
analyzed: adamha ati atha nam rājā gijjhā kira yojana sata matthake ṭhatvā kuṇapam passanti
translated: we gave them to him.” Then the king said, “It is said that vultures see a corpse a hundred leagues away,

original: kasmā tvaṃ attano oḍḍitaṃ pāsaṃ na passasī”ti vatvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kasmā tvam attanaḥ oḍḍitam pāsam na passasi iti vatvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: but why don’t you see the noose you have thrown over yourself?” and uttered the first stanza:

original: “Yaṃ nu gijjho yojanasataṃ, kuṇapāni avekkhati;
analyzed: yam nu gijjhaḥ yojana satam kuṇapāni avekkhati
translated: “Why is it that the vulture, though he sees a corpse a hundred leagues away,

original: Kasmā jālañca pāsañca, āsajjāpi na bujjhasī”ti.🔽Tattha yanti nipātamattaṃ, nūti nāmatthe nipāto. Gijjho nāma yojanasataṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: kasmai jālañca pāsañca āsajja api na bujjhasi iti  tattha yanti nipāta mattam nu uti nāma atthe nipātaḥ gijjhaḥ nāma yojana satam atikkamitvā
translated: Does not see the net and noose that he himself has entered?”🔽Here the word “why” is merely an expression of wonder. The vulture sees corpses that are a hundred leagues away,

original: ṭhitāni kuṇapāni avekkhati, passatīti attho. Āsajjāpīti āsādetvāpi, sampāpuṇitvāpīti
analyzed: ṭhitāni kuṇapāni avekkhati passati iti attho āsajja api iti āsādetvā api sampāpuṇitvā api iti
translated: that is, he looks at them. “Though he has entered” means though he has approached, though he has reached.

original: attho. “Tvaṃ attano atthāya oḍḍitaṃ jālañca pāsañca patvāpi kasmā na bujjhasī”ti pucchi.
analyzed: attho tvam attanaḥ atthāya oḍḍitam jālañca pāsañca patvā api kasmai na bujjhasi iti pucchi
translated: “You are a bird, and you have been caught in a net and a snare set for yourself. Why do you not understand?”

original: Gijjho tassa vacanaṃ sutvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: gijjhaḥ tassa vacanam sutvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: When the vulture heard this, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Yadā parābhavo hoti, poso jīvitasaṅkhaye;
analyzed: yadā parābhavaḥ posaḥ jīvita saṅkhaye
translated: When a man is in misfortune, when his life is ebbing away,

original: Atha jālañca pāsañca, āsajjāpi na bujjhatī”ti.
analyzed: atha jālañca pāsañca āsajja api na bujjhati iti
translated: Then he does not understand, though he be caught in net and snare.

original: Tattha parābhavoti vināso. Posoti satto.🔽Gijjhassa vacanaṃ sutvā rājā seṭṭhiṃ pucchi – “saccaṃ kira, mahāseṭṭhi, gijjhehi🔽tumhākaṃ gehe vatthādīni ābhatānī”ti. “Saccaṃ, devā”ti. “Kahaṃ tānī”ti? “Deva, mayā🔽tāni sabbāni visuṃ ṭhapitāni, yaṃ yesaṃ santakaṃ, taṃ tesaṃ dassāmi, imaṃ gijjhaṃ
analyzed: tattha parābhavaḥ ati vināsaḥ posaḥ ti satto  gijjhassa vacanam sutvā rājā seṭṭhim pucchi saccam kira mahā seṭṭhi gijjhehi  tumhākam gehe vattha ādīni ābhatāni iti saccam deva ati kaham tāni iti deva mayā  tāni sabbāni visum ṭhapitāni yam yesam santakam tam tesam dassāmi imam gijjham
translated: Herein, misfortune means destruction. A man means a being.

original: vissajjethā”ti gijjhaṃ vissajjāpetvā mahāseṭṭhiṃ sabbesaṃ santakāni dāpesi.
analyzed: vissajjetha ati gijjham vissajjāpetvā mahāseṭṭhim sabbesam santakāni dāpesi
translated: When the vulture had spoken thus, the king asked the treasurer, “Is it true, great treasurer, that the vultures have carried off your goods?” “It is true, your majesty.” “Where are they?” “Your majesty, I have set them all aside separately. I will give to each what belongs to him. Let this vulture be set free.” So the great treasurer had the vulture set free, and gave to each man what belonged to him.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths clear, and identified the Birth: at the conclusion,

original: mātuposakabhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā rājā ānando ahosi, bārāṇasiseṭṭhi
analyzed: mātu uposaka bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā rājā ānandaḥ ahosi bārāṇasi seṭṭhi
translated: The lay-disciple was established in the fruit of Stream-Entry. “At that time the king was Ānanda, the merchant of Bārāṇasī was Sāriputta, and I myself was the vulture who was a lay-disciple.”

original: sāriputto, mātuposakagijjho pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: sāriputto mātu uposaka gijjhaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: So said the Teacher.

original: Gijjhajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: gijjha jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: The explanation of the Vulture Birth-Story is the fourth.

original: [165] 5. Nakulajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nakula jātaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Nakula Birth-Story

original: Saddhiṃ katvā amittenāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto seṇibhaṇḍanaṃ ārabbha kathesi.🔽Vatthu heṭṭhā uragajātake kathitasadisameva. Idhāpi satthā “na, bhikkhave, ime dve
analyzed: saddhim katvā amittena ati idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ seṇi bhaṇḍanam ārabbha kathesi  vatthu heṭṭhā uraga jātake kathita sadisam eva idha api satthā na bhikkhave ime dve
translated: “Having made peace with his enemies,” etc. — this was told by the Teacher while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a quarrel between Seṇiya and Bhaṇḍu.

original: mahāmattā idāneva mayā samaggā katā, pubbepāhaṃ ime samagge akāsiṃyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: mahāmattā idānā iva mayā samaggā katā pubbe pā aham ime samagge vatvā atītam āhari
translated: The story is the same as that of the Uraga Birth-Story below. Here also the Teacher said, “Monks, these two ministers were not reconciled by me only now, but formerly also I reconciled them.” So saying, he related the story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto ekasmiṃ gāmake brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto ekasmin gāmake brāhmaṇa kule
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a brāhmaṇa family in a certain village in the kingdom of Bārāṇasī, which was ruled by King Brahmadatta.

original: nibbattitvā vayappatto takkasilāyaṃ sabbasippāni uggahetvā gharāvāsaṃ pahāya isipabbajjaṃ
analyzed: nibbattitvā vaya pattaḥ takkasilāyam sabba sippāni uggahetvā ghara āvāsam pahāya isi pabbajjam
translated: Having attained maturity, he mastered all the arts at Takkasilā, renounced the world, and became a monk.

original: pabbajitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā uñchācariyāya vanamūlaphalāhāro🔽himavantapadese vāsaṃ kappesi. Tassa caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ ekasmiṃ vammike nakulo, tasseva
analyzed: pabbajitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyaḥ ca nibbattetvā uñchā cariyāya vana mūla phala āhāraḥ  himavanta padese vāsam kappesi tassa caṅkamana koṭiyam ekasmin vammike nakulaḥ tassa iva
translated: After he had gone forth, and had attained the super-knowledges and the meditations, he lived on alms, and subsisted on the wild fruits and roots of the forest.🔽He made his home in the Himalayas. At the end of his walk he made his nest in a termite-mound,

original: santike ekasmiṃ rukkhabile sappo ca vāsaṃ kappesi. Te ubhopi ahinakulā niccakālaṃ
analyzed: santike ekasmim rukkha bile sappaḥ ca vāsam kappesi te ubho pi ahi nakulā niccakālam
translated: and near him a snake made his home in a tree-hollow. Both of them were of the snake-race, and they were always quarrelling.

original: kalahaṃ karonti. Bodhisatto tesaṃ kalahe ādīnavañca mettābhāvanāya ca ānisaṃsaṃ kathetvā
analyzed: kalaham karonti bodhisatto tesam kalahe ādīnavam ca mettā bhāvanāya ca ānisaṃsam kathetvā
translated: The Bodhisatta told them the danger of quarrelling, and the benefit of the practice of loving-kindness,

original: “kalahaṃ nāma akatvā samaggavāsaṃ vasituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti ovaditvā ubhopi te samagge akāsi.
analyzed: kalaham nāma a katvā samagga vāsam vasitum vaṭṭati iti ovaditvā ubhau api te samagge akāsi
translated: and admonished them, saying: “It is not right to live together in discord. You ought to live in harmony.”🔽So he brought them to live in harmony.

original: Atha sappassa bahinikkhantakāle nakulo caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ vammikassa biladvāre sīsaṃ
analyzed: atha sappassa bahi nikkhanta kāle nakulaḥ caṅkamana koṭiyam vammikassa bila dvāre sīsam
translated: Then when the snake came out, the mongoose put his head out at the mouth of the hole in the termite-mound at the end of the walk,

original: nīharitvā mukhaṃ vivaritvā nipanno assasanto passasanto niddaṃ upagañchi. Bodhisatto
analyzed: nīharitvā mukham vivaritvā nipannaḥ assasantaḥ passasantaḥ niddam upagañchi bodhisatto
translated: opened his mouth, and fell asleep, breathing in and out. The Bodhisatta

original: taṃ tathā niddāyamānaṃ disvā “kiṃ nu kho te nissāya bhayaṃ uppanna”nti pucchanto
analyzed: tam tathā niddāyamānam disvā kim nu kho te nissāya bhayam uppannanti pucchantaḥ
translated: saw him sleeping thus, and asked him: “What fear have you that you should sleep thus?”

original: paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: And he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Sandhiṃ katvā amittena, aṇḍajena jalābuja;
analyzed: sandhim katvā amittena aṇḍa jena jalābu ja
translated: “Having made peace with a foe, an egg-born, and a water-born,

original: Vivariya dāṭhaṃ sesi, kuto te bhayamāgata”nti.
analyzed: vivariya sesi kutas te bhayam āgatanti
translated: You opened your mouth and lay down: whence came your fear?”

original: Tattha sandhiṃ katvāti mittabhāvaṃ karitvā. Aṇḍajenāti aṇḍakose nibbattena nāgena. Jalābujāti nakulaṃ ālapati. So hi jalābumhi jātattā “jalābujo”ti vuccati. Vivariyāti vivaritvā.
analyzed: tattha sandhim katvā iti mitta bhāvam karitvā aṇḍa jena ati aṇḍa kose nibbattena nāgena jalābu jā iti nakulam ālapati saḥ hi jalābumhi jāta ttā jalābu jo ti vuccati vivariyā ati vivaritvā
translated: Herein, having made peace means having made friends. An egg-born means a nāga born in an egg-shell. A water-born means he addresses the mongoose. For he is called a water-born because he is born in water. You opened your mouth means having opened your mouth.

original: Evaṃ bodhisattena vutto nakulo “ayya, paccāmitto nāma na avajānitabbo āsaṅkitabboyevā”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam bodhisattena vuttaḥ nakulaḥ ayya paccāmittaḥ nāma na avajānitabbaḥ āsaṅkitabbaḥ iva iva ati vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: When the mongoose was thus addressed by the Bodhisatta, he said: “Sir, an enemy should not be despised; he should be feared.” And he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Saṅketheva amittasmiṃ, mittasmimpi na vissase;
analyzed: saṅketha iva amittasmin mittasmin pi na
translated: “In a foe who is treacherous, trust not even a friend;

original: Abhayā bhayamuppannaṃ, api mūlāni kantatī”ti.
analyzed: abhayā bhayam uppannam api mūlāni kantati iti
translated: From a place of safety fear may come: it may even tear up the roots.”

original: Tattha abhayā bhayamuppannanti na ito te bhayamuppannanti abhayo, ko so? Mitto. Yañhi
analyzed: tattha abhayāḥ bhayam uppannanti na itas te bhayam uppannanti abhayaḥ kaḥ saḥ mittaḥ yat hi
translated: Herein, from a place of safety fear may come means from a place where there is no fear fear may come. Who is it? A friend. For

original: mittasmimpi vissāse sati tato bhayaṃ uppajjati, taṃ mūlānipi kantati, mittassa sabbarandhānaṃ
analyzed: mittasmim pi vissāse sati tatas bhayam uppajjati tam mūlāni api kantati mittassa
translated: if one trusts even a friend, fear may arise from him and it may even tear up the roots, all the openings of the friend’s body.

original: viditattā mūlaghaccāya saṃvattatīti attho.
analyzed: viditattā mūlaghaccāya saṃvattati iti atthaḥ
translated: the meaning is, it leads to the destruction of the root.

original: Atha naṃ bodhisatto “mā bhāyi, yathā sappo tayi na dubbhati, evamahaṃ karissāmi,
analyzed: atha nam bodhisattaḥ mā bhāyi yathā sappaḥ tayi na evam aham karissāmi
translated: The Bodhisatta said to him, “Do not fear. I will so act that the snake will not harm you.

original: tvaṃ ito paṭṭhāya tasmiṃ āsaṅkaṃ mā karī”ti ovaditvā cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā
analyzed: tvam itas paṭṭhāya tasmin āsaṅkam mā kari iti ovaditvā cattāraḥ brahmavihāre bhāvetvā
translated: From this time forth do not be afraid of him.” And he admonished him. Then he developed the four divine states,

original: brahmalokaparāyaṇo ahosi. Tepi yathākammaṃ gatā.
analyzed: brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ ahosi te pi yathākammam gatā
translated: and passed on to the Brahma-world. The snake and the jackal went their way.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā sappo ca nakulo ca ime dve mahāmattā ahesuṃ, tāpaso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā sappo ca nakulo ca ime dve mahāmattāḥ ahesum tāpasaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the snake and the jackal were the two ministers, and I myself was the ascetic.”

original: Nakulajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: nakula jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: The Birth of Nakula.

original: [166] 6. Upasāḷakajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Upasāḷakanāmānīti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto ekaṃ upasāḷakaṃ nāma susānasuddhikaṃ
analyzed: upasāḷaka jātaka vaṇṇanā  upasāḷaka nāmāni iti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ ekam upasāḷakam nāma susāna suddhikam
translated: The Birth Story of Upasīla🔽When the Teacher was in residence at Veḷuvana, he told this story about a certain Upasīla, a brahman who lived in a charnel-ground.

original: brāhmaṇaṃ ārabbha kathesi. So kira aḍḍho ahosi mahaddhano, diṭṭhigatikattā pana dhuravihāre
analyzed: brāhmaṇam ārabbha kathesi so kira aḍḍhaḥ ahosi mahat dhanaḥ diṭṭhi gatikattā pana dhura vihāre
translated: He was rich and wealthy, but because of his false views he did not go to the monastery,

original: vasantānampi buddhānaṃ saṅgahaṃ nāma na akāsi. Putto panassa paṇḍito ahosi ñāṇasampanno.
analyzed: vasantānam pi buddhānam saṅgaham nāma na akāsi puttaḥ pana assa paṇḍitaḥ ahosi ñāṇa sampannaḥ
translated: but he did not make a cemetery for the use of all. But his son was wise and learned.

original: So mahallakakāle puttaṃ āha – “mā kho maṃ, tāta, aññassa vasalassa jhāpitasusāne🔽jhāpehi, ekasmiṃ pana anucchiṭṭhasusāneyeva maṃ jhāpeyyāsī”ti. “Tāta, ahaṃ tumhākaṃ🔽jhāpetabbayuttakaṃ ṭhānaṃ na jānāmi, sādhu vata maṃ ādāya gantvā ‘imasmiṃ ṭhāne maṃ
analyzed: saḥ mahallaka kāle puttam āha mā kho mama tāta aññassa vasalassa jhāpita susāne  jhāpehi ekasmin pana mam jhāpeyyāsi iti tāta aham tumhākam  jhāpetabba yuttakam ṭhānam na jānāmi sādhu vata mam ādāya gantvā imasmin ṭhāne mam
translated: When the son grew up, the father said to him, “My dear son, do not cremate me in a cemetery that has been used by other outcasts.

original: jhāpeyyāsī’ti tumheva ācikkhathā”ti. Brāhmaṇo “sādhu, tātā”ti taṃ ādāya nagarā nikkhamitvā🔽gijjhakūṭamatthakaṃ abhiruhitvā “tāta, idaṃ aññassa vasalassa ajhāpitaṭṭhānaṃ, ettha
analyzed: jhāpeyyāsi iti tumhā iva ācikkhatha ati brāhmaṇaḥ sādhu tāta ati tam ādāya nagarā nikkhamitvā  gijjhakūṭa matthakam abhiruhitvā tāta idam aññassa vasalassa a jhāpita ṭṭhānam ettha
translated: But cremate me in a cemetery that has not been used by any one else.” “Father, I do not know a place suitable for your cremation. It would be well for you to take me with you and show me the place where you wish me to cremate you.” “Very well, my dear son,” said the Brahman, and taking his son with him, he went out of the city and climbed to the top of Vulture Peak.

original: maṃ jhāpeyyāsī”ti vatvā puttena saddhiṃ pabbatā otarituṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: mam jhāpeyyāsi iti vatvā puttena saddhim pabbatā otaritum ārabhi
translated: “My dear son,” said he, “this is a place that has not been used by any other outcast; here cremate me.” So saying, he began to descend the mountain with his son.

original: Satthā pana taṃ divasaṃ paccūsakāle bodhaneyyabandhave olokento tesaṃ pitāputtānaṃ
analyzed: satthā pana tam divasam paccūsa kāle bodhaneyya bandhave olokento tesam pitāputtānam
translated: But on that day the Teacher, at early dawn, surveyed the world of men, in order to discover whom he should convert. Seeing these two, father and son,

original: sotāpattimaggassa upanissayaṃ addasa. Tasmā maggaṃ gahetvā ṭhitaluddako viya pabbatapādaṃ
analyzed: sotāpatti maggassa upanissayam addasa tasmā maggam gahetvā ṭhita luddakaḥ viya pabbata pādam
translated: He saw that the stream of merit flowing from the gift of the cakes was the condition for the attainment of the Fruit of Conversion. Therefore he went to the foot of the mountain, as a hunter goes to a place where he has seen deer, and sat down, waiting for the time when the deities would descend from the mountain top.

original: gantvā tesaṃ pabbatamatthakā otarantānaṃ āgamayamāno nisīdi, te otarantā satthāraṃ
analyzed: gantvā tesam pabbata matthakā otarantānam āgamayamānaḥ nisīdi te otarantā satthāram
translated: As the deities descended, they saw the Teacher.

original: addasaṃsu. Satthā paṭisanthāraṃ karonto “kahaṃ gamissatha brāhmaṇā”ti pucchi. Māṇavo
analyzed: satthā paṭisanthāram karonto kaham gamissatha brāhmaṇa ati pucchi māṇavaḥ
translated: The Teacher welcomed them and asked them, “Brahmans, where are you going?” The student related the facts to him.

original: tamatthaṃ ārocesi. Satthā “tena hi ehi, tava pitarā ācikkhitaṭṭhānaṃ gacchāmā”ti

analyzed: āha bodhisatto uppannaḥ kalyāṇa saddaḥ nāma na antaradhāpetum vaṭṭati iti tatas va nivattitvā

translated: “What is it, great treasurer, that you have gone away and come back again?”

analyzed: kalyāṇa saddaḥ na antaradhāpetabbaḥ pabbajissāmaham pabbajjam me anujānāhi iti etam attham

translated: The story will be told in detail in the Uddālaka birth-story in the Pakiṇṇaka.

original: nāyaṃ bhikkhu idāneva kuhako, pubbepi makkaṭo hutvā aggissa kāraṇā kohaññaṃ akāsiyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: na ayam bhikkhu idānā iva kuhakaḥ pubbe pi makkaṭaḥ hutvā aggissa kāraṇā kohaññam a kāsiyā iva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: But on this occasion the Master said, “Monks, this monk was not only a hypocrite now, but in a previous state of existence also, when he was a monkey, he was a hypocrite for the sake of fire.” So saying, he related the following story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto ekasmiṃ kāsigāmake brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto ekasmin kāsigāmake brāhmaṇa kule
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was born in a Brāhman family in the province of Kāsi.

original: nibbattitvā vayappatto takkasilāyaṃ sippaṃ uggaṇhitvā gharāvāsaṃ saṇṭhapesi. Athassa
analyzed: nibbattitvā vaya patto takkasilāyam sippam uggaṇhitvā ghara āvāsam saṇṭhapesi
translated: When he was born, he was brought up in Takkasilā, and when he was grown up he took a wife.

original: brāhmaṇī ekaṃ puttaṃ vijāyitvā puttassa ādhāvitvā paridhāvitvā vicaraṇakāle kālamakāsi.
analyzed: brāhmaṇī ekam puttam vijāyitvā puttassa ādhāvitvā paridhāvitvā vicaraṇa kāle kālam akāsi
translated: But his wife died after giving birth to a son.

original: Bodhisatto tassā petakiccaṃ katvā “kiṃ me dāni gharāvāsena, puttaṃ gahetvā pabbajissāmī”ti
analyzed: bodhisatto tassā peta kiccam katvā kim me dāni ghara āvāsena puttam gahetvā pabbajissāmi iti
translated: The Bodhisatta thought, “What is the use of my living in the world? I will take my son and go forth into homelessness.”

original: assumukhaṃ ñātimittavaggaṃ pahāya puttaṃ ādāya himavantaṃ pavisitvā isipabbajjaṃ🔽pabbajitvā tattha vanamūlaphalāhāro vāsaṃ kappesi. So ekadivasaṃ vassānakāle deve
analyzed: assumukham ñāti mitta vaggam pahāya puttam ādāya himavantam pavisitvā isipabbajjam  pabbajitvā tattha vana mūla phala āhāraḥ vāsam kappesi saḥ eka divasam vassāna kāle deve
translated: So he left his relatives and friends, took his son with him, and entered the Himalayas. There he went forth into homelessness,🔽and lived on wild roots and fruits. One day, when it was raining,

original: vassante sāradārūni aggiṃ jāletvā visibbanto phalakatthare nipajji, puttopissa tāpasakumārako
analyzed: vassante sāra dārūni aggim jāletvā visibbantaḥ phalakatthare nipajji putto pi issa tāpasa kumārako
translated: he lit a fire of resinous wood, and as he was drying his clothes he lay down on a bed of leaves. His son, the young ascetic,

original: pitu pāde sambāhantova nisīdi.
analyzed: pitu pāde
translated: sat down and massaged his father’s feet.

original: Atheko vanamakkaṭo sītena pīḷiyamāno tassa paṇṇasālāya taṃ aggiṃ disvā “sacāhaṃ ettha
analyzed: atha ekaḥ vana makkaṭaḥ sītena pīḍiyamāno tassa paṇṇa sālāya tam aggim disvā sacā aham ettha
translated: Then a wild monkey, suffering from the cold, saw the fire in the Bodhisatta’s leaf-hut, and thought, “If I go there,

original: pavisissāmi, ‘makkaṭo makkaṭo’ti maṃ pothetvā nīharissanti, aggiṃ visibbetuṃ na labhissāmi,🔽atthi dāni me upāyo, tāpasavesaṃ gahetvā kohaññaṃ katvā pavisissāmī”ti cintetvā ekassa
analyzed: pavisissāmi makkaṭaḥ makkaṭaḥ iti mam pothetvā nīharissanti aggim visibbetum na labhissāmi  atthi dāni me upāyaḥ tāpasa vesam gahetvā kohaññam katvā pavisissāmi iti cintetvā ekassa
translated: “If I enter, they will drive me out, crying, ‘A monkey! a monkey!’ and I shall not be able to make a fire.🔽There is a way out for me. I will put on the robes of a dead ascetic, assume the appearance of an ascetic, and enter.” So he thought, and he put on the robes of a dead ascetic,

original: matatāpasassa vakkalāni nivāsetvā pacchiñca aṅkusayaṭṭhiñca gahetvā paṇṇasāladvāre
analyzed: mata tāpasassa vakkalāni nivāsetvā pacchiñca aṅkusayaṭṭhiñca gahetvā paṇṇasāla dvāre
translated: took a staff and a water-pot, and stood at the door of the leaf-hut,

original: ekaṃ tālarukkhaṃ nissāya saṃkuṭito aṭṭhāsi. Tāpasakumārako taṃ disvā makkaṭabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ekam tāla rukkham nissāya saṃkuṭitaḥ aṭṭhāsi tāpasa kumārako tam disvā makkaṭa bhāvam
translated: leaning against a palm-tree. The young ascetic, not knowing that he was a monkey,

original: ajānanto “eko mahallakatāpaso sītena pīḷito aggiṃ visibbetuṃ āgato bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: a jānantaḥ ekaḥ mahallaka tāpasaḥ sītena pīḍitaḥ aggim visibbetum āgataḥ bhavissati iti
translated: thought to himself, “This must be an old ascetic who has come to make a fire, being troubled with the cold.”

original: pitu tāpasassa kathetvā “etaṃ paṇṇasālaṃ pavesetvā visibbāpessāmī”ti cintetvā pitaraṃ
analyzed: pitu tāpasassa kathetvā etam paṇṇa sālam pavesetvā visibbāpessāmi iti cintetvā pitaram
translated: So he told his father, the ascetic, and thought, “I will take him into the leaf-hut and make him a fire.” Without telling his father,

original: ālapanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ālapantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Tāta māṇavako eso, tālamūlaṃ apassito;
analyzed: tāta māṇavakaḥ esaḥ tāla mūlam a passitaḥ
translated: “Dear father, here is a young man, who has come to the foot of the palm-tree;

original: Agārakañcidaṃ atthi, handa demassagāraka”nti.
analyzed: agārakam cidam atthi handa demassa agārakam ti
translated: There is a hut here; let us give him the hut.”

original: Tattha māṇavakoti sattādhivacanaṃ. Tena “tāta, eso eko māṇavako satto eko tāpaso”ti
analyzed: tattha māṇavakaḥ iti satta adhivacanam tena tāta esaḥ ekaḥ māṇavako satto ekaḥ tāpaso ti
translated: Here the word “boy” is a term for a living being. By it is meant: “Father, this is a certain boy, a certain living being, a certain ascetic.”

original: dīpeti. Tālamūlaṃ apassitoti tālakkhandhaṃ nissāya ṭhito. Agārakañcidaṃ atthīti idañca
analyzed: dīpeti tāla mūlam a passitoti tāla kkhandham nissāya ṭhitaḥ agārakam ca idam atthi iti idam ca
translated: “Not seeing the foot of a palm-tree”: standing in the vicinity of a palm-tree’s trunk. “There is a certain hut”: this

original: amhākaṃ pabbajitāgāraṃ atthi, paṇṇasālaṃ sandhāya vadati. Handāti vavassaggatthe
analyzed: amhākam pabbajita āgāram atthi paṇṇa sālam sandhāya vadati handāti vavassagga atthe
translated: hut of ours for ascetics is there. He is referring to the leaf-hut. “Come”: the particle “handā” is in the sense of “let us.”

original: nipāto. Demassagārakanti etassa ekamante vasanatthāya agārakaṃ dema.
analyzed: nipātaḥ etassa eka mante vasana thāya agārakam dema
translated: “We will give you a hut”: we will give you a hut for living in one corner of this.

original: Bodhisatto puttassa vacanaṃ sutvā uṭṭhāya paṇṇasāladvāre ṭhatvā olokento tassa makkaṭabhāvaṃ
analyzed: bodhisatto puttassa vacanam sutvā uṭṭhāya paṇṇasāla dvāre ṭhatvā olokento tassa makkaṭa bhāvam
translated: Having heard his son’s words, the Bodhisatta rose up, stood at the door of the leaf-hut, and looking at him,

original: ñatvā “tāta, manussānaṃ nāma na evarūpaṃ mukhaṃ hoti, makkaṭo esa, nayidha pakkositabbo”ti
analyzed: ñatvā tāta manussānam nāma na evarūpam mukham hoti makkaṭaḥ esa na yidha pakkositabbaḥ iti
translated: knowing that he was a monkey, said: “Son, the face of men is not like this, he is a monkey, he should not be called in here.”

original: vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Having said this, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Mā kho tvaṃ tāta pakkosi, dūseyya no agārakaṃ;
analyzed: mā kho tvam tāta pakkosi dūseyya naḥ agārakam
translated: “Do not call him in, my son, lest he defile our hut;

original: Netādisaṃ mukhaṃ hoti, brāhmaṇassa susīlino”ti.
analyzed: netādisam mukham hoti brāhmaṇassa su sīlino ti
translated: Such a face as his is not that of a brahmin well-trained.”

original: Tattha dūseyya no agārakanti ayañhi idha paviṭṭho samāno imaṃ kicchena kataṃ paṇṇasālaṃ🔽agginā vā jhāpento uccārādīni vā karonto dūseyya. Netādisanti “etādisaṃ brāhmaṇassa🔽susīlino mukhaṃ na hoti, makkaṭo eso”ti vatvā bodhisatto ekaṃ ummukaṃ gahetvā “kiṃ🔽ettha tiṭṭhasī”ti khipitvā taṃ palāpesi. Makkaṭo vakkalāni chaḍḍetvā rukkhaṃ abhiruhitvā
analyzed: tattha dūseyya no agārakanti ayam hi idha paviṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ imam kicchena katam paṇṇa sālam  agginā vā jhāpentaḥ uccāra ādīni vā karontaḥ dūseyya etādisanti etādisam brāhmaṇassa  susīlinaḥ mukham na hoti makkaṭaḥ esaḥ iti vatvā bodhisattaḥ ekam ummukam gahetvā kim  ettha tiṭṭhasi iti khipitvā tam palāpesi makkaṭaḥ vakkalāni chaḍḍetvā rukkham abhiruhitvā
translated: “He would spoil it, not a householder.” “For if he were to enter here, he would spoil this leaf-hut which I have built with such difficulty, either by burning it with fire or by soiling it with his excreta and so on.” “Not such a one as he.” “A Brahman’s mouth is not like that, he is a monkey.” So saying, the Bodhisatta took up a stick and drove him away, saying, “What are you doing here?” The monkey threw down the leaves, climbed a tree, and sat down.🔽

original: vanasaṇḍaṃ pāvisi. Bodhisatto cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
analyzed: vana saṇḍam pāvisi bodhisatto cattāraḥ brahmavihāre bhāvetvā brahma loka upagaḥ ahosi
translated: “He would destroy it, not a householder.” “For if he should enter here, he would destroy this leaf-hut which I have built with so much difficulty, either by burning it with fire or by soiling it with his excreta.” “Not such a one as this.” “A Brahman’s mouth is not like this; he is a monkey.” So saying, the Bodhisatta took up a stick and drove him away, saying, “What are you doing here?” The monkey dropped his bundle of leaves, climbed a tree, and entered the forest. The Bodhisatta, having developed the four meditations and attained the four formless attainments, was reborn in the Brahma-world.🔽When the Master had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the monkey was the hypocritical monk, Rāhula was the young ascetic, and I myself was the ascetic.”

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā makkaṭo ayaṃ kuhakabhikkhu ahosi, tāpasakumāro rāhulo, tāpaso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Makkaṭajātakavaṇṇanā tatiyā.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā makkaṭaḥ ayam kuhaka bhikkhu ahosi tāpasa kumāraḥ rāhulo tāpasaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  makkaṭa jātaka vaṇṇanā tatiyā
translated: So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,🔽The Birth Story of the Monkey, the third.

original: [174] 4. Dubbhiyamakkaṭajātakaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth Story of the Monkey of Dubbhiya.

original: Adamha te vāri pahūtarūpanti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto devadattaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: adamha te vāri pahūta rūpanti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ devadattam ārabbha kathesi
translated: “But you have plenty of water.” This story the Master told, while dwelling at Veḷuvana, concerning Devadatta.

original: Ekadivasañhi dhammasabhāyaṃ bhikkhū devadattassa akataññumittadubbhibhāvaṃ kathentā
analyzed: eka divasam hi dhamma sabhāyam bhikkhū devadattassa a kataññu mitta dubbhi bhāvam kathentā
translated: For one day the monks were sitting in the Hall of Truth and were talking about Devadatta’s ingratitude and treachery to his friend.

original: nisīdiṃsu. Satthā āgantvā “na, bhikkhave, devadatto idāneva akataññū mittadubbhī,
analyzed: nisīdiṃsu satthā āgantvā na bhikkhave devadattaḥ idānā iva akataññū mitta dubbhī
translated: “Monks,” said the Master, “Devadatta is not the first to be ungrateful and treacherous to his friend.

original: pubbepi evarūpo ahosī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: pubbe pi evarūpaḥ ahosi iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: In times past also he was of like character.” And with this preface he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto ekasmiṃ kāsigāmake brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto ekasmin kāsigāmake brāhmaṇa kule
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a Brāhman family in the province of Kāsi.

original: nibbattitvā vayappatto gharāvāsaṃ saṇṭhapesi. Tasmiṃ pana samaye kāsiraṭṭhe vattanimahāmagge
analyzed: nibbattitvā vaya pattaḥ ghara āvāsam saṇṭhapesi tasmin pana samaye kāsiraṭṭhe vattani mahā magge
translated: When he grew up, he took a wife and settled in a house. Now at that time there was a deep well on the great highway in the province of Kāsi,

original: eko gambhīro udapāno hoti anotaraṇīyo tiracchānānaṃ, maggappaṭipannā puññatthikā
analyzed: ekaḥ gambhīraḥ udapānaḥ hoti anotaraṇīyaḥ tiracchānānam magga ppaṭipannā puññatthikā
translated: which was impassable for animals. People who were travelling along the road and were desirous of doing a good deed,

original: manussā dīgharajjukena vārakena udakaṃ ussiñcitvā ekissā doṇiyā pūretvā tiracchānānaṃ
analyzed: manussāḥ dīgha rajjukena vārakena udakam ussiñcitvā ekissā doṇiyā pūretvā tiracchānānam
translated: would draw water with a long rope and a bucket, and fill a trough with it,

original: pānīyaṃ denti. Tassa sāmantato mahantaṃ araññaṃ, tattha bahū makkaṭā vasanti. Atha
analyzed: pānīyam denti tassa sāmantataḥ mahantam araññam tattha bahū makkaṭāḥ vasanti atha
translated: and gave them water to drink. Near the place was a great forest, and in it there lived many monkeys.

original: tasmiṃ magge dve tīṇi divasāni manussasañcāro pacchijji, tiracchānā pānīyaṃ na labhiṃsu.
analyzed: tasmin magge dve tīṇi divasāni manussa sañcāro pacchijji tiracchānā pānīyam na labhiṃsu
translated: Now it happened that for two or three days the traffic on the road was interrupted, and the animals could not get water.

original: Eko makkaṭo pipāsāturo hutvā pānīyaṃ pariyesanto udapānassa santike vicarati. Bodhisatto
analyzed: ekaḥ makkaṭaḥ pipāsā āturaḥ hutvā pānīyam pariyesantaḥ udapānassa santike vicarati bodhisatto
translated: One monkey, who was suffering from thirst, was wandering about near the water-trough in search of water. The Bodhisatta

original: kenacideva karaṇīyena taṃ maggaṃ paṭipajjitvā tattha gacchanto pānīyaṃ uttāretvā🔽pivitvā hatthapāde dhovitvā ṭhito taṃ makkaṭaṃ addasa. Athassa pipāsitabhāvaṃ ñatvā
analyzed: kenacid eva karaṇīyena tam maggam paṭipajjitvā tattha gacchantaḥ pānīyam uttāretvā  pivitvā hattha pāde dhovitvā ṭhitaḥ tam makkaṭam addasa athassa pipāsita bhāvam ñatvā
translated: was going along that road on some business or other, and as he went he drew water from the trough,🔽and drank and washed his hands and feet, and stood there. He saw the monkey, and knowing that he was suffering from thirst,

original: pānīyaṃ ussiñcitvā doṇiyaṃ ākiritvā adāsi, datvā ca pana “vissamissāmī”ti ekasmiṃ🔽rukkhamūle nipajji. Makkaṭo pānīyaṃ pivitvā avidūre nisīditvā mukhamakkaṭikaṃ karonto
analyzed: pānīyam ussiñcitvā doṇiyam ākiritvā adāsi da tvā ca pana vissamissāmi iti ekasmin  rukkha mūle nipajji makkaṭaḥ pānīyam pivitvā avidūre nisīditvā mukhamakkaṭikam karontaḥ
translated: poured out some water, and having filled his mouth with it, gave it to him. After giving it to him, thinking, “I will rest,” he lay down to sleep

original: bodhisattaṃ bhiṃsāpesi. Bodhisatto tassa taṃ kiriyaṃ disvā “are duṭṭhamakkaṭa, ahaṃ
analyzed: bodhisattam bhiṃsāpesi bodhisatto tassa tam kiriyam disvā are duṭṭha makkaṭa aham
translated: at the foot of a tree. The monkey drank the water, and sitting down not far off, began to make grimaces and to frighten the Bodhisatta. The Bodhisatta, seeing him do this, said, “Ah! you wicked monkey! I gave you water out of pity for you,🔽and this is the way you repay me!”

original: tava pipāsitassa kilantassa bahuṃ pānīyaṃ adāsiṃ, idāni tvaṃ mayhaṃ mukhamakkaṭikaṃ
analyzed: tava pipāsitassa kilantassa bahum pānīyam adāsim idāni tvam mayham mukha makkaṭikam
translated: “You gave me much water to drink when I was thirsty and exhausted; now you should give me a kiss on the mouth.

original: karosi, aho pāpajanassa nāma kato upakāro niratthako”ti vatvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: karosi aho pāpa janassa nāma kataḥ upakāraḥ niratthakaḥ ti vatvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: “You gave me much water to drink when I was thirsty and exhausted; now you make a face at me. Oh, the uselessness of a favor done to a wicked person!” So saying, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Adamha te vāri pahūtarūpaṃ, ghammābhitattassa pipāsitassa;
analyzed: adamha te vāri pahūta rūpam ghamma abhitattassa pipāsitassa
translated: “We gave you water in abundance, To a thirsty man exhausted by the heat;

original: So dāni pitvāna kiriṅkarosi, asaṅgamo pāpajanena seyyo”ti.
analyzed: saḥ dāni pitvāna kiriṅkarosi asaṅgamaḥ pāpa janena
translated: But now, having drunk, you make a face at us; Better is it to have no dealings with the wicked.

original: Tattha so dāni pitvāna kiriṅkarosīti so idāni tvaṃ mayā dinnapānīyaṃ pivitvā mukhamakkaṭikaṃ🔽karonto “kiri kirī”ti saddaṃ karosi. Asaṅgamo pāpajanena seyyoti pāpajanena saddhiṃ
analyzed: tattha saḥ dāni pitvāna kiriṅkarosi iti saḥ idāni tvam mayā dinna pānīyam pivitvā mukha makkaṭikam  karontaḥ kiri kiri iti saddam karosi asaṅgamaḥ pāpa janena seyyo ti pāpa janena saddhim
translated: “Having drunk the water I gave you,” said the monkey, “you make a face at me and go ‘kiri kiri.’ Better is it to have no dealings with the wicked.”

original: saṅgamo na seyyo, asaṅgamova seyyoti.
analyzed: saṅgamaḥ na seyyaḥ asaṅgamaḥ uva seyyaḥ uti
translated: “Better is it to have no dealings with the wicked,” said the crow; “dealings with the wicked are not good.”

original: Taṃ sutvā so mittadubbhī makkaṭo “tvaṃ ‘ettakenavetaṃ niṭṭhita’nti saññaṃ karosi, idāni te sīse vaccaṃ pātetvā gamissāmī”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā saḥ mittadubbhī makkaṭo tvam ettakena vetam niṭṭhitanti saññam karosi idāni te sīse vaccam pātetvā gamissāmi iti vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the monkey, who was a traitor to his friend, said, “You think that is the end of it, do you? Now I will void excrement on your head and go.” So saying, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Ko te suto vā diṭṭho vā, sīlavā nāma makkaṭo;
analyzed: kaḥ te sutaḥ vā diṭṭhaḥ vā sīlavā nāma makkaṭaḥ
translated: “Who ever heard or saw a monkey, A virtuous creature?

original: Idāni kho taṃ ohacchaṃ, esā asmāka dhammatā”ti.🔽Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – bho brāhmaṇa, “makkaṭo kataguṇajānanako ācārasampanno sīlavā
analyzed: idāni kho tam ohaccham esā asmāka dhamma tā ti  tatra ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ bho brāhmaṇa makkaṭaḥ kata guṇa jānanakaḥ ācāra sampanno sīlavā
translated: “But now I will pay you back, for such is the nature of monkeys.”

original: nāma atthī”ti kahaṃ tayā suto vā diṭṭho vā, idāni kho ahaṃ taṃ ohacchaṃ vaccaṃ te🔽sīse katvā pakkamissāmi, asmākañhi makkaṭānaṃ nāma esā dhammatā ayaṃ jātisabhāvo,
analyzed: nāma atthi iti kaham tayā sutaḥ vā diṭṭhaḥ vā idāni kho aham tam ohaccham vaccam te  sīse katvā pakkamissāmi asmākam hi makkaṭānam nāma esā dhamma tā ayam jāti sabhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning of this is as follows: “Sir, have you heard or seen a monkey who knows how to repay a kindness, who is virtuous and well-behaved? If so, where? But now I will pay you back, and I will go away. For such is the nature of monkeys, such is their disposition,

original: yadidaṃ upakārakassa sīse vaccaṃ kātabbanti.

translated: Though he be Satadhamma, is not glad at the gain he has won.”

translated: Herein, the Law is the Law of virtue, which is purity of livelihood. Having cast aside: having taken out, having thrown away. By what is not the Law: by the twenty-one kinds of wrong livelihood called “seeking in wrong ways” . Satadhamma: this is his name. The reading is also “Santadhamma” . Is not glad: just as the student Satadhamma was not glad at the gain he had won, thinking “I have won a dog’s vomit,” so too, in this Dispensation, a clansman gone forth does not rejoice in the gain he has won by wrong livelihood in wrong ways. original: sarīre rogaṃ apassantā “rogamassa na passāmā”ti rañño kathayiṃsu. Rājā bodhisattaṃ
analyzed: sarīre rogam a passantāḥ rogam assa na passāma ati raññaḥ kathayiṃsu rājā bodhisattam
translated: not seeing any disease in the horse’s body, said to the king, “We see no disease in him.” The king sent for the Bodhisat,

original: pesesi – “gaccha vayassa, ettha kāraṇaṃ jānāhī”ti. So gantvā khañjaassabandhasaṃsaggena
analyzed: pesesi gaccha vayassa ettha kāraṇam jānāhi iti saḥ gantvā khañja assa bandha saṃsaggena
translated: saying, “Go, my good man, and find out the cause of this.” He went and found out that the horse had become lame

original: tassa khañjabhūtabhāvaṃ ñatvā rañño tamatthaṃ ārocetvā “saṃsaggadosena nāma evaṃ
analyzed: tassa khañja bhūta bhāvam ñatvā raññaḥ tam attham ārocetvā saṃsagga dosena nāma evam
translated: through the company of the lame groom, and informed the king of the fact. “It is through the fault of bad company🔽that this horse has become lame.

original: hotī”ti dassento paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –-
analyzed: hoti iti dassentaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and uttered the first stanza:

original: “Dūsito giridattena, hayo sāmassa paṇḍavo;
analyzed: dūsitaḥ giridattena hayaḥ sāmassa paṇḍavo
translated: The horse, the king’s auspicious steed, was spoiled by the mountain-god;

original: Porāṇaṃ pakatiṃ hitvā, tassevānuvidhiyyatī”ti.
analyzed: porāṇam pakatim hitvā tassa iva anuvidhiyyati iti
translated: He has abandoned his former nature, and now follows his example.

original: Tattha hayo sāmassāti sāmassa rañño maṅgalasso. Porāṇaṃ pakatiṃ hitvāti attano porāṇapakatiṃ siṅgārabhāvaṃ pahāya. Anuvidhiyyatīti anusikkhati.
analyzed: tattha hayaḥ sāmassa ati sāmassa raññaḥ maṅgalasso porāṇam pakatim hitvā ati attanaḥ porāṇa pakatim siṅgāra bhāvam pahāya anuvidhiyyati iti anusikkhati
translated: Herein, the horse, the king’s auspicious steed, was spoiled by the mountain-god: the king’s auspicious horse was spoiled by the mountain-god. He has abandoned his former nature, and now follows his example: he has abandoned his former nature, his state of being a horse, and now follows the example of the mountain-god.

original: Atha naṃ rājā “idāni vayassa kiṃ kattabba”nti pucchi. Bodhisatto “sundaraṃ assabandhaṃ labhitvā yathā porāṇo bhavissatī”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam rājā idāni vayassa kim kattabbanti pucchi bodhisatto sundaram assa bandham labhitvā yathā porāṇaḥ bhavissati iti vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the king asked: “What is to be done now?” The Bodhisatta said: “If a good horse-trainer is obtained, he will be as he was before.” And he uttered the second stanza:

original: “Sace ca tanujo poso, sikharākārakappito;
analyzed: sace ca tanu jaḥ poso sikhara ākāra kappito
translated: If a man be found who is slender, and has the shape of a peak,

original: Ānane naṃ gahetvāna, maṇḍale parivattaye;
analyzed: ānane nam maṇḍale parivattaye
translated: You should seize him by the mouth, and make him turn round in a circle;

original: Khippameva pahantvāna, tassevānuvidhiyyatī”ti.
analyzed: khippam eva pahantvāna tassa iva anuvidhiyyati iti
translated: Then he will quickly abandon his former nature, and follow his example.

original: Tattha tanujoti tassa anujo. Anurūpaṃ jāto hi anujo, tassa anujo tanujo. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: tattha tanujaḥ ti tassa anujaḥ anurūpam jātaḥ hi anujaḥ tassa anujaḥ tanujaḥ idam vuttam
translated: Herein, a man who is slender and has the shape of a peak: a man who is slender and has the shape of a peak. For a man who is born in accordance with the example is called an anujo . The anujo of that is a tanujo . This is what is meant.

original: hoti – sace hi, mahārāja, tassa siṅgārassa ācārasampannassa assassa anurūpaṃ jāto
analyzed: hoti sace hi mahā rāja tassa siṅgārassa ācāra sampannassa assassa anurūpam jātaḥ
translated: If, sire, the trappings of the well-bred horse were to be born in a man who was well-bred and of good conduct,

original: siṅgāro ācārasampanno poso. Sikharākārakappitoti sikharena sundarena ākārena kappitakesamassu
analyzed: siṅgāraḥ ācāra sampanno poso sikhara ākāra kappito ti sikharena sundarena ākārena kappita kesa massu
translated: then the trappings would be in harmony with the horse. The man’s hair and beard would be trimmed in a beautiful manner like the horse’s mane and tail.

original: taṃ assaṃ ānane gahetvā assamaṇḍale parivatteyya, khippamevesa taṃ khañjabhāvaṃ pahāya🔽“ayaṃ siṅgāro ācārasampanno assagopako maṃ sikkhāpetī”ti saññāya khippameva tassa
analyzed: tam assam ānane gahetvā assa maṇḍale parivatteyya khippam eva īsa tam khañja bhāvam pahāya  ayam siṅgāraḥ ācāra sampannaḥ assagopako mama sikkhāpeti iti saññāya khippam eva tassa
translated: He would take the horse by the mouth and turn it round in the horse-yard. Quickly would the horse abandon its wildness

original: anuvidhiyyati anusikkhissati, pakatibhāveyeva ṭhassatīti attho. Rājā tathā kāresi,
analyzed: anuvidhiyyati anusikkhissati atthaḥ rājā tathā kāresi
translated: and, thinking: ‘This horse-keeper who is well-bred and of good conduct is training me,’ it would quickly submit to his guidance and training. The meaning is that it would remain in its natural state. The king did as he was told,

original: asso pakatibhāve patiṭṭhāsi. Rājā “tiracchānānampi nāma āsayaṃ jānissatī”ti tuṭṭhacitto
analyzed: asso pakati bhāve patiṭṭhāsi rājā tiracchānānam pi nāma āsayam jānissati iti tuṭṭha citto
translated: and the horse settled down in its natural state. The king was pleased and thought: ‘He will even know the disposition of animals.’

original: bodhisattassa mahantaṃ yasaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: bodhisattassa mahantam yasam adāsi
translated: And he gave the Bodhisatta great honour.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā giridatto devadatto ahosi, asso vipakkhasevako bhikkhu, rājā ānando, amaccapaṇḍito pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā giridattaḥ devadattaḥ ahosi assaḥ vipakkha sevakaḥ bhikkhu rājā ānandaḥ amacca paṇḍitaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: The Master, having related this story, identified the Birth by saying, “At that time Devadatta was Giridatta, the horse was the monk Vipakkhasevaka, the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the wise minister.”

original: Giridattajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: giridatta jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: The Story of Giridatta.

original: [185] 5. Anabhiratijātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of Anabhirati🔽“As in troubled water, in water that is muddy, turbid, and muddy-looking, the man looking for fish, the man looking for turtles, the man looking for water-animals, would not see the fish, the turtles, the water-animals moving about, so too, in a mind that is troubled, turbid, and muddy-looking, with thoughts of sensual desire invading it, a monk does not see as it really is his own profit, the profit of others, and the profit of both.”

original: Yathodake āvile appasanneti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto aññataraṃ brāhmaṇakumāraṃ
analyzed: yathā udake āvile appasanne ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ aññataram brāhmaṇa kumāraṃ
translated: The Master told this story while dwelling at Jetavana, about a certain young brāhman.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Sāvatthiyaṃ kira eko brāhmaṇakumāro tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū bahū khattiyakumāre
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi sāvatthiyam kira ekaḥ brāhmaṇa kumāraḥ tiṇṇam vedānam pāragū bahū khattiya kumāre
translated: In Sāvatthi, it seems, there was a young brāhman who had mastered the three Vedas, and who taught them to many young brāhmans and young khattiyas.

original: ca brāhmaṇakumāre ca mante vācesi. So aparabhāge gharāvāsaṃ saṇṭhapetvā vatthālaṅkāradāsadāsikhettavatthugomahiṃsaputtadārādīnaṃ
analyzed: ca brāhmaṇa kumāre ca mante vācesi saḥ aparabhāge ghara āvāsam saṇṭhapetvā vattha alaṅkāra dāsa dāsi khetta vatthu go mahiṃsa putta dāra ādīnam
translated: Later on, he took a wife, and, thinking of the things he would need for his household, such as clothes, ornaments, male and female slaves, fields, land, cattle, buffaloes, sons, daughters, and so on,

original: atthāya cintayamāno rāgadosamohavasiko hutvā āvilacitto ahosi, mante paṭipāṭiyā parivattetuṃ
analyzed: atthāya cintayamānaḥ rāga dosa moha vasikaḥ hutvā āvila cittaḥ ahosi mante paṭipāṭiyā parivattetum
translated: he became a prey to lust, hatred, and ignorance, and his mind became troubled.

original: nāsakkhi, ito cito ca mantā na paṭibhaṃsu. So ekadivasaṃ bahuṃ gandhamālādiṃ gahetvā
analyzed: na asakkhi itas citas ca mantā na paṭibhaṃsu saḥ eka divasam bahum gandha mālā ādim gahetvā
translated: He was unable to do so, and his recitations would not come to him. One day he took a great quantity of perfumes and garlands,

original: jetavanaṃ gantvā satthāraṃ pūjetvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Satthā tena saddhiṃ
analyzed: jetavanam gantvā satthāram pūjetvā vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi satthā tena saddhim
translated: went to the Jetavana, paid his respects to the Teacher, and sat down respectfully on one side. The Teacher

original: paṭisanthāraṃ katvā “kiṃ, māṇava, mante vācesi, paguṇā te mantā”ti pucchi. “Pubbe
analyzed: paṭisanthāram katvā kim māṇava mante vācesi paguṇā te mantā ati pucchi pubbe
translated: conversed with him, and then asked him, “Student, are you reciting the mantras? Are you familiar with the mantras?” “Reverend Sir,

original: me, bhante, mantā paguṇā ahesuṃ, gharāvāsassa pana gahitakālato paṭṭhāya cittaṃ me
analyzed: me bhante mantā paguṇāḥ ahesum gharāvāsassa pana gahita kālato paṭṭhāya cittam me
translated: formerly I was familiar with the mantras, but ever since I took a wife, my mind has been troubled,

original: āvilaṃ jātaṃ, tena me mantā na paguṇā”ti. Atha naṃ satthā “na kho, māṇava, idāneva,🔽pubbepi te cittassa anāvilakāle tava mantā paguṇā ahesuṃ, rāgādīhi pana āvilakāle
analyzed: āvilam jātam tena me mantā na paguṇāti atha nam satthā na kho māṇava idānā iva  pubbe pi te cittassa anāvila kāle tava mantāḥ paguṇāḥ ahesum rāga ādīhi pana āvila kāle
translated: and therefore I am not familiar with the mantras.” Then said the Teacher to him, “Student, this is not the first time your mind has been troubled;

original: tava mantā na paṭibhaṃsū”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: tava mantā na vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: in a previous state of existence also your mind was troubled, and therefore your recitations would not come to you.” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto brāhmaṇamahāsālakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ brāhmaṇa mahāsāla kule nibbattitvā
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, in the city of Bārāṇasī, in the kingdom of Brahmadatta, the Bodhisatta took birth in the family of a great Brahman.

original: vayappatto takkasilāyaṃ mante uggaṇhitvā disāpāmokkho ācariyo hutvā bārāṇasiyaṃ bahū
analyzed: vaya pattaḥ takkasilāyam mante uggaṇhitvā disāpāmokkhaḥ ācariyaḥ hutvā bārāṇasiyam bahū
translated: When he had reached the age of reason, he studied the Vedas in Takkasilā, and became a teacher, the foremost in the whole country. He taught many princes and Brahmans

original: khattiyakumāre ca brāhmaṇakumāre ca mante vācesi. Tassa santike eko brāhmaṇamāṇavo
analyzed: khattiya kumāre ca brāhmaṇa kumāre ca mante vācesi tassa santike ekaḥ brāhmaṇa māṇavaḥ
translated: in Bārāṇasī. A certain Brahman student

original: tayo vede paguṇe akāsi, ekapadepi nikkaṅkho piṭṭhiācariyo hutvā mante vācesi. So🔽aparena samayena gharāvāsaṃ gahetvā gharāvāsacintāya āvilacitto mante parivattetuṃ
analyzed: tayaḥ vede paguṇe akāsi eka pade pi nikkaṅkhaḥ piṭṭhi ācariyaḥ hutvā mante vācesi so  aparena samayena ghara āvāsam gahetvā ghara āvāsa cintāya āvila cittaḥ mante parivattetum
translated: mastered the three Vedas under him, and became his assistant teacher, being free from doubt even as to a single syllable. He🔽afterwards took a wife, and his mind being troubled with thoughts of his home, he was unable to recite the Vedas. Then his teacher,

original: nāsakkhi. Atha naṃ ācariyo attano santikaṃ āgataṃ “kiṃ, māṇava, paguṇā te mantā”ti🔽pucchitvā “gharāvāsagahitakālato paṭṭhāya me cittaṃ āvilaṃ jātaṃ, mante parivattetuṃ🔽na sakkomī”ti vutte “tāta, āvile cittamhi paguṇāpi mantā na paṭibhanti, anāvile pana
analyzed: na asakkhi atha nam ācariyaḥ attano santikam āgatam kim māṇava paguṇā te mantā ati  pucchitvā ghara āvāsa gahita kālataḥ paṭṭhāya me cittam āvilam jātam mante parivattetum  na sakkomi iti vutte tāta āvile cittamhi paguṇāḥ api mantāḥ na paṭibhanti anāvile pana
translated: when he came to him, asked him, “Have you mastered the Vedas, student?”🔽“Since I took a wife,” he replied, “my mind has been troubled, and I am unable to recite the Vedas.”

original: citte appaṭibhāṇaṃ nāma natthī”ti vatvā imā gāthā āha –
analyzed: citte appaṭibhāṇam nāma natthi iti vatvā imāḥ gāthāḥ āha
translated: “My dear,” said the teacher, “when the mind is troubled, even though the Vedas have been mastered, they do not come to mind; but when the mind is untroubled, there is nothing that does not come to mind.” So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Yathodake āvile appasanne, na passati sippikasambukañca;
analyzed: yathā udake āvile appasanne na passati sippika sambukam ca
translated: As in troubled, muddy water the oyster finds not its pearl,

original: Sakkharaṃ vālukaṃ macchagumbaṃ, evaṃ āvilamhi citte;🔽Na so passati attadatthaṃ paratthaṃ.
analyzed: sakkharam vālukam macchagumbam evam āvilamhi citte  na so passati atta dattham parattham
translated: Does not see a shell, a gravel, or a fish, so also one with a disturbed mind,

original: “Yathodake acche vippasanne, so passati sippikasambukañca;
analyzed: yathā udake acche vippasanne so passati sippika sambukañca
translated: “Just as one who looks into a pool of water that is undisturbed, clear, and pure,

original: Sakkharaṃ vālukaṃ macchagumbaṃ, evaṃ anāvilamhi citte;
analyzed: sakkharam vālukam macchagumbam evam anāvilamhi citte
translated: Does see a shell, a gravel, or a fish, so also one with an undisturbed mind,

original: So passati atthadatthaṃ parattha”nti.
analyzed: so passati attha dattham paratthanti
translated: Does see his own benefit and the benefit of others.”

original: Tattha āvileti kaddamāluḷite. Appasanneti tāyeva āvilatāya avippasanne. Sippikasambukañcāti🔽sippikañca sambukañca. Macchagumbanti macchaghaṭaṃ. Evaṃ āvilamhīti evameva rāgādīhi
analyzed: tattha āvilā iti kaddama āluḷite appasannā iti tāya iva āvila tāya a vippasanne sippika sambukam ca ati  sippikam ca sambukam ca maccha gumbanti maccha ghaṭam evam evam eva
translated: Herein, disturbed means muddy with mud. Not clear means not clear because of that very muddiness. A shell and a gravel means

original: āvile citte. Attadatthaṃ paratthanti neva attadatthaṃ na paratthaṃ passatīti attho.
analyzed: āvile citte atta dattham paratthanti na iva atta dattham na parattham passati iti attho
translated: a shell and a gravel. A fish means a fish-trap. Just as one with a disturbed mind does not see his own benefit and the benefit of others, so also one with a mind disturbed by lust, hatred, and delusion does not see his own benefit and the benefit of others.

original: So passatīti evameva anāvile citte so puriso attadatthaṃ paratthañca passatīti.
analyzed: so passati iti evam eva anāvile citte so puriso atta dattham paratthañca passati iti
translated: So also one with an undisturbed mind does see his own benefit and the benefit of others.

original: Satthā imaṃ atītaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: satthā imam atītam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: After relating this story of the past, the Teacher identified the Birth Stories, saying, “At that time the king was I myself.”

original: brāhmaṇakumāro sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā māṇavo ayameva māṇavo ahosi, ācariyo
analyzed: brāhmaṇa kumāro sotāpatti phale tadā māṇavaḥ ayam eva māṇavaḥ ahosi ācariyo
translated: and the young brāhman was established in the fruit of conversion. “The young brāhman of that time is this young brāhman.

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pana aham eva
translated: I was his teacher then, just as I am now.”

original: Anabhiratijātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: anabhirati jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: The Story of Anabhirati.

original: [186] 6. Dadhivāhanajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Vaṇṇagandharasūpetoti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto vipakkhaseviṃ bhikkhuṃ ārabbha
analyzed: vaṇṇa gandhara sūpeto ti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ vipakkhasevim bhikkhum ārabbha
translated: The Story of Dadhivahana

original: kathesi. Vatthu heṭṭhā kathitameva. Satthā pana “bhikkhave, asādhusannivāso nāma
analyzed: kathesi vatthu heṭṭhā kathitam eva satthā pana bhikkhave asādhusannivāsaḥ nāma
translated: Possessed of beauty, fragrance, and taste. The Master told this tale while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, concerning a monk who was a bad companion. The story is related below.

original: pāpo anatthakaro, tattha manussabhūtānaṃ tāva pāpasannivāsassa anatthakaratāya kiṃ🔽vattabbaṃ, pubbe pana asātena amadhurena nimbarukkhena saddhiṃ sannivāsamāgamma madhuraraso
analyzed: pāpaḥ anattha karo tattha manussa bhūtānam tāva pāpa sannivāsassa anattha kara tāya kim  vattabbam pubbe pana asātena amadhurena nimba rukkhena saddhim sannivāsam āgamma madhura rasaḥ
translated: “Monks, a bad companion is a sinner, and brings misfortune. What need be said of men?

original: dibbarasapaṭibhāgo acetano ambarukkhopi amadhuro tittako jāto”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: dibba rasa paṭibhāgaḥ acetanaḥ amba rukkhaḥ api amadhuraḥ tittakaḥ jātaḥ iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: In the past, even a tree, which is without sense, by living with a tree that was bad, that was not sweet, that was a nimba tree, became sweet, and had a taste like that of the gods.” So saying, he told an old-world tale.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente kāsiraṭṭhe cattāro bhātaro brāhmaṇā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente kāsiraṭṭhe cattāraḥ bhātaraḥ brāhmaṇā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, there were four brothers, brāhmans, in the province of Kāsi.

original: isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā himavantapadese paṭipāṭiyā paṇṇasālā katvā vāsaṃ kappesuṃ.
analyzed: isipabbajjam pabbajitvā himavanta padese paṭipāṭiyā paṇṇa sālā katvā vāsam kappesuṃ
translated: They went forth into the homeless life under the seers, and they built leaf-huts in the Himalayas and lived there.

original: Tesaṃ jeṭṭhakabhātā kālaṃ katvā sakkattaṃ pāpuṇi. So taṃ kāraṇaṃ ñatvā antarantarā
analyzed: tesam jeṭṭhaka bhātā kālam katvā sakkattam pāpuṇi saḥ tam kāraṇam ñatvā antarantarā
translated: The eldest of them died and was reborn as Sakka. He remembered the reason for his rebirth, and from time to time

original: sattaṭṭhadivasaccayena tesaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ gacchanto ekadivasaṃ jeṭṭhakatāpasaṃ vanditvā
analyzed: satta ṭṭha divasa cayena tesam upaṭṭhānam gacchantaḥ eka divasam jeṭṭhaka tāpasam vanditvā
translated: he went to wait on them. After seven or eight days had passed, he went to wait on them one day. He saluted the eldest of the ascetics,

original: pakkosāpito pavisitvā rājānaṃ vanditvā “tvaṃ uyyānapālo”ti puṭṭho “āma, devā”ti vatvā
