translated: The king sent for him, and he went in, saluted the king, and when asked, “Are you a keeper of a pleasure garden?” said, “Yes, your majesty.”

original: attano ānubhāvaṃ vaṇṇesi. Rājā “gaccha amhākaṃ uyyānapālassa santike hohī”ti āha.🔽Te tato paṭṭhāya dve janā uyyānaṃ paṭijagganti. Adhunāgato uyyānapālo akālapupphāni🔽suṭṭhu pupphāpento akālaphalāni gaṇhāpento uyyānaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ akāsi. Rājā tassa pasīditvā
analyzed: attanaḥ ānubhāvam vaṇṇesi rājā gaccha amhākam uyyāna pālassa santike hohi iti āha  te tatas paṭṭhāya dve janāḥ uyyānam paṭijagganti adhunā āgataḥ uyyāna pālaḥ akāla pupphāni  suṭṭhu pupphāpentaḥ akāla phalāni gaṇhāpentaḥ uyyānam ramaṇīyam akāsi rājā tassa pasīditvā
translated: And he extolled his own ability. The king said, “Go and be our keeper of a pleasure garden.”🔽From that time on there were two keepers of the pleasure garden. The new keeper of the pleasure garden caused the garden to be made beautiful by causing out-of-season flowers to be brought in and out-of-season fruits to be brought in. The king was pleased with him,

original: porāṇakauyyānapālaṃ nīharitvā tasseva uyyānaṃ adāsi. So uyyānassa attano hatthagatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: porāṇaka oyyāna pālam nīharitvā tassa iva uyyānam adāsi saḥ uyyānassa attanaḥ hattha gata bhāvam
translated: and he drove out the old keeper of the pleasure garden and gave the garden into his charge. When the new keeper of the pleasure garden found that the garden was in his charge,

original: ñatvā ambarukkhaṃ parivāretvā nimbe ca phaggavavalliyo ca ropesi, anupubbena nimbā
analyzed: ñatvā amba rukkham parivāretvā nimbe ca phaggava valliyaḥ ca ropesi anupubbena nimbā
translated: he surrounded the mango tree with nimba trees and with creepers of the phāggu plant, and gradually the nimba trees and the creepers of the phāggu plant

original: vaḍḍhiṃsu, mūlehi mūlāni, sākhāhi ca sākhā saṃsaṭṭhā onaddhavinaddhā ahesuṃ. Tena
analyzed: vaḍḍhiṃsu mūlehi mūlāni sākhāhi ca sākhā saṃsaṭṭhāḥ onaddha vinaddhāḥ ahesum tena
translated: and the roots of the branches, and the branches themselves, became entangled with one another.

original: asātaamadhurasaṃsaggena tāvamadhuraphalo ambo tittako jāto nimbapaṇṇasadisaraso,🔽ambaphalānaṃ tittakabhāvaṃ ñatvā uyyānapālo palāyi.🔽Dadhivāhano uyyānaṃ gantvā ambaphalaṃ khādanto mukhe paviṭṭhaṃ ambarasaṃ nimbakasaṭaṃ
analyzed: asāta amadhura saṃsaggena tāva madhura phalaḥ ambaḥ tittakaḥ jātaḥ nimba paṇṇa sadisa rasaḥ  tittaka bhāvam ñatvā uyyāna pālaḥ palāyi  dadhivāhanaḥ uyyānam gantvā amba phalam khādantaḥ mukhe paviṭṭham amba rasam nimbaka saṭam
translated: By this association with the unpalatable and the sweet, the mango tree, which had borne sweet fruit, became bitter, and its fruit tasted like the leaves of the neem tree.🔽When the gardener found that the fruit of the mango tree had become bitter, he ran away.🔽The king went to the garden, and as he was eating the fruit of the mango tree, he found that he could not swallow the juice which he had in his mouth, but spat it out as he would a mouthful of neem leaves.

original: viya ajjhoharituṃ asakkonto kakkāretvā niṭṭhubhi. Tadā bodhisatto tassa atthadhammānusāsako
analyzed: viya ajjhoharitum a sakkonto kakkāretvā niṭṭhubhi tadā bodhisatto tassa attha dhamma anusāsako
translated: At that time the Bodhisatta was the king’s minister and counsellor.

original: amacco ahosi. Rājā bodhisattaṃ āmantetvā “paṇḍita, imassa rukkhassa porāṇakaparihārato
analyzed: amaccaḥ ahosi rājā bodhisattam āmantetvā paṇḍita imassa rukkhassa porāṇaka parihārato
translated: The king, addressing the Bodhisatta, said, “Wise man, there is nothing wanting in the care of this tree which was given to it in former days;

original: parihīnaṃ natthi, evaṃ santepissa phalaṃ tittakaṃ jātaṃ, kiṃ nu kho kāraṇa”nti pucchanto
analyzed: parihīnam natthi evam sante pi issa phalam tittakam jātam kim nu kho kāraṇanti pucchantaḥ
translated: and yet its fruit has become bitter. What is the reason of this?”

original: paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: And he uttered the first stanza:

original: “Vaṇṇagandharasūpeto, amboyaṃ ahuvā pure;
analyzed: vaṇṇa gandhara su upetaḥ pure
translated: “This mango tree, in days of old, Was sweet of scent and sweet of taste;

original: Tameva pūjaṃ labhamāno, kenambo kaṭukapphalo”ti.
analyzed: tam eva pūjam labhamānaḥ kenambaḥ kaṭu kapphalo ti
translated: And now, receiving worship still, Why is its fruit so bitter-tasted?”

original: Athassa kāraṇaṃ ācikkhanto bodhisatto dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha assa kāraṇam ācikkhantaḥ bodhisatto dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Explaining the reason, the Bodhisatta spoke the second stanza:

original: “Pucimandaparivāro, ambo te dadhivāhana;
analyzed: pucimanda parivāraḥ ambo te dadhivāhana
translated: “The Nimba tree surrounds thee, the sour-milk-drinking mango tree;

original: Mūlaṃ mūlena saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, sākhā sākhā nisevare;
analyzed: mūlam mūlena saṃsaṭṭham sākhā sākhā nisevare
translated: The root is mixed with the root, the branch with the branch, the leaf with the leaf;

original: Asātasannivāsena, tenambo kaṭukapphalo”ti.🔽Tattha pucimandaparivāroti nimbarukkhaparivāro. Sākhā sākhā nisevareti pucimandassa🔽sākhāyo ambarukkhassa sākhāyo nisevanti. Asātasannivāsenāti amadhurehi pucimandehi
analyzed: asāta sannivāsena tenambo kaṭu kapphalo ti  tattha pucimanda parivāro ti nimba rukkha parivāro sākhā sākhā nisevareti pucimandassa  sākhāyaḥ amba rukkhassa sākhāyaḥ nisevanti a sāta sannivāsena ati a madhurehi puci mandehi
translated: By living with the unlovely, the mango is bitter-fruited.”

original: saddhiṃ sannivāsena. Tenāti tena kāraṇena ayaṃ ambo kaṭukapphalo asātaphalo tittakaphalo jātoti.
analyzed: saddhim sannivāsena tena ati tena kāraṇena ayam ambo kaṭukapphalo asātaphalo tittakaphalo jāto ti
translated: Herein, the Nimba tree surrounds thee means the mango tree is surrounded by the Nimba tree. The branch with the branch, the leaf with the leaf means the branches of the Nimba tree and the leaves of the Nimba tree are mixed with the branches and leaves of the mango tree. By living with the unlovely means by living together with the unlovely Nimba tree. The mango is bitter-fruited means for this reason the mango is bitter-fruited, unlovely-fruited, sour-fruited.

original: Rājā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā sabbepi pucimande ca phaggavavalliyo ca chindāpetvā mūlāni
analyzed: rājā tassa vacanam sutvā sabbe api pucimande ca phaggava valliyaḥ ca chindāpetvā mūlāni
translated: Hearing his words, the king had all the Nimba trees and the Phaggavavalli creepers cut down, had the roots dug up,

original: uddharāpetvā samantā amadhurapaṃsuṃ harāpetvā madhurapaṃsuṃ pakkhipāpetvā khīrodakasakkharodakagandhodakehi
analyzed: uddharāpetvā samantā a madhura paṃsum harāpetvā madhura paṃsum pakkhipāpetvā khīra udaka sakkhara udaka gandha udakehi
translated: had unlovely earth removed all round, had lovely earth put in its place, and had the tree sprinkled with milk, sugar-water, and perfumed water.

original: ambaṃ paṭijaggāpesi. So madhurasaṃsaggena puna madhurova ahosi. Rājā pakatiuyyānapālasseva
analyzed: ambam paṭijaggāpesi saḥ madhura saṃsaggena puna madhuraḥ uva ahosi rājā pakati uyyāna pālassa iva
translated: and had it tended by a nurse. By reason of the sweet taste it had, it became sweet again. The king gave the garden to the same gardener as before,

original: uyyānaṃ niyyādetvā yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā yathākammaṃ gato.
analyzed: uyyānam niyyādetvā yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā yathākammam gataḥ
translated: and he lived there as long as he lived, and then passed away according to his deeds.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā ahameva paṇḍitāmacco ahosi”nti.🔽Dadhivāhanajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā aham eva paṇḍita amaccaḥ ahosinti  dadhivāhana jātaka vaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time I myself was the wise minister.”🔽The Birth of the Sweet Drink.

original: [187] 7. Catumaṭṭhajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth Story of the Four-cornered.

original: Ucce viṭabhimāruyhāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto aññataraṃ mahallakabhikkhuṃ
analyzed: ucce idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ aññataram mahallaka bhikkhum
translated: Mounting a high tree-top, etc. This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning an old monk.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Ekadivasaṃ kira dvīsu aggasāvakesu aññamaññaṃ pañhapucchanavissajjanakathāya
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi eka divasam kira dvīsu aggasāvakesu aññamaññam pañha pucchana vissajjana kathāya
translated: One day, it seems, the two chief disciples were sitting together discussing a question.

original: nisinnesu eko mahallako bhikkhu tesaṃ santikaṃ gantvā tatiyo hutvā nisīditvā “bhante,
analyzed: nisinnesu ekaḥ mahallakaḥ bhikkhu tesam santikam gantvā tatiyaḥ hutvā nisīditvā bhante
translated: An old monk came up to them, and sat down as the third. “Reverend Sirs,” said he,

original: mayampi tumhe pañhaṃ pucchissāma, tumhepi attano kaṅkhaṃ amhe pucchathā”ti āha. Therā
analyzed: mayam pi tumhe pañham pucchissāma tumhe pi attano kaṅkham amhe pucchatha iti āha therā
translated: “we will ask you a question, and you must ask us your question.” The two elders

original: taṃ jigucchitvā uṭṭhāya pakkamiṃsu. Therānaṃ dhammaṃ sotuṃ nisinnaparisā samāgamassa
analyzed: tam jigucchitvā uṭṭhāya pakkamiṃsu therānam dhammam sotum nisinna parisā samāgamassa
translated: and, disgusted with them, rose up and left. The company of people who had been sitting down to hear the Law,

original: bhinnakāle satthu santikaṃ gantvā “kiṃ akāle āgatatthā”ti vutte taṃ kāraṇaṃ ārocayiṃsu.
analyzed: bhinna kāle satthu santikam gantvā kim akāle āgatattha ati vutte tam kāraṇam ārocayiṃsu
translated: when the assembly was broken up, went to the Teacher and said, “Why have you come at an improper time?” When this had been said, they told him the reason.

original: Satthā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva sāriputtamoggallānā etaṃ jigucchitvā akathetvā pakkamanti,
analyzed: satthā na bhikkhave idānā iva sāriputta moggallānāḥ etam jigucchitvā a kathetvā pakkamanti
translated: “Monks,” said the Teacher, “this is not the first time Sāriputta and Moggallāna have been disgusted with them and have left without taking leave of them;

original: pubbepi pakkamiṃsū”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: pubbe api pakkamiṃsu iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: in a previous state of existence also they did the same thing.” So saying, he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto araññāyatane rukkhadevatā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ araññāyatane rukkha devatā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was a tree-spirit in a certain forest-tract.

original: ahosi. Atha dve haṃsapotakā cittakūṭapabbatā nikkhamitvā tasmiṃ rukkhe nisīditvā🔽gocarāya gantvā nivattantāpi tasmiṃyeva vissamitvā cittakūṭaṃ gacchanti. Gacchante
analyzed: ahosi atha dve haṃsa potakā cittakūṭa pabbatā nikkhamitvā tasmin rukkhe nisīditvā  gocarāya gantvā nivattantā api tasmin yeva vissamitvā cittakūṭam gacchanti gacchante
translated: Now two young geese, leaving Cittakūṭa mountain, sat down in that tree.🔽After they had gone out for food and returned, they would play about in that very tree and then go to Cittakūṭa. As time went on,🔽they became intimate with the Bodhisatta. When they went out,

original: gacchante kāle tesaṃ bodhisattena saddhiṃ vissāso ahosi. Gacchantā ca āgacchantā
analyzed: gacchante kāle tesam bodhisattena saddhim vissāsaḥ ahosi gacchantā ca āgacchantā
translated: they would say, “We are going out for food.” When they returned,🔽they would say, “We have returned from our foraging.”

original: ca aññamaññaṃ sammoditvā dhammakathaṃ kathetvā pakkamiṃsu. Athekadivasaṃ tesu rukkhagge
analyzed: ca aññam aññam sammoditvā dhamma katham kathetvā pakkamiṃsu atha eka divasam tesu rukkha agge
translated: and after exchanging friendly greetings and holding conversation on various topics, they departed. One day, as they were sitting in the tree-top,

original: nisīditvā bodhisattena saddhiṃ kathentesu eko siṅgālo tassa rukkhassa heṭṭhā ṭhatvā
analyzed: nisīditvā bodhisattena saddhim kathentesu ekaḥ siṅgālo tassa rukkhassa heṭṭhā ṭhatvā
translated: and holding conversation with the Bodhisatta, a jackal, who was sitting below the tree,

original: tehi haṃsapotakehi saddhiṃ mantento paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tehi haṃsa potakehi saddhim mantentaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and holding conversation with the young haṃsas, spoke the first stanza:

original: “Ucce viṭabhimāruyha, mantayavho rahogatā;
analyzed: ucce mantayavhaḥ rahaḥ gatā
translated: “Up in the tree-top, with your mouths agape, you hold your secret conclave;

original: Nīce oruyha mantavho, migarājāpi sossatī”ti.
analyzed: nīce oruyha mantavhaḥ miga rājā api sossati iti
translated: Down on the ground, with your mouths agape, you hold your conclave; the king of beasts will hear you.”

original: Tattha ucce viṭabhimāruyhāti pakatiyā ca ucce imasmiṃ rukkhe uccataraṃ ekaṃ viṭapaṃ🔽abhiruhitvā. Mantayavhoti mantetha kathetha. Nīce oruyhāti otaritvā nīce ṭhāne ṭhatvā
analyzed: tattha ucce pakatiyā ca ucce imasmin rukkhe uccataram ekam viṭapam  abhiruhitvā mantayavhaḥ iti mantetha kathetha nīce oruyhāti otaritvā nīce ṭhāne ṭhatvā
translated: Herein, up in the tree-top means having gone up to a branch of the tree higher than the usual height.🔽With your mouths agape means hold your conversation. Down on the ground means having come down, having gone to a place lower down.

original: mantetha. Migarājāpi sossatīti attānaṃ migarājānaṃ katvā āha. Haṃsapotakā jigucchitvā
analyzed: mantetha miga rājā api sossati iti attānam miga rājānam katvā āha haṃsa potakāḥ jigucchitvā
translated: With your mouths agape means hold your conversation. The king of beasts will hear you means he speaks of himself as the king of beasts. The young haṃsas, being disgusted,

original: uṭṭhāya cittakūṭameva gatā.
analyzed: uṭṭhāya cittakūṭam eva gatā
translated: rose up and went to the Cittakūṭa mountain.

original: Tesaṃ gatakāle bodhisatto siṅgālassa dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tesam gata kāle bodhisatto siṅgālassa dutiyam gātham āha
translated: When they had gone, the Bodhisatta spoke the second stanza to the jackal:

original: “Yaṃ suvaṇṇo suvaṇṇena, devo devena mantaye;
analyzed: yam suvaṇṇaḥ suvaṇṇena devaḥ devena mantaye
translated: “O thou of golden hue, what dost thou, O bird, consult with the other bird?

original: Kiṃ tettha catumaṭṭhassa, bilaṃ pavisa jambukā”ti.🔽Tattha suvaṇṇoti sundaravaṇṇo. Suvaṇṇenāti dutiyena haṃsapotakena. Devo devenāti
analyzed: kim te ittha catumaṭṭhassa bilam pavisa jambuka ati  tattha suvaṇṇo ti sundara vaṇṇaḥ suvaṇṇena ati dutiyena haṃsa potakena devaḥ devena ati
translated: What hast thou to do with the four-footed beast? Enter thou the hole, O jackal!”

original: teyeva dve deve katvā katheti. Catumaṭṭhassāti sarīrena jātiyā sarena guṇenāti imehi
analyzed: teyeva dve deve katvā kathā iti sarīrena jātiyā sarena guṇena ati imehi
translated: Herein, he of golden hue is the beautiful-hued bird. With the other bird is the second young bird. O bird is the bird. What hast thou to do with the four-footed beast? The four-footed beast is the jackal. What hast thou to do with the four-footed beast? What hast thou to do with the jackal? What is the meaning of the words? The meaning is this: “What hast thou to do with the four-footed beast that is impure in body, in birth, in voice, and in qualities?”

original: catūhi maṭṭhassa suddhassāti akkharattho. Asuddhaṃyeva pana taṃ pasaṃsāvacanena nindanto
analyzed: catūhi maṭṭhassa suddhassa ati akkhara atthaḥ asuddham yeva pana tam pasaṃsā vacanena nindantaḥ
translated: But though he is impure, he praises him with the words, “What hast thou to do with the four-footed beast?”

original: evamāha, catūhi lāmakassa kiṃ te ettha siṅgālassāti ayamettha adhippāyo. “Bilaṃ pavisā”ti
analyzed: evam āha catūhi lāmakassa kim te ettha siṅgālassa ati ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ bilam pavisa ati
translated: The meaning is this: “What hast thou to do with the four-footed beast that is impure in body, in birth, in voice, and in qualities?”

original: idaṃ bodhisatto bheravārammaṇaṃ dassetvā taṃ palāpento āha.
analyzed: idam bodhisattaḥ bherava ārammaṇam dassetvā tam palāpentaḥ āha
translated: Enter thou the hole is what the Bodhisatta said in order to frighten the jackal and drive him away.🔽When he had concluded this lesson, the Master identified the Birth: “At that time the old jackal was the Elder, the two young birds were Sāriputta and Moggallāna, and I myself was the tree-spirit.”

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā siṅgālo mahallako ahosi, dve haṃsapotakā sāriputtamoggallānā, rukkhadevatā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā siṅgālaḥ mahallakaḥ ahosi dve haṃsa potakā sāriputta moggallānā rukkha devatā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: The Master related this Birth, “At that time I was the tree-spirit.”

original: Catumaṭṭhajātakavaṇṇanā sattamā.
analyzed: catumaṭṭha jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā
translated: The Commentary on the Catumaṭṭha Birth is finished.

original: [188] 8. Sīhakotthujātakavaṇṇanā
translated: 8. The Story of the Lion’s Whelping

original: Sīhaṅgulī sīhanakhoti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kokālikaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: sīhaṅgulī sīha nakhaḥ ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ kokālikam ārabbha kathesi eka divasam
translated: The Lion’s Claw. This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning Kokālika. One day, it seems,

original: kira kokāliko aññesu bahussutesu dhammaṃ kathentesu sayampi kathetukāmo ahosīti sabbaṃ
analyzed: kira kokālikaḥ aññesu bahu ssutesu dhammam kathentesu sayam pi kathetu kāmo ahosi iti sabbam
translated: Kokālika, while other learned men were preaching the Law, was desirous of preaching it himself. The whole story

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva vitthāretabbaṃ. Taṃ pana pavattiṃ sutvā satthā “na, bhikkhave,
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva vitthāretabbam tam pana pavattim sutvā satthā na bhikkhave
translated: should be told in detail in the way given above. When the Master heard of this occurrence, he said, “Monks,

original: kokāliko idāneva attano saddena pākaṭo jāto, pubbepi pākaṭo ahosī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: kokālikaḥ idānā iva attanaḥ saddena pākaṭaḥ jātaḥ pubbe pi pākaṭaḥ ahosi iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: Kokālika has not become notorious by his own voice only, but in a previous state of existence also he became notorious.” So saying, he related a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto himavantapadese sīho hutvā🔽ekāya siṅgāliyā saddhiṃ saṃvāsamanvāya puttaṃ paṭilabhi. So aṅgulīhi nakhehi kesarena
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ himavanta padese sīhaḥ hutvā  ekāya siṅgāliyā saddhim saṃvāsam anvāya puttam paṭilabhi saḥ aṅgulīhi nakhehi kesarena
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was a lion in the Himalayas.🔽He lived in companionship with a lioness, and had a cub. This cub was like his father in his claws, his tail, his mane,

original: vaṇṇena saṇṭhānenāti imehi ākārehi pitusadiso ahosi, saddena mātusadiso. Athekadivasaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇena saṇṭhānena ati imehi ākārehi pitu sadisaḥ ahosi saddena mātu sadisaḥ atha eka divasam
translated: his colour, and his shape, but in his voice he was like his mother. One day,

original: deve vassitvā vigate sīhesu naditvā sīhakīḷaṃ kīḷantesu sopi tesaṃ antare naditukāmo🔽hutvā siṅgālikaṃ nādaṃ nadi. Athassa saddaṃ sutvā sīhā tuṇhī ahesuṃ. Tassa saddaṃ
analyzed: deve vassitvā vigate sīhesu naditvā sīha kīḷam kīḷantesu saḥ api tesam antare naditu kāmaḥ  hutvā siṅgālikam nādam nadi athassa saddam sutvā sīhā tuṇhī ahesum tassa saddam
translated: When the rain had ceased, the lions roared and indulged in their lion-play. The jackal, too, desired to roar among them.🔽He roared a jackal-roar. When the lions heard his voice, they became silent. Another Bodhisatta, a kinsman of the Bodhisatta, hearing his voice,

original: sutvā aparo bodhisattassa sajātiputto “tāta, ayaṃ sīho vaṇṇādīhi amhehi samāno, saddo
analyzed: sutvā aparaḥ bodhisattassa sajāti putto tāta ayam sīhaḥ vaṇṇa ādīhi amhehi samānaḥ saddo
translated: said, “Dear brother, this lion is like us in color and so on, but his voice

original: panassa aññādiso, ko nāmeso”ti pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: panassa aññādiso kaḥ nāma iso ti pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: is different. Who is he?” and asked the question in the first stanza:

original: “Sīhaṅgulī sīhanakho, sīhapādapatiṭṭhito;
analyzed: sīha aṅgulī sīha nakho sīha pāda patiṭṭhito
translated: “A lion with lion claws and lion paws, a lion standing on lion feet,

original: So sīho sīhasaṅghamhi, eko nadati aññathā”ti.
analyzed: so sīhaḥ sīha saṅghamhi ekaḥ nadati aññathā ati
translated: This lion in the midst of a company of lions roars in a way that is different.”

original: Tattha sīhapādapatiṭṭhitoti sīhapādeheva patiṭṭhito. Eko nadati aññathāti ekova avasesasīhehi asadisena siṅgālasaddena nadanto aññathā nadati.
analyzed: tattha sīha pāda patiṭṭhitaḥ ti sīha pādehi iva patiṭṭhitaḥ ekaḥ nadati aññathā ati ekaḥ iva avasesa sīhehi asadisena siṅgāla saddena nadantaḥ aññathā nadati
translated: Herein, standing on lion feet means standing on lion paws. Roars in a way that is different means roars in a way that is not like the other lions.

original: Taṃ sutvā bodhisatto “tāta, esa tava bhātā siṅgāliyā putto, rūpena mayā sadiso, saddena
analyzed: tam sutvā bodhisatto tāta esa tava bhātā siṅgāliyā putto rūpena mayā sadisaḥ saddena
translated: Hearing this, the Bodhisatta said, “Dear brother, this is your brother, the son of a jackal. In appearance he is like me, but in voice he is not.

original: mātarā sadiso”ti vatvā siṅgāliputtaṃ āmantetvā “tāta, tvaṃ ito paṭṭhāya idha vasanto
analyzed: mātarā sadisaḥ iti vatvā siṅgāli puttam āmantetvā tāta tvam itas paṭṭhāya idha vasanto
translated: “You are like your mother.” Then he addressed the jackal’s cub, saying, “My dear, you must live here henceforth.

original: appasaddo vasa, sace puna nadissasi, siṅgālabhāvaṃ te jānissantī”ti ovadanto dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: appa saddaḥ vasa sace puna na dissasi siṅgāla bhāvam te jānissanti iti ovadantaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Live quietly. If you howl again, they will know that you are a jackal.” And he uttered the second stanza:

original: “Mā tvaṃ nadi rājaputta, appasaddo vane vasa;
analyzed: mā tvam nadi rāja putta appasaddaḥ vane vasa
translated: “Do not howl, O prince of beasts, but live in silence in the forest;

original: Sarena kho taṃ jāneyyuṃ, na hi te pettiko saro”ti.
analyzed: sarena kho tam jāneyyum na hi te pettikaḥ saroti
translated: By your voice they will know you, for your voice is not your father’s.”

original: Tattha rājaputtāti sīhassa migarañño putta. Imañca pana ovādaṃ sutvā puna so nadituṃ nāma na ussahi.
analyzed: tattha rāja puttā ati sīhassa migarañño putta iman ca pana ovādam sutvā puna saḥ naditum nāma na ussahi
translated: Here “prince of beasts” means the cub of the lion, king of beasts. And after hearing this admonition, the cub never again dared to howl.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā siṅgālo kokāliko ahosi, sajātiputto rāhulo, migarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Sīhakotthujātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā siṅgālaḥ kokālikaḥ ahosi sajāti putto rāhulaḥ miga rājā pana aham eva ahosinti  sīhakotthujātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: When the Teacher had related this parable, he identified the characters in the Jātaka as follows: “At that time the jackal was Kokālika, the jackal’s cub was Rāhula, and I myself was the king of beasts.”🔽So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,🔽The Jātaka of the Lion’s Cub is ended.

original: [189] 9. Sīhacammajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Jātaka of the Lion-skin is ended.

original: Netaṃ sīhassa naditanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kokālikaññeva ārabbha kathesi. So imasmiṃ kāle sarabhaññaṃ bhaṇitukāmo ahosi. Satthā taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: na itam sīhassa naditanti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ārabbha kathesi saḥ imasmin kāle sarabhaññam bhaṇitu kāmo ahosi satthā tam pavattim sutvā atītam āhari
translated: This story the Master told while living at Jetavana about Kokālika. Kokālika wanted to make a speech in the assembly. The Master heard of it, and in order to prevent him from speaking, he related the following story.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto kassakakule nibbattitvā vayappatto
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto kassaka kule nibbattitvā vaya patto
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a family of cultivators. When he grew up,

original: kasikammena jīvikaṃ kappesi. Tasmiṃ kāle eko vāṇijo gadrabhabhārakena vohāraṃ karonto
analyzed: kasi kammena jīvikam kappesi tasmin kāle ekaḥ vāṇijaḥ gadrabha bhārakena vohāram karontaḥ
translated: he made a living by his own labour. At that time a certain merchant, who was trading with a load of asses,

original: vicarati. So gatagataṭṭhāne gadrabhassa piṭṭhito bhaṇḍikaṃ otāretvā gadrabhaṃ sīhacammena
analyzed: vicarati saḥ gata gata ṭṭhāne gadrabhassa piṭṭhitaḥ bhaṇḍikam otāretvā gadrabham sīha cammena
translated: came to Benares. He used to unload his wares from the backs of the asses, and then cover the asses with the skin of a lion,

original: pārupitvā sāliyavakhettesu vissajjeti. Khettarakkhakā taṃ disvā “sīho”ti saññāya
analyzed: pārupitvā sāli yava khettesu vissajjeti khetta rakkhakā tam disvā sīhaḥ iti saññāya
translated: and turn them loose in the fields of rice and barley. The keepers of the fields, seeing the lion’s skin,

original: upasaṅkamituṃ na sakkonti. Athekadivasaṃ so vāṇijo ekasmiṃ gāmadvāre nivāsaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: upasaṅkamitum na sakkonti atha eka divasam saḥ vāṇijaḥ ekasmin gāma dvāre nivāsam gahetvā
translated: thought that there was a lion underneath, and dared not approach. One day the merchant took up his quarters at the gate of a certain village,

original: pātarāsaṃ pacāpento tato gadrabhaṃ sīhacammaṃ pārupitvā yavakhette vissajjesi. Khettarakkhakā
analyzed: tatas gadrabham sīha cammam pārupitvā yava khette vissajjesi khetta rakkhakā
translated: and while he was having his breakfast, he covered the ass with the lion’s skin and turned it loose in a field of barley. The keepers of the field,🔽seeing the lion’s skin, thought that there was a lion underneath, and dared not approach.

original: “sīho”ti saññāya taṃ upasaṅkamituṃ asakkontā gehaṃ gantvā ārocesuṃ. Sakalagāmavāsino
analyzed: sīhaḥ iti saññāya tam upasaṅkamitum a sakkontāḥ geham gantvā ārocesum sakala gāma vāsinaḥ
translated: The whole village

original: āvudhāni gahetvā saṅkhe dhamentā bheriyo vādentā khettasamīpaṃ gantvā unnadiṃsu,
analyzed: āvudhāni gahetvā saṅkhe dhamentā bheriyaḥ vādentā khetta samīpam gantvā unnadiṃsu
translated: went to the field, taking their weapons, blowing their conches, beating their drums, and shouting.🔽The ass, frightened at the fear of death, brayed like an ass. Then the Bodhisatta,

original: gadrabho maraṇabhayabhīto gadrabharavaṃ ravi. Athassa gadrabhabhāvaṃ ñatvā bodhisatto
analyzed: gadrabhaḥ maraṇa bhaya bhītaḥ gadrabha ravam athassa gadrabha bhāvam ñatvā bodhisatto
translated: knowing him to be an ass,

original: paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: spoke the first stanza:

original: “Netaṃ sīhassa naditaṃ, na byagghassa na dīpino;
analyzed: netam sīhassa naditam na byagghassa na dīpinaḥ
translated: “This is not the roar of a lion, nor of a tiger, nor of a leopard;

original: Pāruto sīhacammena, jammo nadati gadrabho”ti.
analyzed: pārutaḥ sīha cammena jammaḥ nadati
translated: A cheat, covered with a lion’s skin, the ass is braying.”

original: Tattha jammoti lāmako. Gāmavāsinopi tassa gadrabhabhāvaṃ ñatvā taṃ aṭṭhīni bhañjantā pothetvā sīhacammaṃ ādāya agamaṃsu.
analyzed: tattha jammoti lāmakaḥ gāma vāsinaḥ api tassa gadrabha bhāvam ñatvā tam aṭṭhīni bhañjantā pothetvā sīha cammam ādāya agamaṃsu
translated: Herein, a cheat means a contemptible fellow. The villagers, knowing him to be an ass, broke his bones, and, after beating him, took the lion’s skin and went away.

original: Atha so vāṇijo āgantvā taṃ byasanabhāvappattaṃ gadrabhaṃ disvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha saḥ vāṇijaḥ āgantvā tam byasana bhāva ppattam gadrabham disvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the merchant, coming back, seeing the ass in this state of misfortune, spoke the second stanza:

original: “Cirampi kho taṃ khādeyya, gadrabho haritaṃ yavaṃ;
analyzed: ciram pi khalu tam khādeyya gadrabhaḥ haritam yavam
translated: “For a long time he might have eaten, the ass, green barley;

original: Pāruto sīhacammena, ravamānova dūsayī”ti.
analyzed: pārutaḥ sīha cammena ravamānaḥ iva dūsayīti
translated: But, covered with a lion’s skin, he has spoiled himself by braying.”

original: Tattha tanti nipātamattaṃ, ayaṃ gadrabho attano gadrabhabhāvaṃ ajānāpetvā sīhacammena
analyzed: tattha tanti nipāta mattam ayam gadrabhaḥ attanaḥ gadrabha bhāvam sīha cammena
translated: Herein, the mere letter “tan” is the ass. This ass, not knowing his own status as an ass,🔽

original: pāruto cirampi kālaṃ haritaṃ yavaṃ khādeyyāti attho. Ravamānova dūsayīti attano pana
analyzed: ciram pi kālam haritam yavam khādeyyāti attho ravamānaḥ iva dūsayīti
translated: The meaning is: “Though he be clothed in the skin of a lion, yet for a long time will he eat green barley, as a donkey does.”

original: gadrabharavaṃ ravamānovesa attānaṃ dūsayi, natthettha sīhacammassa dosoti. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: attānam dūsayi nattha ittha sīha cammassa doso ti tasmin
translated: But by braying he betrayed himself. The meaning is: “But by braying his donkey-bray he betrayed himself. The skin of the lion is not to blame.”

original: evaṃ kathenteyeva gadrabho tattheva nipanno mari, vāṇijopi taṃ pahāya pakkāmi.
analyzed: evam gadrabhaḥ tattha iva nipannaḥ vāṇijaḥ api tam pahāya pakkāmi
translated: While he was thus speaking, the donkey fell down dead right there, and the merchant left him there and went his way.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā vāṇijo devadatto ahosi, gadrabho kokāliko, paṇḍitakassako pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā vāṇijaḥ devadattaḥ ahosi gadrabhaḥ kokāliko paṇḍita kassakaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth by saying, “Devadatta was the merchant, Kokālika the donkey, and I myself was the wise farmer.”

original: Sīhacammajātakavaṇṇanā navamā.
analyzed: sīhacammajātakavaṇṇanā navamā
translated: The story of the Lion’s Skin.

original: [190] 10. Sīlānisaṃsajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Benefits of Morality.

original: Passa saddhāya sīlassāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ saddhaṃ upāsakaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: passa saddhāya sīlassa āti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam saddham upāsakam ārabbha
translated: This religious instruction was given by the Teacher while he was in residence at Jetavana with reference to a certain faithful layman.

original: kathesi. So kira saddho pasanno ariyasāvako ekadivasaṃ jetavanaṃ gacchanto sāyaṃ
analyzed: kathesi saḥ kira saddhaḥ pasannaḥ ariya sāvakaḥ eka divasam jetavanam gacchantaḥ sāyam
translated: The story goes that this faithful and devout lay disciple, on his way to Jetavana,

original: aciravatinadītīraṃ gantvā nāvike nāvaṃ tīre ṭhapetvā dhammassavanatthāya gate titthe
analyzed: aciravati nadī tīram gantvā nāvike nāvam tīre ṭhapetvā dhammassavana tthāya gate titthe
translated: reached the bank of the river Aciravatī in the evening. The boatmen had left their boats on the bank and gone to the village to hear the Law.

original: nāvaṃ adisvā buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā nadiṃ otari, pādā udakamhi na osīdiṃsu.
analyzed: nāvam a disvā buddha ārammaṇam pītim gahetvā nadim otari pādāḥ udakamhi na osīdiṃsu
translated: Not seeing a boat, he took his stand on the bank, and fixing his whole thought on the Buddha, entered the river. His feet sank not in the water.

original: So pathavītale gacchanto viya vemajjhaṃ gatakāle vīciṃ passi. Athassa buddhārammaṇā
analyzed: saḥ pathavī tale gacchantaḥ viya vemajjham gata kāle vīcim passi athassa buddha ārammaṇā
translated: As he went on, walking as on dry land, he saw the waves. Then the thought of the Buddha, which he had fixed in his mind, became dim,

original: pīti mandā jātā, pādā osīdituṃ ārabhiṃsu, so puna buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ daḷhaṃ katvā
analyzed: pīti mandā jātā pādāḥ osīditum ārabhiṃsu saḥ puna buddha ārammaṇam pītim daḷham katvā
translated: and his feet began to sink. He fixed his thought on the Buddha with redoubled energy,

original: udakapiṭṭheneva gantvā jetavanaṃ pavisitvā satthāraṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Satthā
analyzed: udaka piṭṭhena iva gantvā jetavanam pavisitvā satthāram vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi satthā
translated: and going on as before, reached Jetavana. He saluted the Teacher, and sat down respectfully on one side. The Teacher

original: tena saddhiṃ paṭisanthāraṃ katvā “upāsaka, kacci maggaṃ āgacchanto appakilamathena
analyzed: tena saddhim paṭisanthāram katvā upāsaka kacci maggam āgacchantaḥ appa kilamathena
translated: welcomed him, and said, “Lay disciple, as you came along the road, I suppose you came without fatigue?”

original: āgatosī”ti pucchitvā “bhante, buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā udakapiṭṭhe patiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: āgataḥ asi iti pucchitvā bhante buddha ārammaṇam pītim gahetvā udaka piṭṭhe patiṭṭham
translated: “Reverend Sir, fixing my thought on the Buddha, I walked on the water, and reached this place without fatigue.”

original: labhitvā pathaviṃ maddanto viya āgatomhī”ti vutte “na kho pana, upāsaka, tvaññeva
analyzed: labhitvā pathavim maddantaḥ viya āgataḥ amhi iti vutte na kho pana upāsaka tvaññā eva
translated: and I have come here as if I had been thrown up on the land.”

original: buddhaguṇe anussaritvā patiṭṭhaṃ laddho, pubbepi upāsakā samuddamajjhe nāvāya bhinnāya
analyzed: buddha guṇe anussaritvā patiṭṭham laddhaḥ pubbe api upāsakā samudda majjhe nāvāya bhinnāya
translated: “Lay disciple, you are not the only one who has found support by calling to mind the special qualities of the Buddha. Formerly, lay disciples, when a ship was wrecked in the midst of the ocean,

original: buddhaguṇe anussarantā patiṭṭhaṃ labhiṃsū”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: buddha guṇe anussarantā patiṭṭham labhiṃsu iti vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: certain lay disciples found support by calling to mind the special qualities of the Buddha.”🔽So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte kassapasammāsambuddhakāle sotāpanno ariyasāvako ekena nhāpitakuṭumbikena saddhiṃ
analyzed: atīte kassapa sammāsambuddha kāle sotāpannaḥ ariyasāvakaḥ ekena nhāpita kuṭumbikena saddhiṃ
translated: In the dispensation of the Supremely Enlightened Kassapa, a certain lay disciple who had attained the Fruit of Conversion went aboard ship with a certain barber.

original: nāvaṃ abhiruhi, tassa nhāpitassa bhariyā “ayya, imassa sukhadukkhaṃ tava bhāro”ti
analyzed: nāvam abhiruhi tassa nhāpitassa bhariyā ayye imassa sukha dukkham tava bhāro ti
translated: The barber’s wife said to him, “Husband, you are responsible for his happiness and his woe.”

original: nhāpitaṃ tassa upāsakassa hatthe nikkhipi. Atha sā nāvā sattame divase samuddamajjhe
analyzed: nhāpitam tassa upāsakassa hatthe nikkhipi atha sā nāvā sattame divase samudda majjhe
translated: So saying, she placed the lay disciple in the hands of the barber. Now on the seventh day the ship was wrecked in mid-ocean.

original: bhinnā, tepi dve janā ekasmiṃ phalake nipannā ekaṃ dīpakaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu. Tattha so nhāpito
analyzed: bhinnā te pi dve janāḥ ekasmin phalake nipannāḥ ekam dīpakam pāpuṇiṃsu tattha saḥ nhāpito
translated: The two men caught hold of a plank and reached an island. There the barber killed birds and cooked them and ate them, and gave to the lay disciple also.

original: sakuṇe māretvā pacitvā khādanto upāsakassapi deti. Upāsako “alaṃ mayha”nti na khādati.
analyzed: sakuṇe māretvā pacitvā khādantaḥ upāsakassa api deti upāsakaḥ alam na khādati
translated: The lay disciple said, “I have no need of this,” and ate not.

original: So cintesi – “imasmiṃ ṭhāne amhākaṃ ṭhapetvā tīṇi saraṇāni aññā patiṭṭhā natthī”ti.
analyzed: saḥ cintesi imasmin ṭhāne amhākam ṭhapetvā tīṇi saraṇāni aññā patiṭṭhā natthi iti
translated: He thought to himself, “In this place, except for the Three Jewels, there is no other refuge for us.”

original: So tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ guṇe anussari. Athassānusarantassa tasmiṃ dīpake nibbatto nāgarājā
analyzed: so tiṇṇam ratanānam guṇe anussari athassa anusarantassa tasmin dīpake nibbattaḥ nāga rājā
translated: He called to mind the virtues of the Three Jewels. As he thus called them to mind, the king of the Nāgas, who had been reborn in that island,

original: attano sarīraṃ mahānāvaṃ katvā māpesi, samuddadevatā niyāmako ahosi, nāvā sattahi
analyzed: attano sarīram mahā nāvam katvā māpesi samudda devatā niyāmakaḥ ahosi nāvā sattahi
translated: caused his own body to be made into a great ship. The goddess of the sea became the steersman. The ship was filled with the Seven Jewels.

original: ratanehi pūrayittha, tayo kūpakā indanīlamaṇimayā ahesuṃ, suvaṇṇamayo laṅkāro, rajatamayāni
analyzed: ratanehi pūrayittha tayo kūpakāḥ inda nīla maṇi mayāḥ ahesum suvaṇṇa mayaḥ laṅkāraḥ rajata mayāni
translated: The three wells were made of sapphire, the ornaments were of gold, the sails were of silver,

original: yottāni, suvaṇṇamayāni yaṭṭhiphiyāni.🔽Samuddadevatā nāvāya ṭhatvā “atthi jambudīpagamikā”ti ghosesi. Upāsako “mayaṃ gamissāmā”ti🔽āha. Tena hi ehi, nāvaṃ abhiruhāti. So nāvaṃ abhiruhitvā nhāpitaṃ pakkosi, samuddadevatā
analyzed: yottāni suvaṇṇa mayāni yaṭṭhiphiyāni  samudda devatā nāvāya ṭhatvā atthi jambudīpa gamikā ati ghosesi upāsakaḥ mayam gamissāma ati  āha tena hi ehi nāvam abhiruha ati saḥ nāvam abhiruhitvā nhāpitam pakkosi samudda devatā
translated: and the oars were of gold.🔽The goddess of the sea, standing in the ship, cried out, “Is there any one who is going to the Island of Jambu?” The lay disciple said, “We will go.”

original: – “tuyhaññeva labbhati, na etassā”ti āha. “Kiṃkāraṇā”ti? “Etassa sīlaguṇācāro natthi,
analyzed: labbhati na etassa ati āha kiṃkāraṇā ati etassa sīla guṇa ācāro natthi
translated: “Very well,” said she, “come aboard.” He came aboard, and called to the barber to come also. The goddess of the sea said to him, “You alone may come aboard, but he may not.” “Why is that?” asked the lay disciple. “He has neither virtue nor good conduct.”

original: taṃ kāraṇaṃ. Ahañhi tuyhaṃ nāvaṃ āhariṃ, na etassā”ti. “Hotu, ahaṃ attanā dinnadānena

translated: His eyes were fixed on her, his heart was bound to her, and he gave orders to a minister, saying, “Go and find out whether this woman has a husband or not.” The minister went and found out that she had a husband.

original: “sassāmikā kira, deva, yānake nisinno puriso etissā sāmiko”ti āha.🔽Rājā paṭibaddhacittaṃ vinodetuṃ asakkonto kilesāturo hutvā “ekena naṃ upāyena mārāpetvā
analyzed: sa sāmikā kira deva yānake nisinno puriso etissā sāmiko ti āha  rājā paṭibaddha cittam vinodetum a sakkontaḥ kilesa āturaḥ hutvā ekena nam upāyena mārāpetvā
translated: “Your majesty, the man who is sitting in the chariot with her is her husband.”🔽The king, unable to rid himself of his passion, became a prey to lust, and thought to himself, “By some means or other I will kill him and get the woman.”

original: itthiṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti cintetvā ekaṃ purisaṃ āmantetvā “gaccha, bho, imaṃ cūḷāmaṇiṃ
analyzed: itthim gaṇhissāmi iti cintetvā ekam purisam āmantetvā gaccha bho imam cūḷāmaṇim
translated: So he called a man to him and said, “Go, take this crest-jewel

original: vīthiṃ gacchanto viya hutvā etassa purisassa yānake pakkhipitvā ehī”ti cūḷāmaṇiṃ
analyzed: vīthim gacchantaḥ viya hutvā etassa purisassa yānake pakkhipitvā ehi iti cūḷāmaṇiṃ
translated: and place it in the chariot of that man as though you were going along the street.” So saying, he gave him the crest-jewel

original: datvā uyyojesi. So “sādhū”ti taṃ gahetvā gantvā yānake ṭhapetvā “ṭhapito me, devā”ti
analyzed: datvā uyyojesi saḥ sādhu iti tam gahetvā gantvā yānake ṭhapetvā ṭhapitaḥ me deva iti
translated: and sent him away. The man said, “Very well,” took the jewel, went and placed it in the chariot, and returned and reported the matter to the king.

original: āgantvā ārocesi. Rājā “cūḷāmaṇi me naṭṭho”ti āha, manussā ekakolāhalaṃ akaṃsu. Rājā
analyzed: āgantvā ārocesi rājā cūḷāmaṇi me naṭṭhaḥ ti āha manussāḥ eka kolāhalam akaṃsu rājā
translated: The king said, “My crest-jewel is lost,” and the people raised a great clamor. The king

original: “sabbadvārāni pidahitvā sañcāraṃ chinditvā coraṃ pariyesathā”ti āha, rājapurisā tathā🔽akaṃsu, nagaraṃ ekasaṅkhobhaṃ ahosi. Itaro puriso manusse gahetvā bodhisattassa santikaṃ
analyzed: sabba dvārāni pidahitvā sañcāram chinditvā coram āha rāja purisā tathā  akaṃsu nagaram eka saṅkhobham ahosi itaraḥ purisaḥ manusse gahetvā bodhisattassa santikaṃ
translated: “Shut all the gates, cut off all communication, and search for the thief.” The king’s men did as they were told.

original: gantvā “bho, yānakaṃ ṭhapehi, rañño cūḷāmaṇi naṭṭho, yānakaṃ sodhessāmī”ti yānakaṃ
analyzed: gantvā bho yānakam ṭhapehi rañño cūḷāmaṇi naṭṭhaḥ yānakam sodhessāmi iti yānakam
translated: The whole city was in an uproar. The other man took the people to the Bodhisatta and said, “Look here, stop the carriage; the king’s crest-jewel is missing; I will search the carriage.”

original: sodhento attanā ṭhapitamaṇiṃ gahetvā bodhisattaṃ gahetvā “maṇicoro”ti hatthehi ca
analyzed: sodhentaḥ attanā ṭhapita maṇim gahetvā bodhisattam gahetvā hatthehi ca
translated: While searching the carriage he took the jewel which he had hidden, and seizing the Bodhisatta, said, “Here is the jewel-thief.” He beat him with his hands and feet,

original: pādehi ca pothetvā pacchābāhaṃ bandhitvā netvā “ayaṃ maṇicoro”ti rañño dassesi. Rājāpi
analyzed: pādehi ca pothetvā pacchābāham bandhitvā netvā ayam maṇi coro ti raññaḥ dassesi rājā api
translated: bound his hands behind his back, and took him to the king, saying, “Here is the jewel-thief.” The king ordered,

original: “sīsamassa chindathā”ti āṇāpesi.
analyzed: sīsam assa chindatha ati āṇāpesi
translated: “Cut off his head.”

original: Atha naṃ rājapurisā catukke catukke kasāhi tāḷentā dakkhiṇadvārena nagarā nikkhamāpesuṃ.
analyzed: atha nam rāja purisā catukke catukke kasāhi tāḷentā dakkhiṇa dvārena nagarā nikkhamāpesuṃ
translated: The king’s men took him out of the city by the southern gate, beating him at every cross-roads with whips.

original: Sujātāpi yānakaṃ pahāya bāhā paggayha paridevamānā “sāmi, maṃ nissāya imaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: sujātā api yānakam pahāya bāhā paggayha paridevamānā sāmi mama nissāya imam dukkham
translated: Sujata, throwing off her carriage, threw up her arms and lamented, “My husband, it is through me that you have come to this misery.

original: pattosī”ti paridevamānā pacchato pacchato agamāsi. Rājapurisā “sīsamassa chindissāmā”ti🔽bodhisattaṃ uttānaṃ nipajjāpesuṃ. Taṃ disvā sujātā attano sīlaguṇaṃ āvajjetvā “natthi
analyzed: patto asi iti paridevamānā pacchatas pacchatas agamāsi rāja purisā sīsam assa chindissāma ati  bodhisattam uttānam nipajjāpesum tam disvā sujātā attano sīla guṇam āvajjetvā natthi
translated: and followed after him, lamenting. The king’s men, thinking to cut off his head,

original: vata maññe imasmiṃ loke sīlavantānaṃ viheṭhake pāpasāhasikamanusse nisedhetuṃ samatthā
analyzed: vata maññe imasmin loke sīlavantānam viheṭhake pāpa sāhasika manusse nisedhetum samatthā
translated: laid the Bodhisatta on his back. Seeing this, Sujātā, recollecting her own virtue, said: “There are, indeed, no gods in this world able to restrain wicked, violent men who oppress the virtuous.

original: devatā nāmā”tiādīni vatvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: devatāḥ nāma ati ādīni vatvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: ” And so on. Then she spoke the first stanza:

original: “Na santi devā pavasanti nūna, na hi nūna santi idha lokapālā;
analyzed: na santi devā pavasanti nūna na hi nūna santi idha lokapālā
translated: “No gods are there, no guardians of the world,

original: Sahasā karontānamasaññatānaṃ, na hi nūna santi paṭisedhitāro”ti.
analyzed: sahasā karontānam asaññatānam na hi nūna santi paṭisedhitāraḥ ti
translated: No one to check the violent and unrestrained.

original: Tattha na santi, devāti imasmiṃ loke sīlavantānaṃ olokanakā pāpānañca nisedhakā na🔽santi nūna devā. Pavasanti nūnāti evarūpesu vā kiccesu uppannesu nūna pavasanti pavāsaṃ
analyzed: tattha na santi devāti imasmin loke sīlavantānam olokanakā pāpānam ca nisedhakā na  santi nūna devā pavasanti nūna ati evarūpesu vā kiccesu uppannesu nūna pavasanti pavāsam
translated: ” Herein, no gods are there means that in this world there are no gods who look on the virtuous and restrain the wicked.🔽No guardians of the world means that when such business as this arises, they do not go forth, do not go to the place where the business is.

original: gacchanti. Idha, lokapālāti imasmiṃ loke lokapālasammatā samaṇabrāhmaṇāpi sīlavantānaṃ
analyzed: gacchanti imasmin loke lokapāla sammatā samaṇa brāhmaṇā api
translated: No one to check the violent and unrestrained means that in this world there are no ascetics and brahmans acknowledged as guardians of the world who can restrain the violent and unrestrained.

original: anuggāhakā na hi nūna santi. Sahasā karontānamasaññatānanti sahasā avīmaṃsitvā sāhasikaṃ🔽dāruṇaṃ kammaṃ karontānaṃ dussīlānaṃ. Paṭisedhitāroti evarūpaṃ kammaṃ mā karittha,
analyzed: anuggāhakāḥ na hi nūna santi sahasā sahasā a vīmaṃsitvā sāhasikam  dāruṇam kammam karontānam dussīlānam paṭisedhitāro ti evarūpam kammam mā karittha
translated: “There are none who will reprove” means that there are none who will reprove those who do evil deeds rashly, without reflection,🔽and who are unvirtuous. “There are none who will restrain” means that there are none who will restrain them, saying, “Do not do such deeds;

original: na labbhā etaṃ kātunti paṭisedhentā natthīti attho.🔽Evaṃ tāya sīlasampannāya paridevamānāya sakkassa devarañño nisinnāsanaṃ uṇhākāraṃ
analyzed: na labbhā etam kātunti paṭisedhentā na atthi iti attho  evam tāya sīla sampannāya paridevamānāya sakkassa deva raññaḥ nisinna āsanam uṇhākāram
translated: it is not right to do them.”

original: dassesi, sakko “ko nu kho maṃ sakkattato cāvetukāmo”ti āvajjento imaṃ kāraṇaṃ ñatvā
analyzed: dassesi sakkaḥ kaḥ nu kho mam sakkattataḥ cāvetu kāmaḥ iti āvajjentaḥ imam kāraṇam ñatvā
translated: Thus, as she was lamenting in this way, the seat of Sakka, the king of the gods, became hot because of her virtue. Sakka thought, “Who is trying to deprive me of my position?”

original: “bārāṇasirājā atipharusakammaṃ karoti, sīlasampannaṃ sujātaṃ kilameti, gantuṃ dāni🔽me vaṭṭatī”ti devalokā oruyha attano ānubhāvena hatthipiṭṭhe nisinnaṃ taṃ pāparājānaṃ
analyzed: bārāṇasi rājā ati pharusa kammam karoti sīla sampannam su jātam kilameti gantum dāni  me vaṭṭati iti deva lokāḥ oruyha attanaḥ ānubhāvena hatthi piṭṭhe nisinnam tam pāpa rājānam
translated: He understood the reason for it and thought, “The king of Bārāṇasī is doing very cruel deeds. He is oppressing Sujāta, who is virtuous. I must go🔽and help him.” He descended from the world of the gods and, by his own power, made the wicked king fall from the back of his elephant onto his back on the ground,

original: hatthikkhandhato otāretvā dhammagaṇḍikāya uttānaṃ nipajjāpetvā bodhisattaṃ ukkhipitvā
analyzed: hatthi kkhandhataḥ otāretvā dhammagaṇḍikāya uttānam nipajjāpetvā bodhisattam ukkhipitvā
translated: and he lifted up the Bodhisatta.

original: sabbālaṅkārehi alaṅkaritvā rājavesaṃ gāhāpetvā hatthikkhandhe nisīdāpesi. Rājapurisā
analyzed: sabba alaṅkārehi alaṅkaritvā rāja vesam gāhāpetvā hatthi kkhandhe nisīdāpesi rāja purisā
translated: and having adorned him with all ornaments, he made him put on royal garments and seated him on the back of an elephant. The king’s men

analyzed: pharasum ukkhipitvā sīsam chindantā rañño sīsam chindiṃsu chinna kāleya iva cassa rañño
translated: raised an axe and cut off his head, and at the very moment of his head being cut off they

original: sīsabhāvaṃ jāniṃsu. Sakko devarājā dissamānakasarīreneva bodhisattassa santikaṃ gantvā
analyzed: sīsa bhāvam jāniṃsu sakkaḥ devarājā dissamānaka sarīrena iva bodhisattassa santikam gantvā
translated: recognised the head to be that of the king. Sakka, King of the Gods, went to the Bodhisatta’s presence with his body still visible,

original: bodhisattassa rājābhisekaṃ katvā sujātāya ca aggamahesiṭṭhānaṃ dāpesi. Amaccā ceva
analyzed: bodhisattassa rāja abhisekam katvā sujātāya ca aggamahesi ṭṭhānam dāpesi amaccā ca iva
translated: and after performing the royal consecration for the Bodhisatta, he gave Sujātā the position of chief queen. The ministers

original: brāhmaṇagahapatikādayo ca sakkaṃ devarājānaṃ disvā “adhammikarājā mārito, idāni amhehi
analyzed: brāhmaṇa gahapatika ādayaḥ ca sakkam devarājānam disvā adhammika rājā māritaḥ idāni amhehi
translated: and the brahmin householders and so on, after seeing Sakka, King of the Gods, (thought): “The unrighteous king has been killed, now we have obtained a righteous king

original: sakkadattiko dhammikarājā laddho”ti somanassappattā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: sakkadattikaḥ dhammika rājā laddhaḥ ti somanassa ppattāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: given by Sakka.” They were filled with joy.

original: Sakkopi ākāse ṭhatvā “ayaṃ vo sakkadattiko rājā, ito paṭṭhāya dhammena rajjaṃ kāressati.
analyzed: sakko api ākāse ṭhatvā ayam vaḥ sakkadattikaḥ rājā itas paṭṭhāya dhammena rajjam kāressati
translated: Sakka, standing in the sky, (said): “This is your king given by Sakka, from now on he will rule righteously.

original: Sace hi rājā adhammiko hoti, devo akāle vassati, kāle na vassati, chātabhayaṃ rogabhayaṃ
analyzed: sace hi rājā adhammikaḥ hoti devaḥ akāle vassati kāle na vassati chāta bhayam roga bhayam
translated: If the king is unrighteous, the god rains at the wrong time, and does not rain at the right time, there is a danger of famine, a danger of disease,

original: satthabhayanti imāni tīṇi bhayāni upagatāneva hontī”ti ovadanto dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sattha bhayanti imāni tīṇi bhayāni upagatāna eva honti iti ovadantaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: These three fears are already come to him.” So speaking, he pronounced the second stanza:

original: “Akāle vassatī tassa, kāle tassa na vassati;
analyzed: akāle vassati tassa kāle tassa na vassati
translated: “At the wrong time it rains for him, at the right time it rains not for him;

original: Saggā ca cavati ṭhānā, nanu so tāvatā hato”ti.
analyzed: saggā ca cavati ṭhānā nanu saḥ tāvatā hataḥ iti
translated: He falls from his place in heaven, is he not then destroyed thereby?”

original: Tattha akāleti adhammikarañño rajje ayuttakāle sassānaṃ pakkakāle vā lāyanamaddanādikāle🔽vā devo vassati. Kāleti yuttapayuttakāle vapanakāle taruṇasassakāle gabbhaggahaṇakāle
analyzed: tattha akāle ti adhammika raññaḥ rajje ayutta kāle sassānam pakka kāle vā lāyana maddana ādi kāle  vā devaḥ vassati kāleti yutta payutta kāle vapana kāle taruṇa sassa kāle gabbha ggahaṇa kāle
translated: Herein, at the wrong time means that in the realm of a unrighteous king the rain falls at an unfitting time, at the time when the crops are ripe, or at the time of threshing and winnowing,🔽or at the time of sowing, or at the time when the crops are young, or at the time of conception. At the right time means that it rains not at the fitting time, at the time of sowing, or at the time when the crops are young, or at the time of conception.

original: ca na vassati. Saggā ca cavati ṭhānāti saggasaṅkhātā ṭhānā devalokā cavatīti attho.
analyzed: ca na vassati saggā ca cavati ṭhānā ati sagga saṅkhātā ṭhānā deva lokā cavati iti attho
translated: He falls from his place in heaven means that he falls from his place called heaven, from the world of the gods.

original: Adhammikarājā hi appaṭilābhavasena devalokā cavati nāma, saggepi vā rajjaṃ kārento🔽adhammikarājā tato cavatītipi attho. Nanu so tāvatā hatoti nanu so adhammiko rājā
analyzed: adhammika rājā hi appaṭilābha vasena deva lokā cavati nāma sagge pi vā rajjam kārento  adhammika rājā tatas cavati iti pi atthaḥ nanu so tāvatā hataḥ ti nanu saḥ adhammikaḥ rājā
translated: For a unrighteous king falls from the world of the gods by way of non-acquisition. Or the meaning may be that a unrighteous king, even while reigning in heaven,

original: ettakena hato hoti. Atha vā ekaṃsavācī ettha nu-kāro, neso ekaṃsena ettāvatā hato,
analyzed: ettakena hataḥ hoti atha vai ekaṃsa vācī ettha nukāraḥ na isaḥ ekaṃsena ettāvatā hataḥ
translated: falls from there. Is he not then destroyed thereby? means that he is destroyed by so much. Or else, the nu-kāra is used here in the sense of ekaṃsena, not in the sense of ekaṃsena ettāvatā hato,

original: aṭṭhasu pana mahānirayesu soḷasasu ca ussadanirayesu dīgharattaṃ so haññissatīti ayamettha attho.
analyzed: aṭṭhasu pana mahānirayesu soḷasasu ca ussada nirayesu dīgharattam saḥ haññissati iti ayam ettha attho
translated: “For a long time he will be tortured in the eight great hells and in the sixteen minor hells.”

original: Evaṃ sakko mahājanassa ovādaṃ datvā attano devaṭṭhānameva agamāsi. Bodhisattopi dhammena rajjaṃ kāretvā saggapuraṃ pūresi.
analyzed: evam sakkaḥ mahā janassa ovādam da tvā attanaḥ devaṭṭhānam eva agamāsi bodhisattaḥ api dhammena rajjam kāretvā saggapuram pūresi
translated: Thus did Sakka give counsel to the multitude, and then he returned to his own abode. The Bodhisatta ruled the kingdom righteously and filled the city of the gods.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he expounded the Truths, and identified the Birth:

original: adhammikarājā devadatto ahosi, sakko anuruddho, sujātā rāhulamātā, sakkadattiyarājā
analyzed: adhammika rājā devadattaḥ ahosi sakkaḥ anuruddhaḥ sujātā rāhula mātā sakkadattiya rājā
translated: “At that time Devadatta was the unrighteous king, Anuruddha was Sakka, Sujātā was Rāhulamātā,

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Maṇicorajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: pana aham eva  maṇi cora jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: and I myself was the king who gave away his head.”🔽So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: [195] 5. Pabbatūpattharajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Pabbatūpatthare rammeti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kosalarājānaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: pabbata upatthare rammā iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ kosala rājānam ārabbha kathesi
translated: The Conversion of King Udena🔽This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a king of Kosala.

original: Kosalarañño kira eko amacco antepure padussi. Rājāpi parivīmaṃsamāno taṃ tathato
analyzed: kosala raññaḥ kira ekaḥ amaccaḥ antepure padussi rājā api parivīmaṃsamānaḥ tam tathatas
translated: A certain minister of the king of Kosala was guilty of a crime in the palace. The king, in order to find out the truth, had him arrested and put in chains.

original: ñatvā “satthu ārocessāmī”ti jetavanaṃ gantvā satthāraṃ vanditvā “bhante, amhākaṃ
analyzed: ñatvā satthu ārocessāmi iti jetavanam gantvā satthāram vanditvā bhante amhākam
translated: “I will inform the Teacher,” and went to Jetavana, saluted the Teacher, and asked him, “Reverend Sir,

original: antepure eko amacco padussi, tassa kiṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti pucchi. Atha naṃ satthā “upakārako
analyzed: antepure ekaḥ amacco padussi tassa kim kātum vaṭṭati iti pucchi atha nam satthā upakārako
translated: a minister in our palace has committed a crime. What should be done with him?” The Teacher asked him, “Great king,

original: te, mahārāja, so ca amacco sā ca itthī piyā”ti pucchitvā “āma, bhante, ativiya upakārako
analyzed: te mahā rāja saḥ ca amacco sā ca itthī piyāti pucchitvā āma bhante upakārako
translated: is this minister a benefactor of yours, and is this woman dear to you?” “Yes, Reverend Sir, he is a very great benefactor,

analyzed: sakalam rāja kulam sandhāreti sā api me itthī piyā iti vutte mahā rāja attanaḥ upakārakesu
translated: and he supports the whole royal family, and this woman is dear to me.” “Great king,” said the Teacher, “it is not right to be angry with those who are one’s benefactors,

original: sevakesu piyāsu ca itthīsu dubbhituṃ na sakkā’ti pubbepi rājāno paṇḍitānaṃ kathaṃ
analyzed: sevakesu piyāsu ca itthīsu na sakkā ati pubbe pi rājāno paṇḍitānam katham
translated: nor with those who are one’s servants, nor with those who are dear to one. In the days of yore, kings, having heard the words of the wise,
