analyzed: sutvā vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: were even-tempered.” So saying, he told an old-time story.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto amaccakule nibbattitvā vayappatto
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ amacca kule nibbattitvā vaya patto
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was born in the family of a minister,

original: tassa atthadhammānusāsako ahosi. Athassa rañño eko amacco antepure padussi. Rājā
analyzed: tassa attha dhamma anusāsakaḥ ahosi athassa raññaḥ ekaḥ amaccaḥ antepure padussi rājā
translated: and when he grew up, he became the minister’s adviser in all matters of profit and of righteousness. Now a certain minister of the king committed a crime in the palace. The king

original: naṃ tathato ñatvā “amaccopi me bahūpakāro, ayaṃ itthīpi me piyā, dvepi ime nāsetuṃ
analyzed: nam tathatas ñatvā amaccaḥ pi me bahu upakāraḥ ayam itthī pi me piyā dve pi ime
translated: “The minister is very helpful to me, and I love this woman. I cannot do without either of them.

original: na sakkā, paṇḍitāmaccaṃ pañhaṃ pucchitvā sace sahitabbaṃ bhavissati, sahissāmi, no
analyzed: na sakkā paṇḍita amaccam pañham pucchitvā sace sahitabbam bhavissati sahissāmi no
translated: If I ask the wise minister a question and if he answers it, I will accept it;

original: ce, na sahissāmī”ti bodhisattaṃ pakkosāpetvā āsanaṃ datvā “paṇḍita, pañhaṃ pucchissāmī”ti
analyzed: ce na sahissāmi iti bodhisattam pakkosāpetvā āsanam da tvā paṇḍita pañham pucchissāmi iti
translated: if not, I will not accept it.” So he summoned the Bodhisatta, gave him a seat, and said, “Wise man, I will ask you a question.”

original: vatvā “pucchatha, mahārāja, vissajjessāmī”ti vutte pañhaṃ pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vatvā pucchatha mahā rāja vissajjessāmi iti vutte pañham pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: “Ask, great king, and I will answer.” When the question was put, he answered it with the first stanza:

original: “Pabbatūpatthare ramme, jātā pokkharaṇī sivā;
analyzed: pabbata upatthare ramme jātā pokkharaṇī sivā
translated: “On a delightful mountain-top, A lotus-pool was formed, and there

original: Taṃ siṅgālo apāpāyi, jānaṃ sīhena rakkhita”nti.
analyzed: tam siṅgālaḥ apāpāyi jānam sīhena rakkhitanti
translated: The jackal drove away the lion, Though he knew the lion guarded it.”

original: Tattha pabbatūpatthare rammeti himavantapabbatapāde pattharitvā ṭhite aṅgaṇaṭṭhāneti🔽attho. Jātā pokkharaṇī sivāti sivā sītalā madhurodakā pokkharaṇī nibbattā, apica
analyzed: tattha pabbata upatthare rammā iti himavanta pabbata pāde pattharitvā ṭhite aṅgaṇa ṭṭhānā iti  atthaḥ jātā pokkharaṇī sivā ati sivā sītalā madhura udakā pokkharaṇī nibbattā apica
translated: Herein, on a delightful mountain-top means in a place on the slope of the Himalayas, a mountain-top that is delightful, a courtyard formed by the mountain-top.🔽A lotus-pool was formed means a lotus-pool was formed that was cool and had sweet water. Moreover, a river covered with lotuses is also a lotus-pool.

original: kho pokkharasañchannā nadīpi pokkharaṇīyeva. Apāpāyīti apa-iti upasaggo, apāyīti
analyzed: kho pokkhara sañchannā nadī pi pokkharaṇīyā iva apāpāyi iti apaiti upasaggaḥ apāyi iti
translated: The prefix apa- is a negative particle; apāyī means he did not go away.

original: attho. Jānaṃ sīhena rakkhitanti sā pokkharaṇī sīhaparibhogā sīhena rakkhitā, sopi
analyzed: sā pokkharaṇī sīha paribhogā sīhena rakkhitā sā upi
translated: The meaning is: Knowing that the lotus-pond was guarded by a lion, the jackal,

original: naṃ siṅgālo “sīhena rakkhitā aya”nti jānantova apāyi. Taṃ kiṃ maññati, bālo siṅgālo
analyzed: nam siṅgālo sīhena rakkhitāḥ ayanti jānanto iva apāyi tam kim maññati bālaḥ siṅgālo
translated: knowing that it was guarded by a lion, went away. What do you think, was the foolish jackal

original: sīhassa abhāyitvā piveyya evarūpaṃ pokkharaṇinti ayametthādhippāyo.
analyzed: sīhassa piveyya evarūpam pokkharaṇin ti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ
translated: able to drink the water of that lotus-pond without fearing the lion? This is the purport here.

original: Bodhisatto “addhā etassa antepure eko amacco paduṭṭho bhavissatī”ti ñatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ addhā etassa antepure ekaḥ amacco paduṭṭhaḥ bhavissati iti ñatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: The Bodhisatta thought: “Surely, there is a wicked minister in his palace.” Knowing this, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Pivanti ce mahārāja, sāpadāni mahānadiṃ;
analyzed: pivanti ce mahā rāja sāpadāni mahānadim
translated: “If, O great king, all the beasts drink from the great river,

original: Na tena anadī hoti, khamassu yadi te piyā”ti.
analyzed: na tena anadī hoti khamassu yadi te piyāti
translated: It is not for that reason that the river is no longer a river; forgive me if I have offended you.”

original: Tattha sāpadānīti na kevalaṃ siṅgālova, avasesāni sunakhapasadabiḷāramigādīni sabbasāpadāni
analyzed: tattha sāpadāni iti na kevalam avasesāni sunakha pasada biḷāra miga ādīni sabba sāpadāni
translated: Herein, all the beasts means not only the jackal, but also the remaining dogs, cats, foxes, deer, and so on.🔽If all the beasts drink from the river which is covered with lotuses and has received the name “lotus-pond,”

original: taṃ pokkharasañchannattā “pokkharaṇī”ti laddhanāmaṃ nadiṃ pivanti ce. Na tena anadī
analyzed: tam pokkhara sañchanna ttā pokkharaṇī iti laddha nāmam nadim pivanti ce na tena a nadī
translated: It is not for that reason that the river is no longer a river.

original: hotīti nadiyañhi dvipadacatuppadāpi ahimacchāpi sabbe pipāsitā pānīyaṃ pivanti, na
analyzed: hoti iti sabbe pipāsitā pānīyam pivanti na
translated: For the river is drunk by both bipeds and quadrupeds, by snakes and fish, and by all who are thirsty. It is not for that reason that the river is no longer a river.

original: sā tena kāraṇena anadī nāma hoti, nāpi ucchiṭṭhanadī. Kasmā? Sabbesaṃ sādhāraṇattā.
analyzed: sā tena kāraṇena anadī nāma hoti na api ucchiṭṭhanadī kasmā sabbesam sādhāraṇa ttā
translated: and for that reason it is not an impure river, nor a river of refuse. Why? Because it is common to all.

original: Yathā nadī yena kenaci pītā na dussati, evaṃ itthīpi kilesavasena sāmikaṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: yathā nadī yena kenacid pītā na dussati evam itthī api kilesa vasena sāmikam atikkamitvā
translated: Just as a river, when drunk by one, does not become impure, so also a woman, when violated by one man through lust,

original: aññena saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ gatā neva anitthī hoti. Kasmā? Sabbesaṃ sādhāraṇabhāvena.
analyzed: aññena saddhim saṃvāsam gatā na iva anitthī hoti kasmā sabbesam sādhāraṇa bhāvena
translated: does not become an unwoman. Why? Because of her commonness to all.

original: Nāpi ucchiṭṭhitthī. Kasmā? Odakantikatāya suddhabhāvena. Khamassu yadi te piyāti
analyzed: nā api ucchiṭṭhitthī kasmai odakantikatāya suddha bhāvena khamassu yadi te piyāti
translated: Nor is she a woman of refuse. Why? Because of her purity, which is like the water in the river. If you love her, forgive her.

original: yadi pana te sā itthī piyā, so ca amacco bahūpakāro, tesaṃ ubhinnampi khamassu majjhattabhāvena tiṭṭhāhīti.
analyzed: yadi pana te sā itthī piyā so ca amaccaḥ bahu upakāro tesam ubhinnam pi khamassu majjhatta bhāvena tiṭṭhāhi iti
translated: If you love that woman and if that minister is very helpful to you, forgive them both and be impartial.

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto rañño ovādaṃ adāsi. Rājā tassa ovāde ṭhatvā “puna evarūpaṃ pāpakammaṃ
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ rañño ovādam adāsi rājā tassa ovāde ṭhatvā punar evarūpam pāpa kammam
translated: Thus the Great Being gave advice to the king. The king, following his advice, said, “Do not commit such a crime again.”

original: mā karitthā”ti vatvā ubhinnampi khami. Tato paṭṭhāya te oramiṃsu. Rājāpi dānādīni
analyzed: mā karittha ati vatvā ubhinnam api khami tato paṭṭhāya te oramiṃsu rājā api dāna ādīni
translated: and he forgave them both. From that time on they were reconciled. The king also, having performed such meritorious deeds as charity,

original: puññāni katvā jīvitapariyosāne saggapuraṃ pūresi. Kosalarājāpi imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ
analyzed: puññāni katvā jīvita pariyosāne saggapuram pūresi kosala rājā api imam dhamma desanam
translated: at the end of his life was reborn in the city of the gods. The king of Kosala, having heard this Dhamma instruction,

original: sutvā tesaṃ ubhinnampi khamitvā majjhatto ahosi.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā rājā ānando ahosi, paṇḍitāmacco pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: sutvā tesam ubhinnam pi khamitvā majjhattaḥ ahosi  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā rājā ānandaḥ ahosi paṇḍita amacco pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: and having heard the complaints of both, he remained impartial.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth by saying in conclusion, “At that time the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the wise minister.”

original: Pabbatūpattharajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: pabbatūpatthara jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: Thus did the Master tell this story.

original: [196] 6. Valāhakassajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth of Valāhaka.

original: Ye na kāhanti ovādanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuṃ ārabbha
analyzed: ye na ovādanti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum ārabbha
translated: They who do not follow counsel. The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a monk who was discontented.

original: kathesi. So hi bhikkhu satthārā “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti puṭṭho
analyzed: kathesi saḥ hi bhikkhu satthārā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ
translated: For this monk, when asked by the Master, “Is it true, monk, that you are discontented?”

original: “sacca”nti vatvā “kiṃ kāraṇā”ti vutte “ekaṃ alaṅkataṃ mātugāmaṃ disvā kilesavasenā”ti
analyzed: saccam ti vatvā kim kāraṇā iti vutte ekam alaṅkatam mātu gāmam disvā kilesa vasena ati
translated: answered, “It is true.” “What is the reason?” “Because I saw a woman adorned with ornaments, and lust arose in me.”

original: āha. Atha naṃ satthā “itthiyo nāmetā bhikkhu attano rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbehi
analyzed: āha atha nam satthā itthiyaḥ nāma itāḥ bhikkhu attanaḥ rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabbehi
translated: Then the Master said to him, “Monks, women, by their beauty, their voice, their scent, their taste, their touch,

original: ceva itthikuttavilāsehi ca purise palobhetvā attano vase katvā vasaṃ upagatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ca iva itthi kutta vilāsehi ca purise palobhetvā attanaḥ vase katvā vasam upagata bhāvam
translated: and by their womanly wiles,

original: ñatvā sīlavināsañceva dhanavināsañca pāpanaṭṭhena ‘yakkhiniyo’ti vuccanti. Pubbepi
analyzed: ñatvā sīla vināsam ca iva dhana vināsam ca pāpanaṭṭhena yakkhiniyaḥ ti vuccanti pubbe pi
translated: and because they destroy both virtue and wealth, they are called ‘yakkhinīs’ in the sense of bringing misfortune.🔽For in the past, too,

original: hi yakkhiniyo itthikuttena ekaṃ purisasatthaṃ upasaṅkamitvā vāṇije palobhetvā attano🔽vase katvā puna aññe purise disvā te sabbepi jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpetvā ubhohi hanukapassehi
analyzed: hi yakkhiniyaḥ itthi kuttena ekam purisa sattham upasaṅkamitvā vāṇije palobhetvā attano  vase katvā puna aññe purise disvā te sabbe pi jīvita kkhayam pāpetvā ubhohi hanu kapassehi
translated: yakkhinīs, having assumed the form of women, enticed a band of merchants, brought them under their power,

original: lohitena paggharantena mukhaṃ pūrāpetvā khādiṃsū”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: lohitena paggharantena mukham pūrāpetvā khādiṃsu iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: and when they saw other men, they killed them all, and with blood gushing from both their cheeks, they filled their mouths and ate them.” So saying, he related the following story.

original: Atīte tambapaṇṇidīpe sirīsavatthu nāma yakkhanagaraṃ ahosi, tattha yakkhiniyo vasiṃsu.
analyzed: atīte tambapaṇṇi dīpe sirīsavatthu nāma yakkha nagaram ahosi tattha yakkhiniyaḥ vasiṃsu
translated: In the past, in the island of Tambapaṇṇi, there was a city of the yakkhas called Sirīsa. There the yakkhinīs lived.

original: Tā bhinnanāvānaṃ vāṇijānaṃ āgatakāle alaṅkatapaṭiyattā khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ gāhāpetvā🔽dāsigaṇaparivutā dārake aṅkenādāya vāṇije upasaṅkamanti. Tesaṃ “manussāvāsaṃ āgatamhā”ti
analyzed: tāḥ bhinnanāvānam vāṇijānam āgata kāle alaṅkata paṭiyattā khādanīya bhojanīyam gāhāpetvā  dāsi gaṇa parivutāḥ dārake aṅkena ādāya vāṇije upasaṅkamanti tesam manussa āvāsam āgatamha ati
translated: When a shipwrecked band of merchants came there, they had themselves adorned and decked out, took food and drink in their hands,

original: sañjānanatthaṃ tattha tattha kasigorakkhādīni karonte manusse gogaṇe sunakheti evamādīni
analyzed: sañjānana attham tattha tattha kasi gorakkha ādīni karonte manusse go gaṇe sunakha iti evamādīni
translated: and surrounded by a retinue of slave women, with their children on their hips, they approached the merchants. In order that they might think, “We have come to a place inhabited by men,” they had men working here and there in the fields, in the care of cattle, and so on, and they had cows, dogs, and so on.

original: dassenti, vāṇijānaṃ santikaṃ gantvā “imaṃ yāguṃ pivatha, bhattaṃ bhuñjatha, khādanīyaṃ
analyzed: dassenti vāṇijānam santikam gantvā imam yāgum pivatha bhattam bhuñjatha khādanīyam
translated: and they went to the merchants and said, “Drink this gruel, eat this rice, eat this fresh food,

original: khādathā”ti vadanti. Vāṇijā ajānantā tāhi dinnaṃ paribhuñjanti. Atha tesaṃ khāditvā
analyzed: khādatha ati vadanti vāṇijāḥ a jānantā tāhi dinnam paribhuñjanti atha khāditvā
translated: eat this dried food.” The merchants, not knowing, ate and drank what they gave them. Then, after they had eaten,

original: bhuñjitvā pivitvā vissamitakāle paṭisanthāraṃ karonti, “tumhe kattha vāsikā, kuto
analyzed: bhuñjitvā pivitvā vissamita kāle paṭisanthāram karonti tumhe kattha vāsikā kutas
translated: drunk, and were finished, they made polite conversation, asking, “Where do you live, where have you come from,

original: āgatā, kahaṃ gacchissatha, kena kammena idhāgatatthā”ti pucchanti. “Bhinnanāvā hutvā
analyzed: āgatāḥ kaham gacchissatha kena kammena idha āgatattha ati pucchanti bhinna nāvāḥ hutvā
translated: where are you going, and why have you come here?” When they said, “We have come here after our ship was wrecked,”

original: idhāgatamhā”ti vutte “sādhu, ayyā, amhākampi sāmikānaṃ nāvaṃ abhiruhitvā gatānaṃ🔽tīṇi saṃvaccharāni atikkantāni, te matā bhavissanti; tumhepi vāṇijāyeva, mayaṃ tumhākaṃ
analyzed: idha āgatamha iti vutte sādhu ayyāḥ amhākam pi sāmikānam nāvam abhiruhitvā gatānam  tīṇi saṃvaccharāni atikkantāni te matāḥ bhavissanti tumhe pi mayam tumhākam
translated: they said, “Good, masters, three years have passed since we too boarded our husbands’ ship and left,

original: pādaparicārikā bhavissāmā”ti vatvā te vāṇije itthikuttahāvabhāvavilāsehi palobhetvā
analyzed: pāda paricārikāḥ bhavissāma ati vatvā te vāṇije itthi kutta hāva bhāva vilāsehi palobhetvā
translated: they must be dead; you are merchants, and we will be your servants.” After they had enticed the merchants with the beauty of their youth,

original: yakkhanagaraṃ netvā sace paṭhamagahitā manussā atthi, te devasaṅkhalikāya bandhitvā
analyzed: yakkha nagaram netvā sace paṭhama gahitāḥ manussāḥ atthi te deva saṅkhalikāya bandhitvā
translated: they led them to the demon city and, if there were any men they had not previously taken, they bound them with divine fetters🔽and

original: kāraṇaghare pakkhipanti, attano vasanaṭṭhāne bhinnanāve manusse alabhantiyo pana
analyzed: kāraṇa ghare pakkhipanti attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhāne bhinna nāve manusse alabhantiyaḥ pana
translated: and they put them in the prison-house. But if they did not get men to put in the wrecked ship in their own dwelling-place,

original: parato kalyāṇiṃ orato nāgadīpanti evaṃ samuddatīraṃ anusañcaranti. Ayaṃ tāsaṃ dhammatā.
analyzed: paratas kalyāṇim oratas evam samudda tīram anusañcaranti ayam tāsam dhamma tā
translated: they went along the sea-shore from Kalyāṇī to Nāgadīpa. This is their nature.

original: Athekadivasaṃ pañcasatā bhinnanāvā vāṇijā tāsaṃ nagarasamīpe uttariṃsu. Tā tesaṃ
analyzed: atha eka divasam pañca satā bhinna nāvāḥ vāṇijā tāsam nagara samīpe uttariṃsu tā tesam
translated: Then one day five hundred merchants in a wrecked ship came to the shore near their town. They went

original: santikaṃ gantvā palobhetvā yakkhanagaraṃ netvā paṭhamaṃ gahite manusse devasaṅkhalikāya
analyzed: santikam gantvā palobhetvā yakkha nagaram netvā paṭhamam gahite manusse deva saṅkhalikāya
translated: to them and, after tempting them, led them to the city of the ogresses and put the first men they seized in chains

original: bandhitvā kāraṇaghare pakkhipitvā jeṭṭhayakkhinī jeṭṭhakavāṇijaṃ, sesā seseti tā
analyzed: bandhitvā kāraṇa ghare pakkhipitvā jeṭṭha yakkhinī jeṭṭhaka vāṇijam sesā sesā iti tā
translated: and put them in the prison-house. The chief ogress took the chief merchant, and the others took the others.

original: pañcasatā yakkhiniyo te pañcasate vāṇije attano sāmike akaṃsu. Atha sā jeṭṭhayakkhinī
analyzed: pañcasatāḥ yakkhiniyo te pañcasate vāṇije attano sāmike akaṃsu atha sā jeṭṭha yakkhinī
translated: Those five hundred ogresses made those five hundred merchants their own men. Then the chief ogress

original: rattibhāge vāṇije niddaṃ upagate uṭṭhāya gantvā kāraṇaghare manusse māretvā maṃsaṃ
analyzed: ratti bhāge vāṇije niddam upagate uṭṭhāya gantvā kāraṇa ghare manusse māretvā maṃsaṃ
translated: at night, when the merchants had gone to sleep, got up and went and killed the men in the prison-house and ate their flesh

original: khāditvā āgacchati, sesāpi tatheva karonti. Jeṭṭhayakkhiniyā manussamaṃsaṃ khāditvā
analyzed: khāditvā āgacchati sesā api tathā iva karonti jeṭṭha yakkhiniyāḥ manussa maṃsam khāditvā
translated: and came back. The others did the same. The chief ogress, after eating human flesh,

original: āgatakāle sarīraṃ sītalaṃ hoti. Jeṭṭhavāṇijo pariggaṇhanto tassā yakkhinibhāvaṃ ñatvā
analyzed: āgata kāle sarīram sītalam hoti jeṭṭha vāṇijaḥ pariggaṇhanto tassāḥ yakkhi nibhāvam ñatvā
translated: and when they came back the bodies were cold. The chief merchant, examining them, found out that they were really Yakkhas,

original: “imā pañcasatā yakkhiniyo bhavissanti, amhehi palāyituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti punadivase pātova
analyzed: imāḥ pañca satāḥ yakkhiniyaḥ bhavissanti amhehi palāyitum vaṭṭati iti puna divase
translated: and he said to himself, “These are five hundred Yakkhinīs, and not women. We must escape from them.” So the next morning,

original: mukhadhovanatthāya gantvā sesavāṇijānaṃ ārocesi – “imā yakkhiniyo, na manussitthiyo,
analyzed: mukha dhovana tthāya gantvā sesa vāṇijānam ārocesi imāḥ yakkhiniyaḥ na manussitthiyaḥ
translated: when they went to wash their faces, he told the other merchants, “These are Yakkhinīs, not women.

original: aññesaṃ bhinnanāvānaṃ āgatakāle te sāmike katvā amhepi khādissanti, etha ito palāyissāmā”ti🔽tesu pañcasatesu aḍḍhateyyasatā “na mayaṃ etā vijahituṃ sakkhissāma, tumhe gacchatha,
analyzed: aññesam bhinna nāvānam āgata kāle te sāmike katvā amhe pi khādissanti etha itas palāyissāma ati  tesu pañca satesu aḍḍhateyya satāḥ na mayam etāḥ vijahitum sakkhissāma tumhe gacchatha
translated: When other shipwrecked men come, they will make them their husbands and eat us up. Come, let us escape from them.”🔽Of the five hundred merchants two hundred and fifty said, “We cannot leave them. You go.

original: mayaṃ na palāyissāmā”ti āhaṃsu. Jeṭṭhavāṇijo attano vacanakāre aḍḍhateyyasate gahetvā tāsaṃ bhīto palāyi.
analyzed: mayam na palāyissāma ati āhaṃsu jeṭṭha vāṇijaḥ attanaḥ vacanakāre aḍḍhateyya sate gahetvā tāsam bhītaḥ palāyi
translated: We will not escape.” The chief merchant took the two hundred and fifty who would go with him and, fearing the Yakkhinīs, escaped.

original: Tasmiṃ pana kāle bodhisatto valāhakassayoniyaṃ nibbatti, sabbaseto kāḷasīso muñjakeso
analyzed: tasmin pana kāle bodhisattaḥ valāhakassayoniyam nibbatti sabbasetaḥ kāḷasīsaḥ muñjakeso
translated: Now at that time the Bodhisatta had been reborn in the womb of a she-cloud, and was all white, with a black head and hair like muñja grass.

original: iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo ahosi. So himavantato ākāse uppatitvā tambapaṇṇidīpaṃ gantvā
analyzed: id himāḥ vehāsaṅgamaḥ ahosi saḥ himavantataḥ ākāse uppatitvā tambapaṇṇi dīpam gantvā
translated: and he became a magician, and he went through the air to the Island of Tambapaṇṇi.

original: tattha tambapaṇṇisare pallale sayaṃjātasāliṃ khāditvā gacchati. Evaṃ gacchanto ca
analyzed: tattha tamba paṇṇisare pallale sayaṃjāta sālim khāditvā gacchati evam ca
translated: Having gone there, he ate the wild rice which grew of itself in the marsh of Tambapaṇṇi, and then he went away. As he went away

original: “janapadaṃ gantukāmā atthī”ti tikkhattuṃ karuṇāparibhāvitaṃ mānusiṃ vācaṃ bhāsati.
analyzed: janapadam gantu kāmā atthi iti tikkhattum karuṇā paribhāvitam mānusim vācam bhāsati
translated: he spoke to them in a human voice, which was full of compassion, three times, saying: “Are there any who wish to go to the country?”

original: Te bodhisattassa vacanaṃ sutvā upasaṅkamitvā añjaliṃ paggayha “sāmi, mayaṃ janapadaṃ
analyzed: te bodhisattassa vacanam sutvā upasaṅkamitvā añjalim paggayha sāmi mayam janapadam
translated: Having heard the words of the Bodhisatta, they approached him, and raising their joined hands, they said: “Master, we wish to go to the country.”

original: gamissāmā”ti āhaṃsu. Tena hi mayhaṃ piṭṭhiṃ abhiruhathāti. Appekacce abhiruhiṃsu,
analyzed: gamissāma iti āhaṃsu tena hi mayham piṭṭhim abhiruhatha ati appa ekacce abhiruhiṃsu
translated: “Then,” said he, “mount on my back.” Some of them mounted on his back,

original: tesu ekacce vāladhiṃ gaṇhiṃsu, ekacce añjaliṃ paggahetvā aṭṭhaṃsuyeva. Bodhisatto🔽antamaso añjaliṃ paggahetvā ṭhite sabbepi te aḍḍhateyyasate vāṇije attano ānubhāvena
analyzed: tesu ekacce vāladhim gaṇhiṃsu ekacce añjalim paggahetvā aṭṭhaṃsuyā iva bodhisatto  antamasaḥ añjalim paggahetvā ṭhite sabbe api te aḍḍhateyya sate vāṇije attanaḥ ānubhāvena
translated: some took hold of his tail, and some stood with their joined hands raised. The Bodhisatta

original: janapadaṃ netvā sakasakaṭṭhānesu patiṭṭhapetvā attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ āgamāsi. Tāpi
analyzed: janapadam netvā saka saka ṭṭhānesu patiṭṭhapetvā attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānam tā api
translated: having by his own power taken all those two hundred and fifty merchants to the country, and having established them in their respective homes, returned to his own dwelling-place.

original: kho yakkhiniyo aññesaṃ āgatakāle tattha ohīnake aḍḍhateyyasate manusse vadhitvā khādiṃsu.
analyzed: kho yakkhiniyaḥ aññesam āgata kāle tattha ohīnake aḍḍhateyya sate manusse vadhitvā khādiṃsu
translated: and when other merchants came, they killed and ate two hundred and fifty of them.

original: Satthā bhikkhū āmantetvā “bhikkhave, yathā te yakkhinīnaṃ vasaṃ gatā vāṇijā jīvitakkhayaṃ
analyzed: satthā bhikkhū āmantetvā bhikkhave yathā te yakkhinīnam vasam gatāḥ vāṇijāḥ jīvita kkhayam
translated: The Teacher addressed the monks, saying, “Monks, just as those merchants who fell into the power of the she-devils perished,

original: pattā, valāhakassarājassa vacanakarā vāṇijā sakasakaṭṭhānesu patiṭṭhitā, evameva
analyzed: pattāḥ valāhakassa rājassa vacanakarāḥ vāṇijāḥ saka saka ṭṭhānesu patiṭṭhitāḥ evam eva
translated: but those who obeyed the words of the king of the merchants were established in their own country,

original: buddhānaṃ ovādaṃ akarontā bhikkhūpi bhikkhuniyopi upāsakāpi upāsikāyopi catūsu apāyesu
analyzed: buddhānam ovādam a karontāḥ bhikkhū api bhikkhuniyaḥ api upāsakā api upāsikāyaḥ api catūsu apāyesu
translated: even so, monks, those monks and nuns and laymen and laywomen who do not obey the admonitions of the Buddhas,

original: pañcavidhabandhanakammakaraṇaṭṭhānādīsu mahādukkhaṃ pāpuṇanti. Ovādakarā pana tisso
analyzed: pañcavidha bandhana kamma karaṇa ṭṭhāna ādīsu mahā dukkham pāpuṇanti ovāda karā pana tisso
translated: fall into the four states of suffering, and into the five places of bondage and punishment, and so on, and experience great suffering. But those who obey the admonitions of the Buddhas,

original: kulasampattiyo ca cha kāmasagge vīsati brahmaloketi imāni ca ṭhānāni patvā amatamahānibbānaṃ
analyzed: kula sampattiyaḥ ca cha kāmasagge vīsati brahmaloka iti imāni ca ṭhānāni patvā amatamahānibbānam
translated: having attained the three kinds of prosperity, the six heavens of sensual delight, and the twenty worlds of Brahmā, and having attained the Deathless, the Supreme State of Nibbāna,

original: sacchikatvā mahantaṃ sukhaṃ anubhavantī”ti vatvā abhisambuddho hutvā imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: sacchikatvā mahantam sukham anubhavanti iti vatvā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: experience great happiness.” So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: “Ye na kāhanti ovādaṃ, narā buddhena desitaṃ;
analyzed: ye na ovādam narāḥ buddhena desitam
translated: Those who do not obey the admonitions of the Buddha,

original: Byasanaṃ te gamissanti, rakkhasīhiva vāṇijā.
analyzed: byasanam te gamissanti rakkhasīhi iva vāṇijā
translated: As did the merchants by the Sirens.🔽But they who follow the advice

original: “Ye ca kāhanti ovādaṃ, narā buddhena desitaṃ;
analyzed: ye ca ovādam narāḥ buddhena desitam
translated: Which the Enlightened One hath given,🔽Will reach the further shore in safety,

original: Sotthiṃ pāraṃ gamissanti, valāheneva vāṇijā”ti.
analyzed: sa utthim pāram gamissanti valāhena iva vāṇijāti
translated: As did the merchants by the wind.

original: Tattha ye na kāhantīti ye na karissanti. Byasanaṃ te gamissantīti te mahāvināsaṃ🔽pāpuṇissanti. Rakkhasīhiva vāṇijāti rakkhasīhi palobhitavāṇijā viya. Sotthiṃ pāraṃ
analyzed: tattha ye na ye na karissanti byasanam te gamissanti iti te mahā vināsam  pāpuṇissanti rakkhasīhi iva vāṇijāḥ ti rakkhasīhi palobhita vāṇijāḥ viya sotthim pāram
translated: Herein, they who do not follow are they who will not do it. They will come to destruction means they will come to a great disaster.🔽As did the merchants by the Sirens means as did the merchants who were tempted by the Sirens. They will reach the further shore in safety means they will reach Nibbāna without hindrance.

original: gamissantīti anantarāyena nibbānaṃ pāpuṇissanti. Valāheneva vāṇijāti valāheneva “āgacchathā”ti
analyzed: gamissanti iti anantarāyena nibbānam pāpuṇissanti valāhena iva vāṇijā ati valāhena iva āgacchatha ati
translated: As did the merchants by the wind means as did the merchants who did the bidding of the wind when he said, “Come.”

original: vuttā tassa vacanakarā vāṇijā viya. Yathā hi te samuddapāraṃ gantvā sakasakaṭṭhānaṃ🔽agamaṃsu, evaṃ buddhānaṃ ovādakarā saṃsārapāraṃ nibbānaṃ gacchantīti amatamahānibbānena
analyzed: vuttā tassa vacana karāḥ vāṇijāḥ viya yathā hi te samudda pāram gantvā saka saka ṭṭhānam  evam buddhānam ovāda karā saṃsāra pāram nibbānam gacchanti iti amata mahānibbānena
translated: For just as they reached the further shore of the ocean and returned to their own country,

original: dhammadesanāya kūṭaṃ gaṇhi.
analyzed: dhamma desanāya kūṭam gaṇhi
translated: so they who do the bidding of the Buddhas go to Nibbāna, the further shore of the round of rebirths. Thus he took up the thread of the True Idea with the Great Nibbāna, which is above all conditioned things.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – saccapariyosāne
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: At the end of the lesson, after showing the Truths,🔽the Master identified the Birth: “At that time the merchant who did the bidding of the wind was Ananda, and the merchant who did not do his bidding was Devadatta.”

original: ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi, aññepi bahū sotāpattiphalasakadāgāmiphalaanāgāmiphalaarahattaphalāni
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi aññe pi bahū sotāpatti phala sakadāgāmi phala anāgāmi phala arahatta phalāni
translated: The discontented monk was established in the fruit of Stream-Entry, and many others attained the fruits of Conversion, of Once-Returner, of Non-Returner, and of Arahatship.

original: pāpuṇiṃsu. “Tadā valāhakassarājassa vacanakarā aḍḍhateyyasatā vāṇijā buddhaparisā
analyzed: pāpuṇiṃsu tadā valāhakassa rājassa vacana karāḥ aḍḍhateyya satāḥ vāṇijāḥ buddha parisā
translated: The two hundred and fifty merchants who carried out the orders of the king of the clouds were the assembly of the Buddha,

original: ahesuṃ, valāhakassarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Valāhakassajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.
analyzed: ahesum valāhakassa rājā pana aham eva  valāhakassajātaka vaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: and I was the king of the clouds.”🔽So said the Exalted One, and the monks were delighted and praised the Exalted One’s words.🔽The Story of the King of the Clouds, the Sixth.

original: [197] 7. Mittāmittajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Friend and the Foe

original: Na naṃ umhayate disvāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ ārabbha🔽kathesi. Aññataro bhikkhu “mayā gahite mayhaṃ upajjhāyo na kujjhissatī”ti upajjhāyena
analyzed: na nam umhayate disvā iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ aññataram bhikkhum ārabbha  kathesi aññataraḥ bhikkhu mayā gahite mayham upajjhāyaḥ na kujjhissati iti upajjhāyena
translated: This story the Master told while living at Jetavana about a certain monk.🔽This monk thought, “If I take it, my preceptor will not be angry,” and so he took a piece of cloth which his preceptor had laid aside in confidence, and made a pair of sandals.

original: ṭhapitaṃ vissāsena ekaṃ vatthakhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā upāhanatthavikaṃ katvā pacchā upajjhāyaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapitam vissāsena ekam vattha khaṇḍam gahetvā upāhana tthavikam katvā pacchā upajjhāyam
translated: Afterwards he asked his preceptor’s pardon.🔽His preceptor said, “Why did you take it?”

original: āpucchi. Atha taṃ upajjhāyo “kiṃkāraṇā gaṇhī”ti vatvā “mayā gahite na kujjhissatīti
analyzed: āpucchi atha tam upajjhāyaḥ kiṃkāraṇā gaṇhi iti vatvā mayā gahite na kujjhissati iti
translated: “Because I thought, ‘If I take it, you will not be angry.’ ”

original: tumhākaṃ vissāsenā”ti vutte “ko mayā saddhiṃ tuyhaṃ vissāso nāmā”ti vatvā kuddho
analyzed: tumhākam vissāsena ati vutte kaḥ mayā saddhim tuyham vissāsaḥ nāma ati vatvā kuddhaḥ
translated: “I have confidence in you.” “What confidence can I have in you?” So saying, he became angry,

original: uṭṭhahitvā pahari. Tassa sā kiriyā bhikkhūsu pākaṭā jātā. Athekadivasaṃ bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ🔽kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ – “āvuso, asuko kira daharo upajjhāyassa vissāsena vatthakhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: uṭṭhahitvā tassa sā kiriyā bhikkhūsu pākaṭā jātā atha eka divasam bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ  katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso asukaḥ kira daharaḥ upajjhāyassa vissāsena vattha khaṇḍam
translated: rose up, and struck him. The deed became known among the monks. One day the monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth:

original: gahetvā upāhanatthavikaṃ akāsi. Atha naṃ upajjhāyo ‘ko mayā saddhiṃ tuyhaṃ vissāso
analyzed: gahetvā upāhana tthavikam akāsi atha nam upajjhāyo kaḥ mayā saddhim tuyham vissāsaḥ
translated: “It seems that a certain young monk, having confidence in his preceptor, took a piece of cloth from his store and made a pair of sandals for him. When the preceptor said to him, ‘What confidence can I have in you?’ he became angry,

original: nāmā’ti vatvā kuddho uṭṭhahitvā paharī”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave,🔽etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idānevesa
analyzed: nāma ati vatvā kuddhaḥ uṭṭhahitvā pahari iti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave  etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave
translated: rose up, and struck him.” The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?” When they told him,

original: bhikkhu attano saddhivihārikena saddhiṃ avissāsiko, pubbepi avissāsikoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: bhikkhu attano saddhivihārikena saddhim avissāsiko pubbe pi avissāsikaḥ yeva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: he said, “Monks, this is not the first time he has failed to have confidence in his pupil; in a previous state of existence also he failed to have confidence in him.” So saying, he related the following🔽Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto kāsiraṭṭhe brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto kāsiraṭṭhe brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in the family of a brāhman in the country of Kāsi.

original: vayappatto isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā gaṇasatthā🔽hutvā himavantapadese vāsaṃ kappesi. Tasmiṃ isigaṇe eko tāpaso bodhisattassa vacanaṃ🔽akatvā ekaṃ matamātikaṃ hatthipotakaṃ paṭijaggi. Atha naṃ so vuddhippatto māretvā
analyzed: vaya pattaḥ isipabbajjam pabbajitvā abhiññā ca samāpattiyaḥ ca nibbattetvā gaṇa satthā  hutvā himavanta padese vāsam kappesi tasmin isi gaṇe ekaḥ tāpasaḥ bodhisattassa vacanam  a katvā ekam mata mātikam hatthi potakam paṭijaggi atha nam saḥ vuddhi pattaḥ māretvā
translated: When he had grown up, he went forth into the homeless state, and after attaining the Supernatural Powers and Attainments, he became the teacher of a company of seers.🔽He dwelt in the Himalayas, and in his company there was one seer who did not obey the Bodhisatta’s words, but kept a young elephant that had lost its mother.

original: araññaṃ pāvisi. Tassa sarīrakiccaṃ katvā isigaṇo bodhisattaṃ parivāretvā – “bhante,
analyzed: araññam pāvisi tassa sarīra kiccam katvā isi gaṇaḥ bodhisattam parivāretvā bhante
translated: When the elephant had grown up, he killed the seer, and went into the forest. The company of seers, after performing the funeral rites, surrounded the Bodhisatta, and asked him,

original: kena nu ko kāraṇena mittabhāvo vā amittabhāvo vā sakkā jānitu”nti pucchi. Bodhisatto
analyzed: kena nu ko kāraṇena mitta bhāvaḥ vā amitta bhāvaḥ vā sakkā jānitun ti pucchi bodhisatto
translated: “Reverend Sir, by what means can one know whether a man is a friend or not a friend?” The Bodhisatta

original: “iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇenā”ti ācikkhanto imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇena ati ācikkhantaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: said, “By these and those means,” and he spoke these verses:—

original: “Na naṃ umhayate disvā, na ca naṃ paṭinandati;
analyzed: na nam umhayate disvā na ca nam paṭinandati
translated: “He does not welcome him when he sees him, nor does he greet him;

original: Cakkhūni cassa na dadāti, paṭilomañca vattati.
analyzed: cakkhūni ca assa na dadāti paṭilomam ca vattati
translated: He does not give him his eye, but acts in a contrary way.

original: “Ete bhavanti ākārā, amittasmiṃ patiṭṭhitā;
analyzed: ete bhavanti ākārāḥ amittasmin patiṭṭhitā
translated: “These are the signs that are established In a foe,

original: Yehi amittaṃ jāneyya, disvā sutvā ca paṇḍito”ti.🔽Tattha na naṃ umhayate disvāti yo hi yassa amitto hoti, so taṃ puggalaṃ disvā na🔽umhayate, hasitaṃ na karoti, pahaṭṭhākāraṃ na dasseti. Na ca naṃ paṭinandatīti tassa🔽vacanaṃ sutvāpi taṃ puggalaṃ na paṭinandati, sādhu subhāsitanti na cānumodati. Cakkhūni🔽cassa na dadātīti cakkhunā cakkhuṃ āhacca paṭimukho hutvā na oloketi, aññato cakkhūni
analyzed: yehi amittam jāneyya disvā sutvā ca paṇḍita uti  tattha na nam umhayate disvā ati yaḥ hi yassa amittaḥ hoti saḥ tam puggalam disvā na  umhayate hasitam na karoti pahaṭṭha ākāram na dasseti na ca nam paṭinandati iti tassa  vacanam sutvā api tam puggalam na paṭinandati sādhu su bhāsitanti na ca anumodati cakkhūni  cassa na dadāti iti cakkhunā cakkhum āhacca paṭimukhaḥ hutvā na oloketi aññatas cakkhūni
translated: By which a wise man, having seen and heard, Should know him as a foe.”

original: harati. Paṭilomañca vattatīti tassa kāyakammampi vacīkammampi na roceti, paṭilomagāhaṃ🔽gaṇhāti paccanīkagāhaṃ. Ākārāti kāraṇāni. Yehi amittanti yehi kāraṇehi tāni kāraṇāni
analyzed: harati paṭilomam ca vattati iti tassa kāya kammam pi vacī kammam pi na roceti paṭiloma gāham 🔽gaṇhāti paccanīka gāham ākārāti kāraṇāni yehi amittam ti yehi kāraṇehi tāni kāraṇāni
translated: Herein, he does not greet him when he sees him: whoever is another’s foe does not greet him when he sees him, he does not smile, he does not show a glad reaction. He does not welcome him: having heard his speech, he does not welcome the person, he does not rejoice, saying “Well said, well spoken.” He does not give him his eye: he does not look at him face to face, eye to eye; he turns his eyes away. He speaks against him: he does not approve of his bodily action or his speech, he takes up a contrary position, he takes up an opposite position. Signs: reasons. By which a foe: by which reasons, by which grounds, by which causes, by which conditions, he should know him as a foe.

original: disvā sutvā ca paṇḍito puggalo “ayaṃ me amitto”ti jāneyya, tato viparītehi pana mittabhāvo jānitabboti.
analyzed: disvā sutvā ca paṇḍitaḥ puggalo ayam me amittaḥ iti jāneyya tatas viparītehi pana mitta bhāvaḥ jānitabbo ti
translated: The wise man, seeing and hearing this, will know that this is an enemy. But the opposite of this will show you a friend.

original: Evaṃ bodhisatto mittāmittabhāvakāraṇāni ācikkhitvā brahmavihāre bhāvetvā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
analyzed: evam bodhisattaḥ mitta amitta bhāva kāraṇāni ācikkhitvā brahmavihāre bhāvetvā brahma loka upagaḥ ahosi
translated: Thus did the Bodhisatta declare the causes of friendship and enmity, and then, having developed the divine abidings, he passed to the Brahma-world.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā hatthiposakatāpaso saddhivihāriko ahosi, hatthī upajjhāyo, isigaṇo buddhaparisā, gaṇasatthā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā hatthi posaka tāpasaḥ saddhivihārikaḥ ahosi hatthī upajjhāyaḥ isi gaṇaḥ buddha parisā gaṇa satthā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Master had ended his lesson, he made the connexion and identified the Birth: “At that time the elephant-keeper was the pupil, the elephant was the teacher, the crowd of seers was the company of monks, and I myself was the teacher of the crowd.”

original: Mittāmittajātakavaṇṇanā sattamā.🔽[198] 8. Rādhajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: mitta amitta jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā  rādha jātaka vaṇṇanā
translated: So saying, he joined the Truths with the Birth.

original: Pavāsā āgato tātāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuṃ ārabbha🔽kathesi. So kira satthārā “saccaṃ kira, tvaṃ bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhito”ti puṭṭho “saccaṃ,🔽bhante”ti vatvā “kiṃkāraṇā”ti vutte “ekaṃ alaṅkataitthiṃ disvā kilesavasenā”ti āha.
analyzed: pavāsā āgataḥ tāta ati idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum ārabbha 🔽kathesi saḥ kira satthārā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ ti puṭṭhaḥ saccam 🔽bhanta iti vatvā kiṃkāraṇā iti vutte ekam alaṅkataitthim disvā kilesa vasena ati āha
translated: The story of the Birth of the Friend and the Foe was ended.

original: Atha naṃ satthā “mātugāmo nāma bhikkhu na sakkā rakkhituṃ, pubbepi dovārike ṭhapetvā
analyzed: atha nam satthā mātugāmaḥ nāma bhikkhu na sakkā rakkhitum pubbe pi dovārike ṭhapetvā

analyzed: rakkhantā api rakkhitum na sakkhiṃsu kim te itthiyā laddhā api sā rakkhitum na sakkā iti vatvā atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto suva yoniyam nibbatti rādhotissa
translated: were unable to do so. What have you to do with a woman? Even if you get one, you will not be able to keep her.” So saying, he related the following

original: nāmaṃ, kaniṭṭhabhātā panassa poṭṭhapādo nāma. Te ubhopi taruṇakāleyeva eko luddako
analyzed: nāmam kaniṭṭha bhātā panassa poṭṭhapādaḥ nāma te ubho pi ekaḥ luddako

analyzed: gahetvā bārāṇasiyam aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa adāsi brāhmaṇaḥ te putta ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā

original: paṭijaggi. Brāhmaṇassa pana brāhmaṇī arakkhitā dussīlā. So vohārakaraṇatthāya gacchanto
analyzed: paṭijaggi brāhmaṇassa pana brāhmaṇī arakkhitā dussīlā saḥ vohāra karaṇa tthāya gacchantaḥ
translated: Now the Brahman’s wife was unchaste and of evil conduct. Whenever the Brahman went away on business,

analyzed: te suva potake āmantetvā tātāḥ aham vohāra karaṇa tthāya gacchāmi kāle vā vikāle vā
translated: she would call in a paramour. The Brahman, before going away, would say to the dogs, “Dears, I am going away on business. Whether it be day or night,🔽if you hear my wife and her paramour quarrelling, you must not bark.”

original: tumhākaṃ mātu karaṇakammaṃ olokeyyātha, aññassa purisassa gamanabhāvaṃ vā agamanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tumhākam mātu karaṇa kammaṃ olokeyyātha aññassa purisassa gamana bhāvam vā a gamana bhāvam
translated: “Look at your mother’s work, whether she goes to another man or not,

original: vā jāneyyāthā”ti brāhmaṇiṃ suvapotakānaṃ paṭicchāpetvā agamāsi. Sā tassa nikkhantakālato
analyzed: vā jāneyyātha ati brāhmaṇim suva potakānam paṭicchāpetvā agamāsi sā tassa nikkhanta kālataḥ
translated: “Look at the actions of your mother. You will know whether or not another man has been with her.” He then covered up the young brahmin’s eyes and left. From the time of his departure,

translated: she behaved improperly. There was no limit to the number of men who came and went, both by night and by day.

original: Taṃ disvā poṭṭhapādo rādhaṃ pucchi – “brāhmaṇo imaṃ brāhmaṇiṃ amhākaṃ niyyādetvā🔽gato, ayañca pāpakammaṃ karoti, vadāmi na”nti. Rādho “mā vadāhī”ti āha. So tassa
analyzed: tam disvā poṭṭhapādaḥ rādham pucchi brāhmaṇaḥ imam brāhmaṇim amhākam niyyādetvā  gataḥ ayaṃ ca pāpa kammam karoti vadāmi rādho mā vadāhi iti āha saḥ tassa
translated: Seeing this, Poṭṭhapāda asked Rādha, “The brahmin gave this brahminī to us,

original: vacanaṃ aggahetvā “amma, kiṃkāraṇā pāpakammaṃ karosī”ti āha. Sā taṃ māretukāmā hutvā
analyzed: vacanam aggahetvā amma kiṃkāraṇā pāpa kammam karosi iti āha sā tam mā āretu kāmā hutvā
translated: and then he left. But she is doing evil. What shall I do?” Rādha said, “Don’t say anything.” But Poṭṭhapāda didn’t accept his advice. He said to her, “Mother, why are you doing this evil?” Desiring to kill him,

original: “tāta, tvaṃ nāma mayhaṃ putto, ito paṭṭhāya na karissāmi, ehi, tāta, tāvā”ti piyāyamānā
analyzed: tāta tvam nāma mayham puttaḥ itas paṭṭhāya na karissāmi ehi tāta tāva ati piyāyamānā
translated: she said, “Dear, you are my son. From now on I won’t do this. Come, dear, come.”

original: viya pakkositvā āgataṃ gahetvā “tvaṃ maṃ ovadasi, attano pamāṇaṃ na jānāsī”ti gīvaṃ
analyzed: viya pakkositvā āgatam gahetvā tvam mama ovadasi attanaḥ pamāṇam na jānāsi iti gīvam
translated: As if loving him, she called him over. When he came, she grabbed him, saying, “You advise me. You don’t know your own measure.” She then grabbed his throat and strangled him to death.

original: parivattetvā māretvā uddhanantaresu pakkhipi. Brāhmaṇo āgantvā vissamitvā bodhisattaṃ
analyzed: parivattetvā māretvā uddha anantaresu brāhmaṇaḥ āgantvā vissamitvā bodhisattam
translated: and after turning him over, killed him and threw him into the charcoal pit. The Brahman came and after looking about, asked the Bodhisatta,

original: “kiṃ, tāta rādha, mātā te anācāraṃ karoti, na karotī”ti pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: kim tāta rādha mātā te anācāram karoti na karoti iti pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: “Dear Rādha, does your mother behave improperly or not?” and asking this, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Pavāsā āgato tāta, idāni nacirāgato;
analyzed: āgataḥ tāta idāni nacira āgataḥ
translated: “Dear Rādha, I have come from abroad, and now I have come back after a long absence.

original: Kaccinnu tāta te mātā, na aññamupasevatī”ti.
analyzed: kaccit nu tāta te mātā na aññam upasevati iti
translated: Dear Rādha, I ask you, does your mother behave improperly with another man?”

original: Tassattho – ahaṃ, tāta rādha, pavāsā āgato, so camhi idāneva āgato nacirāgato, tena pavattiṃ ajānanto taṃ pucchāmi – “kacci nu te, tāta, mātā aññaṃ purisaṃ na upasevatī”ti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ aham tāta rādha pavāsā āgataḥ saḥ ca mhi idānā iva āgataḥ nacira āgataḥ tena pavattim a jānantaḥ tam pucchāmi kacci nu te tāta mātā aññam purisam na upasevati iti
translated: The meaning is this: “Dear Rādha, I have come from abroad, and I have come back only just now, not long ago. Therefore, not knowing what has happened, I ask you, dear Rādha, does your mother behave improperly with another man?”

original: Rādho “tāta, paṇḍitā nāma bhūtaṃ vā abhūtaṃ vā aniyyānikaṃ nāma na kathesu”nti ñāpento dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tāta paṇḍitāḥ nāma bhūtam vā abhūtam vā aniyyānikam nāma na kathesunti ñāpentaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Rādha, thinking, “Father, the wise do not speak of what is true or what is not true, if it is not to the point,” spoke the second stanza, in order to make him understand:

original: “Na kho panetaṃ subhaṇaṃ, giraṃ saccupasaṃhitaṃ;
analyzed: na kho pana itam subhaṇam giram sacca upasaṃhitam
translated: “This is not a good question, father, nor is it a question that should be asked.

original: Sayetha poṭṭhapādova, mummure upakūthito”ti.
analyzed: poṭṭhapādaḥ uva mummure upakūthitaḥ iti
translated: You should lie down, father, like Poṭṭhapāda, and mutter and grumble.”

analyzed: tattha giranti vacanam tat hi yathā idāni girā evam tadā giranti vuccati so suvapotako
translated: Herein, the word “gira” is the same as the word “girā” as used at the present day.

original: liṅgaṃ anādiyitvā evamāha. Ayaṃ panettha attho – tāta, paṇḍitena nāma saccupasaṃhitaṃ
analyzed: liṅgam an ādiyitvā evam āha ayam pana itthā tāta paṇḍitena nāma sacca upasaṃhitam
translated: The young brāhman, disregarding the grammatical gender, said, “Tātā.”🔽The meaning is this: “Father, it is not well said that a wise man should speak the truth.

original: yathābhūtaṃ atthayuttaṃ sabhāvavacanampi aniyyānikaṃ na subhaṇaṃ. Aniyyānikañca saccaṃ
analyzed: yathābhūtam attha yuttam sabhāva vacanam pi aniyyānikam na subhaṇam aniyyānikam ca saccam
translated: For if a man speaks the truth that is not profitable,

analyzed: bhaṇantaḥ poṭṭhapādaḥ uva mummure upakūthitaḥ yathā poṭṭhapādaḥ kukkuḷe jhāmaḥ
translated: he will lie down like Poṭṭhapāda, writhing and moaning, as Poṭṭhapāda lies down in the fire, writhing and moaning.”

original: sayati, evaṃ sayeyyāti. “Upakūdhito”tipi pāṭho, ayamevattho.
analyzed: sayati evam pāṭhaḥ ayam eva attho
translated: The reading is also upakūṭhito, which has the same meaning.

original: Evaṃ bodhisatto brāhmaṇassa dhammaṃ desetvā “mayāpi imasmiṃ ṭhāne vasituṃ na sakkā”ti brāhmaṇaṃ āpucchitvā araññameva pāvisi.
analyzed: evam bodhisattaḥ brāhmaṇassa dhammam desetvā mayā api imasmin ṭhāne vasitum na sakkā ati brāhmaṇam āpucchitvā araññam eva pāvisi
translated: Thus the Bodhisatta, having preached the Law to the brāhman, said, “I cannot live here,” and took leave of the brāhman, and went away to the forest.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths clear, and identified the Birth:

original: ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā poṭṭhapādo ānando ahosi, rādho
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā poṭṭhapādaḥ ānandaḥ ahosi rādho
translated: The discontented monk was established in the fruit of Stream-Entry. “At that time, the potter was Ānanda,

translated: and I was Rādha.”

original: Rādhajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: rādha jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: The Story of Rādha’s Birth is finished.

original: [199] 9. Gahapatijātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Householder

original: Ubhayaṃ me na khamatīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ukkaṇṭhitameva bhikkhuṃ ārabbha🔽kathesi. Kathento ca “mātugāmo nāma arakkhito, pāpakammaṃ katvā yena kenaci upāyena
analyzed: ubhayam me na khamati iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ukkaṇṭhitam eva bhikkhum ārabbha  kathesi kathentaḥ ca mātugāmaḥ nāma arakkhitaḥ pāpa kammam katvā yena kenaci upāyena
translated: When the Teacher was dwelling in Jeta’s Wood, he told this story concerning a discontented monk.🔽“Women are unrestrained,” he said, “and having done evil, they deceive their husbands by any means.

original: sāmikaṃ vañcetiyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: sāmikam vatvā atītam āhari
translated: ” Then he told an old tale.

translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a householder’s family in the Kāsi country.

analyzed: vaya pattaḥ ghara āvāsam gaṇhi tassa bhariyā dussīlā gāma bhojakena saddhim anācāram

analyzed: carati bodhisatto tam ñatvā pariggaṇhanto carati tadā pana antovasse bījesu nīhaṭesu
translated: The Bodhisatta found this out, and watched her. Then, in the rainy season, when the seed had been sown,

analyzed: chātakam ahosi sassānam gabbha gahaṇa kālo jāto sakala gāma vāsinaḥ itas māsa dvayena
translated: The time had come for the crops to be gathered in. All the villagers, having agreed together, said, “In two months’ time

analyzed: sassāni uddharitvā vīhim dassāma ati ekatas hutvā gāmabhojakassa hatthatas ekam jaragoṇam
translated: we will gather in the crops and give you the rice.” They took a decrepit cow from the village overseer,

original: gahetvā maṃsaṃ khādiṃsu.
analyzed: gahetvā maṃsam khādiṃsu
translated: and ate the meat.

original: Athekadivasaṃ gāmabhājako khaṇaṃ oloketvā bodhisattassa bahigatavelāyaṃ gehaṃ pāvisi.
analyzed: atha eka divasam gāma bhājakaḥ khaṇam oloketvā bodhisattassa bahigata velāyam geham pāvisi
translated: One day the village overseer, having watched his opportunity, entered the house while the Bodhisatta was away from home.

original: Tesaṃ sukhanipannakkhaṇeyeva bodhisatto gāmadvārena pavisitvā gehābhimukho pāyāsi.
analyzed: tesam sukha nipanna kkhaṇeya iva bodhisattaḥ gāma dvārena pavisitvā geha abhimukhaḥ pāyāsi
translated: The moment they were comfortably seated, the Bodhisatta entered the village and made straight for the house.🔽The woman, looking out of the door, saw him coming, and thought, “Who is that?”

original: Sā itthī gāmadvārābhimukhī taṃ disvā “ko nu kho eso”ti ummāre ṭhatvā olokentī “soyevā”ti🔽ñatvā gāmabhojakassa ācikkhi, gāmabhojako bhīto pakampi. Atha naṃ sā “mā bhāyi, attheko
analyzed: sā itthī gāma dvāra abhimukhī tam disvā kaḥ nu khalu esaḥ iti ummāre ṭhatvā olokentī soyā iva ati  ñatvā gāmabhojakassa ācikkhi gāmabhojakaḥ bhītaḥ pakampi atha nam sā mā bhāyi attha ekaḥ
translated: She looked again, and seeing that it was he,

analyzed: upāyaḥ amhehi tava hatthataḥ goṇa maṃsam khāditam tvam maṃsa mūlam sodhentaḥ viya hohi
translated: she told the village overseer, who was frightened and trembled. “Do not be afraid,” she said. “There is a way out of this. We have eaten the meat of your cow, but you must pretend to look for the meat,🔽and

analyzed: aham koṭṭham āruyha koṭṭha dvāre ṭhatvā vīhi natthi iti vakkhāmi tvam geha majjhe
translated: I will climb up into the granary and stand at the door and say, ‘There is no corn.’ You stand in the middle of the house

original: ṭhatvā ‘amhākaṃ ghare dārakā chātā, maṃsamūlaṃ me dehī’ti punappunaṃ codeyyāsī”ti
analyzed: amhākam ghare dārakā chātā maṃsa mūlam me dehi iti punappunam codeyyā asi iti
translated: and keep on saying, ‘Our children are hungry; give me the price of some meat.’ ”

original: vatvā koṭṭhaṃ āruyha koṭṭhadvāre nisīdi. Itaro gehamajjhe ṭhatvā “maṃsamūlaṃ dehī”ti
analyzed: vatvā koṭṭham āruyha koṭṭha dvāre nisīdi itaraḥ geha majjhe ṭhatvā maṃsa mūlam dehi iti
translated: So saying, he climbed up into the granary and sat down at the door. The other stood in the middle of the house and said, “Give me the price of some meat.”

original: vadati. Sā koṭṭhadvāre nisinnā “koṭṭhe vīhi natthi, sasse uddharante dassāmi gacchāhī”ti āha.
analyzed: vadati sā koṭṭha dvāre nisinnā koṭṭhe vīhi natthi sasse uddharante dassāmi gacchāhi iti āha
translated: She, sitting at the door of the granary, said, “There is no corn in the granary; I will give you some when the rice is harvested; go away.”

original: Bodhisatto gehaṃ pavisitvā tesaṃ kiriyaṃ disvā “imāya pāpāya kataupāyo esa bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ geham pavisitvā tesam kiriyam disvā imāya pāpāya kata upāyaḥ esa bhavissati iti
translated: The Bodhisatta entered the house and seeing what they were doing, thought to himself, “This must be the work of that wicked woman.”

original: ñatvā gāmabhojakaṃ āmantetvā “so gāmabhojaka amhe tava jaragoṇassa maṃsaṃ khādantā
analyzed: ñatvā gāmabhojakam āmantetvā saḥ gāmabhojaka amhe tava jaragoṇassa maṃsam khādantā
translated: So he called the village overseer and said, “You village overseer, we were eating the flesh of your old ox,

original: ‘ito māsadvayena vīhiṃ dassāmā’ti khādimha, tvaṃ aḍḍhamāsampi anatikkamitvā idāneva
analyzed: itas māsa dvayena vīhim dassāma ati khādimha tvam aḍḍha māsam pi an atikkamitvā idānā iva
translated: and we said, ‘In two months we will give you the price of it.’ We ate it on credit. You have not waited even half a month,

original: kasmā āharāpesi, na tvaṃ iminā kāraṇena āgato, aññena kāraṇena āgato bhavissasi,
analyzed: kasmai āhara apesi na tvam iminā kāraṇena āgataḥ aññena kāraṇena āgataḥ bhavissasi
translated: but have come to-day and asked for the price. You have not come for this reason, but for some other reason.

original: mayhaṃ tava kiriyā na ruccati, ayampi anācārā pāpadhammā koṭṭhe vīhīnaṃ abhāvaṃ jānāti,🔽sā dāni koṭṭhaṃ āruyha ‘vīhi natthī’ti vadati, tvampi ‘dehī’ti vadati, ubhinnampi
analyzed: mayham tava kiriyā na ruccati ayam pi anācārā pāpa dhammā koṭṭhe vīhīnam abhāvam jānāti  sā dāni koṭṭham āruyha vīhi natthi iti vadati tvam pi dehi iti vadati ubhinnam pi
translated: “I do not approve of your action. This woman, too, is a bad woman, a shameless woman, a woman of evil conduct. She knows the state of the grain in the granary.🔽She has climbed up into the granary and says, ‘There is no grain.’ You say, ‘Give it.’ I do not approve of the action of both of you.

original: vo karaṇaṃ mayhaṃ na ruccatī”ti etamatthaṃ pakāsento imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: vaḥ karaṇam mayham na ruccati iti etam attham pakāsentaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: Expounding this matter, he spoke these verses:

original: “Ubhayaṃ me na khamati, ubhayaṃ me na ruccati;
analyzed: ubhayam me na khamati ubhayam me na ruccati
translated: “I do not approve of both, I do not like both:

original: Yācāyaṃ koṭṭhamotiṇṇā, nadassaṃ iti bhāsati.
analyzed: yāca ayam iti bhāsati
translated: She has climbed up into the granary and says, ‘There is no grain.’

original: “Taṃ taṃ gāmapati brūmi, kadare appasmi jīvite;
analyzed: tam tam gāma pati brūmi kadare jīvite
translated: “I tell you this, O headman of the village, in this short life:

original: Dve māse saṅgaraṃ katvā, maṃsaṃ jaraggavaṃ kisaṃ;
analyzed: dve māse saṅgaram katvā maṃsam jaraggavam kisam
translated: Having fought for two months, the flesh of the old buffalo was wasted.

original: Appattakāle codesi, tampi mayhaṃ na ruccatī”ti.🔽Tattha taṃ taṃ gāmapati brūmīti, ambho gāmajeṭṭhaka, tena kāraṇena taṃ vadāmi. Kadare
analyzed: appatta kāle codesi tam pi mayham na ruccati iti  tattha tam tam gāma pati brūmi iti ambho gāma jeṭṭhaka tena kāraṇena tam vadāmi kadare
translated: She complained at the wrong time; that, too, I do not approve.”

analyzed: nivesentena patiṭṭhāpentena kassa nu kho dātabbā kim rūpa sampannassa udāhu vaya pattassa

original: tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.

translated: Once upon a time, in the city of Benares, when Brahmadatta was reigning there, the Bodhisatta was born in a Brāhman family.

original: vayappatto takkasilāyaṃ sippaṃ uggaṇhitvā āgantvā bārāṇasiyaṃ disāpāmokkho ācariyo

analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ kassa nu kho dātabbā ati a jānantaḥ ācariyam pucchitvā dātabba yuttakassa
translated: The Brāhman, not knowing to whom he should give his daughters, thought, “I will give them to those who are worthy of them, after asking my teacher.”

original: dassāmī”ti tassa santikaṃ gantvā tamatthaṃ pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: dassāmi iti tassa santikam gantvā tam attham pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: So he went to the teacher, and asked him the question, and spoke the first stanza:

original: “Sarīradabyaṃ vuḍḍhabyaṃ, sojaccaṃ sādhusīliyaṃ;

translated: “The body’s strength, the strength of age, the strength of purity, the strength of virtue,

translated: To the Brāhman we put the question: which of these is the best?”

original: Tattha “sarīradabya”ntiādīhi tesaṃ catunnaṃ vijjamāne guṇe pakāseti. Ayañhettha adhippāyo🔽– dhītaro me cattāro janā patthenti, tesu ekassa sarīradabyamatthi, sarīrasampadā🔽abhirūpabhāvo saṃvijjati. Ekassa vuḍḍhabyaṃ vuḍḍhibhāvo mahallakatā atthi. Ekassa
analyzed: tattha tesam catunnam vijjamāne guṇe pakāseti ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ  dhītaraḥ me cattāraḥ janā patthenti tesu ekassa sarīra dabyam atthi sarīra sampadā  abhirūpa bhāvaḥ saṃvijjati ekassa vuḍḍhabyam vuḍḍhi bhāvaḥ mahallaka tā atthi ekassa
translated: Herein, with the words “a body’s grace” he proclaims the four qualities that are present in them. This is the purport:

original: sojaccaṃ sujātitā jātisampadā atthi. “Sujacca”ntipi pāṭho. Ekassa sādhusīliyaṃ sundarasīlabhāvo🔽sīlasampadā atthi. Brāhmaṇaṃ teva pucchāmāti tesu asukassa nāmetā dātabbāti ajānantā🔽mayaṃ bhavantaṃ brāhmaṇaññeva pucchāma. Kannu tesaṃ vanimhaseti tesaṃ catunnaṃ janānaṃ

translated: “These four people are asking for my daughters. One of them has a body’s grace, a beauty of body, a handsome appearance. One has a body’s age, a body’s maturity, old age. One has a body’s purity, a good birth, a beauty of birth. The reading is also “sujacca.” One has a body’s virtue, a beauty of virtue, a good character.

original: kaṃ vanimhase, kaṃ icchāma, kassa tā kumārikā dadāmāti pucchati.
analyzed: kam kam icchāma kassa tā kumārikāḥ dadāma ati pucchati
translated: “I ask the Brahman” : not knowing which of them to give the girls to, we ask the Brahman. “Which of them do you prefer?” : which of these four do you prefer, which do we give the girls to?

original: Taṃ sutvā ācariyo “rūpasampadādīsu vijjamānāsupi vipannasīlo gārayho, tasmā taṃ nappamāṇaṃ, amhākaṃ sīlavantabhāvo ruccatī”ti imamatthaṃ pakāsento dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –

translated: On hearing this, the teacher said, “Even though there is beauty of form, etc., the man of evil character is to be blamed. Therefore, that is not a criterion. We prefer the possession of virtue.” So saying, he uttered the second stanza:

analyzed: natthi iti na vadāmi vuḍḍhabyassa namaḥ kareti vuḍḍha bhāvassa pana namakkāram eva  karomi vuḍḍha bhāvaḥ hi vandanam ānanam labhati attho atthi sujātasmin ti sujāte pi  purise vuḍḍhi atthi icchitabbāya iva sīlam asmāka ruccati iti amhākam
translated: I do not say that there is not. I pay homage to the aged means that I pay homage to the aged.🔽For the aged are to be honored and revered. original: pana sīlameva ruccati. Sīlavā hi ācārasampanno sarīradabyavirahitopi pujjo pāsaṃsoti.

analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ tassa vacanam sutvā sīlavantassa iva dhītaraḥ adāsi  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne  brāhmaṇaḥ sotāpatti phale tadā brāhmaṇaḥ ayam eva brāhmaṇaḥ ahosi disāpāmokkhaḥ
translated: The Brahman, hearing his words, gave him his virtuous daughters.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths clear, and at the conclusion of the Truths the Brahman was established in the Fruit of Conversion.

translated: Even in the days of yore, before the appearance of the Buddha, certain ascetics cultivated loving-kindness towards the four royal families of snakes and were thereby delivered from the fear of those snakes.” So saying, he told a story of the past.🔽Once upon a time when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares,🔽the Bodhisatta was born as a snake in the Himalayas. When he was born, he was of the color of the fire that burns at the end of the world, and his eyes were like the eyes of a cat. He was a great snake, and his name was Mahākāliṅga. He had four sons, and he lived in a certain forest. In that forest there were four royal families of snakes, and the Bodhisatta cultivated loving-kindness towards them. The first was the family of the snake named Kāla, the second that of the snake named Kāḷaka, the third that of the snake named Paṇḍara, and the fourth that of the snake named Mahāpaṇḍara. The Bodhisatta cultivated loving-kindness towards these four royal families of snakes, and he himself lived in a certain tree.
