translated: for these are also Nāga-king families, namely, the Erapatha-Nāga-king family, the Chabyāputa-Nāga-king family, and the Kaṇhāgotamaka-Nāga-king family.

original: Evaṃ cattāri nāgarājakulāni dassetvā “sace tumhe etesu mettaṃ bhāvetuṃ sakkhissatha, dīghajātikā vo na ḍaṃsissanti na viheṭhessantī”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam cattāri nāga rāja kulāni dassetvā sace tumhe etesu mettam bhāvetum sakkhissatha dīgha jātikāḥ vaḥ na ḍaṃsissanti na viheṭhessanti iti vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Having thus shown four Nāga-king families, he said, “If you can develop good will for these, the long-lived ones will not bite you or harm you,” and he uttered the second stanza:

original: “Apādakehi me mettaṃ, mettaṃ dvipādakehi me;
analyzed: a pādakehi me mettam mettam dvi pādakehi me
translated: I have good will for legless ones, and for two-footed ones as well;

original: Catuppadehi me mettaṃ, mettaṃ bahuppadehi me”ti.
analyzed: catuppadehi me mettam mettam bahuppadehi me iti
translated: I have good will for four-footed ones, and for many-footed ones too.

original: Tattha paṭhamapadena odissakaṃ katvā sabbesu apādakesu dīghajātikesu ceva macchesu
analyzed: tattha paṭhama padena odissakam katvā sabbesu a pādakesu dīgha jātikesu ca iva macchesu
translated: Herein, by the first line he shows the development of good will for all legless creatures, for long-lived creatures, and for fish,

original: ca mettābhāvanā dassitā, dutiyapadena manussesu ceva pakkhijātesu ca, tatiyapadena
analyzed: ca mettā bhāvanā dassitā dutiya padena manussesu ca iva pakkhi jātesu ca tatiya padena
translated: by the second line for human beings and for the two-footed species of birds,

original: hatthiassādīsu sabbacatuppadesu, catutthapadena vicchikasatapadiuccāliṅgapāṇakamakkaṭakādīsu.
analyzed: hatthi assa ādīsu sabba catuppadesu catuttha padena
translated: in the four-footed animals such as elephants, horses, etc.,

original: Evaṃ sarūpena mettābhāvanaṃ dassetvā idāni āyācanavasena dassento imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: evam sarūpena mettā bhāvanam dassetvā idāni āyācana vasena dassentaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: Having thus shown the development of loving-kindness by its own characteristics, he now said this stanza showing it by way of supplication:

original: “Mā maṃ apādako hiṃsi, mā maṃ hiṃsi dvipādako;
analyzed: mā mama a pādakaḥ hiṃsi mā mama hiṃsi dvi pādakaḥ
translated: “May no biped harm me, may no quadruped harm me;

original: Mā maṃ catuppado hiṃsi, mā maṃ hiṃsi bahuppado”ti.
analyzed: mā mama catuppadaḥ hiṃsi mā mama hiṃsi bahuppadaḥ ti
translated: May no many-footed creature harm me, may no footless creature harm me.”

original: Tattha mā manti etesu apādakādīsu koci ekopi mā maṃ hiṃsatu, mā viheṭhetūti evaṃ āyācantā mettaṃ bhāvethāti attho.
analyzed: tattha mā manti etesu a pādaka ādīsu koci ekaḥ api mā mam hiṃsatu mā viheṭhetu uti evam āyācantā mā ittam bhāvetha ati attho
translated: Herein, the meaning is that one should develop loving-kindness by supplicating thus: “May none of these bipeds, etc., harm me, may none afflict me.”

original: Idāni anodissakavasena mettābhāvanaṃ dassento imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: idāni anodissaka vasena mettā bhāvanam dassentaḥ imam gātham āha
translated: Now, showing the development of loving-kindness by way of non-direction, he said this stanza:

original: “Sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā, sabbe bhūtā ca kevalā;
analyzed: sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā ca kevalā
translated: “May all creatures, all breathing beings, all who are born, all who exist,

original: Sabbe bhadrāni passantu, mā kañci pāpamāgamā”ti.
analyzed: sabbe bhadrāni passantu mā kañci pāpam āgamāti
translated: May all see what is auspicious, may none meet with anything evil.”

original: Tattha taṇhādiṭṭhivasena vaṭṭe pañcasu khandhesu āsattā visattā laggā laggitāti sattā,
analyzed: tattha taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena vaṭṭe pañcasu khandhesu āsattā visattā laggā laggitā ati sattā
translated: Herein, they are creatures sattā because they are attached to, cling to, the five categories of form, etc., by craving and views, and because they are scattered in the round of rebirths.

original: assāsapassāsapavattanasaṅkhātena pāṇanavasena pāṇā, bhūtabhāvitanibbattanavasena🔽bhūtāti evaṃ vacanamattaviseso veditabbo. Avisesena pana sabbānipetāni padāni sabbasattasaṅgāhakāneva.
analyzed: assāsa passāsa pavattana saṅkhātena pāṇana vasena pāṇāḥ bhūta bhāvita nibbattana vasena  bhūtā ati evam vacana matta visesaḥ veditabbaḥ avisesena pana sabba anipetāni padāni sabba satta saṅgāhakāni eva
translated: “Life” is so called because of the occurrence of in-breaths and out-breaths, which are a sign of the presence of life.🔽“Beings” is so called because of the presence of the four great entities and the derived matter.🔽This is the difference in the wording only. But without distinction all these terms include all living beings.🔽“All”: complete. This is a synonym for the word “all.”

original: Kevalāti sakalā. Idaṃ sabbasaddasseva hi pariyāyavacanaṃ. Bhadrāni passantūti sabbepete
analyzed: kevalā ati sakalā idam sabba saddassa iva hi pariyāya vacanam bhadrāni passantu iti
translated: “May they be happy”: may all these beings

original: sattā bhadrāni sādhūni kalyāṇāneva passantu. Mā kañci pāpamāgamāti etesu kañci ekaṃ
analyzed: sattāḥ bhadrāni sādhūni kalyāṇān eva passantu mā kañci pāpam āgamāti etesu kañci ekam
translated: see what is good, that is, what is excellent, what is noble.

original: sattampi pāpaṃ lāmakaṃ dukkhaṃ mā āgamā, mā āgacchatu mā pāpuṇātu, sabbe averā abyāpajjā
analyzed: sattam pi pāpam lāmakam dukkham mā āgamā mā āgacchatu mā pāpuṇātu sabbe averāḥ a byāpajjā
translated: “Let not the least misfortune come to any of them”: let not any misfortune, any evil, any suffering come to any one of them, let it not approach, let it not reach any one.🔽“May they all be free from hate and let them not be troubled”: may they be free from hate, free from affliction.

original: sukhī niddukkhā hontūti.
analyzed: sukhī niddukkhāḥ hontu uti
translated: “May they be happy and may they live in comfort”: may they be happy and free from pain.

original: Evaṃ “sabbasattesu anodissakavasena mettaṃ bhāvethā”ti vatvā puna tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ guṇe anussarāpetuṃ –🔽“Appamāṇo buddho, appamāṇo dhammo;
analyzed: evam sabba sattesu anodissaka vasena mettam bhāvetha iti vatvā puna tiṇṇam ratanānam guṇe  appamāṇaḥ buddhaḥ appamāṇaḥ dhammaḥ
translated: Having thus advised them to develop loving-kindness by directing it towards all beings without making any distinctions, he now said, “The Buddha is immeasurable, the Dhamma is immeasurable, the Sangha is immeasurable,” in order to remind them of the special qualities of the Three Jewels.

original: Appamāṇo saṅgho”ti āha.
analyzed: appamāṇaḥ saṅghaḥ iti āha
translated: “The Buddha is immeasurable, the Dhamma is immeasurable, the Sangha is immeasurable.”

original: Tattha pamāṇakarānaṃ kilesānaṃ abhāvena guṇānañca pamāṇābhāvena buddharatanaṃ appamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha pamāṇa karānam kilesānam abhāvena guṇānam ca pamāṇa abhāvena buddha ratanam appamāṇam
translated: The Buddha Jewel is immeasurable because there is no measure of the defilements that have been abandoned in it, and because there is no measure of the noble qualities that exist in it.

original: Dhammoti navavidho lokuttaradhammo. Tassapi pamāṇaṃ kātuṃ na sakkāti appamāṇo. Tena
analyzed: dhammo ti navavidhaḥ lokuttara dhammo tassa api pamāṇam kātum na sakkāti appamāṇaḥ tena
translated: The Dhamma is the ninefold supramundane Dhamma. It too is immeasurable because it cannot be measured.

original: appamāṇena dhammena samannāgatattā saṅghopi appamāṇo.
analyzed: appamāṇena dhammena samannāgata ttā saṅghaḥ api appamāṇaḥ
translated: The Sangha is immeasurable because it possesses the immeasurable Dhamma.

original: Iti bodhisatto “imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ guṇe anussarathā”ti vatvā tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ appamāṇaguṇataṃ dassetvā sappamāṇe satte dassetuṃ –
analyzed: iti bodhisattaḥ imesam tiṇṇam rata nānam guṇe anussaratha iti vatvā tiṇṇam rata nānam appamāṇa guṇatam dassetvā sa ppamāṇe satte dassetum
translated: Thus the Bodhisatta said: “Remember the qualities of these three Jewels.” Having shown the immeasurable qualities of the three Jewels, he said the following verses in order to show the measurable creatures:

original: “Pamāṇavantāni sarīsapāni, ahi vicchika satapadī;
analyzed: pamāṇavantāni sarīsapāni ahi vicchika satapadī
translated: “Creatures with a measure are: snakes, scorpions, centipedes,

original: Uṇṇanābhi sarabū mūsikā”ti āha.🔽Tattha sarīsapānīti sappadīghajātikānaṃ nāmaṃ. Te hi sarantā gacchanti, sirena vā
analyzed: uṇṇanābhi sarabū mūsikā iti āha  tattha sarīsapāni iti sappa dīgha jātikānam nāmam te hi sarantā gacchanti sirena vā
translated: monkeys, mongooses, and rats.”🔽Here, “creatures” is a name for those creatures that move by crawling. They are called “crawlers” because they crawl along the ground.

original: sapantīti sarīsapā. “Ahī”tiādi tesaṃ sarūpato nidassanaṃ. Tattha uṇṇanābhīti makkaṭako.
analyzed: sapantīti sarīsapāḥ ahi itiādi tesam sarūpataḥ nidassanam tattha uṇṇanābhī iti makkaṭako
translated: “Snakes” and so on are mentioned in order to show their individual forms. Here, “monkeys” means the monkey-like creatures.

original: Tassa hi nābhito uṇṇāsadisaṃ suttaṃ nikkhamati, tasmā “uṇṇanābhī”ti vuccati. Sarabūti gharagoḷikā.🔽Iti bodhisatto “yasmā etesaṃ antorāgādayo pamāṇakarā dhammā atthi, tasmā tāni sarīsapādīni
analyzed: tassa hi nābhitas uṇṇā sadisam suttam nikkhamati tasmā uṇṇanābhī iti vuccati sarabū ti gharagoḷikā  iti bodhisatto yasmai etesam antorāga ādayo pamāṇa karāḥ dhammāḥ atthi tasmai tāni sarīsapādīni
translated: For a thread like a tuft of cotton comes out from his navel, and that is why he is called “Tuft-Navel.” “Sarabhu” is a house-lizard.🔽So the Bodhisatta showed that these creatures, snakes, etc.,

original: pamāṇavantānī”ti dassetvā “appamāṇānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ ānubhāvena ime pamāṇavantā
analyzed: pamāṇavantāni iti dassetvā appamāṇānam tiṇṇam ratanānam ānubhāvena ime pamāṇavantā
translated: are of a size because they have within them such things as lust, etc., which are the causes of their size, and he said: “By the power of the three incomparable treasures, these creatures,

original: sattā rattindivaṃ parittakammaṃ karontūti evaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ guṇe anussarathā”ti
analyzed: sattāḥ rattindivam paritta kammam karontu uti evam tiṇṇam rata nānam guṇe anussaratha ati
translated: which are of a size, may work for a short time day and night. Thus remember the virtues of the three treasures.”

original: vatvā tato uttari kattabbaṃ dassetuṃ imaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vatvā tatas uttari kattabbam dassetum imam gātham āha
translated: And then, in order to show what should be done next, he uttered this stanza:

original: “Katā me rakkhā katā me parittā, paṭikkamantu bhūtāni;
analyzed: katā me rakkhā katā me parittā paṭikkamantu bhūtāni
translated: “My protection is made, my safeguard is made; let the creatures go back.

original: Sohaṃ namo bhagavato, namo sattannaṃ sammāsambuddhāna”nti.
analyzed: saḥ ham namaḥ bhagavataḥ namaḥ sattannam sammāsambuddhānam ti
translated: I pay homage to the Blessed One, I pay homage to the seven Supremely Enlightened Ones.”

original: Tattha katā me rakkhāti mayā ratanattayaguṇe anussarantena attano rakkhā gutti katā.
analyzed: tattha katā me rakkhā ati mayā ratanattaya guṇe anussarantena attanaḥ rakkhā gutti katā
translated: Herein, my protection is made means my protection, my safeguard, is made by me who remembers the virtues of the Three Treasures.

original: Katā me parittāti parittāṇampi me attano kataṃ. Paṭikkamantu bhūtānīti mayi ahitajjhāsayāni🔽bhūtāni paṭikkamantu apagacchantu. Sohaṃ namo bhagavatoti so ahaṃ evaṃ kataparitto🔽atītassa parinibbutassa sabbassapi buddhassa bhagavato namo karomi. Namo sattannaṃ
analyzed: katā me parittā ati me attano katam paṭikkamantu bhūtāni iti mayi  bhūtāni paṭikkamantu apagacchantu saḥ ham namaḥ bhagavataḥ iti saḥ aham evam kata parittaḥ  atītassa parinibbutassa sabbassa api buddhassa bhagavataḥ namaḥ karomi namaḥ
translated: I have made protection: I have made protection for myself. Let the beings turn back: Let the beings who are intent on my harm turn back,🔽let them depart. I pay homage to the Blessed One: Thus having made protection,🔽I pay homage to the Blessed One, to the Fully Enlightened One, to all the Buddhas of the past who have attained final Nibbana.

original: sammāsambuddhānanti visesena pana atīte paṭipāṭiyā parinibbutānaṃ sattannaṃ sammāsambuddhānaṃ namo karomīti.
analyzed: sammāsambuddhānam ti visesena pana atīte paṭipāṭiyā parinibbutānam sattannam sammāsambuddhānam namaḥ karomi iti
translated: I have made my protection: I have made my protection for myself. Let the beings turn back: let the beings who are disposed to do me harm turn back, let them go away. I pay homage to the Blessed One: thus having made my protection, I pay homage to the Blessed One, to all the Buddhas who have attained final Nibbana. I pay homage to the Seven: but especially I pay homage to the Seven Buddhas who have attained final Nibbana in the past in regular succession.

original: Evaṃ “namakkāraṃ karontāpi satta buddhe anussarathā”ti bodhisatto isigaṇassa imaṃ
analyzed: evam namakkāram karontā api satta buddhe anussaratha ati bodhisatto isi gaṇassa imaṃ
translated: Thus the Bodhisatta, having composed this protection, gave it to the company of seers, saying: “Remembering the Seven Buddhas, pay homage to them as you recite this protection.”

original: parittaṃ bandhitvā adāsi. Ādito pana paṭṭhāya dvīhi gāthāhi catūsu ahirājakulesu🔽mettāya dīpitattā odissakānodissakavasena vā dvinnaṃ mettābhāvanānaṃ dīpitattā idaṃ
analyzed: parittam bandhitvā adāsi āditaḥ pana paṭṭhāya dvīhi gāthāhi catūsu ahi rāja kulesu  mettāya dīpita ttā odissaka anodissaka vasena vā dvinnam mettā bhāvanānam dīpita ttā idam
translated: But from the beginning, since loving-kindness was demonstrated in the four royal families of the nagas by means of two stanzas,🔽this protection should be understood as being stated here because of the demonstration of two kinds of practice of loving-kindness, namely, that with a specific object and that without a specific object. Or some other reason should be sought.

original: parittaṃ idha vuttanti veditabbaṃ, aññaṃ vā kāraṇaṃ pariyesitabbaṃ. Tato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: parittam idha vuttanti veditabbam aññam vā kāraṇam pariyesitabbam tatas paṭṭhāya
translated: From there on,

original: isigaṇo bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā mettaṃ bhāvesi, buddhaguṇe anussari. Evametesu
analyzed: isi gaṇaḥ bodhisattassa ovāde ṭhatvā mettam bhāvesi buddha guṇe evam etesu
translated: The company of seers, abiding in the instruction of the Bodhisatta, cultivated loving-kindness, and called to mind the virtues of the Buddha. As they thus called to mind

original: buddhaguṇe anussarantesuyeva sabbe dīghajātikā paṭikkamiṃsu. Bodhisattopi brahmavihāre
analyzed: buddha guṇe anussarantesu yeva sabbe dīgha jātikā paṭikkamiṃsu bodhisattaḥ api brahmavihāre
translated: the virtues of the Buddha, all the long-lived seers turned back. The Bodhisatta also, having cultivated the divine abodes,

original: bhāvetvā brahmalokaparāyaṇo ahosi.
analyzed: bhāvetvā brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ ahosi
translated: was reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā isigaṇo buddhaparisā ahosi, gaṇasatthā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā isi gaṇaḥ buddha parisā ahosi gaṇa satthā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this dhamma discourse, he made the connection and identified the Birth Story, saying, “At that time the company of seers was the company of the Buddha, and I myself was the teacher of the company.”

original: Khandhajātakavaṇṇanā tatiyā.
analyzed: khandha jātaka vaṇṇanā tatiyā
translated: The Commentary on the Khandha Birth Story is finished.

original: [204] 4. Vīrakajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vīraka jātaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Vīraka Birth Story

original: Api vīraka passesīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto sugatālayaṃ ārabbha kathesi.🔽Devadattassa parisaṃ gahetvā āgatesu hi theresu satthā “sāriputta, devadatto tumhe
analyzed: api vīraka passesi iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ sugata ālayam ārabbha kathesi  devadattassa parisam gahetvā āgatesu hi theresu satthā sāriputta devadatto tumhe
translated: “Even Vīraka saw it,” was spoken by the Teacher while he was in residence at Jetavana, concerning the Sugata-home.🔽For when the Elders, having taken Devadatta’s company with them, came to the Teacher, the Teacher asked them, “Sāriputta, what did Devadatta do when he saw you?”🔽“He showed us the Sugata-home, Reverend Sir.”

original: disvā kiṃ akāsī”ti pucchitvā “sugatālayaṃ, bhante, dassesī”ti vutte “na kho, sāriputta,
analyzed: disvā kim akāsi iti pucchitvā sugata ālayam bhante dassesi iti vutte na kho sāriputta
translated: “Sāriputta, Devadatta is not the only one who has shown you the Sugata-home.

original: idāneva devadatto mama anukiriyaṃ karonto vināsaṃ patto, pubbepi vināsaṃ pāpuṇī”ti
analyzed: idānā iva devadattaḥ mama anukiriyam karontaḥ vināsam pattaḥ pubbe api vināsam pāpuṇi iti
translated: “It is not only now that Devadatta has come to ruin by imitating me; in the past also he came to ruin by imitating me.”

original: vatvā therena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vatvā therena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: When the Elder requested him to tell the story, he related the following:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto himavantapadese udakakākayoniyaṃ🔽nibbattitvā ekaṃ saraṃ upanissāya vasi, “vīrako”tissa nāmaṃ ahosi. Tadā kāsiraṭṭhe
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ himavanta padese udakakākayoniyam  nibbattitvā ekam saram upanissāya vasi vīrakotissa nāmam ahosi tadā kāsiraṭṭhe
translated: In times long past, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in the world of the birds, in the womb of a water-crow.

original: dubbhikkhaṃ ahosi, manussā kākabhattaṃ vā dātuṃ yakkhanāgabalikammaṃ vā kātuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu.🔽Chātakaraṭṭhato kākā yebhuyyena araññaṃ pavisiṃsu. Tattheko bārāṇasivāsī saviṭṭhako🔽nāma kāko kākiṃ ādāya vīrakassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā taṃ saraṃ nissāya ekamante vāsaṃ
analyzed: dubbhikkham ahosi manussā kāka bhattam vā dātum yakkha nāga bali kammam vā kātum na asakkhiṃsu  chātakaraṭṭhataḥ kākāḥ yebhuyyena araññam pavisiṃsu tattha ekaḥ bārāṇasi vāsī sa viṭṭhakaḥ  nāma kāko kākim ādāya vīrakassa vasanaṭṭhānam gantvā tam saram nissāya eka mante vāsam
translated: He lived near a lake, and his name was Vīraka. At that time there was a famine in the kingdom of Kāsi, and the people were unable either to give food to the crows or to perform the rites of the Yakkhas and Nāgas.🔽The crows from the Chātaka mountain entered the forest in great numbers. There was a crow living in Benares, named Saviṭṭhaka,🔽who took his wife with him and went to the place where Vīraka lived, and made his home near the lake.

original: kappesi. So ekadivasaṃ tasmiṃ sare gocaraṃ gaṇhanto vīrakaṃ saraṃ otaritvā macche
analyzed: kappesi saḥ eka divasam tasmin sare gocaram gaṇhantaḥ vīrakam saram otaritvā macche
translated: One day, as he was gathering food in the lake, Vīraka entered the water and caught a fish,

original: khāditvā paccuttaritvā sarīraṃ sukkhāpentaṃ disvā “imaṃ udakakākaṃ nissāya sakkā
analyzed: khāditvā paccuttaritvā sarīram sukkhāpentam disvā imam udaka kākam nissāya sakkā
translated: and seeing him come out of the water and dry himself, thought, “By means of this water-crow I can get many fish.

original: bahū macche laddhuṃ, imaṃ upaṭṭhahissāmī”ti taṃ upasaṅkamitvā “kiṃ, sammā”ti vutte
analyzed: bahū macche laddhum imam upaṭṭhahissāmi iti tam upasaṅkamitvā kim sammā iti vutte
translated: I will wait on him.” So he went to him and said, “What is it, my good man?”

original: “icchāmi taṃ sāmi upaṭṭhahitu”nti vatvā “sādhū”ti tena sampaṭicchito tato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: icchāmi tam sāmi upaṭṭhahitun ti vatvā sādhu iti tena sampaṭicchitaḥ tatas paṭṭhāya
translated: “I wish to wait on you, sir.” “Very well,” said the other, and consented to be waited on by him.

original: upaṭṭhāsi. Vīrakopi tato paṭṭhāya attano yāpanamattaṃ khāditvā macche uddharitvā
analyzed: upaṭṭhāsi vīrakaḥ api tatas paṭṭhāya attanaḥ yāpana mattam khāditvā macche uddharitvā
translated: From that time on, Vīraka ate just enough to keep himself alive, and gave the rest of the fish to the water-crow.

original: saviṭṭhakassa deti. Sopi attano yāpanamattaṃ khāditvā sesaṃ kākiyā deti.🔽Tassa aparabhāge māno uppajji – “ayampi udakakāko kāḷako, ahampi kāḷako, akkhituṇḍapādehipi
analyzed: sa viṭṭhakassa deti saḥ api attanaḥ yāpana mattam khāditvā sesam kākiyā deti  tassa aparabhāge mānaḥ uppajji ayam pi udakakāko kāḷakaḥ aham pi kāḷakaḥ akkhi tuṇḍa pādehi pi
translated: The water-crow ate just enough to keep himself alive, and gave the rest to the female crow.

original: etassa ca mayhañca nānākaraṇaṃ natthi, ito paṭṭhāya iminā gahitamacchehi mayhaṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: etassa ca mayham ca nānākaraṇam natthi itas paṭṭhāya iminā gahitam acchehi mayham kammaṃ
translated: After a time pride arose in him, and he thought, “This water-crow is black, and I am black. There is no difference between him and me. From this time forth I will have nothing to do with the fish he catches.

original: natthi, ahameva gaṇhissāmī”ti. So vīrakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā “samma, ito paṭṭhāya ahameva
analyzed: natthi aham eva gaṇhissāmi iti so vīrakam upasaṅkamitvā samma itas paṭṭhāya aham eva
translated: I will catch them myself.” So he went to Vīraka and said, “My good man, from this time forth I will catch the fish myself.

original: saraṃ otaritvā macche gaṇhissāmī”ti vatvā “na tvaṃ, samma, udakaṃ otaritvā macche
analyzed: saram otaritvā macche gaṇhissāmi iti vatvā na tvam samme udakam otaritvā macche
translated: “I will go down into the water and catch some fish.”🔽“You can’t go down into the water and catch fish.

original: gaṇhanakakule nibbatto, mā nassī”ti tena vāriyamānopi vacanaṃ anādiyitvā saraṃ oruyha
analyzed: gaṇhanaka kule nibbattaḥ mā nassi iti tena vāriyamānaḥ api vacanam an ādiyitvā saram oruyha
translated: “I will go down into the pool and catch some fish.” “You were not born in a family that went down into the water and caught fish. Do not be lost.” But in spite of his brother’s warning, he paid no attention to his words, went down into the pool,

original: udakaṃ pavisitvā ummujjamāno sevālaṃ chinditvā nikkhamituṃ nāsakkhi, sevālantare🔽laggi, aggatuṇḍameva paññāyi. So nirassāso antoudakeyeva jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpuṇi. Athassa🔽bhariyā āgamanaṃ apassamānā taṃ pavattiṃ jānanatthaṃ vīrakassa santikaṃ gantvā “sāmi,
analyzed: udakam pavisitvā ummujjamānaḥ sevālam chinditvā nikkhamitum na asakkhi sevāla antare  laggi agga tuṇḍam eva paññāyi saḥ nirassāsaḥ antoudakeyā iva jīvita kkhayam pāpuṇi  bhariyā āgamanam a passamānā tam pavattim jānana attham vīrakassa santikam gantvā sāmi
translated: and entered the water. As he was rising to the surface, he cut through the moss and was unable to get out. He became entangled in the moss,

original: saviṭṭhako na paññāyati, kahaṃ nu kho so”ti pucchamānā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sa viṭṭhakaḥ na paññāyati kaham nu kho sā iti pucchamānā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and only the tip of his beak was visible. He became exhausted and died in the water. Then his wife, not seeing him return, went to Vīraka in order to find out what had happened. “Husband,” said she, “Saviṭṭha is not to be seen. Where can he be?” So saying, she repeated the first stanza:

original: “Api vīraka passesi, sakuṇaṃ mañjubhāṇakaṃ;
analyzed: api vīraka passesi sakuṇam mañju bhāṇakam
translated: “Have you seen, O Vīraka, a bird of pleasant voice,

original: Mayūragīvasaṅkāsaṃ, patiṃ mayhaṃ saviṭṭhaka”nti.
analyzed: mayūra gīva saṅkāsam patim mayham
translated: Like a peacock’s neck, my husband Saviṭṭha?”

original: Tattha api, vīraka, passesīti, sāmi vīraka, api passasi. Mañjubhāṇakanti mañjubhāṇinaṃ.
analyzed: tattha api vīraka passesi iti sāmi vīraka api passasi mañjubhāṇakam ti mañjubhāṇinam
translated: “Have you seen, O Vīraka?” means, “Husband Vīraka, have you seen?” “A bird of pleasant voice” means, “a bird of sweet voice.”

original: Sā hi rāgavasena “madhurassaro me patī”ti maññati, tasmā evamāha. Mayūragīvasaṅkāsanti
analyzed: sā hi rāga vasena madhurassaraḥ me patiḥ iti maññati tasmai evam āha mayūra gīva saṅkāsanti
translated: For she thought, “My husband has a sweet voice,” and so she said, “My husband’s voice is like a peacock’s call.”

original: moragīvasamānavaṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: mā uragīva samāna vaṇṇam
translated: “Like a peacock’s neck” means having the same color as a peacock’s neck.

original: Taṃ sutvā vīrako “āma, jānāmi te sāmikassa gataṭṭhāna”nti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā vīrakaḥ āma jānāmi te sāmikassa gata ṭṭhānam ti vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, Vīraka said, “Yes, I know where your husband has gone,” and he spoke the second verse:🔽“The bird that roams the water’s edge,

original: “Udakathalacarassa pakkhino, niccaṃ āmakamacchabhojino;
analyzed: udaka thala carassa pakkhinaḥ niccam āmaka maccha bhojinaḥ
translated: always eating fresh fish,🔽his imitator, Saviṭṭhaka,

original: Tassānukaraṃ saviṭṭhako, sevāle paliguṇṭhito mato”ti.
analyzed: tassa anukaram sa viṭṭhakaḥ sevāle paliguṇṭhitaḥ mato ti
translated: is dead, entangled in a reed.”

original: Tattha udakathalacarassāti udake ca thale ca carituṃ samatthassa. Pakkhinoti attānaṃ🔽sandhāya vadati. Tassānukaranti tassa anukaronto. Sevāle paliguṇṭhito matoti udakaṃ
analyzed: tattha udaka thala carassa ati udake ca thale ca caritum samatthassa pakkhinoti attānam  sandhāya vadati tassa anukaranti tassa anukarontaḥ sevāle paliguṇṭhitaḥ mato ti udakaṃ
translated: Herein, that roams the water’s edge is able to roam in water and on land. The bird refers to himself.

original: pavisitvā sevālaṃ chinditvā nikkhamituṃ asakkonto sevālapariyonaddho antoudakeyeva
analyzed: pavisitvā sevālam chinditvā nikkhamitum a sakkonto sevāla pariyonaddhaḥ
translated: His imitator is imitating him. Entangled in a reed, dead is unable to enter the water, cut the reed, and come out. Entangled in the reed,🔽he is dead in the water. Look, his beak is visible.

original: mato, passa, etassa tuṇḍaṃ dissatīti. Taṃ sutvā kākī paridevitvā bārāṇasimeva agamāsi.
analyzed: mato passaḥ etassa tuṇḍam dissati iti tam sutvā kākī paridevitvā bārāṇasim eva agamāsi
translated: Hearing this, the crow wailed and went to Bārāṇasī.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā saviṭṭhako devadatto ahosi, vīrako pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā saviṭṭhakaḥ devadatto ahosi vīrakaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: The Master, having related this story, identified the Birth by saying, “Devadatta was Saviṭṭha, and I myself was Vīraka.”

original: Vīrakajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: vīraka jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: The Birth Story of Vīraka is ended.

original: [205] 5. Gaṅgeyyajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Sobhati maccho gaṅgeyyoti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto dve daharabhikkhū ārabbha
analyzed: sobhati macchas gaṅgeyyā ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ dve dahara bhikkhū ārabbha
translated: The Birth Story of Gaṅgeya

original: kathesi. Te kira sāvatthivāsino kulaputtā sāsane pabbajitvā asubhabhāvanaṃ anunuyuñjitvā
analyzed: kathesi te kira sāvatthi vāsinaḥ kula puttā sāsane pabbajitvā asubha bhāvanam anunuyuñjitvā
translated: “A fish is beautiful in the Gaṅgā,” etc. The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning two young monks. These two young men, it would appear, were sons of good families in Sāvatthi, who had gone forth in the Dispensation. They had been instructed in the meditation on foulness,

original: rūpapasaṃsakā hutvā rūpaṃ upalāḷentā vicariṃsu. Te ekadivasaṃ “tvaṃ na sobhasi, ahaṃ🔽sobhāmī”ti rūpaṃ nissāya uppannavivādā avidūre nisinnaṃ ekaṃ mahallakattheraṃ disvā
analyzed: rūpapasaṃsakāḥ hutvā rūpam vicariṃsu te eka divasam tvam na sobhasi aham  sobhāmi iti rūpam nissāya uppanna vivādā avidūre nisinnam ekam mahallaka ttheram disvā
translated: and they went about, praising beauty. One day they fell into a dispute, saying, “You are not beautiful, I am beautiful.”🔽They saw an aged monk sitting not far away, and they thought, “He will know whether we are beautiful or not.”

original: “eso amhākaṃ sobhanabhāvaṃ vā asobhanabhāvaṃ vā jānissatī”ti taṃ upasaṅkamitvā “bhante,
analyzed: esaḥ amhākam sobhana bhāvam vā asobhana bhāvam vā jānissati iti tam upasaṅkamitvā bhante
translated: So they went to him and asked, “Venerable sir,

original: ko amhesu sobhano”ti pucchiṃsu. So “āvuso, tumhehi ahameva sobhanataro”ti āha. Daharā
analyzed: kaḥ amhesu sobhanaḥ iti saḥ āvuso tumhehi aham eva sobhanataraḥ iti āha daharā
translated: who is the more beautiful of us?” “I am more beautiful than you are, friends.”

original: “ayaṃ mahallako amhehi pucchitaṃ akathetvā apucchitaṃ kathetī”ti taṃ paribhāsitvā
analyzed: ayam mahallakaḥ amhehi pucchitam a kathetvā a pucchitam katheti iti tam paribhāsitvā
translated: “This old monk, instead of answering the questions we asked him, has talked about something else.” So saying, they left him and went their way.

original: pakkamiṃsu. Sā tesaṃ kiriyā bhikkhusaṅghe pākaṭā jātā. Athekadivasaṃ dhammasabhāyaṃ🔽kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ – “āvuso, asuko mahallako thero kira te rūpanissitake dahare
analyzed: pakkamiṃsu sā tesam kiriyā bhikkhu saṅghe pākaṭā jātā atha eka divasam dhammasabhāyam  katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso asukaḥ mahallakaḥ theraḥ kira te rūpa nissitake dahare
translated: The conduct of the old monk became known throughout the whole fraternity of monks. One day, as the monks were sitting in the Hall of Truth,

original: lajjāpesī”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti
analyzed: lajjā pesi iti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati
translated: they began a discussion of the incident, saying, “Brethren, it is reported that a certain old monk has shamed those young monks who are devoted to the pleasures of sense.” The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what is the subject that engages your attention now as you sit here all gathered together?”

original: pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, ime dve daharā idāneva rūpapasaṃsakā,
analyzed: pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave ime dve daharā idānā iva rūpa pasaṃsakā
translated: When they told him, he said, “Monks, those two young monks are not the only ones who have been devoted to the pleasures of sense;

original: pubbepete rūpameva upalāḷentā vicariṃsū”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: pubbe pete rūpam eva upalāḷentā vicariṃsu iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: in a previous state of existence also they wandered about, delighting in the pleasures of sense.” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto gaṅgātīre rukkhadevatā ahosi.🔽Tadā gaṅgāyamunānaṃ samāgamaṭṭhāne gaṅgeyyo ca yāmuneyyo ca dve macchā “ahaṃ sobhāmi,
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ gaṅgā tīre rukkha devatā ahosi 🔽tadā gaṅgā yamunānam samāgama ṭṭhāne ca yāmuneyyo ca dve macchā aham sobhāmi
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, in the city of Bārāṇasī, in the province of Kāsi, there lived a certain householder.🔽One day, as he was going to the river to bathe, he saw a certain woman of the city, and immediately conceived an affection for her.

original: tvaṃ na sobhasī”ti rūpaṃ nissāya vivadamānā avidūre gaṅgātīre kacchapaṃ nipannaṃ
analyzed: tvam na sobhasi iti rūpam nissāya vivadamānāḥ avidūre gaṅgā tīre kacchapam nipannam
translated: “You are not beautiful.” They argued about beauty, and not far away on the bank of the Ganges they saw a turtle lying down.

original: disvā “eso amhākaṃ sobhanabhāvaṃ vā asobhanabhāvaṃ vā jānissatī”ti taṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: disvā esaḥ amhākam sobhana bhāvam vā asobhana bhāvam vā jānissati iti tam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: They went to him and said, “This turtle will know whether we are beautiful or not.”

original: “kiṃ nu kho, samma kacchapa, gaṅgeyyo sobhati, udāhu yāmuneyyo”ti pucchiṃsu. Kacchapo
analyzed: kim nu kho samma kacchapa gaṅgeyyo sobhati udāhu yāmuneyyo ti pucchiṃsu kacchapo
translated: “Is the fish of the Ganges beautiful, or is the fish of the Yamunā beautiful?”

original: “gaṅgeyyopi sobhati, yāmuneyyopi sobhati, tumhehi pana dvīhi ahameva atirekataraṃ
analyzed: sobhati sobhati tumhehi pana dvīhi aham eva atirekataram
translated: “The fish of the Ganges is beautiful, and the fish of the Yamunā is beautiful, but I am more beautiful than both of you.”

original: sobhāmī”ti imamatthaṃ pakāsento paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sobhāmi iti imam attham pakāsento paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: Explaining this matter, he spoke the first verse:

original: “Sobhati maccho gaṅgeyyo, atho sobhati yāmuno;
analyzed: sobhati macchas gaṅgeyyaḥ atho sobhati yāmunaḥ
translated: “The fish of the Ganges is beautiful, and the fish of the Yamunā is beautiful;

original: Catuppadoyaṃ puriso, nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo;
analyzed: catuppadaḥ yam purisaḥ nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ
translated: But the man with four legs, round as a banyan tree,

original: Īsakāyatagīvo ca, sabbeva atirocatī”ti.
analyzed: īsakāyatagīvo ca sabbā iva atirocati iti
translated: With a long neck like a chariot pole, is more beautiful than all.”

original: Tattha catuppadoyanti catuppado ayaṃ. Purisoti attānaṃ sandhāya vadati. Nigrodhaparimaṇḍaloti
analyzed: tattha catuppadoyanti catuppadaḥ ayam puriso iti attānam sandhāya vadati nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ ti
translated: Herein, with four legs means this one with four legs. Man means he spoke referring to himself. Round as a banyan tree means well-formed like a banyan tree.

original: sujāto nigrodho viya parimaṇḍalo. Īsakāyatagīvoti rathīsā viya āyatagīvo. Sabbeva
analyzed: su jātaḥ nigrodhaḥ viya parimaṇḍalaḥ īsaka āyata gīvaḥ ti rathīsāḥ viya āyata gīvaḥ sabbā iva
translated: With a long neck like a chariot pole means with a long neck like a chariot pole. All means all of you.

original: atirocatīti evaṃ saṇṭhānasampanno kacchapo sabbeva atirocati, ahameva sabbe tumhe🔽atikkamitvā sobhāmīti vadati.
analyzed: atirocati iti evam saṇṭhāna sampannaḥ kacchapo sabbā iva atirocati aham eva sabbe tumhe  atikkamitvā sobhāmi iti vadati
translated: I surpass you all.”🔽The fish, being angry at his words, said, “You wicked tortoise, you have not answered our question, but have said something else.”

original: Macchā tassa kathaṃ hutvā “ambho! Pāpakacchapa amhehi pucchitaṃ akathetvā aññameva kathesī”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: macchā tassa katham hutvā ambho pāpakacchapa amhehi pucchitam a kathetvā aññam eva kathesi iti vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: And they spoke the second stanza:

original: “Yaṃ pucchito na taṃ akkhāsi, aññaṃ akkhāsi pucchito;
analyzed: yam pucchitaḥ na tam akkhāsi aññam akkhāsi pucchitaḥ
translated: “You have not answered what we asked, but have said something else;

original: Atthappasaṃsako poso, nāyaṃ asmāka ruccatī”ti.🔽Tattha attappasaṃsakoti attānaṃ pasaṃsanasīlo attukkaṃsako poso. Nāyaṃ asmāka ruccatīti🔽ayaṃ pāpakacchapo amhākaṃ na ruccati na khamatīti kacchapassa upari udakaṃ khipitvā
analyzed: attha ppasaṃsakaḥ posaḥ na ayam asmāka ruccati iti  tattha atta ppasaṃsakaḥ ti attānam pasaṃsana sīlaḥ attukkaṃsakaḥ posaḥ na ayam asmāka ruccati iti  ayam pāpa kacchapaḥ amhākam na ruccati na khamati iti kacchapassa upari udakam khipitvā
translated: This man who praises himself is not to our taste.”🔽Here “attappasaṃsako” means “one who praises himself,” “one who extols himself.” “Nāyaṃ asmāka ruccatī” means “this wicked tortoise is not to our taste.”

original: sakaṭṭhānameva gamiṃsu.
analyzed: saka ṭṭhānam eva gamiṃsu
translated: And so they threw water over the tortoise and went back to their own place.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā dve macchā dve daharabhikkhū
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā dve macchā dve dahara bhikkhū
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the two fish were the two young monks,🔽and the tortoise was Devadatta.

original: ahesuṃ, kacchapo mahallako, imassa kāraṇassa paccakkhakārikā gaṅgātīre nibbattarukkhadevatā
analyzed: ahesum kacchapaḥ mahallakaḥ imassa kāraṇassa paccakkha kārikā gaṅgā tīre nibbatta rukkha devatā
translated: were the crocodile, the old tortoise, and the tree-spirit on the bank of the Ganges who witnessed the incident.

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Gaṅgeyyajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: pana aham eva  gaṅgeyya jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: But I myself was the monkey.”🔽The Story of the Monkey on the Ganges is finished.

original: [206] 6. Kuruṅgamigajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: . The Story of the Leader of the Herd of Deer

original: Iṅgha vaṭṭamayaṃ pāsanti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto devadattaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: iṅgha vaṭṭa mayam pāsanti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ devadattam ārabbha kathesi
translated: “Come, let us make a snare of creepers.” This story the Master told, while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, concerning Devadatta.

original: Tadā hi satthā “devadatto vadhāya parisakkatī”ti sutvā “na, bhikkhave, devadatto
analyzed: tadā hi satthā devadattaḥ vadhāya parisakkati iti sutvā na bhikkhave devadatto
translated: For the Master, hearing that Devadatta was plotting to kill him, said, “Monks, Devadatta is not now only plotting to kill me;

original: idāneva mayhaṃ vadhāya parisakkati, pubbepi parisakkiyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: idānā iva mayham vadhāya parisakkati pubbe pi parisakkiyā iva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: in the past also he plotted to kill me.” And so saying, he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto kuruṅgamigo hutvā araññe🔽ekassa sarassa avidūre ekasmiṃ gumbe vāsaṃ kappesi. Tasseva sarassa avidūre ekasmiṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto kuruṅgamigaḥ hutvā araññe  ekassa sarassa avidūre ekasmin gumbe vāsam kappesi tassa iva sarassa avidūre ekasmin
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was a deer, the leader of a herd of deer.🔽He lived in a thicket not far from a certain lake,

original: rukkhagge satapatto, sarasmiṃ pana kacchapo vāsaṃ kappesi. Evaṃ te tayopi sahāyakā
analyzed: rukkha agge sata pattaḥ sarasmim pana kacchapaḥ vāsam kappesi evam te tayo api sahāyakā
translated: and in a tree-top near the lake lived a peacock, while in the lake lived a tortoise. Thus these three were friends.

original: aññamaññaṃ piyasaṃvāsaṃ vasiṃsu. Atheko migaluddako araññe caranto pānīyatitthe bodhisattassa
analyzed: aññam aññam piya saṃvāsam vasiṃsu atha ekaḥ migaluddakaḥ araññe carantaḥ pānīya titthe bodhisattassa
translated: and lived in mutual affection. Then a certain hunter, wandering in the forest, saw the Bodhisatta🔽

original: padavalañjaṃ disvā lohanigaḷasadisaṃ vaṭṭamayaṃ pāsaṃ oḍḍetvā agamāsi. Bodhisatto
analyzed: pada valañjam disvā loha nigaḷa sadisam vaṭṭa mayam pāsam oḍḍetvā agamāsi bodhisatto
translated: and lived in mutual affection. Now a certain hunter, wandering in the forest, saw the Bodhisatta’s footprints at the water-trough, and, setting a snare like a ring of iron, went away. The Bodhisatta,

original: pānīyaṃ pātuṃ āgato paṭhamayāmeyeva pāse bajjhitvā baddharavaṃ ravi. Tassa tena saddena
analyzed: pānīyam pātum āgataḥ paṭhama yāmeya iva pāse bajjhitvā baddha ravam ravi tassa tena saddena
translated: coming to drink water, was caught in the first step by the snare, and gave a cry of distress. At the sound of his cry

original: rukkhaggato satapatto udakato ca kacchapo āgantvā “kiṃ nu kho kātabba”nti mantayiṃsu.
analyzed: rukkha aggataḥ sata pattaḥ udakataḥ ca kacchapaḥ āgantvā kim nu kho kātabbanti mantayiṃsu
translated: the peacock on the tree and the tortoise in the water came to him, and said, “What is to be done?”

original: Atha satapatto kacchapaṃ āmantetvā “samma, tava dantā atthi, tvaṃ imaṃ pāsaṃ chinda,
analyzed: atha satapattaḥ kacchapam āmantetvā samma tava dantāḥ atthi tvam imam pāsam chinda
translated: Then the peacock, addressing the tortoise, said, “My friend, you have teeth; you must bite through this snare;

original: ahaṃ gantvā yathā so nāgacchati, tathā karissāmi, evaṃ amhehi dvīhipi kataparakkamena
analyzed: aham gantvā yathā saḥ na āgacchati tathā karissāmi evam amhehi dvīhi pi kata parakkamena
translated: I will go and do what I can to prevent the hunter coming. Thus by the two of us making a double effort,

original: sahāyo no jīvitaṃ labhissatī”ti imamatthaṃ pakāsento paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sahāyaḥ naḥ jīvitam labhissati iti imam attham pakāsentaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: our friend will recover his life.” And in order to make this clear he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Iṅgha vaṭṭamayaṃ pāsaṃ, chinda dantehi kacchapa;
analyzed: iṅgha vaṭṭa mayam pāsam chinda dantehi kacchapa
translated: “Come, tortoise, with your teeth bite through this snare of twisted string;

original: Ahaṃ tathā karissāmi, yathā nehiti luddako”ti.
analyzed: aham tathā karissāmi yathā luddakā uti
translated: I will do what I can to keep the hunter from coming here.”

original: Atha kacchapo cammavarattaṃ khādituṃ ārabhi, satapatto luddakassa vasanagāmaṃ gato🔽avidūre rukkhe nisīdi. Luddako paccūsakāleyeva sattiṃ gahetvā nikkhami. Sakuṇo tassa🔽nikkhamanabhāvaṃ ñatvā vassitvā pakkhe papphoṭetvā taṃ purimadvārena nikkhamantaṃ
analyzed: atha kacchapaḥ camma varattam khāditum ārabhi sata pattaḥ luddakassa vasana gāmam gataḥ  avidūre rukkhe nisīdi luddako paccūsa kāleya iva sattim gahetvā nikkhami sakuṇaḥ tassa  nikkhamana bhāvam ñatvā vassitvā pakkhe papphoṭetvā tam purima dvārena nikkhamantam
translated: Then the tortoise began to eat the skin of the snake. The peacock went to the village where the hunter lived.🔽He sat down on a tree not far away. The hunter went out at dawn, taking his spear with him. The bird🔽knew that he was going out, and he rained down on the hunter, flapping his wings. He struck the hunter

original: mukhe pahari. Luddo “kāḷakaṇṇinā sakuṇenamhi pahaṭo”ti nivattitvā thokaṃ sayitvā
analyzed: mukhe luddaḥ kāḷakaṇṇinā pahaṭaḥ iti nivattitvā thokam sayitvā
translated: in the face as he was going out through the front door. The hunter thought, “I have been struck by a black-eared bird,” and he turned back. He lay down for a while,

original: puna sattiṃ gahetvā uṭṭhāsi. Sakuṇo “ayaṃ paṭhamaṃ purimadvārena nikkhanto idāni🔽pacchimadvārena nikkhamissatī”ti ñatvā gantvā pacchimagehe nisīdi. Luddopi “purimadvārena🔽me nikkhantena kāḷakaṇṇī sakuṇo diṭṭho, idāni pacchimadvārena nikkhamissāmī”ti pacchimadvārena
analyzed: puna sattim gahetvā uṭṭhāsi sakuṇaḥ ayam paṭhamam purima dvārena nikkhantaḥ idāni  pacchima dvārena nikkhamissati iti ñatvā gantvā pacchima gehe nisīdi luddaḥ api purima dvārena  me nikkhantena kāḷakaṇṇī sakuṇaḥ diṭṭhaḥ idāni pacchima dvārena nikkhamissāmi iti pacchima dvārena
translated: and then he got up, taking his spear with him. The bird thought, “He went out through the front door the first time, but this time🔽he will go out through the back door.” He went and sat down in the back room. The hunter thought, “I saw the black-eared bird🔽go out through the front door, but this time he will go out through the back door.” He went out through the back door,

original: nikkhami, sakuṇo puna vassitvā gantvā mukhe pahari. Luddo “punapi kāḷakaṇṇīsakuṇena
analyzed: nikkhami sakuṇo puna vassitvā gantvā mukhe pahari luddaḥ puna api kāḷakaṇṇī sakuṇena
translated: and the bird rained down on him again. He struck the hunter in the face. The hunter thought, “I have been struck again by the black-eared bird.

original: pahaṭo, na dāni me esa nikkhamituṃ detī”ti nivattitvā yāva aruṇuggamanā sayitvā aruṇuggamanavelāya
analyzed: pahaṭaḥ na dāni me esa nikkhamitum deti iti nivattitvā yāva aruṇuggamanā sayitvā aruṇuggamana velāya
translated: “He has been caught, and now he will not let me out.” So he turned back and lay down until sunrise.

original: sattiṃ gahetvā nikkhami. Sakuṇo vegena gantvā “luddo āgacchatī”ti bodhisattassa kathesi.
analyzed: sattim gahetvā nikkhami sakuṇaḥ vegena gantvā luddaḥ āgacchati iti bodhisattassa kathesi
translated: At the time of sunrise he took his knife and went out. The bird went quickly and told the Bodhisatta that the hunter was coming.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe kacchapena ekameva cammavaddhaṃ ṭhapetvā sesavarattā khāditā honti.
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe kacchapena ekam eva camma vaddham ṭhapetvā khāditāḥ honti
translated: At that moment the tortoise had eaten all the other skins except one.

original: Dantā panassa patanākārappattā jātā, mukhato lohitaṃ paggharati. Bodhisatto luddaputtaṃ🔽sattiṃ gahetvā asanivegena āgacchantaṃ disvā taṃ vaddhaṃ chinditvā vanaṃ pāvisi,
analyzed: dantāḥ panassa patana ākāra ppattāḥ jātāḥ mukhataḥ lohitam paggharati bodhisattaḥ ludda puttam  sattim gahetvā asanivegena āgacchantam disvā tam vaddham chinditvā vanam pāvisi
translated: His teeth had fallen out, and blood was flowing from his mouth. The Bodhisatta saw the hunter’s son coming quickly with his knife in his hand,

original: sakuṇo rukkhagge nisīdi, kacchapo pana dubbalattā tattheva nipajji. Luddo kacchapaṃ
analyzed: sakuṇaḥ rukkhagge nisīdi kacchapo pana dubbala ttā tattha iva nipajji luddaḥ kacchapaṃ
translated: and cutting the skin, he entered the forest. The bird sat down on a branch, but the tortoise, being weak, lay down there. The hunter took the tortoise,

original: gahetvā pasibbake pakkhipitvā ekasmiṃ khāṇuke laggesi. Bodhisatto nivattitvā olokento
analyzed: gahetvā pasibbake pakkhipitvā ekasmin khāṇuke laggesi bodhisattaḥ nivattitvā olokentaḥ
translated: put him in his basket, and hung him on a stick. The Bodhisatta turned back and looked.

original: kacchapassa gahitabhāvaṃ ñatvā “sahāyassa jīvitadānaṃ dassāmī”ti dubbalo viya hutvā
analyzed: kacchapassa gahita bhāvam ñatvā sahāyassa jīvita dānam dassāmi iti dubbalaḥ viya hutvā
translated: Seeing that the tortoise had been caught, he thought, “I will give my friend his life,” and pretending to be weak,

original: luddassa attānaṃ dassesi. So “dubbalo esa bhavissati, māressāmi na”nti sattiṃ ādāya🔽anubandhi. Bodhisatto nātidūre nāccāsanne gacchanto taṃ ādāya araññaṃ pāvisi, dūraṃ
analyzed: luddassa attānam dassesi saḥ dubbalaḥ esa bhavissati māressāmi nanti sattim ādāya  anubandhi bodhisatto na atidūre na acca āsanne gacchantaḥ tam ādāya araññam pāvisi dūram
translated: and showed himself to the hunter. The hunter thought to himself, “He must be weak, I can catch him.” So he took his knife

original: gatabhāvaṃ ñatvā padaṃ vañcetvā aññena maggena vātavegena gantvā siṅgena pasibbakaṃ
analyzed: gata bhāvam ñatvā padam vañcetvā aññena maggena vāta vegena gantvā siṅgena pasibbakam
translated: and followed close behind the deer. The Bodhisatta went neither too far nor too near, and taking the hunter with him, entered the forest. When he knew that they were far enough in, he deceived the hunter as to his tracks, and going by a different path, with the speed of the wind, he caught the peacock with his antlers,

original: ukkhipitvā bhūmiyaṃ pātetvā phāletvā kacchapaṃ nīhari. Satapattopi rukkhā otari.🔽Bodhisatto dvinnampi ovādaṃ dadamāno “ahaṃ tumhe nissāya jīvitaṃ labhiṃ, tumhehi🔽sahāyakassa kattabbaṃ mayhaṃ kataṃ, idāni luddo āgantvā tumhe gaṇheyya, tasmā, samma
analyzed: ukkhipitvā bhūmiyam pātetvā phāletvā kacchapam nīhari sata patto pi rukkhā otari  bodhisattaḥ dvinnam pi ovādam dadamānaḥ aham tumhe nissāya jīvitam tumhehi  sahāyakassa kattabbam mayham katam idāni luddaḥ āgantvā tumhe gaṇheyya tasmai samma
translated: threw him to the ground, and broke his back. Then he drew the tortoise out of his shell. The peacock also came down from the tree.

original: satapatta, tvaṃ attano puttake gahetvā aññattha yāhi, tvampi, samma kacchapa, udakaṃ
analyzed: satapatta tvam attano puttake gahetvā aññattha yāhi tvam pi samma kacchapa udakaṃ
translated: The Bodhisatta, giving advice to both, said, “By you I have obtained my life. You have done for me what a friend should do. Now the hunter will come and catch you. Therefore, my friend, the peacock, you must take your young ones and go elsewhere. And you, my friend, the tortoise, must go into the water.”

original: pavisāhī”ti āha. Te tathā akaṃsu.
analyzed: pavisāhi iti āha te tathā akaṃsu
translated: They did as he advised.

original: Satthā abhisambuddho hutvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: satthā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: When the Teacher had attained enlightenment, he pronounced the second stanza:—

original: “Kacchapo pāvisī vāriṃ, kuruṅgo pāvisī vanaṃ;
analyzed: kacchapaḥ pāvisī vārim kuruṅgaḥ pāvisī vanam
translated: “The tortoise entered the water, the peacock entered the forest,

original: Satapatto dumaggamhā, dūre putte apānayī”ti.
analyzed: sata pattaḥ dūre putte apānayi iti
translated: The peacock, from the top of the tree, brought his young ones far away.”

original: Tattha apānayīti ānayi, gahetvā agamāsīti attho;
analyzed: tattha apānayi iti ānayi gahetvā agamāsi iti attho
translated: Herein, brought his young ones far away means he brought them, he went away taking them with him.

original: Luddopi taṃ ṭhānaṃ āgantvā kañci apassitvā chinnapasibbakaṃ gahetvā domanassappatto attano gehaṃ agamāsi. Te tayopi sahāyā yāvajīvaṃ vissāsaṃ acchinditvā yathākammaṃ gatā.
analyzed: luddaḥ api tam ṭhānam āgantvā kañci a passitvā chinna pasibbakam gahetvā domanassa pattaḥ attanaḥ geham agamāsi te tayo api sahāyāḥ yāvajīvam vissāsam a chinditvā yathākammam gatā
translated: The hunter, coming to that place and seeing no one, took the torn net and in great dejection went to his own home. And these three friends, never breaking their friendship as long as they lived, passed on according to their deeds.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā luddako devadatto ahosi, satapatto sāriputto, kacchapo moggallāno, kuruṅgamigo pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Kuruṅgamigajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.🔽[207] 7. Assakajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā luddakaḥ devadattaḥ ahosi satapatto sāriputto kacchapaḥ moggallānaḥ kuruṅgamigo pana aham eva ahosinti  kuruṅga miga jātaka vaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: When the Master had related this story, he made the connection between the Jātaka and the present occasion, saying, “At that time Devadatta was the hunter, Sāriputta was the peacock, Moggallāna was the tortoise, and I myself was the peacock.”🔽So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,🔽The Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told this story of the past.

original: Ayamassakarājenāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto purāṇadutiyikāpalobhanaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: ayam assaka rājena ati idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ purāṇa dutiyikā apalobhanam ārabbha
translated: The story of the past was as follows. The Master, in this connection, said to the monks,

original: kathesi. So hi bhikkhu satthārā “saccaṃ kira, tvaṃ bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti puṭṭho
analyzed: kathesi saḥ hi bhikkhu satthārā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ
translated: “Yes, Reverend Sir.”🔽“By whom were you made discontented?”

original: “sacca”nti vatvā “kena ukkaṇṭhāpitosī”ti vutte “purāṇadutiyikāyā”ti āha. Atha naṃ
analyzed: saccam iti vatvā kena ukkaṇṭhāpitaḥ asi iti vutte purāṇadutiyikāya iti āha atha naṃ
translated: “By my former wife.”

original: satthā “na idāneva tassā bhikkhu itthiyā tayi sineho atthi, pubbepi tvaṃ taṃ nissāya🔽mahādukkhaṃ patto”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: satthā na idānā iva tassā bhikkhu itthiyā tayi sinehaḥ atthi pubbe pi tvam tam nissāya  mahā dukkham patto ti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: “Not only now, monk, but formerly also you suffered great sorrow on account of that woman.”

original: Atīte kāsiraṭṭhe pāṭalinagare assako nāma rājā rajjaṃ kāresi. Tassa uparī nāma aggamahesī
analyzed: atīte kāsiraṭṭhe pāṭali nagare assakaḥ nāma rājā rajjam kāresi tassa uparī nāma agga mahesī
translated: Once upon a time, monks, in the city of Pāṭali in the realm of Kāsi, a king named Assaka was ruling. His chief queen was named Upārī.

original: piyā ahosi manāpā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā atikkantā mānusavaṇṇaṃ, apattā dibbavaṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: piyā ahosi manāpā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā atikkantā mānusa vaṇṇam a pattā dibba vaṇṇam
translated: She was dear to him and beloved, beautiful, and graceful, surpassing human beauty, but not yet having attained divine beauty.

original: Sā kālamakāsi, tassā kālakiriyāya rājā sokābhibhūto ahosi dukkhī dummano. So tassā
analyzed: sā kālam akāsi tassā kāla kiriyāya rājā soka abhibhūtaḥ ahosi dukkhī dummanaḥ saḥ tassā
translated: She died, and on account of her death the king was overcome with grief, sorrowful and sad. He had her body

original: sarīraṃ doṇiyaṃ nipajjāpetvā telakalalaṃ pakkhipāpetvā heṭṭhāmañce ṭhapāpetvā nirāhāro
analyzed: sarīram doṇiyam nipajjāpetvā tela kalalam pakkhipāpetvā heṭṭhāmañce ṭhapāpetvā nirāhāraḥ
translated: placed in a coffin, had it sealed with wax, had it placed on a couch, and had it set up in a hall. He himself,🔽without eating or drinking,

original: rodamāno paridevamāno nipajji. Mātāpitaro avasesañātakā mittāmaccabrāhmaṇagahapatikādayopi
analyzed: rodamānaḥ paridevamānaḥ nipajji mātā pitaraḥ avasesa ñātakāḥ mittā macca brāhmaṇa gahapatika ādayaḥ api
translated: and he lay down and wept and lamented. His parents, his other relatives, his friends, his acquaintances, the Brahmins and the householders, etc.,

original: “mā soci, mahārāja, aniccā saṅkhārā”tiādīni vadantā saññāpetuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu. Tassa
analyzed: mā soci mahā rāja aniccā saṅkhāra ati ādīni vadantā saññāpetum na asakkhiṃsu tassa
translated: tried to comfort him, saying, “Do not grieve, great king, for all conditioned things are impermanent.” But they were not able to comfort him.🔽While he was lamenting thus, seven days passed. At that time the Bodhisatta,

original: vilapantasseva satta divasā atikkantā. Tadā bodhisatto pañcābhiññaaṭṭhasamāpattilābhī
analyzed: vilapantassa iva satta divasāḥ atikkantā tadā bodhisatto pañca abhiñña aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī
translated: having attained the five super-knowledges and the eight attainments,

original: tāpaso hutvā himavantapadese viharanto ālokaṃ vaḍḍhetvā dibbena cakkhunā jambudīpaṃ
analyzed: tāpasaḥ hutvā himavanta padese viharantaḥ ālokam vaḍḍhetvā dibbena cakkhunā jambudīpam
translated: was living in the Himalayas as a hermit. He increased his radiance, and with his divine eye he looked over the Rose-Apple Island.

original: olokento taṃ rājānaṃ tathā paridevamānaṃ disvā “etassa mayā avassayena bhavitabba”nti
analyzed: olokentaḥ tam rājānam tathā paridevamānam disvā etassa mayā avassayena bhavitabbanti
translated: Seeing the king lamenting in this way, he thought, “I must go and advise him.”

original: iddhānubhāvena ākāse uppatitvā rañño uyyāne otaritvā maṅgalasilāpaṭṭe kañcanapaṭimā viya nisīdi.
analyzed: iddha anubhāvena ākāse uppatitvā raññaḥ uyyāne otaritvā maṅgala silā paṭṭe kañcana paṭimā viya nisīdi
translated: So he rose up into the air by his psychic power, and he descended into the king’s garden and sat down on the auspicious slab of stone like a golden image.

original: Atheko pāṭalinagaravāsī brāhmaṇamāṇavo uyyānaṃ gato bodhisattaṃ disvā vanditvā nisīdi.
analyzed: atha ikaḥ pāṭali nagara vāsī brāhmaṇa māṇavaḥ uyyānam gataḥ bodhisattam disvā vanditvā nisīdi
translated: Then a young Brahmin who lived in Pāṭaliputta went to the garden, and when he saw the Bodhisatta, he worshipped him and sat down.

original: Bodhisatto tena saddhiṃ paṭisanthāraṃ katvā “kiṃ, māṇava, rājā dhammiko”ti pucchi.
analyzed: bodhisatto tena saddhim paṭisanthāram katvā kim māṇava rājā dhammikaḥ iti pucchi
translated: The Bodhisatta exchanged friendly greetings with him and asked, “What is the king like, young Brahmin?”

original: “Āma, bhante, dhammiko rājā, bhariyā panassa kālakatā, so tassā sarīraṃ doṇiyaṃ pakkhipāpetvā
analyzed: āma bhante dhammikaḥ rājā bhariyā panassa kāla katā so tassā sarīram doṇiyam pakkhipāpetvā
translated: “Yes, Reverend Sir, the king is just, but his wife is dead, and he has had her body placed in a coffin

original: vilapamāno nipanno, ajja sattamo divaso, kissa tumhe rājānaṃ evarūpā dukkhā na mocetha,
analyzed: vilapamānaḥ nipannaḥ ajja sattamaḥ divasaḥ kissa tumhe rājānam evarūpāḥ dukkhāḥ na mocetha
translated: and is lying down lamenting. To-day is the seventh day. Why do you not deliver the king from such grief?

original: yuttaṃ nu kho tumhādisesu sīlavantesu saṃvijjamānesu rañño evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ anubhavitu”nti.
analyzed: yuttam nu kho tumhādisesu sīlavantesu saṃvijjamānesu raññaḥ evarūpam dukkham anubhavitun ti
translated: Is it right that the king should suffer such grief while such virtuous men as you are in existence?”

original: “Na kho ahaṃ, māṇava, rājānaṃ jānāmi, sace pana so āgantvā maṃ puccheyya, ahamevassa
analyzed: na kho aham māṇava rājānam jānāmi sace pana saḥ āgantvā mam puccheyya aham eva assa
translated: “I do not know the king, young man, but if he should come and ask me, I would tell him

original: tassā nibbattaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhitvā rañño santikeyeva taṃ kathāpeyya”nti. “Tena hi,
analyzed: tassāḥ nibbatta ṭṭhānam ācikkhitvā rañño santike iya iva tam kathāpeyyanti tena hi
translated: where she has been reborn. I would send him to the king himself.” “Well then, Reverend Sir,

original: bhante, yāva rājānaṃ ānemi, tāva imeva nisīdathā”ti māṇavo bodhisattassa paṭiññaṃ
analyzed: bhante yāva rājānam ānemi tāva ime eva nisīdatha ati māṇavaḥ bodhisattassa paṭiññam
translated: while I go and fetch the king, you must remain here.” The young man, having received the Bodhisatta’s promise,

original: gahetvā rañño santikaṃ gantvā tamatthaṃ ārocetvā “tassa dibbacakkhukassa santikaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā rañño santikam gantvā tam attham ārocetvā tassa dibbacakkhukassa santikam
translated: went to the king and told him the news, saying, “It is fitting that you should go to this man who has the divine eye

original: gantuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti āha.
analyzed: gantum vaṭṭati iti āha
translated: and ask him.”

original: Rājā “upariṃ kira daṭṭhuṃ labhissāmī”ti tuṭṭhamānaso rathaṃ abhiruhitvā tattha gantvā
analyzed: rājā uparim kira daṭṭhum labhissāmi iti tuṭṭha mānasaḥ ratham abhiruhitvā tattha gantvā

analyzed: bodhisattam vanditvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ saccam kira tumhe deviyā nibbatta ṭṭhānam
translated: He saluted the Bodhisatta and sat down on one side, and asked him, “Is it true that you know where the queen was born?

analyzed: jānātha ati pucchi āma mahā rāja ati kattha nibbattā ati sā kho mahā rāja rūpasmiṃyeva

analyzed: na aham saddahāmi iti tena hi te dassetvā kathāpemi iti sādhu kathāpetha ati bodhisatto

original: attano ānubhāvena “ubhopi gomayapiṇḍaṃ vaṭṭayamānā rañño purato āgacchantū”ti tesaṃ

analyzed: āgamanam akāsi te tathā iva āgamiṃsu bodhisatto tam dassento ayam te mahā rāja
translated: They came as he had said. The Bodhisatta, pointing to them, said, “There, great king,

analyzed: uparidevī tam jahitvā gomaya pāṇakassa pacchatas pacchatas gacchati passatha nanti

analyzed: āha bhante uparī nāma gomaya pāṇaka yoniyam nibbattissati iti na saddahāmahanti

analyzed: kathāpemi nam mahā rāja ati kathāpetha bhanta iti

analyzed: bhante iti āha tvam atīta bhave kā nāma ahosi iti bhante assakaraññaḥ aggamahesī
translated: Reverend Sir?” “In a previous existence, what was your name?” “Reverend Sir, I was the chief queen of the King of the Assakas,

original: uparī nāma ahosi”nti. “Kiṃ pana te idāni assakarājā piyo, udāhu gomayapāṇako”ti?
analyzed: upari nāma ahosinti kim pana te idāni assaka rājā piyaḥ udāhu gomaya pāṇakaḥ ti

analyzed: bhante saḥ mayham purima jātiyā sāmiko tadā aham imasmin uyyāne tena saddhim rūpa sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabbe

analyzed: anubhavamānā vicarim idāni pana me bhava saṅkhepa gata kālataḥ paṭṭhāya saḥ kim hoti

analyzed: aham hi idāni assaka rājānam māretvā tassa gala lohitena mayham sāmikassa gomaya pāṇakassa

analyzed: pāde makkheyyanti vatvā parisamajjhe manussa bhāsāya imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca

translated: Herein, this delightful park was enjoyed by me with the King of Assaka means that this delightful park was enjoyed by me

analyzed: assaka rājena saddhim vicaritaḥ anukāmaya kāmena ati nipāta mattam mayā tam kāmayamānāya
translated: with the King of Assaka in the past. Out of love means out of love for him;

translated: with him who loved me means the meaning is: with him who loved me in that existence. Dear means dear in that existence. With new happiness and sorrow

analyzed: porāṇam apidhīyati iti bhante navena hi sukhena porāṇam sukham navena ca dukkhena

analyzed: porāṇam dukkham pidhīyati paṭicchādīyati esā lokassa dhamma tā ati dīpeti tasmai assa karaññā ava
translated: the old sorrow is covered over, concealed, this is the way of the world, is what is shown. Therefore the insect is dearer to me than the King of Assaka.

analyzed: kīṭaḥ piyataraḥ mama ati yasmai navena porāṇam pidhīyati tasmai mama sataguṇena

translated: a thousand times dearer to me than you, O king of horses.”

analyzed: tam sutvā assaka rājā vippaṭisārī hutvā tattha ṭhitaḥ uva kuṇapam nīharāpetvā sīsam nhatvā
translated: Hearing this, the king of horses was filled with remorse. Standing there, he had the corpse removed, washed his head,

original: Bodhisattopi rājānaṃ ovaditvā nissokaṃ katvā himavantameva agamāsi.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne🔽ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā uparī purāṇadutiyikā ahosi, assakarājā
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ api rājānam ovaditvā nissokam katvā himavantam eva agamāsi  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne  ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā uparī purāṇadutiyikā ahosi assaka rājā
translated: The Bodhisatta, having instructed the king and made him free from grief, went to the Himalayas.

analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitaḥ bhikkhu māṇavaḥ sāriputto tāpasaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  assaka jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā
translated: The Teacher, having related this dhamma talk, having revealed the Truths, identified the Birth Story: “At that time the old second wife was the present discontented nun, the king of horses was the discontented monk, the young man was Sāriputta, but I myself was the ascetic.”🔽The commentary on the Assaka Jātaka is finished.

original: [208] 8. Susumārajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Susumāra Jātaka is finished.

original: Alaṃ metehi ambehīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto devadattassa vadhāya parisakkanaṃ🔽ārabbha kathesi. Tadā hi satthā “devadatto vadhāya parisakkatī”ti sutvā “na, bhikkhave,🔽idāneva devadatto mayhaṃ vadhāya parisakkati, pubbepi parisakkiyeva, santāsamattampi
analyzed: alam mā itehi ambehi iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ devadattassa vadhāya parisakkanam  ārabbha kathesi tadā hi satthā devadattaḥ vadhāya parisakkati iti sutvā na bhikkhave  idānā iva devadattaḥ mayham vadhāya parisakkati pubbe pi parisakkiyā iva santāsa mattam pi
translated: “What need have I of these mangoes?” This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning Devadatta’s attempt to kill him. original: pana kātuṃ na sakkhī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: pana kātum na sakkhi iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: “I have enough of these mangoes.” This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning Devadatta’s attempt to kill him. For when the Master heard that Devadatta was trying to kill him, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time Devadatta has tried to kill me; in a previous state of existence also he tried to kill me, but was unable to do so.” So saying, he related a story of the past.

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente himavanta padese bodhisatto kapi yoniyam
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was born in the monkey tribe in the Himalayas.

analyzed: araññāyatane vāsam kappesi tadā gaṅgāya ekaḥ susumāraḥ vasi athassa bhariyā bodhisattassa

analyzed: sarīram disvā tassa hadaya maṃse dohaḷam uppādetvā susumāram āha aham sāmi etassa
translated: So she said to her husband, “My dear, I have a longing for the heart of that monkey.”

analyzed: kapi rājassa hadaya maṃsam khāditu kāmā ati bhadde mayam jala gocarā eso thala gocaro
translated: “I am desirous of eating the heart of the king of the monkeys.” “My dear, we live in the water, he lives on land.

original: kinti naṃ gaṇhituṃ sakkhissāmā”ti. “Yena kenaci upāyena gaṇha, sace na labhissāmi,
analyzed: kinti nam gaṇhitum sakkhissāma ati yena kenacid upāyena gaṇha sace na labhissāmi
translated: How can we get him?” “Get him by some means or other. If I cannot get🔽him, I shall die.” “Then do not grieve. There is a way. I will make him eat

original: marissāmī”ti. “Tena hi mā soci, attheko upāyo, khādāpessāmi taṃ tassa hadayamaṃsa”nti
analyzed: marissāmi iti tena hi mā soci attha ekaḥ upāyaḥ khādāpessāmi tam tassa hadaya maṃsanti
translated: your child, and then I will get his heart for you.”

original: susumāriṃ samassāsetvā bodhisattassa gaṅgāya pānīyaṃ pivitvā gaṅgātīre nisinnakāle
analyzed: susumārim samassāsetvā bodhisattassa gaṅgāya pānīyam pivitvā gaṅgā tīre nisinna kāle
translated: She comforted her, and when the Bodhisatta had drunk water in the Ganges and was sitting on the bank,

analyzed: santikam gantvā evam āha vānara indo imasmin padese kasāya phalāni khādantaḥ kim tvam
translated: she went to him and said, “King of the monkeys, while you are eating the ripe fruit in this place,

analyzed: carasi pāragaṅgāya ambala buja ādīnam madhura phalānam antaḥ natthi
translated: why do you range only in the place where you are? There are sweet fruits on the other side of the Ganges, such as mangoes, bread-fruit, and so on.

original: kiṃ te tattha gantvā phalāphalaṃ khādituṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti? “Kumbhīlarāja, gaṅgā mahodakā
analyzed: kim te tattha gantvā phala aphalam khāditum na vaṭṭati iti kumbhīla rāja gaṅgā mahā udakā
translated: Why should you not go there and eat the various fruits?” “King of the tortoises, the Ganges is a great river,

analyzed: vitthiṇṇā katham tattha gamissāmi iti sace icchasi aham tam mama piṭṭhim āropetvā
translated: wide and deep. How can I get there?” “If you wish, I will carry you on my back,🔽and

analyzed: nessāmi iti saḥ saddahitvā sādhu uti sampaṭicchi tena hi ehi piṭṭhim me abhirūha ati
translated: I will give it to you.” The other consented, saying, “Very well.” “Then come,” said the crocodile, “and mount on my back.”

original: ca vutte taṃ abhiruhi. Susumāro thokaṃ netvā udake osīdāpesi.🔽Bodhisatto “samma, udake maṃ osīdāpesi, kiṃ nu kho eta”nti āha. “Nāhaṃ taṃ dhammasudhammatāya
analyzed: ca vutte tam abhiruhi susumāraḥ thokam netvā udake osīdāpesi  bodhisatto samma udake mam osīdāpesi kim nu kho etat ti āha na aham tam dhamma su dhamma tāya
translated: So the monkey mounted on the crocodile’s back, and the crocodile carried him a little way and then plunged into the water and sank.

original: gahetvā gacchāmi, bhariyāya pana me tava hadayamaṃse dohaḷo uppanno, tamahaṃ tava🔽hadayaṃ khādāpetukāmo”ti. “Samma, kathentena te sundaraṃ kataṃ. Sace hi amhākaṃ udare
analyzed: gahetvā gacchāmi bhariyāya pana me tava hadaya maṃse dohaḷaḥ uppannaḥ tam aham tava  hadayam samma kathentena te sundaram katam sace hi amhākam udare
translated: The monkey said, “My friend, why do you sink?” “I do not carry you off because I am a lover of righteousness. But my wife is in a state of pregnancy, and she has a craving for your heart. I am taking you to her that she may eat your heart.”

original: hadayaṃ bhaveyya, sākhaggesu carantānaṃ cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ bhaveyyā”ti. “Kahaṃ pana tumhe🔽ṭhapethā”ti? Bodhisatto avidūre ekaṃ udumbaraṃ pakkaphalapiṇḍisañchannaṃ dassento
analyzed: hadayam bhaveyya sākhaggesu carantānam cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam bhaveyya ati kaham pana tumhe  ṭhapetha iti bodhisattaḥ avidūre ekam udumbaram pakka phala piṇḍi sañchannam dassento
translated: “My friend, you have done well to tell me. If we monkeys had hearts, they would be crushed to bits as we swing from branch to branch.” “But where do you keep your hearts?”

original: “passetāni amhākaṃ hadayāni etasmiṃ udumbare olambantī”ti āha. “Sace me hadayaṃ dassasi,
analyzed: passa itāni amhākam hadayāni etasmin udumbare olambanti iti āha sace me hadayam dassasi
translated: The monkey pointed to a fig tree not far away, saying, “Look at our hearts hanging on that fig tree.” “If you will show me your heart,

analyzed: aham tam na māressāmi iti tena hi mam ettha nehi aham te rukkhe olambantam dassāmi iti
translated: “I will not kill him.” “Well then, take me there, and I will show you how to hang him from a tree.”

original: So taṃ ādāya tattha agamāsi. Bodhisatto tassa piṭṭhito uppatitvā udumbararukkhe nisīditvā
analyzed: saḥ tam ādāya tattha agamāsi bodhisatto tassa piṭṭhitaḥ uppatitvā udumbara rukkhe nisīditvā
translated: So the crocodile took the monkey there, and the Bodhisatta flew up from behind him, and sat down in the udumbara tree.

original: “samma, bāla susumāra, ‘imesaṃ sattānaṃ hadayaṃ nāma rukkhagge hotī’ti saññī ahosi,
analyzed: samma bāla susumāra imesam sattānam hadayam nāma rukkhagge hoti iti saññī ahosi
translated: “You fool, you silly crocodile, you thought that the heart of all animals was in the tree-top.

original: bālosi, ahaṃ taṃ vañcesiṃ, tava phalāphalaṃ taveva hotu, sarīrameva pana te mahantaṃ
analyzed: aham tam tava phala aphalam tava iva sarīram eva te mahantam
translated: You are a fool, and I have deceived you. Let the fruit be yours, but your body is mine.

original: paññā pana natthī”ti vatvā imamatthaṃ pakāsento imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: paññā pana natthi iti vatvā imam attham pakāsentaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: You have no sense.” So saying, he expounded the Law by pronouncing the following Stanzas,

original: “Alaṃ metehi ambehi, jambūhi panasehi ca;
analyzed: alam metehi ambehi jambūhi panasehi ca
translated: “Enough of these mangoes, of these rose-apples and bread-fruit;

original: Yāni pāraṃ samuddassa, varaṃ mayhaṃ udumbaro.
analyzed: yāni pāram samuddassa varam mayham udumbaraḥ
translated: Better for me is the udumbara tree, which is beyond the sea.

original: “Mahatī vata te bondi, na ca paññā tadūpikā;
analyzed: mahatī vata te bondi na ca paññā tad dūpikā
translated: “Great is your body, but your sense is not equal to it;

original: Susumāra vañcito mesi, gaccha dāni yathāsukha”nti.
analyzed: susumāra vañcitaḥ mā isi gaccha dāni
translated: You are deceived, O crocodile, go now as you came.”

original: Tattha alaṃ metehīti yāni tayā dīpake niddiṭṭhāni, etehi mayhaṃ alaṃ. Varaṃ mayhaṃ
analyzed: tattha alam mā itehi iti yāni tayā dīpake niddiṭṭhāni etehi mayham alam varam mayham
