original: caritvā jīvikaṃ kappesi. Tadā kāsiraṭṭhe ekasmiṃ gāmake ekassa brāhmaṇassa brāhmaṇī
analyzed: caritvā jīvikam kappesi tadā kāsiraṭṭhe ekasmin gāmake ekassa brāhmaṇassa brāhmaṇī
translated: and so earned his living. At that time in a certain village in the kingdom of Kāsī, a brāhmaṇa’s wife,

original: dussīlā pāpadhammā aticāraṃ carati. Athekadivasaṃ brāhmaṇe kenacideva karaṇīyena
analyzed: dussīlā pāpa dhammā aticāram carati atha eka divasam brāhmaṇe kenacid eva karaṇīyena
translated: who was unchaste and wicked, was committing adultery. One day when the brāhmaṇa had gone out on some business,

original: bahi gate tassā jāro taṃ khaṇaṃ oloketvā taṃ gehaṃ pāvisi. Sā tena saddhiṃ aticaritvā
analyzed: bahi gate tassāḥ jāraḥ tam khaṇam oloketvā tam geham pāvisi sā tena saddhim aticaritvā
translated: her lover, seeing his opportunity, entered the house. She committed adultery with him,

original: “muhuttaṃ accha, bhuñjitvāva gamissasī”ti bhattaṃ sampādetvā sūpabyañjanasampannaṃ
analyzed: muhuttam accha bhuñjitvā ava gamissasi iti bhattam sampādetvā su upabyañjana sampannam
translated: and said, “Wait a moment, you shall eat and then go.” She prepared a meal, with curry and condiments,

original: uṇhabhattaṃ vaḍḍhetvā “tvaṃ bhuñjā”ti tassa datvā sayaṃ brāhmaṇassa āgamanaṃ olokayamānā
analyzed: uṇha bhattam vaḍḍhetvā tvam bhuñjāti tassa da tvā sayam brāhmaṇassa āgamanam olokayamānā
translated: She heated up the food, and gave it to him to eat, saying, “Eat this.” Then she stood at the door, watching for the return of the Brahman.

original: dvāre aṭṭhāsi. Bodhisatto brāhmaṇiyā jārassa bhuñjanaṭṭhāne piṇḍaṃ paccāsīsanto aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: dvāre aṭṭhāsi bodhisattaḥ brāhmaṇiyāḥ jārassa bhuñjana ṭṭhāne piṇḍam paccāsīsantaḥ aṭṭhāsi
translated: The Bodhisattvas stood in the place where the Brahman’s paramour was to eat, waiting for the food.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe brāhmaṇo gehābhimukho āgacchati. Brāhmaṇī taṃ āgacchantaṃ disvā vegena
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe brāhmaṇaḥ geha abhimukhaḥ āgacchati brāhmaṇī tam āgacchantam disvā vegena
translated: At that moment the Brahman came home. The Brahman’s wife saw him coming, and quickly

original: pavisitvā “uṭṭhehi, brāhmaṇo āgacchatī”ti jāraṃ koṭṭhe otāretvā brāhmaṇassa pavisitvā
analyzed: pavisitvā uṭṭhehi brāhmaṇaḥ āgacchati iti jāram koṭṭhe otāretvā brāhmaṇassa pavisitvā
translated: went out, saying, “Rise up, the Brahman is coming.” She drew the paramour into the stable, and when the Brahman had entered the house and sat down,

original: nisinnakāle phalakaṃ upanetvā hatthadhovanaṃ datvā itarena bhuttāvasiṭṭhassa sītabhattassa
analyzed: nisinna kāle phalakam upanetvā hattha dhovanam da tvā itarena bhutta avasiṭṭhassa sītabhattassa
translated: she brought him a bench and gave him water to wash his hands. Then she heated up the food that had been left over from the other meal,

original: upari uṇhabhattaṃ vaḍḍhetvā brāhmaṇassa adāsi. So bhatte hatthaṃ otāretvā upari uṇhaṃ🔽heṭṭhā ca bhattaṃ sītalaṃ disvā cintesi – “iminā aññassa bhuttādhikena ucchiṭṭhabhattena
analyzed: upari uṇha bhattam vaḍḍhetvā brāhmaṇassa adāsi saḥ bhatte hattham otāretvā upari uṇham  heṭṭhā ca bhattam sītalam disvā cintesi iminā aññassa bhutta adhikena ucchiṭṭha bhattena
translated: and gave it to the Brahman. He put his hand into the food, and when he found that the top was hot and the bottom cold,

original: bhavitabba”nti. So brāhmaṇiṃ pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: bhavitabbanti saḥ brāhmaṇim pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: he thought to himself, “This must be the leavings of another’s meal.” He asked the Brahman’s wife, and in reply she recited the first stanza:

original: “Añño uparimo vaṇṇo, añño vaṇṇo ca heṭṭhimo;
analyzed: aññaḥ uparimaḥ vaṇṇaḥ aññaḥ vaṇṇaḥ ca heṭṭhimaḥ
translated: The lower part is another;

original: Brāhmaṇī tveva pucchāmi, kiṃ heṭṭhā kiñca upparī”ti.🔽Tattha vaṇṇoti ākāro. Ayañhi uparimassa uṇhabhāvaṃ heṭṭhimassa ca sītabhāvaṃ pucchanto
analyzed: brāhmaṇī tu eva pucchāmi kim heṭṭhā kiñca uppari iti  tattha vaṇṇo ti ākāraḥ ayam hi uparimassa uṇha bhāvam heṭṭhimassa ca sīta bhāvam pucchanto
translated: I ask you, Brahman lady, what is below, and what is above?”🔽Herein, colour is appearance. For he said this, asking whether the upper part was hot and the lower part was cold.

original: evamāha. Kiṃ heṭṭhā kiñca upparīti vuḍḍhitabhattena nāma upari sītalena, heṭṭhā uṇhena🔽bhavitabbaṃ, idañca pana na tādisaṃ, tena taṃ pucchāmi – “kena kāraṇena upari bhattaṃ
analyzed: evam āha kim heṭṭhā kiñca uppari iti vuḍḍhita bhattena nāma upari sītalena heṭṭhā uṇhena  bhavitabbam idam ca pana na tādisam tena tam pucchāmi kena kāraṇena upari bhattam
translated: What is below, and what is above? The food that is cooked must be cold above and hot below,

original: uṇhaṃ, heṭṭhimaṃ sītala”nti.
analyzed: uṇham heṭṭhimam sītalanti
translated: but this is not like that, so I ask you, ‘For what reason is the food hot above and cold below?’”

original: Brāhmaṇī attanā katakammassa uttānabhāvabhayena brāhmaṇe punappunaṃ kathentepi tuṇhīyeva🔽ahosi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe naṭaputtassa etadahosi – “koṭṭhe nisīdāpitapāpapurisena jārena
analyzed: brāhmaṇī attanā kata kammassa uttāna bhāva bhayena brāhmaṇe punappunam kathente pi tuṇhīya iva  ahosi tasmin khaṇe naṭa puttassa etat ahosi koṭṭhe nisīdāpita pāpa purisena jārena
translated: The Brahman lady, being afraid of revealing the matter she had done, remained silent🔽though the Brahman kept on asking her again and again. At that moment the thought occurred to the son of the actor: “This must be a man of sin whom my master has had put in the cellar,

original: bhavitabbaṃ, iminā gehassāmikena, brāhmaṇī pana attanā katakammassa pākaṭabhāvabhayena
analyzed: bhavitabbam iminā geha sāmikena brāhmaṇī pana attanā kata kammassa pākaṭa bhāva bhayena
translated: but the Brahman lady, being afraid of revealing the matter she has done,

original: kiñci na katheti, handāhaṃ imissā katakammaṃ pakāsetvā jārassa koṭṭhake nisīdāpitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: kiñci na kathā iti handa aham imissā kata kammam pakāsetvā jārassa koṭṭhake nisīdāpita bhāvam
translated: “She does not say anything. Well, I will reveal her secret and tell the brahmin how she had her lover sit in the house.”

original: brāhmaṇassa kathemī”ti. So brāhmaṇassa gehā nikkhantakālato paṭṭhāya itarassa gehapavesanaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇassa kathemi iti saḥ brāhmaṇassa gehā nikkhanta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya itarassa geha pavesanaṃ
translated: From the time the brahmin left his house until the time the other man entered the house,

original: aticaraṇaṃ aggabhattabhuñjanaṃ brāhmaṇiyā dvāre ṭhatvā maggaṃ olokanaṃ itarassa koṭṭhe
analyzed: aticaraṇam aggabhatta bhuñjanam brāhmaṇiyāḥ dvāre ṭhatvā maggam olokanam itarassa koṭṭhe
translated: from the time of the adultery until the time of eating the best food, from the time the brahmin’s wife stood at the door and looked at the road until the time the other man was lowered into the house,

original: otāritabhāvanti sabbaṃ taṃ pavattiṃ ācikkhitvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: otārita bhāvanti sabbam tam pavattim ācikkhitvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: he told the brahmin all that had happened and spoke the second verse:

original: “Ahaṃ naṭosmi bhaddante, bhikkhakosmi idhāgato;
analyzed: aham naṭaḥ asmi bhaddante bhikkhakaḥ asmi idha āgataḥ
translated: “I am an actor, good sir, a beggar who has come here.

original: Ayañhi koṭṭhamotiṇṇo, ayaṃ so yaṃ gavesasī”ti.
analyzed: ayam hi koṭṭha motiṇṇaḥ ayam saḥ yam gavesasi iti
translated: This one has entered the house; he is the one you seek.”

original: Tattha ahaṃ naṭosmi, bhaddanteti, sāmi, ahaṃ naṭajātiko. Bhikkhakosmi idhāgatoti
analyzed: tattha aham naṭaḥ asmi bhaddanta iti sāmi aham naṭa jātikaḥ bhikkhakaḥ asmi idha āgataḥ ti
translated: There, I am an actor, good sir: I am of the actor caste. A beggar who has come here:

original: svāhaṃ imaṃ ṭhānaṃ bhikkhako bhikkhaṃ pariyesamāno āgatosmi. Ayañhi koṭṭhamotiṇṇoti
analyzed: svāham imam ṭhānam bhikkhakaḥ bhikkham pariyesamānaḥ āgataḥ asmi ayam hi koṭṭha motiṇṇaḥ ti
translated: I have come to this place as a beggar seeking alms. This one has entered the house:

original: ayaṃ pana etissā jāro imaṃ bhattaṃ bhuñjanto tava bhayena koṭṭhaṃ otiṇṇo. Ayaṃ so
analyzed: ayam pana etissā jāraḥ imam bhattam bhuñjanto tava bhayena koṭṭham otiṇṇaḥ ayam so
translated: but this lover of hers, while eating the food, has entered the house out of fear of you. He is the one you seek.

original: yaṃ gavesasīti yaṃ tvaṃ kassa nu kho iminā ucchiṭṭhakena bhavitabbanti gavesasi,
analyzed: yam gavesasi iti yam tvam kassa nu kho iminā ucchiṭṭhakena bhavitabbanti gavesasi
translated: “What is it that you are seeking?” means “What is it that you are seeking, thinking, ‘To whom can this refuse belong?’”

original: ayaṃ so. Cūḷāya naṃ gahetvā koṭṭhā nīharitvā yathā na punevarūpaṃ pāpaṃ karoti, tathā🔽assa satiṃ janehīti vatvā pakkāmi. Brāhmaṇo ubhopi te yathā naṃ na punevarūpaṃ pāpaṃ
analyzed: ayam saḥ gahetvā koṭṭhā nīharitvā yathā na punar īvarūpam pāpam karoti tathā  assa satim janehi iti vatvā brāhmaṇaḥ ubhau api te yathā nam na punar īvarūpam pāpam
translated: “Here it is.” Take her by the hand, lead her out of the house, and make her remember her duty so that she will not commit such a sin again.

original: karonti, tajjanapothanehi tathā sikkhāpetvā yathākammaṃ gato.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: karonti tad jana pothanehi tathā sikkhāpetvā yathākammam gataḥ  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: Thus speak and depart.” The Brahman, in order that she might not commit such a sin again, instructed her in the precepts of the Law, and then departed.

original: ukkaṇṭhito bhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā brāhmaṇī purāṇadutiyikā ahosi,
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitaḥ bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā brāhmaṇī purāṇa dutiyikā ahosi
translated: The Teacher related this story, explained the Law, and identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the Brahman’s wife was the former wife of the Brahman,

original: brāhmaṇo ukkaṇṭhito bhikkhu, naṭaputto pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Ucchiṭṭhabhattajātakavaṇṇanā dutiyā.
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ ukkaṇṭhitaḥ bhikkhu naṭa putto pana aham eva ahosinti  ucchiṭṭha bhatta jātaka vaṇṇanā dutiyā
translated: the Brahman was the monk who was dissatisfied, and I myself was the actor.”🔽The Story of the Refused Food.

original: [213] 3. Bharujātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Younger Brother.

original: Isīnamantaraṃ katvāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kosalarājānaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Bhagavato hi bhikkhusaṅghassa ca lābhasakkāro mahā ahosi. Yathāha –
analyzed: isīnam antaram katvā iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ kosala rājānam ārabbha kathesi bhagavataḥ hi bhikkhu saṅghassa ca lābha sakkāraḥ mahā ahosi yathā āha
translated: Having made a space between the seers, the Teacher, while dwelling in Jetavana, related this story concerning the King of Kosala. The Blessed One and the Order of Monks were greatly honored with gifts and reverential treatment, as is related in the following words:

original: “Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito lābhī🔽cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ. Bhikkhusaṅghopi kho sakkato
analyzed: tena khaḥ pana samayena bhagavā sakkataḥ hoti garukataḥ mānitaḥ pūjitaḥ apacitaḥ lābhī  cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārānam bhikkhu saṅghaḥ api kho sakkataḥ
translated: “Now at that time the Blessed One was honored, revered, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated, and he obtained the requisites of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines for the sick.

original: hoti…pe… parikkhārānaṃ. Aññatitthiyā pana paribbājakā asakkatā honti…pe… parikkhārāna”nti.🔽Te evaṃ parihīnalābhasakkārā ahorattaṃ guḷhasannipātaṃ katvā mantayanti “samaṇassa
analyzed: hoti pe parikkhārānaṃ añña titthiyāḥ pana paribbājakāḥ asakkatāḥ honti pe parikkhārānaṃ  te evam parihīna lābha sakkārāḥ ahorattam guḷha sannipātam katvā mantayanti samaṇassa
translated: The Order of Monks also was honored, revered, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated, and it obtained the requisites of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines for the sick. But the ascetics of other sects were not honored, revered, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated, and they did not obtain the requisites of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines for the sick.”

original: gotamassa uppannakālato paṭṭhāya mayaṃ hatalābhasakkārā jātā, samaṇo gotamo lābhaggayasaggappatto
analyzed: gotamassa uppanna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya mayam hata lābha sakkārā jātā samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ lābha ggaya sagga ppatto
translated: These ascetics of other sects, having lost the gifts and the honor, held a secret meeting day and night and discussed the matter, saying, “Ever since the time of the appearance of the monk Gotama, we have lost our gifts and our honor. The monk Gotama has obtained the highest gifts and honor.

original: jāto, kena nu kho kāraṇenassa esā sampattī”ti. Tatreke evamāhaṃsu – “samaṇo gotamo
analyzed: jātaḥ kena nu khalu kāraṇena assa esā sampatti iti tatra eke evam āhaṃsu samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ
translated: For what reason has he obtained this distinction?” Some of them said, “The monk Gotama is possessed of the thirty-two marks of a Great Man.

original: sakalajambudīpassa uttamaṭṭhāne bhūmisīse vasati. Tenassa lābhasakkāro uppajjatī”ti,
analyzed: sakala jambudīpassa uttama ṭṭhāne bhūmi sīse vasati tena assa lābha sakkāro uppajjati iti
translated: He lives in the most excellent place in all of India, on the top of the earth. That is why he gets so much gain and honour.”

original: sesā “atthetaṃ kāraṇaṃ, mayampi jetavanapiṭṭhe titthiyārāmaṃ kāremu, evaṃ lābhino🔽bhavissāmā”ti āhaṃsu. Te sabbepi “evameta”nti sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā “sacepi mayaṃ rañño🔽anārocetvā ārāmaṃ kāressāma, bhikkhū vāressanti, lañjaṃ labhitvā abhijjanako nāma
analyzed: sesāḥ kāraṇam mayam pi jetavana piṭṭhe titthiya ārāmam kāremu evam lābhinaḥ  bhavissāma ati āhaṃsu te sabbe api evam etat ti sanniṭṭhānam katvā sace pi mayam rañño  an ārocetvā ārāmam kāressāma bhikkhū vāressanti lañjam labhitvā abhijjanakaḥ nāma
translated: The others said, “There is a reason for that. We too will build a monastery for the sectarians on the outskirts of Jeta’s Wood. In that way we will get gain and honour.”

original: natthi, tasmā rañño lañjaṃ datvā ārāmaṭṭhānaṃ gaṇhissāmā”ti sammantetvā upaṭṭhāke🔽yācitvā rañño satasahassaṃ datvā “mahārāja, mayaṃ jetavanapiṭṭhiyaṃ titthiyārāmaṃ
analyzed: na atthi tasmai raññaḥ lañjam datvā ārāmaṭṭhānam gaṇhissāma ati sammantetvā upaṭṭhāke  yācitvā rañño sata sahassam da tvā mahā rāja mayam jetavana piṭṭhiyam titthiya ārāmam
translated: They all agreed, saying, “That’s right.” And they made a plan: “Even if we build a monastery without informing the king, the monks will object. There is no one who can get away with bribery. So we will give the king a bribe and get a site for our monastery.”

original: karissāma, sace bhikkhū ‘kātuṃ na dassāmā’ti tumhākaṃ ārocenti, nesaṃ paṭivacanaṃ
analyzed: karissāma sace bhikkhū kātum na dassāma ati tumhākam ārocenti na īsam paṭivacanam
translated: They asked for and received a bribe of a hundred thousand from the king, saying, “Great king, we will build a monastery for the sectarians on the outskirts of Jeta’s Wood. If the monks inform you, saying, ‘We won’t allow it,’ you must not give them an answer.”

original: na dātabba”nti āhaṃsu. Rājā lañjalobhena “sādhū”ti sampaṭicchi.
analyzed: na dātabbanti āhaṃsu rājā lañja lobhena sādhu iti sampaṭicchi
translated: The king agreed out of greed for the bribe.

original: Titthiyā rājānaṃ saṅgaṇhitvā vaḍḍhakiṃ pakkosāpetvā kammaṃ paṭṭhapesuṃ, mahāsaddo
analyzed: titthiyāḥ rājānam saṅgaṇhitvā vaḍḍhakim pakkosāpetvā kammam paṭṭhapesum mahā saddaḥ
translated: The sectarians, having gained the king’s favor, summoned the builder and set him to work. There was a great noise.

original: ahosi. Satthā “ke panete, ānanda, uccāsaddamahāsaddā”ti pucchi. “Aññatitthiyā, bhante,
analyzed: ahosi satthā ke pana ete ānanda uccāsadda mahāsaddā ti pucchi añña titthiyāḥ bhante
translated: The Teacher asked, “Ānanda, what is that great noise?” “Reverend Sir,

original: jetavanapiṭṭhiyaṃ titthiyārāmaṃ kārenti, tattheso saddo”ti. “Ānanda, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: jetavana piṭṭhiyam titthiya ārāmam kārenti tattha iso saddo ti ānanda na etam ṭhānam
translated: the sectarians are building a monastery for the sectarians on the slope of Jetavana. That is the noise.” “Ānanda, that is not a suitable place

original: titthiyārāmassa anucchavikaṃ, titthiyā uccāsaddakāmā, na sakkā tehi saddhiṃ vasitu”nti🔽vatvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātetvā “gacchatha, bhikkhave, rañño ācikkhitvā titthiyārāmakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: titthiya ārāmassa anucchavikam titthiyāḥ uccāsadda kāmāḥ na sakkā tehi saddhim vasitunti  vatvā bhikkhu saṅgham sannipātetvā gacchatha bhikkhave raññaḥ ācikkhitvā titthiya ārāma karaṇam
translated: for a monastery for the sectarians. The sectarians like noise; it is not possible to live with them.”🔽Having so said, he assembled the Order of monks and said, “Go, monks, and after informing the king,

original: nivārethā”ti āha. Bhikkhusaṅgho gantvā rañño nivesanadvāre aṭṭhāsi. Rājā saṅghassa🔽āgatabhāvaṃ sutvāpi “titthiyārāmaṃ nissāya āgatā bhavissantī”ti lañjassa gahitattā
analyzed: nivāretha iti āha bhikkhu saṅghaḥ gantvā raññaḥ nivesana dvāre aṭṭhāsi rājā saṅghassa  āgata bhāvam sutvā api titthiya ārāmam nissāya āgatāḥ bhavissanti iti lañjassa gahita ttā
translated: cause him to forbid the building of a monastery for the sectarians.” The Order of monks went and stood at the door of the king’s palace. The king,🔽although he heard that the Order of monks had come, said, “The king is not at home,” because he had taken a bribe.

original: “rājā gehe natthī”ti vadāpesi. Bhikkhū gantvā satthu ārocesuṃ. Satthā “lañjaṃ nissāya
analyzed: rājā gehe natthi iti vadāpesi bhikkhū gantvā satthu ārocesuṃ satthā lañjam nissāya
translated: The monks went and informed the Teacher. The Teacher said, “Because of a bribe

original: evaṃ karotī”ti dve aggasāvake pesesi. Rājā tesampi āgatabhāvaṃ sutvā tatheva vadāpesi.
analyzed: evam karoti iti dve aggasāvake pesesi rājā tesam pi āgata bhāvam sutvā tathā iva vadāpesi
translated: “He is doing so.” The king heard that the two chief disciples had come, and he sent for them in the same way.

translated: write it on a leaf, have the crow’s flesh cooked, wrap the leaf and the flesh in a white cloth,

original: rājamuddikāya lañchetvā pesessāmi. Yadi paṇḍito bhavissati, paṇṇaṃ vācetvā kākamaṃsabhāvaṃ
analyzed: rājamuddikāya lañchetvā pesessāmi yadi paṇḍitaḥ bhavissati paṇṇam vācetvā kāka maṃsa bhāvam
translated: seal it with the royal seal, and send it. If he is wise, he will read the leaf, understand that it is crow’s flesh,

original: ñatvā āgamissati, no ce, nāgamissatī”ti “puṇṇaṃ nadi”nti imaṃ gāthaṃ paṇṇe likhi –
analyzed: ñatvā āgamissati no ce na āgamissati iti puṇṇam nadinti imam gātham paṇṇe
translated: and come. If not, he will not come.” He wrote the verse “The river is full” on the leaf:

original: “Puṇṇaṃ nadiṃ yena ca peyyamāhu, jātaṃ yavaṃ yena ca guyhamāhu;
analyzed: puṇṇam nadim yena ca peyyam āhu jātam yavam yena ca guyham āhu
translated: “The river is full, by which they say ‘crow’s drink’; the barley is born, by which they say ‘secret’;

original: Dūraṃ gataṃ yena ca avhayanti, so tyāgato handa ca bhuñja brāhmaṇā”ti.🔽Tattha puṇṇaṃ nadiṃ yena ca peyyamāhūti kākapeyyā nadīhi vadantā yena puṇṇaṃ nadiṃ
analyzed: dūram gatam yena ca avhayanti saḥ tya āgataḥ handa ca bhuñja brāhmaṇa ati  tattha puṇṇam nadim yena ca peyyam āhūti kākapeyyāḥ nadīhi vadantāḥ yena puṇṇam nadim
translated: By which they say ‘gone far,’ he is abandoned. Come, brahmin, eat.”🔽Here, they say “crow’s drink” by which the river is full,

original: kākapeyyamāhu, na hi apuṇṇā nadī “kākapeyyā”ti vuccati. Yadāpi nadītīre ṭhatvā gīvaṃ
analyzed: kākapeyyam āhu na hi apuṇṇā nadī kākapeyyā ati vuccati yadā api nadī tīre ṭhatvā
translated: the crow’s drink river. For a river that is not full is not called “crow’s drink.” When standing on the river bank,

original: pasāretvā kākena pātuṃ sakkā hoti, tadā naṃ “kākapeyyā”ti vadanti. Jātaṃ yavaṃ yena🔽ca guyhamāhūti yavanti desanāsīsamattaṃ, idha pana sabbampi jātaṃ uggataṃ sampannataruṇasassaṃ
analyzed: pasāretvā kākena pātum sakkā hoti tadā nam kākapeyyā iti vadanti jātam yavam yena  ca desanāsīsa mattam idha pana sabbam pi jātam uggatam sampanna taruṇa sassam
translated: When it has grown so that a crow can drink from it, then they call it a crow’s drink. The barley that is grown:

original: adhippetaṃ. Tañhi yadā anto paviṭṭhakākaṃ paṭicchādetuṃ sakkoti, tadā guyhatīti guyhaṃ.
analyzed: adhippetam tat hi yadā antar paviṭṭha kākam paṭicchādetum sakkoti tadā guyhati iti guyham
translated: The barley is the mere head of the teaching. But here all the barley that is grown, arisen, come forth, and is well-grown young grain is intended. For when it is able to conceal a crow that has entered it, then it is a secret, thus it is a secret place.

original: Kiṃ guyhati? Kākaṃ. Iti kākassa guyhaṃ kākaguyhanti taṃ vadamānā kākena guyhavacanassa
analyzed: kim guyhati kākam iti kākassa guyham kāka guyhanti tam vadamānā kākena guyha vacanassa
translated: What is the secret? A crow. Thus it is the secret of the crow, the crow’s secret. Saying “the crow’s secret,” they say “secret” with reference to the crow’s secret talk.

original: kāraṇabhūtena “guyha”nti vadanti. Tena vuttaṃ “yena ca guyhamāhū”ti. Dūraṃ gataṃ
analyzed: kāraṇa bhūtena guyhanti vadanti tena vuttam yena ca dūram gatam
translated: Therefore it is said: “The barley that is grown is called a secret place because of the crow’s secret talk.”🔽The one who goes far away:

original: yena ca avhayantīti dūraṃ gataṃ vippavutthaṃ piyapuggalaṃ yaṃ āgantvā nisinnaṃ disvā
analyzed: yena ca avhayanti iti dūram gatam vippavuttham piya puggalam yam āgantvā nisinnam disvā
translated: The one who goes far away, who is absent, is a dear person. When he comes and sits down,

original: sace itthannāmo āgacchati, vassa kākāti vā vassantaññeva vā sutvā “yathā kāko vassati,
analyzed: sace itthannāmaḥ āgacchati vā vassantaññā iva vā sutvā yathā kākaḥ vassati
translated: if someone says, “If so-and-so comes, he will crow,” or if he hears him crowing, then they say, “As the crow crows,

original: itthannāmo āgamissatī”ti evaṃ vadantā yena ca avhayanti kathenti mantenti, udāharantīti
analyzed: itthannāmaḥ āgamissati iti evam vadantā yena ca avhayanti kathenti mantenti udāharanti iti
translated: so-and-so will come,” and they talk, consult, discuss, and say, “The one who goes far away is called a crow because of the crow’s talk.”

original: attho. So tyāgatoti so te ānīto. Handa ca bhuñja, brāhmaṇāti gaṇha, brāhmaṇa, bhuñjassu🔽naṃ, khāda idaṃ kākamaṃsanti attho.
analyzed: attho saḥ tyāgataḥ iti saḥ te ānītaḥ handa ca bhuñja brāhmaṇa ati gaṇha brāhmaṇa bhuñjassu  naṃ khāde idam
translated: Take him, Brahmin, and eat him. Eat this flesh of the flesh-eater, is the meaning.

original: Iti rājā imaṃ gāthaṃ paṇṇe likhitvā bodhisattassa pesesi. So paṇṇaṃ vācetvā “rājā maṃ daṭṭhukāmo”ti ñatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: iti rājā imam gātham paṇṇe likhitvā bodhisattassa pesesi saḥ paṇṇam vācetvā rājā mam daṭṭhu kāmaḥ iti ñatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: So the king wrote this verse on a piece of paper and sent it to the Bodhisatta. The Bodhisatta, having had the paper read, knowing that the king wanted to see him, spoke the second verse:

original: “Yato maṃ saratī rājā, vāyasampi pahetave;
analyzed: yatas mam saratī rājā vāyasam pi pahetave
translated: “Since the king remembers me, and wants even the flesh of a crow,

original: Haṃsā koñcā mayūrā ca, asatīyeva pāpiyā”ti.
analyzed: haṃsā koñcā mayūrā ca asatīyā iva pāpiyā ati
translated: Geese, cranes, and peacocks are not worth a sixteenth part of me.”

original: Tattha yato maṃ saratī rājā, vāyasampi pahetaveti yadā rājā vāyasamaṃsaṃ labhitvā
analyzed: tattha yatas mam saratī rājā vāyasam pi pahetavai iti yadā rājā vāyasa maṃsam labhitvā
translated: Herein, since the king remembers me, and wants even the flesh of a crow, means when the king, having obtained the flesh of a crow,

original: tampi pahetuṃ maṃ sarati. Haṃsā koñcā mayūrā cāti yadā panassa ete haṃsādayo upanītā
analyzed: tam pi pahetum mam sarati haṃsā koñcā mayūrā ca ati yadā ete haṃsa ādayaḥ upanītā
translated: remembers me and wants to have me brought. Geese, cranes, and peacocks, means when these geese and so on are brought,

original: bhavissanti, ekāni haṃsamaṃsādīni lacchati, tadā maṃ kasmā na sarissatīti attho?
analyzed: bhavissanti ekāni haṃsa maṃsa ādīni lacchati tadā mam kasmā na sarissati iti attho
translated: and he will obtain some flesh of geese and so on, why then will he not remember me? is the meaning.

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “haṃsakoñcamayūrāna”nti pāṭho. So sundaratarā, imesaṃ haṃsādīnaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam pana haṃsa koñca mayūra ananti pāṭhaḥ saḥ sundaratarā imesam haṃsa ādīnam
translated: But in the Commentary the reading is “haṃsa-koñca-mayūrānaṃ.” That is more beautiful.

original: maṃsaṃ labhitvā kasmā maṃ na sarissati, sarissatiyevāti attho. Asatīyeva pāpiyāti🔽yaṃ vā taṃ vā labhitvā saraṇaṃ nāma sundaraṃ, lokasmiṃ pana asatiyeva pāpiyā, asatikaraṇaṃyeva
analyzed: maṃsam labhitvā kasmā mam na sarissati sarissatiyā iva ati attho asatīyā iva pāpiyā ati  yam vā tam vā labhitvā saraṇam nāma sundaram lokasmin pana
translated: “There is no worse evil than unfaithfulness.”

original: hīnaṃ lāmakaṃ, tañca amhākaṃ rañño natthi. Sarati maṃ rājā, āgamanaṃ me paccāsīsati,
analyzed: hīnam lāmakam tat ca amhākam raññaḥ natthi sarati mam rājā āgamanam me paccāsīsati
translated: “If he gets meat, he will remember me, for remembrance is a good thing. But in the world there is no worse evil than unfaithfulness. Unfaithfulness is a low, vile thing. But this is not in me. The king remembers me, and he will expect me to come back.

original: tasmā gamissāmīti yānaṃ yojāpetvā gantvā rājānaṃ passi, rājā tussitvā purohitaṭṭhāneyeva patiṭṭhāpesi.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā rājā ānando ahosi, purohito pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: tasmā gamissāmi iti yānam yojāpetvā gantvā rājānam passi rājā tussitvā purohita ṭṭhāneya iva patiṭṭhāpesi  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā rājā ānandaḥ ahosi purohitaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: Therefore I will go.” So he had a carriage harnessed and went to the king. The king was pleased and made him his chaplain.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the characters in the Jātaka as follows, “At that time King Udena was Ānanda, and I myself was the chaplain.”

original: Puṇṇanadījātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: puṇṇanadījātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: Thus did the Teacher tell this story of the past.

original: [215] 5. Kacchapajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Full-Moon Night on the Ganges🔽The story of the Tortoise.

original: Avadhī vata attānanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kokālikaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Vatthu
analyzed: avadhī vata attānam ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ kokālikam ārabbha kathesi vatthu
translated: “He who has slain himself!” This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning Kokālika.

original: mahātakkārijātake āvi-bhavissati. Tadā pana satthā “na, bhikkhave, kokāliko idāneva
analyzed: mahātakkārijātake āvibhavissati tadā pana satthā na bhikkhave kokālikaḥ idānā iva
translated: will appear in the Mahā-takkārijātaka.

original: vācāya hato, pubbepi vācāya hatoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vācāya hataḥ pubbe pi vācāya hataḥ yeva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: But at that time the Teacher said, “Monks, Kokālika was not only slain by speech in this present life, but in a previous state of existence also he was slain by speech.” So saying, he related the following🔽Story of the Past:🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, a certain monk, who was a preacher of the Law, was reborn in the world of the Tusita gods.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto amaccakule nibbattitvā vayappatto
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ amacca kule nibbattitvā vaya patto
translated: Now at that time in Benares, under the sway of King Brahmadatta, there lived a certain minister, who was a preacher of the Law.

original: tassa atthadhammānusāsako ahosi. So pana rājā bahubhāṇī ahosi, tasmiṃ kathente aññesaṃ🔽vacanassa okāso nāma natthi. Bodhisatto tassa taṃ bahubhāṇitaṃ vāretukāmo ekaṃ upāyaṃ
analyzed: tassa attha dhamma anusāsakaḥ ahosi so pana rājā bahu bhāṇī ahosi tasmin kathente aññesam  vacanassa okāsaḥ nāma natthi bodhisatto tassa tam bahu bhāṇitam vāretu kāmo ekam upāyam
translated: This minister, desirous of preventing the king from talking so much, went about seeking some means of doing so.

original: upadhārento vicarati. Tasmiñca kāle himavantapadese ekasmiṃ sare kacchapo vasati,
analyzed: upadhārentaḥ vicarati tasmin ca kāle himavanta padese ekasmin sare kacchapaḥ vasati
translated: Now at that time in a certain lake in the Himalayas there lived a tortoise.

original: dve haṃsapotakā gocarāya carantā tena saddhiṃ vissāsaṃ akaṃsu. Te daḷhavissāsikā
analyzed: dve haṃsa potakā gocarāya carantā tena saddhim vissāsam akaṃsu te daḷha vissāsikā
translated: Two young geese, who were great friends of his, went about with him on their wanderings.

original: hutvā ekadivasaṃ kacchapaṃ āhaṃsu – “samma kacchapa, amhākaṃ himavante cittakūṭapabbatatale
analyzed: hutvā eka divasam kacchapam āhaṃsu samma kacchapa amhākam himavante cittakūṭa pabbata tale
translated: One day the young geese said to the tortoise, “My dear tortoise, on the peak of the Citta mountain in the Himalayas

original: kañcanaguhāyaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ ramaṇīyo padeso, gacchasi amhākaṃ saddhi”nti. “Ahaṃ🔽kinti katvā gamissāmī”ti? “Mayaṃ taṃ gahetvā gamissāma, sace tvaṃ mukhaṃ rakkhituṃ
analyzed: vasana ṭṭhānam ramaṇīyaḥ padesaḥ gacchasi amhākam saddhinti aham  kinti katvā gamissāmi iti mayam tam gahetvā gamissāma sace tvam mukham rakkhitum
translated: “The Golden Cave is a delightful place to live. Come, let us go there together.” “How can I go?” “We will take you. If you can keep your mouth shut,🔽we will take you.”

original: sakkhissasi, kassaci kiñci na kathessasī”ti. “Rakkhissāmi, sāmi, gahetvā maṃ gacchathā”ti.🔽Te “sādhū”ti vatvā ekaṃ daṇḍakaṃ kacchapena ḍaṃsāpetvā sayaṃ tassa ubho koṭiyo ḍaṃsitvā🔽ākāsaṃ pakkhandiṃsu. Taṃ tathā haṃsehi nīyamānaṃ gāmadārakā disvā “dve haṃsā kacchapaṃ
analyzed: sakkhissasi kassaci kiñci na kathessasi iti rakkhissāmi sāmi gahetvā mama gacchatha ati  te sādhu iti vatvā ekam daṇḍakam kacchapena ḍaṃsāpetvā sayam tassa ubho koṭiyaḥ ḍaṃsitvā  ākāsam tam tathā haṃsehi nīyamānam gāma dārakāḥ disvā dve haṃsā kacchapam
translated: “The Golden Cave is a delightful place to live. Come, let us go there together.” “How can I go?” “We will carry you. If you can keep your mouth shut, you will not say anything to anyone.” “I will keep my mouth shut. Take me with you.”🔽“Very well,” said the geese. One of them bit the turtle on the back, and the other bit him on the front, and they flew up into the air.

original: daṇḍakena harantī”ti āhaṃsu.
analyzed: daṇḍakena haranti iti āhaṃsu
translated: The boys of the village saw the turtle thus carried along by the geese, and cried out, “Two geese are carrying off a turtle on a stick.”

original: Kacchapo “yadi maṃ sahāyakā nenti, tumhākaṃ ettha kiṃ duṭṭhaceṭakā”ti vattukāmo haṃsānaṃ
analyzed: kacchapaḥ yadi mam sahāyakāḥ nenti tumhākam ettha kim duṭṭha ceṭaka ati vattu kāmaḥ haṃsānam
translated: The turtle thought to himself, “If my friends are carrying me off, what business is that of yours, you rascally village boys?” and he opened his mouth to speak.

original: sīghavegatāya bārāṇasinagare rājanivesanassa uparibhāgaṃ sampattakāle daṭṭhaṭṭhānato
analyzed: sīgha vegatāya bārāṇasi nagare rāja nivesanassa upari bhāgam sampatta kāle daṭṭha ṭṭhānato
translated: But the geese flew so swiftly that they reached the palace of King Brahmadatta at Benares before the turtle could get his mouth open.

original: daṇḍakaṃ vissajjetvā ākāsaṅgaṇe patitvā dvebhāgo ahosi, “kacchapo ākāsato patitvā
analyzed: daṇḍakam vissajjetvā ākāsa ṅgaṇe patitvā dvebhāgaḥ ahosi kacchapaḥ ākāsataḥ patitvā
translated: The crocodile, letting go his hold, fell to the ground, and was split in two. “The tortoise has fallen from the sky

original: dvedhā bhinno”ti ekakolāhalaṃ ahosi. Rājā bodhisattaṃ ādāya amaccagaṇaparivuto taṃ
analyzed: dvedhā eka kolāhalam ahosi rājā bodhisattam ādāya amacca gaṇa parivutaḥ taṃ
translated: and is split in two,” was the general cry. The king, taking the Bodhisatta with him, surrounded by his ministers, went to the spot,

original: ṭhānaṃ gantvā kacchapaṃ disvā bodhisattaṃ pucchi – “paṇḍita, kinti katvā esa patito”ti?🔽Bodhisatto “cirapaṭikaṅkhohaṃ rājānaṃ ovaditukāmo upāyaṃ upadhārento carāmi, iminā
analyzed: ṭhānam gantvā kacchapam disvā bodhisattam pucchi paṇḍita kinti katvā esa patitoti  bodhisatto cira paṭikaṅkhaḥ uham rājānam ovaditu kāmaḥ upāyam upadhārentaḥ carāmi iminā
translated: and seeing the tortoise, asked the Bodhisatta, “Wise man, how came this to pass?”

original: kacchapena haṃsehi saddhiṃ vissāso kato bhavissati, tehi imaṃ ‘himavantaṃ nesssāmā’ti🔽daṇḍakaṃ ḍaṃsāpetvā ākāsaṃ pakkhantehi bhavitabbaṃ, atha iminā kassaci vacanaṃ sutvā🔽arakkhitamukhatāya kiñci vattukāmena daṇḍakā vissaṭṭho bhavissati, evaṃ ākāsato patitvā
analyzed: kacchapena haṃsehi saddhim vissāsaḥ kataḥ bhavissati tehi imam himavantam nesssāma ati  daṇḍakam ḍaṃsāpetvā ākāsam pakkhantehi bhavitabbam atha iminā kassaci vacanam sutvā  a rakkhita mukha tāya kiñci vattu kāmena daṇḍakā vissaṭṭhaḥ bhavissati evam ākāsataḥ patitvā
translated: The Bodhisatta thought, “I have long been waiting for an opportunity to give the king advice. I have been seeking for a way to do so. This crocodile must have made friends with the geese. They must have said to him, ‘We will take you to the Himalayas.’🔽And they must have made him bite the stick, and have flown up into the air with him. Then, as he was not guarded, he must have said something,

original: jīvitakkhayaṃ patteneva bhavitabba”nti cintetvā “āma mahārāja, atimukharā nāma apariyantavacanā
analyzed: jīvita khayam pattena iva bhavitabban ti cintetvā āma mahā rāja atimukharā nāma apariyanta vacanā
translated: and the stick must have slipped from his mouth, and so he has fallen from the sky and lost his life.” And he said, “Yes, your majesty, those who are too talkative are not able to keep their counsel.

original: evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ pāpuṇantiyevā”ti vatvā imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: evarūpam dukkham pāpuṇantiyā iva ati vatvā imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: and they will suffer such suffering.” Then he spoke these verses:

original: “Avadhī vata attānaṃ, kacchapo byāharaṃ giraṃ;
analyzed: avadhī vata attānam kacchapaḥ byāharam giram
translated: “He killed himself, the tortoise, speaking words,

original: Suggahītasmiṃ kaṭṭhasmiṃ, vācāya sakiyāvadhi.
analyzed: kaṭṭhasmim vācāya
translated: When the stick was well-held, the words were able to reach.

original: “Etampi disvā naravīriyaseṭṭha, vācaṃ pamuñce kusalaṃ nātivelaṃ;
analyzed: etam pi disvā nara vīriya seṭṭha vācam pamuñce kusalam na ativelam
translated: “Having seen this, too, O Best of Men, he spoke words that were good, not too much;

original: Passasi bahubhāṇena, kacchapaṃ byasanaṃ gata”nti.
analyzed: passasi bahu bhāṇena kacchapam byasanam gatanti
translated: Do you see that by speaking much, the tortoise came to destruction?”

original: Tattha avadhī vatāti ghātesi vata. Byāharanti byāharanto. Suggahītasmiṃ kaṭṭhasminti🔽mukhena suṭṭhu ḍaṃsitvā gahite daṇḍake. Vācāya sakiyāvadhīti atimukharatāya akāle
analyzed: tattha avadhī vata ati ghātesi vata byāharanti byāharantaḥ suggahītasmin kaṭṭhasmin ti  mukhena suṭṭhu ḍaṃsitvā gahite daṇḍake vācāya ati mukharatāya akāle
translated: There, he said, “He killed himself, the tortoise, speaking words,” speaking words. “When the stick was well-held,”

original: vācaṃ nicchārento daṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā tāya sakāya vācāya attānaṃ avadhi ghātesi.
analyzed: vācam nicchārentaḥ daṭṭha ṭṭhānam vissajjetvā tāya sakāya vācāya attānam avadhi ghātesi
translated: after having well-bitten with his mouth the stick that was held. “The words were able to reach,” after having let go the place that was bitten, he killed himself, the tortoise, by his own words, by speaking at the wrong time because of his excessive talk.

original: Evamesa jīvitakkhayaṃ patto, na aññathāti. Etampi disvāti etampi kāraṇaṃ disvā. Naravīriyaseṭṭhāti
analyzed: evam esa jīvita kkhayam pattaḥ na aññathā ati etam pi disvā ati etam pi kāraṇam disvā nara vīriya seṭṭha iti
translated: Thus he came to the destruction of life, not otherwise. “Having seen this, too,” having seen this reason. “O Best of Men,”

original: naresu vīriyena seṭṭha uttamavīriya rājavara. Vācaṃ pamuñce kusalaṃ nātivelanti saccādipaṭisaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: naresu vīriyena seṭṭha uttama vīriya rāja vara vācam pamuñce kusalam sacca ādi paṭisaṃyuttam
translated: He should let loose a wholesome speech, not at the wrong time.

original: kusalameva paṇḍito puriso muñceyya nicchāreyya, tampi hitaṃ kālayuttaṃ, na ativelaṃ,
analyzed: kusalam eva paṇḍitaḥ purisaḥ muñceyya hitam kāla yuttam na ativelam
translated: A wise man should let loose, should utter, only wholesome speech, and that at the right time, not at the wrong time,🔽not speech that is out of season, that is not to the point. Do you see?

original: atikkantakālaṃ apariyantavācaṃ na bhāseyya. Passasīti nanu paccakkhato passasi. Bahubhāṇenāti
analyzed: atikkanta kālam a pariyanta vācam na bhāseyya passasi iti nanu paccakkhataḥ passasi bahu bhāṇena ati
translated: Through much talk,

original: bahubhaṇanena. Kacchapaṃ byasanaṃ gatanti etaṃ kacchapaṃ jīvitakkhayaṃ pattanti.
analyzed: bahu bhaṇanena kacchapam byasanam gatanti etam kacchapam jīvita kkhayam pattanti
translated: the tortoise came to destruction.🔽The king, thinking, “He is speaking of me,” said, “He is speaking of us, the wise ones.”

original: Rājā “maṃ sandhāya bhāsatī”ti ñatvā “amhe sandhāya kathesi, paṇḍitā”ti āha. Bodhisatto🔽“mahārāja, tvaṃ vā hohi añño vā, yo koci pamāṇātikkantaṃ bhāsanto evarūpaṃ byasanaṃ
analyzed: rājā mam sandhāya bhāsati iti ñatvā amhe sandhāya kathesi paṇḍita iti āha bodhisatto  mahā rāja tvam vā hohi aññaḥ vā yaḥ koci pamāṇa atikkantam bhāsantaḥ evarūpam byasanam
translated: The Bodhisatta,🔽making it clear, said, “Great king, whether it is you or anyone else, whoever speaks beyond measure will come to destruction

original: pāpuṇātī”ti pākaṭaṃ katvā kathesi. Rājā tato paṭṭhāya viramitvā mandabhāṇī ahosi.
analyzed: pāpuṇāti iti pākaṭam katvā kathesi rājā tatas paṭṭhāya viramitvā manda bhāṇī ahosi
translated: in this way.” The king, from that time forth, refrained, and became a man of few words.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā kacchapo kokāliko ahosi, dve haṃsapotakā dve mahātherā, rājā ānando, amaccapaṇḍito pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Kacchapajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā kacchapo kokālikaḥ ahosi dve haṃsa potakā dve mahā therāḥ rājā ānandaḥ amacca paṇḍitaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  kacchapajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: The Master, having related this story, identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the tortoise was Kokālika, the two young geese were the two Elders, the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the wise minister.”🔽The Birth of the Tortoise.

original: [216] 6. Macchajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth-Story of the Fish

original: Na māyamaggi tapatīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto purāṇadutiyikāpalobhanaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: na mā ayam aggi tapati iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ purāṇa dutiyikā apalobhanam ārabbha
translated: (Jā 518) This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a monk who was tempted by a former wife.

original: kathesi. Tañhi bhikkhuṃ satthā “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti pucchi.
analyzed: kathesi tat hi bhikkhum satthā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asi iti pucchi
translated: For the Master asked the monk, “Is it true, monk, that you are discontented?”

original: “Saccaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “kena ukkaṇṭhāpitosī”ti puṭṭho “purāṇadutiyikāyā”ti āha.
analyzed: saccam bhante iti vutte kena ukkaṇṭhāpitaḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ purāṇa dutiyikāya iti āha
translated: “It is true, Reverend Sir.” “By whom were you tempted to discontent?” “By my former wife.”

original: Atha naṃ satthā “ayaṃ te bhikkhu itthī anatthakārikā, pubbepi tvaṃ etaṃ nissāya sūlena
analyzed: atha nam satthā ayam te bhikkhu itthī anattha kārikā pubbe pi tvam etam nissāya sūlena
translated: Then the Master said, “This woman, monk, has been your undoing. In a former state of existence also, through her, you were pierced with a spear,

original: vijjhitvā aṅgāresu pacitvā khāditabbataṃ patto paṇḍite nissāya jīvitaṃ alatthā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vijjhitvā aṅgāresu pacitvā khāditabbatam patto paṇḍite nissāya jīvitam alattha ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: and were almost ready to be roasted and eaten, but through the help of the wise you escaped with your life.” So saying, he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto tassa purohito ahosi. Athekadivasaṃ🔽kevaṭṭā jāle laggaṃ macchaṃ uddharitvā uṇhavālukāpiṭṭhe ṭhapetvā “aṅgāresu naṃ pacitvā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto tassa purohitaḥ ahosi atha eka divasam  kevaṭṭā jāle laggam maccham uddharitvā uṇha vālukā piṭṭhe ṭhapetvā aṅgāresu nam pacitvā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was his chaplain. One day

original: khādissāmā”ti sūlaṃ tacchiṃsu. Maccho macchiṃ ārabbha paridevamāno imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: khādissāma ati sūlam macchaḥ macchim ārabbha paridevamānaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: some fishermen drew out a fish from their net and laid it on the hot sand. They then sharpened a stake and said, “We will roast it on a spit and eat it.” The fish, thinking of the other fish, lamented and spoke these verses:

original: “Na māyamaggi tapati, na sūlo sādhutacchito;
analyzed: na mā ayam aggi tapati na sūlaḥ sādhu tacchitaḥ
translated: “The fire does not burn me, nor the stake well sharpened;

original: Yañca maṃ maññate macchī, aññaṃ so ratiyā gato.
analyzed: yat ca mam maññate macchī aññam saḥ ratiyā gataḥ
translated: but the fish that I think of, he has gone to another’s delight.

original: “So maṃ dahati rāgaggi, cittaṃ cūpatapeti maṃ;
analyzed: saḥ mam dahati rāgaggi cittam cūpatapeti mam
translated: “That fire of passion burns me, and my mind is troubled;

original: Jālino muñcathāyirā maṃ, na kāme haññate kvacī”ti.🔽Tattha na māyamaggi tapatīti na maṃ ayaṃ aggi tapati, na tāpaṃ janeti, na socayatīti
analyzed: jālinaḥ muñcatha ayirāḥ mam na kāme haññate kvaci iti  tattha na mā ayam aggi tapati iti na mam ayam aggi tapati na tāpam janeti na socayati iti
translated: from the fisherman’s net release me, for nowhere is one safe from death.”🔽Herein, the fire does not burn me means this fire does not burn me, does not cause heat, does not make sorrow.

original: attho. Na sūloti ayaṃ sūlopi sādhutacchito maṃ na tapati, na me sokaṃ uppādeti. Yañca
analyzed: ayam sūlaḥ iti ayam sūlaḥ upi sādhu tacchitaḥ mam na tapati na me sokam yat ca
translated: Nor the stake means this stake also, well sharpened, does not burn me, does not cause sorrow to arise in me. But the fish

original: maṃ maññateti yaṃ pana maṃ macchī evaṃ maññati “aññaṃ macchiṃ so pañcakāmaguṇaratiyā
analyzed: mam maññata iti yam pana mam macchī evam maññati aññam macchim saḥ pañca kāmaguṇa ratiyā
translated: “She thinks I am”: but that fish thinks thus: “He is another fish who is enjoying the five strands of sense pleasure

original: gato”ti, tadeva maṃ tapati socayati. So maṃ dahatīti yo panesa rāgaggi, so maṃ dahati
analyzed: gata uti tat eva mam tapati socayati saḥ mam dahati iti yaḥ pana isa rāgaggi saḥ mam dahati
translated: “She thinks of me” : but that fish thinks of me thus: “He has gone to enjoy the five strands of sense pleasure with another fish.” That burns me, that grieves me. “He burns me” : but this fire of lust burns me.

original: jhāpeti. Cittaṃ cūpatapeti manti rāgasampayuttakaṃ mama cittameva ca maṃ upatāpeti🔽kilameti viheṭheti. Jālinoti kevaṭṭe ālapati. Te hi jālassa atthitāya “jālino”ti
analyzed: cittam rāga sampayuttakam mama cittam eva ca mam upatāpeti  kilameti viheṭheti jālino ti kevaṭṭe ālapati te hi jālassa atthitāya jālino ti
translated: “It makes my mind tremble” : my mind, which is associated with lust, trembles.

original: vuccanti. Muñcathāyirā manti muñcatha maṃ sāminoti yācati. Na kāme haññate kvacīti
analyzed: muñcatha ayirāḥ muñcatha mam yācati na kāme kvaci iti
translated: “It makes me tremble” : it makes me tremble, it afflicts me. “O fishermen” : he addresses the fishermen. For they are called “fishermen” because of the existence of their nets. “Release me” : he requests them, saying, “Release me, masters.” “Nowhere is one killed for sensual pleasures” :

original: kāme patiṭṭhito kāmena nīyamāno satto na kvaci haññati. Na hi taṃ tumhādisā hanituṃ🔽anucchavikāti paridevati. Atha vā kāmeti hetuvacane bhummaṃ, kāmahetu macchiṃ anubandhamāno
analyzed: kāme patiṭṭhitaḥ kāmena nīyamānaḥ sattaḥ na kvaci haññati na hi tam tumhādisā hanitum  anucchavikā ati paridevati atha vā kāma iti hetuvacane bhummam kāma hetu macchim anubandhamānaḥ
translated: a being who is established in sensual pleasures, who is being led away by sensual pleasures, is not killed anywhere. For you are not worthy to kill me,

original: nāma na kvaci tumhādisehi haññatīti paridevati. Tasmiṃ khaṇe bodhisatto nadītīraṃ
analyzed: nāma na kvacid tumha ādisehi haññati iti paridevati tasmin khaṇe bodhisattaḥ nadī tīram
translated: he laments. Or else, “kāma” is in the instrumental case in the sense of cause: “For the sake of sensual pleasures” . A fish that is being pursued for the sake of sensual pleasures is not killed anywhere by the likes of you, he laments. At that moment the Bodhisatta,

original: gato tassa macchassa paridevitasaddaṃ sutvā kevaṭṭe upasaṅkamitvā taṃ macchaṃ mocesi.
analyzed: gataḥ tassa macchassa paridevita saddam sutvā kevaṭṭe upasaṅkamitvā tam maccham mocesi
translated: The king, hearing the lamentations of the fish, went to the fisherman and set the fish free.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he expounded the Law, and at the conclusion of his discourse

original: ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā macchī purāṇadutiyikā ahosi, maccho
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā macchī purāṇadutiyikā ahosi maccho
translated: the monk who was filled with remorse was established in the fruit of conversion. The fish of that time is now the monk who was filled with remorse.🔽The fisherman is now the monk’s former wife.

original: ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu, purohito pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Macchajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu purohitaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  maccha jātaka vaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: The Brahman is now myself.🔽The Story of the Fish.

original: [217] 7. Seggujātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Ass

original: Sabbo lokoti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ paṇṇikaupāsakaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: sabbaḥ lokaḥ ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam paṇṇika upāsakam ārabbha kathesi
translated: When the Teacher was in residence at Jetavana, he told this story concerning a certain lay disciple who was a tree-planter.

original: Vatthu ekakanipāte vitthāritameva. Idhāpi satthā taṃ “kiṃ, upāsaka, cirassaṃ āgatosī”ti
analyzed: vatthu ekaka nipāte vitthāritam eva idha api satthā tam kim upāsaka cirassam āgataḥ asi iti
translated: The story is related at length in the Ekakanipāta. Here the Teacher asked the lay disciple, “Why have you come so late, lay disciple?”

original: pucchi. Paṇṇikaupāsako “dhītā me, bhante, niccaṃ pahaṃsitamukhī, tamahaṃ vīmaṃsitvā
analyzed: pucchi paṇṇika aupāsakaḥ dhītā me bhante niccam pahaṃsita mukhī tam aham vīmaṃsitvā
translated: The lay disciple replied, “Reverend Sir, my daughter is always frowning; I have been watching her to find out the reason why.”

original: ekassa kuladārakassa adāsiṃ, tattha itikattabbatāya tumhākaṃ dassanāya āgantuṃ okāsaṃ
analyzed: ekassa kula dārakassa adāsim tattha itikattabba tāya tumhākam dassanāya āgantum okāsam
translated: and gave her to a young man of good family. But because she had to attend to her duties there, she had no opportunity to come and see you.

original: na labhi”nti āha. Atha naṃ satthā “na kho, upāsaka, idānevesā sīlavatī, pubbepi sīlavatī,
analyzed: na labhinti āha atha nam satthā na kho upāsaka idāneva isā sīlavatī pubbe pi sīlavatī
translated: ” The Teacher replied, “Lay disciple, she was virtuous not only now, but in a previous state of existence also;

original: tvañca na idānevetaṃ vīmaṃsasi, pubbepi vīmaṃsiyevā”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: tvam ca naḥ idānā iva etam vīmaṃsasi pubbe pi vīmaṃsiyā iva ati vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: and not only now, but in a previous state of existence also, did you examine her. ” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto rukkhadevatā ahosi. Tadā🔽ayameva paṇṇikaupāsako “dhītaraṃ vīmaṃsissāmī”ti araññaṃ netvā kilesavasena icchanto
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto rukkha devatā ahosi tadā  ayam eva paṇṇika aupāsakaḥ dhītaram vīmaṃsissāmi iti araññam netvā kilesa vasena icchantaḥ
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, she was the daughter of a certain treasurer of Benares, and he was the son of another treasurer.🔽Now this treasurer’s son, in order to test his daughter, took her to the forest, and as if he were desirous of her on account of his own evil passions, seized her by the hand.

original: viya hatthe gaṇhi. Atha naṃ paridevamānaṃ paṭhamagāthāya ajjhabhāsi –
analyzed: viya hatthe gaṇhi atha nam paridevamānam paṭhama gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: Then she wept and lamented. He addressed her in the first stanza:

original: “Sabbo loko attamano ahosi, akovidā gāmadhammassa seggu;
analyzed: sabbaḥ lokaḥ atta manaḥ ahosi akovidā gāma dhammassa seggu
translated: “All the world is satisfied, the fool, ignorant of the ways of the world, the fool.

original: Komāri ko nāma tavajja dhammo, yaṃ tvaṃ gahitā pavane parodasī”ti.
analyzed: komāri kaḥ nāma tava jja dhammaḥ yam tvam gahitā pavane parodasi iti
translated: What is the reason, young girl, for your weeping, now that you are seized by the hand in the forest?”

original: Tattha sabbo loko attamano ahosīti, amma, sakalopi sattaloko etissā kāmasevanāya🔽attamano jāto. Akovidā gāmadhammassa seggūti seggūti tassā nāmaṃ. Tena tvaṃ pana,
analyzed: tattha sabbaḥ lokaḥ atta manaḥ ahosi iti amma sakalaḥ api satta lokaḥ etissā kāma sevanāya  atta manaḥ jātaḥ akovidā gāma dhammassa seggūti seggūti tassāḥ nāmam tena tvam pana
translated: Therein, all the world was pleased with her, Mother, the entire world of living beings was pleased with her because of her sexual intercourse.🔽She was a fool, a village woman, a simpleton, a simpleton was her name. Therefore,

original: amma, seggu akovidā gāmadhammassa, imasmiṃ gāmadhamme vasaladhamme akusalāsīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: amma akovidā gāma dhammassa imasmin gāma dhamme vasala dhamme akusalā asi iti vuttam
translated: Mother, you are a simpleton, a fool, a village woman, unskilled in this village custom, this low-class custom, it is said.

original: hoti. Komāri ko nāma tavajja dhammoti, amma, kumāri ko nāmesa tava ajja sabhāvo.🔽Yaṃ tvaṃ gahitā pavane parodasīti tvaṃ mayā imasmiṃ pavane santhavavasena hatthe
analyzed: hoti komāri kaḥ nāma tava ajja dhammo ti amma kumāri kaḥ nāma isa tava ajja sabhāvo  yam tvam gahitā pavane parodasi iti tvam mayā imasmin pavane santhava vasena hatthe
translated: What is your name, young girl? What is your name today, young girl?

original: gahitā parodasi na sampaṭicchasi, ko esa tava sabhāvo, kiṃ kumārikāyeva tvanti pucchati.
analyzed: gahitā parodasi na sampaṭicchasi kaḥ esa tava sabhāvaḥ kim kumārikāya iva pucchati
translated: Mother, when you were seized in the forest and wept, when you were seized by me in this forest for the purpose of intercourse and wept, you did not consent, what is this your nature? What are you, just a young girl?” he asks.

original: Taṃ sutvā kumārikā “āma, tāta, kumārikāyevāhaṃ, nāhaṃ methunadhammaṃ nāma jānāmī”ti vatvā paridevamānā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –🔽“Yo dukkhaphuṭṭhāya bhaveyya tāṇaṃ, so me pitā dubbhi vane karoti;
analyzed: tam sutvā kumārikā āma tāta kumārikāya iva aham na aham methuna dhammam nāma jānāmi iti vatvā paridevamānā dutiyam gātham āha 🔽yaḥ dukkha phuṭṭhāya bhaveyya tāṇam saḥ me pitā vane karoti
translated: Having heard that, the young girl said, “Yes, Father, I am just a young girl, I do not know anything about sexual intercourse,” and while lamenting, she spoke the second verse:

original: Sā kassa kandāmi vanassa majjhe, yo tāyitā so sahasaṃ karotī”ti.
analyzed: sā kassa kandāmi vanassa majjhe yaḥ tāyitā saḥ sahasam karoti iti
translated: Whom shall I weep for in the forest? He who should protect me, he is the one who acts with violence.”

original: Sā heṭṭhā kathitāyeva. Iti so paṇṇiko tadā dhītaraṃ vīmaṃsitvā gehaṃ netvā kuladārakassa datvā yathākammaṃ gato.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: sā heṭṭhā kathitāya iva iti saḥ paṇṇiko tadā dhītaram vīmaṃsitvā geham netvā kula dārakassa da tvā yathākammam gataḥ  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: The rest of the story is the same as the foregoing. Thus the merchant, having tested his daughter, took her home, gave her to a young man of good family, and went his way.

original: paṇṇikaupāsako sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā dhītā dhītāyeva, pitā pitāyeva ahosi,
analyzed: paṇṇika aupāsako sotāpatti phale tadā dhītā dhītāya iva pitā pitāya iva ahosi
translated: The Teacher, having related this story, explained the Truths, and identified the Birth: — “At that time the daughter was the daughter, the father was the father,

original: tassa kāraṇassa paccakkhakārikā rukkhadevatā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Seggujātakavaṇṇanā sattamā.
analyzed: tassa kāraṇassa paccakkha kārikā rukkha devatā pana aham eva ahosinti  seggu jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā
translated: and I myself was the tree-spirit who witnessed the matter.”🔽The Story of the Mango-tree Birth.

original: [218] 8. Kūṭavāṇijajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Saṭhassa sāṭheyyamidanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ kūṭavāṇijaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: saṭhassa sāṭheyyam idam ti idam satthāḥ jetavane viharantaḥ ekam kūṭa vāṇijam ārabbha
translated: The Story of the Merchant-Trickster.🔽This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a certain trickster.

original: kathesi. Sāvatthivāsino hi kūṭavāṇijo ca paṇḍitavāṇijo ca dve vāṇijā mittikā hutvā
analyzed: kathesi sāvatthi vāsinaḥ hi kūṭa vāṇijaḥ ca paṇḍita vāṇijaḥ ca dve vāṇijā mittikāḥ hutvā
translated: Two merchants, one a trickster, the other a shrewd man, lived at Sāvatthi.

original: pañca sakaṭasatāni bhaṇḍassa pūrāpetvā pubbantato aparantaṃ vicaramānā vohāraṃ katvā
analyzed: pañca sakaṭa satāni bhaṇḍassa pūrāpetvā pubbantataḥ aparantam vicaramānā vohāram katvā
translated: Five hundred carts were filled with the merchandise, and the merchants traveled from the east to the west, conducting business as they went.

original: bahuṃ lābhaṃ labhitvā sāvatthiṃ paccāgamiṃsu. Paṇḍitavāṇijo kūṭavāṇijaṃ āha – “samma,
analyzed: bahum lābham labhitvā sāvatthim pacca āgamiṃsu paṇḍita vāṇijaḥ kūṭa vāṇijam āha samma
translated: They made a great profit, and returned to Sāvatthi. The shrewd merchant said to the crooked merchant, “Friend,

original: bhaṇḍaṃ bhājemā”ti. Kūṭavāṇijo “ayaṃ dīgharattaṃ dukkhaseyyāya dubbhojanena kilanto
analyzed: bhaṇḍam bhājema ati kūṭa vāṇijaḥ ayam dīgharattam dukkha seyyāya dubbhojanena kilantaḥ
translated: let us divide our merchandise.” The crooked merchant thought to himself, “This man has been traveling for a long time, sleeping badly and eating badly.

original: attano ghare nānaggarasaṃ bhattaṃ bhuñjitvā ajīrakena marissati, atha sabbampetaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ ghare nānagga rasam bhattam bhuñjitvā ajīrakena marissati atha sabbam petam
translated: He is worn out, and if he eats a good meal in his own house, he will die of indigestion, and all this merchandise will be mine.”

original: bhaṇḍaṃ mayhameva bhavissatī”ti cintetvā “nakkhattaṃ na manāpaṃ, divaso na manāpo,
analyzed: bhaṇḍam mayham eva bhavissati iti cintetvā nakkhattam na manāpam divasaḥ na manāpaḥ
translated: So he said, “The stars are not favorable, the day is not favorable.

original: sve jānissāmi, punadivase jānissāmī”ti kālaṃ khepeti. Atha naṃ paṇḍitavāṇijo nippīḷetvā
analyzed: sve jānissāmi puna divase jānissāmi iti kālam khepeti atha nam paṇḍita vāṇijaḥ nippīḍetvā
translated: I will know tomorrow, I will know the next day.” Thus he put off the division of the merchandise. Finally the shrewd merchant,

original: bhājāpetvā gandhamālaṃ ādāya satthu santikaṃ gantvā satthāraṃ pūjetvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ
analyzed: bhājāpetvā gandha mālam ādāya satthu santikam gantvā satthāram pūjetvā vanditvā ekamantam
translated: having pressed him, had the merchandise divided. Taking perfumes and garlands, he went to the Teacher, paid obeisance to him, and sat down respectfully on one side.🔽The Teacher asked him, “Why have you come so late?”

original: nisīdi. Satthā “kadā āgatosī”ti pucchitvā “aḍḍhamāsamatto me, bhante, āgatassā”ti
analyzed: nisīdi satthā kadā āgatosi iti pucchitvā aḍḍha māsa mattaḥ me bhante āgatassa ati
translated: “Reverend Sir, I have been gone a month and a half.”

original: vatvā “atha kasmā evaṃ papañcaṃ katvā buddhupaṭṭhānaṃ āgatosī”ti puṭṭho taṃ pavattiṃ
analyzed: vatvā atha kasmai evam papañcam katvā buddha upaṭṭhānam āgataḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ tam pavattim
translated: The treasurer told him the whole story.

original: ārocesi. Satthā “na kho, upāsaka, idāneva, pubbepesa kūṭavāṇijoyevā”ti vatvā tena
analyzed: ārocesi satthā na kho upāsakaḥ idānā iva vatvā tena
translated: The Teacher said, “Lay disciple, this is not the first time he has done this; in a previous state of existence also he was a fraudulent trader.”🔽And at the request of the treasurer, he related the following

original: yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto amaccakule nibbattitvā vayappatto
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ amacca kule nibbattitvā vaya patto
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, when Brahmadatta was reigning in the city of Benares, the Bodhisatta was born in the family of a minister, and when he grew up,

original: tassa vinicchayāmacco ahosi. Tadā gāmavāsī ca nagaravāsī ca dve vāṇijā mittā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: tassa vinicchayā amaccaḥ ahosi tadā gāma vāsī ca nagara vāsī ca dve vāṇijāḥ mittāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: he became the minister of justice for that king. At that time there were two merchants, one living in the country and the other in the city, who were friends.

original: Gāmavāsī nagaravāsissa santike pañca phālasatāni ṭhapesi. So te phāle vikkiṇitvā
analyzed: gāma vāsī nagara vāsissa santike pañca phāla satāni ṭhapesi saḥ te phāle vikkiṇitvā
translated: The country merchant placed five hundred jars of molasses in the hands of the city merchant, and the latter sold the molasses

original: mūlaṃ gahetvā phālānaṃ ṭhapitaṭṭhāne mūsikavaccaṃ ākiritvā ṭhapesi. Aparabhāge gāmavāsī🔽āgantvā “phāle me dehī”ti āha. Kūṭavāṇijo “phālā te mūsikāhi khāditā”ti mūsikavaccaṃ
analyzed: mūlam gahetvā phālānam ṭhapita ṭṭhāne mūsika vaccam ākiritvā ṭhapesi aparabhāge gāma vāsī  āgantvā phāle me dehi iti āha kūṭa vāṇijaḥ phālā te khāditā ati mūsika vaccam
translated: and took the price. He then covered the place where he had stored the molasses with a layer of rat-dung and left it at that. After a time the country merchant🔽came and said, “Give me the price of my molasses.” The fraudulent trader said, “The rats have eaten your molasses.” And he showed him the rat-dung.

original: dassesi. Itaro “khāditāva hontu, mūsikāhi khādite kiṃ sakkā kātu”nti nhānatthāya
analyzed: dassesi itaro khāditāva hontu mūsikāhi khādite kim sakkā kātunti nhāna atthāya
translated: The other said, “Let them eat it; what can I do if the rats eat it?” And he went away to bathe.

original: tassa puttaṃ ādāya gacchanto ekassa sahāyakassa gehe “imassa katthaci gantuṃ mā adatthā”ti
analyzed: tassa puttam ādāya gacchantaḥ ekassa sahāyakassa gehe imassa katthaci gantum mā adattha ati
translated: Taking his son with him, he went to the house of a friend and said, “Do not give this boy anything to eat.”

original: vatvā antogabbhe nisīdāpetvā sayaṃ nhāyitvā kūṭavāṇijassa gehaṃ agamāsi. So “putto🔽me kaha”nti āha. “Samma, tava puttaṃ tīre ṭhapetvā mama udake nimuggakāle eko kulalo
analyzed: vatvā antogabbhe nisīdāpetvā sayam nhāyitvā kūṭa vāṇijassa geham agamāsi saḥ putto  me kahanti āha samma tava puttam tīre ṭhapetvā mama udake nimugga kāle ekaḥ kulalo
translated: He had the boy sit down in the inner room and went himself to bathe. He went to the house of the swindler and said, “Where is my son?”🔽“Good man, I left your son on the bank while I went into the water. A crane came and grabbed your son with his beak.

original: āgantvā tava puttaṃ nakhapañjarena gahetvā ākāsaṃ pakkhanto, ahaṃ pāṇiṃ paharitvā
analyzed: āgantvā tava puttam nakha pañjarena gahetvā ākāsam pakkhantaḥ aham pāṇim paharitvā
translated: I beat my arms and cried out, but I was not able to rescue him.”

original: viravitvā vāyamantopi mocetuṃ nāsakkhi”nti. “Tvaṃ musā bhaṇasi, kulalā dārake gahetvā
analyzed: viravitvā vā āyamantaḥ api mocetum na asakkhinti tvam musā bhaṇasi kulalā dārake gahetvā
translated: “You are lying. There are no cranes able to grab boys and fly away with them.”

original: gantuṃ samatthā nāma natthī”ti. “Samma, hotu, ayuttepi honte ahaṃ kiṃ karomi, kulaleneva
analyzed: gantum samatthā nāma natthi iti samma hotu ayutte pi honte aham kim karomi kulalena iva
translated: “Good man, what can I do if it happened? The boy was carried off by a crane.”

original: te putto nīto”ti. So taṃ santajjetvā “are duṭṭhacora manussamāraka, idāni taṃ vinicchayaṃ
analyzed: te puttaḥ nītaḥ iti saḥ tam santajjetvā are duṭṭha cora manussa māraka idāni tam vinicchayam
translated: The swindler scolded him, “You wicked thief, you murderer of men! Now I will take you before the judges and have you punished.”

original: gantvā kaḍḍhāpessāmī”ti nikkhami. So “mama ruccanakameva karosī”ti teneva saddhiṃ
analyzed: gantvā kaḍḍhāpessāmi iti nikkhami saḥ mama ruccanakam eva karosi iti tena iva saddhim
translated: He left, saying, “You are doing just what I want.”

original: vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ agamāsi.🔽Kūṭavāṇijo bodhisattaṃ āha – “ayaṃ, sāmi, mama puttaṃ gahetvā nhāyituṃ gato, ‘kahaṃ🔽me putto’ti vutte ‘kulalena haṭo’ti āha, vinicchinatha me aḍḍa”nti. Bodhisatto “saccaṃ
analyzed: vinicchaya ṭṭhānam agamāsi  kūṭa vāṇijaḥ bodhisattam āha ayam sāmi mama puttam gahetvā nhāyitum gataḥ kaham  me putto ti vutte kulalena haṭaḥ iti āha vinicchinatha me aḍḍanti bodhisatto saccam
translated: and went to the place of judgment.

original: bhaṇe”ti itaraṃ pucchi. So āha – “āma, sāmi, ahaṃ taṃ ādāya gato, senena pahaṭabhāvo🔽saccameva, sāmī”ti. “Kiṃ pana loke kulalā nāma dārake harantī”ti? “Sāmi, ahampi tumhe🔽pucchāmi – “kulalā dārake gahetvā ākāse gantuṃ na sakkonti, mūsikā pana ayaphāle
analyzed: bhaṇa iti itaram pucchi saḥ āha sāmi aham tam ādāya gataḥ senena pahaṭa bhāvaḥ  saccam eva sāmi iti kim pana loke kulalāḥ nāma dārake haranti iti sāmi aham pi tumhe  pucchāmi kulalā dārake gahetvā ākāse gantum na sakkonti mūsikā pana aya phāle
translated: The merchant said to the Bodhisatta, “Sir, this man took my son away with him to bathe, and when I asked him, ‘Where is my son?’ he said, ‘He was carried off by a water-sprite.’ Decide between us.” The Bodhisatta asked the other, “Is it true?”

original: khādantī”ti. “Idaṃ kiṃ nāmā”ti? “Sāmi, mayā etassa ghare pañca phālasatāni ṭhapitāni,
analyzed: khādanti iti idam kim nāma ati sāmi mayā etassa ghare pañca phāla satāni ṭhapitāni
translated: “Yes, sir, I took him away with me, and it is true that he was carried off by a water-sprite.” “But do water-sprites in the world carry off children?” “Sir, I ask you, do water-sprites carry off children and fly up into the air? But mice eat iron-pots.” “What is this?” “Sir, I had five hundred pots placed in his house,

original: svāyaṃ ‘phālā te mūsikāhi khāditā’ti vatvā ‘idaṃ te phāle khāditamūsikānaṃ vacca’nti
analyzed: su āyam phālā te mūsikā ahi khāditā iti vatvā idam te phāle khādita mūsikānam vaccanti
translated: and he says, ‘The pots have been eaten by mice,’ and he says, ‘This is the dung of the mice that ate your pots.’

original: vaccaṃ dasseti, sāmi, mūsikā ce phāle khādanti, kulalāpi dārake harissanti. Sace
analyzed: vaccam dasseti sāmi mūsikā ce phāle khādanti dārake harissanti sace
translated: “If the rats eat the seed-paddy, my lord, the Kulalas will carry off the children.

original: na khādanti, senāpi taṃ na harissanti. Eso pana ‘phālā te mūsikāhi khāditā’ti vadati,
analyzed: na khādanti tam na harissanti esā u pana phālā te mūsikāhi khāditā iti vadati
translated: If they do not eat it, the Senas will not carry off the children. But he says, ‘The rats have eaten your seed-paddy.’

original: tesaṃ khāditabhāvaṃ vā akhāditabhāvaṃ vā jānātha, aḍḍaṃ me vinicchinathā”ti. Bodhisatto🔽“saṭhassa paṭisāṭheyyaṃ katvā jinissāmīti iminā cintitaṃ bhavissatī”ti ñatvā “suṭṭhu
analyzed: tesam khādita bhāvam vā a khādita bhāvam vā jānātha aḍḍam me vinicchinatha ati bodhisatto  saṭhassa paṭisāṭheyyam katvā jinissāmi iti iminā cintitam bhavissati iti ñatvā suṭṭhu
translated: Find out whether it has been eaten or not, and decide my case.”

original: te cintita”nti vatvā imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: te vatvā imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: The Bodhisatta, thinking, “He will win by deceiving the deceiver,” said, “You have thought well.

original: “Saṭhassa sāṭheyyamiṃda sucintitaṃ, paccoḍḍitaṃ paṭikūṭassa kūṭaṃ;
analyzed: saṭhassa sāṭheyyam iṃda su cintitam paccoḍḍitam paṭikūṭassa kūṭam
translated: “The deceit of the deceiver is well thought out, the trick of the trickster is well prepared;

original: Phālaṃ ce khādeyyuṃ mūsikā, kasmā kumāraṃ kulalā na hareyyuṃ.
analyzed: phālam ce khādeyyum mūsikā kasmai kumāram kulalā na hareyyum
translated: If the rats eat the seed-paddy, why should not the Kulalas carry off the children?

original: “Kūṭassa hi santi kūṭakūṭā, bhavati cāpi nikatino nikatyā;
analyzed: hi santi kūṭa kūṭāḥ bhavati ca api nikatinaḥ nikatyā
translated: “For the trickster has tricks, and the trick has tricks;

original: Dehi puttanaṭṭha phālanaṭṭhassa phālaṃ, mā te puttamahāsi phālanaṭṭho”ti.
analyzed: dehi putta naṭṭha phāla naṭṭhassa phālam mā te putta mahā asi phāla naṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: Give the seed-paddy to the man who lost the children, lest your son be lost to the man who lost the seed-paddy.”

original: Tattha saṭhassāti saṭhabhāvena kerāṭikena “ekaṃ upāyaṃ katvā parasantakaṃ khādituṃ
analyzed: tattha saṭhassa ati saṭha bhāvena kerāṭikena ekam upāyam katvā para santakam khāditum
translated: Herein, a cheat is a swindler who thinks, “I will eat the other’s food by some means or other.”

original: vaṭṭatī”ti saṭhassa. Sāṭheyyamidaṃ sucintitanti idaṃ paṭisāṭheyyaṃ cintentena tayā🔽suṭṭhu cintitaṃ. Paccoḍḍitaṃ paṭikūṭassa kūṭanti kūṭassa puggalassa tayā paṭikūṭaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti saṭhassa sāṭheyyam idam su cintitam ti idam paṭisāṭheyyam cintentena tayā  suṭṭhu cintitam paccoḍḍitam paṭikūṭassa kūṭanti kūṭassa puggalassa tayā paṭikūṭam
translated: This deceit is well thought out: this deceit of yours is well thought out by you who are thinking of it.🔽The cheat’s counter-cheat is well countered: the cheat’s counter-cheat is well countered by you, well matched, as if it were a counterpart, is the meaning.

original: suṭṭhu paccoḍḍitaṃ, paṭibhāgaṃ katvā oḍḍitasadisameva katanti attho. Phālaṃ ce khādeyyuṃ🔽mūsikāti yadi mūsikā phālaṃ khādeyyuṃ. Kasmā kumāraṃ kulalā na hareyyunti mūsikāsu
analyzed: suṭṭhu paccoḍḍitam paṭibhāgam katvā oḍḍita sadisam eva katam ti phālam ce khādeyyuṃ  mūsikā ati yadi mūsikā phālam khādeyyum kasmai kumāram kulalāḥ na hareyyun ti mūsikāsu
translated: If mice were to eat the plough-share: if mice were to eat the plough-share,

original: phāle khādantīsu kulalā kiṃ kāraṇā kumāraṃ no hareyyuṃ.🔽Kūṭassa hi santi kūṭakūṭāti tvaṃ “ahameva mūsikāhi phāle khādāpitapuriso kūṭo”ti
analyzed: phāle khādantīsu kim kāraṇā kumāram no hareyyuṃ  kūṭassa hi santi kūṭa kūṭā ati tvam aham eva phāle khādāpita puriso kūṭaḥ ti
translated: Why should the rats not carry off the boy? : if mice were to eat the plough-share, why should the rats not carry off the boy?

original: maññasi, tādisassa pana kūṭassa imasmiṃ loke bahū kūṭā santi, kūṭassa kūṭāti kūṭapaṭikūṭānaṃ
analyzed: maññasi tādisassa pana kūṭassa imasmin loke bahū kūṭā santi kūṭassa kūṭa ati kūṭa paṭikūṭānam
translated: For the cheat has other cheats: you think “I am the cheat who got the mice to eat the plough-share,” but there are many cheats in this world like you, other cheats, counter-cheats,

original: etaṃ nāmaṃ, kūṭassa paṭikūṭā nāma santīti vuttaṃ hoti. Bhavati cāpi nikatino nikatyāti
analyzed: etam nāma kūṭassa paṭikūṭāḥ nāma santi iti vuttam hoti bhavati ca api nikatino nikatyā ati
translated: “There is a counter-counter to the counter,” i.e. there is another swindler who is a counter to the swindler who is a counter.🔽“And there is a near one to the near one,”

original: nikatino nekatikassa vañcanakapuggalassa nikatyā aparo nikatikārako vañcanakapuriso🔽bhavatiyeva. Dehi puttanaṭṭha phālanaṭṭhassa phālanti ambho naṭṭhaputta purisa, etassa🔽naṭṭhaphālassa phālaṃ dehi. Mā te puttamahāsi phālanaṭṭhoti sace hissa phālaṃ na
analyzed: nikatinaḥ nekatikassa vañcanaka puggalassa nikatyā aparaḥ nikati kārakaḥ vañcanaka puriso  bhavatiyā iva dehi putta naṭṭha phāla naṭṭhassa phālanti ambhaḥ naṭṭha putta purisa etassa  naṭṭha phālassa phālam dehi mā te putta mahā asi phāla naṭṭhaḥ ti sace hissa phālam na
translated: i.e. there is another swindler who is a counter to the swindler who is a counter.🔽“Give the plough to the man whose oxen are lost,🔽give the plough to the man whose oxen are lost, good man,🔽give the plough to this man whose oxen are lost.”

original: dassasi, puttaṃ te harissati, taṃ te esa mā haratu, phālamassa dehīti. “Demi, sāmi,
analyzed: dassasi puttam te harissati tam te esa mā haratu phālam assa dehi iti demi sāmi
translated: “Don’t let your oxen be lost,” i.e. if you don’t give him the plough, he will take away your oxen. Let him take away the plough instead of your oxen.🔽“I will give it, master, if he will give me my oxen.”

original: sace me puttaṃ detī”ti. “Demi, sāmi, sace me phāle detī”ti. Evaṃ naṭṭhaputto puttaṃ,
analyzed: sace me puttam deti iti demi sāmi sace me phāle deti iti evam naṭṭha puttaḥ puttam
translated: “I will give it, master, if he will give me the plough.”🔽Thus the man whose oxen were lost got his oxen,

original: naṭṭhaphālo ca phālaṃ paṭilabhitvā ubhopi yathākammaṃ gatā.
analyzed: naṭṭha phālo ca phālam paṭilabhitvā ubho api yathākammam gatā
translated: and the man whose plough was lost got his plough. And both went away according to their deserts.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā kūṭavāṇijo idāni kūṭavāṇijova, paṇḍitavāṇijo paṇḍitavāṇijoyeva, vinicchayāmacco pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā kūṭa vāṇijaḥ idāni kūṭa vāṇijaḥ uva paṇḍita vāṇijaḥ paṇḍita vāṇijaḥ yeva pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: The Master, having related this story, identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the crooked merchant was the crooked merchant of the present day, the clever merchant was the clever merchant of the present day, and I myself was the judge.”

original: Kūṭavāṇijajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: kūṭa vāṇija jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: The Birth of the Crooked Merchant.

original: [219] 9. Garahitajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Hiraññaṃ me suvaṇṇaṃ meti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ anabhiratiyā ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuṃ
analyzed: hiraññam me suvaṇṇam me ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam an abhiratiyā ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhuṃ
translated: The Birth Story of the Reproved (Jātaka 108)

original: ārabbha kathesi. Etassa hi paccekaṃ gahitaṃ ārammaṇaṃ nāma natthi, anabhirativāsaṃ
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi etassa hi paccekam gahitam ārammaṇam nāma natthi an abhirati vāsam
translated: “Gold is mine, silver is mine,”—the Master told this tale while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a monk who was discontented. For this monk had no special object of desire; he was discontented because he was living in a place where he was not used to living.

original: vasantaṃ pana taṃ satthu santikaṃ ānesuṃ. So satthārā “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu,
analyzed: vasantam pana tam satthu santikam ānesuṃ saḥ satthārā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu
translated: The monks took him to the Master. The Master asked him, “Is it true, monk, that you are discontented?”

original: ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti puṭṭho “sacca”nti vatvā “kiṃkāraṇā”ti vutte “kilesavasenā”ti āha.
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asi iti puṭṭhaḥ saccam ti vatvā kiṃkāraṇā iti vutte kilesa vasena ati āha
translated: “Yes, Sir,” he replied. “What is the reason?” “Because of the passions, Sir.”

original: Atha naṃ satthā “ayaṃ, bhikkhu, kileso nāma pubbe tiracchānehipi garahito, tvaṃ evarūpe
analyzed: atha nam satthā ayam bhikkhu kilesaḥ nāma pubbe tiracchānehi pi garahito tvam evarūpe
translated: Then the Master said, “This passion, monk, was reproved even by animals in the past. You,

original: sāsane pabbajito kasmā tiracchānehipi garahitakilesavasena ukkaṇṭhito”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: sāsane pabbajito kasmā gara hita kilesa vasena ukkaṇṭhitaḥ iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: “Why did you, who have gone forth in the Dispensation of the Buddha, become discontented through the defilement of lust, which is censured even by the beasts?”

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto himavantapadese vānarayoniyaṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ himavanta padese vānara yoniyam

original: nibbatti. Tamenaṃ eko vanacarako gahetvā ānetvā rañño adāsi. So ciraṃ rājagehe vasamāno
analyzed: nibbatti tam enam ekaḥ vana carakaḥ gahetvā ānetvā raññaḥ adāsi saḥ ciram rāja gehe vasamānaḥ

analyzed: vatta sampannaḥ ahosi manussa loke vattamānam kiriyam yebhuyyena aññāsi rājā tassa
translated: and was well behaved. He knew most of the things that were done in the human world. The king

original: vatte pasīditvā vanacarakaṃ pakkosāpetvā “imaṃ vānaraṃ gahitaṭṭhāneyeva vissajjehī”ti🔽āṇāpesi, so tathā akāsi. Vānaragaṇo bodhisattassa āgatabhāvaṃ ñatvā tassa dassanatthāya
analyzed: vatte pasīditvā vana carakam pakkosāpetvā imam vānaram gahita ṭṭhāne iya iva vissajjehi iti  so tathā akāsi vānara gaṇaḥ bodhisattassa āgata bhāvam ñatvā tassa dassana tthāya
translated: was pleased with his behaviour, and summoning the forester, ordered him, “Let the monkey go free where you caught him.”🔽He did so. The troop of monkeys, knowing that the Bodhisatta had come, assembled on a great flat rock in order to see him.

original: mahante pāsāṇapiṭṭhe sannipatitvā bodhisattena saddhiṃ sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ katvā
analyzed: mahante pāsāṇa piṭṭhe sannipatitvā bodhisattena saddhim sammodanīyam katham katvā
translated: After exchanging greetings with the Bodhisatta, they asked him,

original: “samma, kahaṃ ettakaṃ kālaṃ vutthosī”ti āha. “Bārāṇasiyaṃ rājanivesane”ti. “Atha
analyzed: samma kaham ettakam kālam vutthaḥ asi iti āha bārāṇasiyam rāja nivesana iti atha
translated: “Friend, where have you been all this time?” “In the royal palace at Bārāṇasī.” “What did you eat there?”

original: kathaṃ muttosī”ti? “Rājā maṃ keḷimakkaṭaṃ katvā mama vatte pasanno maṃ vissajjesī”ti.
analyzed: katham muttaḥ asi iti rājā mam keḷi makkaṭam katvā mama vatte pasannaḥ mama vissajjesi iti
translated: “How did you get out?” “The king, being pleased with my performance, set me free.”

original: Atha naṃ te vānarā “manussaloke vattamānakiriyaṃ nāma tumhe jānissatha, amhākampi
analyzed: atha nam te vānarāḥ manussa loke vattamānakiriyam nāma tumhe jānissatha amhākam pi
translated: Then the monkeys said to him, “You know what is going on in the world of men.

original: tāva kathetha, sotukāmamhā”ti āhaṃsu. “Mā maṃ manussānaṃ kiriyaṃ pucchathā”ti. “Kathetha
analyzed: tāva kathetha sotu kāmamha ati āhaṃsu mā mama manussānam kiriyam pucchatha ati kathetha
translated: Tell us, we are anxious to hear.” “Do not ask me about the affairs of men.” “Tell us,

analyzed: sotu kāmamha ati bodhisatto pi manussāḥ nāma khattiyāḥ api brāhmaṇāḥ api mayham mayham ti

original: vadanti, hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccataṃ na jānanti, suṇātha dāni tesaṃ andhabālānaṃ
analyzed: vadanti hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena anicca tam na jānanti suṇātha dāni tesam andha bālānam
translated: They do not know impermanence, the state of non-existence. Listen now to the doings of those blind fools.”

original: kāraṇa”nti vatvā imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: vatvā imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: And he spoke these verses:

original: “Hiraññaṃ me suvaṇṇaṃ me, esā rattiṃ divā kathā;
analyzed: hiraññam me suvaṇṇam me ā esā rattim divā kathā
translated: “Gold is mine, silver is mine,” such is the talk by night and day

translated: Of foolish men who see not the Ariyan way.

analyzed: dve dve gahapatayaḥ gehe ekaḥ tattha amassuko

analyzed: kītaḥ dhanena bahunā saḥ tam vitudate jananti
translated: He is marked with many a sign, he is bought with much wealth, he is a monk.”

original: Tattha hiraññaṃ me suvaṇṇaṃ meti desanāsīsamattametaṃ, iminā pana padadvayena dasavidhampi🔽ratanaṃ sabbaṃ, pubbaṇṇāparaṇṇaṃ khettavatthuṃ dvipadacatuppadañca sabbaṃ dassento
analyzed: tattha hiraññam me suvaṇṇam me iti desa nāsīsa mattam etam iminā pana pada dvayena dasavidham pi  ratanam sabbam pubbaṇṇa aparaṇṇam khetta vatthum dvipada catuppadam ca sabbam dassento
translated: Here, “My gold, my silver” is merely the beginning of the teaching. But with this pair of phrases he shows all the ten kinds of
