translated: by day and by night of men. But they do not know anything else, such as “The five aggregates are impermanent” or “Having offered, one does not become” ;

original: apassatanti ariyānaṃ buddhādīnaṃ dhammaṃ, ariyaṃ vā niddosaṃ navavidhaṃ lokuttaradhammaṃ
analyzed: apassatanti ariyānam buddha ādīnam dhammam ariyam vā niddosam navavidham lokuttara dhammaṃ
translated: thus lamenting, they wander about. “Foolish” means of little wisdom. “Not seeing the Ariyan Truth” : the truth of the Noble Ones, the Buddhas and so on; or the Noble Truth, the faultless, supramundane truth of the nine kinds.

original: apassantānaṃ esāva kathā. Aññā pana “aniccaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā”ti tesaṃ kathā nāma natthi.
analyzed: a passantānam esā ava kathā aññā pana aniccam vā dukkham vā ti tesam kathā nāma natthi
translated: Not seeing this, this is their talk. But they have no talk of “impermanence” or “suffering.”

analyzed: gahapatayoti gehe adhipati bhūtāḥ ekaḥ tattha ati tesu dvīsu ghara sāmikesu ekaḥ iti mātugāmam
translated: “Householders” : those who are masters of the house. “One of them” : of the two householders, one, the woman’s husband,

original: sandhāya vadati. Tattha veṇikatoti kataveṇī, nānappakārena saṇṭhāpitakesakalāpoti
analyzed: sandhāya vadati tattha veṇi kataḥ ti kata veṇī nānā pakārena saṇṭhāpita kesa kalāpo ti
translated: and he spoke with reference to that.🔽Herein, the braided is the braided hair, the meaning is that he was a monk who had arranged his hair in various ways.

analyzed: attho atho aṅkita kaṇṇakaḥ iti atha su eva viddha kaṇṇaḥ chidda kaṇṇaḥ iti lamba kaṇṇatam sandhāya āha  kītaḥ dhanena bahunā ati saḥ pana isa a massukaḥ lamba tthanaḥ veṇikataḥ aṅkita kaṇṇaḥ mātā pitūnam
translated: The pierced ear: he was also pierced in the ear, with a hole in the ear, he had a long ear-lobe, is what is said.🔽Bought with much money: he was not a slave, he was not a low-born man, he was a monk who had arranged his hair in various ways, who had a pierced ear, who had been bought with much money given to his parents,

original: bahuṃ dhanaṃ datvā kīto, maṇḍetvā pasādhetvā yānaṃ āropetvā mahantena parivārena
analyzed: bahum dhanam datvā kītaḥ maṇḍetvā pasādhetvā yānam āropetvā mahantena parivārena
translated: who had been bought, adorned, and pleased, who had been mounted on a vehicle and brought to the house with a great retinue.

original: gharaṃ ānīto. So taṃ vitudate jananti so gahapati āgatakālato paṭṭhāya tasmiṃ gehe
analyzed: gharam ānītaḥ saḥ tam vitudate jananti saḥ gahapati āgata kālataḥ paṭṭhāya tasmin gehe
translated: He tormented the people there: that householder, from the time of his arrival in the house,

analyzed: dāsa kammakara ādi bhedam janam are duṭṭha dāsa duṭṭha dāsi imam na karosi iti mukha sattīhi  vitudati sāmikaḥ viya hutvā mahājanam vicāreti evam tāva manussa loke ativiya ayuttanti

original: manussalokaṃ garahi.

translated: and he treated the great multitude as if he were their master. Thus he criticized the human world, saying, “It is extremely unsuitable in the human world.”

original: Taṃ sutvā sabbe vānarā “mā kathetha, mā kathetha, asotabbayuttakaṃ assumhā”ti ubhohi🔽hatthehi kaṇṇe daḷhaṃ pidahiṃsu. “Imasmiṃ ṭhāne amhehi idaṃ ayuttaṃ suta”nti taṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā sabbe vānarāḥ mā kathetha mā kathetha a sotabba yuttakam assumha ati ubhohi  hatthehi kaṇṇe daḷham pidahiṃsu imasmin ṭhāne amhehi idam ayuttam tam
translated: When they heard this, all the monkeys cried out, “Don’t say that, don’t say that! We have heard what should not be heard.”

original: ṭhānampi garahitvā aññattha agamaṃsu. So piṭṭhipāsāṇo garahitapiṭṭhipāsāṇoyeva kira nāma jāto.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne🔽so bhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā vānaragaṇo buddhaparisā ahosi, vānarindo
analyzed: ṭhānam pi garahitvā aññattha agamaṃsu so piṭṭhi pāsāṇaḥ garahita piṭṭhi pāsāṇaḥ yā iva kira nāma jātaḥ  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne  so bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā vānara gaṇaḥ buddha parisā ahosi vānarindo
translated: And they stopped their ears with both hands. “In this place we have heard what should not be heard,” and they reviled that place, and went elsewhere. And that rock is called the Reviled Rock to this day.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths clear, and identified the Birth by saying in conclusion, “At that time the troop of monkeys was the company of the Buddha, the chief of the monkeys was Devadatta, and I myself was the chief of the monkeys.”

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pana aham eva
translated: So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: Garahitajātakavaṇṇanā navamā.

translated: The Reviled Birth is ended.

original: [220] 10. Dhammadhajajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Dhammadhaja Birth-Story

translated: “Living happily, with a happy heart,” etc. This story the Master told, while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, concerning Devadatta’s attempt to kill him.

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam yasapāṇi nāma rājā rajjam kāresi kāḷakaḥ nāmassa senāpati ahosi  tadā bodhisatto tassa iva purohitaḥ ahosi nāmena dhammadhajaḥ nāma rañño pana sīsa ppasādhana kappako
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the general of his army was called Kāḷaka.🔽The Bodhisatta was his chaplain, named Dhammadhaja, and the king’s barber was called Chattapāṇi.

original: chattapāṇi nāma. Rājā dhammena rajjaṃ kāreti, senāpati panassa vinicchayaṃ karonto
analyzed: chattapāṇi nāma rājā dhammena rajjam kāreti senāpati panassa vinicchayam karontaḥ
translated: The king ruled righteously, but the general, in his judicial decisions,

translated: devoured the people’s substance, and, having taken bribes, he made the innocent guilty. One day

analyzed: vinicchaye parājitaḥ manussaḥ bāhā paggayha kandantaḥ vinicchayā nikkhantaḥ rāja upaṭṭhānam
translated: a man who had been defeated in a lawsuit went out of the court, weeping and beating his breast, and as he was going to the king’s palace

analyzed: gacchantam bodhisattam disvā tassa pādesu patitvā tumha ādisesu nāma sāmi rañño
translated: he saw the Bodhisatta coming out, and fell at his feet, saying, “Sir, while you, who are the king’s adviser in what is good for him and in righteousness,

analyzed: atthañca dhammañca anusāsantesu kāḷaka senāpati lañjam gahetvā assāmike sāmike karoti iti
translated: are alive, the general Kāḷaka takes bribes and makes the innocent guilty.”

original: attano parājitabhāvaṃ bodhisattassa kathesi. Bodhisatto kāruññaṃ uppādetvā “ehi bhaṇe,
analyzed: attano parājita bhāvam bodhisattassa kathesi bodhisatto kāruññam uppādetvā ehi bhaṇe
translated: and told the Bodhisatta that he had been defeated. The Bodhisatta, moved with pity, said, “Come,

analyzed: aḍḍam te vinicchinissāmi iti tam gahetvā vinicchaya ṭṭhānam agamāsi mahā janaḥ sannipati
translated: I will decide the wager for you.” And taking him with him, he went to the place of judgment. A great crowd assembled,

original: bodhisatto taṃ aḍḍaṃ paṭivinicchinitvā sāmikaññeva sāmikaṃ akāsi.
analyzed: bodhisatto tam aḍḍam paṭivinicchinitvā sāmikam na eva sāmikam akāsi
translated: and the Bodhisatta decided the wager, and made the owner the winner.

original: Mahājano sādhukāraṃ adāsi, so saddo mahā ahosi. Rājā taṃ sutvā “kiṃ saddo nāmeso”ti
analyzed: mahā janaḥ sādhukāram adāsi saḥ saddaḥ mahā ahosi rājā tam sutvā kim saddaḥ nāma iso ti
translated: The people shouted applause, and the noise was great. The king, hearing it, asked, “What is this noise?”

analyzed: pucchi deva dhamma dhaja paṇḍitena dubbinicchitaḥ aḍḍaḥ su vinicchitaḥ tatra īsa sādhukāra saddo ti
translated: “Your majesty, the wager, wrongly decided by the wise Dhammadhaja, has been rightly decided, and that is the sound of applause.”

analyzed: rājā tuṭṭhaḥ bodhisattam pakkosāpetvā aḍḍaḥ kira te ācariya vinicchitaḥ iti pucchi
translated: The king, pleased, sent for the Bodhisatta, and asked him, “Teacher, I hear that you have decided a wager.”

analyzed: āma mahā rāja kāḷakena dubbinicchitam aḍḍam vinicchininti vutte itas dāni paṭṭhāya

translated: And he slandered the Bodhisatta to the king, saying: “Great king, the wise Dhammadhaja will seize your kingdom.”

analyzed: rājā a saddahantaḥ mā evam avacāti paṭikkhipitvā puna tena sace me na saddahatha  tassa āgamana kāle vāta pānena atha anena sakala nagarassa hatthe kata bhāvam
translated: The king did not believe him, and said: “Do not say so.” But he slandered him again and again, and at last said: “If you will not believe me,🔽when he comes, look at him through a window. Then you will see that he has the whole city in his power,

original: passissathā”ti vutte rājā tassa aḍḍakārakaparisaṃ disvā “etasseva parisā”ti saññāya
analyzed: passissatha ati vutte rājā tassa aḍḍakāraka parisam disvā etassa iva parisā iti saññāya
translated: and that he has made all the people his own.” The king, seeing the crowd of his supporters, thought: “This is his crowd,”

original: bhijjitvā “kiṃ karoma senāpatī”ti pucchi. “Deva, etaṃ māretuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. “Oḷārikadosaṃ
analyzed: bhijjitvā kim karoma senāpati iti pucchi deva etam māretum vaṭṭati iti oḷārika dosam
translated: and he was divided in mind. And he asked: “What shall I do, general?” “Sire, it is right to put him to death.” “But he is a man of great virtue,

translated: I am sitting here remembering the True Idea. The True Idea is the idea of the hundred of good people, of the wise, of Buddhas, of Paccekabuddhas, and of Buddhas’ disciples.

analyzed: dukkhanti ayam hi aṭṭhavidhaḥ loka dhammo iminā pana abbhāhatā santaḥ na kampanti na
translated: Gain, loss, fame, obscurity, deprecation, praise, pleasure, pain: this is the eightfold worldly idea. But those who are struck by this do not tremble or waver or vacillate;

original: pavedhenti, ayamettha akampanasaṅkhāto sataṃ dhammo imaṃ anussaranto nisinnomhīti dīpeti.
analyzed: pavedhenti ayam ettha akampana saṅkhāto satam dhammaḥ imam anussarantaḥ nisinnaḥ amhi iti dīpeti
translated: this is the True Idea here called ‘ not trembling ‘. I am sitting here remembering this.”

original: Atha naṃ sakko “evaṃ sante, brāhmaṇa, imasmiṃ ṭhāne kasmā nisinnosī”ti. “Rājā caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: atha nam sakkaḥ evam sante brāhmaṇaḥ imasmin ṭhāne kasmā nisinnaḥ asi iti rājā catur aṅga samannāgatam
translated: Then Sakka said ‘ If that is so, brahmin, why are you sitting here ? ‘ ‘ The king, who is endowed with the four forms of army

analyzed: uyyāna pālam tādisam na sakkomi laddhum saḥ ham kim me parassa hatthe maraṇena
translated: “I cannot get a keeper of the garden such as I want, and I think, ‘What is the use of my dying in another’s service?

analyzed: araññam pavisitvā anātha maraṇam marissāmi iti cintetvā idha āgantvā nisinnaḥ ti brāhmaṇa
translated: I will enter the forest and die the death of a hermit.’ Thinking thus, I have come here and am sitting down.” “Brahman,

analyzed: aham sakkaḥ deva rājā mayā te uyyāna ādīni māpitāni catur aṅga samannāgatam uyyāna pālam
translated: I am Sakka, king of the gods, and I have had your garden made. It is not possible to get a keeper of the garden endowed with the four qualities.

original: māpetuṃ na sakkā, tumhākaṃ rañño sīsappasādhanakappako chattapāṇi nāma, so caturaṅgasamannāgato,
analyzed: māpetum na sakkā tumhākam rañño sīsappasādhana kappako chattapāṇi nāma so catur aṅga samannāgato
translated: But your king has a servant named Chattapāni, who is a barber by trade, and he is endowed with the four qualities.

analyzed: catur aṅga samannāgatena uyyāna pālena atthe sati etam kappakam uyyāna pālam kātum vadehi iti
translated: If you have need of a keeper of the garden endowed with the four qualities, tell your king to make this Chattapāni keeper of the garden.”

analyzed: iti sakkaḥ bodhisattassa ovādam da tvā mā bhāyi iti samassāsetvā attanaḥ devapuram eva gataḥ
translated: Thus Sakka gave the Bodhisatta advice, and comforting him, saying, “Do not fear,” he returned to his own city.

analyzed: bodhisattaḥ geham gantvā bhutta pāta rāsaḥ rājadvāram gantvā chatta pāṇim tattha iva disvā
translated: The Bodhisatta went home, and after breakfast went to the king’s gate, and there he saw Chattapāni.

analyzed: hatthe gahetvā tvam kira samma chatta pāṇi catur aṅga samannāgataḥ asi iti pucchitvā
translated: and taking him by the hand, asked him, “Is it true, my good Chattapāṇi, that you are endowed with the four qualities?”🔽“Who told you that I was endowed with the four qualities?”

original: “ko te mayhaṃ caturaṅgasamannāgatabhāvaṃ ācikkhī”ti vutte “sakko, devarājā”ti vatvā
analyzed: kaḥ te mayham catur aṅga samannāgata bhāvam ācikkhi iti vutte sakkaḥ devarājā iti vatvā
translated: “Sakka, king of the gods.”🔽“For what reason did he tell you?”

original: “kiṃkāraṇā ācikkhī”ti puṭṭho “iminā nāma kāraṇenā”ti sabbaṃ ācikkhi. So “āma, ahaṃ
analyzed: kiṃkāraṇā ācikkhi iti puṭṭhaḥ iminā nāma kāraṇena ati sabbam ācikkhi saḥ āma aham

analyzed: catur aṅga samannāgataḥ ti āha atha nam bodhisattaḥ hatthe gahetvā ava rañño santikam
translated: Then the Bodhisatta, taking him by the hand, went to the king,

analyzed: gantvā ayam mahā rāja chatta pāṇi catur aṅga samannāgataḥ catur aṅga samannāgatena  uyyāna pālena atthe sati imam uyyāna pālam karotha iti āha atha nam rājā tvam kira

If you have need of a park-keeper endowed with the four qualities,🔽appoint this man to the office of park-keeper.”🔽Then the king asked him, “Is it true that you are endowed with the four qualities?”🔽“Yes, your majesty.”

original: caturaṅgasamannāgatosī”ti pucchi. “Āma, mahārājā”ti. “Katamehi caturaṅgehi samannāgatosī”ti?

original: “Anusūyako ahaṃ deva, amajjapāyako ahaṃ;

original: kathento imaṃ gāthamāha –

analyzed: imasmin hi jātake āgata nayena iva ekasmin kāle ayam chattapāṇi rājā hutvā  pādamūlikehi saddhim sampad ussitvā bodhisattam attanaḥ manoratham a pūrentam na a setu kāmāya

analyzed: deviyā paribhinnaḥ bandhāpesi tadā nam bandhitvā ānītaḥ bodhisattaḥ yathābhūtam deviyā  dosam āropetvā sayam muttaḥ raññā bandhāpite sabbe api te pādamūlike mocetvā etesam ca

analyzed: deviyā ca aparādham khamatha mahā rājā iti ovadi sabbam heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva vitthārato

analyzed: amaṃsaka bhojanam nāma upanāmetum na sakkomi kinti karomi iti āha tāta mayham putto  raññā piyaḥ manāpaḥ puttam me disvā rājā tam eva cumbantaḥ parissajantaḥ attanaḥ atthi bhāvam pi

translated: and seated on the king’s lap. When the king was playing with his son, the cook brought the food.🔽The king, intoxicated with wine, did not see the meat in the dish and asked: “Where is the meat?” “Today,

analyzed: devaḥ uposatha divasam mā āghāta tāya maṃsam na laddhanti vutte mayham maṃsam nāma

original: asakkonto “dhanukoṭiṃ nissāya jīvissāmi, luddakammaṃ katvā jīvikaṃ kappessāmī”ti
analyzed: a sakkontaḥ dhanu koṭim nissāya jīvissāmi ludda kammam katvā jīvikam kappessāmi iti
translated: Unable to do so, he thought, “I will live by the end of the bow. I will make a living by the work of a hunter.”

original: bārāṇasito nikkhamitvā paccantagāmake vasanto dhanukalāpasannaddho araññaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: bārāṇasitaḥ nikkhamitvā paccanta gāmake vasantaḥ dhanu kalāpa sannaddhaḥ araññam pavisitvā
translated: He left Bārāṇasī, went to live in a border village, and, armed with bow and arrows, entered the forest.

original: nānāmige māretvā maṃsavikkayena jīvikaṃ kappesi. So ekadivasaṃ araññe kiñci alabhitvā
analyzed: nānā mige māretvā maṃsa vikkayena jīvikam kappesi saḥ eka divasam araññe kiñci a labhitvā
translated: He made a living by killing various animals and selling their meat. One day, not finding anything in the forest,

analyzed: āgacchantaḥ aṅgaṇa pariyante ṭhitam nigrodha rukkham disvā api nāma ittha kiñci bhaveyya ati

original: nigrodharukkhābhimukho pāyāsi.
analyzed: nigrodha rukkha abhimukhaḥ pāyāsi
translated: He went to the banyan tree.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe ubhopi te bhātaro mātaraṃ phalāni khādāpetvā purato katvā viṭapabbhantare
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe ubhaḥ api te bhātaraḥ mātaram phalāni khādāpetvā puratas katvā viṭa pabbhantare
translated: At that moment, the two brothers had fed their mother some fruit and were sitting in the branches in front of her.

analyzed: nisinnā tam āgacchantam disvā kim naḥ mātaram karissati iti sākhantare nilīyiṃsu
translated: When they saw him coming, they thought, “What will he do to our mother?” and they hid in the branches.

original: disvā cintesi – “kiṃ me tucchahatthagamanena imaṃ makkaṭiṃ vijjhitvā gahetvā gamissāmī”ti.
analyzed: disvā cintesi kim me tuccha hattha gamanena imam makkaṭim vijjhitvā gahetvā gamissāmi iti
translated: and seeing this, he thought, “What is the use of my going home empty-handed? I will shoot this monkey and take her home.”

original: So tassā vijjhanatthāya dhanuṃ gaṇhi. Taṃ disvā bodhisatto “tāta cūḷanandiya, eso
analyzed: saḥ tassāḥ vijjhana tthāya dhanum gaṇhi tam disvā bodhisatto tāta cūḷanandiyaḥ eso
translated: So he took his bow to shoot her. Seeing this, the Bodhisatta thought, “Dear Cūḷa-Nandiya, this man

analyzed: me purisaḥ mātaram vijjhitu kāmaḥ aham assā jīvita dānam dassāmi tvam mama accayena mātaram

original: paṭijaggeyyāsī”ti vatvā sākhantarā nikkhamitvā “bho purisa, mā me mātaraṃ vijjhi,
analyzed: paṭijaggeyyāsi iti vatvā sā akhantarā nikkhamitvā bho purisa mā me mātaram vijjhi
translated: after I am gone.” So saying, he left the branch and stood in front of the man, saying, “Sir, do not shoot my mother.

original: esā andhā jarādubbalā, ahamassā jīvitadānaṃ demi, tvaṃ etaṃ amāretvā maṃ mārehī”ti
analyzed: esā andhā jarā dubbalā aham assā jīvita dānam demi tvam etam a māretvā mama mārehi iti
translated: She is blind and old and weak. I will give you my life in exchange for hers. Do not kill her, but kill me instead.”

original: tassa paṭiññaṃ gahetvā sarassa āsannaṭṭhāne nisīdi. So nikkaruṇo bodhisattaṃ vijjhitvā🔽pātetvā mātarampissa vijjhituṃ puna dhanuṃ sannayhi. Taṃ disvā cūḷanandiyo “ayaṃ
analyzed: tassa paṭiññam gahetvā sarassaḥ āsanna ṭṭhāne nisīdi saḥ nikkaruṇaḥ bodhisattam vijjhitvā  pātetvā mātaram pissa vijjhitum puna dhanum tam disvā cūḷanandiyaḥ ayam
translated: So saying, he took an oath, and sat down near the water. The man, without a thought of pity, shot the Bodhisatta,

original: me mātaraṃ vijjhitukāmo, ekadivasampi kho me mātā jīvamānā laddhajīvitāyeva nāma
analyzed: me mātaram vijjhitu kāmaḥ eka divasam pi kho me mātā jīvamānā laddha jīvitāya iva nāma
translated: and when he fell, he took up his bow to shoot the mother. Seeing this, Cūḷa-Nandiya thought, “This man is going to shoot my mother. If my mother lives even one day, she will have a day of life.

original: hoti, jīvitadānamassā dassāmī”ti sākhantarā nikkhamitvā “bho purisa, mā me mātaraṃ
analyzed: hoti jīvita dānam assā dassāmi iti sā akhantarā nikkhamitvā bho purisa mā me mātaram
translated: “I will give her life in exchange for my own.” So he came out from among the branches, and said, “Good man, do not kill my mother.

analyzed: vijjhi aham assā jīvita dānam dammi tvam mam vijjhitvā amhe dve bhātike gahetvā amhākam
translated: I will give her life in exchange for my own. You kill me, and taking both of us, my mother and me,

analyzed: mātu jīvita dānam dehi iti tassa paṭiññam gahetvā sarassa āsanna ṭṭhāne nisīdi saḥ tam pi
translated: give her life in exchange for your own.” So he made a promise to the man, and sat down near the edge of the pool. The man killed him, too, and threw him in,

original: vijjhitvā pātetvā “ayaṃ makkaṭī ghare dārakānaṃ bhavissatī”ti mātarampi tesaṃ vijjhitvā
analyzed: vijjhitvā pātetvā ayam makkaṭī ghare dārakānam bhavissati iti mātaram pi tesam vijjhitvā
translated: and said, “This monkey will be for the children in the house.” So he killed the mother, too, and threw her in, and taking all three bodies,

analyzed: pāta itvā kājena ādāya geha abhimukhaḥ pāyāsi  athassa pāpa purisassa gehe asani patitvā bhariyam ca dve dārake ca gehena iva saddhim  jhāpesi piṭṭhi vaṃsa thūṇa mattam avasissi athassa nam ekaḥ purisaḥ disvā
translated: he set out for home.🔽Then a thunderbolt fell on the house of that wicked man, and killed his wife and two children, and burned the house to the ground, leaving only the charred framework. A man saw him at the village gate,

original: taṃ pavattiṃ ārocesi. So puttadārasokena abhibhūto tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne maṃsakājañja
analyzed: tam pavattim ārocesi saḥ putta dāra sokena abhibhūtaḥ tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne

analyzed: dhanuñca chaḍḍetvā vattham pahāya naggaḥ bāhā paggayha paridevamānaḥ gantvā gharam  pāvisi athassa sā thūṇā bhijjitvā sīse patitvā sīsam bhindi pathavī vivaram adāsi
translated: and throwing away his bow and arrows, and stripping off his clothes, he went naked, with his arms upraised, lamenting, and entered his house.🔽Then a pillar split and fell on his head and broke his head. The earth opened and swallowed him up,

analyzed: avīcitaḥ jālā uṭṭhahi so pathaviyā giliyamāno ācariyassa ovādam saritvā imam vata
translated: and a flame of fire sprang up. As he was being swallowed up by the earth, he remembered the teacher’s advice, and lamenting, “This is the very thing

analyzed: kāraṇam disvā pārāsariya brāhmaṇaḥ mayham ovādam adāsi iti paridevamānaḥ imam gāthā dvayam āha
translated: that the brāhmaṇa Pārāsariya saw and advised me,” he uttered this stanza:

analyzed: idam pārāsariyaḥ yat abravi
translated: “This is the very word of the teacher,🔽which Pārāsariya spoke:

original: Māsu tvaṃ akari pāpaṃ, yaṃ tvaṃ pacchā kataṃ tape.
analyzed: māsu tvam akari pāpam yam tvam pacchā katam tape
translated: ‘Do not do evil, that you may not repent;🔽“Whatever a man does,

original: “Yāni karoti puriso, tāni attani passati;
analyzed: yāni karoti puriso tāni attani passati
translated: he experiences the fruit of it himself.

original: Kalyāṇakārī kalyāṇaṃ, pāpakārī ca pāpakaṃ;
analyzed: kalyāṇa kārī kalyāṇam pāpa kārī ca pāpakam
translated: The doer of good goes to a good destiny; the doer of evil goes to an evil destiny.

analyzed: yādisam vapate bījam tādisam harate phalanti
translated: Whatever seed a man sows, that he reaps.”

original: Tassattho – yaṃ pārāsariyo brāhmaṇo abravi – “māsu tvaṃ pāpaṃ akarī, yaṃ kataṃ pacchā
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yam pārāsariyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ abravi māsu tvam pāpam akarī yam katam pacchā
translated: The meaning is: The brāhmaṇa Pārāsariya said, “Do not do evil, that you may not repent;

analyzed: tvañc eva tapeyya ati idam tam ācariyassa vacanam yāni kāya vacī manaḥ dvārehi kammāni
translated: “You alone must suffer the consequences.” This was the teacher’s statement. Whatever deeds a man performs by means of the doors of body, speech, and mind,

analyzed: puriso karoti tesam vipākam paṭilabhanto tāni yeva attani passati kalyāṇa kamma kārī

translated: experiences the good results thereof; he who performs evil deeds experiences the evil results thereof, the low, the vile, the results of demerit.

analyzed: lokasmin pi hi yādisam vapate bījam tādisam harate phalam bīja anurūpam bīja anucchavikam eva
translated: For in the world whatever seed a man sows, that he reaps as fruit. The fruit is in accordance with the seed, the fruit is of the same nature as the seed.

analyzed: phalam harati gaṇhāti anubhavati iti iti saḥ paridevantaḥ pathavim pavisitvā avīci mahāniraye nibbatti
translated: Thus he entered the earth and was reborn in the Avīci hell.

analyzed: satthā na bhikkhave devadattaḥ idānā iva pubbe pi kakkhaḷaḥ pharusaḥ
translated: The Teacher said, “Monks, Devadatta was not always so. In the past also he was hard-hearted and cruel and devoid of pity.”

analyzed: vatvā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā luddaka purisaḥ devadatto
translated: So saying, he related the following

analyzed: ahosi disāpāmokkhaḥ ācariyaḥ sāriputto cūḷanandiyaḥ ānandaḥ mātā mahāpajāpatigotamī
translated: In the dispensation of Kassapa, the Supremely Enlightened One, there lived a certain hunter who was a disciple of a certain teacher who was chief of a company of five hundred. The hunter went forth in the dispensation of Kassapa, the Supremely Enlightened One, and attained the Fruit of Conversion. He was known as the Elder Cūḷa-Nandiya. The teacher of this Elder was known as the Elder Mahā-Nandiya. The mother of the Elder Cūḷa-Nandiya was known as Mahā-Pajāpatī Gotamī.

original: mahānandiyo pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pana aham eva
translated: But I was the one who was greatly delighted.”🔽So said the Exalted One, and the monks rejoiced in his words.

original: Cūḷanandiyajātakavaṇṇanā dutiyā.🔽[223] 3. Puṭabhattajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Name namantassa bhaje bhajantanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ kuṭumbikaṃ

translated: The Story of the Little-Joy🔽Name-and-Name-Reciter, the man who honors, honors in return. This story the Master told, while dwelling in the Jeta Grove, concerning a certain householder.

analyzed: ārabbha kathesi sāvatthi nagara vāsī kirekaḥ kuṭumbikaḥ ekena janapada kuṭumbikena saddhiṃ  vohāram akāsi saḥ attanaḥ bhariyam ādāya tassa dhāraṇakassa santikam agamāsi dhāraṇakaḥ
translated: A certain householder, it seems, who dwelt in the city of Sāvatthi, made a friend of a certain householder in the provinces.

original: “dātuṃ na sakkomī”ti na kiñci adāsi, itaro kujjhitvā bhattaṃ abhuñjitvāva nikkhami.
analyzed: dātum na sakkomi iti na kiñci adāsi itaraḥ kujjhitvā bhattam a bhuñjitvā ava nikkhami
translated: The latter, taking his wife with him, went to the house of his friend. The friend, however, was unable to give him anything, and so gave him nothing. The other, angry at this, ate no food, but went away.

original: Atha naṃ antarāmagge chātajjhattaṃ disvā maggapaṭipannā purisā “bhariyāyapi datvā🔽bhuñjāhī”ti bhattapuṭaṃ adaṃsu. So taṃ gahetvā tassā adātukāmo hutvā “bhadde, idaṃ
analyzed: atha nam antarāmagge chāta ajjhattam disvā magga paṭipannā purisā  bhuñjāhi iti bhatta puṭam so tam gahetvā tassāḥ a dātu kāmaḥ hutvā bhadde idam
translated: Now on the way, the men who were traveling with him, seeing that he was hungry, gave him a basket of food, saying, “Eat this, and give the rest to your wife.”🔽He took it, and, being unwilling to give it to her, said, “My dear, this is a place where robbers lie in wait. You go on ahead.”

original: corānaṃ tiṭṭhanaṭṭhānaṃ, tvaṃ purato yāhī”ti uyyojetvā sabbaṃ bhattaṃ bhuñjitvā tucchapuṭaṃ
analyzed: corānam tiṭṭhana ṭṭhānam tvam puratas yāhi iti uyyojetvā sabbam bhattam bhuñjitvā tuccha puṭam
translated: So saying, he sent her on ahead, and ate all the food himself, and went on his way with an empty basket.

original: dassetvā “bhadde, abhattakaṃ tucchapuṭameva adaṃsū”ti āha. Sā tena ekakeneva bhuttabhāvaṃ🔽ñatvā domanassappattā ahosi. Te ubhopi jetavanapiṭṭhivihārena gacchantā “pānīyaṃ
analyzed: dassetvā bhadde abhattakam tuccha puṭam eva adaṃsu iti āha sā tena ekakena iva bhutta bhāvam  ñatvā domanassa pattā ahosi te ubho pi jetavana piṭṭhivihārena gacchantā pānīyam
translated: “My dear, they gave me nothing but an empty bowl.” She understood from this that he had eaten alone,

original: pivissāmā”ti jetavanaṃ pavisiṃsu.
analyzed: pivissāma ati jetavanam pavisiṃsu
translated: and she was grieved. As they were going along the road to the monastery on the bank of the river Jeta, they entered the monastery, thinking that they would drink water.

analyzed: satthā api tesaññeva āgamanam olokentaḥ maggam gahetvā ṭhita luddakaḥ viya gandhakuṭi chāyāya
translated: The Teacher, who was watching for their coming, sat down in the shadow of the Perfumed Chamber, like a hunter who has taken up his position and is watching for the deer.

analyzed: nisīdi te satthāram disvā upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā nisīdiṃsu satthā tehi saddhim
translated: When they saw the Teacher, they approached him, saluted him, and sat down. The Teacher exchanged greetings with them,

translated: and then asked them, “Lay disciples, does this husband of yours love you and cherish you?” “Reverend Sir,

analyzed: aham etassa sa snehā ayam pana mayham nisnehaḥ tiṭṭhantu aññe pi divasāḥ ajja iva īsa
translated: I love him and cherish him, but he does not love me and cherish me. Let alone other days, today

analyzed: antara āmagge puṭa bhattam labhitvā mayham a datvā bhuñji iti upāsike
translated: on the way he got a bowl of rice and ate it himself, without giving me any.” “Lay disciple,

analyzed: tvam etassa hita kāmā sa snehā ayam pana yadā pana tava
translated: You are affectionate and wish him well, but he is as if without affection. But when, relying on the wise,

analyzed: guṇe jānāti tadā te sabbissariyam niyyādeti iti vatvā tāya yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: You are kind and affectionate to him, but he is not affectionate to you. But when he comes to know your virtues by the help of the wise, then he will give you all his power.” So saying, he told the story of the past.

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ amacca kule nibbattitvā vaya patto
translated: Once upon a time when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was born in the family of a minister. When he grew up,

analyzed: āsaṅkantaḥ nīhari so attanaḥ bhariyam gahetvā nagarā nikkhamma ekasmin kāsika gāmake
translated: So he banished him. He took his wife with him, and left the city. He settled in a certain village in Kāsi,

analyzed: vāsam kappesi saḥ aparabhāge pitu kālakata bhāvam sutvā kula santakam rajjam gaṇhissāmi iti
translated: and lived there. After some time he heard that his father was dead, and he thought, “I will take the kingdom, which is mine by hereditary right.”

original: bārāṇasiṃ paccāgacchanto antarāmagge “bhariyāyapi datvā bhuñjāhī”ti bhattapuṭaṃ labhitvā
analyzed: bārāṇasim paccāgacchantaḥ antara āmagge da tvā bhuñjāhi iti bhatta puṭam labhitvā
translated: So he set out for Benares. On the way he received a basket of food, with the words, “Eat this after giving some to your wife.”

original: tassā adatvā sayameva taṃ bhuñji. Sā “kakkhaḷo vatāyaṃ puriso”ti domanassappattā
analyzed: tassāḥ a datvā sayam eva tam bhuñji sā kakkhaḷaḥ vata ayam puriso ti domanassa pattā
translated: But he ate it all himself, and gave her none. She was very sorry, and said, “This man is hard.”

original: ahosi. So bārāṇasiyaṃ rajjaṃ gahetvā taṃ aggamahesiṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā “ettakameva etissā
analyzed: ahosi saḥ bārāṇasiyam rajjam gahetvā tam aggamahesi ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā ettakam eva etissā
translated: He took over the kingdom of Bārāṇasī and made her his chief queen, saying, “That’s enough for her.

original: ala”nti na aññaṃ sakkāraṃ vā sammānaṃ vā karoti, “kathaṃ yāpesī”tipi naṃ na pucchati.🔽Bodhisatto cintesi – “ayaṃ devī rañño bahūpakārā sasnehā, rājā panetaṃ kismiñci na
analyzed: na aññam sakkāram vā sammānam vā karoti katham nam na pucchati  bodhisatto cintesi ayam devī raññaḥ bahu upakārā sa snehā rājā pana itam kismiñci na
translated: and he made her his chief consort. But he gave her no other honour or respect, and he never asked her how she was.

original: maññati, sakkārasammānamassā kāressāmī”ti taṃ upasaṅkamitvā upacāraṃ katvā ekamantaṃ🔽ṭhatvā “kiṃ, tātā”ti vutte “kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpetuṃ mayaṃ, devi, tumhe upaṭṭhahāma,
analyzed: maññati sakkāra sammānam assā kāressāmi iti tam upasaṅkamitvā upacāram katvā ekamantam  ṭhatvā kim tāta iti vutte katham samuṭṭhāpetum mayam devi tumhe upaṭṭhahāma
translated: The Bodhisatta thought to himself, “This queen has been a great help to the king, and he loves her dearly; but he does not think much of her. I will see to it that he shows her honour and respect.” So he went to her, made her a polite bow, and stood on one side.

original: kiṃ nāma mahallakānaṃ pitūnaṃ vatthakhaṇḍaṃ vā bhattapiṇḍaṃ vā dātuṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti🔽āha. “Tāta, ahaṃ attanāva kiñci na labhāmi, tumhākaṃ kiṃ dassāmi, nanu labhanakāle
analyzed: kim nāma mahallakānam pitūnam vattha khaṇḍam vā bhatta piṇḍam vā dātum na vaṭṭati iti  āha tāta aham kiñci na labhāmi tumhākam kim dassāmi nanu labhana kāle
translated: “What is it, dear?” said she. “We will wait on you, queen,” he replied. “What is the harm in giving to old fathers a piece of cloth or a morsel of food?”

original: adāsiṃ, idāni pana me rājā na kiñci deti. Tiṭṭhatu aññaṃ dānaṃ, rajjaṃ gaṇhituṃ āgacchanto
analyzed: adāsim idāni pana me rājā na kiñci deti tiṭṭhatu aññam dānam rajjam gaṇhitum āgacchantaḥ
translated: “Dear, I get nothing myself, so what can I give you? When I got anything, I gave it to you. But now the king gives me nothing. Let alone other gifts, when he came to take the kingdom, he gave me nothing.

original: antarāmagge bhattapuṭaṃ labhitvā bhattamattampi me adatvā attanāva bhuñjī”ti. “Kiṃ
analyzed: antara āmagge bhatta puṭam labhitvā bhattam attam pi me a datvā bhuñji iti kim
translated: and on the way he found a basket of food, and instead of giving it to me he ate it all himself.” “What did you say, friend?”

original: pana, amma, rañño santike evaṃ kathetuṃ sakkhissathā”ti? “Sakkhissāmi, tātā”ti. “Tena🔽hi ajjeva mama rañño santike ṭhitakāle mayi pucchante evaṃ kathetha ajjeva vo guṇaṃ
analyzed: pana amma rañño santike evam kathetum sakkhissatha ati sakkhissāmi tāta ati tena  hi ajja iva mama rañño santike ṭhita kāle mayi pucchante evam kathetha ajja iva vaḥ guṇam
translated: and on the way you got a basket of food, and you ate it all yourself, without giving me so much as a morsel.” “But, mother, can you speak thus in the presence of the king?” “I can, my son.” “Well then,

original: jānāpessāmī”ti evaṃ vatvā bodhisatto purimataraṃ gantvā rañño santike aṭṭhāsi. Sāpi
analyzed: jānāpessāmi iti evam vatvā bodhisatto purimataram gantvā rañño santike aṭṭhāsi sā api
translated: this very day, while I am standing in the presence of the king, when he asks me a question, tell him this, and I will make him understand your virtues this very day.” So saying, the Bodhisatta went on ahead, and stood in the presence of the king.

original: gantvā rañño samīpe aṭṭhāsi.🔽Atha naṃ bodhisatto “amma, tumhe ativiya kakkhaḷā, kiṃ nāma pitūnaṃ vatthakhaṇḍaṃ🔽vā bhattapiṇḍamattaṃ vā dātuṃ na vaṭṭatī”ti āha. “Tāta, ahameva rañño santikā kiñci
analyzed: gantvā rañño samīpe aṭṭhāsi  atha nam bodhisattaḥ amma tumhe ativiya kakkhaḷā kim nāma pitūnam vattha khaṇḍam  vā bhatta piṇḍa mattam vā dātum na vaṭṭati iti āha tāta aham eva rañño santikā kiñci
translated: She also went and stood in the presence of the king.

original: na labhāmi, tumhākaṃ kiṃ dassāmī”ti? “Nanu aggamahesiṭṭhānaṃ te laddha”nti? “Tāta,🔽kismiñci sammāne asati aggamahesiṭṭhānaṃ kiṃ karissati, idāni me tumhākaṃ rājā kiṃ
analyzed: na labhāmi tumhākam kim dassāmi iti nanu aggamahesi ṭṭhānam te laddhanti tāta 🔽kismiñci sammāne asati agga mahesi ṭṭhānam kim karissati idāni me tumhākam rājā kim
translated: The Bodhisatta said to her, “Mother, you are very hard. Is it not right to give your father a piece of cloth or a morsel of food?” “My son, I get nothing from the king. What can I give you?” “But have you not obtained the rank of chief consort?” “My son, what is the use of the rank of chief consort, if there is no reward? What can your king do for me now?

original: dassati, so antarāmagge bhattapuṭaṃ labhitvā tato kiñci adatvā sayameva bhuñjī”ti.
analyzed: dassati saḥ antara āmagge bhatta puṭam labhitvā tatas kiñci a datvā sayam eva bhuñji iti
translated: “If he does, he will get a meal on the way, and he will eat it himself without giving you any.”

original: Bodhisatto “evaṃ kira, mahārājā”ti pucchi. Rājā adhivāsesi. Bodhisatto tassa adhivāsanaṃ
analyzed: bodhisatto evam kira mahā rāja iti pucchi rājā adhivāsesi bodhisatto tassa adhivāsanaṃ
translated: “Is it so, great king?” asked the Bodhisatta. The king assented. The Bodhisatta,

original: viditvā “tena hi, amma, rañño appiyakālato paṭṭhāya kiṃ tumhākaṃ idha vāsena. Lokasmiñhi
analyzed: viditvā tena hi amma raññaḥ appiya kālataḥ paṭṭhāya kim tumhākam idha vāsena lokasmin hi
translated: understanding his assent, said, “Well then, mother, what have you to do with living here since the king is displeased?

original: appiyasampayogo ca dukkho, tumhākaṃ idha vāse sati rañño appiyasampayogova dukkhaṃ
analyzed: appiya sampayogo ca dukkhaḥ tumhākam idha vāse sati raññaḥ appiya sampayogo uva dukkham
translated: For it is painful to be associated with one whom one dislikes. If you live here, it will be painful for you to be associated with one whom you dislike.

original: bhavissati, ime sattā nāma bhajante bhajanti, abhajanabhāvaṃ ñatvā aññattha gantabbaṃ,
analyzed: bhavissati ime sattāḥ nāma bhajante bhajanti a bhajana bhāvam ñatvā aññattha gantabbam
translated: These creatures associate with those who associate with them, but when they find that they are not liked, they should go elsewhere,

original: mahanto lokasannivāso”ti vatvā imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: mahantaḥ loka sannivāsāḥ iti vatvā imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: for the world is wide.” And he pronounced the following Stanzas,

original: “Name namantassa bhaje bhajantaṃ, kiccānukubbassa kareyya kiccaṃ;
analyzed: name namantassa bhaje bhajantam kicca anukubbassa kareyya kiccam
translated: “He who is saluted should salute in return; he who does a service should have his service requited;

original: Nānatthakāmassa kareyya atthaṃ, asambhajantampi na sambhajeyya.
analyzed: nānattha kāmassa kareyya attham a sambhajantam pi na sambhajeyya
translated: He who desires his good should do good to another; he should not associate with him who does not associate with him.

original: “Caje cajantaṃ vanathaṃ na kayirā, apetacittena na sambhajeyya;
analyzed: caje cajantam vanatham na kayirāḥ apeta cittena na sambhajeyya
translated: “He should not be angry with him who is angry; he should not be spiteful to him who is spiteful;

original: Dijo dumaṃ khīṇaphalanti ñatvā, aññaṃ samekkheyya mahā hi loko”ti.🔽Tattha name namantassa bhaje bhajantanti yo attano namati, tasseva paṭinameyya. Yo🔽ca bhajati, tameva bhajeyya. Kiccānukubbassa kareyya kiccanti attano uppannakiccaṃ🔽anukubbantasseva tassapi uppannakiccaṃ paṭikareyya. Caje cajantaṃ vanathaṃ na kayirāti
analyzed: dijaḥ dumam khīṇa phalanti ñatvā aññam samekkheyya mahā hi loko ti  tattha name namantassa bhaje yaḥ attanaḥ namati tassa iva paṭinameyya yaḥ  ca bhajati tam eva bhajeyya kicca anukubbassa kareyya kiccanti attanaḥ uppanna kiccam  anukubbantassa iva tassa api uppanna kiccam paṭikareyya caje cajantam vanatham na
translated: The bird, knowing the tree to be exhausted of fruit, would seek another, for the world is great.

original: attānaṃ jahantaṃ jaheyyeva, tasmiṃ taṇhāsaṅkhātaṃ vanathaṃ na kareyya. Apetacittenāti
analyzed: attānam jahantam jaheyya iva tasmin taṇhā saṅkhātam vanatham na kareyya apeta cittena ati
translated: Herein, he who bows to one who bows to him, serves one who serves him, does what should be done for one who does what should be done for him, abandons one who abandons him: he should bow to one who bows to him, serve one who serves him, do what should be done for one who does what should be done for him, abandon one who abandons him. He should not make a thicket of craving in regard to one who abandons him.

original: vigatacittena vipallatthacittena. Na sambhajeyyāti tathārūpena saddhiṃ na samāgaccheyya.🔽Dijo dumanti yathā sakuṇo pubbe phalitampi rukkhaṃ phale khīṇe “khīṇaphalo aya”nti
analyzed: vigata cittena vipallattha cittena na sambhajeyya ati tathārūpena saddhim na samāgaccheyya  dijaḥ dumanti yathā sakuṇaḥ pubbe phalitam pi rukkham phale khīṇe khīṇa phalaḥ ayanti
translated: With a mind that has gone elsewhere: with a mind that has gone away, with a mind that has fallen away. He should not associate: he should not associate with such a one.

original: ñatvā taṃ chaḍḍetvā aññaṃ samekkhati pariyesati, evaṃ aññaṃ samekkheyya. Mahā hi
analyzed: ñatvā tam chaḍḍetvā aññam samekkhati pariyesati evam aññam samekkheyya mahā hi
translated: The bird: just as a bird, knowing that a tree is exhausted of fruit, abandons it, seeks another, looks around for another, so he should look around for another. For the world is great.

original: esa loko, atha tumhe sasnehaṃ ekaṃ purisaṃ labhissathāti.
analyzed: esa lokaḥ atha tumhe sa sneham ekam purisam labhissatha ati
translated: “This is the world, and you will get one man to love you.”

original: Taṃ sutvā bārāṇasirājā deviyā sabbissariyaṃ adāsi. Tato paṭṭhāya samaggā sammodamānā vasiṃsu.
analyzed: tam sutvā bārāṇasi rājā deviyā sabbissariyam adāsi tatas paṭṭhāya samaggā sammodamānā vasiṃsu
translated: When the king of Benares heard this, he gave his queen all the power and authority. From that time on they lived together in peace and harmony.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths clear, and identified the Birth by saying in conclusion,

original: dve jayampatikā sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahiṃsu. “Tadā jayampatikā ime dve jayampatikā
analyzed: dve sotāpatti phale tadā jayampatikā ime dve jayampatikā
translated: “At that time the two Jayampatis were the two Jayampatis of the present day,

original: ahesuṃ, paṇḍitāmacco pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: ahesum paṇḍitāmacco pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: and I myself was the wise minister.”🔽So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: Puṭabhattajātakavaṇṇanā tatiyā.🔽[224] 4. Kumbhilajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: puṭabhatta jātaka vaṇṇanā tatiyā
translated: The Story of the Dish of Rice.🔽The Story of the Ass in the Well

original: Yassete caturo dhammāti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto devadattaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: yassa ete caturaḥ dhammā ti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ devadattam ārabbha kathesi
translated: When the Teacher was in residence at Veḷuvana, he told this story of the past in order to illustrate the four qualities, in connection with Devadatta.

original: “Yassete caturo dhammā, vānarinda yathā tava;
analyzed: yassa ete caturaḥ dhammāḥ vānarinda yathā tava
translated: “He who possesses these four qualities, O king of the monkeys, as you do,

original: Saccaṃ dhammo dhiti cāgo, diṭṭhaṃ so ativattati.
analyzed: saccam dhammaḥ cāgaḥ diṭṭham saḥ ativattati
translated: Truth, righteousness, patience, and charity, will surpass all others.

original: “Yassa cete na vijjanti, guṇā paramabhaddakā;
analyzed: yassa ca ite na vijjanti guṇā parama bhaddakā
translated: “But he who does not possess these four qualities, so excellent and so rare,

original: Saccaṃ dhammo dhiti cāgo, diṭṭhaṃ so nātivattatī”ti.
analyzed: saccam dhammaḥ cāgaḥ diṭṭham saḥ na ativattati iti
translated: Truth, righteousness, patience, and charity, He will not overstep the bounds of right.

original: Tattha guṇā paramabhaddakāti yassa ete paramabhaddakā cattāro rāsaṭṭhena piṇḍaṭṭhena
analyzed: tattha guṇā parama bhaddakā ti yassa ete parama bhaddakā cattāro rāsaṭṭhena piṇḍaṭṭhena
translated: Herein, the best of qualities is the fourfold quality consisting of the best of friends, the best of enemies, the best of neutrals, and the best of all.

original: guṇā na vijjanti, so paccāmittaṃ atikkamituṃ na sakkotīti. Sesamettha sabbaṃ heṭṭhā🔽kumbhilajātake vuttanayameva saddhiṃ samodhānenāti.🔽Kumbhilajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: guṇāḥ na vijjanti so pacca amittam atikkamitum na sakkoti iti sesam ettha sabbam heṭṭhā  kumbhila jātake vutta nayam eva saddhim samodhānena ati  kumbhila jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: He who does not possess these fourfold qualities is unable to overcome his enemies. The rest of this story is like the Kumbha Jātaka.🔽The Kumbha Jātaka is finished.

original: [225] 5. Khantivaṇṇajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Khantivaṇṇajātaka is finished.

original: Atthi me puriso, devāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kosalarājānaṃ ārabbha kathesi.🔽Tassa kireko bahūpakāro amacco antepure padussi. Rājā “upakārako me”ti ñatvāpi adhivāsetvā🔽satthu ārocesi. Satthā “porāṇakarājānopi, mahārāja, evaṃ adhivāsesuṃyevā”ti vatvā
analyzed: atthi me purisaḥ deva ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ kosala rājānam ārabbha kathesi  tassa kira ekaḥ bahu upakāraḥ amaccaḥ antepure padussi rājā upakārakaḥ mā iti ñatvā api adhivāsetvā  satthu ārocesi satthā porāṇaka rājānaḥ api mahā rāja evam vatvā
translated: “I have a man, your majesty,” so it was that the Master told this story while living at Jetavana about King Pasena of Kosala.🔽It seems that a certain minister who was very helpful to the king was plotting against him in the palace. The king, knowing that the man had been very helpful to him, bore with him.

original: tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: Later he told the Master about it. The Master said, “Great king, the kings of old bore with such people.”🔽Then at the king’s request he related the Khantivaṇṇajātaka.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente eko amacco tassa antepure padussi, amaccassāpi🔽sevako tassa gehe padussi. So tassa aparādhaṃ adhivāsetuṃ asakkonto taṃ ādāya rañño
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente ekaḥ amacco tassa antepure amaccassa api  sevako tassa gehe padussi saḥ tassa aparādham adhivāsetum a sakkontaḥ tam ādāya rañño
translated: Long ago, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, a certain minister was guilty of a crime in the palace of the king.

original: santikaṃ gantvā “deva, eko me upaṭṭhāko sabbakiccakārako, so mayhaṃ gehe padussi,
analyzed: santikam gantvā deva ekaḥ me upaṭṭhāko sabba kicca kārako so mayham gehe padussi
translated: A servant of the minister was guilty of a crime in the house of the minister. The minister was unable to forgive the servant. So he took the servant with him and went to the king, saying, “Your majesty, I have a servant who does all my work. He has been guilty of a crime in my house.

original: tassa kiṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tassa kim kātum vaṭṭati iti pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: What is the proper course for me to follow?” And he uttered the first stanza:

original: “Atthi me puriso deva, sabbakiccesu byāvaṭo;
analyzed: atthi me purisaḥ deva sabba kiccesu byāvaṭaḥ
translated: “I have a man, O king, who does all my work;

original: Tassa cekoparādhatthi, tattha tvaṃ kinti maññasī”ti.🔽Tattha tassa cekoparādhatthīti tassa ca purisassa eko aparādho atthi. Tattha tvaṃ🔽kinti maññasīti tattha tassa purisassa aparādhe tvaṃ “kiṃ kātabba”nti maññasi, yathā
analyzed: tassa tattha tvam kinti maññasi iti  tattha tassa ca ika uparādha tthi iti tassa ca purisassa ekaḥ aparādhaḥ atthi tattha tvam  kim ti maññasi iti tattha tassa purisassa aparādhe tvam kim kātabbanti maññasi yathā
translated: He has been guilty of a crime, and now I ask, What is the proper course?”

original: te cittaṃ uppajjati, tadanurūpamassa daṇḍaṃ paṇehīti dīpeti.🔽Taṃ sutvā rājā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: te cittam uppajjati tad anurūpam assa daṇḍam paṇehi iti dīpeti 🔽tam sutvā rājā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: “He has been guilty of a crime” means that the man has been guilty of a single crime. “What is the proper course” means that you think, “What is the proper course for me to follow in the case of this man’s crime?” “Instruct me” means that you should instruct me in the punishment that is proper for the crime.

original: “Amhākampatthi puriso, ediso idha vijjati;
analyzed: purisaḥ edisaḥ idha vijjati
translated: “We have a man like this, who is most useful to us;🔽He is hard to find, endowed with all good qualities;

original: Dullabho aṅgasampanno, khantirasmāka ruccatī”ti.
analyzed: dullabhaḥ aṅga sampannaḥ khantiḥ asmāka ruccati iti
translated: Patience is what we like.”

original: Tassattho – amhākampi rājūnaṃ sataṃ ediso bahūpakāro agāre dussanakapuriso atthi,
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ amhākam pi rājūnam satam edisaḥ bahu upakāraḥ agāre dussanaka purisaḥ atthi
translated: The meaning is: We kings have a man like this, who is most useful to us in the palace,

original: so ca kho idha vijjati, idānipi idheva saṃvijjati, mayaṃ rājānopi samānā tassa bahūpakārataṃ
analyzed: saḥ ca kho idha vijjati idāni api idhā iva saṃvijjati mayam rājāno api samānā tassa
translated: and he is still here, he is still alive. We kings can put up with him because of his great usefulness to us,

original: sandhāya adhivāsema, tuyhaṃ pana araññopi sato adhivāsanabhāro jāto. Aṅgasampanno
analyzed: sandhāya adhivāsema tuyham pana araññaḥ api sataḥ adhivāsana bhāraḥ jātaḥ aṅga sampanno
translated: but you have to put up with him even though he is in the forest.

original: hi sabbehi guṇakoṭṭhāsehi samannāgato puriso nāma dullabho, tena kāraṇena asmākaṃ
analyzed: hi sabbehi guṇa koṭṭhāsehi samannāgataḥ purisaḥ nāma dullabhaḥ tena kāraṇena asmākam
translated: A man endowed with all good qualities is hard to find. For that reason

original: evarūpesu ṭhānesu adhivāsanakhantiyeva ruccatīti.
analyzed: evarūpesu ṭhānesu adhivāsana khantiyā iva ruccati iti
translated: patience in putting up with such a man is what we like.”

original: Amacco attānaṃ sandhāya rañño vuttabhāvaṃ ñatvā tato paṭṭhāya antepure padussituṃ na visahi, sopissa sevako rañño ārocitabhāvaṃ ñatvā tato paṭṭhāya taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ na visahi.
analyzed: amaccaḥ attānam sandhāya raññaḥ vutta bhāvam ñatvā tatas paṭṭhāya antepure padussitum na visahi saḥ upissa sevakaḥ raññaḥ ārocita bhāvam ñatvā tatas paṭṭhāya tam kammam kātum na visahi
translated: The minister, referring to himself, understood the king’s meaning. From then on he could not bear to cause trouble in the palace. The king’s servant, too, understood the king’s meaning. From then on he could not bear to do that deed.

analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā aham eva bārāṇasi rājā
translated: The Teacher, having related this story, identified the Birth by saying in conclusion, “At that time the King of Bārāṇasī was myself.”

original: ahosi”nti. Sopi amacco rañño satthu kathitabhāvaṃ ñatvā tato paṭṭhāya taṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ nāsakkhīti.
analyzed: ahosin ti so api amaccaḥ rañño satthu kathita bhāvam ñatvā tatas paṭṭhāya tam kammam kātum na asakkhi iti
translated: The minister, having learned that the king knew all about his conduct, was unable to continue his evil course.

original: Khantivaṇṇajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.
analyzed: khantivaṇṇa jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: The Story of the Birth of Khantivaṇṇa is ended.

original: [226] 6. Kosiyajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Birth of Kosiya

original: Kāle nikkhamanā sādhūti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kosalarājānaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Kosalarājā paccantavūpasamanatthāya akāle nikkhami. Vatthu heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: kāle nikkhamanā sādhu iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ kosala rājānam ārabbha kathesi kosala rājā paccanta vūpasamana tthāya akāle nikkhami vatthu heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: “It is well to go out at the proper time.” The Teacher, while in residence at Jetavana, told this story of a king of Kosala. The king of Kosala went out at an improper time to suppress a rebellion in the border regions. The story is the same as the one told above.

original: Satthā pana atītaṃ āharitvā āha – “mahārāja, atīte bārāṇasirājā akāle nikkhamitvā🔽uyyāne khandhāvāraṃ nivesayi. Tasmiṃ kāle eko ulūkasakuṇo veḷugumbaṃ pavisitvā nilīyi.
analyzed: satthā pana atītam āharitvā āha  mahā rāja atīte bārāṇasi rājā akāle nikkhamitvā  uyyāne khandhāvāram nivesayi tasmin kāle ekaḥ ulūka sakuṇaḥ veḷugumbam pavisitvā nilīyi
translated: The Teacher, however, related the following story of the past: “Great king, in times past, the king of Bārāṇasī went out at an improper time,🔽and pitched his camp in the garden. At that time a certain owl, entering a clump of reeds, sat down.

original: Kākasenā āgantvā ‘nikkhantameva taṃ gaṇhissāmā”’ti parivāresi. So sūriyatthaṅgamanaṃ
analyzed: kākasenā āgantvā nikkhantam eva tam gaṇhissāma ati parivāresi saḥ sūriyatthaṅgamanam
translated: A flock of crows came and surrounded him, saying, ‘We will seize him as soon as he comes out.’ The owl, seeing the sun go down,

original: anoloketvā akāleyeva nikkhamitvā palāyituṃ ārabhi. Atha naṃ kākā parivāretvā tuṇḍehi🔽koṭṭentā paripātesuṃ. Rājā bodhisattaṃ āmantetvā “kiṃ nu kho, paṇḍita, ime kākā kosiyaṃ
analyzed: anoloketvā akāleyā iva nikkhamitvā palāyitum ārabhi atha nam kākā parivāretvā tuṇḍehi  rājā bodhisattam āmantetvā kim nu kho paṇḍita ime kākā kosiyam
translated: without looking about him, went out at the wrong time and began to run away. Then the crows surrounded him and pecked at him with their beaks.🔽The king asked the Bodhisatta, “Why, O wise one, do these crows peck at the crow?”

original: paripātentī”ti pucchi. Bodhisatto “akāle, mahārāja, attano vasanaṭṭhānā nikkhamantā
analyzed: paripātenti iti pucchi bodhisatto akāle mahā rāja attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānā nikkhamantā
translated: “At the wrong time, O king, if one goes out from his own dwelling-place,

analyzed: evarūpam dukkham paṭilabhantiyā iva tasmai akāle attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānā nikkhamitum na
translated: he will suffer such misery. Therefore it is not right to go out from one’s own dwelling-place at the wrong time.”

original: vaṭṭatī”ti imamatthaṃ pakāsento imaṃ gāthādvayamāha –
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti imam attham pakāsentaḥ imam gāthā dvayam āha
translated: So saying, he expounded the Twin Stanzas:

original: Akālena hi nikkhamma, ekakampi bahujjano;

translated: For if one goes out at the wrong time, even a single man,

translated: “The wise man, who knows the rules of conduct, who follows the openings of others,

analyzed: tattha kāle nikkhamanā sādhu iti mahā rāja nikkhamanā nāma nikkhamanam vā parakkamanam  vā yutta payutta kāle sādhu na akāle sādhu nikkhamoti akāle pana attanaḥ vasana ṭhānato

analyzed: attham joteti attanaḥ appamattakam pi vuḍḍhim uppādetum na sakkoti atha kho ekakam pi  bahujjanaḥ so paccatthika janaḥ etam akāle nikkhamantam vā parakkamantam vā ekakam

original: parivāretvā mahāvināsaṃ pāpeti. Tatrāyaṃ upamā – dhaṅkasenāva kosiyaṃ, yathā ayaṃ

original: na nikkhamitabbaṃ na parakkamitabbanti.
analyzed: na nikkhamitabbam na parakkamitabbanti
translated: So, beginning with animals, no one should go out or return at the wrong time from his own dwelling place.

analyzed: dutiya gāthāya paṇḍitaḥ vidhi iti porāṇaka paṇḍitehi
translated: In the second stanza, “wise” means “intelligent.” “Tradition” means “the line of conduct laid down by the wise of old.” “Rules” means

analyzed: koṭṭhāsaḥ vā saṃvidahanam vā vivara anugū iti vivaram anugacchantaḥ jānantaḥ sabba amitta iti
translated: “a section” or “arrangement.” “Following the line” means “knowing the line.” “All enemies” means

analyzed: sabbe amitte vasīkatvā ti attanaḥ vase katvā kosiyaḥ uvā ti imamhā bāla kosiyā añño paṇḍita kosiyaḥ
translated: “all foes.” “Having brought under his control” means “having brought under his own power.” “Like a crow” means “like a wise crow, other than this foolish crow.”

analyzed: vidhino koṭṭhāsa saṅkhātam vidhānam vā tassa vā vidhinaḥ vidhānam saṃvidahanam anuṭṭhānam  jānāti saḥ vidhi vidhāna ññū paresam attanaḥ pacca amittānam vivaram ñatvā yathā nāma
translated: or the plan itself, which is called the “corner” of the plan, or the carrying out of the plan, the putting of it into effect,🔽he knows. He who knows the plan and its carrying out, having discovered the weak points of his enemies, both of his own people and of others,

original: paṇḍito kosiyo rattisaṅkhāte attano kāle nikkhamitvā ca parakkamitvā ca tattha tattha
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ kosiyaḥ ratti saṅkhāte attano kāle nikkhamitvā ca parakkamitvā ca tattha tattha
translated: just as a wise fowler, having gone out at the proper time, which is called night, and having spread his net in various places,

analyzed: sayitānañca iva kākānam sīsāni chindamānaḥ te sabbe amitte vasīkatvā sukhī siyā evam
translated: cuts off the heads of the crows that come to roost there, and having brought all his enemies under his control, becomes happy,

analyzed: dhīraḥ api kāle nikkhamitvā parakkamitvā attanaḥ pacca amitte vasīkatvā sukhī niddukkhaḥ
translated: so the wise man, having gone out at the proper time, and having spread his net in various places, and having brought his enemies under his control, becomes happy, free from sorrow.

analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā rājā ānandaḥ ahosi paṇḍita amacco pana aham eva ahosinti  kosiya jātaka vaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: The Teacher, having related this dhamma discourse, identified the Birth Story, saying, “At that time the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the wise fowler.”🔽The Commentary on the Kosiya Birth Story is the sixth.

original: [227] 7. Gūthapāṇajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Gūthapāṇi Birth Story

analyzed: sūraḥ sūrena saṅgamma iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ aññataram bhikkhum ārabbha
translated: “The hero with the hero” . The Master told this story while dwelling at Jetavana, about a certain monk.

analyzed: kathesi tasmin kira kāle jetavanataḥ ekaḥ nigama gāmaḥ tattha
translated: This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a certain monk. It seems that at that time there was a certain village, two and a half leagues from Jetavana,

analyzed: bahūni salākabhatta pakkhiyabhattāni atthi tatra ekaḥ pañhapucchakaḥ koṇḍaḥ vasati saḥ  salāka bhatta pakkhiya bhattānaṃ atthāya āgate dahare ca sāmaṇere ca ke khādanti ke

analyzed: pivanti ke bhuñjanti iti pañham pucchitvā kathetum a sakkonte lajjā pesi te tassa
translated: “Who eats? Who drinks? Who eats rice?” he would ask. And if they failed to answer, he would shame them.

original: bhayena salākabhattapakkhiyabhattatthāya taṃ gāmaṃ na gacchanti. Athekadivasaṃ eko🔽bhikkhu salākaggaṃ gantvā “bhante, asukagāme salākabhattaṃ vā pakkhiyabhattaṃ vā
analyzed: bhayena salāka bhatta pakkhiya bhatta tthāya tam gāmam na gacchanti atha eka divasam ekaḥ  bhikkhu salākaggam gantvā bhante asuka gāme salāka bhattam vā pakkhiya bhattam vā
translated: Through fear of him they did not go to the village for tickets and invitations. Now one day a certain monk went to the village for tickets,🔽and asked, “Reverend Sir, is there any invitation to a meal by tickets or to a meal given by a particular person in such and such a village?”

original: atthī”ti pucchitvā “atthāvuso, tattha paneko koṇḍo pañhaṃ pucchati, taṃ kathetuṃ
analyzed: atthi iti pucchitvā atthi āvuso tattha panekaḥ koṇḍo pañham pucchati tam kathetum
translated: “There is, brother. But there is a cock there who asks a question. If you can answer his question, you may go.”

analyzed: a sakkonte akkosati paribhāsati tassa bhayena koci gantum na sakkoti iti vutte bhante
translated: If anyone should go there, he would be unable to return.”

analyzed: tattha bhattāni mayham aham tam dametvā nibbisevanam katvā tatas paṭṭhāya
translated: “Venerable Sir, give me my food there. I will tame him and make him harmless. From then on

analyzed: tumhe disvā palāyanakam karissāmi iti āha bhikkhū sādhu uti sampaṭicchitvā tassa
translated: I will make him run away when he sees you.” The monks agreed, saying, “Very well.”

original: tattha bhattāni pāpesuṃ.
analyzed: tattha bhattāni pāpesuṃ
translated: They gave him his food there.

analyzed: saḥ tattha gantvā gāma dvāre cīvaram tam disvā caṇḍameṇḍakaḥ vegena  upagantvā pañham me samaṇa kathehi iti āha upāsaka gāme caritvā yāgum ādāya
translated: He went there and put on his robe at the village gate. When the ogre saw him, he rushed at him🔽like a fierce bull elephant and said, “Explain a question to me, monk.”🔽“Lay follower, after walking for alms in the village, bring back rice gruel and give it to me in the sitting hall.”

analyzed: āha saḥ api nam bhikkhu yāgum tāva me pātum dehi āsana sālam tāva sammajjitum dehi
translated: The monk said, “Give me the rice gruel to drink. Sweep the sitting hall.

translated: “How shall I answer your question?” said the other, and immediately knocked him down, and began to beat him, as if he were grinding his bones to pieces.

original: pañhaṃ pucchitakāle jānissāmī”ti santajjetvā pakkāmi. So tato paṭṭhāya bhikkhū disvāva🔽palāyati. Aparabhāge tassa bhikkhuno sā kiriyā bhikkhusaṅghe pākaṭā jātā. Athekadivasaṃ🔽dhammasabhāyaṃ bhikkhū kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ – “āvuso, asukabhikkhu kira koṇḍassa
analyzed: pañham pucchita kāle jānissāmi iti santajjetvā pakkāmi so tatas paṭṭhāya bhikkhū disvā ava  palāyati aparabhāge tassa bhikkhuno sā kiriyā bhikkhu saṅghe pākaṭā jātā atha eka divasam  dhammasabhāyam bhikkhū katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso asuka bhikkhu kira koṇḍassa
translated: Then he took some excrement and threw it into his mouth, saying, “From this time forth, whenever any monk comes to this village, I will know how to deal with him.” So saying, he went his way. From that time forth, whenever he saw a monk, he ran away.

original: mukhe gūthaṃ pakkhipitvā gato”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi
analyzed: mukhe gūtham pakkhipitvā gataḥ ti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi
translated: After a time the deed of this monk became known throughout the whole fraternity of monks. One day the monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth: “Brethren, it seems that a certain monk threw excrement into the mouth of a certain other monk and went his way.” The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?”

original: kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, so bhikkhu idāneva
analyzed: kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave saḥ bhikkhu idānā iva
translated: “What are you sitting here talking about?” When they told him, he said, “Monks, that monk did not deceive that man with mud only;

original: taṃ mīḷhena āsādeti, pubbepi āsādesiyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte aṅgamagadhavāsino aññamaññassa raṭṭhaṃ gacchantā ekadivasaṃ dvinnaṃ raṭṭhānaṃ🔽sīmantare ekaṃ saraṃ nissāya vasitvā suraṃ pivitvā macchamaṃsaṃ khāditvā pātova yānāni
analyzed: tam mīḷhena āsādeti pubbe pi āsādesiyā iva āti vatvā atītam āhari  atīte aṅga magadha vāsinaḥ aññamaññassa raṭṭham gacchantāḥ eka divasam dvinnam raṭṭhānam  sīmantare ekam saram nissāya vasitvā suram pivitvā maccha maṃsam khāditvā pātaḥ uva yānāni
translated: he deceived him in a previous state of existence also.” So saying, he related the following

original: yojetvā pakkamiṃsu. Tesaṃ gatakāle eko gūthakhādako pāṇako gūthagandhena āgantvā
analyzed: yojetvā pakkamiṃsu tesam gata kāle ekaḥ gūtha khādakaḥ pāṇakaḥ gūtha gandhena āgantvā
translated: In the days of yore, the inhabitants of Aṅga and Magadha used to go to each other’s country on trading expeditions. One day, as they were returning from a visit to the country of Magadha, they stopped on the border of the two countries, near a certain lake, and drank strong drink and ate fish. In the morning they harnessed their vehicles and started on their way.

original: tesaṃ pītaṭṭhāne chaḍḍitaṃ suraṃ disvā pipāsāya pivitvā matto hutvā gūthapuñjaṃ abhiruhi,
analyzed: tesam pīta ṭṭhāne chaḍḍitam suram disvā pipāsāya pivitvā mattaḥ hutvā gūtha puñjam abhiruhi
translated: After they had gone, a certain worm, which lived on ordure, came thither, attracted by the smell of the strong drink which they had thrown away. He drank the strong drink, became intoxicated, and climbed up a pile of ordure.

original: allagūthaṃ tasmiṃ āruḷhe thokaṃ onami. So “pathavī maṃ dhāretuṃ na sakkotī”ti viravi.
analyzed: alla gūtham tasmin āruḍhe thokam onami saḥ pathavī mam dhāretum na sakkoti iti
translated: As he climbed up the pile of ordure, the ordure stuck to his legs and pulled him down a little. He cried out, “The earth is unable to support me.”

original: Tasmiññeva khaṇe eko mattavaravāraṇo taṃ padesaṃ patvā gūthagandhaṃ ghāyitvā jigucchanto
analyzed: tasmin ñeva khaṇe ekaḥ matta vara vāraṇaḥ tam padesam patvā gūtha gandham ghāyitvā jigucchantaḥ
translated: At that moment a certain rutting elephant came to that place. Smelling the smell of the ordure, he became disgusted and cried out,

original: paṭikkami. So taṃ disvā “esa mama bhayena palāyatī”ti saññī hutvā “iminā me saddhiṃ
analyzed: paṭikkami saḥ tam disvā esa mama bhayena palāyati iti saññī hutvā iminā me saddhim
translated: and he went away. Seeing him, he thought, “He is running away out of fear of me,” and he went after him.

original: saṅgāmaṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti taṃ avhayanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saṅgāmam kātum vaṭṭati iti tam paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: and he went away. The other, seeing him, thought, “He is running away out of fear of me,” and, thinking, “I must fight with him,” he called to him, saying the first stanza:

original: “Sūro sūrena saṅgamma, vikkantena pahārinā;
analyzed: sūraḥ sūrena saṅgamma vikkantena pahārinā
translated: “The hero with the hero met, the bold man with the man of might,

original: Ehi nāga nivattassu, kiṃ nu bhīto palāyasi;
analyzed: ehi nāga nivattassu kim nu bhītaḥ palāyasi
translated: Come, Naga, turn and face me! Why in fear runest thou away?

original: Passantu aṅgamagadhā, mama tuyhañca vikkama”nti.
analyzed: passantu aṅga magadhāḥ mama tuyhañca vikkamanti
translated: Let Anga and Magadha see the prowess of thee and me.”

original: Tassattho – tvaṃ sūro mayā sūrena saddhiṃ samāgantvā vīriyavikkamena vikkantena pahāradānasamatthatāya
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ tvam sūraḥ mayā sūrena saddhim samāgantvā vīriya vikkamena vikkantena pahāra dāna samattha tāya
translated: This is the meaning: You are a hero. Having met me, a hero, with the prowess of my energy, bold,

original: pahārinā kiṃkāraṇā asaṅgāmetvāva gacchasi, nanu nāma ekasampahāropi dātabbo siyā,
analyzed: pahārinā kiṃkāraṇā gacchasi nanu nāma eka sampahāraḥ api dātabbaḥ siyā
translated: and able to give a blow, for what reason do you go away without fighting? Should not at least one blow be given?

original: tasmā ehi nāga nivattassu, ettakeneva maraṇabhayatajjito hutvā kiṃ nu bhīto palāyasi,
analyzed: tasmai ehi nāga ettakena iva maraṇa bhaya tajjitaḥ hutvā kim nu bhītaḥ palāyasi
translated: Therefore, come, Naga, turn and face me. Why, being terrified by the mere fear of death, do you run away?

original: ime imaṃ sīmaṃ antaraṃ katvā vasantā passantu, aṅgamagadhā mama tuyhañca vikkamaṃ
analyzed: ime imam sīmam antaram katvā vasantā passantu aṅga magadhāḥ mama vikkamam
translated: Let Anga and Magadha, living within this boundary, see the prowess of thee and me.

original: ubhinnampi amhākaṃ parakkamaṃ passantūti.
analyzed: ubhinnam pi amhākam parakkamam passantu uti
translated: Let them see the prowess of both of us.

original: So hatthī kaṇṇaṃ datvā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā nivattitvā tassa santikaṃ gantvā taṃ apasādento dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saḥ hatthī kaṇṇam da tvā tassa vacanam sutvā nivattitvā tassa santikam gantvā tam apasādentaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: The elephant, after listening to his words, turned back, went to him, and in order to dissuade him, spoke the second stanza:

original: “Na taṃ pādā vadhissāmi, na dantehi na soṇḍiyā;
analyzed: na tam pādā vadhissāmi na dantehi na soṇḍiyā
translated: I will not kill you with my feet, nor with my tusks, nor with my trunk;

original: Mīḷhena taṃ vadhissāmi, pūti haññatu pūtinā”ti.
analyzed: mīḷhena tam vadhissāmi pūti haññatu pūtinā ati
translated: I will kill you with my dung; let the foul be killed by the foul.

original: Tassattho – na taṃ pādādīhi vadhissāmi, tuyhaṃ pana anucchavikena mīḷhena taṃ vadhissāmīti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ na tam pāda ādīhi vadhissāmi tuyham pana anucchavikena mīḷhena tam vadhissāmi iti
translated: The meaning of this is: I will not kill you with my feet, etc., but I will kill you with dung suitable for you.

original: Evañca pana vatvā “pūtigūthapāṇako pūtināva haññatū”ti tassa matthake mahantaṃ laṇḍaṃ
analyzed: evañca pana vatvā pūti gūtha pāṇako pūti nāva haññatu iti tassa matthake mahantam laṇḍaṃ
translated: After speaking thus, “Let the one who carries a vessel of foul-smelling dung be killed by the foul,” he dropped a great lump of dung on his head,

original: pātetvā udakaṃ vissajjetvā tattheva taṃ jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpetvā koñcanādaṃ nadanto araññameva pāvisi.
analyzed: pātetvā udakam vissajjetvā tattha iva tam jīvita kkhayam pāpetvā koñca nādam nadantaḥ araññam eva pāvisi
translated: let the water run off, and killed him right there. Then he went back to the forest, crying out the cry of a crane.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā gūthapāṇako koṇḍo
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā gūthapāṇakaḥ koṇḍo
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the characters in the Jātaka as follows: “At that time, monks, the crane who carried a vessel of dung was the monk who was bitten by the snake,

original: ahosi, vāraṇo so bhikkhu, taṃ kāraṇaṃ paccakkhato disvā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nivutthadevatā
analyzed: ahosi vāraṇaḥ saḥ bhikkhu tam kāraṇam paccakkhataḥ disvā tasmim vana saṇḍe nivuttha devatā
translated: the elephant was the monk who was bitten by the snake, and the deity who lived in that forest and witnessed the incident

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pana aham eva
translated: was I myself.”

original: Gūthapāṇajātakavaṇṇanā sattamā.
analyzed: gūthapāṇa jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā
translated: The Story of the Birth as a Dung-Beetle is ended.

original: [228] 8. Kāmanītajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: . The Story of the Birth as Kāmanīta

original: Tayo girinti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto kāmanītabrāhmaṇaṃ nāma ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: tayaḥ girin ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ kāmanītabrāhmaṇam nāma ārabbha kathesi
translated: This story the Master told, while living in Jetavana, about a certain priest.

original: Vatthu paccuppannañca atītañca dvādasakanipāte kāmajātake āvibhavissati. Tesu pana
analyzed: vatthu paccuppannam ca atītam ca dvādasaka nipāte kāma jātake āvibhavissati tesu pana
translated: The story of the present will be told in the Dvādasakanipāta, in the Kāma Jātaka, and the story of the past will be told in the same place.

original: dvīsu rājaputtesu jeṭṭhako āgantvā bārāṇasiyaṃ rājā ahosi, kaniṭṭho uparājā. Tesu
analyzed: dvīsu rāja puttesu jeṭṭhakaḥ āgantvā bārāṇasiyam rājā ahosi kaniṭṭhaḥ uparājā tesu
translated: Of the two brothers, the elder became king of Benares, and the younger was his minister.🔽The king was so devoted to the pleasures of sense and so greedy for wealth that he was a perfect slave to them.

original: rājā vatthukāmakilesakāmesu atitto dhanalolo ahosi. Tadā bodhisatto sakko devarājā🔽hutvā jambudīpaṃ olokento tassa rañño dvīsupi kāmesu atittabhāvaṃ ñatvā “imaṃ rājānaṃ
analyzed: rājā vatthu kāma kilesa kāmesu atittaḥ dhana lolaḥ ahosi tadā bodhisatto sakkaḥ devarājā  hutvā jambudīpam olokento tassa raññaḥ dvīsu pi kāmesu atitta bhāvam ñatvā imam rājānam
translated: Now Sakka, the king of the gods, was at that time the Bodhisatta.🔽He looked down upon Jambudīpa, and seeing that the king was so devoted to the pleasures of sense, thought, “I will catch this king and shame him.”

original: niggaṇhitvā lajjāpessāmī”ti brāhmaṇamāṇavavaṇṇena āgantvā rājānaṃ passi, raññā ca
analyzed: niggaṇhitvā lajjā pessāmi iti brāhmaṇa māṇava vaṇṇena āgantvā rājānam passi raññā ca
translated: So he came down in the guise of a young brahman, and the king saw him.🔽“What is your business, young man?” asked the king.

original: “kenatthena āgatosi māṇavā”ti vutte “ahaṃ, mahārāja, tīṇi nagarāni passāmi khemāni
analyzed: kena atthena āgataḥ asi māṇava ati vutte aham mahā rāja tīṇi nagarāni passāmi khemāni
translated: “I see, great king,” said the young man, “three cities that are safe and secure.

original: subhikkhāni pahūtahatthiassarathapattīni hiraññasuvaṇṇālaṅkārabharitāni, sakkā ca🔽pana tāni appakeneva balena gaṇhituṃ, ahaṃ te tāni gahetvā dātuṃ āgato”ti āha. “Kadā
analyzed: subhikkhāni pahūta hatthi assa ratha pattīni hirañña suvaṇṇa alaṅkāra bharitāni sakkā ca  pana tāni appakena iva balena gaṇhitum aham te tāni gahetvā dātum āgataḥ iti āha kadā
translated: “The country is prosperous, the elephants, horses, chariots, and foot-soldiers are numerous, and the people are rich in gold, silver, and jewels.

original: gacchāma, māṇavā”ti vutte “sve mahārājā”ti. “Tena hi gaccha, pātova āgaccheyyāsī”ti.
analyzed: gacchāma māṇava ati vutte sve mahā rāja ati tena hi gaccha āgaccheyyāsi iti
translated: I have come to tell you that I can take possession of these countries with a small force.” “When shall we go, young man?” “To-morrow, great king.” “Very well, then, go and come back in the morning.”

original: “Sādhu, mahārāja, vegena balaṃ sajjehī”ti vatvā sakko sakaṭṭhānameva gato.🔽Rājā punadivase bheriṃ carāpetvā balasajjaṃ kāretvā amacce pakkosāpetvā hiyyo eko🔽brāhmaṇamāṇavo “uttarapañcāle indapatte kekaketi imesu tīsu nagaresu rajjaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: sādhu mahā rāja vegena balam sajjehi iti vatvā sakko saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ  rājā puna divase bherim carāpetvā balasajjam kāretvā amacce pakkosāpetvā hiyyaḥ ekaḥ  brāhmaṇa māṇavaḥ uttarapañcāle indapatte kekaka iti imesu tīsu nagaresu rajjam gahetvā
translated: “Very well, great king,” replied the young man, and he returned to his own place.

original: dassāmī”ti āha, taṃ māṇavaṃ ādāya tīsu nagaresu rajjaṃ gaṇhissāma, vegena naṃ pakkosathāti.
analyzed: dassāmi iti āha tam māṇavam ādāya tīsu nagaresu rajjam gaṇhissāma vegena nam pakkosatha ati
translated: The king caused a proclamation to be made on the following day, and had his army prepared for battle. He summoned his ministers and said to them, “Yesterday a certain young brāhman said to me, ‘I will take possession of the three cities of Uttarapañcāla, Indapatta, and Kekana.’ I will go with that young man and take possession of those three cities. Send for him quickly.”

original: “Katthassa, deva, nivāso dāpito”ti? “Na me tassa nivāsagehaṃ dāpita”nti. “Nivāsaparibbayo
analyzed: katthassa deva nivāsaḥ dāpito ti na me tassa nivāsa geham dāpitanti nivāsa paribbayaḥ
translated: “Where, your majesty, did you have his dwelling prepared?” “I did not have his dwelling prepared.” “Then, your majesty, you must prepare a dwelling for him.

original: pana dinno”ti? “Sopi na dinno”ti. Atha “kahaṃ naṃ passissāmā”ti? “Nagaravīthīsu olokethā”ti.
analyzed: pana dinnaḥ ti saḥ api na dinnaḥ ti atha kaham nam passissāma ati nagara vīthīsu oloketha ati
translated: “But was it given?” “That was not given either.” Then they said, “Where shall we find it?” “Look for it in the streets of the city.”

original: Te olokentā adisvā “na passāma, mahārājā”ti āhaṃsu. Rañño māṇavaṃ apassantassa “evaṃ
analyzed: te olokentāḥ a disvā na passāma mahā rāja iti āhaṃsu raññaḥ māṇavam a passantassa evam
translated: Looking for it, they could not find it. They said, “We cannot find it, great king.” The king, not seeing the student, thought, “I have lost my great power

original: mahantā nāma issariyā parihīnomhī”ti mahāsoko udapādi, hadayavatthu uṇhaṃ ahosi,
analyzed: mahantā nāma issariyā parihīno mhi iti mahā sokaḥ udapādi hadaya vatthu uṇham ahosi
translated: and my great wealth.” A great sorrow arose in him, and his heart was hot.

original: vatthulohitaṃ kuppi, lohitapakkhandikā udapādi, vejjā tikicchituṃ nāsakkhiṃsu.
analyzed: vatthu lohitam kuppi lohita pakkhandikā udapādi vejjā tikicchitum na asakkhiṃsu
translated: The blood in his body was disturbed, and a blood disease arose. The physicians could not cure him.

original: Tato tīhacatūhaccayena sakko āvajjamāno tassa taṃ ābādhaṃ ñatvā “tikicchissāmi na”nti
analyzed: tatas tīha catūha cayena sakkaḥ āvajjamāno tassa tam ābādham ñatvā tikicchissāmi
translated: After three or four months, Sakka, who was aware of this, thought, “I will cure him.”

original: brāhmaṇavaṇṇena āgantvā dvāre ṭhatvā “vejjabrāhmaṇo tumhākaṃ tikicchanatthāya āgato”ti
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vaṇṇena āgantvā dvāre ṭhatvā vejja brāhmaṇaḥ tumhākam tikicchana tthāya āgataḥ ti
translated: Disguising himself as a brahman, he went to the king’s door and had it announced, “A brahman physician has come to treat the king.”

original: ārocāpesi. Rājā taṃ sutvā “mahantamahantā rājavejjā maṃ tikicchituṃ nāsakkhiṃsu,
analyzed: ārocāpesi rājā tam sutvā mahanta mahantāḥ rāja vejjāḥ mam tikicchitum na asakkhiṃsu
translated: The king, hearing this, said, “Great physicians have not been able to cure me.

original: paribbayamassa dāpetvā uyyojethā”ti āha. Sakko taṃ sutvā “mayhaṃ neva nivāsaparibbayena
analyzed: paribbayam assa dāpetvā uyyojetha ati āha sakko tam sutvā mayham na iva nivāsa paribbayena
translated: Give him his fee and send him away.” Sakka, hearing this, thought, “I do not want his fee.

original: attho, vejjalābhampi na gaṇhissāmi, tikicchissāmi naṃ, puna rājā maṃ passatū”ti āha.
analyzed: attho vejja lābham pi na gaṇhissāmi tikicchissāmi nam punar rājā mama passatu uti āha
translated: “I will not accept any fee from you, but I will cure you. Let the king see me again.”

original: Rājā taṃ sutvā “tena hi āgacchatū”ti āha. Sakko pavisitvā jayāpetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi,
analyzed: rājā tam sutvā tena hi āgacchatu iti āha sakko pavisitvā jayāpetvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi
translated: When the king heard this, he said, “Very well, let him come.” Sakka entered the palace, paid his respects, and stood at one side.

original: rājā “tvaṃ maṃ tikicchasī”ti āha. “Āma, devā”ti. “Tena hi tikicchassū”ti. “Sādhu,🔽mahārāja, byādhino me lakkhaṇaṃ kathetha, kena kāraṇena uppanno, kiṃ khāditaṃ vā
analyzed: rājā tvam mam tikicchasi iti āha deva ati tena hi tikicchassu iti sādhu  mahā rāja byādhinaḥ me lakkhaṇam kathetha kena kāraṇena uppannaḥ kim khāditam vā
translated: The king said to him, “You will cure me?” “Yes, your majesty.” “Then cure me.” “Very well,

original: pītaṃ vā nissāya, udāhu diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā”ti? “Tāta, mayhaṃ byādhi sutaṃ nissāya🔽uppanno”ti. “Kiṃ te suta”nti. “Tāta eko māṇavo āgantvā mayhaṃ ‘tīsu nagaresu rajjaṃ
analyzed: pītam vā nissāya udāhu diṭṭham vā sutam vā ati tāta mayham byādhi sutam nissāya  uppannaḥ iti kim te sutam ti tāta ekaḥ māṇavaḥ āgantvā mayham tīsu nagaresu rajjam
translated: great king, tell me the symptoms of your disease. For what reason did it arise? Was it through eating or drinking something, or through something you saw or heard?” “My disease, dear sir, arose

original: gaṇhitvā dassāmī’ti āha, ahaṃ tassa nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ vā nivāsaparibbayaṃ vā na dāpesiṃ,
analyzed: gaṇhitvā dassāmi iti āha aham tassa nivāsa ṭṭhānam vā nivāsa paribbayam vā na dāpesiṃ
translated: through something I heard.” “What did you hear?” “Dear sir, a young brahman came to me and said, ‘I will win the kingship for you in three cities.’ I did not give him a place to live in or a salary.

original: so mayhaṃ kujjhitvā aññassa rañño santikaṃ gato bhavissati. Atha me ‘evaṃ mahantā
analyzed: saḥ mayham kujjhitvā aññassa rañño santikam gataḥ bhavissati atha me evam mahantā
translated: He became angry with me and went to another king. Then he said, ‘I will destroy the king’s army.’ I was frightened and said, ‘Do not destroy it.’

original: nāma issariyā parihīnomhī’ti cintentassa ayaṃ byādhi uppanno. Sace sakkosi tvaṃ me
