original: niggatā vijjulatā caranti, evaṃ vicarantā nagaraṃ parivāretvā rajjaṃ gaṇhathāti vadati.
analyzed: niggatāḥ vijju latā caranti evam vicarantāḥ nagaram parivāretvā rajjam gaṇhatha iti vadati
translated: and that the lightning flashes were the flashes of their swords, and that they were going about in this way in order to surround the city and take possession of the kingdom.

original: Iti so rājā gajjitvā senaṃ vicāretvā nagaradvārasamīpaṃ gantvā dvārakoṭṭhakaṃ disvā
analyzed: iti saḥ rājā gajjitvā senam vicāretvā nagara dvāra samīpam gantvā dvāra koṭṭhakam disvā
translated: So the king, having thus thundered and having sent out his army, went to the city gate and saw the gatehouse.🔽“What is this?” said he. “This is the king’s palace.”

original: “idaṃ rañño vasanageha”nti pucchitvā “ayaṃ nagaradvārakoṭṭhako”ti vutte “nagaradvārakoṭṭhako
analyzed: idam raññaḥ vasana gehanti pucchitvā ayam nagara dvāra koṭṭhako ti vutte nagara dvāra koṭṭhako
translated: “This is the city gatehouse.”🔽“If the gatehouse is such, what must the king’s palace be like?”

original: tāva evarūpo, rañño nivesanaṃ kīdisaṃ bhavissatī”ti vatvā “vejayantapāsādasadisa”nti
analyzed: tāva evarūpaḥ raññaḥ nivesanam kīdisam bhavissati iti vatvā vejayanta pāsāda sadisanti
translated: “It is like the Vejayanta Palace.”

original: sutvā “evaṃ yasasampannena raññā saddhiṃ yujjhituṃ na sakkhissāmā”ti dvārakoṭṭhakaṃ
analyzed: sutvā evam yasa sampannena raññā saddhim yujjhitum na sakkhissāma ati dvāra koṭṭhakam
translated: “We cannot fight with a king so prosperous as this.”

original: disvāva nivattitvā palāyitvā bārāṇasimeva agamāsi.
analyzed: disvā ava nivattitvā palāyitvā bārāṇasim eva agamāsi
translated: And looking at the gatehouse, he turned back and fled, and went to Bārāṇasī.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the king of Bārāṇasī was the wandering ascetic who fled, and I myself was the king of Takkasilā.”

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā bārāṇasirājā palāyitaparibbājako ahosi, takkasilarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Palāyitajātakavaṇṇanā navamā.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā bārāṇasi rājā palāyita paribbājakaḥ ahosi takkasila rājā pana aham eva ahosinti  palāyita jātaka vaṇṇanā navamā
translated: So saying, he joined the Birth:🔽“At that time the king of Bārāṇasī was the wandering ascetic who fled, and I myself was the king of Takkasilā.”🔽The Story of the Second Fledgling Birth is ended.

original: [230] 10. Dutiyapalāyitajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya palāyita jātaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Second Fledgling Birth is ended.

original: Dhajamaparimitanti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ palāyitaparibbājakameva ārabbha
analyzed: dhajam aparimitanti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam palāyita paribbājakam eva ārabbha
translated: This story the Master told, while sojourning at Jetavana, concerning a certain renegade monk.

original: kathesi. Imasmiṃ pana vatthusmiṃ so paribbājako jetavanaṃ pāvisi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe satthā
analyzed: kathesi imasmin pana vatthusmin saḥ paribbājakaḥ jetavanam pāvisi tasmin khaṇe satthā
translated: For on this occasion the renegade monk entered the monastery of Jetavana. At that moment the Master,

original: mahājanaparivuto alaṅkatadhammāsane nisinno manosilātale sīhanādaṃ nadanto sīhapotako🔽viya dhammaṃ deseti. Paribbājako dasabalassa brahmasarīrapaṭibhāgaṃ rūpaṃ puṇṇacandasassirikaṃ
analyzed: mahā jana parivutaḥ alaṅkata dhamma āsane nisinnaḥ manaḥ silā tale sīha nādam nadanto sīha potako  viya dhammaṃ deseti paribbājakaḥ dasabalassa brahma sarīra paṭibhāgam rūpam puṇṇa canda sassirikam
translated: surrounded by a great multitude, was seated on the pulpit of the Law, adorned with all its ornaments, and was preaching the Law, like a lion cub roaring on the top of a rock.

original: mukhaṃ suvaṇṇapaṭṭasadisaṃ nalāṭañca disvā “ko evarūpaṃ purisuttamaṃ jinituṃ sakkhissatī”ti
analyzed: mukham suvaṇṇa paṭṭa sadisam nalāṭam ca disvā kaḥ evarūpam purisuttamam jinitum sakkhissati iti
translated: The renegade monk, beholding the beauty of the body of the Master, which resembled the body of Brahma, and his face, which was radiant as the full moon, and his forehead, which resembled a golden plate, thought to himself, “Who is able to conquer such a man as this?”

original: nivattitvā parisantaraṃ pavisitvā palāyi. Mahājano taṃ anubandhitvā nivattitvā satthussa🔽taṃ pavattiṃ ārocesi. Satthā “na so paribbājako idāneva, pubbepi mama suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: nivattitvā parisantaram pavisitvā palāyi mahā janaḥ tam anubandhitvā nivattitvā satthussa  tam pavattim ārocesi satthā na saḥ paribbājakaḥ idānā iva pubbe pi mama suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam
translated: And turning back, he entered the outer court of the monastery and fled. The multitude pursued him, and turning back, informed the Master of his conduct.

original: mukhaṃ disvā palātoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: mukham disvā vatvā atītam āhari
translated: The Master said, “Not now only, but formerly also, when he beheld my face of golden beauty, he fled.” So saying, he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bodhisatto bārāṇasiyaṃ rajjaṃ kāresi, takkasilāyaṃ eko gandhārarājā. So “bārāṇasiṃ🔽gahessāmī”ti caturaṅginiyā senāya āgantvā nagaraṃ parivāretvā nagaradvāre ṭhito attano🔽balavāhanaṃ oloketvā “ko ettakaṃ balavāhanaṃ jinituṃ sakkhissatī”ti attano senaṃ
analyzed: atīte bodhisattaḥ bārāṇasiyam rajjam kāresi takkasilāyam ekaḥ gandhāra rājā saḥ bārāṇasim  gahessāmi iti caturaṅginiyā senāyaḥ āgantvā nagaram parivāretvā nagara dvāre ṭhitaḥ  balavāhanam oloketvā kaḥ ettakam balavāhanam jinitum sakkhissati iti attanaḥ senam
translated: Long ago, the Bodhisatta was king of Bārāṇasī, and a certain Gandhārarāja was king of Takkasilā. The latter, thinking to conquer Bārāṇasī, marched against it with his four-fold army, and, having surrounded the city, took up his position at the city gate. Looking over his own army, he said, “Who is able to conquer such a force as this?”🔽🔽

original: saṃvaṇṇetvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇetvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: Once upon a time when the Bodhisatta was ruling at Bārāṇasī, there was a king of the Gandhāras ruling at Takkasilā. He thought: “I will conquer Bārāṇasī.” So he came with a four-fold army and surrounded the city. He stood at the city gate and looked at his own army. “Who can conquer such a great army?” he thought. He praised his own army and spoke this verse:

original: “Dhajamaparimitaṃ anantapāraṃ, duppasahaṃ dhaṅkehi sāgaraṃva;
analyzed: dhajam aparimitam ananta pāram duppasaham dhaṅkehi sāgaram va
translated: “My banner is immeasurable, its end is infinite, it is invincible like the ocean by the waves,

original: Girimiva anilena duppasayho, duppasaho ahamajja tādisenā”ti.
analyzed: girim iva anilena duppasayhaḥ duppasahaḥ aham ajja tādisena ati
translated: like a mountain by the wind, I am invincible today by such an army.”

original: Tattha dhajamaparimitanti idaṃ tāva me rathesu morachade ṭhapetvā ussāpitadhajameva
analyzed: tattha dhajam aparimitanti idam tāva me rathesu mora chade ṭhapetvā ussāpita dhajam eva
translated: Herein, his banner is immeasurable means that in my chariots the banners are raised on peacock-feathers,

original: aparimitaṃ bahuṃ anekasatasaṅkhyaṃ. Anantapāranti balavāhanampi me “ettakā hatthī
analyzed: aparimitam bahum aneka sata saṅkhyam me ettakā hatthī
translated: immeasurable, many, numbering many hundreds. Its end is infinite means that my army too is infinite, its end cannot be measured, it cannot be counted thus: “So many elephants,

original: ettakā assā ettakā rathā ettakā pattī”ti gaṇanaparicchedarahitaṃ anantapāraṃ. Duppasahanti
analyzed: ettakāḥ assāḥ ettakāḥ rathāḥ ettakā pattī iti gaṇana pariccheda rahitam ananta pāram duppasahanti
translated: so many horses, so many chariots, so many foot-soldiers.” It is invincible means that it is invincible by the waves of the ocean, by the wind on a mountain.

original: na sakkā paṭisattūhi sahituṃ abhibhavituṃ. Yathā kiṃ? Dhaṅkehi sāgaraṃva, yathā sāgaro
analyzed: na sakkā paṭisattūhi sahitum abhibhavitum yathā kim dhaṅkehi sāgaram iva yathā sāgaraḥ
translated: He is incapable of being overcome by his enemies. How so? As the ocean by the birds. As the ocean,

original: bahūhi kākehi vegavikkhambhanavasena vā atikkamanavasena vā duppasaho, evaṃ duppasahaṃ.🔽Girimiva anilena duppasayhoti apica me ayaṃ balakāyo yathā pabbato vātena akampanīyato
analyzed: bahūhi kākehi vega vikkhambhana vasena vā atikkamana vasena vā duppasahaḥ evam duppasaham  girim iva anilena duppasayhaḥ ti apica me ayam balakāyaḥ yathā pabbataḥ vātena a kampanīyato
translated: is incapable of being overcome by the many crows, either by way of checking its speed or by way of passing over it, so is he incapable of being overcome.🔽As a mountain by the wind. Moreover, this my army is incapable of being overcome by another army, just as a mountain is incapable of being shaken by the wind.

original: duppasaho, tathā aññena balakāyena duppasaho. Duppasaho ahamajja tādisenāti svāhaṃ
analyzed: duppasahaḥ tathā aññena balakāyena duppasahaḥ duppasahaḥ aham ajja tādisena ati svāham
translated: Incapable of being overcome am I today by one such as he. I,

original: iminā balena samannāgato ajja tādisena duppasahoti aṭṭālake ṭhitaṃ bodhisattaṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: iminā balena samannāgataḥ ajja tādisena aṭṭālake ṭhitam bodhisattam sandhāya vadati
translated: endowed with this army, am today incapable of being overcome by one such as he. Thus he speaks, referring to the Bodisat who is standing on the Aṭṭahassa mountain.

original: Athassa so puṇṇacandasassirikaṃ attano mukhaṃ dassetvā “bāla, mā vippalapasi, idāni te balavāhanaṃ mattavāraṇo viya naḷavanaṃ viddhaṃsessāmī”ti santajjetvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa saḥ attanaḥ mukham dassetvā bāla mā vippalapasi idāni te bala vāhanam matta vāraṇaḥ viya naḷa vanam viddhaṃsessāmi iti santajjetvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the other, showing him his face, which was as beautiful as the full moon, said: “Fool, do not prattle so. Now I will crush your mighty army, as an infuriated elephant crushes a thicket of reeds.” Thus reproaching him, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Mā bāliyaṃ vilapi na hissa tādisaṃ, viḍayhase na hi labhase nisedhakaṃ;
analyzed: mā bāliyam vilapi na hi issa tādisam viḍayhase na hi labhase nisedhakam
translated: “Do not prattle, fool! There is none such as he. You will not find a check to him,

original: Āsajjasi gajamiva ekacārinaṃ, yo taṃ padā naḷamiva pothayissatī”ti.
analyzed: āsajjasi gajam iva ekacārinam yaḥ tam padā naḷam iva pothayissati iti
translated: You’re blubbering like a fool, like one who’ll be crushed by him, like a reed by the foot.

original: Tattha mā bāliyaṃ vilapīti mā attano bālabhāvaṃ vippalapasi. Na hissa tādisanti na🔽hi assa tādiso, ayameva vā pāṭho. Tādiso “anantapāraṃ me balavāhana”nti evarūpaṃ
analyzed: tattha mā bāliyam vilapi iti mā attanaḥ bāla bhāvam vippalapasi na hissa na  hi assa tādisaḥ ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ tādisaḥ ananta pāram me evarūpam
translated: Herein, don’t blubber like a fool means don’t prattle on about your own foolishness. For he’s not like that means

original: takkento rajjañca gahetuṃ samattho nāma na hi assa, na hotīti attho. Viḍayhaseti
analyzed: takkentaḥ rajjam ca gahetum samatthaḥ nāma na hi assa na hoti iti atthaḥ viḍayhasā iti
translated: for he is not like that. Or this is the reading: Tādiso na hissa, which means: “He’s not like that, he’s not able to take over the kingdom with such a boast as ‘My army is powerful and has no limits.’“ You’re just burning up means

original: tvaṃ bāla, kevalaṃ rāgadosamohamānapariḷāhena viḍayhasiyeva. Na hi labhase nisedhakanti🔽mādisaṃ pana pasayha abhibhavitvā nisedhakaṃ na tāva labhasi, ajja taṃ āgatamaggeneva🔽palāpessāmi. Āsajjasīti upagacchasi. Gajamiva ekacārinanti ekacārinaṃ mattavaravāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tvam bāla kevalam rāga dosa moha māna pariḷāhena na hi labhase  mādisam pana pasayha abhibhavitvā nisedhakam na tāva labhasi ajja tam āgata maggena iva  palāpessāmi āsajjasi iti upagacchasi gajam iva ekacārinam ti ekacārinam matta vara vāraṇam
translated: you’re just burning up with passion, hatred, delusion, conceit, and fever, O fool. For you won’t get a chance to stop me means🔽but you won’t get a chance to stop me, to overpower and overcome one like me. Today I’ll drive you away by the very path you came on. You’re blubbering means you’re approaching. Like a solitary elephant means like a solitary, rutting, excellent bull elephant. Like a reed by the foot means just as a rutting, excellent bull elephant would crush a reed with his foot,

original: viya. Yo taṃ padā naḷamiva pothayissatīti yo taṃ yathā nāma mattavaravāraṇo pādā
analyzed: viya yaḥ tam padā naḷam iva pothayissati iti yaḥ tam yathā nāma matta vara vāraṇaḥ
translated: so too, I’ll crush you with my foot.

original: naḷaṃ potheti saṃcuṇṇeti, evaṃ pothayissati, taṃ tvaṃ āsajjasīti attānaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: naḷam potheti saṃcuṇṇā iti evam pothayissati tam tvam āsajjasi iti attānam sandhāya āha
translated: “You are attacking me, who am crushing and grinding the reed.”

original: Evaṃ tajjentassa panassa kathaṃ sutvā gandhārarājā ullokento kañcanapaṭṭasadisaṃ mahānalāṭaṃ disvā attano gahaṇabhīto nivattitvā palāyanto sakanagarameva agamāsi.
analyzed: evam panassa katham sutvā gandhāra rājā ullokentaḥ kañcana paṭṭa sadisam mahā nalāṭam disvā gahaṇa bhītaḥ nivattitvā palāyantaḥ saka nagaram eva agamāsi
translated: When the king of the Gandharvas heard this, he looked up and saw the king’s great forehead, which was like a piece of gold leaf. In fear and trembling he turned and fled, and returned to his own city.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the king of the Gandharvas was the fleeing Wanderer, and I myself was the king of Benares.”

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā gandhārarājā palāyitaparibbājako ahosi, bārāṇasirājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.

original: Satthā imaṃ kāraṇaṃ dassetvā abhisambuddho hutvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –

translated: “Even so, one who flies down to the bait of the world, is tormented, following the will of the mind.

analyzed: saḥ haññatī ñāti sakhāna majjhe maccha anugaḥ soḥ iva suṃsumāroti

analyzed: haññati kilamati mahā vināsam  evam satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne

original: [234] 4. Asitābhūjātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth of Asitābhū

analyzed: na bhikkhave idāneva isā kula dhītā attha gavesikā pubbe pi attha gavesikāya iva ati vatvā atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto isipabbajjam pabbajitvā abhiññā  ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā himavanta padese vāsam kappesi tadā bārāṇasi rājā attano  puttassa brahmadatta kumārassa parivāra sampattim disvā uppanna āsaṅkaḥ puttam raṭṭhā  pabbājesi saḥ asitābhum nāma attanaḥ devim ādāya himavantam pavisitvā maccha maṃsa phala aphalāni
translated: “Monks, this girl was not only a seeker after the truth in her present life, but in a previous state of existence also she was a seeker after the truth.” So saying, he related the following

original: khādanto paṇṇasālāya nivāsaṃ kappesi. So ekaṃ kinnariṃ disvā paṭibaddhacitto “imaṃ🔽pajāpatiṃ karissāmī”ti asitābhuṃ agaṇetvā tassā anupadaṃ agamāsi. Sā taṃ kinnariṃ
analyzed: khādantaḥ paṇṇa sālāya nivāsam kappesi saḥ ekam kinnarim disvā paṭibaddha cittaḥ imaṃ 🔽pajāpatim karissāmi iti asitābhum a gaṇetvā tassāḥ anupadam agamāsi sā tam kinnarim
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, a certain seer, who had attained the Supernatural Faculties and the High Powers, was dwelling in the Himalayas. Now the king of Benares, Brahmadatta by name, having seen the splendor of the retinue of his son, Prince Brahmadatta, became envious, and banished his son from the kingdom. The prince, taking with him his wife, Asitābhū by name, entered the Himalayas, and there dwelt in a leaf-hut, subsisting upon fish, flesh, fruits, and roots. One day he saw a Kinnarī, and became enamored of her. “I will make her my wife,” said he, and without so much as asking leave of Asitābhū, he followed the Kinnarī. The Kinnarī, seeing him following her, said to him, “I am a Kinnarī, and you are a human being. We are not of the same species. Do not follow me.” But he paid no attention to her words, and continued to follow her. The Kinnarī, seeing that he was determined to follow her, took him to her home, which was a beautiful city. There she gave him a house to live in, and provided him with food and clothing. But she said to him, “You must not go outside the city.” The prince, thinking to himself, “I will go and see the city,” went out of the house. But as soon as he had gone outside the house, he found himself in the Himalayas, in the same place where he had been before.

original: anubandhamānaṃ disvā “ayaṃ maṃ agaṇetvā kinnariṃ anubandhati, kiṃ me iminā”ti virattacittā🔽hutvā bodhisattaṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā attano kasiṇaparikammaṃ kathāpetvā kasiṇaṃ
analyzed: anubandhamānam disvā ayam mam a gaṇetvā kinnarim anubandhati kim me viratta cittā  hutvā bodhisattam upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā attano kasiṇa parikammam kathāpetvā kasiṇam
translated: Seeing him following her, she thought, “He does not care for me, but follows the Kinnarī. What have I to do with him?”🔽and then she went to the Bodhisatta, paid obeisance to him, and asked him to teach her the preliminary exercise of the kasiṇa.

analyzed: olokentī abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā bodhisattam vanditvā āgantvā attano

translated: Sukhā gharā vacchanakhāti. This story the Master told while sojourning at Jetavana, concerning Roja the wrestler.

original: So kirāyasmato ānandassa gihisahāyo. So ekadivasaṃ āgamanatthāya therassa sāsanaṃ
analyzed: so kira āyasmataḥ ānandassa gihi sahāyo so eka divasam āgamana tthāya therassa sāsanam
translated: Roja, it seems, was a friend of the venerable Ānanda’s in the world. One day he sent a message to the Elder,

original: pāhesi, thero satthāraṃ āpucchitvā agamāsi. So theraṃ nānaggarasabhojanaṃ bhojetvā🔽ekamantaṃ nisinno therena saddhiṃ paṭisanthāraṃ katvā theraṃ gihibhogehi pañcahi
analyzed: thero satthāram āpucchitvā agamāsi saḥ theram nānagga rasa bhojanam bhojetvā  ekamantam nisinnaḥ therena saddhim paṭisanthāram katvā theram gihi bhogehi pañcahi
translated: saying, “Come, I will give you a feast.” The Elder, after informing the Master, went to Roja’s house. Roja entertained the Elder with a feast of choice food,

original: kāmaguṇehi nimantento “bhante ānanda, mama gehe pahūtaṃ saviññāṇakaaviññāṇakaratanaṃ,
analyzed: kāma guṇehi nimantentaḥ bhante ānanda mama gehe pahūtam sa viññāṇaka aviññāṇaka ratanam
translated: and then sat down respectfully beside him. After exchanging greetings with the Elder, Roja invited him to enjoy the pleasures of the world, saying, “Reverend Ānanda, in my house there is much wealth, both animate and inanimate.

original: idaṃ majjhe bhinditvā tuyhaṃ dammi, ehi ubho agāraṃ ajjhāvasāmā”ti. Thero tassa kāmaguṇesu
analyzed: idam majjhe bhinditvā tuyham dammi ehi ubho agāram ajjhāvasāma ti thero tassa kāma guṇesu
translated: I will divide it in two parts. I will give you one part. Come, let us both enjoy the pleasures of the world.” The Elder preached the Law to him, pointing out the peril in the pleasures of the world.

original: ādīnavaṃ kathetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ gantvā “diṭṭho te, ānanda, rojo”ti satthārā
analyzed: ādīnavam kathetvā uṭṭhāya āsanā vihāram gantvā diṭṭhaḥ te ānanda rojā iti satthārā
translated: Then he rose from his seat and went to the monastery. The Master asked him, “Ānanda, did you see Roja?”

original: pucchito “āma, bhante”ti vatvā “kimassa kathesī”ti vutte “bhante, maṃ rojo gharāvāsena
analyzed: pucchitaḥ āma bhante iti vatvā kim assa kathesi iti vutte bhante mam rojaḥ ghara āvāsena
translated: “Yes, Sir.” “What did you talk about?” “Sir, Roja invited me to enjoy the pleasures of the world.”

original: nimantesi, athassāhaṃ gharāvāse ceva kāmaguṇesu ca ādīnavaṃ kathesi”nti. Satthā “na
analyzed: nimantesi athassa aham ghara āvāse ca iva kāma guṇesu ca ādīnavam kathesinti satthā na
translated: and invited me to her house, and I preached to her the danger of the pleasures of sense and the advantages of the life of a nun.” The Teacher said:🔽

original: kho, ānanda, rojo mallo idāneva pabbajite gharāvāsena nimantesi, pubbepi nimantesiyevā”ti
analyzed: kho ānanda rojaḥ mallaḥ idānā iva pabbajite gharāvāsena nimantesi pubbe pi nimantesiya eva ati
translated: and invited me to return to the world and enjoy the pleasures of sense.” The Teacher said, “Ānanda, this is not the first time that Roja the Mallian has invited a monk to return to the world; he did the same thing in a previous state of existence.”🔽And at the request of Ānanda, he related the following

original: vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto aññatarasmiṃ nigamagāme brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ aññatarasmim nigama gāme brāhmaṇa kule
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a certain market-town in the family of a brāhman.

original: nibbattitvā vayappatto isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā himavantapadese ciraṃ vasitvā loṇambilasevanatthāya
analyzed: nibbattitvā vaya pattaḥ isipabbajjam pabbajitvā himavanta padese ciram vasitvā loṇambila sevana tthāya
translated: When he had grown up, he retired from the world and became a monk. After living for a long time in the Himalayas, he came to Bārāṇasī to obtain salt and sour gruel.

original: bārāṇasiṃ patvā rājuyyāne vasitvā punadivase bārāṇasiṃ pāvisi. Athassa bārāṇasiseṭṭhi
analyzed: bārāṇasim patvā rājuyyāne vasitvā puna divase bārāṇasim pāvisi athassa bārāṇasi seṭṭhi
translated: He spent the night in the royal park, and on the following day entered Bārāṇasī. A certain merchant of Bārāṇasī

original: ācāravihāre pasīditvā gehaṃ netvā bhojetvā uyyāne vasanatthāya paṭiññaṃ gahetvā taṃ
analyzed: ācāra vihāre pasīditvā geham netvā bhojetvā uyyāne vasana tthāya paṭiññam gahetvā tam
translated: was converted by his conduct and deportment, took him to his house, and fed him. After obtaining his promise to live in his pleasure garden,

original: paṭijagganto uyyāne vasāpesi. Te aññamaññaṃ uppannasinehā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: paṭijaggantaḥ uyyāne vasāpesi te aññamaññam uppanna sinehāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: he took care of him and caused him to live in his pleasure garden. The two became enamored of each other.

original: Athekadivasaṃ bārāṇasiseṭṭhi bodhisatte pemavissāsavasena evaṃ cintesi – “pabbajjā🔽nāma dukkhā, mama sahāyaṃ vacchanakhaparibbājakaṃ uppabbājetvā sabbaṃ vibhavaṃ majjhe🔽bhinditvā tassa datvā dvepi samaggavāsaṃ vasissāmā”ti. So ekadivasaṃ bhattakiccapariyosāne
analyzed: atha eka divasam bārāṇasi seṭṭhi bodhisatte pema vissāsa vasena evam cintesi pabbajjā  nāma dukkhā mama sahāyam vacchanakha paribbājakam uppabbājetvā sabbam vibhavam majjhe  bhinditvā tassa da tvā dve pi samagga vāsam vasissāma ati saḥ eka divasam bhatta kicca pariyosāne
translated: Now one day the merchant of Bārāṇasī, out of affection and confidence in the Bodhisatta, thought thus: “The life of a recluse is a hard life. I will get my friend, the Wanderer Vaccha, to go forth, and will divide my wealth in the middle and give him half. Then we will live together in peace and happiness.” At the end of his meal🔽he said to the Bodhisatta,

original: tena saddhiṃ madhurapaṭisanthāraṃ katvā “bhante vacchanakha, pabbajjā nāma dukkhā,
analyzed: tena saddhim madhura paṭisanthāram katvā bhante vacchanakha pabbajjā nāma dukkhā
translated: Now one day the merchant of Bārāṇasī, out of affection and confidence in the Bodhisatta, thought thus: “The life of a recluse is a hard life. I will get my friend Vaccha, the Wanderer, to go forth, and will divide all my wealth in the middle and give it to him. Then we will both live together in happiness.” At the end of the meal he made sweet conversation with him, and said: “Reverend Vaccha, the life of a recluse is a hard life.

original: sukho gharāvāso, ehi ubho samaggā kāme paribhuñjantā vasāmā”ti vatvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: sukhaḥ ghara āvāsaḥ ehi ubho samaggā kāme paribhuñjantā vasāma iti vatvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: The life of a householder is a happy life. Come, let us both live together, enjoying the pleasures of the senses.” And he pronounced the first stanza:

original: “Sukhā gharā vacchanakha, sahiraññā sabhojanā;
analyzed: sukhā gharā vaccha nakha sa hiraññā sa bhojanā
translated: “Happy is the life of home, Vaccha, with wealth and food to spare;

original: Yattha bhutvā pivitvā ca, sayeyyātha anussuko”ti.
analyzed: yattha bhutvā pivitvā ca sayeyyātha anussukoti
translated: Where, having eaten and drunk one’s fill, one may lie down and sleep secure.”

original: Tattha sahiraññāti sattaratanasampannā. Sabhojanāti bahukhādanīyabhojanīyā. Yattha
analyzed: tattha sa hiraññā ati satta ratana sampannā sa bhojanā ati bahu khādanīya bhojanīyā yattha
translated: Here “with wealth and food to spare” means possessing the seven treasures and having plenty of food and drink.

original: bhutvā pivitvā cāti yesu sahiraññabhojanesu gharesu nānaggarasāni bhojanāni paribhuñjitvā
analyzed: bhutvā pivitvā ca ati yesu sa hirañña bhojanesu gharesu nānagga rasāni bhojanāni paribhuñjitvā
translated: Having eaten and drunk, and then🔽Having eaten various kinds of food in houses where there is much to eat, and having drunk various kinds of drinks,

original: nānāpānāni ca pivitvā. Sayeyyātha anussukoti yesu alaṅkatasirisayanapiṭṭhe anussuko
analyzed: nānā pānāni ca pivitvā sayeyyātha anussuko ti yesu alaṅkata siri sayana piṭṭhe anussuko
translated: Having slept in the bed of a decorated and perfumed couch,

original: hutvā sayeyyāsi, te gharā nāma ativiya sukhāti.
analyzed: hutvā sayeyyāsi te gharā nāma ativiya sukhāti
translated: you may go to sleep. These houses are very pleasant indeed.”

original: Athassa taṃ sutvā bodhisatto “mahāseṭṭhi, tvaṃ aññāṇatāya kāmagiddho hutvā gharāvāsassa
analyzed: athassa tam sutvā bodhisattaḥ mahā seṭṭhi tvam aññāṇa tāya kāma giddhaḥ hutvā gharāvāsassa
translated: Then the Bodhisatta, having heard him, said: “Great treasurer, you, being ignorant, and infatuated with sensual pleasures, have spoken of the virtues of the household life

original: guṇaṃ, pabbajjāya ca aguṇaṃ kathesi, gharāvāsassa te aguṇaṃ kathessāmi, suṇāhi dānī”ti
analyzed: guṇam pabbajjāya ca aguṇam kathesi gharāvāsassa te aguṇam kathessāmi suṇāhi dāni iti
translated: and the faults of the homeless life. I will speak to you of the faults of the household life. Now listen.”

original: vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: And he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Gharā nānīhamānassa, gharā nābhaṇato musā;
analyzed: gharā na a nīhamānassa gharā na ābhaṇataḥ musā
translated: “The house is not for one who does not strive, the house is not for one who tells a lie;

original: Gharā nādinnadaṇḍassa, paresaṃ anikubbato;
analyzed: na a dinna daṇḍassa paresam a nikubbataḥ
translated: The house is not for one who does not give, the house is not for one who does not act for others;

original: Evaṃ chiddaṃ durabhisambhavaṃ, ko gharaṃ paṭipajjatī”ti.
analyzed: evam chiddam durabhisambhavam kaḥ gharam paṭipajjati iti
translated: Thus the house is hard to enter, who will enter the house?”

original: Tattha gharā nānīhamānassāti niccakālaṃ kasigorakkhādikaraṇena anīhamānassa avāyamantassa
analyzed: tattha gharā na anīhamānassa ati nicca kālam kasi gorakkha ādi karaṇena anīhamānassa avāyamantassa
translated: Herein, the house is not for one who does not strive: for one who does not strive, who does not exert himself, by constantly working at agriculture, cattle-rearing, and so on.

original: gharā nāma natthi, gharāvāso na patiṭṭhātīti attho. Gharā nābhaṇato musāti khettavatthuhiraññasuvaṇṇādīnaṃ🔽atthāya amusābhaṇatopi gharā nāma natthi. Gharā nādinnadaṇḍassa, paresaṃ anikubbatoti🔽nādinnadaṇḍassāti aggahitadaṇḍassa, nikkhittadaṇḍassa paresaṃ anikubbato gharā nāma
analyzed: gharā nāma natthi gharā vāsaḥ na patiṭṭhāti iti atthaḥ gharā na ābhaṇataḥ musā ti khetta vatthu hirañña suvaṇṇa ādīnam  atthāya amusā bhaṇataḥ pi gharā nāma natthi gharā na ādinna daṇḍassa paresam a nikubbato ti  na ādinna daṇḍassa ati aggahita daṇḍassa nikkhitta daṇḍassa paresam a nikubbataḥ gharā nāma
translated: For the sake of fields, land, gold, silver, etc., there is no house for one who does not tell lies.🔽There is no house for one who does not carry a stick, who does not oppress others.🔽“Who does not carry a stick” means one who does not hold a stick, one who has laid aside a stick. There is no house for one who does not oppress others.

original: natthi. Yo pana ādinnadaṇḍo hutvā paresaṃ dāsakammakarādīnaṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ aparādhe
analyzed: natthi yaḥ pana ādinna daṇḍaḥ hutvā paresam dāsa kammakara ādīnam tasmim tasmim aparādhe
translated: But the meaning is: there is a household life for one who carries a stick and who, in the various offenses of servants, laborers, etc.,

original: aparādhānurūpaṃ vadhabandhanachedanatāḷanādivasena karoti, tasseva gharāvāso saṇṭhahatīti
analyzed: aparādha anurūpam vadha bandhana chedana tāḷana ādi vasena karoti tassa iva ghara āvāsaḥ saṇṭhahati iti
translated: acts in accordance with the offense by way of killing, binding, cutting off a limb, beating, etc.

original: attho. Evaṃ chiddaṃ durabhisambhavaṃ, ko gharaṃ paṭipajjatīti taṃ dāni evaṃ etesaṃ
analyzed: attho evam chiddam durabhisambhavam kaḥ gharam paṭipajjati iti tam dāni evam etesam
translated: Thus, when there is a breach, how difficult to enter upon, who would enter upon a house?🔽Now, when there is no doing of these things, such as coveting, etc., and when there is the making of a breach by way of the various kinds of loss,

original: īhanādīnaṃ akaraṇe sati tāya tāya parihāniyā chiddaṃ karaṇepi sati niccameva kātabbato
analyzed: īhanā ādīnam akaraṇe sati tāya tāya parihāniyā chiddam karaṇe api sati niccam eva kātabbato
translated: because of the necessity of always doing them,

original: durabhisambhavaṃ durārādhanīyaṃ, niccaṃ karontassapi vā durabhisambhavameva duppūraṃ
analyzed: durabhisambhavam durārādhanīyam niccam karontaḥ api vā durabhisambhavam eva duppūram
translated: “It is hard to find a home that is not a source of trouble, and even if you find one, it is hard to fill it.”

original: gharāvāsaṃ “ahaṃ nipparitasso hutvā ajjhāvasissāmī”ti ko paṭipajjatīti.
analyzed: ghara āvāsam aham nipparitassaḥ hutvā ajjhāvasissāmi iti kaḥ paṭipajjati iti
translated: Who is there that would live in a home, thinking, “I will live in a home without being troubled by the cares of the world?”

original: Evaṃ mahāsatto gharāvāsassa dosaṃ kathetvā uyyānameva agamāsi.
analyzed: evam mahāsattaḥ ghara āvāsassa dosam kathetvā uyyānam eva agamāsi
translated: Thus did the Great Being declare the evils of a home and then return to the garden.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā bārāṇasiseṭṭhi rojo mallo ahosi, vacchanakhaparibbājako pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā bārāṇasi seṭṭhi rojaḥ mallaḥ ahosi vacchanakha paribbājakaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this parable, he identified the Birth-Story, saying, “At that time the chief of Benares was Roja the Mallian, and I myself was the Wanderer Vaccha-Khaka.”🔽Thus did the Master tell the story of the past.

original: Vacchanakhajātakavaṇṇanā pañcamā.🔽[236] 6. Bakajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vaccha nakha jātaka vaṇṇanā pañcamā
translated: The Birth-Story of Vaccha-Khaka.

original: Bhaddako vatayaṃ pakkhīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ kuhakabhikkhuṃ ārabbha
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ vata ayam pakkhī ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam kuhaka bhikkhum ārabbha
translated: “How good a bird is this!” This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a certain crafty monk.

original: kathesi. Tañhi satthā ānetvā dassitaṃ disvā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepesa kuhakoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: kathesi tat hi satthā ānetvā dassitam disvā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pesa iva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: For the Master brought him, and showed him to the monks, saying, “Monks, this is not the first time he has been crafty; in a previous state of existence also he was crafty.” And so saying, he told a story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto himavantapadese ekasmiṃ sare
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ himavanta padese ekasmin sare
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was a fish in a lake in the Himalayas.

original: maccho hutvā mahāparivāro vasi. Atheko bako “macche khādissāmī”ti sarassa āsannaṭṭhāne
analyzed: macchaḥ hutvā mahā parivāraḥ vasi atha ekaḥ bakaḥ macche khādissāmi iti sarassa āsanna ṭhāne
translated: He had a large retinue. Now a crane, thinking to eat fish,

original: sīsaṃ pātetvā pakkhe pasāretvā mandamando macche olokento aṭṭhāsi tesaṃ pamādaṃ āgamayamāno.
analyzed: sīsam pātetvā pakkhe pasāretvā manda mandaḥ macche olokento aṭṭhāsi tesam pamādam āgamayamāno
translated: lowered his head near the lake, spread out his wings, and stood looking slowly round at the fish, waiting for them to show carelessness.

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe bodhisatto macchagaṇaparivuto gocaraṃ gaṇhanto taṃ ṭhānaṃ pāpuṇi. Macchagaṇo
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe bodhisattaḥ macchagaṇa parivutaḥ gocaram gaṇhantaḥ tam ṭhānam pāpuṇi macchagaṇaḥ
translated: At that moment the Bodhisatta, with a crowd of fish about him, came to that place in search of food. The crowd of fish

original: taṃ bakaṃ passitvā paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam bakam passitvā paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: saw the crane, and spoke the first stanza:

original: “Bhaddako vatayaṃ pakkhī, dijo kumudasannibho;
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ vatayam pakkhī dijaḥ kumuda sannibho
translated: “Happy is this bird, a god, like a white water-lily;

original: Vūpasantehi pakkhehi, mandamandova jhāyatī”ti.
analyzed: vūpasantehi pakkhehi manda mandaḥ uva jhāyati iti
translated: With his wings folded up, he sits and broods, slowly, slowly.”

original: Tattha mandamandova jhāyatīti abalabalo viya hutvā kiñci ajānanto viya ekakova jhāyatīti.
analyzed: tattha manda mandaḥ uva jhāyati iti abala balaḥ viya hutvā kiñci a jānantaḥ viya ekakaḥ iva jhāyati iti
translated: Here “slowly, slowly” means that he sits alone as if he were helpless and knew nothing.

original: Atha naṃ bodhisatto oloketvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam bodhisattaḥ oloketvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the Bodhisatta looked at him and spoke the second stanza:

original: “Nāssa sīlaṃ vijānātha, anaññāya pasaṃsatha;
analyzed: na assa sīlam vijānātha an aññāya pasaṃsatha
translated: “His virtue you do not know, nor why we praise him;

original: Amhe dijo na pāleti, tena pakkhī na phandatī”ti.
analyzed: amhe dijaḥ na pāleti tena pakkhī na phandati iti
translated: The bird does not fly, because the fish does not protect me.”

original: Tattha anaññāyāti ajānitvā. Amhe dijo na pāletīti esa dijo amhe na rakkhati na gopāyati,
analyzed: tattha an aññāya ati a jānitvā amhe dijaḥ na pāleti iti esa dijaḥ amhe na rakkhati na gopāyati
translated: Herein, not knowing means not having understood. The bird does not fly means that this fish does not protect me, does not guard me.

original: “kataraṃ nu kho etesu kabaḷaṃ karissāmī”ti upadhāreti. Tena pakkhī na phandatīti
analyzed: kataram nu khalu etesu kabaḷam karissāmi iti upadhāreti tena pakkhī na phandati iti
translated: “Which of these morsels shall I eat?” He thinks thus. The bird does not fly means

original: tenāyaṃ sakuṇo na phandati na calatīti. Evaṃ vutte macchagaṇo udakaṃ khobhetvā bakaṃ palāpesi.
analyzed: tena ayam sakuṇaḥ na phandati na calati iti evam vutte macchagaṇaḥ udakam khobhetvā bakam palāpesi
translated: that this bird does not fly, does not move. When this was said, the shoal of fish churned up the water and frightened the crane.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā bako kuhako bhikkhu ahosi, maccharājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Bakajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.🔽[237] 7. Sāketajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Ko nu kho bhagavā hetūti idaṃ satthā sāketaṃ upanissāya viharanto sāketaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā bakaḥ kuhakaḥ bhikkhu ahosi maccha rājā pana aham eva ahosinti  baka jātaka vaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā        kaḥ nu kho bhagavā hetu iti idam satthā sāketam upanissāya viharantaḥ sāketam brāhmaṇam
translated: After telling this story, the Master identified the Birth: “At that time the crane was the deceitful monk, and I myself was the king of the fish.”

original: [239] 9. Haritamaṇḍūkajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Master told this lesson while dwelling in Jetavana, and referring to a certain monk. The story goes that this monk, who was a novice in the time of Kassapa Buddha, was once sent by his teacher to a village for some oil. He took a measure, and going to a shop, asked for oil. The shopman filled the measure with oil, and the novice, taking it, went on his way. On the road he met a friend, and the two went to a shop and bought some cakes. They sat down and began to eat the cakes, and the oil-measure was placed on one side. When they had finished eating, the novice took the measure and went on his way. The shopman saw him, and said, “You have not paid for the cakes.” “I have not had any cakes,” said the novice. “You have,” said the shopman. “I have not,” said the novice. “You have,” said the shopman. “You have not,” said the novice. Thus they disputed, and the novice was arrested and taken before the king. The king asked him, “Did you or did you not eat the cakes?” “I did not,” said the novice. “You did,” said the king. “I did not,” said the novice. “You did,” said the king. “You did not,” said the novice. “You did,” said the king. “You did not,” said the novice. “You did,” said the king. “You did not,” said the novice. “You did,” said the king. “You did not,” said the novice. “You did,” said the king. “

analyzed: domanassa patto kañci a jānāpetvā ava pavisati atha eka divasam dhammasabhāyam bhikkhū
translated: in the Hall of Truth, were discussing the matter.

original: kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ “āvuso, ajātasattu mātulaṃ jinitvā tussati, parājito domanassappatto
analyzed: katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso ajātasattu mātulam jinitvā tussati parājitaḥ domanassa ppatto

original: hotī”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: hoti iti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā
translated: The Teacher came in and asked them, “Monks, what is it that you are sitting here now talking about?”

original: “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepesa jinitvā tussati, parājito
analyzed: imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pesa jinitvā tussati parājitaḥ
translated: When they told him, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time he has been pleased with his victory and his opponent grieved at his defeat;

analyzed: domanassa patto hoti iti vatvā atītam āhari
translated: in a previous state of existence also he was pleased with his victory and his opponent grieved at his defeat.” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto nīlamaṇḍūkayoniyaṃ nibbatti.
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ nīlamaṇḍūka yoniyam nibbatti
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn as a blue frog.

original: Tadā manussā nadīkandarādīsu tattha tattha macche gahaṇatthāya kumīnāni oḍḍesuṃ.🔽Ekasmiṃ kumīne bahū macchā pavisiṃsu. Atheko udakāsīviso macche khādanto taṃ kumīnaṃ
analyzed: tadā manussāḥ nadī kandara ādīsu tattha tattha macche gahaṇa atthāya kumīnāni oḍḍesuṃ  ekasmin kumīne bahū macchā pavisiṃsu atha ekaḥ uda kāsīvisaḥ macche khādantaḥ tam kumīnam
translated: At that time men were in the habit of setting nets in the rivers and other waters for the purpose of catching fish.🔽In one of these nets many fish were caught. Now a water-snake, in search of food, came to the net and

analyzed: pāvisi bahū macchāḥ ekatas hutvā tam khādantāḥ eka lohitam akaṃsu so paṭisaraṇam a passanto

original: maraṇabhayatajjito kumīnamukhena nikkhamitvā vedanāppatto udakapariyante nipajji.
analyzed: maraṇa bhaya tajjitaḥ kumīna mukhena nikkhamitvā vedanā appatto udaka pariyante nipajji
translated: and, terrified at the fear of death, he came out through the mouth of the crocodile and, overcome with pain, lay down at the edge of the water.

original: Nīlamaṇḍūkopi tasmiṃ khaṇe uppatitvā kumīnasūlamatthake nipanno hoti. Āsīviso vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nīla maṇḍūkaḥ api tasmin khaṇe uppatitvā kumīna sūla matthake nipannaḥ hoti āsīvisaḥ vinicchaya ṭṭhānam
translated: At that moment the blue frog had jumped up and was sitting on the top of the crocodile’s horn. The snake, unable to find a place to settle down,

original: alabhanto tattha nipannaṃ taṃ disvā “samma nīlamaṇḍūka, imesaṃ macchānaṃ kiriyā ruccati
analyzed: a labhanto tattha nipannam tam disvā samma nīla maṇḍūkaḥ imesam macchānam kiriyā ruccati
translated: saw him sitting there and asked, “My dear blue frog, do you approve of the way these fish are acting?

original: tuyha”nti pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: ” and, asking this, he spoke the first stanza:

original: “Āsīvisampi maṃ santaṃ, paviṭṭhaṃ kumināmukhaṃ;
analyzed: mam santam paviṭṭham kumināmukham
translated: “Though I am a snake, a poisonous snake, and have entered the mouth of a crocodile,

original: Ruccate haritāmātā, yaṃ maṃ khādanti macchakā”ti.
analyzed: ruccate haritāmātā yam mam khādanti mat śakāti
translated: I approve of the way the fish are eating me.”

original: Tattha āsīvisampi maṃ santanti maṃ āgatavisaṃ samānaṃ. Ruccate haritāmātā, yaṃ maṃ khādanti macchakāti etaṃ tava ruccati haritamaṇḍūkaputtāti vadati.
analyzed: tattha āsīvisam pi mam āgatavisam samānam ruccate yam mam khādanti etam tava ruccati harita maṇḍūka putta ati vadati
translated: Herein, though I am a snake, a poisonous snake means though I am a snake, a snake with poison that has come. I approve of the way the fish are eating me means this is approved by you, O son of the green frog.

original: Atha naṃ haritamaṇḍūko “āma, samma, ruccatī”ti. “Kiṃkāraṇā”ti? “Sace tvampi tava
analyzed: atha nam harita maṇḍūkaḥ sace tvam pi tava
translated: Then the green frog said, “Yes, my dear, I approve.” “Why?” “If you too

original: padesaṃ āgate macche khādasi, macchāpi attano padesaṃ āgataṃ taṃ khādanti, attano
analyzed: padesam āgate macche khādasi maccha api attano padesam āgatam tam khādanti attano
translated: He eats the fish that come into his own territory, and the fish eat him when he comes into their territory.

original: visaye padese gocarabhūmiyaṃ abalavā nāma natthī”ti vatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: visaye padese gocara bhūmiyam abalavā nāma natthi iti vatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: There is no one who is weak in his own territory, in his own domain, in his own range.” Then he uttered the second stanza:

original: “Vilumpateva puriso, yāvassa upakappati;
analyzed: vilumpatā iva purisaḥ yāva assa upakappati
translated: “The man who robs another, so long as he is not himself robbed,

original: Yadā caññe vilumpanti, so vilutto vilumpatī”ti.
analyzed: yadā caññe vilumpanti saḥ viluttaḥ vilumpati iti
translated: When others rob him, then the robber is robbed.”

original: Tattha vilumpateva puriso, yāvassa upakappatīti yāva assa purisassa issariyaṃ upakappati
analyzed: tattha vilumpatā iva purisaḥ yāva assa upakappati iti yāva assa purisassa issariyam upakappati
translated: Herein, the man who robs another, so long as he is not himself robbed means that so long as his own power and influence are not robbed,

original: ijjhati pavattati, tāva so aññaṃ vilumpatiyeva. “Yāva so upakappatī”tipi pāṭho, yattakaṃ🔽kālaṃ so puriso sakkoti vilumpitunti attho. Yadā caññe vilumpantīti yadā ca aññe
analyzed: ijjhati pavattati tāva so aññam vilumpati yāva so upakappati iti pi pāṭhaḥ yattakam  kālam so puriso sakkoti vilumpitunti atthaḥ yadā ca aññe vilumpanti iti yadā ca aññe
translated: so long as they are not taken away from him, he robs another. “So long as he is not himself robbed” is also a reading, the meaning of which is: for as long as he is able to rob.

original: issarā hutvā vilumpanti. So vilutto vilumpatīti atha so vilumpako aññehi vilumpati.
analyzed: issarāḥ hutvā vilumpanti saḥ viluttaḥ vilumpati iti atha so vilumpakaḥ aññehi vilumpati
translated: When others rob him means when others become powerful and rob him. Then the robber is robbed means then the robber is robbed by others.

original: “Vilumpate”tipi pāṭho, ayamevattho. “Vilumpana”ntipi paṭhanti, tassattho na sameti.
analyzed: vilumpatā iti pi pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ vilumpanam tipi paṭhanti tassa atthaḥ na sameti
translated: “The robber is robbed” is also a reading, the meaning of which is the same. “The robber is robbed” is also a reading, the meaning of which is not correct.

original: Evaṃ “vilumpako puna vilumpaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti bodhisattena aḍḍe vinicchite udakāsīvisassa
analyzed: evam vilumpakaḥ puna vilumpam pāpuṇāti iti bodhisattena aḍḍe vinicchite uda kāsīvisassa
translated: When the Bodhisatta had thus decided the case, the water-snake,

original: dubbalabhāvaṃ ñatvā “paccāmittaṃ gaṇhissāmā”ti macchagaṇā kumīnamukhā nikkhamitvā
analyzed: dubbala bhāvam ñatvā pacca amittam gaṇhissāma ati macchagaṇā kumīna mukhā nikkhamitvā
translated: knowing that he was weak, the fishes, thinking, “We will seize our enemy,” came out of the mouth of the crocodile,

original: tattheva naṃ jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpetvā pakkamuṃ.
analyzed: tattha iva nam jīvita khayam pāpetvā pakkamum
translated: and there and then killed him and went their way.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the water-snake was Ajātasattu, and I myself was the green frog.”

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā udakāsīviso ajātasattu ahosi, nīlamaṇḍūko pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā udakāsīvisaḥ ajātasattu ahosi nīlamaṇḍūko pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: So saying, he joined the connection, and identified the Birth: “At that time Devadatta was the water-snake, and I myself was the green frog.”

original: Haritamaṇḍūkajātakavaṇṇanā navamā.
analyzed: harita maṇḍūka jātaka vaṇṇanā navamā
translated: The Birth of the Green Frog.

original: [240] 10. Mahāpiṅgalajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: 10. The Birth of the Great Tawny One.

original: Sabbo janoti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto devadattaṃ ārabbha kathesi. Devadatte
analyzed: sabbaḥ janaḥ ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ devadattam ārabbha kathesi devadatte
translated: This story the Master, while dwelling in Jetavana, told concerning Devadatta. Devadatta,

original: satthari āghātaṃ bandhitvā navamāsaccayena jetavanadvārakoṭṭhake pathaviyaṃ nimugge
analyzed: satthari āghātam bandhitvā nava māsa cayena jetavana dvāra koṭṭhake pathaviyam nimugge
translated: having conceived hatred against the Master, after nine months, was swallowed up in the earth at the gate of Jetavana.

original: jetavanavāsino ca sakalaraṭṭhavāsino ca “buddhapaṭikaṇṭako devadatto pathaviyā gilito,
analyzed: jetavana vāsino ca sakala raṭṭha vāsino ca buddha paṭikaṇṭakaḥ devadatto pathaviyā gilitaḥ
translated: The dwellers in Jetavana and the inhabitants of the whole kingdom, saying, “Devadatta, the enemy of Buddha, has been swallowed up by the earth,

original: nihatapaccāmitto dāni sammāsambuddho jāto”ti tuṭṭhahaṭṭhā ahesuṃ. Tesaṃ kathaṃ sutvā
analyzed: nihata paccāmittaḥ dāni sammāsambuddhaḥ jātaḥ iti tuṭṭha haṭṭhāḥ ahesum tesam katham sutvā
translated: “Now the Supremely Enlightened One has destroyed his foes.” And they were filled with joy.

original: paramparaghosena sakalajambudīpavāsino yakkhabhūtadevagaṇā ca tuṭṭhahaṭṭhā eva ahesuṃ.🔽Athekadivasaṃ bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ – “āvuso, devadatte pathaviyaṃ
analyzed: parampara ghosena sakala jambudīpa vāsinaḥ yakkha bhūta deva gaṇā ca tuṭṭha haṭṭhāḥ eva ahesuṃ  atha eka divasam bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso devadatte pathaviyam
translated: And hearing their talk, the Yakkhas, Bhūtas, and Devas dwelling in all Jambudīpa were filled with joy.

original: nimugge ‘buddhapaṭikaṇṭako devadatto pathaviyā gilito’ti mahājano attamano jāto”ti.
analyzed: nimugge buddha paṭikaṇṭakaḥ devadatto pathaviyā gilitaḥ iti mahā janaḥ atta manaḥ jātaḥ iti
translated: One day the monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth: “Brethren, when Devadatta was swallowed up in the earth, the people were filled with joy and cried, ‘Devadatta, the enemy of Buddha, has been swallowed up in the earth.’ ”

original: Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya🔽nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva devadatte mate mahājano tussati ceva hasati
analyzed: satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya  nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva devadatte mate mahājanaḥ tussati ca iva hasati
translated: The Teacher drew near and asked, “Monks, what is the subject that engages your attention now as you sit here all gathered together?” When they told him,

original: ca, pubbepi tussi ceva hasi cā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: ca pubbe pi tussi ca iva hasi ca ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: he said, “Monks, this is not the first time the people have been filled with joy and cried, ‘Devadatta, the enemy of Buddha, has been swallowed up in the earth.’ ” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ mahāpiṅgalo nāma rājā adhammena visamena rajjaṃ kāresi, chandādivasena
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam mahāpiṅgalaḥ nāma rājā adhammena visamena rajjam kāresi chanda ādi vasena
translated: In the dispensation of the Supremely Enlightened One Kassapa, in the city of Bārāṇasī, there ruled a king named Mahāpiṅgala. He governed unrighteously and unjustly, according to his own caprice.

original: pāpakammāni karonto daṇḍabalijaṅghakahāpaṇādiggahaṇena ucchuyante ucchuṃ viya mahājanaṃ🔽pīḷesi kakkhaḷo pharuso sāhasiko, paresu anuddayāmattampi nāmassa natthi, gehe itthīnampi🔽puttadhītānampi amaccabrāhmaṇagahapatikādīnampi appiyo amanāpo, akkhimhi patitarajaṃ
analyzed: pāpa kammāni karontaḥ daṇḍa bali jaṅgha kahā paṇa ādi ggahaṇena ucchuyante ucchum viya mahājanam  pīḷesi kakkhaḷaḥ pharusaḥ sāhasiko paresu an uddayāmattam pi nāmassa natthi gehe itthīnam pi  putta dhītānam pi amacca brāhmaṇa gahapatika ādīnam appiyaḥ amanāpaḥ akkhimhi patita rajam
translated: He oppressed the people with the seizure of fines, of forced labour, of conveyances, of garlands, perfumes and so on,🔽he was harsh, rough, violent, he had no pity for others, he was not dear or pleasing to his wives in his house,🔽to his sons and daughters, to his ministers, brahmans, lay people, etc., he was like a speck of dust in the eye,

original: viya, bhattapiṇḍe sakkharā viya, paṇhiṃ vijjhitvā paviṭṭhakaṇṭako viya ca ahosi.
analyzed: viya bhatta piṇḍe sakkharā viya paṇhim vijjhitvā paviṭṭha kaṇṭakaḥ viya ca ahosi
translated: He oppressed the people with the exaction of taxes, of forced labour, of fines, of confiscations, and so on. He was harsh, cruel, and violent, and had no pity even for his own people. He was not dear or beloved to his wives, his sons and daughters, his ministers, brahmans, householders, and so on. He was as disagreeable to them as a speck of dust in the eye, as a grain of sand in the mouth, as a thorn in the foot.

original: Tadā bodhisatto mahāpiṅgalassa putto hutvā nibbatti. Mahāpiṅgalo dīgharattaṃ rajjaṃ🔽kāretvā kālamakāsi. Tasmiṃ kālakate sakalabārāṇasivāsino haṭṭhatuṭṭhā mahāhasitaṃ
analyzed: tadā bodhisattaḥ mahāpiṅgalassa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti mahāpiṅgalaḥ dīgharattam rajjam  kāretvā kālam akāsi tasmin kālakate sakala bārāṇasi vāsinaḥ haṭṭha tuṭṭhāḥ mahā hasitam
translated: Now the Bodhisatta was born as the son of Mahāpiṅgala. Mahāpiṅgala reigned a long time,🔽and then died. When he was dead, all the inhabitants of Bārāṇasī were delighted and rejoiced greatly.

original: hasitvā dārūnaṃ sakaṭasahassena mahāpiṅgalaṃ jhāpetvā anekehi ghaṭasahassehi āḷāhanaṃ
analyzed: hasitvā sakaṭa sahassena mahā piṅgalam jhāpetvā anekehi ghaṭa sahassehi āḷāhanam
translated: They burned Mahāpiṅgala with a thousand cartloads of wood, and extinguished the fire with many thousands of jars of water.

original: nibbāpetvā bodhisattaṃ rajje abhisiñcitvā “dhammiko no rājā laddho”ti haṭṭhatuṭṭhā
analyzed: nibbāpetvā bodhisattam rajje abhisiñcitvā dhammikaḥ naḥ rājā laddhaḥ iti haṭṭha tuṭṭhā
translated: Then they anointed the Bodhisatta king, and being delighted and joyful, they said, “We have obtained a righteous king.”

original: nagare ussavabheriṃ carāpetvā samussitadhajapaṭākaṃ nagaraṃ alaṅkaritvā dvāre dvāre
analyzed: nagare ussava bherim cara āpetvā samussita dhaja paṭākam nagaram alaṅkaritvā dvāre dvāre
translated: and had the city decorated with flags and banners. At the city gates

original: maṇḍapaṃ kāretvā vippakiṇṇalājakusumamaṇḍitatalesu alaṅkatamaṇḍapesu nisīditvā khādiṃsu ceva piviṃsu ca.
analyzed: maṇḍapam kāretvā vippakiṇṇa lāja kusuma maṇḍita talesu alaṅkata maṇḍapesu nisīditvā khādiṃsu ca iva piviṃsu ca
translated: he had pavilions erected, and in these, which were adorned with garlands of flowers and were tastefully decorated, he and his retinue sat down and ate and drank.

original: Bodhisattopi alaṅkate mahātale samussitasetacchattassa pallaṅkavarassa majjhe mahāyasaṃ🔽anubhavanto nisīdi. Amaccā ca brāhmaṇagahapatiraṭṭhikadovārikādayo ca rājānaṃ parivāretvā
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ api alaṅkate mahā tale samussita seta chattassa pallaṅka varassa majjhe mahā āyasam  anubhavantaḥ nisīdi amaccā ca brāhmaṇa gaha pati raṭṭhika dovārika ādayo ca rājānam parivāretvā
translated: The Bodhisatta, too, sat down in the middle of a magnificent dais, under a white sunshade held over his head, on a splendid couch,

original: aṭṭhaṃsu. Atheko dovāriko nātidūre ṭhatvā assasanto passasanto parodi. Bodhisatto
analyzed: atha ekaḥ dovārikaḥ na atidūre ṭhatvā assasantaḥ passasantaḥ parodi bodhisatto
translated: surrounded by his ministers, brāhmans, householders, country people, door-keepers, and others. Now one of the door-keepers, who was standing not far off, began to sigh and weep. The Bodhisatta,

original: taṃ disvā “samma dovārika, mama pitari kālakate sabbe tuṭṭhapahaṭṭhā ussavaṃ kīḷantā
analyzed: tam disvā samma dovārika mama pitari kāla kate sabbe tuṭṭha pahaṭṭhāḥ ussavam kīḷantā
translated: seeing him, said, “Good door-keeper, when my father died, all were well pleased and went about rejoicing and making merry,

original: vicaranti, tvaṃ pana rodamāno ṭhito, kiṃ nu kho mama pitā taveva piyo ahosi manāpo”ti
analyzed: vicaranti tvam pana rodamānaḥ ṭhitaḥ kim nu khalu mama pitā tava iva piyaḥ ahosi manāpā uti
translated: but you are standing here weeping. Was my father dear to you and beloved?”

original: pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: And asking this, he spoke the first stanza:—

original: “Sabbo jano hiṃsito piṅgalena, tasmiṃ mate paccayā vedayanti;
analyzed: sabbaḥ janaḥ hiṃsitaḥ piṅgalena tasmim mate paccayāḥ vedayanti
translated: “All people were oppressed by Piṅgala, when he died, his dependents felt pain.

original: Piyo nu te āsi akaṇhanetto, kasmā nu tvaṃ rodasi dvārapālā”ti.
analyzed: piyaḥ nu te āsi a kaṇha netto kasmai nu tvam rodasi dvārapāla ati
translated: Was he dear to you, you of the unclouded eye? Why do you weep, O doorkeeper?”

original: Tattha hiṃsitoti nānappakārehi daṇḍabaliādīhi pīḷito. Piṅgalenāti piṅgalakkhena.
analyzed: tattha hiṃsito ti nānappakārehi daṇḍa bali ādīhi pīḷitaḥ piṅgalena ati piṅga lakkhena
translated: There, “oppressed” means afflicted by various kinds of punishments, taxes, etc. “Piṅgala” means “tawny-coloured.”

original: Tassa kira dvepi akkhīni nibbiddhapiṅgalāni biḷārakkhivaṇṇāni ahesuṃ, tenevassa “piṅgalo”ti
analyzed: tassa kira dve pi akkhīni nibbiddha piṅgalāni biḷārakkhi vaṇṇāni ahesum tena iva assa piṅgalaḥ ti
translated: It is said that both his eyes were tawny-coloured like the eyes of a cat, and that is why they gave him the name “Piṅgala.”

original: nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Paccayā vedayantīti pītiyo pavedayanti. Akaṇhanettoti piṅgalanetto.
analyzed: nāmam paccayā vedayanti iti pītiyaḥ pavedayanti a kaṇha netto ti piṅgala netto
translated: “His dependents felt pain” means they felt joy. “Unclouded eye” means tawny-coloured eye.

original: Kasmā nu tvanti kena nu kāraṇena tvaṃ rodasi. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “kasmā tuva”nti pāṭho.
analyzed: kasmai nu kena nu kāraṇena tvam rodasi pana kasmai
translated: “Why do you weep” means for what reason do you weep? But in the commentary the reading is “kasmā tuva.”

analyzed: siṅgālaḥ mānatthaddhaḥ ca parivārena atthiko
translated: and seeking a retinue,🔽obtained a great kingdom,

analyzed: evam eva manussesu yaḥ hoti parivāravā
translated: he who has a retinue,🔽is great among them,

original: So hi tattha mahā hoti, siṅgālo viya dāṭhina”nti.
analyzed: saḥ hi tattha mahā hoti siṅgālaḥ viya

translated: The commentary on the Sunakkha Jātaka🔽When the Teacher was dwelling in Jeta’s Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof, he told this story about a dog that ate food in the āsanasālā.

analyzed: atha eka divasam ekaḥ gāma vāsī puriso tam ṭhānam patto su nakham disvā pānīya hārakānam  uttari sāṭakam ca kahāpaṇam ca da tvā gaddūlena bandhitvā tam ādāya saḥ gahetvā
translated: One day a certain villager came to that place, saw the dog, and gave the water-carriers

analyzed: nīyamānaḥ na vassi dinnam dinnam khādanto pacchatas pacchatas agamāsi atha saḥ puriso

analyzed: gataḥ bhikkhū tam disvā tena gata kāraṇam jānitvā sāyanha samaye dhamma sabhāyam katham  samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso āsana sālāya su nakhaḥ bandhana mokkha kusalaḥ vissaṭṭha mattaḥ va

translated: but in a previous state of existence also he was skilled in this.” And so saying, he related a story of the past.

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto kāsiraṭṭhe ekasmin mahā bhogakule  nibbattitvā vaya ppattaḥ ghara āvāsam aggahesi tadā bārāṇasiyam ekassa manussassa sunakhaḥ
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a family of great wealth in the kingdom of Kāsi.🔽When he grew up, he took unto himself a wife, and at that time in Benares there was a certain man who had a dog.

original: ahosi, so piṇḍibhattaṃ labhanto thūlasarīro jāto. Atheko gāmavāsī bārāṇasiṃ āgato
analyzed: saḥ piṇḍi bhattam labhantaḥ thūla sarīraḥ jātaḥ atha ekaḥ gāma vāsī bārāṇasim āgataḥ
translated: This dog, getting his food by begging, had grown fat. Now a certain villager came to Benares,

translated: Foolish indeed is this dog, that he does not eat the bait;

translated: And yet he will be freed from the trap, and go home without a care.

translated: Here ‘he will be freed’ means ‘he will be released’; this is the reading. ‘And go home without a care’ means that he will go to his own dwelling place, well-fed and happy.

translated: Hearing this, the dog spoke the second stanza:

translated: I have decided, I have made up my mind, and I have set my heart on it;

translated: ‘I have set my heart on it’ means ‘I have set my heart on this’;

analyzed: kālam ca paṭikaṅkhāmi iti kālam paṭimānemi yāva jano ti yāva ayam mahā janaḥ pasupatu  niddam okkamatu tāva aham kālam paṭimānemi itarathā hi ayam su nakhaḥ palāyati iti
translated: I will wait for the time when the great multitude will be asleep.🔽Otherwise there will be a cry of “The dog is running away!”

original: ravo uppajjeyya, tasmā rattibhāge sabbesaṃ suttakāle cammayottaṃ khāditvā palāyissāmīti.
analyzed: ravaḥ uppajjeyya tasmā ratti bhāge sabbesam sutta kāle camma yottam khāditvā palāyissāmi iti
translated: Therefore I will wait until all are asleep, and then I will eat the leather strap and run away.”

original: So evaṃ vatvā mahājane niddaṃ okkante yottaṃ khāditvā suhito hutvā palāyitvā attano
analyzed: saḥ evam vatvā mahājane niddam okkante yottam khāditvā su hitaḥ hutvā palāyitvā
translated: Having so said, when the great multitude was asleep, he ate the leather strap, and being well satisfied, he ran away and returned to his own

original: sāmikānaṃ gharameva gato.
analyzed: gharam eva gataḥ
translated: master’s house.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā sunakhova etarahi sunakho, paṇḍitapuriso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Sunakhajātakavaṇṇanā dutiyā.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā sunakhaḥ iva etarahi sunakhaḥ paṇḍita puriso pana aham eva ahosinti  sunakha jātaka vaṇṇanā dutiyā
translated: When the Teacher had related this parable, he identified the Birth by saying, “At that time the dog was the dog of the present, and the wise man was myself.”🔽The Birth of the Dog.

original: [243] 3. Guttilajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Birth of the Leather-strap.

original: Sattatantiṃ sumadhuranti idaṃ satthā veḷuvane viharanto devadattaṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: satta tantim su madhuranti idam satthā veḷuvane viharantaḥ devadattam ārabbha kathesi
translated: The story of the Leather-strap is related in the Commentary on the Dhammapada, verse 270.

original: Tasmiñhi kāle bhikkhū devadattaṃ āhaṃsu – “āvuso devadatta, sammāsambuddho tuyhaṃ
analyzed: tasmin hi kāle bhikkhū devadattam āhaṃsu āvuso devadatta sammāsambuddhaḥ tuyham
translated: At that time the monks said to Devadatta, “Friend Devadatta, the Supremely Enlightened One is your teacher;

original: ācariyo, tvaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ nissāya tīṇi piṭakāni uggaṇhi, cattāri jhānāni uppādesi,
analyzed: ācariyaḥ tvam sammāsambuddham nissāya tīṇi piṭakāni uggaṇhi cattāri jhānāni uppādesi
translated: you have learned the Three Piṭakas by heart and have developed the four meditations under the Supremely Enlightened One.

original: ācariyassa nāma paṭisattunā bhavituṃ na yutta”nti. Devadatto “kiṃ pana me, āvuso,
analyzed: ācariyassa nāma paṭisattunā bhavitum na yuttanti devadatto kim pana me āvuso
translated: It is not proper for you to oppose your teacher.” Devadatta replied, “Friends, how can the monk Gotama be my teacher?

original: samaṇo gotamo ācariyo, nanu mayā attano baleneva tīṇi piṭakāni uggahitāni, cattāri🔽jhānāni uppāditānī”ti ācariyaṃ paccakkhāsi. Bhikkhū dhammasabhāyaṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ🔽“āvuso, devadatto ācariyaṃ paccakkhāya sammāsambuddhassa paṭisattu hutvā mahāvināsaṃ
analyzed: samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ācariyaḥ nanu mayā attanaḥ balena iva tīṇi piṭakāni uggahitāni cattāri  jhānāni uppāditāni iti ācariyam paccakkhāsi bhikkhū dhammasabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ  āvuso devadattaḥ ācariyam paccakkhāya sammāsambuddhassa paṭisattu hutvā mahā vināsam
translated: I have learned the Three Piṭakas and have developed the four meditations by my own strength.” Thus did he deny his teacher.🔽The monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth: “Brethren, Devadatta denied his teacher and became the monk Gotama’s opponent, and as a consequence has met with destruction.”

original: patto”ti. Satthā āgantvā “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: patto ti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā
translated: The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what is the subject that engages your attention now as you sit here all gathered together?”

original: “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, devadatto idāneva ācariyaṃ paccakkhāya mama
analyzed: imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave devadatto idānā iva ācariyam paccakkhāya mama
translated: When they told him, he said, “Monks, this is not the first time Devadatta has denied his teacher and become my opponent;

original: paṭisattu hutvā vināsaṃ pāpuṇāti, pubbepi pattoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: paṭisattu hutvā vināsam pāpuṇāti pubbe pi patto yā iva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: and he was destroyed by his enemy, just as he is now.”

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto gandhabbakule nibbatti, “guttilakumāro”tissa
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ gandhabba kule nibbatti guttila kumāra ūtissa
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in the Gandhabba world, and was called Prince Guttila.

original: nāmaṃ akaṃsu. So vayappatto gandhabbasippe nipphattiṃ patvā guttilagandhabbo nāma
analyzed: nāmam akaṃsu saḥ vaya pattaḥ gandhabba sippe nipphattim patvā guttilagandhabbaḥ nāma
translated: When he grew up, he became a Gandhabba of great skill, and was known as Guttila the Gandhabba.

original: sakalajambudīpe aggagandhabbo ahosi. So dārābharaṇaṃ akatvā andhe mātāpitaro posesi.
analyzed: sakala jambudīpe agga gandhabbaḥ ahosi saḥ dāra ābharaṇam a katvā andhe mātā pitaraḥ posesi

analyzed: bhikkhūnam bhikkhunīnam ca kula gehe vāsam upagatānam santike dhammam assosi aparā  nāvāya upakaṭṭhāya velāya bhuttassa bhikkhuno udake ṭhatvā udakam adāsi aparā agāra majjhe  vasamānā akkodhanā hutvā aparā attanaḥ laddha koṭṭhāsataḥ pi
translated: Another gave a five-ingredient incense offering to the shrine of the Blessed One Kassapa. Another, while living in a house, was not angry but was always kind and helpful.

original: saṃvibhāgaṃ katvāva paribhuñji, sīlavatī ca ahosi, aparā paragehe dāsī hutvā nikkodhanā

original: tattha nibbattā, sabbaṃ bodhisatto pucchi. Tāpissa attano katakammaṃ gāthāhiyeva🔽kathesuṃ. Taṃ sutvā bodhisatto “lābhā vata me, suladdhaṃ vata me, svāhaṃ idhāgantvā🔽appamattakenapi kammena paṭiladdhadibbasampattiyo assosiṃ. Ito dāni paṭṭhāya manussalokaṃ
analyzed: tattha nibbattā sabbam bodhisatto pucchi tāpissa attanaḥ kata kammam gāthā hiyā iva  kathesum tam sutvā bodhisattaḥ lābhāḥ vata me su laddham vata me svāham idha āgantvā  appamattakena api kammena paṭiladdha dibba sampattiyaḥ assosim itas dāni paṭṭhāya manussa lokaṃ
translated: And each of them told him in verse what deed she had performed.

original: gantvā dānādīni kusalakammāneva karissāmī”ti vatvā imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi –
analyzed: gantvā dāna ādīni kusala kammāni eva karissāmi iti vatvā imam udānam udānesi
translated: When the Bodhisatta had heard all this, he said, “How fortunate I am, how very fortunate, that I have come here and have heard of the heavenly bliss to be obtained by the performance of even a slight good deed. original: “Svāgataṃ vata me ajja, suppabhātaṃ suhuṭṭhitaṃ;
analyzed: svāgatam vata me ajja su pabhātam su huṭṭhitam
translated: “How fortunate I am this day, how well I have awakened and risen,

analyzed: yam addasāmi devatāyo accharā kāma vaṇṇiyaḥ
translated: That I have seen these celestial nymphs, so lovely as the Apsarases.

analyzed: svā aham tattha gamissāmi yattha gantvā na socara iti
translated: I will go to that place, having gone to which one does not grieve.”

original: Atha naṃ sattāhaccayena devarājā mātalisaṅgāhakaṃ āṇāpetvā rathe nisīdāpetvā bārāṇasimeva
analyzed: atha nam sattāhaccayena devarājā mātali saṅgāhakam āṇāpetvā rathe nisīdāpetvā bārāṇasim eva
translated: After seven days had passed, the king of the gods commanded Mātali, the charioteer of Sakka, to take him on the chariot and set him down in Bārāṇasī.

original: pesesi. So bārāṇasiṃ gantvā devaloke attanā diṭṭhakāraṇaṃ manussānaṃ ācikkhi. Tato
analyzed: pesesi saḥ bārāṇasim gantvā deva loke attanā diṭṭha kāraṇam manussānam ācikkhi tatas

analyzed: paṭṭhāya manussā saussāhā puññāni kātum maññiṃsu

translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time Devadatta was the mouse, Anuruddha was Sakka, Ānanda was the king, and I myself was Guttila-gandhabba.”

original: [244] 4. Vigaticchajātakavaṇṇanā

analyzed: yam passati na tam icchati iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam palāyikam paribbājakam  ārabbha kathesi saḥ kira sakala jambudīpe paṭivādam a labhitvā sāvatthim āgantvā kaḥ

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto kāsiraṭṭhe brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā

translated: and taking up his abode in a leaf-hut on the bank of the Ganges, he dwelt in dependence on a certain village. Now it happened that a certain

Atha🔽naṃ bodhisatto “vaṇṇagandhaparibhāvitaṃ gaṅgāpānīyaṃ pivissatī”ti pucchi. Paribbājako🔽vādena ottharanto “kā gaṅgā, vālukā gaṅgā, udakaṃ gaṅgā, orimatīraṃ gaṅgā, pārimatīraṃ🔽gaṅgā”ti āha. Bodhisatto “tvaṃ pana, paribbājaka, ṭhapetvā udakaṃ vālukaṃ orimatīraṃ
analyzed: paribbājakaḥ sakala jambudīpe paṭivādam a labhitvā tam nigamam patvā atthi nu kho koci  mayā saddhim vādam kātum samatthaḥ ti pucchitvā atthi iti bodhisattassa ānubhāvam  sutvā mahā jana parivutaḥ tassa vasana ṭṭhānam gantvā paṭisanthāram katvā nisīdi atha  nam bodhisattaḥ vaṇṇa gandha paribhāvitam gaṅgā pānīyam pivissati iti pucchi paribbājako  vādena kā gaṅgā vālukā gaṅgā udakam gaṅgā orima tīram gaṅgā pārima tīram  gaṅgā iti āha bodhisatto tvam pana paribbājaka ṭhapetvā udakam vālukam orima tīram
translated: The wanderer, not finding anyone to dispute with him in all India, came to that town, and asked, “Is there anyone here able to dispute with me?” On hearing that there was, and that it was the power of the Bodhisatta, he went to the Bodhisatta’s dwelling, surrounded by a great crowd, and after exchanging greetings, sat down. Then the Bodhisatta asked him, “Will you drink the water of the Ganges, perfumed with colour and scent?” The wanderer, in order to confound him, said, “What is the Ganges? Is the sand the Ganges, or is the water the Ganges, or is the near bank the Ganges, or is the far bank the Ganges?” The Bodhisatta said, “But, wanderer, setting aside the water, the sand, the near bank, and the far bank,

original: pārimatīrañca kahaṃ gaṅgaṃ labhissasī”ti āha. Paribbājako appaṭibhāno hutvā uṭṭhāya🔽palāyi. Tasmiṃ palāte bodhisatto nisinnaparisāya dhammaṃ desento imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: pārima tīram ca kaham gaṅgam labhissasi iti āha paribbājakaḥ appaṭibhānaḥ hutvā uṭṭhāya 🔽palāyi tasmin palāte bodhisattaḥ nisinna parisāya dhammaṃ desentaḥ imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: The wanderer, not finding a disputant in all India, came to that town, and asked, “Is there any one here able to hold a discussion with me?” On hearing that there was, and that it was the power of the Bodhisatta, he went with a great crowd to the place where the Bodhisatta was living, and after exchanging greetings, sat down. Then the Bodhisatta asked him, “Will you drink the water of the Ganges, perfumed with its colour and fragrance?” The wanderer, being unable to answer, said, “What is the Ganges? Is the sand the Ganges, or the water, or the near bank, or the far bank?” The Bodhisatta said, “But, wanderer, where will you find the Ganges, except in the water, the sand, the near bank, and the far bank?” The wanderer, being unable to reply, rose up and fled. When he had fled, the Bodhisatta, teaching the Dhamma to the assembly that was sitting there, spoke these verses:

original: “Yaṃ passati na taṃ icchati, yañca na passati taṃ kiricchati;
analyzed: yam passati na tam icchati yam ca na passati tam kiricchati
translated: “He does not want what he sees, and what he does not see he wants.

original: Maññāmi ciraṃ carissati, na hi taṃ lacchati yaṃ sa icchati.
analyzed: maññāmi ciram carissati na hi tam lacchati yam saḥ icchati
translated: I think he will wander long, for he will not get what he wants.

original: “Yaṃ labhati na tena tussati, yañca pattheti laddhaṃ hīḷeti;
analyzed: yam labhati na tena tussati yam ca pattheti laddham hīḷeti
translated: “He is not satisfied with what he gets, and what he wants he spurns when gained.

original: Icchā hi anantagocarā, vigaticchāna namo karomase”ti.
analyzed: icchā hi ananta gocarā namaḥ karomasa iti
translated: For craving has an endless range: we pay homage to him who has ended craving.”

original: Tattha yaṃ passatīti yaṃ udakādiṃ passati, taṃ gaṅgāti na icchati. Yañca na passatīti
analyzed: tattha yam passati iti yam udaka ādim passati tam gaṅgā ati na icchati yam ca na passati iti
translated: Herein, he does not want what he sees: he does not want what he sees, water, etc., to be the Ganges. What he does not see:

original: yañca udakādivinimuttaṃ gaṅgaṃ na passati, taṃ kiricchati. Maññāmi ciraṃ carissatīti
analyzed: yam ca udaka ādi vinimuttam gaṅgam na passati tam kiricchati maññāmi ciram carissati iti
translated: he wants what he does not see, the Ganges apart from the water, etc., to be the Ganges. I think he will wander long:

original: ahaṃ evaṃ maññāmi – ayaṃ paribbājako evarūpaṃ gaṅgaṃ pariyesanto ciraṃ carissati.
analyzed: aham evam maññāmi ayam paribbājakaḥ evarūpam gaṅgam pariyesantaḥ ciram carissati
translated: I think this wanderer will wander long seeking a Ganges of that kind.

original: Yathā vā udakādivinimuttaṃ gaṅgaṃ, evaṃ rūpādivinimuttaṃ attānampi pariyesanto saṃsāre
analyzed: yathā vai udaka ādi vinimuttam gaṅgam evam rūpa ādi vinimuttam attānam pi pariyesantaḥ saṃsāre
translated: Or alternatively, just as the Ganges is apart from the water, etc., so too the self is apart from material form, etc., and he will wander long in saṃsāra seeking a self of that kind. For he will not get what he wants:

original: ciraṃ carissati. Na hi taṃ lacchatīti ciraṃ carantopi yaṃ taṃ evarūpaṃ gaṅgaṃ vā
analyzed: ciram carissati na hi tam lacchati iti ciram carantaḥ api yam tam evarūpam gaṅgam vā
translated: even though he wanders long, he will not get what he wants, a Ganges of that kind, or a self of that kind.

original: attānaṃ vā icchati, taṃ na lacchati. Yaṃ labhatīti yaṃ udakaṃ vā rūpādiṃ vā labhati,🔽tena na tussati. Yañca pattheti laddhaṃ hīḷetīti evaṃ laddhena atussanto yaṃ yaṃ
analyzed: attānam vai icchati tam na lacchati yam labhati iti yam udakam vā rūpa ādim vā labhati  tena na tussati yam ca pattheti laddham hīḷeti iti evam laddhena a tussantaḥ yam yam
translated: he does not get what he wants. “What he gets” : he gets water or visible forms, etc.,

original: sampattiṃ pattheti, taṃ taṃ labhitvā “kiṃ etāyā”ti hīḷeti avamaññati. Icchā hi anantagocarāti
analyzed: sampattim pattheti tam tam labhitvā kim etāya ati hīḷā iti avamaññati icchā hi ananta gocarā ati
translated: but he is not satisfied with it. “What he seeks he spurns when gained” : not being satisfied with what he has gained, he spurns and despises whatever prosperity he gains, whatever he seeks.🔽For craving has an infinite range.

original: laddhaṃ hīḷetvā aññamaññaṃ ārammaṇaṃ icchanato ayaṃ icchā nāma taṇhā anantagocarā.
analyzed: laddham hi iḷetvā aññam aññam ārammaṇam icchanataḥ ayam icchā nāma taṇhā ananta gocarā
translated: Spurning what he has gained, he craves for something else. This craving is called “desire” and has an infinite range.🔽We pay homage to those who have overcome desire.

original: Vigaticchāna namo karomaseti tasmā ye vigaticchā buddhādayo, tesaṃ mayaṃ namakkāraṃ karomāti.
analyzed: vigaticcha ana namaḥ karomasa iti tasmai ye vigaticchāḥ buddha ādayo tesam mayam namakkāram karoma ati
translated: Therefore we pay homage to those who have overcome desire, the Buddhas and the rest.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā paribbājako etarahi paribbājako ahosi, tāpaso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā paribbājakaḥ etarahi paribbājakaḥ ahosi tāpasaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: Having related this dhamma instruction, the Teacher identified the Birth Stories: “At that time the wanderer was the present wanderer, and I myself was the ascetic.”

original: Vigaticchajātakavaṇṇanā catutthā.
analyzed: vigaticcha jātaka vaṇṇanā catutthā
translated: The commentary on the Vigaticcha Jātaka is finished.

original: [245] 5. Mūlapariyāyajātakavaṇṇanā

analyzed: kālaḥ ghasati bhūtāni iti idam satthā ukkaṭṭham nissāya subhaga vane viharantaḥ mūlapariyāya suttantaṃ

analyzed: mayam pi tāni jānāma evam sante kim tassa amhehi nānākaraṇanti buddha upaṭṭhānam na  gacchanti paṭipakkhāḥ hutvā caranti

analyzed: atha eka divasam satthā tesu āgantvā attano santike nisinnesu aṭṭhahi bhūmīhi paṭimaṇḍetvā  mūla pariyāya suttantam kathesi te na kiñci atha na isam etat ahosi mayam
translated: Now one day the Master, after seating himself in the midst of these monks, who had come to wait upon him, preached the Discourse on the Root of all Good, which is adorned with eight topics.🔽But they failed to understand the meaning of a single sentence. analyzed: tam sutvā te bhikkhū arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu mūlapariyāya suttanta pariyosāne pana  satthari ukkaṭṭhāyam viharanteyeva bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ  āvuso aho buddhānam ānubhāvaḥ te nāma brāhmaṇa pabbajitā tathā māna mada mattā bhagavatā
