translated: “Let him enter” means let him enter this. “All” means the whole, the entire.

original: Bodhisatto puttassa vacanaṃ sutvā uṭṭhāya olokento makkaṭabhāvaṃ ñatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: bodhisatto puttassa vacanam sutvā uṭṭhāya olokentaḥ makkaṭa bhāvam ñatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: The Bodhisatta, hearing the words of his son, rose up and looked at him. Seeing that he was a monkey, he spoke the second stanza:

original: “Nāyaṃ isī upasamasaṃyame rato, kapī ayaṃ dumavarasākhagocaro;
analyzed: na ayam upasama saṃyame kapī ayam
translated: “This is no seer who delights in peace and self-control, this is a monkey, a wanderer in the branches of the forest trees;

original: So dūsako rosako cāpi jammo, sace vajemampi dūseyyagāra”nti.🔽Tattha dumavarasākhagocaroti dumavarānaṃ sākhagocaro. So dūsako rosako cāpi jammoti
analyzed: saḥ dūsakaḥ rosakaḥ ca api jammo sace  tattha duma vara sākha gocaro ti so dūsakaḥ rosakaḥ ca api jammo ti
translated: He is a defiler, a brawler, and a fool. If he should enter, he would defile the hermitage.”🔽Herein, his range is the branches of the best trees. He is a defiler, a brawler, and a fool.

original: so evaṃ gatagataṭṭhānassa dūsanato dūsako, ghaṭṭanatāya rosako, lāmakabhāvena jammo.
analyzed: saḥ evam gata gata ṭṭhānassa dūsanataḥ dūsakaḥ ghaṭṭana tāya rosakaḥ lāmaka bhāvena jammo
translated: He is a defiler because he defiles the places he visits. He is a brawler because he is quarrelsome. He is a fool because he is stupid.

original: Sace vajeti yadi imaṃ paṇṇasālaṃ vaje paviseyya, sabbaṃ uccārapassāvakaraṇena ca
analyzed: sace vaja iti yadi imam paṇṇa sālam vaje paviseyya sabbam uccāra passāva karaṇena ca
translated: If he should enter: if he should enter this leaf hut. He would defile all: he would defile all by his excrement and urine

original: aggidānena ca dūseyyāti.
analyzed: aggi dānena ca dūseyya ati
translated: and by his fire.

original: Evañca pana vatvā bodhisatto ummukaṃ gahetvā taṃ santāsetvā palāpesi. So uppatitvā
analyzed: evam ca pana vatvā bodhisattaḥ ummukam gahetvā tam santāsetvā palāpesi saḥ uppatitvā
translated: Having thus spoken, the Bodhisatta took up a clod of earth and frightened him away. He flew up into the air

original: vanaṃ pakkhanto tathā pakkhantova ahosi, na puna taṃ ṭhānaṃ agamāsi. Bodhisatto abhiññā
analyzed: vanam pakkhantaḥ tathā pakkhantaḥ iva ahosi na puna tam ṭhānam agamāsi bodhisatto abhiññā
translated: and went away to the forest. He went away and never returned. The Bodhisatta attained the super-knowledges

original: ca samāpattiyo ca nibbattetvā tāpasakumārassa kasiṇaparikammaṃ ācikkhi, sopi abhiññā
analyzed: ca samāpattiyaḥ ca nibbattetvā tāpasa kumārassa kasiṇa parikammam ācikkhi sā api abhiññā
translated: and the meditative absorptions. He taught the young ascetic the preliminary work for the kasiṇa, and he too attained the super-knowledges

original: ca samāpattiyo ca uppādesi. Te ubhopi aparihīnajjhānā brahmalokaparāyaṇā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: ca samāpattiyaḥ ca uppādesi te ubho api a parihīna jjhānāḥ brahma loka parāyaṇāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: and the meditative absorptions. Both of them, without losing their meditative absorptions, passed away to the Brahma-world.

original: Satthā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, porāṇato paṭṭhāyapesa kuhakoyevā”ti imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ🔽āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi. Saccapariyosāne keci sotāpannā, keci🔽sakadāgāmino, keci anāgāmino keci arahanto ahesuṃ. “Tadā makkaṭo kuhakabhikkhu ahosi,
analyzed: satthā na bhikkhave idānā iva porāṇato imam dhamma desanaṃ  āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne keci sotāpannā keci  sakadāgāminaḥ keci anāgāminaḥ keci arahantaḥ ahesum tadā makkaṭaḥ kuhaka bhikkhu ahosi
translated: “Monks, this monk was a cheat not only now, but formerly also.” So saying, the Teacher related the following🔽Birth-Story of the Past:🔽At the conclusion of the Truths, some attained the Fruit of Conversion, some the Fruit of the Second Path, some the Fruit of the Third Path, some the Fruit of the Fourth Path. The monkey was the cheat monk.

original: putto rāhulo, pitā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Kapijātakavaṇṇanā dasamā.
analyzed: putto rāhulaḥ pitā pana aham eva ahosinti  kapijātakavaṇṇanā dasamā
translated: “Monks, this monk was a cheat not only now, but formerly also.” And preaching the Law, he related this Jātaka in detail. At the conclusion of the Truths, some attained the Fruit of Conversion, some the Fruit of the Second Path, some the Fruit of the Third Path, some the Fruit of the Fourth Path, some the state of the Anāgāmin, some that of the Arhat. At that time the monkey was the hypocritical monk, the son was Rāhula, and I myself was the father.🔽Thus did the Exalted One speak, and the monks were delighted and rejoiced at his words.🔽The story of the Monkey is the tenth.

original: Siṅgālavaggo dasamo.
analyzed: siṅgāla vaggaḥ dasamaḥ
translated: The tenth chapter is called “The Chapter of the Jackal.”

original: Tassuddānaṃ –🔽Sabbadāṭhī ca sunakho, guttilo vigaticchā ca;
analyzed: tassa uddānam  sabbadāṭhī ca sunakhaḥ guttilaḥ vigaticchā ca
translated: The summary:

original: Mūlapariyāyaṃ bālovādaṃ, pādañjali kiṃ sukopamaṃ;🔽Sālakaṃ kapi te dasa.
analyzed: bāla vādam kim  sālakam kapi te dasa
translated: The dog, the jackal, the fox, the crow, the owl, the vulture, the snake, the tortoise, the monkey, the parrot.

original: Atha vagguddānaṃ –🔽Daḷhavaggo ca santhavo, kalyāṇadhammāsadiso;🔽Rūhako daḷhavaggo ca, bīraṇathambhakāsāvo;🔽Upāhano siṅgālo ca, dasavaggā duke siyuṃ.
analyzed: atha vagguddānam  daḷha vaggaḥ ca santhavaḥ kalyāṇa dhamma asadiso  rūhakaḥ daḷhavaggaḥ ca bīraṇa thambha kāsāvaḥ  upāhanaḥ siṅgālaḥ ca dasa vaggāḥ duke siyum
translated: The summary of the chapter:

original: Dukanipātavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽3. Tikanipāto🔽1. Saṅkappavaggo
analyzed: duka nipāta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽tika nipātaḥ 🔽saṅkappa vaggaḥ
translated: The chapter of the strong man, the chapter of the union, the chapter of the good man, the chapter of the growth, the chapter of the strong man, the chapter of the bamboo, the chapter of the robe, the chapter of the fan, the chapter of the jackal. These are the ten chapters.

original: [251] 1. Saṅkapparāgajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The Birth Story of Saṅkapparāga (in the Jātakanidāna)

original: Saṅkapparāgadhotenāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhuṃ ārabbha kathesi.
analyzed: saṅkappa rāga dhotena ati idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum ārabbha kathesi
translated: Saṅkapparāgadho tena, etc. This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a monk who was discontented.

original: Sāvatthinagaravāsī kireko kulaputto sāsane uraṃ datvā pabbajitvā ekadivasaṃ sāvatthiyaṃ
analyzed: sāvatthi nagara vāsī kira ekaḥ kula putto sāsane uram da tvā pabbajitvā eka divasam sāvatthiyam
translated: A certain young man of good family, it seems, who lived in the city of Sāvatthi, gave his heart to the religion, and became a monk. One day, as he was going his round for alms in Sāvatthi,

original: piṇḍāya caranto ekaṃ alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ itthiṃ disvā uppannakāmarāgo anabhirato vicari.🔽Tamenaṃ ācariyupajjhāyādayo disvā anabhiratikāraṇaṃ pucchitvā vibbhamitukāmabhāvamassa
analyzed: piṇḍāya carantaḥ ekam alaṅkata paṭiyattam itthim disvā uppanna kāma rāgaḥ an abhirataḥ vicari  tam enam ācariya upajjhāya ādayaḥ disvā an abhirati kāraṇam pucchitvā vibbhamitu kāma bhāvam assa
translated: he saw a woman who was gaily dressed and bejewelled. The thought of love sprang up in his mind, and he went about discontented.🔽His teacher and preceptor, seeing him, asked him the reason of his discontent,

original: ñatvā “āvuso, satthā nāma kāmarāgādikilesapīḷitānaṃ kilese hāretvā saccāni pakāsetvā
analyzed: ñatvā āvuso satthā nāma kāma rāga ādi kilesa pīḍitānam kilese hāretvā saccāni pakāsetvā
translated: and finding out that he was desirous of leaving the Order, said to him, “Brother, the Master is able to remove the passions of those who are afflicted with the passions of love, etc., to reveal the Truths to them,

original: sotāpattiphalādīni deti, ehi taṃ satthu santikaṃ nessāmā”ti ādāya agamaṃsu. Satthārā
analyzed: sotāpatti phala ādīni deti ehi tam satthu santikam nessāma ati ādāya agamaṃsu satthārā
translated: and to bestow on them the Fruit of Conversion and the other fruits. Come, we will take you to the Master.” So saying, they took him with them and went to the Master.

original: ca “kiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, anicchamānakaññeva bhikkhuṃ gahetvā āgatatthā”ti vutte
analyzed: ca kim nu kho bhikkhave an icchamāna kaññā iva bhikkhum gahetvā āgata ttha iti vutte
translated: The Master asked them, “Monks, why have you brought this monk with you, whether he likes to go or not?”

original: tamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ. Satthā “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhito”ti pucchitvā “saccaṃ,🔽bhante”ti vutte “kiṃkāraṇā”ti pucchi. So tamatthaṃ ārocesi. Atha naṃ satthā “itthiyo
analyzed: tam attham ārocesuṃ satthā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ ti pucchitvā saccam  bhante iti vutte kiṃkāraṇā iti pucchi saḥ tam attham ārocesi atha nam satthā itthiyo
translated: “Yes, Reverend Sir.”🔽“What is the reason?”

original: nāmetā, bhikkhu, pubbe jhānabalena vikkhambhitakilesānaṃ visuddhasattānampi saṃkilesaṃ🔽uppādesuṃ, tādisaṃ tucchapuggalaṃ kiṃkāraṇā na saṃkilesissanti, visuddhāpi sattā🔽saṃkilissanti, uttamayasasamaṅginopi āyasakyaṃ pāpuṇanti, pageva aparisuddhā. Sinerukampanakavāto
analyzed: nāma etāḥ bhikkhu pubbe jhāna balena vikkhambhita kilesānam visuddha sattānam pi saṃkilesam  uppādesum tādisam tuccha puggalam kiṃkāraṇāḥ na saṃkilesissanti visuddhāḥ api sattā  saṃkilissanti uttama yasa samaṅginaḥ api āyasakyam pāpuṇanti pagā iva a parisuddhā sineru kampanaka vāto
translated: The monk told him the reason. Then the Teacher said to him, “Monks, women have caused the corruption of even such men as have subdued their passions by the power of meditation and are therefore pure in heart.🔽How much more likely are they to corrupt such a worthless fellow as you are! Even men of pure character are corrupted by women, and men of high reputation fall into disgrace, to say nothing of men of impure character.

original: purāṇapaṇṇakasaṭaṃ kiṃ na kampessati, bodhitale nisīditvā abhisambujjhanakasattaṃ
analyzed: purāṇa paṇṇaka saṭam kim na kampessati bodhi tale nisīditvā abhisambujjhanaka sattam
translated: Does not the wind that shakes Mount Sineru shake also a heap of dry leaves? Even the man who sat down on the Diamond Seat and became Buddha was shaken by passion.

original: ayaṃ kileso āloḷesi, tādisaṃ kiṃ na āloḷessatī”ti vatvā tehi yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: ayam kilesaḥ āloḷesi tādisam kim naḥ āloḷessati iti vatvā tehi yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: How much more likely is such a worthless fellow as you to be shaken by passion?” So saying, he related the following

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto asītikoṭivibhave brāhmaṇamahāsālakule
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ asīti koṭi vibhave brāhmaṇa mahāsāla kule
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, in the city of Bārāṇasī, in the province of Kāsi, there was a great family of Brahmans, possessing a hundred thousand niyutas of treasure.

original: nibbattitvā vayappatto takkasilāyaṃ sabbasippāni uggaṇhitvā bārāṇasiṃ paccāgantvā
analyzed: nibbattitvā vaya patto takkasilāyam sabba sippāni uggaṇhitvā bārāṇasim paccāgantvā
translated: When he had grown up, he went to Takkasilā and learned all the arts. Then he returned to Bārāṇasī and

original: katadārapariggaho mātāpitūnaṃ accayena tesaṃ matakiccāni katvā hiraññolokanakammaṃ
analyzed: kata dāra pariggahaḥ mātā pitūnam accayena tesam mata kiccāni katvā hiraññolokana kammam
translated: married. After his parents died, he performed the funeral rites for them and set about looking for the treasure.

original: karonto “idaṃ dhanaṃ paññāyati, yehi panetaṃ sambhataṃ, te na paññāyantī”ti āvajjento
analyzed: karontaḥ idam dhanam paññāyati yehi pana itam sambhatam te na paññāyanti iti āvajjentaḥ
translated: He thought, “The treasure is here, but those who accumulated it are not.” He was deeply moved, and sweat broke out on his body.

original: saṃvegappatto ahosi, sarīrā sedā mucciṃsu. So gharāvāse ciraṃ vasanto mahādānaṃ datvā🔽kāme pahāya assumukhaṃ ñātisaṅghaṃ pariccajitvā himavantaṃ pavisitvā isipabbajjaṃ
analyzed: saṃvega pattaḥ ahosi sarīrā sedā mucciṃsu saḥ ghara āvāse ciram vasantaḥ mahā dānam da tvā  kāme pahāya assumukham ñāti saṅgham pariccajitvā himavantam pavisitvā isipabbajjam
translated: After living in the household life for a long time, he gave a great deal of alms,🔽and then he renounced the world. He left the household life with a sorrowful face, and he went to the Himalayas.

original: pabbajitvā ramaṇīye padese paṇṇasālaṃ māpetvā uñchācariyāya vanamūlaphalādīhi yāpento
analyzed: pabbajitvā ramaṇīye padese paṇṇa sālam māpetvā uñchā cariyāya vana mūla phala ādīhi yāpento
translated: He went forth as an ascetic and had a leaf hut built in a delightful place. He lived on roots, fruits, and so on, and he made his living by gleaning.

original: nacirasseva abhiññā ca samāpattiyo ca uppādetvā jhānakīḷaṃ kīḷanto ciraṃ vasitvā
analyzed: nacirassa eva abhiññā ca samāpattiyaḥ ca uppādetvā jhāna kīḷam kīḍantaḥ ciram vasitvā
translated: Before long he attained the supernormal powers and the meditative absorptions. He lived for a long time, enjoying the play of the meditative absorptions.🔽Then he thought, “I will go to the human path and enjoy salt and sour foods. In this way my body will be strong

original: cintesi – “manussapathaṃ gantvā loṇambilaṃ upasevissāmi, evaṃ me sarīrañceva thiraṃ
analyzed: cintesi manussa patham gantvā loṇambilam upasevissāmi evam me sarīram ca iva thiram
translated: and

original: bhavissati, jaṅghavihāro ca kato bhavissati, ye ca mādisassa sīlasampannassa bhikkhaṃ
analyzed: bhavissati jaṅgha vihāro ca kataḥ bhavissati ye ca mādisassa sīla sampannassa bhikkham
translated: and a place for walking up and down has been made. Those who give alms or pay homage to one like me, who is perfect in morality,

original: vā dassanti, abhivādanādīni vā karissanti, te saggapuraṃ pūressantī”ti.
analyzed: vā dassanti abhivādana ādīni vā karissanti te sagga puram pūressanti iti
translated: will fill the city of heaven.”

original: So himavantā otaritvā anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno bārāṇasiṃ patvā sūriyatthaṅgamanavelāya
analyzed: saḥ himavantau otaritvā anupubbena cārikam caramānaḥ bārāṇasim patvā sūriyatthaṅgamana velāya
translated: He came down from the Himalayas and gradually made his way to Benares. At sunset he looked for a place to stay.

original: vasanaṭṭhānaṃ olokento rājuyyānaṃ disvā “idaṃ paṭisallānasāruppaṃ, ettha vasissāme”ti
analyzed: vasana ṭṭhānam olokento rājuyyānam disvā idam paṭisallāna sāruppam ettha vasissāma iti
translated: Seeing the royal park, he thought, “This is suitable for seclusion. I will stay here.”

original: uyyānaṃ pavisitvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisinno jhānasukhena rattiṃ khepetvā punadivase
analyzed: uyyānam pavisitvā aññatarasmim rukkha mūle nisinnaḥ jhāna sukhena rattim khepetvā puna divase
translated: He entered the park, sat down at the foot of a tree, and spent the night in the bliss of jhāna. The next day🔽he prepared his matted hair, bark garment, and bowl,

original: katasarīrapaṭijaggano pubbaṇhasamaye jaṭājinavakkalāni saṇṭhapetvā bhikkhābhājanaṃ🔽ādāya santindriyo santamānaso iriyāpathasampanno yugamattadassano hutvā sabbākārasampannāya
analyzed: kata sarīra paṭijagganaḥ pubbaṇha samaye jaṭā ajina vakkalāni saṇṭhapetvā bhikkhā bhājanam  ādāya santa indriyaḥ santa mānasaḥ iriyāpatha sampanno yuga matta dassano hutvā sabba ākāra sampannāya
translated: took his bowl,🔽and entered the city. With his senses and mind calm, his deportment perfect, and his gaze downcast to the extent of a plough’s length,

original: attano rūpasiriyā lokassa locanāni ākaḍḍhento nagaraṃ pavisitvā bhikkhāya caranto
analyzed: attanaḥ rūpa siriyā lokassa locanāni ākaḍḍhentaḥ nagaram pavisitvā bhikkhāya carantaḥ
translated: he entered the city, his beauty and splendor perfect in every way, drawing the eyes of the people. As he went on his alms round,

original: rañño nivesanadvāraṃ pāpuṇi. Rājā mahātale caṅkamanto vātapānantarena bodhisattaṃ🔽disvā iriyāpathasmiññeva pasīditvā “sace santadhammo nāma atthi, imassa tena abbhantare
analyzed: raññaḥ nivesana dvāram pāpuṇi rājā mahā tale caṅkamantaḥ vātapāna antarena bodhisattam  disvā iriyāpathasmin ñeva pasīditvā sace santadhammaḥ nāma atthi imassa tena abbhantare
translated: and arrived at the door of the king’s palace. The king, who was walking up and down on the top floor, saw the Bodhisatta

original: bhavitabba”nti cintetvā “gaccha, taṃ tāpasaṃ ānehī”ti ekaṃ amaccaṃ āṇāpesi. So gantvā
analyzed: bhavitabban ti cintetvā gaccha tam tāpasam ānehi iti ekam amaccam āṇāpesi saḥ gantvā
translated: through a window, and was pleased with his deportment. He thought: “If there is such a thing as virtue, he must be full of it.” And he ordered a minister: “Go and bring that ascetic here.” The minister went,

original: vanditvā bhikkhābhājanaṃ gahetvā “rājā, bhante, taṃ pakkosatī”ti āha. Bodhisatto🔽“mahāpuñña, amhe rājā na jānātī”ti āha. “Tena hi, bhante, yāvāhaṃ āgacchāmi, tāva🔽idheva hothā”ti gantvā rañño ārocesi. Rājā “amhākaṃ kulūpakatāpaso natthi, gaccha,
analyzed: vanditvā bhikkhā bhājanam gahetvā rājā bhante tam pakkosati iti āha bodhisatto  mahāpuñña amhe rājā na jānāti iti āha tena hi bhante yāva aham āgacchāmi tāva  idha iva hotha ati gantvā raññaḥ ārocesi rājā amhākam kulūpaka tāpasaḥ natthi gaccha
translated: and after paying homage, he took the alms-bowl and said: “Venerable sir, the king summons you.” The Bodhisatta replied:

original: naṃ ānehī”ti sayampi vātapānena hatthaṃ pasāretvā vandanto “ito etha, bhante”ti āha.
analyzed: naṃ ānehi iti sayam pi vātapānena hattham pasāretvā vandantaḥ itas etha bhante iti āha
translated: “Great is his merit, but the king does not know me.” “Well then, venerable sir, stay here until I return.” And he went and reported to the king. The king said: “We have no ascetic who is our supporter. Go and bring him here.” And he himself, stretching out his hand through the window, paid homage, saying: “Come here, venerable sir.”

original: Bodhisatto amaccassa hatthe bhikkhābhājanaṃ datvā mahātalaṃ abhiruhi.
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ amaccassa hatthe bhikkhā bhājanam da tvā mahā talam abhiruhi
translated: The Bodhisatta gave his alms-bowl into the minister’s hand and ascended the top floor.

original: Atha naṃ rājā vanditvā rājapallaṅke nisīdāpetvā attano sampāditehi yāgukhajjakabhattehi
analyzed: atha nam rājā vanditvā rāja pallaṅke nisīdāpetvā attanaḥ sampāditehi yāgu khajjaka bhattehi
translated: The king saluted him, and having caused him to sit down on the royal seat, served him with the food and drink which he had prepared.

original: parivisitvā katabhattakiccaṃ pañhaṃ pucchi. Pañhabyākaraṇena bhiyyosomattāya pasīditvā🔽vanditvā “bhante, tumhe katthavāsikā, kuto āgatatthā”ti pucchitvā “himavantavāsikā
analyzed: parivisitvā kata bhatta kiccam pañham pucchi pañha byākaraṇena bhiyyosomattāya pasīditvā  vanditvā bhante tumhe katthavāsikā kutas āgatattha ati pucchitvā himavanta vāsikā
translated: After the meal was over, he asked him a question. The Bodhisatta, by his answer, increased the king’s faith still more.🔽The king saluted him, and asked him, “Reverend Sir, where do you live, and whence do you come?” “We live in the Himalayas,

original: mayaṃ, mahārāja, himavantato āgatā”ti vutte puna “kiṃkāraṇā”ti pucchitvā “vassārattakāle,

original: [252] 2. Tilamuṭṭhijātakavaṇṇanā🔽Ajjāpi me taṃ manasīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto aññataraṃ kodhanaṃ bhikkhuṃ🔽ārabbha kathesi. Aññataro kira, bhikkhu, kodhano ahosi upāyāsabahulo, appampi vutto🔽samāno kuppi abhisajji, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi. Athekadivasaṃ bhikkhū🔽dhammasabhāyaṃ kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesuṃ – “āvuso, asuko nāma bhikkhu kodhano upāyāsabahulo
analyzed: tilamuṭṭhijātaka vaṇṇanā  ajja api me tam manasi iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ aññataram kodhanam bhikkhum  ārabbha kathesi aññataraḥ kira bhikkhu kodhanaḥ ahosi upāyāsa bahulaḥ appam pi vutto  samānaḥ kuppi abhisajji kopam ca dosam ca appaccayam ca athekadivasam bhikkhū  dhamma sabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso asukaḥ nāma bhikkhu kodhanaḥ upāyāsa bahulo
translated: 2.The Story of the Handful of Sesamum Seeds

original: uddhane pakkhittaloṇaṃ viya taṭataṭāyanto vicarati, evarūpe nikkodhane buddhasāsane
analyzed: uddhane pakkhitta loṇam viya taṭataṭāyantaḥ vicarati evarūpe nikkodhane buddha sāsane
translated: Even now I remember it. This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about a certain angry monk. This monk was angry and irritable, and if anyone said anything to him, he would fly into a passion, and show anger, hatred, and bitterness. One day the monks began a discussion in the Hall of Truth: “Brethren, such and such a monk is angry and irritable. He goes about like a pot of salt thrown into hot water, bubbling and bubbling up. In the Dispensation of the Buddha, which is free from anger,

original: pabbajito samāno kodhamattampi niggaṇhituṃ na sakkotī”ti. Satthā tesaṃ kathaṃ sutvā
analyzed: pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ kodha mattam pi niggaṇhitum na sakkoti iti satthā tesam katham sutvā
translated: he has gone forth in the Holy Life, and yet he is unable to control his anger.” The Master listened to their talk,

original: ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ pesetvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ pakkosāpetvā “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, kodhano”ti
analyzed: ekam bhikkhum pesetvā tam bhikkhum pakkosāpetvā saccam kira tvam bhikkhu kodhano ti
translated: sent for the monk, and asked him, “Is it true, monk, that you are angry?”

original: pucchitvā “saccaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi ayaṃ kodhano
analyzed: pucchitvā saccam bhante ti vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi ayam kodhano
translated: When they had questioned him and found out that it was true, he said, “Monks, this was not the first time he was angry with her;

original: ahosī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vatvā atītam āhari
translated: in a previous state of existence also he was angry with her.” And so saying, he related a Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente tassa putto brahmadattakumāro nāma ahosi.🔽Porāṇakarājāno ca attano putte “evaṃ ete nihatamānadappā sītuṇhakkhamā lokacārittaññū
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente tassa putto brahmadatta kumāraḥ nāma ahosi  porāṇaka rājāno ca attano putte evam ete nihata māna dappā sītuṇha khamāḥ loka cārittaññū
translated: In times long past, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the son of that king was known as Prince Brahmadatta.

original: ca bhavissantī”ti attano nagare disāpāmokkhaācariye vijjamānepi sippuggahaṇatthāya🔽dūre tiroraṭṭhaṃ pesenti, tasmā sopi rājā soḷasavassuddesikaṃ puttaṃ pakkosāpetvā
analyzed: ca bhavissanti iti attanaḥ nagare disāpāmokkha ācariye vijjamāne pi sippu gahaṇa atthāya  dūre tiroraṭṭham pesenti tasmai saḥ api rājā soḷasa vassuddesikam puttam pakkosāpetvā
translated: Now the kings of old used to send their sons to foreign lands to learn a trade, in order that they might be able to control their pride and haughtiness, and might become accustomed to cold and heat, and learn the ways of the world.

original: ekapaṭalikaupāhanā ca paṇṇacchattañca kahāpaṇasahassañca datvā “tāta, takkasilaṃ
analyzed: eka paṭalikā opāhanā ca paṇṇa chattañca kahā paṇa sahassañca da tvā tāta takkasilam
translated: Therefore this king also sent for his son, who was sixteen years old, and gave him a pair of sandals with straps of a single piece of leather, an umbrella made of palm-leaves, and a thousand pieces of money, and said to him, “My son, go to Takkasilā

original: gantvā sippaṃ uggaṇhā”ti pesesi. So “sādhū”ti mātāpitaro vanditvā nikkhamitvā anupubbena
analyzed: gantvā sippam uggaṇhāti pesesi saḥ sādhu uti mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā nikkhamitvā anupubbena
translated: and learn a trade.” He replied, “Very well,” saluted his parents, and set out. After traveling a long time,

original: takkasilaṃ patvā ācariyassa gehaṃ pucchitvā ācariye māṇavakānaṃ sippaṃ vācetvā uṭṭhāya
analyzed: takkasilam patvā ācariyassa geham pucchitvā ācariye māṇavakānam sippam vācetvā uṭṭhāya
translated: and when they reached Takkasilā, they asked where their teacher’s house was. After the teacher had taught the young men their lessons, they left.

original: gharadvāre caṅkamante gehaṃ gantvā yasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhito ācariyaṃ addasa, tattheva upāhanā🔽omuñcitvā chattañca apanetvā ācariyaṃ vanditvā aṭṭhāsi. So tassa kilantabhāvaṃ ñatvā
analyzed: ghara dvāre caṅkamante geham gantvā yasmin ṭhāne ṭhitaḥ ācariyam addasa tattha iva upāhanā  omuñcitvā chattam ca apanetvā ācariyam vanditvā aṭṭhāsi saḥ tassa kilanta bhāvam ñatvā
translated: and as he was walking up and down outside the door of the house, he went to the house and stood in the place where he could see his teacher. There he took off his shoes🔽and his sunshade, and after worshipping his teacher, he stood there. The teacher, knowing that he was tired,

original: āgantukasaṅgahaṃ kāresi. Kumāro bhuttabhojano thokaṃ vissamitvā ācariyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: āgantuka saṅgaham kāresi kumāraḥ bhutta bhojanaḥ thokam vissamitvā ācariyam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: entertained him as a guest. After the young man had eaten and rested a little, he approached his teacher,

original: vanditvā aṭṭhāsi, “kuto āgatosi, tātā”ti ca vutte “bārāṇasito”ti āha. “Kassa puttosī”ti?
analyzed: vanditvā aṭṭhāsi kutas āgato si tāta ati ca vutte bārāṇasito ti āha kassa putto asi iti
translated: worshipped him, and stood there. “Where have you come from, dear?” he was asked. “From Bārāṇasī,” he replied. “Whose son are you?”

original: “Bārāṇasirañño”ti. “Kenatthenāgatosī”ti? “Sippaṃ uggaṇhatthāyā”ti. “Kiṃ te ācariyabhāgo
analyzed: bārāṇasi rañño ti kena atthena āgataḥ asi iti sippam uggaṇha atthāya ati kim te ācariya bhāgaḥ
translated: “I am the son of the king of Bārāṇasī.” “Why have you come?” “To learn a craft.” “Have you come to be my pupil,

original: ābhato, udāhu dhammantevāsiko hotukāmosī”ti? So “ācariyabhāgo me ābhato”ti vatvā
analyzed: ābhataḥ udāhu dhamma antevāsikaḥ hotu kāmo asi iti saḥ ācariya bhāgaḥ me ābhataḥ ti vatvā
translated: or do you want to be a pupil of the Dhamma?” “I have come to be your pupil,” he said.

original: ācariyassa pādamūle sahassatthavikaṃ ṭhapetvā vandi.
analyzed: ācariyassa pāda mūle sahassatthavikam ṭhapetvā vandi
translated: and after placing a thousand coins at his teacher’s feet, he worshipped him.

original: Dhammantevāsikā divā ācariyassa kammaṃ katvā rattiṃ sippaṃ uggaṇhanti, ācariyabhāgadāyakā
analyzed: dhamma antevāsikāḥ divā ācariyassa kammam katvā rattim sippam uggaṇhanti ācariya bhāga dāyakā
translated: The pupils who lived with him learned their lessons by day and their crafts by night. The pupils who lived with his brother learned only their crafts.

original: gehe jeṭṭhaputtā viya hutvā sippameva uggaṇhanti. Tasmā sopi ācariyo sallahukena🔽subhanakkhattena kumārassa sippaṃ paṭṭhapesi. Kumāropi sippaṃ uggaṇhanto ekadivasaṃ🔽ācariyena saddhiṃ nhāyituṃ agamāsi. Athekā mahallikā itthī tilāni sete katvā pattharitvā
analyzed: gehe jeṭṭha puttāḥ viya hutvā sippam eva uggaṇhanti tasmā saḥ api ācariyaḥ sat lahukena  subha nakkhattena kumārassa sippam paṭṭhapesi kumāraḥ api sippam uggaṇhantaḥ eka divasam  ācariyena saddhim nhāyitum agamāsi atha ekā mahallikā itthī tilāni sete katvā pattharitvā
translated: Therefore the teacher was able to teach his pupil the craft of elephant-riding without delay.🔽The prince, while learning the craft, one day went with his teacher to bathe. Now a certain old woman was sitting there, guarding sesame seeds which she had spread out to dry.

original: rakkhamānā nisīdi. Kumāro setatile disvā khāditukāmo hutvā ekaṃ tilamuṭṭhiṃ gahetvā🔽khādi, mahallikā “taṇhāluko eso”ti kiñci avatvā tuṇhī ahosi. So punadivasepi tāya
analyzed: rakkhamānā nisīdi kumāraḥ seta tile disvā khāditu kāmaḥ hutvā ekam tila muṭṭhim gahetvā  mahallikā taṇhālukaḥ kiñci a vatvā tuṇhī ahosi saḥ puna divase pi
translated: The prince, seeing the sesame seeds, became desirous of eating them, and taking a handful of them,

analyzed: tathā iva sā api nam na āha tadā
translated: he ate them. The old woman thought, “This is a greedy fellow,” and said nothing. The next day he did the same thing, and she said nothing. The third day he did the same thing,

original: mahallikā “disāpāmokkho ācariyo attano antevāsikehi maṃ vilumpāpetī”ti bāhā paggayha
analyzed: mahallikā disāpāmokkhaḥ ācariyaḥ attanaḥ antevāsikehi mam vilumpa apeti iti bāhā paggayha
translated: and the old woman cried out, “My noble teacher is making his pupils rob me!” and she threw up her arms and fell down.

original: kandi. Ācariyo nivattitvā “kiṃ etaṃ, ammā”ti pucchi. “Sāmi, antevāsiko te mayā katānaṃ🔽setatilānaṃ ajjekaṃ muṭṭhiṃ khādi, hiyyo ekaṃ, pare ekaṃ, nanu evaṃ khādanto mama🔽santakaṃ sabbaṃ nāsessatī”ti. “Amma, mā rodi, mūlaṃ te dāpessāmī”ti. “Na me, sāmi,
analyzed: kandi ācariyaḥ nivattitvā kim etam amma ati pucchi sāmi antevāsiko te mayā katānam  ajja ekam muṭṭhim khādi hiyyo ekam pare ekam nanu evam khādantaḥ mama  santakam sabbam na āsessati iti amma mā rodi mūlam te dāpessāmi iti na me sāmi
translated: The teacher returned and asked, “What is the matter, my dear?” “Master, your pupil has eaten a handful of the sugar-cane

original: mūlenattho, yathā panesa kumāro puna evaṃ na karoti, tathā taṃ sikkhāpehī”ti. Ācariyo
analyzed: mūlena atthaḥ yathā pana esa kumāraḥ punar evam na karoti tathā tam sikkhāpehi iti ācariyo
translated: that I have prepared, one day one handful, another day one handful. If he goes on eating in this way, he will destroy all that I have.” “My dear, do not weep. I will give you the price of the sugar-cane.” “Master, I do not want the price of the sugar-cane. But you must train him so that this young man will not do this again.” “Well then, my dear,

original: “tena hi passa, ammā”ti dvīhi māṇavehi taṃ kumāraṃ dvīsu hatthesu gāhāpetvā veḷupesikaṃ
analyzed: tena hi passa amma ati dvīhi māṇavehi tam kumāram dvīsu hatthesu gāhāpetvā veḷu pesikam
translated: you must see to it.” So the teacher had the young man seized by two pupils, one by each arm, and taking a cane

original: gahetvā “puna evarūpaṃ mā akāsī”ti tikkhattuṃ piṭṭhiyaṃ pahari. Kumāro ācariyassa
analyzed: gahetvā punar evarūpam mā akāsi iti tikkhattum piṭṭhiyam kumāraḥ ācariyassa
translated: himself, he struck him three times on the back, saying, “Do not do so again.” The young man,

original: kujjhitvā rattāni akkhīni katvā pādapiṭṭhito yāva kesamatthakā olokesi. Sopissa kujjhitvā
analyzed: kujjhitvā rattāni akkhīni katvā pāda piṭṭhitaḥ yāva kesamatthakāḥ olokesi saḥ upissa kujjhitvā
translated: looking at the teacher with bloodshot eyes, looked him over from the soles of his feet to the tips of his hair. The teacher,

original: olokitabhāvaṃ aññāsi. Kumāro sippaṃ niṭṭhāpetvā “anuyogaṃ datvā mārāpetabbo esa mayā”ti
analyzed: olokita bhāvam aññāsi kumāraḥ sippam niṭṭhāpetvā anuyogam datvā mārāpetabbo esa mayā ati
translated: seeing that the young man was looking at him, realized that the young man was angry. The young man, having completed his training, thought to himself, “I must give him a lesson and then kill him.”

original: tena katadosaṃ hadaye ṭhapetvā gamanakāle ācariyaṃ vanditvā “yadāhaṃ, ācariya, bārāṇasirajjaṃ
analyzed: tena kata dosam hadaye ṭhapetvā gamana kāle ācariyam vanditvā yadā aham ācariya bārāṇasi rajjam
translated: and he harbored the resentment in his heart. When it was time to go, he paid homage to his teacher and said, “Teacher, when I have become king of Bārāṇasī,

original: patvā tumhākaṃ santikaṃ pesessāmi, tadā tumhe āgaccheyyāthā”ti sasineho viya paṭiññaṃ gahetvā pakkāmi.🔽So bārāṇasiṃ patvā mātāpitaro vanditvā sippaṃ dassesi. Rājā “jīvamānena me putto
analyzed: patvā tumhākam santikam pesessāmi tadā tumhe āgaccheyyātha ati sa sinehaḥ viya paṭiññam gahetvā pakkāmi  saḥ bārāṇasim patvā mātā pitaraḥ vanditvā sippam dassesi rājā jīvamānena me putto
translated: and he harboured resentment against his teacher. When the time came for him to go, he paid homage to his teacher and said, “When I have obtained the kingship of Bārāṇasī, teacher, I shall send for you. You may then come.” He took an oath in this way, as if he were a good man, and then he departed.

original: diṭṭho, jīvamānovassa rajjasiriṃ passāmī”ti puttaṃ rajje patiṭṭhāpesi. So rajjasiriṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhaḥ rajja sirim passāmi iti puttam rajje patiṭṭhāpesi saḥ rajja sirim
translated: When he had reached Bārāṇasī, he paid homage to his parents and demonstrated his skill. The king said, “I have seen my son while he was alive. While he is alive, I shall see him enjoy the glory of kingship.” He established his son in the kingship.

original: anubhavamāno ācariyena katadosaṃ saritvā uppannakodho “mārāpessāmi na”nti pakkosanatthāya
analyzed: anubhavamānaḥ ācariyena kata dosam saritvā uppanna kodhaḥ mārāpessāmi nanti pakkosana tthāya
translated: While he was enjoying the glory of kingship, he remembered the resentment his teacher had harboured against him. He became angry and thought, “I shall have him killed.” He sent a messenger to his teacher to summon him.

original: ācariyassa dūtaṃ pāhesi. Ācariyo “taruṇakāle naṃ saññāpetuṃ na sakkhissāmī”ti agantvā
analyzed: ācariyassa dūtam pāhesi ācariyaḥ taruṇa kāle nam saññāpetum na sakkhissāmi iti a gantvā
translated: The teacher thought, “When he is young, I shall not be able to convince him. I shall not go.”

original: tassa rañño majjhimavayakāle “idāni naṃ saññāpetuṃ sakkhissāmī”ti gantvā rājadvāre
analyzed: tassa raññaḥ majjhima vaya kāle idāni nam saññāpetum sakkhissāmi iti gantvā rājadvāre
translated: When the king had reached middle age, he thought, “Now I shall be able to convince him.” He went and stood at the royal gate.

original: ṭhatvā “takkasilācariyo āgato”ti ārocāpesi. Rājā tuṭṭho brāhmaṇaṃ pakkosāpetvā taṃ
analyzed: ṭhatvā takkasilā cariyaḥ āgataḥ iti ārocāpesi rājā tuṭṭhaḥ brāhmaṇam pakkosāpetvā tam
translated: and had him announced, saying: “The teacher Takkasilā has come.” The king was pleased, and he sent for the brāhmaṇa.

original: attano santikaṃ āgataṃ disvāva kodhaṃ uppādetvā rattāni akkhīni katvā amacce āmantetvā
analyzed: attano santikam āgatam disvā ava kodham uppādetvā rattāni akkhīni katvā amacce āmantetvā
translated: When he saw him come into his presence, he became angry, his eyes turned red, and he addressed his ministers, saying:

original: “bho, ajjāpi me ācariyena pahaṭaṭṭhānaṃ rujjati, ācariyo nalāṭena maccuṃ ādāya ‘marissāmī’ti
analyzed: bho ajja api me ācariyena pahaṭa ṭṭhānam rujjati ācariyaḥ nalāṭena maccum ādāya marissāmi iti
translated: “Sirs, even to this day I feel pain in the place where my teacher struck me. The teacher has come to me, taking Death on his forehead, saying: ‘I shall die.’

original: āgato, ajjassa jīvitaṃ natthī”ti vatvā purimā dve gāthā avoca –
analyzed: āgataḥ ajjassa jīvitam natthi iti vatvā purimāḥ dve gāthāḥ avoca
translated: To-day he has no life.” And he spoke the first two stanzas:

original: “Ajjāpi me taṃ manasi, yaṃ maṃ tvaṃ tilamuṭṭhiyā;
analyzed: ajja api me tam manasi yam mam tvam tila muṭṭhiyā
translated: “Even to-day I think of that, that you, with a handful of sesamum,

analyzed: bāhāya mam gahetvāna laṭṭhiyā anutāḷayi
translated: Seized me by the arm and struck me with a stick.

original: “Nanu jīvite na ramasi, yenāsi brāhmaṇāgato;
analyzed: nanu jīvite na ramasi yena asi brāhmaṇa āgataḥ
translated: “Are you not pleased with life, that you have come to me, a brāhmaṇa,

analyzed: yam mama bāhā gahetvāna tikkhattum anutāḍayī iti
translated: That you seized me by the arm and struck me three times?”

original: Tattha yaṃ maṃ bāhāya manti dvīsu padesu upayogavacanaṃ anutāḷanagahaṇāpekkhaṃ. Yaṃ
analyzed: tattha yam mam bāhāya manti dvīsu padesu upayoga vacanam anutāḷana gahaṇa apekkham yam
translated: Here, “that you, with a handful of sesamum,” is a locative absolute, expressing the reason, and looking to the striking and the seizing.

original: maṃ tvaṃ tilamuṭṭhiyā kāraṇā anutāḷayi, anutāḷento ca maṃ bāhāya gahetvā anutāḷayi,
analyzed: mam tvam tilamuṭṭhiyā kāraṇā anutāḷayi anutāḷentaḥ ca mam bāhāya gahetvā anutāḷayi
translated: “That you struck me with a stick” means that you struck me with a stick, seizing me by the arm.

original: taṃ anutāḷanaṃ ajjāpi me manasīti ayañhettha attho. Nanu jīvite na ramasīti maññe
analyzed: tam anutāḷanam ajja api me manasi iti ayan ha itthā atthaḥ nanu jīvite na ramasi iti maññe
translated: “Do you not delight in life?” I think that you do not delight in your own life.

original: tvaṃ attano jīvitamhi nābhiramasi. Yenāsi brāhmaṇāgatoti yasmā brāhmaṇa idha mama
analyzed: tvam na abhiramasi yena asi brāhmaṇa āgataḥ iti yasmai brāhmaṇaḥ mama
translated: “For what reason have you come to me, Brahmin?” For what reason have you come to me, Brahmin,

original: santikaṃ āgatosi. Yaṃ maṃ bāhā gahetvānāti yaṃ mama bāhā gahetvā, yaṃ maṃ bāhāya
analyzed: santikam āgataḥ usi yam mama bāhā gahetvā anāti yam mama bāhā gahetvā yam mam bāhāya
translated: “Seizing me by the arms” means seizing my arms, the meaning is that of seizing me by the arm.

original: gahetvātipi attho. Tikkhattuṃ anutāḷayīti tayo vāre veḷulaṭṭhiyā tāḷesi, ajja dāni
analyzed: gahetvā atipi attho tikkhattum anutāḷayīti tayaḥ vāre veḷulaṭṭhiyā tāḷesi ajja dāni
translated: “Three times you beat me” means three times you beat me with a bamboo stick, today I

original: tassa phalaṃ vindāhīti naṃ maraṇena santajjento evamāha.
analyzed: tassa phalam vindāhi iti nam maraṇena evam āha
translated: “Find the fruit of that” means, tormenting him with death, he said this.

original: Taṃ sutvā ācariyo tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā ācariyaḥ tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Having heard that, the teacher spoke the third verse:

original: “Ariyo anariyaṃ kubbantaṃ, yo daṇḍena nisedhati;
analyzed: ariyaḥ anariyam kubbantam yaḥ daṇḍena nisedhati
translated: “The noble one who restrains the ignoble one with punishment,

translated: That is his teaching, not his enmity, so the wise ones know.”

original: Tattha ariyoti sundarādhivacanametaṃ. So pana ariyo catubbidho hoti ācāraariyo dassanaariyo
analyzed: tattha ariyo ti sundara adhivacanam etam so pana ariyo catubbidhaḥ hoti ācāra ariyo dassana ariyo
translated: Herein, noble one is a word for beautiful. But that noble one is of four kinds: the noble one of conduct, the noble one of view,

analyzed: liṅga ariyo paṭivedha ariyo ti tattha manussaḥ vā hotu tiracchānaḥ vā ariya ācāre ṭhito
translated: the noble one of emblem, the noble one of penetration. Herein, whether he be a human or an animal, he who is established in noble conduct,

translated: He is called “noble in conduct.” And this is said:

analyzed: ariyavattasi vakkaṅga yaḥ piṇḍam apacāyati
translated: “You are a noble one, Vakkhanga, who goes about for alms;

analyzed: cajāmi te tam bhattāram gacchathu ubhau
translated: I praise that lord of yours; go, both of you, as you like.”

original: Rūpena pana iriyāpathena ca pāsādikena dassanīyena samannāgato dassanaariyo nāma. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: rūpena pana iriyāpathena ca pāsādikena dassanīyena samannāgataḥ dassana ariyaḥ nāma vuttam pi ca itaṃ
translated: But one who is pleasing to look at because of his bodily form and deportment is called “noble in appearance.” And this is said:

analyzed: ariya avakāso asi pasanna nettaḥ maññe bhavam pabbajitaḥ kulamhā

analyzed: katham nu cittāni pahāya bhoge pabbaji nikkhamma gharā sa paññā ati
translated: How is it that you have given up wealth and gone forth, wise one, leaving the home life?”

original: Nivāsanapārupanaliṅgaggahaṇena pana samaṇasadiso hutvā vicaranto dussīlopi liṅgaariyo nāma. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ –
analyzed: nivāsana pārupana liṅga ggahaṇena pana samaṇa sadisaḥ hutvā vicarantaḥ dussīlaḥ api liṅgaariyaḥ nāma yam sandhāya vuttam

analyzed: chadanam katvāna subbatānam pakkhandī kula dūsakaḥ pagabbhaḥ
translated: “Having taken on the outward form of the virtuous, the shameless, impudent,

analyzed: māyāvī asaññataḥ palāpo patirūpena caram sa magga dūsī iti
translated: deceitful, unvirtuous, and garrulous home-destroyer, he goes about in outward form, destroying the path.”

original: Buddhādayo pana paṭivedhaariyā nāma. Tena vuttaṃ – “ariyā vuccanti buddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca buddhasāvakā cā”ti. Tesu idha ācāraariyova adhippeto.
analyzed: buddha ādayaḥ pana paṭivedha ariyāḥ nāma tena vuttam ariyāḥ vuccanti buddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca buddha sāvakā ca ati tesu idha ācāra ariyaḥ uva adhippeto
translated: But Buddhas and so on are called Noble Ones by penetration. Hence it is said: “Noble Ones are called Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and Buddhas’ disciples” . Herein, the one who is a noble conduct is intended.🔽Unnoble : unvirtuous, of bad habits.

original: Anariyanti dussīlaṃ pāpadhammaṃ. Kubbantanti pāṇātipātādikaṃ pañcavidhadussīlyakammaṃ

original: karontaṃ, ekameva vā etaṃ atthapadaṃ, anariyaṃ hīnaṃ lāmakaṃ pañcaverabhayakammaṃ
analyzed: karontam ekam eva vai etam attha padam anariyam hīnam lāmakam pañca vera bhaya kammaṃ
translated: Or this is a single word-stem meaning “doing what is unnoble, base, contemptible, and fearful as fivefold killing” .🔽Any : any one of the khattiya, and so on.

original: karontaṃ puggalaṃ. Yoti khattiyādīsu yo koci. Daṇḍenāti yena kenaci paharaṇakena.
analyzed: karontam puggalam yaḥ ti khattiya ādīsu yaḥ koci daṇḍena ati yena kenacid paharaṇakena
translated: With a stick : with whatever is a means of striking.🔽He restrains : he restrains by striking, saying “Do not do so again.”

original: Nisedhatīti “mā puna evarūpaṃ karī”ti paharanto nivāreti. Sāsanaṃ taṃ na taṃ veranti🔽taṃ, mahārāja, akattabbaṃ karonte puttadhītaro vā antevāsike vā evaṃ paharitvā nisedhanaṃ
analyzed: nisedhati iti mā punar evarūpam kari iti paharantaḥ nivāra iti sāsanam tam na tam  tam mahā rāja a kattabbam karonte putta dhītaraḥ vā antevāsike vā evam paharitvā nisedhanam
translated: That is advice, not enmity.🔽That is advice, instruction, admonition, in this world, great king, for one who does what should not be done, for a son or a daughter or a pupil who is struck in this way.

original: nāma imasmiṃ loke sāsanaṃ anusiṭṭhi ovādo, na veraṃ. Iti naṃ paṇḍitā vidūti evametaṃ
analyzed: nāma imasmin loke sāsanam ovādaḥ na iti naṃ paṇḍitāḥ evam etam
translated: It is not enmity. Thus the wise men know.

original: paṇḍitā jānanti. Tasmā, mahārāja, tvampi evaṃ jāna, na evarūpe ṭhāne veraṃ kātuṃ🔽arahasi. Sace hi tvaṃ, mahārāja, mayā evaṃ sikkhāpito nābhavissa, atha gacchante🔽kāle pūvasakkhaliādīni ceva phalāphalādīni ca haranto corakammesu paluddho anupubbena🔽sandhicchedanapanthadūhanagāmaghātakādīni katvā “rājāparādhiko coro”ti sahoḍḍhaṃ
analyzed: paṇḍitāḥ jānanti tasmai mahā rāja tvam pi evam jāna na evarūpe ṭhāne veram kātum  arahasi sace hi tvam mahā rāja mayā evam sikkhāpitaḥ na abhavissa atha gacchante  kāle pūva sakkhali ādīni ca iva phalāphala ādīni ca harantaḥ cora kammesu paluddhaḥ anupubbena  sandhi chedana panthadūhana gāma ghātaka ādīni katvā rāja aparādhikaḥ coraḥ ti sahoḍḍham
translated: the wise know. Therefore, sire, you should know that it is not right to make enmity in such a case. If, sire, you had not been thus instructed by me, then as time went on, taking away the sugar-canes, the coconuts and so on, the fruits and so on, you would have become involved in theft, and in the end🔽you would have cut the fetters, destroyed the roads, plundered the villages, and so on, and you would have been seized and brought before the king as a criminal, and🔽you would have been executed by the king’s men.

original: gahetvā rañño dassito “gacchathassa dosānurūpaṃ daṇḍaṃ upanethā”ti daṇḍabhayaṃ pāpuṇissa,
analyzed: gahetvā raññaḥ dassitaḥ gacchathassa dosa anurūpam daṇḍam upanetha ati daṇḍa bhayam pāpuṇissa
translated: The wise know this. Therefore, sire, you should know that it is not right to make enmity in such a case. If, sire, you had not been thus instructed by me, then as time went on, taking away the sugar-canes, the coconuts and so on, and the fruits and so on, you would have become involved in criminal acts, and in time you would have committed the crimes of breaking into houses, robbing on the highways, and burning villages, and so on. Then you would have been seized by the police, and brought before the king, and the king would have said: ‘Go and inflict the proper punishment on him.’ You would have suffered the fear of punishment.

original: kuto te evarūpā sampatti abhavissa, nanu maṃ nissāya idaṃ issariyaṃ tayā laddhanti🔽evaṃ ācariyo rājānaṃ saññāpesi. Parivāretvā ṭhitā amaccāpissa kathaṃ sutvā “saccaṃ,
analyzed: kutas te evarūpā sampatti abhavissa nanu mama nissāya idam issariyam tayā laddhanti  evam ācariyaḥ rājānam saññāpesi parivāretvā ṭhitā amaccā api issa katham sutvā saccam
translated: How could you have obtained such prosperity as this? Did you not obtain this sovereignty through me?

original: deva, idaṃ issariyaṃ tumhākaṃ ācariyasseva santaka”nti āhaṃsu.
analyzed: deva idam issariyam tumhākam ācariyassa iva santakam ti āhaṃsu
translated: Thus did the teacher instruct the king. The ministers who were standing round about, having heard his words, said: ‘It is true, sire, this sovereignty belongs to your teacher.’

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe rājā ācariyassa guṇaṃ sallakkhetvā “sabbissariyaṃ te, ācariya, dammi,
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe rājā ācariyassa guṇam sallakkhetvā sabbissariyam te ācariya dammi
translated: At that moment the king, perceiving the virtues of the teacher, said, “I give you, teacher, all my sovereignty.

original: rajjaṃ paṭicchā”ti āha. Ācariyo “na me, mahārāja, rajjenattho”ti paṭikkhipi. Rājā
analyzed: rajjam paṭiccha ati āha ācariyaḥ na me mahā rāja rajjena atthaḥ ti paṭikkhipi rājā
translated: Accept the kingdom.” The teacher replied, “Great king, I have no desire for the kingdom.” The king

translated: sent out Takkasilā, and had the teacher’s wife and children brought to him, and gave them great wealth.

original: purohitaṃ katvā pituṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā tassovāde ṭhito dānādīni puññāni katvā saggaparāyaṇo ahosi.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne🔽kodhano bhikkhu anāgāmiphale patiṭṭhahi, bahū janā sotāpannasakadāgāmianāgāmino ahesuṃ.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne  kodhanaḥ bhikkhu anāgāmi phale bahū janā sotāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāminaḥ ahesuṃ
translated: The Teacher, having related this dhamma discourse, revealed the Truths, and identified the Birth:

analyzed: tadā rājā kodhanaḥ bhikkhu ahosi ācariyaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti  tilamuṭṭhi jātaka vaṇṇanā dutiyā
translated: “At that time the angry monk was the angry monk, and I myself was the teacher.”🔽The Story of the Handful of Sesame Seeds.

original: [253] 3. Maṇikaṇṭhajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of Maṇikaṇṭha

translated: The monks of Āḷavī were having huts built by means of begging. They were constantly begging and asking,

analyzed: vihariṃsu purisam detha purisatthakaram detha ati ādīni vadantā manussāḥ upaddutā
translated: saying, “Give a man, give a workman.” The people were annoyed🔽by the begging and by the asking. When they saw the monks,

translated: they were frightened and terrified and ran away.

analyzed: tathā iva paṭipajjiṃsu saḥ pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ bhikkhū āmantetvā pubbāyam
translated: they behaved in the same way. After his meal, when he had returned from his almsround, he asked the monks,

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ mahā vibhave brāhmaṇa kule  nibbatti tassa ādhāvitvā paridhāvitvā vicaraṇa kāle aññaḥ api puññavā satto tassa mātu
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, he said, “In Benares, under King Brahmadatta, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a certain great Brāhman family.🔽When he had grown up and was wandering about here and there, another being of great merit was reborn in the womb of his mother.

analyzed: kucchismim nibbatti te ubhaḥ api bhātaraḥ vaya pattāḥ mātā pitūnam kālakiriyāya saṃvigga hadayā
translated: Both brothers, when they had grown up, were deeply moved by the death of their mother and father,

original: isipabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā gaṅgātīre paṇṇasālaṃ māpetvā vasiṃsu. Tesu jeṭṭhassa uparigaṅgāya
analyzed: isipabbajjam pabbajitvā gaṅgā tīre paṇṇa sālam māpetvā vasiṃsu tesu jeṭṭhassa uparigaṅgāya

analyzed: nāga bhavanā nikkhamitvā gaṅgā tīre māṇavaka vesena vicarantaḥ kaniṭṭhassa assamam gantvā
translated: after coming out from his Nāga abode, wandering on the bank of the Ganges in the guise of a young man, went to the younger brother’s hermitage,

original: vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi, te aññamaññaṃ sammodanīyakathaṃ kathetvā vissāsikā ahesuṃ,
analyzed: vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi te aññamaññam sammodanīya katham kathetvā vissāsikāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: and after worshipping him, he sat down on one side, and after they had exchanged polite and courteous greetings, they became friends,

analyzed: vinā vattitum na asakkhiṃsu maṇikaṇṭhaḥ abhiṇham kaniṭṭha tāpasassa santikam āgantvā  kathā sallāpena nisīditvā gamana kāle tāpase sinehena atta bhāvam vijahitvā bhogehi  tāpasam parikkhipantaḥ parissajitvā upari muddhani mahantam phaṇam dhāretvā thokam
translated: and they were unable to live without each other. Maṇikaṇṭha frequently came into the presence of the younger ascetic,🔽and after sitting down and conversing with him, when it was time to go, he gave up his own body out of affection for the ascetic, and after surrounding the ascetic with his coils,🔽and placing his great hood above his head, he remained there for a while,

original: vasitvā taṃ sinehaṃ vinodetvā sarīraṃ viniveṭhetvā tāpasaṃ vanditvā sakaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: vasitvā tam sineham vinodetvā sarīram viniveṭhetvā tāpasam vanditvā saka ṭṭhānam eva
translated: and after removing that affection, he contracted his body, worshipped the ascetic, and went to his own place.

original: gacchati. Tāpaso tassa bhayena kiso ahosi lūkho dubbaṇṇo uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāto dhamanisanthatagatto.🔽So ekadivasaṃ bhātu santikaṃ agamāsi. Atha naṃ so pucchi – “kissa, tvaṃ bho, kiso
analyzed: gacchati tāpaso tassa bhayena kisaḥ ahosi lūkhaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ uppaṇḍu paṇḍuka jātaḥ dhamani santhata gatto  saḥ eka divasam bhātu santikam agamāsi atha nam so pucchi kissa tvam bho kiso
translated: The ascetic, out of fear of the snake, became thin, haggard, and pale, with veins standing out all over his body.🔽One day he went to his brother. The latter asked him, “Brother, why are you so thin, haggard, and pale, with veins standing out all over your body?”

original: lūkho dubbaṇṇo uppaṇḍuppaṇḍukajāto dhamanisanthatagatto”ti. So tassa taṃ pavattiṃ
analyzed: lūkhaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ uppaṇḍu paṇḍuka jātaḥ dhamani santhata gatto ti saḥ tassa tam pavattim

translated: But when he began to eat more than was good for him,

translated: Herein, as long as he knew moderation in eating: as long as the bird knew moderation in eating. So long did he live his life: for so long did he live his life, live out his days. And never left his mother: this is the climax of the story. He never left his mother and father, is the meaning. But when he began to eat more than was good for him: at what time. He began to eat more than was good for him: he began to eat the mango juice. There and then: at that time. He sank to death: he sank in the very same sea, he was drowned, he became food for the fishes.

original: Tasmā mattaññutā sādhūti yasmā bhojane amattaññū suko samudde osīditvā mato, tasmā

translated: moderation in eating, which is called “non-greed for food,” is good. The meaning is: knowing the right amount is beautiful.

analyzed: atha vā paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ āhāram āhāreti na iva davāya na phāsu vihāraḥ ca ati
translated: Or alternatively, “he consumes food after careful consideration, not for amusement, for intoxication, for the sake of physical beauty and attractiveness, but only for the endurance and continuance of this body, for ending discomfort, and for assisting the holy life,”

analyzed: allam sukkham ca bhuñjantaḥ na bāḷham su hitaḥ siyā
translated: “One should not eat too much, nor should one eat too little. One should eat just enough

translated: “One should drink water after one has eaten four or five mouthfuls,

translated: That is enough for a monk who is intent on living comfortably.

translated: “For a man who is always mindful, who knows the right amount of food,

translated: His feelings will be slight; he will age slowly and preserve his life.”

original: Evaṃ vaṇṇitā mattaññutāpi sādhu.
analyzed: evam vaṇṇitā mattaññu tā api sādhu
translated: Thus moderation is praised.

original: “Kantāre puttamaṃsaṃva, akkhassabbhañjanaṃ yathā;
analyzed: kantāre putta maṃsam iva akkhassa abbhañjanam yathā
translated: “As one who is in the wilderness would eat the flesh of his beloved child,

analyzed: evam āhari āharam
translated: So one who is intent on mere survival should eat, eating only as much as is necessary.”

original: Evaṃ vaṇṇitā agiddhitāpi sādhu. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “agiddhimā”ti likhitaṃ, tato ayaṃ aṭṭhakathāpāṭhova🔽sundarataro. Amattaññū hi sīdantīti bhojane pamāṇaṃ ajānantā hi rasataṇhāvasena pāpakammaṃ
analyzed: evam vaṇṇitā agiddhi tā api sādhu pāḷiyam pana agiddhimā ati likhitam tatas ayam aṭṭhakathā pāṭhaḥ uva  sundarataraḥ amattaññū hi sīdanti iti bhojane pamāṇam a jānantāḥ hi rasa taṇhā vasena pāpa kammaṃ
translated: “Even though not burned, they are well burned indeed.” But in the text the reading is “agiddhimā,” and therefore the reading of the Commentary is preferable.🔽For those who know moderation in eating do not fall into misfortune.

analyzed: te diṭṭhadhamme pi samparāye pi na sīdanti iti
translated: Those who know moderation in eating do not fall into misfortune either in this world or in the world to come.

analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne  bahū sotāpannāḥ api sakadāgāminaḥ api anāgāminaḥ api arahantaḥ api ahesum tadā suka rāja putto
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he expounded the Four Truths and identified the Birth by pronouncing the words of the stanza,

translated: “At that time the king of the Suka birds was the monk who did not know moderation in eating, and I myself was the king of the Suka birds.”

translated: The story of the Suka bird is ended.🔽The story of the Jarūdapāna is ended.

original: [256] 6. Jarūdapānajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the Jarūdapāna is ended.

original: Jarūdapānaṃ khaṇamānāti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto sāvatthivāsino vāṇije ārabbha
analyzed: idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ sāvatthi vāsinaḥ vāṇije ārabbha
translated: The Teacher related this story while dwelling at Jetavana, with reference to some merchants who lived at Sāvatthi.

original: kathesi. Te kira sāvatthiyaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā sakaṭāni pūretvā vohāratthāya gamanakāle
analyzed: kathesi te kira sāvatthiyam bhaṇḍam gahetvā sakaṭāni pūretvā vohāra atthāya gamana kāle
translated: and told it. They had taken goods to Sāvatthi, and having filled their carts, they were about to go on a trading journey.

original: tathāgataṃ nimantetvā saraṇāni gahetvā sīlesu patiṭṭhāya satthāraṃ vanditvā “mayaṃ,
analyzed: tathāgatam nimantetvā saraṇāni gahetvā sīlesu patiṭṭhāya satthāram vanditvā mayam
translated: At the time of their departure they invited the Realised One, took the Refuges, were established in the precepts, and after worshipping the Teacher they said: “Venerable Sir,

analyzed: bhante vohāra atthāya dīgha maggam gamissāma bhaṇḍam vissajjetvā siddhi ppattā sotthinā
translated: we are going on a long journey for trading, after selling our goods and gaining success we will return safely

original: paccāgantvā pana tumhe vandissāmā”ti vatvā maggaṃ paṭipajjiṃsu. Te kantāramagge purāṇaudapānaṃ
analyzed: paccāgantvā pana tumhe vandissāma ati vatvā maggam paṭipajjiṃsu te kantāra magge purāṇa odapānam
translated: and then we will worship you.” After saying this they set out on the road. They saw an old well

original: disvā “imasmiṃ udapāne pānīyaṃ natthi, mayañca pipāsitā, khaṇissāma na”nti khaṇantā
analyzed: disvā imasmin udapāne pānīyam natthi mayam ca pipāsitā khaṇissāma nanti khaṇantā
translated: in the middle of the desert, and thinking: “There is no water in this well, and we are thirsty, let us dig it up,” they dug it up,

original: paṭipāṭiyā bahuṃ ayaṃ…pe… veḷuriyaṃ labhiṃsu. Te teneva santuṭṭhā hutvā tesaṃ ratanānaṃ
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā bahum veḷuriyam labhiṃsu te tena iva santuṭṭhāḥ hutvā tesam
translated: and in succession they found much iron, copper, silver, and crystal. They were satisfied with that, and after filling their carts

original: sakaṭāni pūretvā sotthinā sāvatthiṃ paccāgamiṃsu. Te ābhataṃ dhanaṃ paṭisāmetvā mayaṃ
analyzed: sakaṭāni pūretvā sotthinā sāvatthim paccāgamiṃsu te ābhatam dhanam paṭisāmetvā mayam
translated: with those jewels they returned safely to Sāvatthi. They paid back the money they had borrowed, and thinking:

original: “siddhippattā bhattaṃ dassāmā”ti tathāgataṃ nimantetvā dānaṃ datvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ
analyzed: siddhi pattāḥ bhattam dassāma ati tathāgatam nimantetvā dānam datvā vanditvā ekamantam
translated: “We have gained success, we will give a meal,” they invited the Realised One, gave a gift, worshipped him, and sat down to one side.

original: nisinnā attano dhanassa laddhākāraṃ satthu ārocesuṃ. Satthā “tumhe kho upāsakā tena
analyzed: nisinnāḥ attanaḥ dhanassa laddhākāram satthu ārocesuṃ satthā tumhe kho upāsakā tena
translated: and when they were seated they told the Teacher how they had obtained their wealth. The Teacher said: “You, lay disciples,

original: dhanena santuṭṭhā hutvā pamāṇaññutāya dhanañca jīvitañca alabhittha, porāṇakā pana
analyzed: dhanena santuṭṭhāḥ hutvā pamāṇaññu tāya dhanañca jīvitañca alabhittha porāṇakā pana
translated: and told him how they had got their wealth. The Teacher said, “Lay disciples, you were satisfied with what you got, and by moderation saved both your wealth and your lives; but the ancients,

original: asantuṭṭhā amattaññuno paṇḍitānaṃ vacanaṃ akatvā jīvikkhayaṃ pattā”ti vatvā tehi
analyzed: a santuṭṭhāḥ a mattaññunaḥ paṇḍitānam vacanam a katvā jīvi khayam patta ati vatvā tehi
translated: being discontented and immoderate, lost their lives because they would not follow the advice of the wise.” So saying, he expounded the Law by pronouncing the following Stanza,

original: yācito atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: yācitaḥ atītam āhari
translated: At the request of the lay disciples, he related this story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto bārāṇasiyaṃ vāṇijakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ bārāṇasiyam vāṇija kule nibbattitvā
translated: Once upon a time when Brahmadatta reigned in Benares, the Bodhisatta was born in a family of merchants in Benares,

analyzed: vaya pattaḥ satthavāha jeṭṭhakaḥ ahosi saḥ bārāṇasiyam bhaṇḍam gahetvā sakaṭāni pūretvā  bahū vāṇije ādāya tam eva kantāram paṭipanno tam eva udapānam addasa tattha te vāṇijā
translated: and when he grew up he became the chief of a caravan. He took goods to Benares, filled his carts,🔽and taking many merchants with him, set out for the same desert. He saw the same well, and the merchants,

original: “pānīyaṃ pivissāmā”ti taṃ udapānaṃ khaṇantā paṭipāṭiyā bahūni ayādīni labhiṃsu. Te
analyzed: pānīyam pivissāma ati tam udapānam khaṇantā paṭipāṭiyā bahūni aya ādīni labhiṃsu te
translated: thinking to drink, dug down into the well, and one after another got much iron and other things. They got

original: bahumpi ratanaṃ labhitvā tena asantuṭṭhā “aññampi ettha ito sundarataraṃ bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: bahum pi ratanam labhitvā tena asantuṭṭhāḥ aññam pi ettha itas sundarataram bhavissati iti
translated: so much treasure that they were not satisfied with it, and thinking, “There must be something finer here than this,”🔽they dug down still further.

original: bhiyyosomattāya taṃ khaṇiṃsuyeva. Atha bodhisatto te āha – “bho vāṇijā, lobho nāmesa
analyzed: bhiyyosomattāya tam atha bodhisatto te āha bho vāṇijāḥ lobhaḥ nāma isa
translated: and they were all the more eager to eat it. Then the Bodhisatta said to them, “My friends, greed

original: vināsamūlaṃ, amhehi bahu dhanaṃ laddhaṃ, ettakeneva santuṭṭhā hotha, mā atikhaṇathā”ti.🔽Te tena nivāriyamānāpi khaṇiṃsuyeva. So ca udapāno nāgapariggahito, athassa heṭṭhā
analyzed: vināsa mūlam amhehi bahu dhanam laddham ettakena iva santuṭṭhāḥ hotha mā atikhaṇatha ati  te tena nivāriyamānā api so ca udapānaḥ nāga pariggahitaḥ athassa heṭṭhā
translated: and they began to dig it up more and more. Then the Bodhisatta said to them, “Good traders, greed is the root of destruction. We have got much wealth already; be content with what you have got, and do not dig any more.”

original: vasanakanāgarājā attano vimāne bhijjante leḍḍūsū ca paṃsūsu ca patamānesu kuddho
analyzed: vasanaka nāga rājā vimāne bhijjante ca paṃsūsu ca patamānesu kuddhaḥ
translated: But though he tried to dissuade them, they went on digging. Now the spring was guarded by a Nāga, and the king of the Nāgas, who lived below, saw his palace breaking up and stones and earth falling down, and he was angry.

original: ṭhapetvā bodhisattaṃ avasese sabbepi nāsikavātena paharitvā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpetvā🔽nāgabhavanā nikkhamma sakaṭāni yojetvā sabbaratanānaṃ pūretvā bodhisattaṃ sukhayānake
analyzed: ṭhapetvā bodhisattam avasese sabbe api nāsika vātena paharitvā jīvita khayam pāpetvā  nāga bhavanā nikkhamma sakaṭāni yojetvā sabba rata nānam pūretvā bodhisattam sukha yānake
translated: He blew out his breath through his nostrils, and all the traders were killed, except the Bodhisatta.🔽Then he left his Nāga palace, and yoking his carts, he filled them with all kinds of precious stones, and having placed the Bodhisatta in a comfortable carriage,

original: nisīdāpetvā nāgamāṇavakehi saddhiṃ sakaṭāni yojāpento bodhisattaṃ bārāṇasiṃ netvā
analyzed: nisīdāpetvā nāga māṇavakehi saddhim sakaṭāni yojāpentaḥ bodhisattam bārāṇasim netvā
translated: he had the carts yoked by the young Nāgas, and he himself drove the carriage, and he took the Bodhisatta to Benares,

analyzed: gharam pavesetvā tam paṭisāmetvā attanaḥ nāga bhavanam eva gataḥ bodhisatto tam dhanam
translated: and having brought him to his house, he gave him all the wealth, and having placed him in his own palace, he went to his own Nāga palace. The Bodhisatta,

analyzed: vissajjetvā sakala jambudīpam unnaṅgalam katvā dānam da tvā sīlam samādiyitvā uposatha kammaṃ
translated: and after giving gifts, and after taking upon themselves the precepts of virtue, and after performing the Uposatha duties,

original: katvā jīvitapariyosāne saggapuraṃ pūresi.
analyzed: katvā jīvita pariyosāne sagga puram pūresi
translated: at the end of life filled the city of the gods.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā abhisambuddho hutvā imā gāthā avoca –
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā imāḥ gāthāḥ avoca
translated: When the Teacher had related this Dhamma, after becoming Buddha, he related the following Stanzas,

original: “Jarūdapānaṃ khaṇamānā, vāṇijā udakatthikā;
analyzed: jarū dapānam khaṇamānā vāṇijā udakatthikā
translated: “The merchants, seeking water, while digging,

analyzed: ajjhagamum ayasam loham tipu sīsam ca vāṇijā
translated: came upon iron, copper, and tin,

original: Rajataṃ jātarūpañca, muttā veḷuriyā bahū.
analyzed: rajatam jātarūpam ca muttāḥ veḷuriyāḥ
translated: silver, gold, and many pearls and cat’s eyes.

original: “Te ca tena asantuṭṭhā, bhiyyo bhiyyo akhāṇisuṃ;
analyzed: te ca tena a santuṭṭhāḥ bhiyyas bhiyyas akhāṇisum
translated: “But being dissatisfied with that, they dug still further,

original: Te tatthāsīviso ghoro, tejassī tejasā hani.
analyzed: te ghoro tejassī tejasā hani
translated: and there a terrible poisonous snake,

original: “Tasmā khaṇe nātikhaṇe, atikhātañhi pāpakaṃ;
analyzed: tasmai khaṇe na atikhaṇe atikhātam hi pāpakam
translated: “Therefore, dig when it is time to dig; for digging out of season is evil.

original: Khātena ca dhanaṃ laddhaṃ, atikhātena nāsita”nti.
analyzed: khātena ca dhanam laddham atikhātena
translated: By digging in season one gains wealth, but by digging out of season one is ruined.”

original: Tattha ayasanti kāḷalohaṃ. Lohanti tambalohaṃ. Muttāti muttāyo. Te ca tena asantuṭṭhāti
analyzed: tattha ayasanti kāḷa loham lohanti tamba loham muttā ati te ca tena a santuṭṭhā ti

analyzed: te ca vāṇijā tena dhanena asantuṭṭhā te tattha ati te vāṇijā tasmin udapāne tejassi iti
translated: those merchants being dissatisfied with that wealth. There means in that well. A poisonous snake means

analyzed: visa tejena samannāgato tejasā hani iti visa tejena atikhātena atikhaṇena
translated: and was endowed with great splendor. “By splendor” means by great splendor. “By the over-throw” means by the over-throw.

original: tañca dhanaṃ jīvitañca nāsitaṃ.
analyzed: tat ca dhanam jīvitañca na asitam
translated: and he destroyed both his wealth and his life.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā nāgarājā sāriputto ahosi, satthavāhajeṭṭhako pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā nāga rājā sāriputto ahosi satthavāha jeṭṭhakaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: After relating this story, the Master identified the Birth: “At that time Sāriputta was the king of the Nāgas, and I myself was the chief of the caravan.”

original: Jarūdapānajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.
analyzed: jarūdapānajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: The Story of the Birth as Jarūpāṇin.

original: [257] 7. Gāmaṇicandajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Birth as Gāmaṇi-Canda

analyzed: na ayam kusalaḥ ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ paññāpasaṃsanam ārabbha kathesi
translated: This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning the praise of wisdom.

analyzed: dhammasabhāyan hi bhikkhū dasabalassa paññam pasaṃsantāḥ nisīdiṃsu āvuso tathāgato
translated: For the monks were sitting together in the Hall of Truth praising the Ten-Powered One’s wisdom: “Friends, the Tathāgata

analyzed: lokam paññāya atikkamati iti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya

original: sannisinnā”ti pucchitvā “imāya nāmā”ti vutte “na, bhikkhave, idāneva, pubbepi tathāgato
analyzed: sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi tathāgataḥ
translated: “What are they doing?” “They are discussing the matter of the Buddha’s wisdom.” “Monks, this is not the first time they have done this;

analyzed: paññavāya iva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: in the past, too, they did the same thing.” So saying, he told an old-time story.

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam janasandhaḥ nāma rājā rajjam kāresi bodhisatto tassa agga mahesiyā
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in the womb of the king’s chief consort.

original: kucchimhi nibbatti. Tassa mukhaṃ suparimajjitakañcanādāsatalaṃ viya parisuddhaṃ ahosi
analyzed: kucchimhi nibbatti tassa mukham su parimajjita kañcanā dāsa talam viya parisuddham ahosi
translated: His face was as pure and clear as the surface of well-polished gold, and was exceedingly beautiful.

original: atisobhaggappattaṃ, tenassa nāmaggahaṇadivase “ādāsamukhamāro”ti nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Taṃ
analyzed: ati sobhagga ppattam tena assa nāma ggahaṇa divase ādāsamukhamāro ti nāmam akaṃsu tam
translated: Therefore, on the day when he was named, they gave him the name Ādāsī-mukha.

analyzed: pana pitā tayo vede ca sabbam ca loke kattabba a kattabbam sikkhāpetvā  tassa satta vassika kāle kālam akāsi amaccā mahantena sakkārena rañño sarīra kiccam
translated: Within seven years he had learned the three Vedas and all that ought to be learned in the world.🔽When he was seven years old, his father died. The ministers performed the king’s funeral rites with great pomp,

original: katvā matakadānaṃ datvā sattame divase rājaṅgaṇe sannipatitvā “kumāro atidaharo,
analyzed: katvā mataka dānam da tvā sattame divase rājaṅgaṇe sannipatitvā kumāraḥ ati daharaḥ
translated: and after giving the funeral offerings, on the seventh day they assembled in the royal court and said, “The prince is too young,

original: na sakkā rajje abhisiñcituṃ, vīmaṃsitvā naṃ abhisiñcissāmā”ti ekadivasaṃ nagaraṃ
analyzed: na sakkā rajje abhisiñcitum vīmaṃsitvā nam abhisiñcissāma ati eka divasam nagaram

analyzed: alaṅkārāpetvā vinicchaya ṭṭhānam sajjetvā pallaṅkam paññapetvā kumārassa santikaṃ  gantvā vinicchaya ṭṭhānam deva gantum vaṭṭati iti āhaṃsu kumāraḥ sādhu iti mahantena
translated: decorated, prepared a court of justice, and set up a throne. Then they went to the prince

original: parivārena gantvā pallaṅke nisīdi.
analyzed: parivārena gantvā pallaṅke nisīdi
translated: and said, “Your majesty, it is proper for you to go to the court of justice.” The prince said, “Very well,” and went with a great retinue and sat down on the throne.

original: Tassa nisinnakāle amaccā ekaṃ dvīhi pādehi vicaraṇamakkaṭaṃ vatthuvijjācariyavesaṃ🔽gāhāpetvā vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ netvā “deva, ayaṃ puriso pitu mahārājassa kāle vatthuvijjācariyo🔽paguṇavijjo antobhūmiyaṃ sattaratanaṭṭhāne guṇadosaṃ passati, eteneva gahitaṃ rājakulānaṃ
analyzed: tassa nisinna kāle amaccāḥ ekam dvīhi pādehi vicaraṇa makkaṭam vatthu vijjā cariya vesam  gāhāpetvā vinicchaya ṭṭhānam netvā deva ayam purisaḥ mahā rājassa kāle vatthu vijjā cariyaḥ  paguṇa vijjaḥ antobhūmiyam satta ratana ṭṭhāne guṇa dosam passati etena iva gahitam rāja kulānam
translated: While he was sitting there, the ministers had a monkey brought, which walked on two legs and was dressed in the costume of a teacher of the Vedas.

original: gehaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, imaṃ devo saṅgaṇhitvā ṭhānantare ṭhapetū”ti āhaṃsu. Kumāro taṃ
analyzed: geha ṭṭhānam hoti imam devo saṅgaṇhitvā ṭhapetu iti āhaṃsu kumāraḥ taṃ
translated: They took it to the court of justice and said, “Your majesty, this man was a teacher of the Vedas in the time of your father, the great king. He is skilled in the Vedas and sees the good and bad qualities in the seven treasures in the underworld. Whatever he takes is the property of the royal family and the householders. Your majesty should favor him and appoint him to a position.” The prince

original: heṭṭhā ca uparica oloketvā “nāyaṃ manusso, makkaṭo eso”ti ñatvā “makkaṭā nāma kataṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā ca upari ca oloketvā na ayam manusso makkaṭaḥ eso ti ñatvā makkaṭā nāma katam
translated: Looking up and down, he saw that it was not a man, but a monkey. He thought, “Monkeys know how to destroy what has been done,
