analyzed: katam vid haṃsetum jānanti a katam pana kātum vā vicāretum vā na jānanti iti cintetvā
translated: but they do not know how to do what has not been done, nor how to consider what should be done.”

original: amaccānaṃ paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: amaccānam paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: He spoke the first verse to the ministers:

original: “Nāyaṃ gharānaṃ kusalo, lolo ayaṃ valīmukho;
analyzed: na ayam kusalaḥ lolaḥ ayam
translated: “He is not skilled in building houses, he is a restless, wrinkled-faced monkey.

original: Kataṃ kataṃ kho dūseyya, evaṃ dhammamidaṃ kula”nti.🔽Tattha nāyaṃ gharānaṃ kusaloti ayaṃ satto na gharānaṃ kusalo, gharāni vicāretuṃ vā
analyzed: katam katam kho dūseyya evam dhammam idam kulanti  tattha na ayam kusalaḥ ti ayam satto na kusalaḥ vicāretum vā
translated: What has been done he will destroy, such is the nature of this family.”

original: kātuṃ vā cheko na hoti. Loloti lolajātiko. Valīmukhoti valiyo mukhe assāti valīmukho.
analyzed: kātum vā chekaḥ na hoti lolaḥ ti lola jātikaḥ valīmukho ti valiyaḥ mukhe assa ati valīmukhaḥ
translated: Herein, he is not skilled in building houses means this being is not skilled in building houses, he is not clever in considering or building houses. Restless means of restless nature. Wrinkled-faced means he has wrinkles on his face, thus he is wrinkled-faced.

original: Evaṃ dhammamidaṃkulanti idaṃ makkaṭakulaṃ nāma kataṃ kataṃ dūsetabbaṃ vināsetabbanti evaṃ sabhāvanti.
analyzed: evam dhammam idaṃkulanti idam makkaṭa kulam nāma katam katam dūsetabbam vināsetabbanti evam sabhāvanti
translated: Such is the nature of this family means this monkey family is such that what has been done should be destroyed, should be ruined, thus is its nature.

original: Athāmaccā “evaṃ bhavissati, devā”ti taṃ apanetvā ekāhadvīhaccayena puna tameva alaṅkaritvā
analyzed: atha amaccā evam bhavissati deva iti tam apanetvā ekāha dvīha cayena puna tam eva alaṅkaritvā
translated: Then the ministers said, “It will be so, your majesty,” and they took him away. After one or two days, they decorated him again and brought him back.

original: vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ ānetvā “ayaṃ, deva, pitu mahārājassa kāle vinicchayāmacco, vinicchayasuttamassa
analyzed: vinicchaya ṭṭhānam ānetvā ayam deva mahā rājassa kāle vinicchaya amaccaḥ vinicchaya suttamassa
translated: “Your Majesty, this is the King’s former judge, the man who was skilled in the legal code.

original: supavattitaṃ, imaṃ saṅgaṇhitvā vinicchayakammaṃ kāretuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti āhaṃsu. Kumāro
analyzed: imam saṅgaṇhitvā vinicchaya kammam kāretum vaṭṭati iti āhaṃsu kumāro
translated: He is well-trained, so it would be good to appoint him to the work of judging.” The prince

original: taṃ oloketvā “cittavato manussassa lomaṃ nāma evarūpaṃ na hoti, ayaṃ nicittako vānaro
analyzed: tam oloketvā cittavataḥ manussassa lomam nāma evarūpam na hoti ayam nicittakaḥ vānaraḥ
translated: looked at him and thought, “The hair of a wise man is not like this. This is a wise monkey.

original: vinicchayakammaṃ kātuṃ na sakkhissatī”ti ñatvā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: vinicchaya kammam kātum na sakkhissati iti ñatvā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: He will not be able to do the work of judging.” Understanding this, he spoke a second verse:

original: “Nayidaṃ cittavato lomaṃ, nāyaṃ assāsiko migo;
analyzed: na yidam cittavataḥ lomam na ayam assāsikaḥ migaḥ
translated: “This is not the hair of a wise man, this is not a deer who breathes;

original: Siṭṭhaṃ me janasandhena, nāyaṃ kiñci vijānatī”ti.🔽Tattha nayidaṃ cittavato lomanti yaṃ idaṃ etassa sarīre pharusalomaṃ, idaṃ vicāraṇapaññāya
analyzed: siṭṭham me jana sandhena na ayam kiñci vijānati iti  tattha na idam cittavataḥ yat idam etassa sarīre pharusa lomaṃ idam vicāraṇa paññāya
translated: I am trained in the company of men, he knows nothing at all.”

original: sampayuttacittavato na hoti. Pākatikacittena pana acittako nāma tiracchānagato natthi.
analyzed: sampayutta cittavataḥ na hoti pākatika cittena pana acittakaḥ nāma tiracchāna gataḥ natthi
translated: Herein, this is not the hair of a wise man: the rough hair on his body is not the hair of a wise man who is endowed with the wisdom of discernment. But there is no animal without consciousness who has normal consciousness.

original: Nāyaṃ assāsikoti ayaṃ avassayo vā hutvā anusāsaniṃ vā datvā aññaṃ assāsetuṃ asamatthatāya
analyzed: na ayam assāsikā ti ayam avassayaḥ vā hutvā anusāsanim vā datvā aññam assāsetum a samattha tāya
translated: This is not a deer who breathes: he is not a deer who breathes in the sense of being a support or giving advice or being able to comfort another.

original: na assāsiko. Migoti makkaṭaṃ āha. Siṭṭhaṃ me janasandhenāti mayhaṃ pitarā janasandhena
analyzed: na assāsikaḥ migo ti makkaṭam āha siṭṭham me jana sandhena ati mayham pitarā jana sandhena
translated: He is not a man who breathes in and out. A monkey: he calls a monkey a monkey. I was taught the human way:

original: etaṃ siṭṭhaṃ kathitaṃ, “makkaṭo nāma kāraṇākāraṇaṃ na jānātī”ti evaṃ anusāsanī dinnāti
analyzed: etam siṭṭham kathitam makkaṭaḥ nāma kāraṇa akāraṇam na jānāti iti evam anusāsanī dinnā ati
translated: he shows that his father taught him the human way, saying, “A monkey does not know what is right and what is wrong.”

original: dīpeti. Nāyaṃ kiñci vijānatīti tasmā ayaṃ vānaro na kiñci jānātīti niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: dīpeti na ayam kiñci vijānati iti tasmai ayam vānaraḥ na kiñci jānāti iti niṭṭham ettha gantabbam
translated: This ape does not know anything: therefore it should be concluded that this ape does not know anything.

original: Pāḷiyaṃ pana “nāyaṃ kiñci na dūsaye”ti likhitaṃ, taṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ natthi.
analyzed: pāḷiyam pana na ayam kiñci na dūsayeti likhitam aṭṭhakathāyam natthi
translated: But in the text it is written, “He does not spoil anything,” which is not in the commentary.

original: Amaccā imampi gāthaṃ sutvā “evaṃ bhavissati, devā”ti taṃ apanetvā punapi ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: amaccāḥ imam pi gātham sutvā evam bhavissati deva ati tam apanetvā puna api eka divasam
translated: The ministers, having heard this verse, said, “So it will be, your majesty,” and they took him away. Then one day🔽they decorated him again, brought him to the judgment hall, and said, “Your majesty, this man

original: tameva alaṅkaritvā vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ ānetvā “ayaṃ, deva, puriso pitu mahārājassa
analyzed: tam eva alaṅkaritvā vinicchaya ṭṭhānam ānetvā ayam deva purisaḥ mahā rājassa
translated: during the time of your father the great king

original: kāle mātāpituupaṭṭhānakārako, kulejeṭṭhāpacāyikakammakārako, imaṃ saṅgaṇhituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti
analyzed: kāle mātā pitu upaṭṭhāna kārako imam saṅgaṇhitum vaṭṭati iti
translated: was a servant to his parents, a doer of duties to his family elders. It is proper to take him into your service.”

original: āhaṃsu. Kumāro taṃ oloketvā “makkaṭā nāma calacittā, evarūpaṃ kammaṃ kātuṃ na samatthā”ti
analyzed: āhaṃsu kumāraḥ tam oloketvā makkaṭā nāma cala cittā evarūpam kammam kātum na samatthā ati
translated: The prince, looking at him, said, “Monkeys are fickle-minded. They are not able to do such work.”

original: cintetvā tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: cintetvā tatiyam gātham āha
translated: and he thought and spoke the third stanza:

original: “Na mātaraṃ pitaraṃ vā, bhātaraṃ bhaginiṃ sakaṃ;
analyzed: na mātaram pitaram vā bhātaram bhaginim sakam
translated: Neither mother nor father, nor brother, nor sister,

original: Bhareyya tādiso poso, siṭṭhaṃ dasarathena me”ti.
analyzed: bhareyya tādisaḥ posaḥ siṭṭham dasa rathena mā iti
translated: Would support such a man, as my father has instructed me.

original: Tattha bhātaraṃ bhaginiṃ sakanti attano bhātaraṃ vā bhaginiṃ vā. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “sakha”nti🔽likhitaṃ, taṃ pana aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “sakanti vutte sakabhātikabhaginiyo labbhanti, sakhanti
analyzed: tattha bhātaram bhaginim sakanti attanaḥ bhātaram vā bhaginim vā pāḷiyam pana sakhanti  likhitam tam pana aṭṭhakathāyam sakam ti vutte saka bhātika bhaginiyaḥ labbhanti sakam
translated: Herein, brother, sister, and friend are his own brother, sister, and friend. But in the text it is written “sakha.”

original: vutte sahāyako labbhatī”ti vicāritameva. Bhareyyāti poseyya. Tādiso posoti yādiso
analyzed: vutte sahāyakaḥ labbhati iti vicāritam eva bhareyya ati poseyya tādiso poso iti yādiso
translated: But this has been discussed in the Commentary thus: “When ‘sakā’ is said, one’s own brother and sister are included; when ‘sakha’ is said, a friend is included.”

original: esa dissati, tādiso makkaṭajātiko satto na bhareyya. Siṭṭhaṃ dasarathena meti evaṃ🔽me pitarā anusiṭṭhaṃ. Pitā hissa janaṃ catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi sandahanato “janasandho”ti
analyzed: esa dissati tādisaḥ makkaṭa jātikaḥ satto na bhareyya siṭṭham dasa rathena mā iti evam  me pitarā anusiṭṭham pitā hissa janam catūhi saṅgaha vatthūhi sandahanataḥ jana sandho ti
translated: Would support: would maintain. Such a man: a creature of such a kind as this one appears to be. Would not support: would not maintain. As my father has instructed me:

original: vuccati, dasahi rathehi kattabbākattabbaṃ attano ekeneva rathena karaṇato “dasaratho”ti.
analyzed: vuccati dasahi rathehi kattabba a kattabbam attanaḥ ekena iva rathena karaṇataḥ dasarathaḥ ti
translated: thus by my father. For his father is called “the people’s friend” because he unites people with the four means of aggregation, and he is called “the ten-chariot” because he does in one chariot what should be done by ten chariots.

original: Tassa santikā evarūpassa ovādassa sutattā evamāha.
analyzed: tassa santikā evarūpassa ovādassa suta ttā evam āha
translated: Because he has heard such advice from him, he says thus.

original: Amaccā “evaṃ bhavissati, devā”ti makkaṭaṃ apanetvā “paṇḍito kumāro, sakkhissati rajjaṃ
analyzed: amaccā evam bhavissati deva ati makkaṭam apanetvā paṇḍitaḥ kumāraḥ sakkhissati rajjam
translated: The ministers said, “So be it, your majesty,” and they removed the monkey. “The prince is wise,” they said. “He will be able to rule.

original: kāretu”nti bodhisattaṃ rajje abhisiñcitvā “ādāsamukharañño āṇā”ti nagare bheriṃ carāpesuṃ.
analyzed: kāretunti bodhisattam rajje abhisiñcitvā ādāsa mukha raññaḥ āṇāti nagare bherim carāpesum
translated: The ministers, saying, “So be it, your majesty,” removed the monkey, and said, “The prince is wise; he will be able to rule the kingdom.” So they anointed the Bodhisatta king, and caused the drum to be beaten in the city, saying, “By the command of King Ādāsamukha.”

original: Tato paṭṭhāya bodhisatto dhammena rajjaṃ kāresi, paṇḍitabhāvopissa sakalajambudīpaṃ pattharitvā gato.
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya bodhisatto dhammena rajjam kāresi paṇḍita bhāvaḥ upissa sakala jambudīpam pattharitvā gataḥ
translated: From that time forth the Bodhisatta ruled the kingdom righteously, and the fame of his wisdom spread throughout the whole of India.

original: Paṇḍitabhāvadīpanatthaṃ panassa imāni cuddasa vatthūni ābhatāni –
analyzed: paṇḍita bhāva dīpana attham panassa imāni cuddasa vatthūni ābhatāni
translated: But the following fourteen stories are related in order to illustrate his wisdom.

original: “Goṇo putto hayo ceva, naḷakāro gāmabhojako;🔽Gaṇikā taruṇī sappo, migo tittiradevatā;
analyzed: goṇo putto hayaḥ ca iva naḷakāraḥ gāmabhojako
translated: The ox, the son, the horse, the reed-maker, the village-chief,🔽The harlot, the young wife, the snake, the deer, the partridge, the god,

original: Nāgo tapassino ceva, atho brāhmaṇamāṇavo”ti.
analyzed: nāgaḥ tapassinaḥ ca iva atho brāhmaṇa māṇavaḥ ti
translated: The elephant, the ascetic, and the Brahman youth.

original: Tatrāyaṃ anupubbīkathā – bodhisattasmiñhi rajje abhisiñcite eko janasandharañño pādamūliko
analyzed: tatra ayam anupubbī kathā bodhisattasmin hi rajje abhisiñcite ekaḥ janasandharañño pādamūlikaḥ
translated: Now the story of the ox is as follows:—When the Bodhisatta was anointed king, a certain courtier,

original: nāmena gāmaṇicando nāma evaṃ cintesi – “idaṃ rajjaṃ nāma samānavayehi saddhiṃ sobhati,
analyzed: nāmena gāmaṇicandaḥ nāma evam cintesi idam rajjam nāma samāna vayehi saddhim sobhati
translated: a village-chief named Gaṇicanda, thought thus: “This kingdom is glorious only because of my own age.

original: ahañca mahallako, daharaṃ kumāraṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ na sakkhissāmi, janapade kasikammaṃ
analyzed: aham ca mahallakaḥ daharam kumāram upaṭṭhātum na sakkhissāmi janapade kasi kammam
translated: “I am old and decrepit, and I cannot look after a young boy. In the countryside, there is work in the fields.

original: katvā jīvissāmī”ti, so nagarato tiyojanamattaṃ gantvā ekasmiṃ gāmake vāsaṃ kappesi.
analyzed: katvā jīvissāmi iti saḥ nagarataḥ ti yojana mattam gantvā ekasmin gāmake vāsam kappesi
translated: “I am old and cannot look after a young boy. I will go to the country and live by doing farm work.” He went three leagues from the city and settled in a village.

original: Kasikammatthāya panassa goṇāpi natthi, so deve vuṭṭhe ekaṃ sahāyakaṃ dve goṇe yācitvā🔽sabbadivasaṃ kasitvā tiṇaṃ khādāpetvā goṇe sāmikassa niyyādetuṃ gehaṃ agamāsi. So
analyzed: kasi kamma atthāya panassa goṇā api natthi saḥ deve vuṭṭhe ekam sahāyakam dve goṇe yācitvā  sabbadivasam kasitvā tiṇam khādāpetvā goṇe sāmikassa niyyādetum geham agamāsi saḥ
translated: But he had no oxen for farm work. When the rains were over, he asked a friend for two oxen.🔽After plowing all day, he fed the oxen grass and sent them back to their owner. He then went home.

original: tasmiṃ khaṇe bhariyāya saddhiṃ gehamajjhe nisīditvā bhattaṃ bhuñjati. Goṇāpi paricayena
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe bhariyāya saddhim geha majjhe nisīditvā bhattam bhuñjati paricayena
translated: At that moment, his wife was sitting in the middle of the house eating her meal. The oxen, out of habit,

original: gehaṃ pavisiṃsu, tesu pavisantesu sāmiko thālakaṃ ukkhipi, bhariyā thālakaṃ apanesi.
analyzed: geham pavisiṃsu tesu pavisantesu sāmikaḥ thālakam ukkhipi bhariyā thālakam apanesi
translated: entered the house. When they entered, the husband raised his bowl, and the wife lowered her bowl.

original: Gāmaṇicando “bhattena maṃ nimanteyyu”nti olokento goṇe aniyyādetvāva gato. Corā rattiṃ
analyzed: gāmaṇi candaḥ bhattena mam nimanteyyunti olokentaḥ goṇe gataḥ corāḥ rattim
translated: Thinking, “They are inviting me to eat,” he looked around, and without sending the oxen back, he left. Thieves broke into his barn

original: vajaṃ bhinditvā teyeva goṇe hariṃsu. Goṇasāmiko pātova vajaṃ paviṭṭho te goṇe adisvā
analyzed: vajam bhinditvā goṇe hariṃsu goṇa sāmikaḥ vajam paviṭṭhaḥ te goṇe a disvā
translated: and stole those very oxen. The owner of the oxen entered the barn in the morning, and not seeing the oxen,

original: corehi haṭabhāvaṃ jānantopi “gāmaṇicandassa gīvaṃ karissāmī”ti taṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: corehi haṭa bhāvam jānantaḥ api gāmaṇicandassa gīvam karissāmi iti tam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Knowing that the oxen had been stolen by thieves, he went to the king and said, “I want to have the oxen of Gāmaṇi Caṇḍa.”

original: “bho goṇe, me dehī”ti āha. “Nanu goṇā gehaṃ paviṭṭhā”ti. “Kiṃ pana te mayhaṃ niyyāditā”ti?
analyzed: bho goṇe me dehi iti āha nanu goṇā geham paviṭṭhā ati kim pana te mayham niyyāditā ati
translated: “But the oxen have gone into the house,” said the king. “But have they been given to you?”

original: “Na niyyāditā”ti. “Tena hi ayaṃ te rājadūto, ehī”ti āha. Tesu hi janapadesu yaṃkiñci
analyzed: na tena hi ayam te rāja dūtaḥ ehi iti āha tesu hi janapadesu yaṃkiñcid
translated: “No, they have not been given to me.” “Well then, here is the king’s messenger; go and get them.”

original: sakkharaṃ vā kapālakhaṇḍaṃ vā ukkhipitvā “ayaṃ te rājadūto, ehī”ti vutte yo na gacchati,
analyzed: sakkharam vā kapāla khaṇḍam vā ukkhipitvā ayam te rāja dūtaḥ ehi iti vutte yaḥ na gacchati
translated: For in those parts, if one throws a pebble or a piece of pottery and says, “Here is the king’s messenger; go and get them,”

original: tassa rājāṇaṃ karoti, tasmā so “rājadūto”ti sutvāva nikkhami.
analyzed: tassa rājāṇam karoti tasmai saḥ rāja dūtaḥ iti sutvā ava nikkhami
translated: if the other does not go, the king punishes him. Therefore, hearing that the king’s messenger had come, he went out.

original: So tena saddhiṃ rājakulaṃ gacchanto ekaṃ sahāyakassa vasanagāmaṃ patvā “bho, atichātomhi,
analyzed: saḥ tena saddhim rājakulam gacchantaḥ ekam sahāyakassa vasana gāmam patvā bho atichātaḥ amhi
translated: As he was going to the king’s palace with the messenger, he came to a village where a friend of his lived. He said to the messenger, “Friend, I am very hungry.

original: yāva gāmaṃ pavisitvā āhārakiccaṃ katvā āgacchāmi, tāva idheva hohī”ti vatvā sahāyagehaṃ
analyzed: yāva gāmam pavisitvā āhāra kiccam katvā āgacchāmi tāva idha iva hohi iti vatvā sahāya geham
translated: I will go into the village, eat something, and come back. In the meantime, you may wait here.”🔽He went into his friend’s house. His friend was not there, but his wife was. He said to her, “Lady, there is no cooked food.”

original: pāvisi. Sahāyo panassa gehe natthi, sahāyikā disvā “sāmi, pakkāhāro natthi, muhuttaṃ
analyzed: pāvisi sahāyaḥ panassa gehe natthi sahāyikā disvā sāmi pakkāhāraḥ natthi muhuttam
translated: and entered. But he had no friend in the house, and his wife, seeing him, said: “Husband, there is no cooked food, please wait a moment

original: adhivāsehi, idāneva pacitvā dassāmī”ti nisseṇiyā vegena taṇḍulakoṭṭhakaṃ abhiruhantī
analyzed: adhivāsehi idānā iva pacitvā dassāmi iti nisseṇiyāḥ vegena taṇḍula koṭṭhakam abhiruhantī
translated: “Wait, I will cook some rice and give it to you.” She climbed up the rice-bin with great speed,

original: bhūmiyaṃ pati, taṅkhaṇaññeva tassā sattamāsiko gabbho patito. Tasmiṃ khaṇe tassā
analyzed: bhūmiyam pati taṅ khaṇañca eva tassā satta māsikaḥ gabbho patito tasmin khaṇe tassā
translated: and fell to the ground. At that moment her seventh-month child fell from her womb. At that moment

original: sāmiko āgantvā taṃ disvā “tvaṃ me bhariyaṃ paharitvā gabbhaṃ pātesi, ayaṃ te rājadūto,
analyzed: sāmikaḥ āgantvā tam disvā tvam me bhariyam paharitvā gabbham pātesi ayam te rāja dūto
translated: her husband came and saw her. “You have struck my wife and caused her to miscarry. Here is the king’s messenger.

original: ehī”ti taṃ gahetvā nikkhami. Tato paṭṭhāya dve janā gāmaṇiṃ majjhe katvā gacchanti.
analyzed: ehi iti tam gahetvā nikkhami tatas paṭṭhāya dve janāḥ gāmaṇim majjhe katvā gacchanti
translated: Come!” So saying, he seized him and went out. From that time on the two men went along with the village headman between them.

original: Athekasmiṃ gāmadvāre eko assagopako assaṃ nivattetuṃ na sakkoti, assopi tesaṃ santikena🔽gacchati. Assagopako gāmaṇicandaṃ disvā “mātula gāmaṇicanda, etaṃ tāva assaṃ kenacideva
analyzed: atha ekasmim gāma dvāre ekaḥ assa gopakaḥ assam nivattetum na sakkoti assaḥ api tesam santikena  gacchati assa gopakaḥ gāmaṇi candam disvā mātula gāmaṇi canda etam tāva assam kenacid eva
translated: Then at the gate of a certain village a horse-keeper was unable to stop his horse, and the horse went along with them.

original: paharitvā nivattehī”ti āha. So ekaṃ pāsāṇaṃ gahetvā khipi, pāsāṇo assassa pāde paharitvā
analyzed: paharitvā nivattehi iti āha saḥ ekam pāsāṇam gahetvā khipi pāsāṇaḥ assassa pāde paharitvā
translated: The horse-keeper, seeing that the village headman was fond of horses, said, “Uncle, village headman, strike this horse with something or other and make him stop.” He took a stone and threw it. The stone struck the horse’s foot and broke it

original: eraṇḍadaṇḍakaṃ viya bhindi. Atha naṃ assagopako “tayā me assassa pādo bhinno, ayaṃ
analyzed: eraṇḍa daṇḍakam viya atha nam assagopako tayā me assassa pādaḥ bhinnaḥ ayam
translated: like a castor-oil plant stalk. Then the horse-keeper said, “You have broken my horse’s foot.

original: te rājadūto”ti vatvā gaṇhi.🔽So tīhi janehi nīyamāno cintesi – “ime maṃ rañño dassessanti, ahaṃ goṇamūlampi dātuṃ
analyzed: te rāja dūtā iti vatvā gaṇhi  saḥ tīhi janehi nīyamānaḥ cintesi ime mam raññaḥ dassessanti aham goṇa mūlam pi dātum
translated: “They are the king’s messengers.”

analyzed: yāvatā candima sūriyā pariharanti disā bhanti virocanā
translated: “As long as the sun and moon endure, as long as the world-systems stand,

original: Sabbeva dāsā mandhātu, ye pāṇā pathavissitā.
analyzed: sabbā iva dāsā mandhātu ye pāṇā pathavissitā
translated: All beings that are on the earth are slaves to Mandhatu.

original: “Na kahāpaṇavassena, titti kāmesu vijjati;
analyzed: na kahā paṇa vassena titti kāmesu vijjati
translated: “No one is satisfied with the rain of coins, with sensual pleasures;

original: Appassādā dukhā kāmā, iti viññāya paṇḍito.
analyzed: appassādāḥ dukhā kāmāḥ iti viññāya paṇḍito
translated: The wise one, knowing that sensual pleasures are of little taste and much suffering,

original: “Api dibbesu kāmesu, ratiṃ so nādhigacchati;
analyzed: api dibbesu kāmesu ratim saḥ na adhigacchati
translated: “He does not find delight even in divine sensual pleasures;

original: Taṇhakkhayarato hoti, sammāsambuddhasāvako”ti.
analyzed: taṇha khaya rataḥ hoti sammāsambuddha sāvakaḥ iti
translated: The disciple of the Fully Enlightened One delights in the destruction of craving.”

original: Tattha yāvatāti paricchedavacanaṃ. Pariharantīti yattakena paricchedena sineruṃ pariharanti.
analyzed: tattha yāvatā ati pariccheda vacanam pariharanti iti yattakena paricchedena sinerum pariharanti
translated: Herein, as long as means a term for limitation. They endure means they are limited to the extent that they go around Sineru.

original: Disā bhantīti dasasu disāsu bhāsanti pabhāsanti. Virocanāti ālokakaraṇatāya virocanasabhāvā.
analyzed: disā bhanti iti dasasu disāsu bhāsanti pabhāsanti virocanā ati āloka karaṇatāya virocana sabhāvā
translated: They shine means they shine in the ten world-systems. They are radiant means they have the nature of being radiant by means of their illumination.

original: Sabbeva dāsā mandhātu, ye pāṇā pathavissitāti ettake padese ye pathavinissitā pāṇā🔽janapadavāsino manussā, sabbeva te “dāsā mayaṃ rañño mandhātussa, ayyako no rājā
analyzed: sabbā iva dāsā mandhātu ye pāṇā pathavi sitā ati ettake padese ye pathavi nissitā pāṇā  janapada vāsinaḥ manussā sabbe iva te dāsāḥ mayam raññaḥ mandhātussa ayyakaḥ naḥ rājā
translated: All the people of the land were slaves to King Mandhatu,🔽who had dominion over all the people of the earth in the area of the four continents.

original: mandhātā”ti evaṃ upagatattā bhujissāpi samānā dāsāyeva.🔽Na kahāpaṇavassenāti tesaṃ dāsabhūtānaṃ manussānaṃ anuggahāya yaṃ mandhātā apphoṭetvā🔽sattaratanavassaṃ vassāpeti, taṃ idha “kahāpaṇavassa”nti vuttaṃ. Titti kāmesūti tenāpi
analyzed: mandhātā ati evam upagata ttā bhujissā api samānā dāsāya iva  na kahāpaṇa vassena ati tesam dāsa bhūtānam manussānam anuggahāya yam mandhātā apphoṭetvā  satta ratana vassam vassāpeti tam idha kahāpaṇa vassanti vuttam titti kāmesu iti tena api
translated: Though they were not really slaves, they were considered slaves because they had submitted to the king, saying, “We are the king’s slaves; the king is our master.”

original: kahāpaṇavassena vatthukāmakilesakāmesu titti nāma natthi, evaṃ duppūrā esā taṇhā.🔽Appassādā dukhā kāmāti supinakūpamattā kāmā nāma appassādā parittasukhā, dukkhameva
analyzed: kahāpaṇa vassena vatthu kāma kilesa kāmesu titti nāma natthi evam duppūrā esā taṇhā  appassādā dukhā kāmā ati supinakūpa mattā kāmā nāma appassādā paritta sukhā dukkham eva
translated: Na kahāpaṇavassena: the rain of the seven treasures that King Mandhatu caused to rain down for the benefit of his people is called “the rain of kahāpaṇas” here. Titti kāmesū: even with that rain of kahāpaṇas, there is no satisfaction in sensual pleasures, whether sensual pleasures as objects or sensual pleasures as defilements. Thus craving is difficult to satisfy.

original: panettha bahutaraṃ. Taṃ dukkhakkhandhasuttapariyāyena dīpetabbaṃ. Iti viññāyāti evaṃ jānitvā.
analyzed: pana ittha bahutaram tat dukkhakkhandha sutta pariyāyena dīpetabbam iti viññāya ati evam jānitvā
translated: Appassādā dukhā kāmā: sensual pleasures are like a dream; they are of little taste, of limited pleasure, and suffering is more abundant. This should be illustrated by the discourse on the mass of suffering. Iti viññāya: having known thus.

original: Dibbesūti devatānaṃ paribhogesu rūpādīsu. Ratiṃ soti so vipassako bhikkhu dibbehi
analyzed: dibbesu iti devatānam paribhogesu rūpa ādīsu ratim saḥ iti saḥ vipassakaḥ bhikkhu dibbehi
translated: “In heavenly things” means in the heavenly objects of sense-desire, such as visible forms, etc. “He finds no delight” means that the meditator finds no delight in the heavenly objects of sense-desire, even though he is invited to enjoy them, as did the Venerable Samiddhi. “Delights in the destruction of craving” means delights in Nibbāna. For craving is destroyed by means of Nibbāna, and therefore Nibbāna is called “the destruction of craving.”🔽He delights in it, he takes delight in it. “The disciple of the Perfectly Enlightened One” means the one who has gone forth from the home life into homelessness, who is learned, and who is a meditator.🔽Having related this Dhamma instruction, the Teacher identified the Birth Stories: “At that time the king was Mandhatu, and I myself was the brahmin.”🔽And when the Teacher had related the Mandhatu Birth Story, he had the monks assemble and asked them, “Monks, is there anyone who has not attained any of the fruitions?”🔽Then the monk who had been so eager to go to the monastery of the sectarians came and said, “I have not attained any of the fruitions.”🔽The Teacher said to him, “Monk, you have not attained any of the fruitions because you have not fulfilled the precepts of conduct.”🔽And having so said, he expounded the Law by pronouncing the following Stanzas,🔽The monks who are not heedless, who are devoted to the higher thought, who are ever mindful, and who are not negligent in their duties,

original: kāmehi nimantiyamānopi tesu ratiṃ nādhigacchati āyasmā samiddhi viya. Taṇhakkhayaratoti🔽nibbānarato. Nibbānañhi āgamma taṇhā khīyati, tasmā taṃ “taṇhakkhayo”ti vuccati.
analyzed: kāmehi nimantiyamānaḥ api tesu ratim na adhigacchati viya taṇha khaya rataḥ ti  nibbāna rataḥ nibbānam hi āgamma taṇhā khīyati tasmā tam taṇha kkhayo ti vuccati
translated: Translation: Dibbesūti devatānaṃ paribhogesu rūpādīsu. Ratiṃ soti so vipassako bhikkhu dibbehi kāmehi nimantiyamānopi tesu ratiṃ nādhigacchati āyasmā samiddhi viya. Taṇhakkhayaratoti nibbānarato. Nibbānañhi āgamma taṇhā khīyati, tasmā taṃ “taṇhakkhayo”ti vuccati.

original: Tattha rato hoti abhirato. Sammāsambuddhasāvakoti buddhassa savanante jāto bahussuto yogāvacarapuggalo.
analyzed: tattha rataḥ hoti abhirataḥ sammāsambuddha sāvako ti buddhassa savana ante jātaḥ bahu ssutaḥ yogāvacara puggalo
translated: Tattha rato hoti abhirato. Sammāsambuddhasāvakoti buddhassa savanante jāto bahussuto yogāvacarapuggalo.

original: Evaṃ satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne🔽ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi, aññe pana bahū sotāpattiphalādīni pāpuṇiṃsu.🔽“Tadā mandhāturājā ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Mandhātujātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.🔽[259] 9. Tirīṭavacchajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: evam satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne 🔽ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi aññe pana bahū sotāpatti phala ādīni pāpuṇiṃsu 🔽tadā mandhātu rājā aham eva 🔽man dhātu jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā 🔽tirīṭavacchajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: Evaṃ satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ

analyzed: idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ āyasmataḥ ānandassa kosala raññaḥ mātugāmānam  hatthataḥ pañca satāni raññaḥ hatthataḥ pañca satāni iti dussa sahassa paṭilābha vatthum ārabbha
translated: This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning the women of King Pasenadi of Kosala.

translated: The story of the acquisition of the two thousand robes is told in the Dukanipata, in the Gunajātaka.

analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto kāsiraṭṭhe brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā  nāma ggahaṇa divase tirīṭa vaccha kumāraḥ ti kata nāmaḥ anupubbena vaya ppatto takkasilāyam
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was reborn in a Brahman family in the kingdom of Kāsi.🔽On the day of his birth they gave him the name of Tiritta. As he grew up, he learned all the arts at Takkasilā, and while still a layman,

analyzed: so tāpasānam vasanaṭṭhānanti hatthitaḥ otaritvā vāta ātapena kilantaḥ pipāsito pānīya ghaṭam  olokentaḥ katthaci a disvā caṅkamana koṭiyam udapānam addasa uda kaussiñcana thāya pana

translated: for drawing up the water, and being unable to restrain his thirst, he took a rope that was fastened to the elephant’s hip,🔽and after placing the elephant on the bank of the well, and tying the rope to the elephant’s foot, he lowered himself into the well

analyzed: tathā api so agga pādehi udakam phusitvā ati pipāsitaḥ pipāsam vinodetvā
translated: but still it was not long enough. After touching the water with the tips of his toes, he, being very thirsty, thought: ‘I will satisfy my thirst

analyzed: maraṇam pi su maraṇanti cintetvā udapāne patitvā yāvadattham pivitvā paccuttaritum
translated: “I will remember my death.” So he went to the tank, and drank as much as he wanted, and then tried to get out again.

original: asakkonto tattheva aṭṭhāsi. Hatthīpi susikkhitattā aññattha agantvā rājānaṃ olokento🔽tattheva aṭṭhāsi. Bodhisatto sāyanhasamaye phalāphalaṃ āharitvā hatthiṃ disvā “rājā
analyzed: a sakkontaḥ tattha iva aṭṭhāsi hatthī pi su sikkhita ttā aññattha a gantvā rājānam olokento  tattha iva aṭṭhāsi bodhisatto sāyanha samaye phala aphalam āharitvā hatthim disvā rājā
translated: But he could not do so, and remained there. The elephant, too, being well-trained, did not go elsewhere, but remained there, looking for the king.

original: āgato bhavissati, vammitahatthīyeva pana paññāyati, kiṃ nu kho kāraṇa”nti so hatthisamīpaṃ
analyzed: āgataḥ bhavissati pana paññāyati kim nu kho kāraṇanti so hatthi samīpam
translated: The Bodhisatta, in the evening, brought some fruits, and seeing the elephant, thought, “The king must have come here, but he seems to be sick. What can be the matter?” So he went to the elephant.

original: upasaṅkami. Hatthīpi tassa upasaṅkamanabhāvaṃ ñatvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Bodhisatto
analyzed: upasaṅkami hatthī ipi tassa upasaṅkamana bhāvam ñatvā eka mantam aṭṭhāsi bodhisatto
translated: The elephant, too, knowing that he was coming, stood aside. The Bodhisatta

analyzed: rājānam uttāretvā kāya massa sambāhitvā telena makkhetvā nhāpetvā phalāphalāni khādāpetvā
translated: and pulled him out, and rubbed his body, and anointed him with oil, and bathed him, and made him eat some fruits.

original: hatthissa sannāhaṃ mocesi. Rājā dvīhatīhaṃ vissamitvā bodhisattassa attano santikaṃ
analyzed: hatthissa sannāham mocesi rājā dvīhatīham vissamitvā bodhisattassa attano santikaṃ
translated: And he unfastened the elephant’s harness. The king rested two or three days, and then said to the Bodhisatta,🔽“I will go to my own kingdom.” “Very well, great king,” said the Bodhisatta.

analyzed: bodhisattaḥ api aḍḍha māsa cayena bārāṇasim patvā uyyāne vasitvā puna divase bhikkham  caramānaḥ rājadvāram gataḥ rājā mahā vāta pānam ugghāṭetvā rājaṅgaṇam olokayamānaḥ bodhisattam

analyzed: disvā sañjānitvā pāsādāḥ oruyha vanditvā mahā talam āropetvā samussita seta chatte rāja pallaṅke

original: mahāsakkārasammāno ahosi.

translated: and he was honoured and revered with great respect.

analyzed: tam asahamānāḥ amaccāḥ evarūpam sakkāram ekaḥ api yodhaḥ labhamānaḥ kim nāma na kareyyāti
translated: Unable to bear this, the ministers said, “If even a single soldier can get such honour, what will not be done by him?”

analyzed: vatvā upa rājānam upagantvā deva amhākam rājā ekam tāpasam kim
translated: And they went to the king’s son and said, “Your Majesty, our king is very fond of a certain ascetic.

analyzed: nāma tena tasmim diṭṭham tumhe pi tāva raññā saddhim mantetha ati āhaṃsu saḥ sādhu iti

analyzed: tattha na yimassa vijjā mayam atthi kiñci iti imassa tāpasassa vijjā mayam kiñci kammaṃ

original: natthi. Na bandhavo tiputtabandhavasippabandhavagottabandhavañātibandhavesu aññataropi
analyzed: natthi na bandhavaḥ ti putta bandhava sippabandhava gottabandhava ñātibandhavesu aññataro pi
translated: He is neither kinsman nor friend means he is not a kinsman in the three ways of father’s line, mother’s line, and affinity, nor a friend in the four ways of giving, etc.,

original: na hoti. No pana te sahāyoti sahapaṃsukīḷiko sahāyakopi te na hoti. Kena vaṇṇenāti🔽kena kāraṇena. Tirīṭavacchoti tassa nāmaṃ. Tedaṇḍikoti kuṇḍikaṭhapanatthāya tidaṇḍakaṃ
analyzed: na hoti no pana te sahāyo ti saha paṃsukīḷiko sahāyako api te na hoti kena vaṇṇena ati  kena kāraṇena tirīṭavaccho ti tassa nāmam tedaṇḍiko ti kuṇḍika ṭhapana tthāya tidaṇḍakam
translated: No, he is not. But he was not a playmate of yours, a companion who played with you. For what reason?

original: gahetvā caranto. Aggapiṇḍanti rasasampannaṃ rājārahaṃ aggabhojanaṃ.
analyzed: gahetvā carantaḥ agga piṇḍanti rasa sampannam rāja araham agga bhojanam
translated: For what reason? The young monkey was named Tiritta. The man with the staff was a beggar who went about with a triple staff for the purpose of supporting his crippled leg. The lump of boiled rice was a delicious dish fit for a king.

original: Taṃ sutvā rājā puttaṃ āmantetvā “tāta, mama paccantaṃ gantvā yuddhaparājitassa dvīhatīhaṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā rājā puttam āmantetvā tāta mama paccantam gantvā yuddha parājitassa
translated: Hearing this, the king summoned his son and said to him, “My dear son, do you remember that when I was defeated in battle and was gone from home for two or three days,

original: anāgatabhāvaṃ sarasī”ti vatvā “sarāmī”ti vutte “tadā mayā imaṃ nissāya jīvitaṃ laddha”nti🔽sabbaṃ taṃ pavattiṃ ācikkhitvā “tāta, mayhaṃ jīvitadāyake mama santikaṃ āgate rajjaṃ
analyzed: anāgata bhāvam sarasi iti vatvā sarāmi iti vutte tadā mayā imam nissāya jīvitam laddhanti  sabbam tam pavattim ācikkhitvā tāta mayham jīvita dāyake mama santikam āgate rajjam
translated: you said, ‘I remember.’ ” “Yes, father, I remember.” “At that time I was saved through him.”🔽And he told him the whole story. “My dear son, when he who gave me my life came to me, I was not able to requite him as he deserved, even though I gave him my kingdom.”

original: dadantopi ahaṃ neva etena kataguṇānurūpaṃ kātuṃ sakkomī”ti vatvā itarā dve gāthā avoca –
analyzed: dadantaḥ api aham na iva etena kata guṇa anurūpam kātum sakkomi iti vatvā itarāḥ dve gāthāḥ avoca
translated: And he uttered the two following Stanzas,

original: “Āpāsu me yuddhaparājitassa, ekassa katvā vivanasmi ghore;
analyzed: āpāsu me yuddha parājitassa ekassa katvā vivanasmi ghore
translated: “When I was in distress, defeated in battle, alone, in a terrible wilderness,

original: Pasārayī kicchagatassa pāṇiṃ, tenūdatāriṃ dukhasampareto.
analyzed: pasārayī kiccha gatassa pāṇim dukha samparetaḥ
translated: He stretched out his hand to me, who was in trouble, And pulled me out, though he was beset by suffering.

original: “Etassa kiccena idhānupatto, vesāyino visayā jīvaloke;
analyzed: etassa kiccena idha anupattaḥ vesāyinaḥ visayāḥ jīva loke
translated: “It was for his sake that I came here, O King, The young seer, the son of Vessāmitta, in the world of the living;

original: Lābhāraho tāta tirīṭavaccho, dethassa bhogaṃ yajathañca yañña”nti.
analyzed: lābha araho tāta tirīṭavaccho dethassa bhogam yajathañca yaññanti
translated: He is worthy of gain, dear father, the young seer of the reed-bed; Give him a reward and perform a sacrifice.”

original: Tattha āpāsūti āpadāsu. Ekassāti adutiyassa. Katvāti anukampaṃ karitvā pemaṃ uppādetvā.
analyzed: tattha āpāsu iti āpadāsu ekassa ati adutiyassa katvā iti anukampam karitvā pemam uppādetvā
translated: Herein, in troubles means in calamities. Alone means without a second. Having done means having taken pity, having aroused affection.

original: Vivanasminti pānīyarahite araññe. Ghoreti dāruṇe. Pasārayī kicchagatassa pāṇinti🔽nisseṇiṃ bandhitvā kūpaṃ otāretvā dukkhagatassa mayhaṃ uttāraṇatthāya vīriyapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: vivanasmin ti pānīya rahite araññe ghore iti dāruṇe pasārayī kiccha gatassa  nisseṇim bandhitvā kūpam otāretvā dukkha gatassa mayham uttāraṇa tthāya vīriya paṭisaṃyuttam
translated: In the wilderness means in the forest where there is no water. In the fearful means in the terrible. He stretched out his hand to me, who was in trouble means🔽having bound my feet, he threw me into the pit, and he stretched out his hand, which was connected with energy, in order to pull me out, who was in trouble.

original: hatthaṃ pasāresi. Tenūdatāriṃ dukhasamparetoti tena kāraṇenamhi dukkhaparivāritopi tamhā kūpā uttiṇṇo.
analyzed: hattham pasāresi tena udatārim dukha samparetaḥ ti tena kāraṇena amhi dukkha parivāritaḥ api tamhā kūpā uttiṇṇaḥ
translated: And pulled me out, though he was beset by suffering means for that reason, though I was surrounded by suffering, I got out of that pit.

original: Etassa kiccena idhānupattoti ahaṃ etassa tāpasassa kiccena, etena katassa kiccassānubhāvena
analyzed: etassa kiccena idha anupattaḥ ti aham etassa tāpasassa kiccena etena katassa kiccassa anubhāvena
translated: It was for his sake that I came here, O King means I came here for the sake of that ascetic, by the power of what he did, by the influence of what he did.

original: idhānuppatto. Vesāyino visayāti vesāyī vuccati yamo, tassa visayā. Jīvaloketi manussaloke.
analyzed: idha anuppattaḥ vesāyino visayā ti vesāyī vuccati yamo tassa visayā jīva loke ti manussa loke
translated: “The realm of the overlord” is the realm of Yama, the overlord. “The world of the living” is the human world.

original: Ahañhi imasmiṃ jīvaloke ṭhito yamavisayaṃ maccuvisayaṃ paralokaṃ gato nāma ahosiṃ,🔽somhi etassa kāraṇā tato puna idhāgatoti vuttaṃ hoti. Lābhārahoti lābhaṃ araho catupaccayalābhassa
analyzed: ahan hi imasmin jīva loke ṭhitaḥ yama visayam maccu visayam para lokam gataḥ nāma ahosim  etassa kāraṇā tatas puna idha āgataḥ ti vuttam hoti lābha araho ti lābham araho catu paccaya lābhassa
translated: “I have been there” means: “I, who am now standing in this world of the living, have been to the realm of Yama, the realm of death, which is called the other world.”🔽“I have come back again for this reason” means: “I have come back again for the purpose of teaching the Dhamma.” “Worthy of gifts” means: worthy of receiving the four requisites.

original: anucchaviko. Dethassa bhoganti etena paribhuñjitabbaṃ catupaccayasamaṇaparikkhārasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: anucchavikaḥ etena paribhuñjitabbam catu paccaya samaṇa parikkhāra saṅkhātam
translated: “Give him your wealth” means: give him the wealth consisting of the requisites of the monk, which is to be enjoyed.

original: bhogaṃ etassa detha. Yajathañca yaññanti tvañca amaccā ca nāgarā cāti sabbepi tumhe🔽etassa bhogañca detha, yaññañca yajatha. Tassa hi dīyamāno deyyadhammo tena bhuñjitabbattā
analyzed: bhogam etassa detha yajathañca tvañca amaccā ca nāgarā ca ati sabbe pi tumhe  etassa bhogañca detha yaññañca yajatha tassa hi dīyamānaḥ deyya dhammaḥ tena bhuñjitabba ttā
translated: “And perform your sacrifice” means: you, the ministers, and the citizens, all of you🔽give him your wealth and perform a sacrifice. For the gift given to him is his wealth because it is to be enjoyed by him,

original: bhogo hoti, itaresaṃ dānayaññattā yañño. Tenāha “dethassa bhogaṃ yajathañca yañña”nti.
analyzed: bhogaḥ hoti itaresam dāna yaññattā yañño tena āha dethassa bhogam yajathañca yaññanti
translated: and it is a sacrifice for the others because it is a sacrifice of giving.

original: Evaṃ raññā gaganatale puṇṇacandaṃ uṭṭhāpentena viya bodhisattassa guṇe pakāsite tassa
analyzed: evam raññā gagana tale puṇṇa candam uṭṭhāpentena viya bodhisattassa guṇe pakāsite tassa
translated: Thus the king, as it were, raising up the full moon in the sky, proclaimed the virtues of the Bodhisatta.

original: guṇo sabbatthameva pākaṭo jāto, atirekataro tassa lābhasakkāro udapādi. Tato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: guṇo sabbattham eva pākaṭaḥ jātaḥ atirekataro tassa lābha sakkāro udapādi tatas paṭṭhāya
translated: And the virtues of the Bodhisatta became manifest everywhere, and his gain and honour increased exceedingly. From that time forth

analyzed: uparājā vā amaccāḥ vā aññaḥ vā koci kiñci rājānam vattum na visahi rājā bodhisattassa
translated: neither the king’s brother nor the ministers nor any one else could find fault with the king. The king, abiding in the Bodhisatta’s teaching,

original: ovāde ṭhatvā dānādīni puññāni katvā saggapuraṃ pūresi. Bodhisattopi abhiññā ca samāpattiyo
analyzed: ovāde ṭhatvā dāna ādīni puññāni katvā sagga puram pūresi bodhisatto api abhiññā ca samāpattiyaḥ
translated: and performing works of merit, such as charity, filled the city of the gods. The Bodhisatta also, producing the Supernatural Faculties and the Ecstatic Meditations,

analyzed: ca uppādetvā brahma loka parāyaṇaḥ ahosi
translated: went to the world of Brahmā.

original: Satthā “porāṇakapaṇḍitāpi upakāravasena kariṃsū”ti imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā rājā ānando ahosi, tāpaso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.🔽Tirīṭavacchajātakavaṇṇanā navamā.

translated: The Master, having thus shown how the ancient wise men also did good in return, related the Jātaka to his monks, saying, “At that time the king was Ānanda, and I myself was the ascetic.”

original: [260] 10. Dūtajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Yassatthā dūramāyantīti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ lolabhikkhuṃ ārabbha
analyzed: dūta jātaka vaṇṇanā 🔽dūram āyanti iti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam lola bhikkhum ārabbha
translated: The Stanza, “For whom the axe is far away, etc. ” is the ninth of the Jātakas.

original: kathesi. Vatthu navakanipāte cakkavākajātake āvibhavissati. Satthā pana taṃ bhikkhuṃ🔽āmantetvā “na kho, bhikkhu, idāneva, pubbepi tvaṃ lolo, lolyakāraṇeneva pana asinā
analyzed: kathesi vatthu navaka nipāte cakkavāka jātake āvibhavissati satthā pana tam bhikkhum  āmantetvā na kho bhikkhu idānā iva pubbe pi tvam lolaḥ lolya kāraṇena iva pana asinā
translated: and told it. The story will be related in detail in the Cakkavāka-Jātaka of the Khaggavisāṇa Vagga.

original: sīsacchedanaṃ labhī”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto tassa putto hutvā vayappatto
analyzed: sīsacchedanam labhi iti vatvā atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto tassa putto hutvā vaya ppatto

original: takkasilāyaṃ sabbasippāni uggaṇhitvā pitu accayena rajje patiṭṭhāya bhojanasuddhiko🔽ahosi, tenassa bhojanasuddhikarājātveva nāmaṃ jātaṃ. So kira tathārūpena vidhānena🔽bhattaṃ bhuñjati, yathāssa ekissā bhattapātiyā satasahassaṃ vayaṃ gacchati. Bhuñjanto
analyzed: takkasilāyam sabba sippāni uggaṇhitvā pitu accayena rajje patiṭṭhāya bhojana suddhikaḥ  ahosi tena assa bhojanasuddhikarājā tu eva nāmam jātam saḥ kira tathārūpena vidhānena  bhattam bhuñjati yathā assa ekissā bhatta pātiyā sata sahassam vayam gacchati bhuñjantaḥ
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the Bodhisatta was his son. When he grew up, he learned all the arts in the school of Takkasilā, and after his father’s death succeeded to the throne. He was a king who was very particular about his food,

original: pana antogehe na bhuñjati, attano bhojanavidhānaṃ olokentaṃ mahājanaṃ puññaṃ kāretukāmatāya
analyzed: pana antogehe na bhuñjati attanaḥ bhojana vidhānam olokentam mahājanam puññam kāretu kāma tāya
translated: and therefore he was called King Bhojanasuddhika. He ate his food in such a way that a hundred thousand pieces of money were spent on a single meal. But he did not eat in the inner apartments; he had a great concourse of people come to see how he ate his food, and he did this in order that they might gain merit.

original: rājadvāre ratanamaṇḍapaṃ kāretvā bhojanavelāya taṃ alaṅkarāpetvā kañcanamaye samussitasetacchatte🔽rājapallaṅke nisīditvā khattiyakaññāhi parivuto satasahassagghanikāya suvaṇṇapātiyā
analyzed: rājadvāre ratana maṇḍapam kāretvā bhojana velāya tam alaṅkarāpetvā kañcana maye samussita seta chatte  rāja pallaṅke nisīditvā khattiya kaññāhi parivutaḥ sata sahassa aggha nikāya suvaṇṇa pātiyā
translated: He had a pavilion of jewels made at the royal gate, and at meal-times he had it decorated and sat down on the royal seat under a golden canopy with an upper covering of white silk.🔽Surrounded by the royal maidens, he ate his meal of all kinds of savouries from a golden bowl worth a hundred thousand pieces.

original: sabbarasabhojanaṃ bhuñjati. Atheko lolapuriso tassa bhojanavidhānaṃ oloketvā taṃ
analyzed: sabba rasa bhojanam bhuñjati atha ekaḥ lola puriso tassa bhojana vidhānam oloketvā tam
translated: Then a certain greedy man, seeing the king’s meal,

analyzed: bhojanam bhuñjitu kāmaḥ hutvā pipāsam sandhāretum a sakkontaḥ attha ekaḥ upāyaḥ ti gāḷham
translated: and being desirous of eating it, and unable to control his hunger, thought: “There is a way.” So he put on his clothes tightly,

translated: raised his hands, and crying out “I am a messenger, a messenger,” he went up to the king with a loud voice.

analyzed: tena ca samayena tasmin janapade dūtaḥ asi iti vadantam na tasmai mahā janaḥ
translated: And at that time in that country they did not prevent anyone who said “I am a messenger.” So the great crowd

analyzed: dvidhā bhijjitvā okāsam adāsi saḥ vegena gantvā rañño pātiyā ekam bhatta piṇḍam gahetvā
translated: split in two and gave way. He went quickly and took a lump of rice from the king’s bowl and put it in his mouth.

original: mukhe pakkhipi, athassa “sīsaṃ chindissāmī”ti asigāho asiṃ abbāhesi, rājā “mā paharī”ti
analyzed: mukhe pakkhipi athassa sīsam chindissāmi iti asi gāhaḥ asim abbāhesi rājā mā pahari iti
translated: Then the king’s executioner drew his sword, saying: “I will cut off his head.” The king said: “Do not strike him.

original: nivāresi, “mā bhāyi, bhuñjassū”ti hatthaṃ dhovitvā nisīdi. Bhojanapariyosāne cassa
analyzed: nivāresi mā bhāyi bhuñjassu iti hattham dhovitvā nisīdi bhojana pariyosāne ca ssa
translated: and he said, “Do not be afraid, eat.” He washed his hands and sat down. At the end of the meal,

analyzed: pivana pānīyam ca iva tambūlañca dāpetvā bho purisa tvam dūtaḥ asi iti vadasi
translated: he had his own drinking water and betel brought and said, “Sir, you say you are a messenger.

original: kassa dūtosī”ti pucchi. “Mahārāja ahaṃ taṇhādūto, udaradūto, taṇhā maṃ āṇāpetvā ‘tvaṃ
analyzed: kassa dūtaḥ asi iti pucchi mahā rāja aham taṇhā dūtaḥ udara dūto taṇhā mama āṇāpetvā tvam
translated: To whom are you a messenger?” “Great king, I am a messenger of craving, a messenger of the belly. Craving ordered me,

analyzed: gacchāhi iti dūtam katvā pesesi iti vatvā purimāḥ dve gāthāḥ avoca
translated: ‘Go and tell him,’ and sent me as a messenger.” He spoke the first two stanzas:

original: “Yassatthā dūramāyanti, amittamapi yācituṃ;

translated: “For whose sake do they come from afar, Even to beg of a friend?

translated: I am a messenger of that belly; Do not be angry with me, O lord of chariots.

analyzed: yassa divā ca rattaḥ ca māṇavā
translated: “For whose sake do young men come under control, Both by day and by night?

analyzed: tassu udaraḥ aham dūtaḥ mā me kujjha
translated: I am a messenger of that belly; Do not be angry with me, O lord of chariots.”

analyzed: tattha yassatthāḥ dūram āyanti iti yassa atthāya ime sattā taṇhā vasikāḥ hutvā dūram pi gacchanti
translated: Herein, for whose sake do they come from afar: for whose sake do these beings, being slaves of craving, go even far away. O lord of chariots: O chief of chariot-warriors.

analyzed: rājā tassa vacanam sutvā saccam etam ime sattāḥ udara dūtā taṇhā vasena vicaranti

analyzed: ime satte vicāreti yāva manāpam vata iminā kathitanti tassa purisassa tussitvā tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Craving is what makes them wander about. How pleasant it is that he has spoken thus!” Delighted with the man’s words, the king spoke the third stanza:

analyzed: tattha brāhmaṇa ati ālapanam attam etam saha puṅgavena ati
translated: Here “brahman” is merely a form of address. “Red cows” means cows of a reddish color. “With a bull to lead them” means

translated: with a bull who is the leader of the herd and who protects them from danger. “We too” means I and the rest of the

analyzed: sabbe sattā tassa iva udarassa dūtāḥ bhavāma tasmai aham udara dūtaḥ samānaḥ udara dūtassa
translated: beings are the messengers of that belly. Therefore I, being the messenger of the belly,

analyzed: tuyham kasmā na dajjanti evañca pana vatvā iminā vata purisena a suta pubbam kāraṇam

translated: The prince, having ascertained the truth of the matter, made ready a handsome, well-bred, young elephant, and giving a bribe to the keeper of the royal stables, had the elephant brought to him. Then he waited for the time of the king’s going out.

analyzed: atha ekasmin kāḷa pakkha uposatha divase majjhima yāma samanantare ghanakāḷa meghaḥ vassi

When he reached the place opposite the open space in front of the royal palace,

analyzed: mahā bhittiyam allīyāpetvā vāta pāna samīpe tementaḥ aṭṭhāsi rājā api dhītaram rakkhanto

analyzed: tam hatthe gahetvā vāta pāna samīpam netvā nhāyāhi amma ati ukkhipitvā vāta pānassa

analyzed: hatthe ṭhapesi saḥ tassā hattham gahetvā hattham muñci sā itarasma api  ābharaṇāni omuñcitvā tassāḥ dutiya hatthe piḷandhitvā hatthe ṭhapetvā kumārena

analyzed: saddhim agamāsi rājā dhītāya iva mā iti saññāya tam dārikam nhāna pariyosāne sirigabbhe

analyzed: sayāpetvā dvāram pidhāya lañchetvā ārakkham datvā attano sayanam gantvā nipajji

analyzed: saḥ pabhātāya rattiyā dvāram vivaritvā tam dārikam disvā kim etat ti pucchi sā tassā  kumārena saddhim gata bhāvam kathesi rājā vippaṭisārī hutvā hatthe gahetvā carantena api

analyzed: mātugāmam rakkhitum na sakkā evam arakkhiyā na amitthiyā iti cintetvā itarā dve gāthāḥ avoca
translated: When the night had passed, the king opened the door and saw the girl. He asked, “What is this?” She told him how she had gone with the prince. The king was remorseful. He thought, “Even when I had her in my hands, I was not able to protect a woman. Women are so hard to protect.” He spoke two more verses:

original: “Analā mudusambhāsā, duppūrā tā nadīsamā;
analyzed: analāḥ mudu sambhāsāḥ duppūrā tāḥ nadī samā

analyzed: sīdanti nam viditvānaḥ ārakā parivajjaye

original: “Yaṃ etā upasevanti, chandasā vā dhanena vā;
analyzed: yam etāḥ upasevanti chandasā vā dhanena vā
translated: “Those who serve them, whether out of desire or for money,

analyzed: jātavedaḥ iva sam ṭhānam khippam anudahanti nanti  tattha analā mudu sambhāsā ati mudu vacanena api a sakkuṇeyyā na iva sakkā saṇha vācāya saṅgaṇhitunti

original: attho. Purisehi vā etāsaṃ na alanti analā. Mudusambhāsāti hadaye thaddhepi sambhāsāva
analyzed: attho purisehi vā etāsam na alanti analā mudu sambhāsā ati hadaye thaddhe pi
translated: Herein, they are not to be lit by fire means they cannot be lit by fire, they cannot be kindled by fire. They are hard to talk to means they cannot be won over by gentle speech. The meaning is that it is not possible to win them over by gentle speech. Or else, they are not lit by men. They are hard to talk to means even when their hearts are hard, they are still talkative.

original: mudu etāsanti mudusambhāsā. Duppūrā tā nadīsamāti yathā nadī āgatāgatassa udakassa
analyzed: mudu mudu sambhāsā duppūrā tā yathā nadī āgata āgatassa udakassa

original: “Tiṇṇaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ atitto appaṭivāno mātugāmo kālaṃ karoti. Katamesaṃ
analyzed: tiṇṇam bhikkhave dhammānam atittaḥ appaṭivānaḥ mātugāmaḥ kālam karoti katamesam

analyzed: tiṇṇam methuna samāpattiyā ca vijāyanassa ca alaṅkārassa ca imesam kho bhikkhave
translated: What three?

analyzed: tiṇṇam dhammānam a tittaḥ a paṭivānaḥ mātugāmo kālam karoti iti
translated: Sexual intercourse, bearing children, and adornment. A woman, unrestrained as to these three things, is unrestrained” .

original: Sīdantīti aṭṭhasu mahānirayesu soḷasasu ussadanirayesu nimujjanti. Nanti nipātamattaṃ.

translated: They sink down, thus they are ‘sunk down’ in the eight hells and the sixteen separate hells. The word ‘na’ is a mere particle.

analyzed: evam jānitvā ārakā parivajjaya iti etāḥ itthiyaḥ nāma methuna dhamma ādīhi
translated: Having known thus, thus having known, he should avoid them from afar: these women, having been unrestrained as to sexual intercourse, etc.,

original: atittā kālaṃ katvā etesu nirayesu sīdanti, etā evaṃ attanā sīdamānā kassaññassa sukhāya
analyzed: a tittā kālam katvā etesu nirayesu sīdanti etāḥ evam attanā sīdamānā kassaññassa sukhāya
translated: sink down in these hells after death, and while sinking down they are of no use to anyone else for the sake of happiness,

original: bhavissantī”ti evaṃ ñatvā paṇḍito puriso dūratova tā parivajjayeti dīpeti. Chandasā
analyzed: bhavissanti iti evam ñatvā paṇḍitaḥ purisaḥ dūratas va tā parivajjaya iti dīpeti chandasā
translated: Knowing this, the wise man should avoid them from afar.

original: vā dhanena vāti attano vā chandena ruciyā pemena, bhativasena laddhadhanena vā yaṃ
analyzed: vā dhanena vāti vā chandena ruciyā pemena bhativasena laddha dhanena vā yaṃ
translated: By their own desire, by their own wish, by their own love, or by the wealth they have received from their husbands,

original: purisaṃ etā itthiyo upasevanti bhajanti. Jātavedoti aggi. So hi jātamattova vediyati,
analyzed: purisam etāḥ itthiyaḥ upasevanti bhajanti jātavedaḥ uti aggi saḥ hi jāta mattaḥ uva vediyati
translated: women resort to and serve that man. The fire: this is the fire of lust. For that fire is known, is evident, as soon as it is born.

original: vidito pākaṭo hotīti jātavedo. So yathā attano ṭhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ okāsaṃ anudahati, evametāpi🔽yaṃ upasevanti, taṃ purisaṃ dhanayasasīlapaññāsamannāgatampi tesaṃ sabbesaṃ dhanādīnaṃ
analyzed: viditaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti iti jātavedaḥ saḥ yathā attanaḥ ṭhānam kāraṇam okāsam anudahati evam etā api  yam upasevanti tam purisam dhana yasa sīla paññā samannāgatam pi tesam sabbesam dhana ādīnam
translated: Therefore it is called the fire of lust. Just as that fire consumes its place, its cause, its location, so too

original: vināsanato puna tāya sampattiyā abhabbuppattikaṃ kurumānā khippaṃ anudahanti jhāpenti. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: vināsanataḥ puna tāya sampattiyā abhabbuppattikam kurumānāḥ khippam anudahanti jhāpenti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: these women quickly consume the man they resort to, even if he is endowed with wealth, fame, virtue, and wisdom, by making him incapable of attaining that prosperity again through the destruction of all his wealth, etc. This is said:

original: “Balavanto dubbalā honti, thāmavantopi hāyare;
analyzed: balavantaḥ dubbalāḥ honti thāmavantaḥ api hāyare
translated: “The strong become weak, the stout become emaciated,

analyzed: cakkhumāḥ andhakāḥ honti mātu gāma vasam gatā
translated: the one with eyes becomes blind, having fallen under the power of women.

original: “Guṇavanto nigguṇā honti, paññavantopi hāyare;
analyzed: guṇavantaḥ nigguṇāḥ honti paññavantaḥ api ha āyare
translated: “The virtuous become non-virtuous, the wise become emaciated,

original: Pamattā bandhane senti, mātugāmavasaṃ gatā.
analyzed: pamattāḥ bandhane senti mātu gāma vasam gatā
translated: They who are careless fall into the snare, and are caught by the snare of women.

original: “Ajjhenañca tapaṃ sīlaṃ, saccaṃ cāgaṃ satiṃ matiṃ;
analyzed: tapam sīlam saccam cāgam satim matim
translated: “Self-control, austerity, virtue, truth, charity, mindfulness, wisdom,

original: Acchindanti pamattassa, panthadūbhīva takkarā.
analyzed: a chindanti pamattassa takkarā
translated: Are torn away from the careless man, as the wind tears away a weak reed.

original: “Yasaṃ kittiṃ dhitiṃ sūraṃ, bāhusaccaṃ pajānanaṃ;
analyzed: yasam kittim dhitim sūram bāhusaccam pajānanam
translated: “Fame, glory, courage, strength, learning, and understanding,

original: Khepayanti pamattassa, kaṭṭhapuñjaṃva pāvako”ti.
analyzed: khepayanti pamattassa kaṭṭha puñjam iva
translated: Are carried away from the careless man, as fire carries away a heap of dry grass.”

original: Evaṃ vatvā mahāsatto “bhāgineyyopi mayāva posetabbo”ti mahantena sakkārena dhītaraṃ tasseva datvā taṃ oparajje patiṭṭhapesi. Sopi mātulassa accayena rajje patiṭṭhahi.
analyzed: evam vatvā mahāsattaḥ bhāgineyyaḥ api mayā ava posetabbaḥ iti mahantena sakkārena dhītaram tassa iva da tvā tam oparajje patiṭṭhapesi saḥ api mātulassa accayena rajje patiṭṭhahi
translated: After the Great Being had thus spoken, he gave his daughter to his sister’s son with great honor, and established him as viceroy. And after the death of his uncle, he succeeded to the throne.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesenaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā rājā ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desena āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā rājā aham eva ahosin ti
translated: The Master, having related this story, explained the Truths, and identified the Birth: at the conclusion of the Truths the discontented Brother attained fruition of the First Path: “Then, Brethren, was I myself.”

original: Mudupāṇijātakavaṇṇanā dutiyā.
analyzed: mudupāṇijātakavaṇṇanā dutiyā
translated: The Story of Mudupāṇi is ended.

original: [263] 3. Cūḷapalobhanajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Little Tempter

original: Abhijjamāne vārisminti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto ekaṃ ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhumeva
analyzed: abhijjamāne vārismin ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhum eva
translated: “When the water is rising,” etc. This story was told by the Master while living at Jetavana, about a monk who was discontented.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Tañhi satthā dhammasabhaṃ ānītaṃ “saccaṃ kira, tvaṃ bhikkhu, ukkaṇṭhitosī”ti
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi tat hi satthā dhammasabham ānītam saccam kira tvam bhikkhu ukkaṇṭhitaḥ asi iti
translated: This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a certain monk who was despondent. For the Master, having caused him to be brought into the Congregation, asked him, “Is it true, monk, that you are despondent?”

original: pucchitvā “saccaṃ, bhante”ti vutte “bhikkhu, itthiyo nāmetā porāṇake suddhasattepi
analyzed: pucchitvā saccam bhante ti vutte bhikkhu itthiyaḥ nāma itā porāṇake suddhasatte pi
translated: “It is true, Reverend Sir.” “Monk, women are the ruin of men, even of the pure beings of old.”

original: saṃkilesesu”nti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.
analyzed: vatvā atītam āhari
translated: So saying, he related the following story of the past.

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatto rājā aputtako hutvā attano itthiyo “puttapatthanaṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadattaḥ rājā aputtakaḥ hutvā attano itthiyaḥ putta patthanam
translated: Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, the king had no son. So he said to his wives, “Make a vow for a son.”

original: karothā”ti āha. Tā putte patthenti. Evaṃ addhāne gate bodhisatto brahmalokā cavitvā🔽aggamahesiyā kucchismiṃ nibbatti. Taṃ jātamattaṃ nhāpetvā thaññapāyanatthāya dhātiyā
analyzed: karotha iti āha tā putte patthenti evam addhāne gate bodhisattaḥ brahma lokā cavitvā  aggamahesiyāḥ kucchismiṃ nibbatti tam jāta mattam nhāpetvā thaññapāyana tthāya dhātiyā
translated: They made a vow for a son. After the lapse of some time, the Bodhisatta passed away from the World of Brahmā and was conceived in the womb of the chief queen.

original: adaṃsu. So pāyamāno rodati, atha naṃ aññissā adaṃsu. Mātugāmahatthagato neva tuṇhī

translated: took many garlands, perfumes, and ointments, went to Jetavana, paid obeisance to the Teacher, sat down respectfully on one side,

original: satthārā ca “kiṃ nu kho, upāsaka, na paññāyasī”ti pucchite tamatthaṃ ārocetvā “svāhaṃ,
analyzed: satthārā ca kim nu kho upāsaka na paññāyasi iti pucchite tam attham ārocetvā svāham
translated: The Teacher asked him, “Why, lay disciple, do you not shine?” When he told him the reason, he said, “Well,🔽lay disciple, for so long a time you have been ashamed to wait upon the Buddha.” The Teacher said to him, “Lay disciple,

original: bhante, ettakaṃ kālaṃ lajjāya buddhupaṭṭhānaṃ nāgato”ti āha. Satthā “na, upāsaka,🔽idānevesā kilesavasena taṃ pakkosāpetvā āgatakāle taṃ okāsaṃ akatvā lajjāpesi, pubbepi🔽pana paṇḍitesu paṭibaddhacittā hutvā pakkosāpetvā āgatakāle okāsaṃ akatvā kilametvāva
analyzed: bhante ettakam kālam lajjāya buddha paṭṭhānam na āgataḥ iti āha satthā na upāsaka  idāneva isā kilesa vasena tam pakkosāpetvā āgata kāle tam okāsam a katvā lajjāpesi pubbe pi  pana paṇḍitesu paṭibaddha cittā hutvā pakkosāpetvā āgata kāle okāsam a katvā kilametvā ava
translated: this is not the first time you have done this; in a previous state of existence also you did the same thing.

original: uyyojesī”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto sindhavakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisatto sindhavakule nibbattitvā
translated: In a previous state of existence also you were a horse, and you were the king’s horse. A certain woman, in love with you, sent for you, and when you came, you did not give her an opportunity to do what she wanted, but instead you made her weary and sent her away.” So saying, he related the following,

original: vātaggasindhavo nāma hutvā tassa maṅgalaasso ahosi. Assagopakā taṃ netvā gaṅgāyaṃ
analyzed: vātaggasindhavaḥ nāma hutvā tassa maṅgala assaḥ ahosi assa gopakā tam netvā gaṅgā ayam
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, said he, in the city of Bārāṇasī, in the province of Kāsi, there was a king named Brahmadatta. The Bodhisatta was reborn in the family of a Sindhava horse-dealer, and became the king’s horse, named Vātaggasindhava. The horse-keeper took him to the river and bathed him.

original: nhāpenti. Atha naṃ bhaddalī nāma gadrabhī disvā paṭibaddhacittā hutvā kilesavasena
analyzed: nhāpenti atha nam bhaddalī nāma gadrabhī disvā paṭibaddha cittā hutvā kilesa vasena
translated: A certain mare named Bhaddalī saw him, and fell in love with him. She sent for him, and when he came, she did not give him an opportunity to do what he wanted, but instead she made him weary and sent him away.

original: kampamānā neva tiṇaṃ khādi, na udakaṃ pivi, parisussitvā kisā aṭṭhicammamattā ahosi.
analyzed: kampamānā na iva tiṇam khādi na udakam pivi parisussitvā kisā aṭṭhi camma mattā ahosi
translated: But she did not eat the grass nor drink the water, but dried up and became a mere skeleton.

original: Atha naṃ putto gadrabhapotako mātaraṃ parisussamānaṃ disvā “kiṃ nu kho tvaṃ, amma,
analyzed: atha nam puttaḥ gadrabha potakaḥ mātaram parisussamānam disvā kim nu kho tvam amma
translated: Then her son, the young ass, seeing his mother drying up, said to her, “Mother, why is it that

original: neva tiṇaṃ khādasi, na udakaṃ pivasi, parisussitvā tattha tattha kampamānā nipajjasi,
analyzed: na iva tiṇam khādasi na udakam pivasi parisussitvā tattha tattha kampamānā nipajjasi
translated: you neither eat grass nor drink water, but lie there trembling and drying up?

original: kiṃ te aphāsuka”nti pucchi. Sā akathetvā punappunaṃ vuccamānā tamatthaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: kim te a phāsukanti pucchi sā a kathetvā punappunam vuccamānā tam attham kathesi
translated: What ails you?” She would not tell him, but when he asked her again and again, she told him the reason.

original: Atha naṃ putto samassāsetvā “amma, mā cintayi, ahaṃ taṃ ānessāmī”ti vatvā vātaggasindhavassa
analyzed: atha nam putto samassāsetvā amma mā cintayi aham taṃ ānessāmi iti vatvā vātaggasindhavassa
translated: Then her son comforted her, saying, “Mother, do not worry; I will bring him to you.” So he waited until the wind-footed horse came

original: nhāyituṃ āgatakāle taṃ upasaṅkamitvā “tāta, mayhaṃ mātā tumhesu paṭibaddhacittā nirāhārā
analyzed: nhāyitum āgata kāle tam upasaṅkamitvā tāta mayham mātā tumhesu paṭibaddha cittā nirāhārā
translated: to bathe, and then he went to him and said, “Father, my mother is in love with you, and because she cannot get you, she is drying up and will die.

original: sussitvā marissati, jīvitadānamassā dethā”ti āha. “Sādhu, tāta, dassāmi, assagopakā
analyzed: sussitvā marissati jīvita dānam assā detha iti āha sādhu tāta dassāmi assa gopakā
translated: Give her the gift of life.” “Very well, my son; I will give it to her.

original: maṃ nhāpetvā thokaṃ gaṅgātīre vicaraṇatthāya vissajjenti, tvaṃ mātaraṃ gahetvā taṃ
analyzed: mam nhāpetvā thokam gaṅgā tīre vicaraṇa tthāya vissajjenti tvam mātaram gahetvā tam
translated: The horse-keeper bathes me and then lets me go for a little while to roll on the bank of the Ganges. You take your mother and🔽put her in the place where I roll. I will come there and do what you ask.”

original: padesaṃ ehī”ti. So gantvā mātaraṃ ānetvā tasmiṃ padese vissajjetvā ekamantaṃ paṭicchanno aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: padesam ehi iti saḥ gantvā mātaram ānetvā tasmin padese vissajjetvā eka mantam paṭicchannaḥ aṭṭhāsi
translated: “Come to such and such a place.” He went and brought his mother and let her loose in that place, and then he hid himself on one side.

original: Assagopakāpi vātaggasindhavaṃ tasmiṃ ṭhāne vissajjesuṃ. So taṃ gadrabhiṃ oloketvā
analyzed: assa gopakāḥ api vātagga sindhavam tasmin ṭhāne vissajjesum saḥ tam gadrabhim oloketvā
translated: The horse-dealers let loose the thoroughbred horse in that place. He looked at the she-ass

original: upasaṅkami. Atha sā gadrabhī tasmiṃ upasaṅkamitvā attano sarīraṃ upasiṅghamāne “sacāhaṃ🔽garuṃ akatvā āgatakkhaṇeyevassa okāsaṃ karissāmi, evaṃ me yaso ca issariyañca parihāyissati,
analyzed: upasaṅkami atha sā gadrabhī tasmin upasaṅkamitvā sarīram upasiṅghamāne sacā aham  garum a katvā okāsam karissāmi evam me yasaḥ ca issariyam ca parihāyissati
translated: and approached her. Then she, as he approached her, thought, “If I give him an opportunity as soon as he comes🔽without showing him respect, my fame and my authority will be lost.

original: anicchamānā viya bhavituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti cintetvā sindhavassa heṭṭhāhanuke pādena paharitvā
analyzed: an icchamānā viya bhavitum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā sindhavassa heṭṭhā hanuke pādena paharitvā
translated: It is necessary for me to act as if I did not want him.” So she kicked him with her hind foot under his jaw

original: palāyi, dantamūlamassa bhijjitvā gatakālo viya ahosi. Vātaggasindhavo “ko me etāya
analyzed: palāyi danta mūlam assa bhijjitvā gata kālaḥ viya ahosi vātagga sindhavaḥ kaḥ me etāya
translated: and ran away, as if his tusk had broken off. The thoroughbred horse thought, “What have I to do with her?”

original: attho”ti lajjito tatova palāyi. Sā vippaṭisārinī hutvā tattheva patitvā socamānā nipajji.
analyzed: attho ti lajjitaḥ tatas va palāyi sā vippaṭisārinī hutvā tattha iva patitvā socamānā nipajji
translated: and, ashamed, he ran away from there. She, being remorseful, fell down right there and lay down grieving.

original: Atha naṃ putto upasaṅkamitvā pucchanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam puttaḥ upasaṅkamitvā pucchantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: Then her son approached her and asked her, reciting the first stanza:

original: “Yenāsi kisiyā paṇḍu, yena bhattaṃ na ruccati;
analyzed: yena asi kisiyā paṇḍu yena bhattam na ruccati
translated: And why do you not like your food?

original: Ayaṃ so āgato bhattā, kasmā dāni palāyasī”ti.
analyzed: ayam saḥ āgataḥ bhattā kasmā dāni palāyasi iti
translated: Here is your husband come; why do you run away?”

original: Tattha yenāti tasmiṃ paṭibaddhacittatāya yena kāraṇabhūtena.
analyzed: yena ati tasmim paṭibaddha citta tāya yena kāraṇa bhūtena
translated: Herein, for what reason = for what reason, because of what reason, because of the state of being bound to him.

original: Puttassa vacanaṃ sutvā gadrabhī dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: puttassa vacanam sutvā gadrabhī dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Having heard her son’s words, the gadfly spoke a second stanza:

original: “Sace panādikeneva, santhavo nāma jāyati;
analyzed: sace santhavaḥ nāma jāyati
translated: “But if a union is made at the very first,

original: Yaso hāyati itthīnaṃ, tasmā tāta palāyaha”nti.
analyzed: itthīnam tasmāt tāta palāya hanti
translated: The fame of women is lost; therefore, my son, run away.”

original: Tattha ādikenevātiāditova paṭhamameva. Santhavoti methunadhammasaṃyogavasena mittasanthavo.
analyzed: tattha ādikena iva ati āditaḥ va paṭhamam eva santhavo ti methuna dhamma saṃyoga vasena mitta santhavo
translated: Herein, at the very first = from the very beginning, at the very outset. Union = friendship by way of the union of sexual intercourse.

original: Yaso hāyati itthīnanti, tāta, itthīnañhi garukaṃ akatvā āditova santhavaṃ kurumānānaṃ
analyzed: yasaḥ hāyati tāta itthīn hi garukam a katvā āditas uva santhavam
translated: The fame of women is lost = my son, if women make a union at the very outset without first making themselves respected,

original: yaso hāyati, issariyagabbitabhāvo parihāyatīti. Evaṃ sā itthīnaṃ sabhāvaṃ puttassa kathesi.
analyzed: yasaḥ hāyati issariya gabbita bhāvaḥ parihāyati iti evam sā itthīnam sabhāvam puttassa kathesi
translated: their fame is lost, their state of being sought after by the powerful is lost. Thus she told her son the nature of women.

original: Tatiyagāthaṃ pana satthā abhisambuddho hutvā āha –
analyzed: tatiya gātham pana satthā abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā āha
translated: But the Teacher, having become Enlightened, spoke a third stanza:

original: “Yasassinaṃ kule jātaṃ, āgataṃ yā na icchati;
analyzed: yasassinam kule jātam āgatam yā naḥ icchati
translated: “She who does not like the man born in a famous family,

original: Socati cirarattāya, vātaggamiva bhaddalī”ti.
analyzed: socati cira rattāya vātaggam iva bhaddalī iti
translated: grieves long time, even as the good mare grieves for the wind-god’s son.”

original: Tattha yasassinanti yasasampannaṃ. Yā na icchatīti yā itthī tathārūpaṃ purisaṃ na icchati.
