analyzed: tattha yasassinanti yasa sampannam yā naḥ icchati iti yā itthī tathārūpam purisam naḥ icchati cira rattāya ati cira rattam attho  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne  kuṭumbiko sotāpatti phale tadā gadrabhī sā itthī ahosi vātaggasindhavaḥ
translated: Herein, he who has fame means he who is endowed with fame. She who does not desire means she who does not desire such a man. Long time means for a long time, the meaning is for a long period.🔽After telling this story and expounding the Truths, the Master identified the Birth: “At that time the mare was the woman, and I myself was the wind-god’s son.”

original: pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: pana aham eva
translated: And at the end of the Truths the householder was established in the Fruit of Conversion.

original: Vātaggasindhavajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.🔽[267] 7. Kakkaṭakajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vātaggasindhavajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: The Birth of the Wind-god’s Son.🔽The Story of the Ass-King

original: Siṅgī migoti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto aññataraṃ itthiṃ ārabbha kathesi. Sāvatthiyaṃ
analyzed: siṅgī migo ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ aññataram itthim ārabbha kathesi sāvatthiyam
translated: “The deer-king named Siṅgī” — this story the Master, while dwelling in the Jeta Grove, told about a certain woman. In Sāvatthi, it seems,

original: kireko kuṭumbiko attano bhariyaṃ gahetvā uddhārasodhanatthāya janapadaṃ gantvā uddhāraṃ
analyzed: kirekaḥ kuṭumbikaḥ attanaḥ bhariyam gahetvā uddhāra sodhana tthāya janapadam gantvā uddhāram
translated: a certain householder, having taken his wife, went to the country for the purpose of collecting revenue. Having collected the revenue,🔽he went to a certain village.

original: sodhetvā āgacchanto antarāmagge corehi gahito. Bhariyā panassa abhirūpā pāsādikā🔽dassanīyā, corajeṭṭhako tassā sinehena kuṭumbikaṃ māretuṃ ārabhi. Sā pana itthī sīlavatī
analyzed: sodhetvā āgacchantaḥ antarāmagge corehi gahitaḥ bhariyā panassa abhirūpā pāsādikā  dassanīyā cora jeṭṭhako tassā sinehena kuṭumbikam māretum ārabhi sā pana itthī sīlavatī
translated: On his way back, he was captured by robbers. His wife was very beautiful,🔽and the chief of the robbers, being smitten with love for her, was about to kill her husband. But the wife was virtuous

original: ācārasampannā patidevatā, sā corajeṭṭhakassa pādesu nipatitvā “sāmi, sace mayi sineho🔽atthi, mā mayhaṃ sāmikaṃ mārehi. Sace māresi, ahampi visaṃ vā khāditvā nāsavātaṃ
analyzed: ācāra sampannā pati devatā sā cora jeṭṭhakassa pādesu nipatitvā sāmi sace mayi sinehaḥ  atthi mā mayham sāmikam mārehi sace māresi aham pi visam vā khāditvā
translated: and well-behaved, and she loved her husband as a god. She fell at the feet of the chief of the robbers and said, “My husband, if you have any love for me,

original: vā sannirumbhitvā marissāmi, tayā pana saddhiṃ na gamissāmi, mā me akāraṇena sāmikaṃ
analyzed: vā sannirumbhitvā marissāmi tayā pana saddhim na gamissāmi mā me akāraṇena sāmikam
translated: do not kill my husband. If you kill him, I will either eat poison or hang myself and die. I will not go with you. Do not kill my husband

original: mārehī”ti yācitvā taṃ vissajjāpesi. Te ubhopi sotthinā sāvatthiṃ patvā jetavanapiṭṭhivihārena
analyzed: mārehi iti yācitvā tam vissajjāpesi te ubho api sotthinā sāvatthim patvā jetavana piṭṭhi vihārena
translated: without cause.” Thus she begged him and obtained his pardon. The two of them reached Sāvatthi in safety. As they were going to the rear of the monastery,

original: gacchantā “vihāraṃ pavisitvā satthāraṃ vandissāmā”ti gandhakuṭipariveṇaṃ gantvā satthāraṃ
analyzed: gacchantā vihāram pavisitvā satthāram vandissāma ati gandhakuṭi pariveṇam gantvā satthāram
translated: they thought, “We will enter the monastery and pay our respects to the Teacher.” So they went to the cloister surrounding the Perfumed Chamber.

original: vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Te satthārā “kahaṃ gatattha, upāsakā”ti puṭṭhā “uddhārasodhanatthāyā”ti
analyzed: vanditvā ekamantam nisīdiṃsu te satthārā kaham gatattha upāsakā ati puṭṭhāḥ uddhāra sodhana thāya ati
translated: and sat down respectfully on one side. The Teacher asked them, “Lay disciples, where have you been?”🔽“To get the money,” they replied.

original: āhaṃsu. “Antarāmagge pana ārogyena āgatatthā”ti vutte kuṭumbiko āha – “antarāmagge
analyzed: āhaṃsu antarāmagge pana ārogyena āgata ttha ati vutte kuṭumbikaḥ āha antarāmagge
translated: “But were you well on your return journey?”

original: no, bhante, corā gaṇhiṃsu, tatresā maṃ māriyamānaṃ corajeṭṭhakaṃ yācitvā mocesi,🔽imaṃ nissāya mayā jīvitaṃ laddha”nti. Satthā “na, upāsaka, idānevetāya evaṃ tuyhaṃ
analyzed: no bhante corāḥ gaṇhiṃsu tatra isā mam māriyamānam cora jeṭṭhakam yācitvā mocesi  imam nissāya mayā jīvitam laddhanti satthā na upāsakaḥ evam tuyham
translated: “No, Reverend Sir; on the way we were captured by robbers, and while they were about to put me to death, this man begged the chief of the robbers and saved my life.🔽It is through him that I have escaped with life.”

original: jīvitaṃ dinnaṃ, pubbepi paṇḍitānampi jīvitaṃ adāsiyevā”ti vatvā tena yācito atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente himavante mahāudakarahado, tattha mahāsuvaṇṇakakkaṭako
analyzed: jīvitam dinnam pubbe pi paṇḍitānam pi jīvitam vatvā tena yācitaḥ atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente himavante mahā udaka rahadaḥ tattha mahā suvaṇṇa kakkaṭako
translated: “Lay disciple,” said the Teacher, “it is not now only that he has given you your life; in a previous state of existence also he gave his life to the wise.” So saying, he related the following🔽Once upon a time, when Brahmadatta was reigning in Benares, there was in the Himalayas a great lake of fresh water. In that lake there lived a great golden tortoise.

original: ahosi. So tassa nivāsabhāvena “kuḷīradaho”ti paññāyittha. Kakkaṭako mahā ahosi khalamaṇḍalappamāṇo,
analyzed: ahosi so tassa nivāsa bhāvena kuḷīra daho ti paññāyittha kakkaṭakaḥ mahā ahosi khala maṇḍala ppamāṇo
translated: Because he lived there, the lake was called the Tortoise Lake. The tortoise was so large that he was as big as a waterwheel.

original: hatthī gahetvā vadhitvā khādati. Hatthī tassa bhayena tattha otaritvā gocaraṃ gaṇhituṃ
analyzed: hatthī gahetvā vadhitvā khādati hatthī tassa bhayena tattha otaritvā gocaram gaṇhituṃ
translated: and he killed and ate the elephants. The elephants, being afraid of him, were unable to go down to the river to get water and fodder.

original: na sakkonti. Tadā bodhisatto kuḷīradahaṃ upanissāya vasamānaṃ hatthiyūthajeṭṭhakaṃ
analyzed: na sakkonti tadā bodhisatto kuḷīra daham upanissāya vasamānam hatthi yūtha jeṭṭhakam
translated: At that time the Bodhisatta, as the chief of a herd of elephants,

original: paṭicca kareṇuyā kucchismiṃ paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhi. Athassa mātā “gabbhaṃ rakkhissāmī”ti
analyzed: paṭicca kareṇuyā kucchismim paṭisandhim gaṇhi athassa mātā gabbham rakkhissāmi iti
translated: was living in the neighbourhood of the elephant-pool. He took up his abode in the womb of a she-elephant. Then his mother, thinking “I will protect the child in my womb,”

original: aññaṃ pabbatappadesaṃ gantvā gabbhaṃ rakkhitvā puttaṃ vijāyi. So anukkamena viññutaṃ🔽patto mahāsarīro thāmasampanno sobhaggappatto añjanapabbato viya ahosi. So ekāya
analyzed: aññam pabbata ppadesam gantvā gabbham rakkhitvā puttam vijāyi saḥ anukkamena viññutam  pattaḥ mahā sarīro thāma sampanno sobhagga ppatto añjana pabbataḥ viya ahosi saḥ ekāya
translated: went to another part of the mountain and protected the child in her womb. She gave birth to a son. He gradually grew up,

original: kareṇuyā saddhiṃ saṃvāsaṃ kappetvā “kakkaṭakaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti attano bhariyañca mātarañca
analyzed: kareṇuyā saddhim saṃvāsam kappetvā kakkaṭakam gaṇhissāmi iti attanaḥ bhariyam ca mātaram ca
translated: and became a great elephant, strong and beautiful like the Añjana mountain. He lived with a she-elephant, and then, thinking “I will take a mate,” he took his wife and mother

original: ādāya taṃ hatthiyūthaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pitaraṃ passitvā “tāta, ahaṃ kakkaṭakaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti
analyzed: ādāya tam hatthi yūtham upasaṅkamitvā pitaram passitvā tāta aham kakkaṭakam gaṇhissāmi iti
translated: and went to the herd of elephants. He saw his father, and said “Father, I will take a mate.”

original: āha. Atha naṃ pitā “na sakkhissasi, tātā”ti vāretvā punappunaṃ vadantaṃ “tvaññeva jānissasī”ti āha.
analyzed: āha atha nam pitā na sakkhissasi tāta ati vāretvā punappunam vadantam tvaññā iva jānissasi iti āha
translated: Then his father, trying to dissuade him, said “You will not be able to, my son.” But he kept on asking, and his father said “You will know for yourself.”

original: So kuḷīradahaṃ upanissāya vasante sabbavāraṇe sannipātetvā sabbehi saddhiṃ dahasamīpaṃ
analyzed: saḥ kuḷīra daham upanissāya vasante sabba vāraṇe sannipātetvā sabbehi saddhim daha samīpam
translated: The elephant-king, having taken up his abode near the lake, assembled all the elephants, and with them all went to the lake.

original: gantvā “kiṃ so kakkaṭako otaraṇakāle gaṇhāti, udāhu gocaraṃ gaṇhanakāle, udāhu uttaraṇakāle”ti🔽pucchitvā “uttaraṇakāle”ti sutvā “tena hi tumhe kuḷīradahaṃ otaritvā yāvadatthaṃ
analyzed: gantvā kim saḥ kakkaṭakaḥ otaraṇa kāle gaṇhāti udāhu gocaram gaṇhana kāle udāhu uttaraṇa kāla iti  pucchitvā uttaraṇa kāla iti sutvā tena hi tumhe kuḷīra daham otaritvā yāvadattham
translated: “How does the crocodile seize him?” they asked. “When he is entering the water, or when he is taking his food, or when he is coming out?”

original: gocaraṃ gahetvā paṭhamaṃ uttaratha, ahaṃ pacchato bhavissāmī”ti āha. Vāraṇā tathā🔽kariṃsu. Kuḷīro pacchato uttarantaṃ bodhisattaṃ mahāsaṇḍāsena kammāro lohasalākaṃ🔽viya aḷadvayena pāde daḷhaṃ gaṇhi, kareṇukā bodhisattaṃ avijahitvā samīpeyeva aṭṭhāsi.🔽Bodhisatto ākaḍḍhanto kuḷīraṃ cāletuṃ nāsakkhi, kuḷīro pana taṃ ākaḍḍhanto attano
analyzed: gocaram gahetvā paṭhamam aham pacchatas bhavissāmi iti āha vāraṇā tathā  kariṃsu kuḷīro pacchatas uttarantam bodhisattam mahā saṇḍāsena kammāraḥ loha salākam  pāde daḷham gaṇhi kareṇukā bodhisattam a vijahitvā samīpeya iva aṭṭhāsi  bodhisatto ākaḍḍhantaḥ kuḷīram cāletum na asakkhi kuḷīro pana tam ākaḍḍhantaḥ attano
translated: “When he is coming out,” was the reply. “Well then,” said the elephant-king, “you must enter the lake and take your food as much as you like, and come out first. I will follow after.” The elephants did as they were told,🔽and the crocodile, as the Bodhisatta was coming out last of all, seized him firmly by the feet with his two tusks, as a smith would a piece of iron with a pair of pincers. The she-elephant stood near, not leaving the Bodhisatta.

original: abhimukhaṃ karoti. So maraṇabhayatajjito baddharavaṃ ravi, sabbe vāraṇā maraṇabhayatajjitā
analyzed: abhimukham karoti saḥ maraṇa bhaya tajjitaḥ baddha ravam ravi sabbe vāraṇāḥ maraṇa bhaya tajjitā
translated: The Bodhisatta tried to drag the crocodile, but could not move him; but the crocodile, dragging the Bodhisatta, brought him face to face with himself. The Bodhisatta, terrified at the fear of death, uttered a cry of distress, and all the elephants, terrified at the fear of death,

original: koñcanādaṃ katvā muttakarīsaṃ cajamānā palāyiṃsu, kareṇukāpissa saṇṭhātuṃ asakkontī palāyituṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: koñca nādam katvā mutta karīsam cajamānā palāyiṃsu kareṇukā apissa saṇṭhātum a sakkontī palāyitum ārabhi
translated: and they ran away, leaving their dung and urine behind them. The she-elephant, unable to stand, began to run away.

original: Atha naṃ so attano baddhabhāvaṃ saññāpetvā tassā apalāyanatthaṃ paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam saḥ attanaḥ baddha bhāvam saññāpetvā tassāḥ a palāyana tham paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: Then he made her understand that she was bound, and in order to prevent her running away, he spoke the first stanza:

original: 49. Tattha siṅgī migoti siṅgī suvaṇṇavaṇṇo migo. Dvīhi aḷehi siṅgakiccaṃ sādhentehi
analyzed: tattha siṅgī migo ti siṅgī suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ migo dvīhi aḷehi siṅga kiccam sādhentehi
translated: Herein, a deer with antlers is a deer with antlers of gold, which perform the function of antlers with two knobs.

original: yuttatāya siṅgīti attho. Migoti pana sabbapāṇasaṅgāhakavasena idha kuḷīro vutto.
analyzed: yutta tāya siṅgī iti atthaḥ migo ti pana sabba pāṇa saṅgāhaka vasena idha kuḷīraḥ vutto
translated: The meaning is that he is a deer with antlers because he is endowed with antlers. But here the word “deer” is used to include all animals.

original: Āyatacakkhunettoti ettha dassanaṭṭhena cakkhu, nayanaṭṭhena nettaṃ, āyatāni cakkhusaṅkhātāni
analyzed: āyata cakkhu netto ti ettha dassana ṭṭhena cakkhu nayana ṭṭhena nettam āyatāni cakkhu saṅkhātāni
translated: With eyes and nose extended: here the eye is in the sense of seeing, the nose is in the sense of smelling. He has extended eyes and nose,

original: nettāni assāti āyatacakkhunetto, dīghaakkhīti attho. Aṭṭhimevassa tacakiccaṃ sādhetīti
analyzed: nettāni assa ti āyata cakkhu nettaḥ dīgha akkhī iti atthaḥ sādheti iti
translated: thus he is one with eyes and nose extended; the meaning is, he has long eyes. He has eight teeth that perform the function of teeth.

original: aṭṭhittaco. Tenābhibhūtoti tena migena abhibhūto ajjhotthato niccalaṃ gahito hutvā.
analyzed: tena abhibhūto ti tena migena abhibhūtaḥ ajjhotthataḥ niccalam gahitaḥ hutvā
translated: He is overcome by him: he is overcome by that deer, he is overcome by him, he is caught motionless.

original: Kapaṇaṃ rudāmīti kāruññappatto hutvā rudāmi viravāmi. Mā heva manti maṃ evarūpaṃ
analyzed: kapaṇam rudāmi iti kāruñña ppattaḥ hutvā rudāmi viravāmi mā ha iva manti mama evarūpam
translated: I weep piteously: I weep, I wail, having become one who has pity. Let him not think: let him not think that I am

original: byasanappattaṃ attano pāṇasamaṃ piyasāmikaṃ tvaṃ mā heva jahīti.
analyzed: byasana pattam attanaḥ pāṇa samam piya sāmikam tvam mā ha iva jahi iti
translated: Do not abandon your dear husband who is dear to you as life itself, now that he has fallen into misfortune.”

original: Atha sā kareṇukā nivattitvā taṃ assāsayamānā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha sā kareṇukā nivattitvā tam assāsayamānā dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the female elephant turned back and, in order to reassure him, she spoke the second verse:

original: “Ayya na taṃ jahissāmi, kuñjaraṃ saṭṭhihāyanaṃ;
analyzed: ayya na tam jahissāmi kuñjaram saṭṭhihāyanam
translated: “I will not abandon you, my lord, the elephant sixty years of age;

original: Pathabyā cāturantāya, suppiyo hosi me tuva”nti.
analyzed: pathabyā cāturantāya suppiyaḥ hosi me tuvanti
translated: You are dear to me as the earth with its four continents.”

original: Tattha saṭṭhihāyananti jātiyā saṭṭhivassakālasmiñhi kuñjarā thāmena parihāyanti,
analyzed: tattha saṭṭhihāyanam ti jātiyā saṭṭhivassa kālasmin hi kuñjarāḥ thāmena parihāyanti
translated: Herein, sixty years of age means that elephants decline in strength with age.

original: sā ahaṃ evaṃ thāmahīnaṃ imaṃ byasanaṃ pattaṃ taṃ na jahissāmi, mā bhāyi, imissā hi
analyzed: sā aham evam thāma hīnam imam byasanam pattam tam na jahissāmi mā bhāyi imissā hi
translated: I will not abandon him who has fallen into misfortune, though he is so weak. Do not be afraid. For

original: catūsu disāsu samuddaṃ patvā ṭhitāya cāturantāya pathaviyā tvaṃ mayhaṃ suṭṭhu piyoti.
analyzed: catūsu disāsu samuddam patvā ṭhitāya cāturantāya pathaviyā tvam mayham suṭṭhu
translated: you are dear to me as the earth with its four continents, which stands after reaching the ocean in the four directions.

original: Atha naṃ santhambhetvā “ayya, idāni taṃ kuḷīrena saddhiṃ thokaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ labhamānā vissajjāpessāmī”ti vatvā kuḷīraṃ yācamānā tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: atha nam santhambhetvā ayye idāni tam kuḷīrena saddhim thokam kathā sallāpam labhamānā vissajjāpessāmi iti vatvā kuḷīram yācamānā tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Then, in order to reassure him, she said, “My lord, now I will get you to talk a little with the crocodile and then I will let you go.” And, in order to ask the crocodile for permission, she spoke the third verse:

original: “Ye kuḷīrā samuddasmiṃ, gaṅgāya yamunāya ca;
analyzed: ye gaṅgāya yamunāya ca
translated: “Those crocodiles in the ocean, in the Ganges and in the Yamunā,

original: Tesaṃ tvaṃ vārijo seṭṭho, muñca rodantiyā pati”nti.
analyzed: tesam tvam vāri jaḥ seṭṭhaḥ muñca rodantiyā patinti
translated: Release my husband, thou who weepest.”

original: Tassattho – ye samudde vā gaṅgāya vā yamunāya vā kuḷīrā, sabbesaṃ vaṇṇasampattiyā ca mahantattena ca tvameva seṭṭho uttamo. Tena taṃ yācāmi, mayhaṃ rodamānāya sāmikaṃ muñcāti.
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ ye samudde vā gaṅgāya vā yamunāya vā sabbesam vaṇṇa sampattiyā ca ca tvam eva seṭṭhaḥ uttamaḥ tena tam yācāmi mayham rodamānāya sāmikam muñcāti
translated: The meaning is this: “Thou art the best, the most excellent of all the pools, lakes, rivers, and streams, in respect of the beauty of their waters and their size. Therefore I beseech thee, release my husband, who is weeping.”

original: Kuḷīro tassā kathayamānāya itthisadde nimittaṃ gahetvā ākaḍḍhiyamānaso hutvā vāraṇassa
analyzed: kuḷīraḥ tassā kathayamānāya itthi sadde nimittam gahetvā hutvā vāraṇassa
translated: The crocodile, hearing the woman’s voice, became excited and drew the elephant to him.

original: pādato aḷe viniveṭhento “ayaṃ vissaṭṭho idaṃ nāma karissatī”ti na kiñci aññāsi. Atha🔽naṃ vāraṇo pādaṃ ukkhipitvā piṭṭhiyaṃ akkami, tāvadeva aṭṭhīni bhijjiṃsu. Vāraṇo
analyzed: pādataḥ aḷe viniveṭhentaḥ ayam vissaṭṭhaḥ idam nāma karissati iti na kiñci aññāsi atha  nam vāraṇaḥ pādam ukkhipitvā piṭṭhiyam akkami tāvat eva aṭṭhīni bhijjiṃsu vāraṇaḥ
translated: As he was drawing him to him, he did not know what the elephant was doing, but thought, “This fellow is playing a trick on me.”🔽The elephant raised his foot and struck him on the back, and his bones were broken.

original: tuṭṭharavaṃ ravi, sabbe vāraṇā sannipatitvā kuḷīraṃ nīharitvā mahītale ṭhapetvā maddantā
analyzed: tuṭṭha ravam ravi sabbe vāraṇā sannipatitvā kuḷīram nīharitvā mahī tale ṭhapetvā maddantā
translated: The elephant trumpeted with joy, and all the other elephants gathered round. They pulled the crocodile out of the water and threw him on the ground, where they trampled him to death.

original: cuṇṇavicuṇṇamakaṃsu. Tassa dve aḷā sarīrato bhijjitvā ekamante patiṃsu. So ca kuḷīradaho
analyzed: tassa dve aḷā sarīrataḥ bhijjitvā eka mante patiṃsu saḥ ca kuḷīra daho
translated: Two of his tusks fell off and lay on one side, and the body of the crocodile lay on the other.

original: gaṅgāya ekābaddho, gaṅgāya pūraṇakāle gaṅgodakena pūrati, udake mandībhūte dahato
analyzed: gaṅgāya eka ābaddhaḥ gaṅgāya pūraṇa kāle gaṅgā udakena pūrati udake mandībhūte dahataḥ
translated: When the river was full, the two balls of flesh were filled with river water, and when the water subsided, the fire went out.

original: udakaṃ gaṅgaṃ otarati. Atha dvepi te aḷā uplavitvā gaṅgāya vuyhiṃsu. Tesu eko samuddaṃ
analyzed: udakam gaṅgam otarati atha dve api te aḷāḥ uplavitvā gaṅgāya vuyhiṃsu tesu ekaḥ samuddam
translated: The two balls of flesh floated away, and one of them was carried into the ocean,

original: pāvisi, ekaṃ dasabhātikarājāno udake kīḷamānā labhitvā āḷiṅgaṃ nāma mudiṅgaṃ akaṃsu.
analyzed: ekam dasabhātika rājānaḥ udake kīḍamānāḥ labhitvā āḷiṅgam nāma mudiṅgam akaṃsu
translated: while the other was caught by the ten brothers, the kings, who were playing in the water, and was made into a drum called the Āḷiṅga.

original: Samuddaṃ pana paviṭṭhaṃ asurā gahetvā ālambaraṃ nāma bheriṃ kāresuṃ. Te aparabhāge
analyzed: samuddam pana paviṭṭham asurāḥ gahetvā ālambaram nāma bherim kāresum te aparabhāge
translated: The ball of flesh that was carried into the ocean was caught by the Asuras, who made it into a drum called the Ālambara.

original: sakkena saṅgāme parājitā taṃ chaḍḍetvā palāyiṃsu, atha naṃ sakko attano atthāya gaṇhāpesi.
analyzed: sakkena saṅgāme parājitā tam chaḍḍetvā palāyiṃsu atha nam sakkaḥ attanaḥ atthāya gaṇhāpesi
translated: Later, when they were defeated by Sakka in battle, they abandoned it and fled, and Sakka had it taken for his own use.

original: “Ālambaramegho viya thanatī”ti taṃ sandhāya vadanti.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: ālambara meghaḥ thanati iti tam sandhāya vadanti  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: “It sounds like a cloud,” they said, referring to it.🔽When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths evident, and at the conclusion of the Truths the two, husband and wife, were established in the Fruit of Conversion.

original: ubho jayampatikā sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahiṃsu. “Tadā kareṇukā ayaṃ upāsikā ahosi,
analyzed: ubho sotāpatti phale tadā kareṇukā ayam upāsikā ahosi
translated: “The female lay disciple was at that time the female elephant;

original: vāraṇo pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: vāraṇaḥ pana aham eva
translated: I myself was the male elephant.”

original: Kakkaṭakajātakavaṇṇanā sattamā.
analyzed: kakkaṭaka jātaka vaṇṇanā sattamā
translated: The Stūpa-Defiler’s Jātaka is finished.

original: [268] 8. Ārāmadūsakajātakavaṇṇanā🔽Yo ve sabbasametānanti idaṃ satthā dakkhiṇāgirijanapade aññataraṃ uyyānapālaputtaṃ
analyzed: ārāmadūsaka jātaka vaṇṇanā  idam satthā dakkhiṇāgiri janapade aññataram uyyāna pāla puttam
translated: The Stūpa-Defiler’s Jātaka🔽“He who is the most restrained of all” — this story the Master told while living at Jetavana, about a certain son of a park-keeper in the Southern Hills.

original: ārabbha kathesi. Satthā kira vutthavasso jetavanā nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇāgirijanapade
analyzed: ārabbha kathesi satthā kira vuttha vassaḥ jetavanā nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇāgiri janapade
translated: After the Master had kept the rains, he left Jetavana and went on a visit to the Southern Hills.

original: cārikaṃ cari. Atheko upāsako buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ nimantetvā uyyāne nisīdāpetvā
analyzed: cārikam cari atha ekaḥ upāsakaḥ buddha ppamukham bhikkhu saṅgham nimantetvā uyyāne nisīdāpetvā
translated: A certain lay disciple invited the Congregation of Monks presided over by the Buddha to take a meal with him in the park, and after seating them in the park,

original: yāgukhajjakehi santappetvā “ayyā, uyyānacārikaṃ caritukāmā iminā uyyānapālena saddhiṃ
analyzed: yāgu khajjakehi santappetvā ayyāḥ uyyāna cārikam caritu kāmāḥ iminā uyyāna pālena saddhim
translated: and after refreshing them with rice-gruel and solid food, said, “Venerable Sirs, if you wish to take a walk in the park, take this park-keeper with you.

original: carantū”ti vatvā “ayyānaṃ phalāphalāni dadeyyāsī”ti uyyānapālaṃ āṇāpesi. Bhikkhū🔽caramānā ekaṃ chiddaṭṭhānaṃ disvā “idaṃ ṭhānaṃ chiddaṃ viraḷarukkhaṃ, kiṃ nu kho
analyzed: carantu uti vatvā ayyānam phala aphalāni dadeyyāsi iti uyyāna pālam āṇāpesi bhikkhū  caramānāḥ ekam chiddaṭṭhānam disvā idam ṭhānam chiddam viraḷa rukkham kim nu kho
translated: ” And he gave orders to the park-keeper, saying, “Give the Venerable Sirs fruits and roots.” The monks🔽went on their walk, and seeing a place where there was a gap in the trees, asked, “Why is this place a gap in the trees, and why are the trees sparse?

original: kāraṇa”nti pucchiṃsu. Atha nesaṃ uyyānapālo ācikkhi – “eko kira uyyānapālaputto uparopakesu
analyzed: kāraṇanti pucchiṃsu atha nesam uyyāna pālaḥ ācikkhi ekaḥ kira uyyāna pāla putto uparopakesu
translated: ” Then the park-keeper told them, “It seems that a certain son of a park-keeper,

original: udakaṃ āsiñcanto ‘mūlappamāṇena āsiñcissāmī’ti uppāṭetvā mūlappamāṇena udakaṃ āsiñci,
analyzed: udakam āsiñcantaḥ mūla pamāṇena āsiñcissāmi iti uppāṭetvā mūla ppamāṇena udakam āsiñci
translated: “As he was pouring water on the roots, he thought, ‘I will pour water on the roots to the depth of a span.’ So he dug down to the depth of a span and poured water on the roots.

original: tena taṃ ṭhānaṃ chiddaṃ jāta”nti. Bhikkhū satthu santikaṃ gantvā tamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.
analyzed: tena tam ṭhānam chiddam jātanti bhikkhū satthu santikam gantvā tam attham ārocesuṃ
translated: As a result, the place was broken through.” The monks went to the Teacher and told him the circumstances.

original: Satthā “na, bhikkhave, idāneva pubbepi so kumārako ārāmadūsakoyevā”ti vatvā atītaṃ āhari.🔽Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ vissasene nāma raññe rajjaṃ kārente ussave ghuṭṭhe uyyānapālo “ussavaṃ
analyzed: satthā na bhikkhave idānā iva pubbe pi so kumārakaḥ ārāma dūsakaḥ yā iva ati vatvā atītam āhari  atīte bārāṇasiyam vissasene nāma raññe rajjam kārente ussave ghuṭṭhe uyyāna pālaḥ ussavam
translated: “Monks, that boy was not the first to destroy the pleasure-garden; he did the same thing in a previous state of existence also.” So saying, the Teacher related the following

original: kīḷissāmī”ti uyyānavāsino makkaṭe āha – “idaṃ uyyānaṃ tumhākaṃ bahūpakāraṃ, ahaṃ
analyzed: kīḷissāmi iti uyyāna vāsinaḥ makkaṭe āha idam uyyānam tumhākam bahu upakāram aham
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, when King Vissasapha was reigning in Benares, the festival of lights was celebrated. The keeper of a pleasure-garden said to the monkeys that lived in the pleasure-garden, “This pleasure-garden is of great service to you;

original: sattāhaṃ ussavaṃ kīḷissāmi, tumhe satta divase uparopakesu udakaṃ āsiñcathā”ti. Te🔽“sādhū”ti sampaṭicchiṃsu. So tesaṃ cammaghaṭake datvā pakkāmi. Makkaṭā udakaṃ āsiñcantā
analyzed: satta aham ussavam kīḷissāmi tumhe satta divase uparopakesu udakam āsiñcatha ati te  sādhu iti sampaṭicchiṃsu saḥ tesam camma ghaṭake da tvā makkaṭā udakam āsiñcantā
translated: I am going to celebrate the festival of lights for seven days. You must pour water on the sprouts for seven days.”🔽“Very well,” replied the monkeys, and they agreed to do as he suggested. The keeper of the pleasure-garden gave them water-pots made of leather and departed. The monkeys poured water on the sprouts,

original: uparopakesu āsiñciṃsu. Atha ne makkaṭajeṭṭhako āha – “āgametha tāva, udakaṃ nāma
analyzed: uparopakesu āsiñciṃsu atha ne makkaṭajeṭṭhakaḥ āha āgametha tāva udakam nāma
translated: but they poured water on the sprouts that were not to be watered. Then the chief of the monkeys said to them, “Wait a moment. Water is a thing of value.

original: sabbakālaṃ dullabhaṃ, taṃ rakkhitabbaṃ, uparopake uppāṭetvā mūlappamāṇaṃ ñatvā dīghamūlakesu
analyzed: sabbakālam dullabham tam rakkhitabbam uparopake uppāṭetvā mūla ppamāṇam ñatvā dīgha mūlakesu
translated: “It is difficult to find at all times, and it must be guarded. If the roots are injured, the tree should be dug up and the roots cut to the proper length.

original: bahuṃ, rassamūlakesu appaṃ udakaṃ siñcituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. Te “sādhū”ti vatvā ekacce
analyzed: bahum rassa mūlakesu appam udakam siñcitum vaṭṭati iti te sādhu iti vatvā ekacce
translated: If the roots are long, much water must be given; if the roots are short, little water must be given.”

original: uparopake uppāṭetvā gacchanti, ekacce te ropetvā udakaṃ siñcanti.
analyzed: uparopake uppāṭetvā gacchanti ekacce te ropetvā udakam siñcanti
translated: They agreed, and some of them dug up the trees and carried them away, while others planted them and watered them.

original: Tasmiṃ kāle bodhisatto bārāṇasiyaṃ ekassa kulassa putto ahosi, so kenacideva karaṇīyena
analyzed: tasmin kāle bodhisattaḥ bārāṇasiyam ekassa kulassa puttaḥ ahosi saḥ kenacid eva karaṇīyena
translated: At that time the Bodhisatta was the son of a certain family in Bārāṇasī. He went to the garden on some business,

analyzed: uyyānam gantvā te makkaṭe tathā karonte disvā kaḥ tumhe evam kārā iti iti pucchitvā
translated: and seeing the monkeys acting in this way, asked them, “Who is making you do this?”🔽“The chief of the monkeys,” was the reply. “If this is the wisdom of your chief,” said he,

original: “vānarajeṭṭhako”ti vutte “jeṭṭhakassa tāva vo ayaṃ paññā, tumhākaṃ pana kīdisī bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: vānarajeṭṭhako ti vutte jeṭṭhakassa tāva vaḥ ayam paññā tumhākam pana kīdisī bhavissati iti
translated: “what must the wisdom of the rest of the monkeys be?”

original: tamatthaṃ pakāsento imaṃ paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam attham pakāsentaḥ imam paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: And he uttered the first stanza:🔽“If he, the best of all the wise,

original: “Yo ve sabbasametānaṃ, ahuvā seṭṭhasammato;
analyzed: yaḥ ve sabba sametānam a huvā seṭṭha sammataḥ
translated: Is such as you describe,

original: Tassāyaṃ edisī paññā, kimeva itarā pajā”ti.
analyzed: tassa ayam edisī paññā kim eva itarā
translated: What must the rest of them be like?”

original: Tattha sabbasametānanti imesaṃ sabbesaṃ samānajātīnaṃ. Ahuvāti ahosi. Kimeva itarā pajāti yā itarā etesu lāmikā pajā, kīdisā nu kho tassā paññāti.
analyzed: tattha sabba sametānam ti imesam sabbesam samāna jātīnam ahosi kim eva itarā pajāti yā itarā etesu lāmikā pajā kīdisā nu kho tassā paññā ti
translated: “All these are of the same kind as you, and you were one of them. What was it that made you different from the other monkeys? What is the nature of your wisdom?”

original: Tassa kathaṃ sutvā vānarā dutiyaṃ gāthamāhaṃsu –
analyzed: tassa katham sutvā vānarāḥ dutiyam gātham āhaṃsu
translated: Hearing this, the monkeys spoke the second stanza:

original: “Evameva tuvaṃ brahme, anaññāya vinindasi;
analyzed: evam eva tuvam brahme an aññāya vinindasi
translated: “So, Brahman, you are blaming us without knowing the truth.

original: Kathaṃ mūlaṃ adisvāna, rukkhaṃ jaññā patiṭṭhita”nti.🔽Tattha brahmeti ālapanamattaṃ. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho – tvaṃ, bho purisa, kāraṇākāraṇaṃ🔽ajānitvā evameva amhe vinindasi, rukkhaṃ nāma “gambhīre patiṭṭhito vā esa, na vā”ti
analyzed: katham mūlam a disvāna rukkham jaññā patiṭṭhitanti  tattha brahmā iti ālapana mattam ayam pana ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ tvam bho purisa kāraṇa akāraṇam  a jānitvā evam eva amhe vinindasi rukkham nāma gambhīre patiṭṭhitaḥ vai esa na vāti
translated: How can you know whether a tree is firmly rooted without seeing its roots?”

original: mūlaṃ anuppāṭetvā kathaṃ ñātuṃ sakkā, tena mayaṃ uppāṭetvā mūlappamāṇena udakaṃ āsiñcāmāti.
analyzed: mūlam an uppāṭetvā katham ñātum sakkā tena mayam uppāṭetvā mūla ppamāṇena udakam āsiñcāma ati
translated: Here the word “Brahman” is merely a form of address. The meaning of the stanza is this: “You, sir, without knowing the reason, are blaming us in this way. How can you know whether a tree is firmly rooted or not without digging up the roots? Therefore we dug up the roots and watered them to see how deep they went.”

original: Taṃ sutvā bodhisatto tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: tam sutvā bodhisatto tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the Bodhisatta spoke the third stanza:

original: “Nāhaṃ tumhe vinindāmi, ye caññe vānarā vane;
analyzed: na aham tumhe vinindāmi ye caññe vānarāḥ vane
translated: “I do not blame you, nor the other monkeys in the wood.

original: Vissasenova gārayho, yassatthā rukkharopakā”ti.
analyzed: vissasena uva gārayhaḥ yassatthā
translated: It is only the faithless one who is to be blamed, who cut down the tree that was so useful to us.”

original: Tattha vissasenova gārayhoti bārāṇasirājā vissasenoyeva ettha garahitabbo. Yassatthā rukkharopakāti yassatthāya tumhādisā rukkharopakā jātāti.

translated: “Herein, the one who deserves blame is the one who trusts.” The king of Benares deserves blame for trusting. “For whose sake were you born?” For whose sake were you born as a tree-planter?

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā vānarajeṭṭhako ārāmadūsakakumāro ahosi, paṇḍitapuriso pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā vānarajeṭṭhakaḥ ārāmadūsaka kumāraḥ ahosi paṇḍita puriso pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he identified the Birth: “At that time the chief of the monkeys was the young man who defiled the monastery, and I myself was the wise man.”

original: Ārāmadūsakajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: ārāmadūsaka jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā

analyzed: mahantena yasena anāthapiṇḍikassa gharam pūrayamānā pāvisi mahā kulassa dhītāḥ ahanti
translated: She entered the house of Anathapindika with great pomp, and being the daughter of a great family,

analyzed: ahosi kodhanā caṇḍī pharusā na karoti geha janam

analyzed: tajjentī paharantī carati atha eka divasam satthā pañcahi bhikkhu satehi parivutaḥ anāthapiṇḍikassa

analyzed: geham gantvā nisīdi mahā seṭṭhi dhammam suṇantaḥ iva bhagavantam upanisīdi tasmin khaṇe

analyzed: sujātā dāsa kammakarehi saddhim kalaham karoti satthā dhamma katham ṭhapetvā kim  saddaḥ esaḥ iti āha esā bhante kula suṇhā agāravā na iva assā

analyzed: satthā tena hi ohita sotā suṇohi iti vatvā imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi

translated: “She is unwilling to work, lazy, and gluttonous, harsh, violent, and abusive,

analyzed: tatas dhanam sambhatamassa rakkhati yā evarūpā purisassa bhariyā

analyzed: akkodhanā vasā anuvattinī yā evarūpā purisassa bhariyā
translated: She is not angry, but obeys her husband. A wife like this

analyzed: yāci idha bhariyā vadhakā ati vuccati corī iti ayyā ati ca yā pavuccati

analyzed: mātā bhaginī sakhī iti ca dāsī iti bhariyā ati ca yā pavuccati

analyzed: tvam imāsam sattannam bhariyānam katarā ati vutte dāsi samā aham bhante iti vatvā
translated: which of these seven kinds of wives are you?” “I am like a slave, Reverend Sir.”

translated: Though he was anxious to give her good advice, he thought it was not proper to give her bad advice, and therefore

analyzed: ekam upamam olokentaḥ carati atha eka divasam uyyānam agamāsi mātā api puttena saddhiṃyā iva

analyzed: agamāsi atha antarāmagge kikī sakuṇaḥ viravi bodhisatta parisā tam saddam sutvā kaṇṇe

analyzed: uṭṭhāya anubandhi tatas paṭṭhāya te aññamaññam veram bandhiṃsu sakuṇā suvaṇṇa haṃsam

analyzed: khurappam sindhavam ca iva kakkaṭāḥ rāmadūsakam
translated: The Stanzas on the Razor, the Stanzas on the Sindhu Horse, the Stanzas on the Ass, the Stanzas on the Lover’s Quarrel,

analyzed: su jātam ulūkam dasa  udapāna vaggaḥ
translated: The Stanzas on the Well-born, and the Stanzas on the Owl.🔽The Portion for Recital on the Pond

original: [271] 1. Udapānadūsakajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Stanzas on the Polluter of the Pond

analyzed: āraññikassa isino ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ ekam udapāna dūsaka siṅgālam ārabbha

analyzed: kathesi ekaḥ kira siṅgālaḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa pānīya odapānam uccāra passāvakaraṇena dūsetvā

analyzed: atha nam eka divasam udapāna samīpam āgatam sāmaṇerāḥ paharitvā kilamesum

analyzed: dhamma sabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso udapāna dūsaka siṅgālo kira sāmaṇerehi  kilamita kālato paṭṭhāya puna nivattitvā api na olokesi iti satthā āgantvā kāya nuttha
translated: began a discussion in the Hall of Truth: “Brethren, it seems that the jackal who defiled the trough,

analyzed: bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā ati pucchitvā imāya nāma ati vutte na bhikkhave  idānā iva siṅgālaḥ udapāna dūsakoya iva iva ati vatvā atītam āhari
translated: from the time that he was worried by the novices, has not even looked at the trough, although he has returned to the place.” The Teacher came in and asked, “Monks, what is the subject that you are discussing now as you sit here all gathered together?” When they told him,🔽he said, “Monks, this is not the first time he has done so; in a previous state of existence also he was a jackal and defiled a water-trough.” So saying, he related a Story of the Past:

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ idameva isipatanaṃ ayameva udapāno ahosi. Tadā bodhisatto bārāṇasiyaṃ
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam idam eva isipatanam ayam eva udapānaḥ ahosi tadā bodhisattaḥ bārāṇasiyam

analyzed: kula ghare nibbattitvā vaya pattaḥ isi pabbajjam pabbajitvā isi gaṇa parivutaḥ isipatane
translated: He was born in a certain family, and when he grew up he went forth into the homeless state, and became a seer. He dwelt in the Himalayas, surrounded by a company of seers.

original: vāsaṃ kappesi. Tadā eko siṅgālo idameva udapānaṃ dūsetvā pakkamati. Atha naṃ ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: vāsam kappesi tadā ekaḥ siṅgālaḥ idam eva udapānam dūsetvā pakkamati atha nam eka divasam
translated: Now a certain jackal, having polluted that very tank, would go away. One day

original: tāpasā parivāretvā ṭhitā ekenupāyena gahetvā bodhisattassa santikaṃ ānayiṃsu. Bodhisatto
analyzed: tāpasā parivāretvā ṭhitāḥ ekena upāyena gahetvā bodhisattassa santikam ānayiṃsu bodhisatto
translated: the ascetics surrounded him and caught him by some means or other, and brought him into the presence of the Bodhisatta. The Bodhisatta,

original: siṅgālena saddhiṃ sallapanto paṭhamaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: siṅgālena saddhim sallapantaḥ paṭhamam gātham āha
translated: having a talk with the jackal, spoke the first stanza:

original: “Āraññikassa isino, cirarattatapassino;
analyzed: āraññikassa isinaḥ cira ratta tapassinaḥ
translated: “The seer who dwells in the forest, who has long practiced austerities,

analyzed: kicchākatam udapānam katham samma avāhayi iti  tassa atthaḥ araññe vasana tāya āraññikassa esita guṇa ttā isinaḥ cira rattam tapam nissāya  vutthattā cira ratta tapassino kicchā katam kicchena dukkhena nipphāditam udapānam kathaṃ
translated: How, my good fellow, did you pollute the tank that was made with difficulty?”🔽The meaning is: how, for what purpose, my good fellow jackal, did you pollute the tank that was made with difficulty, that was produced with difficulty, with suffering, by the seer who dwells in the forest because he dwells in the forest, who is a seer because he possesses the qualities of a seer, who has long practiced austerities because he has long practiced austerities, by means of your urine and excrement, by covering it with your urine and excrement?

original: kimatthāya samma siṅgāla, tvaṃ avāhayi muttakarīsena ajjhotthari dūsesi, taṃ vā muttakarīsaṃ
analyzed: kimatthāya samma siṅgāla tvam avāhayi mutta karīsena ajjhotthari dūsesi tam vā mutta karīsam
translated: Or, did you bring your urine and excrement

analyzed: ettha avāhayi pātesi iti

analyzed: tam sutvā siṅgālaḥ dutiyam gātham āha
translated: Hearing this, the jackal spoke the second stanza:

translated: This is the jackal’s nature, that he should drink and then disgorge;

original: Pitupitāmahaṃ dhammo, na taṃ ujjhātumarahasī”ti.🔽Tattha esa dhammoti esa sabhāvo. Yaṃ pitvā ohadāmaseti, samma, yaṃ mayaṃ yattha pānīyaṃ🔽pivāma, tameva ūhadāmapi omuttemapi, esa amhākaṃ siṅgālānaṃ dhammoti dasseti. Pitupitāmahanti🔽pitūnañca pitāmahānañca no esa dhammo. Na taṃ ujjhātumarahasīti taṃ amhākaṃ paveṇiāgataṃ
analyzed: pitu pitāmaham dhammaḥ na tam ujjhātum arahasi iti  tattha esa dhammo ti esa sabhāvaḥ yam pitvā ohadāmasa iti yam yattha pānīyam  tam eva esa amhākam siṅgālānam dhammoti dasseti pitu pitāmahanti  pitūnam ca pitāmahānam ca no esa dhammo na tam ujjhātum arahasi iti tam amhākam paveṇi āgatam
translated: This is the nature of our fathers and grandfathers; you may not blame it.

original: dhammaṃ sabhāvaṃ tvaṃ ujjhātuṃ na arahasi, na yuttaṃ te ettha kujjhitunti.
analyzed: dhammam sabhāvam tvam ujjhātum na arahasi na yuttam te ettha kujjhitum ti
translated: Herein, this is the jackal’s nature means this is the jackal’s nature. That he should drink and then disgorge means, “Friend, wherever we drink water, there we disgorge it and vomit it up; this is the nature of us jackals.” This is the nature of our fathers and grandfathers means this is the nature of our fathers and grandfathers. You may not blame it means you may not blame this nature of ours that has come down from our ancestors; it is not proper for you to be angry about it.

original: Athassa bodhisatto tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: athassa bodhisatto tatiyam gātham āha
translated: Then the Bodhisatta spoke the third stanza:

analyzed: yesam vaḥ edisaḥ dhammaḥ adhammaḥ pana kīdisaḥ  mā vaḥ dhammam adhammam vā addasāma kudācana nti
translated: If this is your nature, what is your unnature?🔽We never wish to see your nature or your unnature.

original: Tattha mā voti tumhākaṃ dhammaṃ vā adhammaṃ vā na mayaṃ kadāci addasāmāti.
analyzed: tattha mā voti tumhākam dhammam vā adhammam vā na mayam kadāci addasāma ati
translated: Herein, we never wish to see your nature or your unnature means we never wish to see your nature or your unnature.

original: Evaṃ bodhisatto tassa ovādaṃ datvā “mā puna āgacchā”ti āha. So tato paṭṭhāya puna nivattitvāpi na olokesi.
analyzed: evam bodhisatto tassa ovādam da tvā mā puna āgacchāti āha saḥ tatas paṭṭhāya puna nivattitvā api na olokesi
translated: Thus did the Bodhisatta give him advice, and then said to him, “Do not come again.” From that time forth, though he turned back and looked, he never saw him again.

analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā udapāna dūsakaḥ ayam eva siṅgālaḥ ahosi gaṇa satthā pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he expounded the Law, and pointing out the Truths, he identified the Birth, “At that time Devadatta was the water-drawer, and I myself was the leader of the band.”🔽The story of the Water-drawer.

original: Udapānadūsakajātakavaṇṇanā paṭhamā.🔽[272] 2. Byagghajātakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: udapānadūsaka jātaka vaṇṇanā paṭhamā

analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā āvuso kokāli karaṭṭha vāsinaḥ manussā tumhe pakkosanti etha gacchāma iti

analyzed: āha gaccha tvam āvuso na mayam āgacchāma iti so therehi paṭikkhitto sayam eva  agamāsi atha bhikkhū dhamma sabhāyam katham samuṭṭhāpesuṃ āvuso kokāliko sāriputta moggallānehi

analyzed: aññā rukkha devatā vasati tasmim vana saṇḍe sīhaḥ ca byagghaḥ ca vasanti tesam bhayena  koci tattha na khettam karoti na rukkham chindati nivattitvā oloketum samatthaḥ

translated: “If I kill him, they will kill me. If he kills him, I shall be released from my debt to him, from my sorrow, and from the sin of taking life.”

original: ca vimutti bhavissatī”ti vatvā tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: ca vimutti bhavissati iti vatvā tatiyam gātham āha
translated: And he uttered the third stanza:

original: “Mamevāyaṃ maññamāno, aññepevaṃ karissati;
analyzed: mama eva ayam maññamānaḥ aññepā ivam karissati
translated: “If he thinks that I am he, He will do as he did before;

original: Te naṃ tattha vadhissanti, sā me mutti bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: te nam tattha vadhissanti sā me mutti bhavissati iti
translated: They will kill him for his pains, And I shall be released from debt.”

original: Katipāhaccayena pana bodhisatto aññattha gato. Añño caṇḍamahiṃso tattha āgantvā aṭṭhāsi.

translated: After a few days the Bodhisatta went away, and another wild elephant came and took up his abode in the same place.

original: Duṭṭhamakkaṭo “soyeva aya”nti saññāya tassa piṭṭhiṃ abhiruhitvā tatheva anācāraṃ
analyzed: duṭṭha makkaṭo soyā iva ayanti saññāya tassa piṭṭhim abhiruhitvā tathā iva anācāram
translated: The wicked monkey, thinking to himself, “This is he,” mounted the back of the new-comer, and behaved in the same wicked manner as before.

original: cari. Atha naṃ so vidhunanto bhūmiyaṃ pātetvā siṅgena hadaye vijjhitvā pādehi madditvā sañcuṇṇesi.
analyzed: atha nam saḥ vidhunantaḥ bhūmiyam pātetvā siṅgena hadaye vijjhitvā pādehi madditvā sañcuṇṇesi
translated: The wild elephant shook him off, and threw him to the ground. Then with his tusks he pierced him in the belly, and with his feet he trampled him to death.

original: Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi – “tadā
analyzed: satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi tadā
translated: When the Teacher had related this religious discourse, he expounded the Truths, and identified the Birth, saying, “At that time Devadatta was the wicked elephant, the wicked monkey was the monkey of to-day, and I myself was the virtuous elephant.”

original: duṭṭhamahiṃso ayaṃ duṭṭhahatthī ahosi, duṭṭhamakkaṭo etarahi ayaṃ makkaṭo, sīlavā
analyzed: duṭṭha mahiṃsaḥ ayam duṭṭha hatthī ahosi duṭṭha makkaṭaḥ etarahi ayam makkaṭaḥ sīlavā
translated: The wicked elephant was Devadatta, the wicked monkey was the monkey of to-day, the virtuous elephant was I myself.

original: mahiṃsarājā pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: mahiṃsa rājā pana aham eva
translated: I was the king of the deer.”

original: Mahiṃsarājajātakavaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā.
analyzed: mahiṃsa rāja jātaka vaṇṇanā aṭṭhamā
translated: So ends the Mahiṃsarāja Jātaka.

original: [279] 9. Satapattajātakavaṇṇanā

analyzed: chabbaggiyānam hi dve janāḥ mettiya bhūmajakāḥ rājagaham upanissāya vihariṃsu dve  kīṭāgirim upanissāya vihariṃsu paṇḍuka lohitakāḥ ime pana dve sāvatthim upanissāya

analyzed: pakkhandi māṇavaḥ tena kata kāraṇam a jānantaḥ ayam maṅgala sakuṇaḥ idāni me

analyzed: gotamassa gandhakuṭiyā samīpe mālā kacavara antare nikkhipitvā etha iti vadiṃsu te tathā  akaṃsu tatas titthiyāḥ sundarim na passāma ati kolāhalam katvā raññaḥ ārocetvā kaham

analyzed: tiṃsa mattā sūkarāḥ vasanti guhāya avidūre ekaḥ sīhaḥ carati tassa maṇimhi chāyā paññāyati  sūkarā sīha chāyam disvā bhītāḥ utrastāḥ appa maṃsa lohitāḥ ahesum te imassa maṇinaḥ

analyzed: avidūre ekam saram gantvā kalale pavaṭṭetvā āgantvā tam maṇim ghaṃsanti saḥ sūkara lomehi 🔽ghaṃsiyamānaḥ vippasannataraḥ ahosi sūkarāḥ upāyam a passantāḥ imassa maṇino vivaṇṇa karaṇa upāyam
translated: So they went to a pool not far off, wallowed in the mud, came back, and rubbed the gem.🔽The more they rubbed it, the clearer it became. Not seeing any other way, they thought, “Let us go to the Bodhisatta and ask him how to discolour this gem.”

original: Atīte bārāṇasiyaṃ brahmadatte rajjaṃ kārente bodhisatto mahālohitagoṇo nāma ahosi,
analyzed: atīte bārāṇasiyam brahmadatte rajjam kārente bodhisattaḥ mahālohitagoṇaḥ nāma ahosi
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, the Bodhisatta was a great ox named Mahālohitagotra,

original: kaniṭṭhabhātā panassa cūḷalohito nāma. Ubhopi goṇā gāmake ekasmiṃ kule kammaṃ karonti.
analyzed: kaniṭṭha bhātā panassa cūḷalohitaḥ nāma ubho api goṇāḥ gāmake ekasmim kule kammam karonti
translated: and his younger brother was named Cūḷalohitagotra. Both of these oxen worked for a certain family in a village.

original: Tassa kulassa ekā vayappattā kumārikā atthi, taṃ aññakulaṃ vāresi. Atha naṃ kulaṃ
analyzed: tassa kulassa ekā vaya pattā kumārikā atthi tam añña kulam vāresi atha nam kulam
translated: This family had a daughter who had reached marriageable age. A certain other family asked for her hand in marriage. This family said,

original: “vivāhakāle uttaribhaṅgo bhavissatī”ti sālūkaṃ nāma sūkaraṃ yāgubhattena paṭijaggi,
analyzed: vivāha kāle uttaribhaṅgaḥ bhavissati iti sālūkam nāma sūkaram yāgu bhattena paṭijaggi
translated: “At the time of the wedding there will be a butt for ridicule.” So they fed a pig named Sālūka with rice and curry,

original: so heṭṭhāmañce sayati. Athekadivasaṃ cūḷalohito bhātaraṃ āha – “bhātika, mayaṃ imasmiṃ
analyzed: saḥ heṭṭhāmañce sayati atha eka divasam cūḷalohitaḥ bhātaram āha bhātika mayam imasmin
translated: and made him lie down on a couch below the house. One day Cūḷalohitagotra said to his brother, “Brother, we are always working for this family.

original: kule kammaṃ karoma, amhe nissāya imaṃ kulaṃ jīvati, atha ca panime manussā amhākaṃ
analyzed: kule kammam karoma amhe nissāya imam kulam jīvati atha ca panime manussāḥ amhākam
translated: “We work in this family. It is through us that this family lives. And yet these people give us only grass and chaff.

original: tiṇapalālamattaṃ denti, imaṃ sūkaraṃ yāgubhattena posenti, heṭṭhāmañce sayāpenti,
analyzed: tiṇa palāla mattam denti imam sūkaram yāgu bhattena posenti heṭṭhā mañce sayāpenti
translated: They feed this pig with rice and curry, and let it sleep on the bed.🔽What will we do for him?”

original: kiṃ nāmesa etesaṃ karissatī”ti. Mahālohito “tāta, mā tvaṃ etassa yāgubhattaṃ patthaya,🔽etissā kumārikāya vivāhadivase etaṃ uttaribhaṅgaṃ kātukāmā ete maṃsassa thūlabhāvakaraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: kim nāma isaḥ etesam karissati iti mahālohitaḥ tāta mā tvam etassa yāgu bhattam patthaya  etissā kumārikāya vivāha divase etam uttari bhaṅgam kātu kāmāḥ ete maṃsassa thūla bhāva karaṇa ttham
translated: “Dear, don’t wish for his rice and curry.🔽On the day of the girl’s wedding, they want to make him the leftover.🔽They are feeding him in order to make his flesh heavy.

original: posenti, katipāhaccayena taṃ passissasi heṭṭhāmañcato nikkhāmetvā vadhitvā khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ
analyzed: posenti kati pāha cayena tam passissasi heṭṭhā mañcataḥ nikkhāmetvā vadhitvā khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam
translated: In a few days, you will see him taken out from under the bed, killed, cut into pieces,

original: chinditvā āgantukabhattaṃ kariyamāna”nti vatvā purimā dve gāthā samuṭṭhāpesi –
analyzed: chinditvā āgantuka bhattam kariyamānan ti vatvā purimā dve gāthā samuṭṭhāpesi
translated: and made into a meal for guests.” And he uttered the first two stanzas:

original: “Mā sālūkassa pihayi, āturannāni bhuñjati;
analyzed: mā sālūkassa ātur annāni bhuñjati
translated: “Don’t envy the pig, for he eats what is stale and spoiled.

original: Appossukko bhusaṃ khāda, etaṃ dīghāyulakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: appa ussukkaḥ bhusam khāde etam dīgha āyu lakkhaṇam
translated: Eat the chaff without complaint: that is the sign of longevity.

original: “Idāni so idhāgantvā, atithī yuttasevako;
analyzed: idāni saḥ idha āgantvā atithī yutta sevako
translated: “Now he will come here, a guest, a servant to be employed.

original: Atha dakkhasi sālūkaṃ, sayantaṃ musaluttara”nti.
analyzed: atha dakkhasi sālūkam sayantam
translated: Then you will see the pig lying on the upper bed.”

original: Tatthāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – tāta, tvaṃ mā sālūkasūkarabhāvaṃ patthayi, ayañhi āturannāni
analyzed: tattha ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ tāta tvam mā sālūka sūkara bhāvam ayan hi ātur annāni
translated: The meaning of the story in brief is as follows: “Dear, do not wish to become a pig that eats rice. For this pig eats food that is unfit to be eaten,

original: maraṇabhojanāni bhuñjati, yāni bhuñjitvā nacirasseva maraṇaṃ pāpuṇissati, tvaṃ pana
analyzed: maraṇa bhojanāni bhuñjati yāni bhuñjitvā nacirassa iva maraṇam pāpuṇissati tvam pana
translated: and after eating it will soon die. But you,

original: appossukko nirālayo hutvā attanā laddhaṃ imaṃ palālamissakaṃ bhusaṃ khāda, etaṃ dīghāyubhāvassa
analyzed: appossukkaḥ nirālayaḥ hutvā attanā laddham imam palāla missakam bhusam khāda etam dīgha āyu bhāvassa
translated: eating this straw-mixed food that you have obtained, being free from care and without a home, will live a long life.

original: lakkhaṇaṃ sañjānananimittaṃ. Idāni katipāhasseva so vevāhikapuriso mahatiyā parisāya🔽yutto yuttasevako idha atithi hutvā āgato bhavissati, athetaṃ sālūkaṃ musalasadisena
analyzed: lakkhaṇam sañjānana nimittam idāni katipāhassa iva saḥ vevāhika purisaḥ mahatiyā parisāya  yuttaḥ yutta sevakaḥ idha hutvā āgataḥ bhavissati atha etam sālūkam musala sadisena
translated: This is a sign that you will live a long life. In a few days the hunter will come here with a large retinue

original: uttaroṭṭhena samannāgatattā musaluttaraṃ māritaṃ sayantaṃ dakkhasīti.
analyzed: uttara uṭṭhena samannāgata ttā musala uttaram māritam sayantam dakkhasi iti
translated: and will kill the pig with a blow of his club. You will see the pig lying dead, killed by the blow of the club.”

original: Tato katipāhasseva vevāhikesu āgatesu sālūkaṃ māretvā uttaribhaṅgamakaṃsu. Ubho goṇā
analyzed: tatas katipāhassa iva vevāhikesu āgatesu sālūkam māretvā uttari bhaṅgam akaṃsu ubhau
translated: In a few days the hunters came and killed the pig. The two oxen

original: taṃ tassa vipattiṃ disvā “amhākaṃ bhusameva vara”nti cintayiṃsu. Satthā abhisambuddho
analyzed: tam tassa vipattim disvā amhākam bhusam eva varanti cintayiṃsu satthā abhisambuddhaḥ
translated: saw the pig’s misfortune and thought, “Our food is better.” The Teacher, having attained enlightenment,

original: hutvā tadatthajotikaṃ tatiyaṃ gāthamāha –
analyzed: hutvā tad attha jotikam tatiyam gātham āha
translated: and in order to make the meaning clear he uttered the third stanza:

original: “Vikantaṃ sūkaraṃ disvā, sayantaṃ musaluttaraṃ;
analyzed: vikantam sūkaram disvā sayantam musala uttaram
translated: “The boars, seeing the boar Vikanta, lying down with the pestle on his back,

original: Jaraggavā vicintesuṃ, varamhākaṃ bhusāmivā”ti.
analyzed: vicintesum
translated: thought, ‘Better for us that he should be dead.’ ”

original: Tattha bhusāmivāti bhusameva amhākaṃ varaṃ uttamanti attho.🔽Satthā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakaṃ samodhānesi, saccapariyosāne
analyzed: tattha bhusām iva ati bhusam eva amhākam varam uttamanti attho  satthā imam dhamma desanam āharitvā saccāni pakāsetvā jātakam samodhānesi sacca pariyosāne
translated: Here “bhusā” means “bhusameva.” The meaning is: “Better for us that he should be dead.”

original: so bhikkhu sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. “Tadā kumārikā etarahi thullakumārikā ahosi,
analyzed: so bhikkhu sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi tadā kumārikā etarahi thullakumārikā ahosi
translated: When the Teacher had related this story, he made the Truths clear, and identified the Birth by saying in conclusion, “At that time the young woman was the present Thullakumārī,

original: sālūko ukkaṇṭhitabhikkhu, cūḷalohito ānando, mahālohito pana ahameva ahosi”nti.
analyzed: sālūkaḥ ukkaṇṭhita bhikkhu cūḷalohitaḥ ānandaḥ mahālohitaḥ pana aham eva ahosinti
translated: the boar who was dissatisfied with the monk was the monk who was dissatisfied, the little hog was Ānanda, and I myself was the great hog.”

original: Sālūkajātakavaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā.
analyzed: sālūka jātaka vaṇṇanā chaṭṭhā
translated: So saying, he pronounced the following Stanza,

original: [287] 7. Lābhagarahajātakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Hog named Lābhagaraha.🔽The Story of the Hog named Nānummatta.

original: Nānummattoti idaṃ satthā jetavane viharanto sāriputtattherassa saddhivihārikaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: na anummattaḥ ti idam satthā jetavane viharantaḥ sāriputta therassa saddhivihārikam ārabbha
translated: This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a certain monk who was a pupil of the Elder Sāriputta.

original: kathesi. Therassa kira saddhivihāriko theraṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisinno
analyzed: kathesi therassa kira saddhivihārikaḥ theram upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ
translated: The monk, it would appear, went to the Elder, saluted him, and sat down respectfully on one side.

original: “lābhuppattipaṭipadaṃ me, bhante, kathetha, kiṃ karonto cīvarādīnaṃ lābhī hotī”ti
analyzed: lābha uppatti paṭipadam me bhante kathetha kim karontaḥ cīvara ādīnam lābhī hoti iti
translated: “Reverend Sir, tell me the way to get gain. What must I do to get robes and so forth?”

original: pucchi. Athassa thero “āvuso, catūhaṅgehi samannāgatassa lābhasakkāro uppajjati,🔽attano abbhantare hirottappaṃ bhinditvā sāmaññaṃ pahāya anummatteneva ummattena viya
analyzed: pucchi athassa theraḥ āvuso catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatassa lābha sakkāro uppajjati  attanaḥ abbhantare hira uttappam bhinditvā sāmaññam pahāya an ummattena iva ummattena viya
translated: He asked. Then the Elder said to him, “Brother, gain and honor come to one who is possessed of four qualities.🔽One must break down shame and fear of sin within oneself, abandon the life of a recluse, and act like one who is mad with a madness of lust.

original: bhavitabbaṃ, pisuṇavācā vattabbā, naṭasadisena bhavitabbaṃ, vikiṇṇavācena kutūhalena🔽bhavitabba”nti imaṃ lābhuppattipaṭipadaṃ kathesi. So taṃ paṭipadaṃ garahitvā uṭṭhāya🔽pakkanto. Thero satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā taṃ pavattiṃ ācikkhi. Satthā “neso,
analyzed: bhavitabbam pisuṇa vācā vattabbā naṭa sadisena bhavitabbam vikiṇṇa vācena kutūhalena  bhavitabbanti imam lābha uppatti paṭipadam kathesi saḥ tam paṭipadam garahitvā uṭṭhāya  pakkantaḥ theraḥ satthāram upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā tam pavattim ācikkhi satthā na eso
translated: One must speak maliciously, and act like an actor, with a voice that is broken and with curiosity.🔽” He reviled this way to get gain, and rising up, he went away. The Elder went to the Teacher, saluted him, and told him what had happened. The Teacher said, “Sāriputta, this monk did not begin to revile gain today only, but in a previous state of existence also he reviled gain.” So saying, he related the following🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, it seems, a certain monk, who was possessed of the four qualities above mentioned, went about reviling gain. The Teacher related his story as follows:

analyzed: sāriputta bhikkhu idānā iva lābham garahati vatvā therena  yācitaḥ atītam āhari
